DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, June 1, or the 10th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1815: Napoleon Bonaparte, emperor of France from 1804 to 1814, swears fidelity to the French Constitution. His military and political might gripped Continental Europe but failed to encompass Great Britain.
1868: James Buchanan, the 15th president of the United States, dies at the age of 77. The first bachelor to be elected president, he tried to maintain a balance between pro-slavery and anti-slavery factions, but his moderate views angered radicals in both North and South, and he was unable to forestall the secession of South Carolina on Dec. 20, 1860.
1926: Marilyn Monroe, the American actress who led a turbulent life and became an icon after her death, is born. She appeared in several motion pictures, including "Some Like it Hot" and "The Misfits."
1929: A state funeral for China's Dr. Sun Yat-sen is held in Nanking at the Dr. Sun Yat-sen Mausoleum on Mount Tzuchinshan.
1931: The Provisional Constitution for the Period of Political Tutelage of the Republic of China is promulgated.
1941: British forces are finally withdrawn from Crete with heavy losses. Some 3,000 Australians are also killed in the evacuation.
1946: The Chinese Petroleum Corp. is established in Shanghai.
1946: The Land Bank of Taiwan is inaugurated.
1957: Chiang Ching-kuo becomes chairman of the Vocational Assistance Commission for Retired Servicemen under the ROC Executive Yuan.
1958: The ROC wins the football championship at the Third Asian Games in Tokyo.
1958: General Charles de Gaulle becomes prime minister of France.
1960: O.K. Yu (Yu Hung-chiun), governor of the Central Bank of China, dies at the age of 65. Yu had formerly served as governor of Taiwan and premier of the ROC.
1968: Helen Keller, the blind and deaf American author and teacher, dies at home in Easton, Connecticut, at the age of 87, ending a life of outstanding courage that brought hope and inspiration to thousands.
1968: The Joint Service Committee for Overseas Chinese and Foreign Investors is established in Taipei.
1972: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the appointment of Fredrick F. Chien as director-general of the Government Information Office; Chen Kuei-hua as director of the Personnel Administration Office; Hsieh Tung-min as governor of Taiwan; Chang Feng-hsu as mayor of Taipei; C.C. Chang as chairman of the Economic Planning Council; and Yang Chia-lin as chairman of the Administrative Research and Evaluation Committee of the Executive Yuan.
1973: Lt. Gen. Chaveng Youngcharoen, commandant of the Royal Thai War College, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1973: The ROC opens regular shipping service to Indonesia.
1975: An automated terminal radar system is installed at Taipei International Airport.
1976: ROC President Yen Chia-kan confers the Order of Propitious Clouds with Special Grand Cordon on Leabua Jonathan, prime minister of the Kingdom of Lesotho, and the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon on Lesotho Foreign Minister Charles D. Molapo.
1978: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the appointment of Lin Yang-kang as governor of Taiwan Province, and of Lee Teng-hui as mayor of Taipei City.
1979: Rhodesia takes the name Zimbabwe, with Bishop Abel Muzorewa as its first black prime minister, ending 89 years of white rule.
1979: The Taiwan Provincial Government decides to raise NT$28.82 billion before 1980 for the construction of the South Link Railroad which is planned for completion in December 1990. Upon completion of the project, a trip around the island will take only a day.
1989: Lee Huan is sworn in as premier of the ROC.
1990: U.S. President George Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev sign a bilateral agreement to stop producing chemical arms and to start destroying existing stocks by the end of 1992.
1999: Dr. Lien Wen-pin, chief physician of President Lee Teng-hui at National Taiwan University Hospital, says the president, now 77 years old, has the body of a 60-year-old and is in extremely good health.
1999: Francisco Flores, 39, is sworn in as the youngest-ever president of El Salvador.
2000: After four years of lackluster operations, the EVA Airways Corporation suspends its flights on the Taipei-Panama City route.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Pleasure derived from the study and criticism of the polite arts, pleasure in admiring and speaking of the excellent qualities of men, and pleasure in having many friends of virtue and talent: these pleasures are beneficial."

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING AFRAID OF COMING TO NEGOTIATING TABLE: CHEN
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, May 31 (CNA) (By Y.C. Chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese leaders are "afraid" of coming to the negotiating table to talk with their Taiwan counterparts because of a lack of confidence, Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday.

Chen, who arrived in Paraguay Thursday for a three-day state visit, told the Spanish-language news agency EFE in an interview that he has long been eager to reopen the gate to rational and productive cross-strait dialogue but that the Communist Chinese have only paid lip service to reopening talks, saying that their reasons for not restarting them are only excuses.

On the topic of reunification of Taiwan and mainland China, Chen said that economic and cultural integration should come first in order to build up mutual trust that can then serve as a basis for peaceful political integration across the Taiwan Strait.
He stressed that peace, equality and the people's will are the three key principles that must be fully observed during the process of cross-strait integration.

During a luncheon hosted by overseas Chinese representatives in Paraguay in honor of Chen, his wife and their entourage, the ROC president said that "giving Taiwan away to others cannot be a way for bringing cross-strait stability."
Chen emphasized that cross-strait stability cannot come about simply by Taiwan raising the white flag and surrendering itself to Beijing.

Speaking in his mother tongue of Taiwanese, which many of the overseas Chinese living or working in Paraguay are familiar with, Chen discounted Beijing's "one country, two systems" overture, saying that if Taiwan accepted it, the Republic of China would disappear from the map.
The "one country, two systems" overture is not acceptable to the 23 million people of Taiwan, Chen stressed, adding that "we have a responsibility to Taiwan's future generations."

Paraguay is the fourth leg of Chen's current five-state diplomatic journey to Latin America, which will also take him to Honduras. Chen and his entourage concluded their visit to Panama Wednesday. Before proceeding to Panama, the ROC president visited El Salvador and Guatemala.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC LOOKING AT WORLD OIL PRICES, NT DOLLAR VALUE IN CONSIDERING HIKE

TEXT.P: Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) will look at world oil prices and the value of the new Taiwan dollar in considering whether to hike domestic petroleum prices, CPC Chairman C. W. Chen said Friday.
But Chen did not mention when a hike might occur or how big it would be, only saying that if there is a hike, it will be modest.

With the recent depreciation of the new Taiwan dollar, the cost of importing crude has risen, putting pressure on the CPC and the other domestic petroleum distributor Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) to raise their prices for petroleum products.

Although the CPC's marketing department has assessed the situation and says the company should hike prices, CPC executives said they would not be rash in doing so based on considerations of market competitiveness and the impact on consumer prices.
Tai Wen-yen, a CPC marketing official, said the new Taiwan dollar's sharp depreciation Monday of 1.005 against the U.S. dollar had a great impact on the cost of imported crude.
Although the value of the new Taiwan dollar has rebounded modestly since Monday, Tai said the CPC will have to monitor the situation for a few days before making a decision.

He said the CPC will try to absorb the impact of the depreciation in the new Taiwan dollar by making up the company's losses in other areas, such as by lowering management costs and expanding its business.

Tai pointed out that for every new Taiwan dollar depreciation, the CPC will incur annual losses of between NT$500 million and NT$600 million. In contrast, the FPG, which currently has a 17 percent market share in Taiwan, will not suffer as much because of the rising cost of imported crude.

The CPC last raised its petroleum prices in April, using as its basis the price at the time of West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude -- US$27.24 per barrel -- and the value of the new Taiwan dollar -- NT$32.9 against the U.S. dollar.

At the present, the price of WTI is hovering at around US$28.5 per barrel, and the new Taiwan dollar is valued at about 33.9 to the greenback, putting greater pressure on both the CPC and the FPG to hike their petroleum prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA REITERATES THAT SOLID TAIWAN-PANAMA TIES UNCHANGED

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) reiterated Friday that formal diplomatic relations between the ROC and Panama remain solid and firm and that this will not change.

MOFA spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue noted the solid and cordial nature of ROC-Panama ties was revealed by the highest possible level of treatment that the Panamanian government accorded to President Chen Shui-bian and his entourage during their three-day state visit to Panama May 28-30.

The closeness of their bilateral relationship was also demonstrated by the signing of a joint communique by Chen and his Panamanian counterpart Mireya Moscoso May 29 reaffirming their commitment to further strengthening the "historically friendly" relationship between the ROC and Panama, Chang said.

She made the remarks in response to questions raised by local reporters regarding comments made by Panamanian Foreign Minister Jose Miguel Aleman to foreign news agencies right after Chen departed Panama that were not favorable to bilateral relations between Taiwan and Panama.

According to the foreign news reports, Aleman said that Panama would welcome diplomatic relations with Beijing, but "with no conditions attached." He also said that "Panama will not break its relations with Taiwan." Beijing refuses to establish diplomatic ties with countries that formally recognize the ROC.

Discounting the foreign news reports, Chang said the MOFA would rather believe the joint communique and all the public remarks made by President Moscoso and Foreign Minister Aleman about relations between the two countries.
"The relationship has been fortified," Moscoso said as she saw Chen off at Panama City's international airport May 30.
Meanwhile, Chang said the MOFA is currently going through proper channels to contact Aleman in order to verify his recent remarks concerning ROC-Panama bilateral relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FIRST LADY DONATES CASH TO PARAGUAYAN FOUNDATION, CHINESE SCHOOL
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, May 31 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China First Lady Wu Shu-chen donated US$20,000 in cash to the Paraguayan First Lady Welfare Foundation Thursday on behalf of the ROC government and people.
Wu made the donation during a visit to Paraguayan President Luis Angel Gonzalez Macchi's official residence, where she received a warm welcome from her Paraguayan counterpart.
Wu said she feels honored to visit the Paraguayan president's official residence, which is also used as an office.
Wu further said she admires the Paraguayan first lady's dedication to promoting charitable and social welfare services for underprivileged groups and low-income families.

Wu, who herself has been confined to a wheelchair since being paralyzed in a car accident 16 years ago, said she is hopeful that the ROC donation can help finance the Paraguayan foundation's charitable and social welfare programs.
"The donation conveys our people's concern for their Paraguayan counterparts and also symbolizes close ties between the two countries," Wu said.
For her part, Paraguayan First Lady Susana Galli de Gonzalez Macchi expressed her gratitude for the ROC donation to help needy Paraguayan people.
Mrs. Gonzalez also said she hopes the two countries can strengthen exchanges of experience in carrying out various social welfare programs.

In the company of Mrs. Gonzalez, Wu later visited a district hospital in Lambare, a city on the outskirts of Asuncion. A team of medical professionals from Taiwan was offering free medical services at the Lambare district hospital.

The medical team was organized by the Taiwan Root Medical Peace Corps (TRMPC), a Taipei-based organization dedicated to providing free medical services to residents in remote regions in Taiwan and other countries.
The team left Taipei May 19 for Bolivia where it offered free services in several mountain villages. And the group arrived in Paraguay May 27.
TRMPC founder Liu Chi-chuan said the team was offering medical services at the Lambare hospital under the arrangement of the Paraguayan First Lady Welfare Foundation.

Wu lauded the group for its efforts to help improve medical services for needy people in developing countries. "Through such efforts, you have helped our country forge friendship with many people around the world," an emotional Wu said.
On Thursday, Wu also visited a Chinese school founded in 1986 with the assistance from the ROC government and overseas Chinese community in Paraguay.

Wu expressed her admiration for all school faculty members as their concerted efforts have made the school one of the top-notch educational institutions in Paraguay. The school now accepts both overseas Chinese and Paraguayan children.
Wu also donated US$30,000 in cash to underscore the ROC government's support for the school.

Wu accompanied President Chen Shui-bian to Paraguay Wednesday for a three-day state visit. This is the first time that Wu has taken part in an overseas trip in her capacity as ROC first lady. The ROC first couple have already visited El Salvador, Guatemala and Panama, and their current five-nation Latin American diplomatic journey will also take them to Honduras.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 34.9 points to close at 5,013.96.

Encouraged by a rebound in U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 5,090.66 and began to go down due to a lack of confidence on the part of investors. The index fluctuated between 5,096.43 and 4,991.32 during trading.

A total of 1.19 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$36.77 billion (US$1.08 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 1.39 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$42.13 billion (US$1.24 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with bank and insurance shares moving up by 0.5 percent.

The other major categories posted losses, with plastics and chemical stocks moving down the most at 1.8 percent, followed by electrical shares at 1 percent, construction stocks at 0.9 percent, cement stocks at 0.8 percent, textile issues at 0.6 percent, pulp and paper issues at 0.3 percent and foodstuff shares at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 345 to 142, with 101 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC EDUCATION MINISTER ATTENDS ACADEMIC SYMPOSIUM IN HONG KONG
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, June 1 (CNA) (By Semy Chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Education Minister Ovid Tzeng departed Hong Kong Friday for Taipei after attending an international academic symposium held at the City University of Hong Kong (CUHK) Thursday.
Tzeng, the first ROC education minister to visit Hong Kong -- a special district of mainland China -- intentionally kept a low profile during his Hong Kong trip.

He told the Hong Kong media at the airport that he was in Hong Kong exclusively for an academic gathering. "Academic exchanges are borderless in nature and I hope to contribute my utmost to the promotion and study of Sinology," he said.
The ROC education minister arrived in Hong Kong Wednesday at the invitation of CUHK, where he attended an international symposium on linguistics.
During his Hong Kong trip, Tzeng also visited Chu-hai College and King-ling College and met with scholars and specialists at those institutes.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAN RANDOMLY ATTACKS JAPANESE MAN, 2 LOCAL WOMEN

TEXT.P: Three people were injured, including a Japanese man, when a man began randomly attacking people Friday morning, police said.
Police said that the suspect Lu Chien-kuang, who lives in a high-rise residential building on Roosevelt Road in southern Taipei, began his attacks at around 8 a.m.

Two women, surnamed Liang and Wang, suffered cuts on the back and arms, respectively. The Japanese man, Takehiro Hattori, 30, who only recently moved into the building, was also attacked when he walked into the elevator on the 12th floor on his way to work.
Hattori suffered the most serious wounds, being hit on the head and back and having two fingers almost cut off when he tried to resist the attacker.
The trio were sent to the National Taiwan University Hospital in stable condition.
The suspect was arrested and did not speak when he was questioned at the police station. He was later sent to the hospital to have his mental state determined.

After interviewing residents of the building, police found that Lu, who recently moved back home from overseas to live with his father whom is said to suffer from dementia, has little contact with his neighbors.
In the last month, the Lus began the habit of throwing cans and bottles down from their 17th floor apartment, inviting protests from their neighbors.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-HK AIR PACT MAY BE EXTENDED FOR MORE THAN 3 MONTHS: MAC

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government does not rule out the possibility of extending an existing aviation agreement with Hong Kong for more than three months after the pact expires June 12, a senior mainland affairs official said Friday.

Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China and has handled exchanges with Hong Kong and Macau since the two former colonies reverted to Beijing rule in 1997 and 1999, respectively.

Although the expiry of the five-year Taiwan-Hong Kong air pact is drawing dear, Hong Kong authorities have so far not informed Taiwan of their plans for negotiations on a new version of the bilateral aviation agreement, as Beijing's attitude toward the issue remains unclear.

Lin said that as this will be the first time that Taiwan and Hong Kong will have held aviation rights talks since Hong Kong's reversion to Beijing rule and the ROC's implementation of a statute on relations with Hong Kong and Macau, the two sides need time to prepare for negotiations on a new accord.

"Therefore, we do not rule out the possibility of extending the existing pact for a suitable period of time after its expiry so that the two sides can have enough time to negotiate a new pact to meet the changing market trends," Lin said, adding that the extension can also help maintain normal operations of flight services between the two places.
He stressed that the ROC looks forward to reaching a new aviation agreement with Hong Kong on a reciprocal basis.
The current Taiwan-Hong Kong aviation pact was signed in 1996 and the two sides originally agreed to review the accord once every five years.

Any possible delay in negotiations for a new version of the pact would be bad news for Taiwan's EVA Airways and Hong Kong's Dragon Air, both of which are eager to see revisions to the existing pact to allow them to increase the number of their flights.

Despite the current cross-strait political stalemate, bilateral trade and economic exchanges have continued to grow. The demand for flight services between Taiwan and Hong Kong -- a major transit stop for cross-Taiwan Strait air traffic -- has been skyrocketing.
Under the present pact, Taiwan and Hong Kong can both allow their carriers to operate a total of 121 weekly flights between the two places.

At present, Taiwan's China Airlines can operate 105 flights per week, while EVA can only operate 16 weekly flights. Meanwhile, Hong Kong assigns 100 flights to its Cathay Pacific Airways and 21 flights to Dragon Air.

With more and more Taiwan investors and managers relocating to mainland China, the Taiwan-Hong Kong route has become one of the hottest and both EVA and Dragon Air have long desired to increase their flights on the route, airline sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ISSUES STAMPS TO COMMEMORATE PIONEERING DOCTOR

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Directorate General of Posts (DGP) issued a set of memorial stamps Friday in commemoration of Canadian missionary doctor George Leslie Mackay, who died in Taiwan 100 years ago.

The stamps were debuted at a ceremony jointly witnessed by DGP Director-General Cheng Wen-cheng, Lee Fu-chuan, head of the Presbyterian Church in Taiwan, and Huang Chun-hsiung, president of Mackay Memorial Hospital in Taipei.

The ceremony was particularly blessed with the participation of John Ross Mackay, grandson of the man who is hailed by the people of Taiwan as one of the foreign pioneers who brought Western medicine and other accoutrements of modern civilization, including photography, to rural Taiwan more than a century ago.
John Mackay, now in his 70s, offered his greetings to guests at the ceremony with a short phrase in Taiwanese dialect, saying "Jiahuahsi (so pleased)" to be here.
Mackay, who was born in Taiwan, said it has been too long since he left Taiwan and that he can hardly remember any other Taiwanese dialect.

A geology professor at Columbia University in the United States who enjoys an international reputation in the field of North Pole studies, Mackay said his memory of his grandfather was slight, as he was born after his grandfather had died.

The Mackay memorial stamp set is the fourth to be printed by a Chinese government as a token to commemorate a foreigner since 1878 -- the fourth year of the Kuanghsu Empire of the Ching Dynasty -- according to Cheng.

Mackay came to Taiwan in 1872 at the age of 28 as a missionary for the Canadian Presbyterian Church. He preached, educated and provided medical services to the people of Taiwan throughout his 29 years in Taiwan until he passed away in 1901 in Tamshui. His grave is located at Oxford College in Tamshui, where his son William is also buried.
Mackay married a Taiwan woman with whom he had three children and their offspring now live in Canada, the United States and Taiwan.

Tamkang High School, Mackay Memorial Hospital and other establishments related to Mackay in Taiwan are currently sponsoring various activities in commemoration of the 100th anniversary of his death, which falls on June 2, a Mackay hospital spokeswoman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC EXPORT-IMPORT BANK ESTABLISHES REP OFFICE IN WARSAW

TEXT.P: The Export-Import Bank of the Republic of China has set up a representative office in Warsaw, an official of the bank said Friday.

The official said that the newly-inaugurated office will coordinate the government agencies concerned with expanding foreign trade policy so as to offer financial assistance and export insurance to local exporters.
The office was formally inaugurated in Poland's capital Thursday, with Chung Su-sheng, president of the bank, presiding over the ceremony.
More than 100 officials of ROC Representative Office in Warsaw, Polish officials and Taiwan businesspeople witnessed the inauguration ceremony.

The ROC is Poland's fourth largest trade partner and the largest market in Asia for Polish products. Poland will become a potential market for Taiwan products if and when Poland joins the European Union.
The bank's setting up of the office in Poland is significant as it will act as a springboard for local businesspeople to expand their business to Central and Eastern Europe, the official said.
Poland is expected to post an economic growth rate of over 5 percent for 2001, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA MOTORS TO ENTER JOINT VENTURE WITH INDIAN CARMAKER

TEXT.P: China Motor Corp. (CMC) will become Taiwan's first carmaker to introduce its products to the subcontinent after entering a joint venture with an Indian carmaker, a local source said Friday.
The source said that CMC will enter a technical cooperation agreement with India's Premier Automobiles Ltd. (PAL) to produce CMC's Varica -- a popular economy van -- to the Indian market.
The Indian production line is expected to begin mass production in October and the sales volume will be set at 10,000 units annually in the initial stage, he said.
CMC, which was Taiwan's No. 1 car exporter last year, has already successfully expanded to mainland China, Southeast Asian and Middle Eastern markets.

The source pointed out that CMC, with its eyes on India's one billion population, entered a technical cooperation agreement with PAL in 1997, the same year it introduced the Varica to the Indian market on a trial basis that proved successful.

According to unofficial statistics, India will be one of the most populous countries in the world by 2005 and will need 800,000 new cars per year. This makes it very important for Taiwan carmakers looking for a market other than mainland China, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK, MACAU WELCOME TO OPEN OFFICES IN TAIWAN: MAC

TEXT.P: Hong Kong and Macau are welcome to open representative offices in Taiwan to forge new mechanisms for mutual exchanges, the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Friday.

The MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China and handles exchanges with Hong Kong and Macau, said in a press release that Taiwan-Hong Kong and Taiwan-Macau ties are litmus to relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Noting that the Republic of China's current Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)-led government has endeavored to promote exchanges and cooperation with Hong Kong and Macau, the MAC said it is hopeful that the Beijing leadership can adopt a pragmatic and forward-looking attitude toward Taiwan's engagements with Hong Kong and Macau to facilitate the establishment of institutionalized mechanisms for their normal contacts and consultations.

The MAC said it is convinced that if Hong Kong and Macau manage to open liaison offices in Taiwan, the moves will be able to foster a scenario beneficial to all of the four Chinese societies -- Taiwan, mainland China, Hong Kong and Macau.

Since the ROC government allowed its people to visit their mainland relatives and make indirect investments on the mainland in the late 1980s, the MAC went on, the intermediary roles of Hong Kong and Macau have become increasingly important in cross-strait relations.
And this upward trend has not been affected by Hong Kong's and Macau's reversions to Beijing's rule in 1997 and 1999, respectively, the MAC stressed.

On the trading front, the MAC said, Taiwan-Hong Kong trade registered a 19.3 percent annual growth to reach US$33 billion last year, and Taiwan-Macau trade also posted a 13.19 percent gain to hit US$360 million.

In terms of personnel exchanges, Taiwan residents made more than 2.8 million visits to Hong Kong and Macau last year, making Taiwan Hong Kong's second largest source of tourist arrivals and Macau's No. 3 source of tourist arrivals. During the same period, Hong Kong and Macau residents made more than 295,000 visits to Taiwan.
After Taiwan opens its door to mainland Chinese tourists in the near future, the MAC said, the intermediary roles of Hong Kong and Macau in cross-strait exchanges will become even more important.

In addition, the MAC said the ROC government has consistently promoted academic exchanges with Hong Kong and Macau and assisted private cultural and arts groups to increase exchanges with their Hong Kong and Macau counterparts.

Nevertheless, the MAC said governmental exchanges between Taiwan and the two areas have not grown as fast as their commercial, social and cultural interchanges since the two formal colonies reverted to Beijing's rule.

Under the restrictions set forth in mainland China's seven principles for handling Taiwan-Hong Kong relations, the MAC said, Taiwan-Hong Kong interaction has even lagged behind cross-strait engagements.
The MAC said it looks forward to seeing the Hong Kong government take more active steps to improve bilateral engagements and resolve practical problems arising from mutual exchanges.

For its part, the MAC said, the ROC government will take a series of goodwill measures to boost bilateral relations, including beefing up the functions of the ROC representative office in Hong Kong, cultivating extensive connections with various Hong Kong social quarters and simplifying visa applications by prospective Hong Kong and Macau visitors to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL MOTORCYCLE MAKER SUCCESSFULLY ENTERS EUROPEAN MARKET
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, May 31 (CNA) (By M.J. Tzou & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Kuang Yang Motorcycle Co. (KYMCO) has successfully introduced its products into the European market, a trade source said here Thursday.

The source said that a KYMCO showroom has been set up by its general agent for the European area on the famed Champs Elysees in the center of Paris, the second KYMCO showroom established in France. The first showroom was set up in downtown Lyons last November.
Gilbert Jost, KYMCO's agent in Europe, said that his company sold US$140 million-worth of KYMCO motorcycles last year, accounting for 4 percent of the total French motorcycle sales.

Noting that KYMCO's products have been well-received in Europe, Jost said that he plans to expand KYMCO sales centers to five next year. He said that his company will also strengthen after-sales service to its customers to help KYMCO become the "most famous motorcycle marque" in Europe.
KYMCO began introducing its products into Europe 20 years ago and now has a sales network covering Germany, Finland, Great Britain, Spain and Italy.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT TO HELP PARAGUAY IN SOCIAL, ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, June 1 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Visiting Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian agreed Friday to help Paraguay implement its economic and social development strategy and speed up the handover of four helicopters to the South American nation.
Chen made the remarks during a meeting with Paraguay President Luis Angel Gonzalez Macchi.
Gonzalez welcomed Chen's visit and expressed appreciation for the assistance over the years given by the ROC to Paraguay.

Gonzalez noted that he was appointed by the nation's Supreme Court of Justice to serve as the president two years ago and had no chance to explain his administration ideals and only recently unveiled his social and economic development strategy in a bid to stimulate Paraguay's industrial development.
Gonzalez said that he hopes to lure more foreign investment into the nation's processing industry of agricultural products, and its lumber, fruit and agricultural product exports.

He also described his ultimate goals as annihilating poverty and promoting development. He suggested that the two nations set up supra-government agency cooperation committees so that high-level officials from both countries could discuss matters of cooperation.

He also expressed the hope that the ROC will provide assistance to the infrastructure construction of his nation, such as road-building, and will deliver the remaining four of six UH-1H helicopters that the ROC promised to donate to Paraguay.
Chen said that the slow pace of the helicopter donation is due to the fact that the ROC must wait for approval from the United States, as the helicopters were purchased from that country.

The president also said that he understands the hardship Gonzalez suffered in the initial stage of his administration, but added that hardship is a "necessary process" for a nation going from a authoritarian to a democratic government.

Chen also noted that Paraguay is a faithful strategic ally of the ROC, as well as a springboard for Taiwan businessmen making inroads into Mercosur (Southern Common Market). He added that the ROC will continue to honor its commitments with regard to previously agreed-upon donations and loans.

Chen also said that since Taiwan was hit by a devastating earthquake Sept. 21, 1999, its reconstruction work has been heavy and expensive. In addition, he went on, Taiwan's economy has been impacted by the world economic slump, but he said the ROC will continue to assist Paraguay within its financial limits.

As Paraguay's economic and social development strategy will involve many government agencies, Chen also agreed to set up a supra-government agency committee so that the two countries can handle related matters.

DOC.HEADLINE: IOC VICE CHAIRMAN ARRIVES IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Kim Un Ryong, vice chairman of the International Olympic Committee (IOC), arrived in Taipei Friday at the invitation of Wu Ching-kuo, an IOC member of the Republic of China.
Kim will be the distinguished guest at a series of invitational table-tennis matches currently being played by the top four women players of the 2000 Sydney Olympic Games.
A match in Kaohsiung has already been held and a match in Hsinchu was scheduled for Friday, with a final to take place Sunday in Taipei.
Soon after his arrival at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, Kim proceeded to Hsinchu, accompanied by Wu and other Taiwan sports promoters.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. ENVOY VISITS KINMEN TO SEE `MINI 3 LINKS' IN ACTION

TEXT.P: The de facto U.S. ambassador to the Republic of China said here Friday he is pleased to see the opening of direct "mini three links" between the ROC's frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu and mainland China's ports of Xiamen and Mawei.

Raymond Burghardt, director of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), made the remarks before wrapping up a two-day visit to Kinmen. The quasi-official AIT handles ROC-U.S. exchanges in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

Burghardt arrived in Kinmen Thursday to see for himself the operations of the Taiwan-initiated "mini three links" program. It was his first visit to the island since the Jan. 1 opening of direct trade, mail and shipping links between the ROC's two offshore islands and the two mainland Chinese port cities in Fujian Province, which faces Taiwan across the Taiwan Strait.
With a view to avoiding any possible speculation that might adversely affect cross-strait relations, Burghardt kept a low profile on his Kinmen visit.

At the end of his visit, Burghardt said he was impressed by the "mini three links" program. He further said that many foreign countries, including the United States, take great interest in the development of cross-strait relations.
As the "mini three links" program is part of cross-strait relations, Burghardt said he traveled to Kinmen to take a look at the program's actual operations.

In his view, Burghardt said, the "mini three links" program will contribute to the development of cross-strait relations. The United States would be very glad to see peaceful engagements between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, he added.

This was Burghardt's second visit to Kinmen since he assumed his current post. He last visited the ROC's defense outpost 18 months ago in the company of National Security Bureau Director Ting Yu-chou. During that unpublicized visit, the U.S. envoy focused his itinerary on visiting military installations and defense facilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT TO BEGIN NEW VISA INFORMATION SERVICE

TEXT.P: The American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) will begin a new telephone visa information service from June 8 to handle requests for visa information, according to a Friday press release.
The press release said the new service is expected to virtually eliminate the busy signals and unanswered calls that have frustrated many callers seeking information about visas.
It will also provide more detailed and comprehensive answers to the most commonly asked questions in a format that will allow callers to choose which information they want to hear, it said.

The telephone number for the new visa information line is 0204-58858 and the recorded service will be available 24 hours a day in English and Mandarin, with a fax-on-demand number of 0204-58958 available for forms and information sheets.

The new telephone service has become necessary because of the increasing volume of visa inquiry calls. AIT currently receives about 15,000 telephone inquiries a month and consular officials processed over 300,000 applications last year for immigrant and non-immigrant visas.
The new visa information service is superior to the existing telephone information system in several ways, according to the press release:
-- It can handles more simultaneous calls, which should eliminate busy signals;
-- The information available is broader in scope and detail;
-- Callers must use a touch-tone phone that has IDD access (Cellular phones and public telephones will also work); and
-- The new service is expected to free up the AIT switchboard so that people who have other business will be able to get through more easily.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT RECEIVES HONORARY DOCTORATE IN PARAGUAY

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian received an honorary doctorate Friday from National Asuncion University and called for enhanced two-way academic exchanges.

In a speech to the National Asuncion University authorities following the ceremony, Chen thanked Paraguay's top university for the honor and said it was the most precious moment of his three-day state visit to the ROC's sole diplomatic ally in South America.

Paraphrasing a poem by U.S. poet Walt Whitman, Chen said he was very touched when looking out at the young, enthusiastic and smiling students of the university. "What I see is not only singing and youth, but the hope and bright future of this country," he said.

The ROC president compared National Asuncion University to his own alma mater -- National Taiwan University -- for its long history and regional academic status. He hailed the university as the cradle of Paraguay's talent and elite and voiced his belief that the leading Paraguayan university will play a pivotal role in the country's future.

"As a faithful ally of Paraguay, I truly believe that the ROC should further boost its academic exchanges with National Asuncion University and help it cultivate more talent to help accelerate Paraguay's development," he said.

Chen attributed the ROC's economic and political progress over the past 50 years to the country's successful education, particularly its higher education. With the country's sole resource -- high quality manpower -- Taiwan has managed to achieve outstanding progress with "locally trained political and economic experts," he noted.

Stressing that the ROC and Paraguay are "genuine partners on the path toward progress," the ROC president wished Paraguay luck in overcoming all its difficulties under the capable leadership of President Luis Angel Gonzalez Macchi and also in achieving its own political and economic miracle.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FM MEETS MACEDONIAN PRIME MINISTER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao has met with Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski in Skopje, the Balkan state's capital, to discuss matters of mutual concern, Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue said Friday.
Tien cut short his Latin American diplomatic tour to fly to Macedonia Thursday in a last-ditch effort to rescue the ROC's diplomatic ties with its war-torn European ally.
Chang told a routine press conference in Taipei that Tien managed to meet Georgievski shortly after his arrival in Skopje Thursday afternoon.

"Their meeting proceeded in a candid, friendly atmosphere," Chang said, adding that as the current Macedonian coalition government is composed of officials from seven different and mutually competing political parties, its political situation is very complicated and volatile.
Chang said Tien has traveled to Skopje to understand the latest situation in that country.
ROC Vice Foreign Minister Chiu Jong-nan also flew from Taipei to Skopje Thursday to join Tien in shoring up the ROC's diplomatic ties with Macedonia.
Chang said both Tien and Chiu will do their utmost to communicate with Macedonian politicians and influential figures in various Macedonian social quarters.

Chang would not made any comments on reports that Macedonian Foreign Minister Ilinka Mitreva had told a group of reporters that her country is prepared to break off diplomatic ties with the ROC in an effort to restore diplomatic relations with mainland China.

Meanwhile, Chang said the proposal to set up a peace fund to help Macedonia maintain its domestic political stability was mainly a personal view of Loh Ping-chang, secretary-general of the ROC's International Cooperation and Development Fund.

Chang said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will make a further evaluation of Loh's proposal. "It's still premature to say whether the MOFA will agree to the proposal to set up a peace fund to help Macedonia," she stressed.

In fact, the ROC had donated US$1 million to Macedonia when fighting between Macedonian forces and ethnic Albanian guerrillas erupted in April this year. Among major countries around the world, the ROC was the first to extend a helping hand to Macedonia.

Macedonia switched recognition to the ROC in 1999, but now is keen to regain mainland China's international support in dealing with a five-month-long ethnic Albanian insurgency along its border with Kosovo.

In reality, the official ROC-Macedonian ties have never been completely smooth. The ROC's envoy in Macedonia, Peter P.C. Cheng, has not yet had the chance to present his credentials to the Macedonian president.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO YEARS TO LIBERALIZATION OF WINE, TOBACCO PRODUCTION: MOF

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance announced Friday that the government will liberalize alcohol and tobacco production within the coming two years.

MOF officials said that the liberalization will be carried out in three separate stages over the two-year period. The first stage will see the opening of the market to producers of beer, wine and rice wine, while the second stage will open the market to distillers and manufacturers of fortified wines. The third stage see the lifting of all remaining restrictions.

The MOF had originally planned to liberalize the production of alcohol and tobacco in three years, but the decline in the local economy in central Taiwan since the Sept. 21, 1999 earthquake led government and civic leaders to recommend earlier liberalization to the Central government so as to help local governments revitalize the economy.
Vice Finance Minister Wang Teh-shan said that the newly adopted alcohol and tobacco production system will not be implemented before July 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND CLOSELY MONITORING BEIJING MILITARY DRILLS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense said Friday it is closely monitoring preparations by mainland China's People's Liberation Army for the largest war games since President Chen Shui-bian took office last year.
Defense ministry officials said the exercises, code named "Liberation One," are no cause for alarm in Taiwan.
Reports have said that the exercises will take place on and around Dongshan Island, off the southeastern coast of China, on June 4 but defense ministry officials have not confirmed the date.

The officials pointed out that any large-scale combined forces drills involving land, sea and air forces will have to mass troops and complete logistic and administrative operations before starting individual exercises for each armed force.
Reports have said that "Liberation One" has yet to begin formal drills and that the mainland has just completed massing its troops and the individual exercises for each armed force.

The defense ministry said they were not sure if the timing of the exercises would coincide with the return of President Chen from his five-nation Latin American trip, but they said they will inform the public when the drills begin.

Wire service reports said that Beijing's war games aim to serve as a "military warning" to the administration of Chen. Beijing is mistrustful of Chen because of his past stance on Taiwan independence and his refusal to endorse mainland China's "one China" principle.

The reports also said that the emphasis of the drills will be mock attacks and occupation of an outlying Taiwanese island and an assault on an aircraft carrier. The exercises are to demonstrate Beijing's determination to protect its sovereign and territorial integrity, the reports said.

Defense ministry officials said that Russian-made Sukhoi SU-27 fighters, which made low-altitude bombing runs in the last military exercises on Dongshan Island two years ago, will again take part in the upcoming exercises, but will carry on the mission of maintaining airborne superiority.
Military generals said that judging from Beijing's military strategy, the drills this time will be to prevent "foreign intervention," and are not aimed at Taiwan directly.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS SHOULD BE ECONOMICS-ORIENTED: JOHN CHANG

TEXT.P: "The concept of cross-strait relations should be 70 percent economics and trade-oriented and 30 percent politics," said John Chang, chairman of the Chamber of Taiwan Businessmen in China.

Chang, who was foreign minister (1996-1997), secretary-general of Kuomintang's Central Committee (1997-1999), secretary-general to the president (1999), and senior advisor to the president (1999-2000), is now dedicating his expertise achieved from long years in the government and the party to the promotion of economic and trade relations across the Taiwan Strait.

In an interview with Taiwan's Central News Agency, Chang said that distrust has blocked the channel of cross-strait exchanges. In a recent visit to mainland China, he observed that without trust, the chance to resume cross-strait dialogue is remote.
"Mutual benefits can only be achieved through mutual support based upon understanding and trust," Chang said.

While a new round of discussions between the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) of Taiwan and the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) of mainland China is on hold, the Taiwan businessmen's associations in mainland China have been functioning as intermediaries, according to Chang.
There are 64 such associations in mainland China, and many of them have established good connections. "These associations are where the Taiwan businessmen would turn in time of need," Chang said.

Chang said that the associations have taken up certain functions comparable to those of a consulate, but their capabilities to solve problems remain limited. "After all, these associations are not authorized with official functions," he added.
There are some 50,000 Taiwan businessmen investing in mainland China, and the number is growing.

"In the past years, Taiwan businessmen have sought their opportunities in Southeast Asia, South America, South Africa and the United States. When domestic investment environments become adverse, businessmen need to find trade opportunities, sometimes even chances of survival overseas.
"Branching out is an irreversible trend, and it is better to work out plans to coordinate the efforts of Taiwan businessmen and help them solve problems," he said.

Chang said that most Taiwan businessmen in mainland China advocate an earlier relaxation of restrictions on direct trade, transportation and postal links. He said that the government should be able to find out a mutually supplementary and beneficiary solution.

Referring to government assistance to Taiwan businessmen, Chang lauded the government's decision to allow local bank's offshore banking units to handle cross-strait monetary businesses. At present, funding is a very complicated process for Taiwan businessmen investing in mainland China.

He said that during his conversations with Taiwan businessmen, many have raised the issue of double-taxation by authorities on both sides of the Strait. They hope that a formula can be worked out to ease their tax burden.
The Chamber of Taiwan Businessmen in China was set up late last year under the initiative of leading political figures and chief negotiators in cross-strait consultations in the past years.

Chang said that the chamber remained low-key in their operations at the beginning, expecting to reinforce their organization first. The line-up of the board is impressive, with President of the Legislative Yuan Wang Jin-pyng and former Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang as honorary chairmen and former SEF vice chairman and secretary-general Chiu Cheyne as vice chairman. Executives of Taiwan businessmen associations have all joined the chamber.

During his two visits to mainland China in December and May, Chang met with ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan, Beijing's Vice Premier Qian Qichen and Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of the State Council.
The functions of the chamber are recognized, Chang said, adding that with coordinated efforts, the chamber will play an active role in cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-DRUG CRUSADE IS BATTLE WITHOUT BOUNDARIES OR END: PREMIER

TEXT.P: The government's crusade against illegal drugs is a battle without boundaries or end, said Premier Chang Chun-hsiung Friday.

Speaking at the opening of a national anti-drug conference organized by the Ministry of Justice, Chang said the crusade against illegal drugs should be a continuous battle which is taken to every corner of the country and should have no limits or end.

Calling illegal drugs one of the "three malignant tumors" undermining the law and order of the island, Chang said illegal drugs not only hurt the people who use them, but also harm their families and society.

The premier said that he was worried about the appearance of new kinds of narcotics and the growing number of young addicts despite the government's persistent efforts to rid the country of the problem.

However, Chang said it was because of the increased efforts of law enforcement units that the United States has removed Taiwan from its list of illegal drug transshipment points this year. He urged drug enforcement officials not to let up in their anti-drug campaign.

Meanwhile, Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan complained at the same event that the government's anti-drug campaign is so poorly organized that it looks like "a cart drawn by two horses (in different directions)."

He said the Investigation Bureau under the Ministry of Justice and the National Police Administration under the Ministry of the Interior were the government's two arms in combating illegal drugs. Instead of cooperating with each other, Chen said, the two agencies are often in competition and thereby foil the efforts of both.

Moreover, Chen said the prosecutors' offices under the Ministry of Justice is the only agency charged by law to rehabilitate convicted drug addicts, while the Department of Health, which is better equipped to deal with the situation, is not required by law to intercede.
To better organize the nation's efforts to combat illegal drugs, Chen advocated the establishment of an anti-drug agency to coordinate the government's operations.

The national anti-drug conference, which first met in 1984, is a forum aimed at pooling government resources to fight the use and distribution of illegal drugs. It is called alternately each year by the Ministry of Justice, the Department of Health and the Ministry of Education.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERNIGHT CRACKDOWN ON DRUNKEN DRIVING POURS NT$ 5 M. FOR TAIPEI CITY

TEXT.P: An overnight crackdown on drunken driving netted Taipei City NT$5 million (US$147,000) in fines, according to police statistics released Friday.
Police said that of the NT$5 million, more than NT$4.24 million was collected in accordance with new, harsher penalties for driving under the influence of alcohol, which came into effect Friday.
The new range of fines for drunken driving is NT$15,000 to NT$60,000, much more than the original NT$6,000 to NT$12,000.
Police wrote citations for 268 drunken driving cases from late Thursday night through early Friday morning. Forty-four drivers were so intoxicated that they were sent to detention centers.
Taipei City sent out 336 policemen who set up 103 check points around the city.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ECONOMY IS GOING AGAINST WORLD SLOWDOWN: VICE PM

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Lai In-jaw said Friday that Taiwan's economy is "going against the current of the global economic recession" and that the government is prepared to take measures to tackle the situation.

Under these circumstances, Taiwan will also face the tough issue of a sluggish economy given the fact that worldwide forecasts have showed that the annual global economic growth rate will not exceed 5 percent for 2001, Lai said.

Should the economies of the United States, the European Union and Japan, which account for three-fourths of the global economy, remain stagnant, it will be hard for the remaining one-fourth to "take off," he said.
The vice premier made the remarks in a key-note speech at the opening of a seminar held at Tamkang University.
According to Lai, the local economy has noticeably dropped as a result of several economic and non-economic factors.

Saying that long-standing difficulties in acquiring land, workers and loans for small businesses is hindering the economy, Lai said political woes are the major reason behind this circle of economic recession at home. He also said that society has paid a price for the disputes over the Fourth Nuclear Power Plant and the bi-weekly 84 work hour scheme.

As to the question of whether Taiwan will follow in Japan's footsteps -- experiencing a 10-year economic recession -- Lai was reserved but stressed that the current government led by President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Chang Chun-hsiung will do its best to rejuvenate the local economy.

Lai outlined four major directions set by the government in its efforts to address the economy: First, improve the local investment climate; second, reduce the unemployment rate; third, increase government spending on public investment projects; and fourth, upgrade administrative efficiency.

Saying that the state-run Taiwan Power Company will no longer be the only electricity supplier, the vice premier said the government has to provide sufficient electricity for all factories around the island. He noted that current power supply in Taiwan is sufficient, although demand in the north is mostly met by power sent from the south.
He said the government will encourage the private sector to set up power plants and promote a diversified energy policy to satisfy a growing demand for power.

While helping traditional businesses to diversify, Lai said the government is also determined to promote start-up industries in Taiwan, such as biotechnology, in the hope of creating broader economic horizons for the country.
Mirroring the view of Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, Lai said Taiwan businesses will be very successful as long as they choose the right product to develop.

Lai also pointed out that a sound financial environment is closely linked to the development of the economy of Taiwan. In addition to continuing to encourage bank mergers, he said that the government is expected to establish a NT$120 billion fund aimed at helping money-losing banking institutions consolidate.

Regarding the issue of how to lower the rising jobless rate, he said the government's NT$810 billion economic stimulus plan will help and that major investment plans will be handled in the future on a case-by-case basis by government agencies in charge.

In the face of these big challenges, the vice premier said that all the people of Taiwan need to work together with the government. Stressing that Taiwan's past economic progress was not made only by the government, Lai said he hoped that the government and the private sector would join forces to find ways to expand the economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIRECT PILGRIMAGE TRIP FROM TAIWAN TO MAINLAND VIA KINMEN DELAYED

TEXT.P: The first direct religious pilgrimage from Taiwan to Xiamen via Taiwan-controlled Kinmen, scheduled to depart Saturday, has been postponed for six days.
The "Kinmen Express" was originally scheduled to carry 370 pilgrims from Kaohsiung to Xiamen via Kinmen Saturday for a six-day trip. The pilgrims are from the Chupaokung Temple of Yunlin County.

This would be the first direct voyage for religious purposes from Taiwan to the mainland via Kinmen after the implementation of the "mini three links" between the offshore islands of Kinmen and Matsu and mainland China's coastal cities in early January.

A spokesman for the owner of the "Kinmen Express" said that the schedule was changed because they had been notified by Xiamen authorities that it would be "unlikely to complete the procedures in time."
After consultations, the spokesman said, the departure date has been tentatively rescheduled for June 8.

Under the new schedule, the "Kinmen Express" will reach Kinmen's Liaolo Harbor from Kaohsiung on the morning of June 6. All passengers are required to complete customs procedures in Kinmen before leaving for Xiamen.
After carrying pilgrims to Xiamen, the ship will return to Kinmen and then go to Xiamen to pick up the passengers June 13.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SCHOLAR GETS HONOR FROM UNIVERSITY OF PARIS
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, June 1 (CNA) (By Tzou Ming-zhie and Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Li Yih-yuan, president of the Chiang Ching-kuo Foundation for International Scholarly Exchange, was accorded an honorary doctorate by the University of Paris Wednesday for his contribution to the promotion of international academic exchanges.
Four other foreign scholars, including two Nobel Prize winners, were honored this year.
Li, 70, was unable to attend the doctorate-presentation ceremony because of health problems and was represented by his friend, Kuo Wei-fan.
A member of Academia Sinica, Li graduated from National Taiwan University and obtained his master of arts in anthropology from Harvard University.
He was cited for his outstanding contribution to the promotion of international studies on sinology and exchanges of cultures since he assumed presidency of the Chiang Ching-kuo foundation in 1989.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER MEETS MACEDONIAN LEADERS
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, June 1 (CNA) (By James Kuo and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China (ROC) Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao -- who had rushed to Skopje Thursday to try and shore up diplomatic ties -- scrambled to call on Macedonian leaders Friday.
Accompanied by ROC envoy to Skopje Peter Chen, Tien called on leaders of various Macedonian political parties but details of the meetings were not released.

Tien and Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Chiu Jung-nan arrived separately in Skopje Thursday amid reports that the Balkan state is moving to normalize ties with Beijing, thus severing relations with Taiwan.
Tien met Thursday with Macedonian Premier Ljubco Georgievski to exchange views on bilateral ties.
Georgievski presided over the opening of diplomatic ties between the two countries in 1999 and visited the island in June of that year.
Macedonia's Foreign Minister, Ilinka Mitreva, told a news conference Thursday that her country is on the way to switching diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.

The Macedonian Information Agency quoted Mitreva as saying Thursday that the normalization of relations with Beijing will involve Taiwan as well. The issue is to be discussed at the next Cabinet meeting.

Taipei diplomats have predicted that war-ravaged Macedonia is in no hurry to reestablish ties with Beijing and Taipei should be able to maintain the status quo at least until January when Macedonia holds its next general election.

Skopje forged diplomatic ties with Taipei in 1999 and became Taipei's second ally in Europe, aside from the Vatican. Taipei has promised to offer Macedonia US$300 million in aid, but this amount has not been fully transferred to the Balkan nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MINISTER TO ATTEND APEC TRADE MINISTERS MEETING IN SHANGHAI

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi said Friday that he will leave for Shanghai next Monday to attend the June 6-7 meeting of trade ministers of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.
The Chinese-Taipei delegation to the meeting will consist of 23 members, the largest ever for such a meeting from Taiwan.
Lin will fly to Hong Kong from Taipei and will proceed to Shanghai on the same day after a brief stopover in Hong Kong.

During the Shanghai meeting, Lin said that he will hold talks with his counterparts from 10 countries -- mainland China, the United States, Singapore, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, Mexico, Japan, Thailand and the Philippines.
He added that he will use his free time in Shanghai to inspect the development of the city.

Regarding the attempt by a mainland Chinese web site to embarrass the Taipei delegation by calling it "Chung Kuo Tai Pei" (China-Taipei) instead of the widely acknowledged "Chung Hua Tai Pei) (Chinese-Taipei), Lin said that his delegation will attend the meeting under the name "Chinese-Taipei" with its Chinese name represented as "Chung Hua Tai Pei."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN ASKS FOR CLOSER ROC-PARAGUAY BUSINESS TIES
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, June 1 (CNA) (By Chen You-cheng and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Visiting Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian advocated closer business ties between his country and Paraguay at a joint news conference with Paraguayan President Luis Gonzalez Macchi Friday.

Chen said Paraguay, as a member state of the Southern Common Market, is a vital gateway for Taiwan businessmen to the huge South American market. He said he will set up an inter-ministry committee to step up cooperation with Paraguay.
Moreover, Chen said Taiwan is also a gateway for Paraguay to enter the Southeast Asian market.
Chen reaffirmed his government's commitment to the cooperation agreement reached by the proceeding ROC government with Paraguay.

On Taiwan's relations with mainland China, Chen said that Taiwan has no intention to annex the mainland, and that if there were any zero-sum games between the two sides, Beijing should take the blame.
The Paraguayan president also said at the news conference that his country would be a good partner for Taiwan to develop the South American market.
The news conference capped Chen's three-day visit to Paraguay. He flew from Asuncion to Honduras after the news conference on the last leg of his five-nation visit to Central America.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL DIGNITY NOT TO BE COMPROMISED IN TIES WITH MACEDONIAN: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China said Friday that it will not compromise its national dignity while making efforts to save its fragile diplomatic relations with Macedonia.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs said in a press release that Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao is now in Skopje to meet Macedonian leaders in an attempt to persuade the Balkan state not to switch its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing. News reports have said that Skopje is on the verge of a diplomatic switch.
"We would like to stress, however, that it is in the national interest that we not try to maintain ties (with Macedonia) at the expense of our national dignity," the release said.

Tien, who cut short his Latin American diplomatic tour to fly to Macedonia Thursday in a last-ditch effort to rescue the ROC's diplomatic ties with its war-torn European ally, met with Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski and other political leaders, Chang Siao-yue, spokeswoman of the ministry said in a news conference held earlier in the day.

"Their meeting proceeded in a candid, friendly atmosphere," Chang said, adding that as the current Macedonian coalition government is composed of officials from seven different and mutually competing political parties, its political situation is very complicated and volatile.
Chang said Tien has traveled to Skopje to be updated on the latest situation in Macedonia.
ROC Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Chiu Jung-nan also flew from Taipei to Skopje Thursday to join Tien in shoring up the ROC's diplomatic ties.
Chang said both Tien and Chiu will do their utmost to communicate with Macedonian politicians and influential figures in various Macedonian social quarters.

Chang would not made any comments on reports that Macedonian Foreign Minister Ilinka Mitreva had told a group of reporters that her country is prepared to break off diplomatic ties with the ROC in an effort to restore diplomatic relations with mainland China.
The ROC and Macedonia forged diplomatic ties in 1999, making the Balkan state Taiwan's second diplomatic ally in Europe, aside from the Vatican.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, June 2, or the 11th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1868: Britain crushes the Marathas in India and annexes their lands.
1886: Grover Stephen Cleveland, the 22nd and 24th president of the United States, marries Francis Folsom in the White House. He was known as an honest independent president opposed to corruption and the "spoils" system.
1896: Italian engineer and inventor Guglielmo Marconi patents in London his wireless telegraph apparatus, a device that transmits spoken messages over long distances without the aid of wires or cables. He shared the 1909 Nobel Prize in physics after transmitting long-wave radio signals across the Atlantic Ocean in 1901.
1904: Johnny Weissmuller, American and Olympic swimming champion, is born. He later turned to acting, playing Tarzan in many films.
1922: Hsu Shih-chang resigns as president of the Beijing government.
1927: Wang Kuo-wei, a master in the study of Chinese literary classics, commits suicide at the age of 50 by jumping into Kunming Lake in the Yi-ho Garden in Beijing. The garden was built by Empress Dowager Tsu Hsi at the end of the Ching dynasty.
1942: Chinese Foreign Minister T.V. Soong and U.S. Secretary of State Cordell Hull sign the Sino-American Lend-Lease Agreement in Washington.
1953: The Archbishop of Canterbury at London's Westminster Abbey lowers the crown of St. Edward onto the head of Princess Elizabeth Alexandra Mary, making her Queen Elizabeth II of Great Britain and Northern Ireland. The ceremony marks the first televised coronation.
1964: The Palestine Liberation Organization is formed in Jerusalem.
1966: Malaysia and Indonesia agree to end five years of hostilities.
1966: Surveyor I, a U.S. automated spacecraft, lands in the southwest sector of the moon's Oceanus Procellanum and begins sending back the first close-up pictures of the moon's surface.
1969: The Australian aircraft carrier Melbourne collides with the U.S. destroyer Frank E. Evans in the South China Sea, killing 74 American sailors.
1973: A three-nation invitational basketball tournament opens in Taipei.
1974: China Airlines starts all-cargo services to the United States' West Coast.
1974: Jig Singhi Wangchuk, 18, is crowned king of Bhutan, becoming the youngest monarch in the world.
1976: Dr. Adnan Khasoggi, chairman of the Saudi Arabian Triad Holding Corporation, and a party of 20 members arrive in Taipei to explore investment possibilities.
1979: Pope John Paul II, the first non-Italian to be elected pope in 456 years, sets foot again on the soil of his native Poland to an emotional welcome. The pope's visit marks a major opening-up in the relationship between the Roman Catholic church and the countries of the Communist bloc.
1983: The ROC Executive Yuan approves a revision to raise by tenfold the compensation for "wrongful detentions and executions."
1984: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo appoints Chiu Chuang-huan, former vice premier, as commissioner of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly and, concurrently, as governor of Taiwan Province.
1985: English football clubs are banned indefinitely from playing in Europe because of hooliganism by English fans abroad.
1985: Hu Nai-yen, an ROC violinist residing in the United States, wins an international music contest held in Belgium.
1990: British actor Sir Rex Harrison dies at the age of 82. He is best remembered for his role as Professor Henry Higgins in the musical "My Fair Lady," a part that he played both on Broadway and on the London stage as well as in the 1964 film version, for which he won a Tony and also an Academy Award.
1992: Representatives from 185 nations take part in the world's largest environmental summit in Rio De Janeiro, Brazil.
1999: Women in Japan finally win the right to use the birth control pill.
2000: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh accepts President Chen Shui-bian's appointment to head a supra-party task force on cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
2000: Kaohsiung Mayor Hsieh Chang-ting is the sole candidate in the running for Democratic Progressive Party chairman, as the official registration deadline ends today.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Pleasure in dissipation, in extravagance, in mere conviviality, are injurious."

DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:
