DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT STARTS 2-DAY STATE VISIT TO HONDURAS
DOC.DATELINE: Tegucigalpa, Honduras, June 1 (CNA) (By Chen You-chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian flew to Honduras from Paraguay Friday for a two-day state visit aimed at further strengthening bilateral ties.

Honduras President Carlos Roberto Flores Facusse, accompanied by key Cabinet ministers, greeted Chen at a military airport outside Tegucigalpa, the nation's capital. The ROC head of state was welcomed with a trumpet fanfare, complete with a 21-gun salute and full military honors.

Flores said in his welcoming speech that ROC-Honduras relations are cordial and solid. "We believe President Chen's visit will further boost bilateral cooperation in various fields," he added. Flores also invited Chen to jointly review the Honduras military honor guard at the welcoming ceremony.
More than 100 overseas Chinese representatives also showed up at the airport to greet Chen and his entourage.

Later, ROC Ambassador Chang ching-yen briefed Chen on Honduras' general situation. Chang told the president that as public order is bad here, the ROC Embassy maintains close contact with Honduras police authorities to protect the safety of ROC expatriates in the Central American state.

In the evening, Chen paid a visit to Flores at the Presidential Office for wide-ranging talks. The two leaders exchanged decorations to signify the close relationship between the two countries. Flores also hosted a state banquet in honor of Chen and his entourage.

Chen will sign a joint communique and hold a joint press conference with Flores, as well as receiving an honorary doctoral degree from a noted Honduras university before ending his goodwill visit to Honduras Saturday.
Honduras is the last leg of Chen's current five-nation diplomatic journey to Latin America, which has already taken him to El Salvador, Guatemala, Panama and Paraguay.

Chen is scheduled to make an overnight transit stop in Houston, Texas on his way home. Rep. Thomas D. DeLay, also the Republican Party whip in the U.S. House of Representatives, will meet Chen during his stopover in Houston.
En route to Latin America, Chen also made a historic two-night transit stop in New York, making him the first incumbent ROC head of state to visit the Big Apple.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-BORN OFFICER TO SERVE AS U.S. PACIFIC COMMAND SPOKESWOMAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 1 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan-born American naval officer will become a spokeswoman for the U.S. Pacific Command from July, military sources said Friday.

Jensin W. Sommer, who was born in the southern Taiwan county of Yunlin and moved to the United States with her family at the age of seven, told CNA in an interview that she will be very pleased to take her new assignment in Hawaii next month.
"Hawaii is closer to Taiwan, where I still have many relatives," said Sommer, who is now a naval press officer at the U.S. Department of Defense.

Sommer, whose maiden name is Weng Jenhsin, graduated from the U.S. Naval Academy 10 years ago and was promoted to lieutenant commander Friday. She also received a master's degree in political science from a Catholic university in Washington, D.C. earlier this week.
Sommer's father, Weng Yi-hsiung, recalled that he and his wife often used to take their daughter to the U.S. Naval Academy in Maryland for pleasure trips on holidays during her childhood.

"Jensin was always impressed by the brilliance and smartness of the white uniforms of the female cadets. This might be a reason behind her decision to pursue a military career," said Weng, who works for the public health department of the Maryland State Government.

Weng originally took part in U.S. Navy-sponsored subtropical diseases research programs in Taiwan. In 1976, he came to the United States for advanced study on a U.S. Navy scholarship and later obtained U.S. residency.

Sommer described herself as lucky to have been able to grow up in the United States, adding that she chose a military career partly out of her wish to contribute to the country. Her husband is also a Navy Academy graduate.
She further said she has fond memories of her childhood in Taiwan and that part of her mind and heart "will be left in Taiwan" forever.
Sommer said she is always very happy whenever she reads or hears of information about Taiwan. "I also take pride in Taiwan's progress in various fields in recent years," she added.

In the future, she said she hopes she can do something to help boost Taiwan-U.S. relations. She last visited her Taiwan relatives in 1994. During her studies at the U.S. Naval Academy, she and several of her classmates also once visited Taiwan under the arrangement of Taiwan's naval authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IMMIGRANT MURDERED IN CANADA, TWO CHARGED

TEXT.P: Canadian police have charged two young men with kidnapping, extortion and first-degree murder of Thomas Ku, a Taiwan immigrant who disappeared two weeks ago near his home in Mississauga, Ontario.
The 48-year-old businessman was reported missing after he vanished May 15 on his way home from work.
Toronto residents Zhiyang Suo, 19, and 20-year-old Feng Wang are each charged with first-degree murder, kidnapping, forcible confinement, robbery and extortion.
The family received several phone calls over the course of the next few days demanding ransom money in exchange for Ku's return, but no money was ever paid, police said Friday.
Investigators traveled Thursday to a wooded area near Peterborough, Ont., where they located the body of a male believed to be that of Ku, police said in a press release.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE WAR GAMES `NOT UNUSUAL': U.S. STATE DEPARTMENT

TEXT.P: The United States government said Friday that war games currently being conducted by the People's Liberation Army (PLA) opposite Taiwan are "not unusual," but added that it will continue to monitor the situation in the Taiwan Strait very closely.

"Really the only aspect of these reports (about the exercises) that's noticeably different from the past is, in fact, the publication in China's state-controlled press of the details of the exercises, including location and the objectives and the equipment to be used," said State Department spokesman Richard Boucher.
He refused to speculate on the motives of Beijing's public announcement of the exercises, codenamed "Liberation One."

Mainland Chinese state media said earlier Friday that the large-scale war games, which include a mock invasion of an island near Taiwan, are a warning not to underestimate Beijing's determination to use force to prevent Taiwan from declaring independence.
In a press release, the U.S. Department of Defense also said the United States will continue to watch the situation very closely.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO CARRY OUT EXISTING ACCORDS WITH PARAGUAY: ROC PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, June 1 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Visiting Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that the ROC government will continue any agreement with Paraguay and will form an inter-ministry committee to push for trade with the Southern Common Market.
Chen made the remarks at a joint press conference with Paraguay President Luis Angel Gonzalez Macchi.

Chen said that any agreement signed during former ROC President Lee Teng-hui's visit to Paraguay, including helping with the construction of the second cross-Paraguay River bridge and forming an industrial zone in Paraguay, will be carried out by his administration.

An ROC Export Processing Zone Administration (EPZA) delegation, led by head Chou Yen, is currently in Paraguay to exchange views with the Paraguayan government on the establishment and management of an industrial zone there.

Chen said the ROC should take active measures, including setting up an inter-ministry committee, to help Paraguay develop its economy and make it a doorway through which the ROC can gain access to the Southern Common Market.

Earlier, Gonzalez conferred a National Merit Order of Marshall Francisco Solano Lopez in Chain Grade, Paraguay's highest civic honor, on Chen. Before the conferring ceremony, the two heads of state signed a joint communique stressing the strengthening of cooperation and exchanges between the two countries.

Speaking at the ceremony, Gonzalez praised Chen for his efforts to strengthen the friendly relations between the peoples of the two countries, saying the notion of the "all people's government" advocated by Chen has surpassed the ROC's boundaries and has reached Paraguay.

Gonzalez also lauded Chen for his achievements in human rights, as well as the promotion of democracy and freedom of speech in the ROC. He expressed confidence that the two countries will continue to join hands to create a more prosperous future.

Chen for his part noted that he last visited Paraguay five years ago when he was the mayor of Taipei City, and added that he was much impressed by the enthusiasm of the people as well as the abundant natural resources of the South American country.
He added that during his most recent visit, he gained a great deal from talks with Gonzalez on matters of mutual concern.

Chen stressed that since Paraguay and the ROC established diplomatic ties in 1957, the two countries have maintained a close and friendly relationship. He said both the two countries have proceeded with political reform, implemented constitutional democracy and have won acclaim from the international community.
Chen wound up his visit to Paraguay and flew to Honduras later that day to continue his five-nation Latin American trip. Honduras is the last leg of his tour.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND MUM ON REPORTS OF U.S. AIRCRAFT CARRIER EN ROUTE TO TAIWAN STRAIT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) declined to comment Saturday on reports that the U.S. aircraft carrier Carl Vinson is sailing toward the Taiwan Strait as mainland China is conducting war games opposite Taiwan.

According to a local cable TV station, the USS Carl Vinson was about 350 nautical miles from Taiwan as of press time, although the vessel's official website placed it just off the coast of Southern California and under way for the Western Pacific. The report quoted unidentified U.S. sources as saying that the aircraft carrier is on a routine training mission.

Despite all evidence to the contrary, however, the TV station speculated that the battleship's voyage "toward the Taiwan Strait" might be related to mainland China's current large-scale exercises on its offshore Dongshan Island near Taiwan.

Responding to the report, MND officials said they have no knowledge about the USS Carl Vinson's current activities. They stressed only that the MND has been keeping tabs on mainland China's military activities and will continue to monitor the situation very closely.
An MND official further said it is the ministry's established policy to refrain from commenting on U.S. warships' activities on the high seas.
Meanwhile, the U.S. State Department said Friday that the war games currently being conducted by the People's Liberation Army (PLA) opposite Taiwan are "not unusual."

"Really the only aspect of these reports (about the exercises) that's noticeably different from the past is, in fact, the publication in China's state-controlled press of the details of the exercises, including location and the objectives and the equipment to be used," said State Department spokesman Richard Boucher.
He refused to speculate on the motives of Beijing's public announcement of the exercises, codenamed "Liberation One."

Mainland Chinese state media said earlier Friday that the large-scale war games, which include a mock invasion of Dongshan Island near Taiwan, are a warning not to underestimate Beijing's determination to use force to prevent Taiwan from declaring independence.
In a press release, the U.S. Department of Defense also said Friday that the United States will continue to watch the Taiwan Strait situation very closely.

DOC.HEADLINE: STATE OF NEVADA SUPPORTS ROC'S WHO MEMBERSHIP
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 1 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Senate and the Assembly of the state of Nevada adopted unanimously Thursday resolutions that support the Republic of China's bid for membership of the World Health Organization (WHO).
The resolutions affirm the ROC's progress in medical and health care and say that if the ROC were given WHO membership, it would definitely contribute to the global medical and health care system.
Victor Tseng, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in San Francisco, went to the Nevada state capital of Carson City Thursday to extend gratitude on behalf of the ROC government.

Tseng noted that although diplomatic affairs fall under the jurisdiction of the U.S. federal government and resolution of a state legislature does not have binding force in the federal government, the Nevada legislature's action indicates that the ROC's appeals to join the international community have gained support not only from Washington, but also from the U.S. grassroots level.
Besides Nevada, the Senate and the Assembly of the state of Utah also adopted resolutions earlier this year to support the ROC's bid to join the WHO.

DOC.HEADLINE: ABORIGINAL ARTIFACTS COLLECTED BY PIONEERING DOCTOR GO ON DISPLAY

TEXT.P: An exhibition of a collection of Taiwanese aboriginal artifacts collected by Canadian missionary doctor George Leslie Mackay more than a century ago opened in Taipei Saturday.
The rare exhibit sheds light on the life and culture of Taiwan's indigenous people before the entry of foreign cultures, organizers said.
Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui cut the ribbon to open the show at Shunyi Taiwan Aborigines Museum at Waishuanghsi in suburban Taipei.

Lee lauded Mackay for his dedicated services to Taiwan. "He helped sow the seeds of Western education and modern civilization in Taiwan. His contributions won him the Taiwan people's eternal respect and remembrance," the former president said.

Lee further said he is very pleased to see the exhibition of Mackay's collection of Taiwanese aboriginal artifacts, which offer local people a rare glimpse into the cultural achievements of the island's indigenous people more than a century ago.

Also present at the opening ceremony were Isqaqavut Yohani, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Aboriginal Affairs, some of Mackay's offspring and officials of the Canadian representative office in Taipei.

On display are 202 aboriginal artifacts, including costume accessories, headdresses used in wedding ceremonies, badges, utensils, belts, weapons, musical instruments, animal fossils and other articles.
Only 10 of the exhibits are provided by domestic cultural groups and all the other 192 items are on loan from the Royal Ontario Museum of Canada.
The exhibits from the Canadian museum were brought to Canada by Mackay in 1893 when he made a visit to his homeland, organizers said.

The exhibition is one of a series of activities marking the 100th anniversary of Mackay's death in Taiwan on June 2, 1901. Mackay came to Taiwan in 1872 at the age of 28 as a missionary for the Canadian Presbyterian Church.

Mackay preached, educated and provided medical services to the people of Taiwan until his death at the age of 57. His grave is located at Oxford Village in Tamsui, a scenic coastal town on the outskirts of Taipei. Mackay married a Taiwan woman with whom he had three children and their offspring now live in Canada, the United States and Taiwan.
On Friday, the Republic of China's Directorate General of Post issued a set of memorial stamps in commemoration of the Canadian missionary doctor.

DOC.HEADLINE: 37 PERCENT OF TAIWAN POPULATION ARE INTERNET USERS

TEXT.P: A survey conducted by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications in March indicates that 37.5 percent of the population in Taiwan are Internet users.

According to the results of the survey, which were only released Saturday, 8.34 million people, or 37.5 percent of the population, said they had used the Internet, up from the 20.1 percent recorded in a similar survey conducted in January 1999.
Of the 8.34 million Internet users, 7.21 million said they had used the Internet in the past month, while 1.13 million others said they had not.

Seventy-seven percent of the respondents said they used the Internet at home the most, followed by 35 percent who said they access the Internet from schools or research institutes and 30 percent who said they use their company office.
About 13 percent said they use Internet cafes, up 9.2 percent over the January 1999 level.
In Taipei City, 56.4 percent of the citizens are Internet users, followed by Kaohsiung City with 41.8 percent, according to the survey results.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TRANSPORT MINISTER TO ATTEND ROC-SWEDEN ECONOMIC MEETING

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Transportation and Communications Yeh Chu-lan is scheduled to leave for Denmark, Sweden and France Monday to attend a series of meetings.

In Denmark on Tuesday, Yeh will visit the electronic toll system of Copenhagen's freeway and then proceed to Sweden, where she will call on Swedish Vice Transportation Minister Lars Rekke on Wednesday and take a high-speed train to a science-based park Thursday.
The 17th ROC-Sweden Economic Cooperation Meeting will open June 8 in Stockholm and Yeh is scheduled to give a speech titled "Taiwan's Telecommunication Policy in the New Century."
She will visit the world famous cellular phone maker Ericsson after the meeting.
The 14th International Road Federation Meeting is slated to be held in Paris from June 11 through June 15.
Yeh plans to visit the Paris metro and the French railway headquarters, as well as tour the headquarters of France's Airbus company after the meeting and is scheduled to return to Taipei June 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT EXPRESSES APPRECIATION FOR HONDURAS' SUPPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Tegucigalpa, Honduras, June 1 (CNA) (By Chen You-chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Visiting Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that the ROC government and people appreciate Honduras' longtime support for Taiwan's bid to upgrade its international profile.
"We are grateful for your support for our national cause in the international arena," Chen said after receiving a decoration from Honduran President Carlos Roberto Flores Facusse.

In a ceremony held at the Honduran Presidential Office, Flores decorated Chen with the Order of Francisco Morazon in the rank of Great Cross in recognition of his contribution to promoting relations between the two countries.
In return, Chen conferred the Order of Brilliant Jade with Grand Cordon on Flores. It is the highest honor the ROC government can present to a foreign head of state.

Chen, who took office in Taiwan's first-ever democratic transfer of power between different political parties last May, noted that both the ROC and Honduras have transformed from authoritarian rule to democracy.

"Honduras began its political democratization 20 years and its major political parties have since taken turns in ruling the country," Chen noted, adding that Taiwan has something to learn from Honduras in this regard as "party rotation" in government is still in its early stages in Taiwan.

Chen further said that he and Flores have many things in common, including their age and legislative experience. Noting that Flores enjoys an approval rating of about 80 percent, Chen said he will take advantage of his current visit to learn from Flores' political achievements.
After the decoration ceremony, Flores hosted a state banquet in honor of Chen and his entourage, to which were invited government officials, lawmakers and business executives.
Chen arrived in Honduras Friday on the last leg of a five-nation diplomatic journey to Latin America that had already taken him to El Salvador, Guatemala, Panama and Paraguay.

He is scheduled to make an overnight transit stop in Houston, Texas on his way home. Rep. Thomas D. DeLay, also the Republican Party whip in the U.S. House of Representatives, will meet Chen during his stopover in Houston.
En route to Latin America, Chen also made a historic two-night transit stop in New York, making him the first incumbent ROC head of state to visit the Big Apple.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN ARRIVES IN HOUSTON ON WAY BACK TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian arrived in Houston Saturday night for a transit stop on his way back to Taiwan.
Chen and his wife were greeted at the airport by Richard Bush, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan, and Chen Chien-jen, Taiwan's representative to the United States.

More than 1,000 Taiwanese living in the southern United States gathered outside the Double Tree hotel where Chen and his entourage was staying to welcome the first ROC president ever to visit Houston. They waved ROC flags and chanted "Long live Taiwan," and "Taiwan, yes, China, no."
Chen waved back to the well-wishers and blew kisses to them for at least 10 minutes.
Meanwhile, a small group of pro-Beijing Chinese protested against Taiwan's separation from mainland China on the other side of the road leading to the hotel.

Chen will meet with Texas members of the House of Representatives Thomas Delay, Solomon Ortiz, Gene Green, Kevin Brady, and Sheila Jackson-Lee as well as his supporters from the local Taiwanese community during his one-day stopover in Houston.
The president and his entourage will eat at a Texas-style steak house called Taste of Texas on Sunday and watch a Major League Baseball game in the afternoon.

Chen and his wife will host a dinner Sunday evening at his hotel for their entourage and the crew of the EVA Airways plane which has taken him on his five-nation trip. Chen will leave for Taiwan at 11:45 p.m. Houston time.
Chen and his entourage flew into Houston from Tegucigalpa, Honduras which was the last stop of his 12-day trip to Latin America.

At a news conference at Tegucigalpa before his departure from Honduras Saturday, Chen said his government is working for the best but prepared for the worst regarding the ROC's relationship with Macedonia. The Balkan nation is reportedly preparing to switch its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.

Saying that Taipei-Skopje ties have been "bumpy" from the very beginning and "never smooth" ever since, Chen said Taipei will make a last-ditch effort to keep its diplomatic ties with Macedonia but will not do so if the dignity of the nation is compromised in the process.

Chen said he has been kept informed of the latest developments by Minster of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao. Tien left Chen's entourage in Panama to fly to Skopje on May 30 to meet Macedonian leaders in an attempt to steady ties with Macedonia.

As to the island's ties with Panama, Chen said Panamanian President Mireya Elisa Moscoso Rodriguez assured him of her country's firm support for the ROC during their meeting on May 29 in Panama City despite reports that Panama might be persuaded by China to switch diplomatic recognition to Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN MEETS WITH US CONGRESSMAN IN HOUSTON

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian met with U.S. Representative Solomon Ortiz, a Democrat from Texas, in Houston Saturday night.
Ortiz called on Chen at Chen's hotel shortly after the ROC president arrived in Houston from Tegucigalpa, Honduras after a five-nation trip to Latin American.
Ortiz said after the 15-minute meeting that he wanted to see Chen to extend his personal respect for the president.

He lauded Chen's aggressiveness in getting things done, saying that he is confident that Chen is capable of solving the long-standing disputes between Taipei and Beijing and forming "a great Chinese community" in spite of the difficulties involved.
Noting Taiwan's generous aid to Central American states, the U.S. congressman said Washington should follow Taipei's example, or cooperate with Taiwan to help states in that region.
Ortiz is one of at least five U.S. congressmen expected to call on Chen during Chen's one-day stopover in Houston on his way back to Taiwan.
Chen also met Saturday night with his Taiwanese-American supporters who gathering outside the hotel to cheer on the first ROC president ever to visit Houston.
Chen was quoted as encouraging his supporters "to join him in fighting for the ROC in his remaining three years in office."
Although Chen was granted a visa by Washington to stop in the United States on his way to and from Central America, he is not supposed to engage in public events, including news conferences.
Chen will leave Houston for Taipei later Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'RUNNING GRANDPA' TO CHALLENGE TAIPEI MAYOR AGAIN
DOC.DATELINE: Houston, June 3 (CNA) (By Maubo Chang) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Taipei, June 3 (CNA): An 85-year-old man, dubbed the "running grandpa," said that he will again challenge Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou after he lost to Ma in the Coca-Cola 2001 International Olympic Day Run held in Taipei Sunday.

Peng Hung-nien, who has won many races both at home and abroad, said jokingly to Ma before the run that "you will not beat me today." Ma replied: "If I don't beat you by at least 10 minutes, I'll consider myself the loser."
Peng finished the 10 kilometer run in 1 hour 20 minutes -- 28 minutes, 48 seconds behind the mayor.

Ma completed the running in 51 minutes, 14 seconds. He said, however, that he had been swimming recently and was out of practice for long-distance runs. He said he should be able to run 10 kilometers in around 41 minutes.
Peng said that he had had a cold and that he would be ready to take on the mayor at the next city-organized race.
More than 2,400 runners took part in the race, organized by the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee (CTOC) and the Taipei City Government and under the sponsorship of Swire Coca Cola Taiwan Ltd.
Participants gathered in the plaza in front of the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in downtown Taipei at 6 a.m. and Ma and Peng shook hands before starting the run.
Participants ran along Chungshan South Road, Jenai Road, Kuangfu South Road, Hsinyi Road, Hangchou S. Road and Aikuo East Road to return to the CKS Memorial Hall.
Running in the event was a set of triplets and 16 sightless runners.
CTOC Chairman Huang Ta-chou, Chi Cheng, bronze medal winner in the 80-meter low hurdles at the 1968 Mexico Olympics, and Ma led participants in warm-up exercises before the run.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER TO GO TO SHANGHAI FOR APEC MINISTERIAL MEETING

TEXT.P: June will be a busy month for exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, with Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi and two other officials visiting the mainland.
Lin will travel to Shanghai via Hong Kong Monday for the meeting of trade ministers at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum scheduled for June 6-7.
Lin will hold talks with Shi Guangsheng, mainland China's minister of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation, and eight other APEC members Tuesday.

Lin said that his meetings with Shi will be related to subjects relevant to APEC. He said that whether or not he will ask for the mainland to sign an investment guarantee agreement will depend on the situation at the time.

Before serving as economics minister, Lin traveled to the mainland several times. He said he would use the sidelines of the APEC meeting to tour city construction projects in Shanghai and would also take the chance to meet with Taiwan businessmen there.
Meanwhile, Lin Wen-yuan, vice chairman of the Commission of National Cooperation, is scheduled to visit the mainland in the first half of June.

Accompanied by Taiwan Sugar Corp. chairman Chien Bin-tsai and other officials of the company, Lin Wen-yuan will travel to Beijing, Qingtao and Hangzhou to inspect the investment environment for commercial flower growing operation. Taisugar is famous for its commercial flower growing business.
Lin Wen-yuan will be the first high-ranking official from the Commission of National Cooperation to visit the mainland.
Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) Vice President Hsieh Jung-hui also left for Beijing Sunday. He will meet with executives of the China National Offshore Oil Corp. and other national companies.
Hsieh is also expected to discuss business cooperation, seek overseas markets for CPC's diesel oil and inspect sites to establish distribution centers in the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S MILITARY DRILLS CONTAIN GREATER POLITICAL MEANING: SCHOLARS

TEXT.P: Mainland China's military drills on Dongshan Island off its southeastern coast, opposite Taiwan, carry more political meaning than military importance, local scholars said Sunday at a seminar.

Chen Yu-chu, a professor of international relations at Chinese Culture University, said mainland China usually holds military exercises under three circumstances. First, to demonstrate its determination to cope with a crisis; second, to show its dissatisfaction toward a certain issue; and third, to conduct routine military exercises.
Chen said mainland China's ongoing military drills on Dongshan Island, code-named "Liberation One," are not simply regular military drills, instead, they are more of a declaration of policy.
According to Chen, the "Liberation One" code-name was only used by mainland China in the 1950s-1960s, and did not even appear during the years when former President Lee Teng-hui was in office.
Judging from the timing and scale of the drills, Chen said the military movements represent a conclusion by Beijing toward President Chen Shui-bian following one year of observation.

When President Chen was inaugurated as the ROC's 10th president May 20 last year and announced his "five noes" in his inaugural address to show his goodwill to mainland China, the Beijing leadership responded by saying that it would "listen to Chen's words and watch his deeds" to see if Chen, a long-time supporter of the pro-Taiwan independence movement, would be true to his words.

Professor Chen further predicted that mainland China will not make any major moves against Taiwan until the island's legislative elections slated for December, but pointed out that Beijing will not remain silent or do nothing. He said he is pessimistic about the future of Taiwan-mainland ties.
Echoing Chen's view, Yang Kai-huang, a professor of political science at Soochow University, said that Beijing has set a "final tone" toward President Chen.
Yang said the timing of mainland China's "Liberation One" military drills carry a high degree of political meaning and that Beijing is also exaggerating the importance of the drills.
In essence, Yang said the current Dongshan military drills contain a greater political meaning than military significance.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AND MAINLAND CHINA MAY COOPERATE IN OIL AND GAS INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: Cross-strait cooperation may improve in the oil and gas industry as mainland China's state-run oil companies have asked Taiwan's state-owned oil company for technological support for a natural gas storage station to be built in Shenzhen.

According to sources from Taiwan's state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC), the company's vice president, Hsieh Jung-hui, is heading for Beijing to meet with CEOs of China National Petroleum Corp. (CNPC), China National Offshore Oil Corp. (CNOOC) and China Petrochemical Corp. to discuss the details of cooperation.

The CNOOC is planing to cooperate with British Petroleum to construct a natural gas storage station in Shenzhen, in mainland China's southeastern Guangdong province, to supply the energy needs of the Guangdong area and Shenzhen's industrial zones.
Considering the CPC's rich experience in building natural gas receiving and storage stations, the CNOOC has asked the CPC for personnel support and technological advice.

Hsieh said the fact that both sides of the Strait speak the same language would help make cooperation easier, but said that any agreements would be subject to approval by the ROC Ministry of Economic Affairs.

Besides the natural gas sector, both sides of the Taiwan Strait may study the possibility of further cooperation in the oil and gas industry, including oil trading and setting up oil storage and distribution centers in mainland China.

The two sides have already tried cross-strait trade on a small scale. The CPC attempted to sell diesel fuel to mainland China on a trial basis via some Hong Kong trading companies, but with limited success because of the many obstacles the CPC had to try to overcome.

As mainland China urgently needs diesel fuel, especially in the industrially advanced eastern and southern areas, the CNPC and China Petrochemical Corp. have been trying to source oil supplies from outside China.
Considering the huge diesel fuel market in mainland China, Singapore, South Korea and Taiwan's private oil company, the Formosa Group, are actively acting to get a piece of the oil supply contracts.
Taiwan's CPC says that mainland China has shown an interest in working with them, according to CPC sources.

After recently attending an Asian petrochemical conference held in Taiwan, the CNPC's vice president and China Petrochemical's chairman visited the CPC and had a meeting with Pan Wen-yen, the CPC's president.

After Taiwan opened the local market to private oil companies, diesel fuel production by the CPC and the Formosa Group has exceeded demand in the Taiwan market. The companies have had to export some 400 million kiloliters of diesel oil annually to other countries.

Commenting on the possibility of cross-strait cooperation in the oil and gas industry, Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi said it is natural that Taiwan oil companies would seek overseas markets since their production is now outpacing local demand.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S Q1 EXPORTS TO US POST NEGATIVE GROWTH
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, June 3 (CNA) (By Elisa Kao) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Taipei, June 3 (CNA): Taiwan's exports to the United States posted a 3.25 percent negative growth in the first quarter compared with a year ago, the Ministry of Economic Affairs' Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said Sunday.

During the same period, mainland China led the four "Asian little tigers" in terms of export growth to the United States with a growth of 12.28 percent, followed by South Korea with 6.1 percent, and Singapore at negative 2.84 percent. But Taiwan's export performance was better than Hong Kong which posted a 9.54 percent negative growth rate.

Officials at the BOFT said that Taiwan products accounted for only 2.97 percent of the U.S. market during the same period, a decrease of 0.25 percent from the previous year, compared to mainland's share of 7.57 percent, South Korea's 3.19 percent, Singapore's 1.41 percent and Hong Kong's 0.8 percent, respectively.

The BOFT officials attributed the shrinking Taiwan exports to the United States to the declining exports of machine tools, plastic products and steel and iron products, Taiwan's main export items to the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN'S NEW 'FIVE NOES' NOT CREATIVE ENOUGH: SCHOLARS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's latest pronouncement on cross-strait relations is not creative enough to break through the cross-strait stalemate, scholars said Sunday.
The scholars made the remarks at a seminar on the effect of Chen's new "five noes" policy on cross-strait relations. The seminar was sponsored by the Cross-strait Cultural Exchange Association.

The president announced the policy while visiting Guatemala during his five-nation Latin American trip last week. The policy refers to no provocation, no misjudgment, no pawn of any other countries, no zero-sum game and no stop to efforts at improving cross-strait ties.

Professor Kuo Chan-li of National Taiwan Ocean University said the new "five noes" is a pragmatic and expedient pronouncement in the new changing landscape of triangular relations among Taipei, Washington and Beijing.
Kuo said the president extended his goodwill and maintained the dignity of the nation when he pronounced the "five noes." But Kuo said that the idea still lacks vision and creativity.

Kuo noted that the domestic economic slump, the exodus of businesses and capital from Taiwan, the weak stock market, rising unemployment, and diplomatic setbacks may all be related to unstable cross-strait relations.

Assistant professor Liang Chung-ming of Fu Jen University said that the new "five noes" are in line with the Chen administration's policy, but that the announcement only gives it a new interpretation.

Liang said the new definition from the U.S. administration of George W. Bush that sees China as a "strategic competitor" rather than a "strategic partner" is also a reason behind Taiwan's promotion of its new "five noes" policy.

Professor Pan Hsi-tang of Tamkang University said that Chen's policy aims to break the cross-strait stalemate, makes clear the new administration's stance of no provocation and solicits the support of the international community to counter Beijing's efforts to stifle Taiwan diplomatically.

Pan noted that when the president first unveiled the "five noes" in his inaugural speech last year, Beijing was not satisfied, but neither could it find any excuse to use the statement against Taiwan.
If one year later, the president is still sticking to his stance of "not doing anything," Pan said, it is not a creative way to improve cross-strait relations.

The original "five noes" were: no declaration of Taiwan independence if Beijing renounced the use of force, no change of the name of the Republic of China, no introduction of "state-to-state relationship" theory into the Constitution, no referendum on the issue of independence (of Taiwan) versus unification (with China), and no abrogation of the National Unification Guidelines.
Pan suggested that to break the cross-strait stalemate, the president will have to address Beijing's cherished "one China" principle squarely even if he doesn't like it.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND AFFAIRS EXPERT URGES BEIJING TO OPEN UP FURTHER

TEXT.P: The current Beijing leadership should allow greater democracy in mainland China to help create a promising future for its people and build positive relations with Taiwan, an expert on mainland affairs said Sunday.

Chang Jung-kung, director of the Kuomintang's Mainland Affairs Department, said that the 1989 crackdown on the unarmed pro-democracy students in Beijing's Tiananmen Square was a major factor which has driven the Chinese communists toward a more open society.
Chang made the remarks at a seminar organized by several foundations to mark the 12th anniversary of the 1989 Tiananmen crackdown.

The veteran mainland China affairs expert called on the present Beijing leadership to outperform their predecessors by "first making some people democratic and rich." Should current Beijing leaders move toward that direction, it would produce a very significant meaning for mainland Chinese people and in cross-strait ties, Chang added.

According to Chang, Taiwan should use democracy to improve mainland China. While Taiwan is seeking to become the standard of democracy for the entire Chinese people, the island also needs to make greater progress in social stability and economic development to underline the values of democracy, he said.

Since mainland Chinese leaders are proud of having achieved noticeable economic progress in coastal provinces, they should also be confident of promoting democracy elsewhere on the mainland, he said, adding that mainland China is still behind Taiwan in establishing a democratic system.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSPORTATION AND COMMUNICATIONS MINISTER TO VISIT SWEDEN, FRANCE

TEXT.P: Minister of Transportation and Communications Yeh Chu-lan will leave for Stockholm, Sweden, Monday for an economic meeting.
Yeh is expected to speak on Taiwan's telecommunications policy in the new era at the 17th ROC-Sweden economic cooperation meeting on June 8.
Yeh will later attend a meeting of the International Road Federation in France during which she will have a chance to meet with her counterparts in France and other countries.
Transportation officials said that the meetings are being arranged, but would not reveal other details.
Yeh is also expected to inspect the electronic tolling system on freeways in Sweden and France before returning home June 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: MESSENGER TO BEIJING A FICTITIOUS STORY: TOP PRESIDENTIAL AIDE

TEXT.P: Secretary-General of the Presidential Office Yu Shyi-kun on Sunday accused an opposition lawmaker of "inflating his significance" by claiming to be an emissary of President Chen Shui-bian to Beijing.

Yu was referring to Legislator Elmer Fung of the New Party, who alleged that he was asked several times by Chen Che-nan, the deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, to convey the president's goodwill to Beijing leaders.

In a news conference held earlier in the day, Fung blamed President Chen for reneging on his promises to pursue Taiwan's eventual reunificiation with mainland China to the detriment of ties with Beijing.

At the news conference, Fung played a tape he said contained conversations between him and Chen Che-nan to support his claim that he was asked by President Chen, through Chen Che-nan, to convey the president's goodwill.
Fung said he was asked to tell Beijing leaders that President Chen meant "reunification" when he vowed to pursue a frame of "political integration" in his new year message.

The pro-reunification lawmaker also claimed that Chen Che-nan told him that President Chen's administration will open direct trade and transportation links with mainland China as soon as the "controversy of the Fourth Nuclear Power Plant is sorted out."
Fung said the president pulled the rug from under his feet by reneging on his promises after Fung relayed the messages to Beijing as the president had asked.

Fung said the president disappointed him and the Beijing leaders afterward by telling a conference of the World Federation of Taiwanese Associations that the "integration" is an extention of former President Lee Teng-hui's advocacy of "a special state-to-state" relationship between Taiwan and mainland China.

Fung, a diehard opponent of Taiwan independence, caused an outcry in Taiwan's political circles Friday by claiming that he was asked on 12 occasions by Chen Che-nan to convey messages to Beijing for the president.

Instead of being a secret emissary as he has been called by the local press, Fung said Sunday that he should be called a messenger who has done his utmost to faithfully relay messages for the president even though the president meant only 1 percent of what he said.

Chen Che-nan said Fung was trying to increase the significance of his trip to mainland China by claiming to be the president's emissary. He did say in a statement Sunday that he had met Fung many times in Fung's office at Fung's request.

As a president's aide in charge of communicating with lawmakers, Chen Che-nan said it is only natural for him to encourage any effort by anyone to improve the island's ties with Beijing, but he said he never authorized Fung on the president's behalf to talk to Beijing as an envoy.
He said he didn't know where Fung's tape came from but stopped short of denying its authenticity.
Yu, Chen Che-nan's immediate superior, supported him by saying that Chen was set up.
He blamed Fung for engineered the whole event in a futile attempt to flout his own importance.
Instead of backing down from promises to open direct trade links with mainland China, Yu said the government is moving in this direction.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, June 4, or the 13th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1738: King George III of Great Britain is born. His mishandling of the American colonies fed American discontent, leading to the American Revolution in 1776.
1831: Prince Leopold, of the House of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha, becomes the first king of Belgium, although King William II of the Netherlands refuses to acknowledge Belgian independence.
1928: Chang Tso-lin, leader of the Fengtien army in China's northeast (Manchuria), is killed by a bomb on a train at Wangkutun near Mukden (Shenyang). His son, Chang Hsueh-liang, succeeds him as the ruler of Manchuria.
1940: A flotilla of naval and civilian craft complete the safe evacuation of some 335,000 out of a total of 400,000 Allied troops from the French coastal town of Dunkirk after the might of the German army swept northward through France.
1944: Rome is liberated by the Allies with U.S. Gen. Mark Clark leading the way into the city.
1954: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek appoints Yen Chia-kan governor of Taiwan.
1956: Egypt refuses to extend the Suez Canal Company's concession after its expiration in 1959, leading to the Suez Crisis.
1959: Charles de Gaulle stuns French colonists in Algeria by telling them they must integrate with the Muslim Algerians if they wish to stay.
1965: The ROC joins a provisional committee on communications satellites.
1970: Dr. Chien Shih-liang becomes president of the ROC's Academia Sinica.
1970: Tonga, a British protectorate, becomes independent.
1973: A Tupolev 144, the Russian supersonic airliner built on the lines of the Concorde, crashes at the Paris Air Show, killing six crew and 27 onlookers.
1982: U.S. Senator Barry Goldwater restates in Taipei that the United States government has no intention of amending the Taiwan Relations Act.
1987: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo appoints Cheyne J.Y. Chiu as the new ambassador to Swaziland.
1987: The ROC Executive Yuan passes a revision of the Law of Negotiable Instruments. The revision is submitted to the Legislative Yuan for approval.
1989: A massive gas explosion wrecks two crowded passenger trains about 1,190 km east of Moscow, killing over 460 people.
1989: The first partially free parliamentary elections in Poland in nearly 50 years end the communist rule imposed by Moscow.
1989: According to an estimate by the International Red Cross, more than 3,000 people are killed as soldiers open fire on student demonstrators in Beijing's Tienanmen Square.
1989: ROC President Lee Teng-hui issues a statement condemning the Tienanmen Massacre.
1990: President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea meets with Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev in Washington.
1991: The communist government in Albania under Fatos Nano resigns after a 20-day general strike.
1994: Five Iraqis and a Kuwaiti are sentenced to death in Kuwait for plotting to kill former U.S. President George Bush with a car bomb while Bush was visiting Kuwait in April 1993.
1999: The Basic Education Law passes three readings at the Legislative Yuan, paving the way for the Ministry of Education to implement a 12-year system of compulsory education for ROC nationals.
2000: An ROC Navy goodwill flotilla reaches the Marshall Islands after sailing 2,220 nautical miles.
2000: "Hello Taipei! Taipei Residents & Migrant Workers," the first carnival for foreign workers, is held in the plaza in front of Taipei Railway Station.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are three things which a man should beware of in the three stages of his life. In youth, when the constitution of his body is not yet formed, he should beware of lust. In manhood, when his physical powers are in full vigor, he should beware of strife. In old age, when the physical powers are in decay, he should beware of greed."

DOC.HEADLINE: VP LU FAILS TO SHOW FOR COURT APPOINTMENT REGARDING LIBEL SUIT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu did not show up Monday at a court room to which she was summoned by Taipei District Court judges for debate with "secret witnesses" regarding the libel suit she filed against the Journalist.

Lu's attorney You Mei-nu said it was not necessary for the Republic of China vice president to appear in person at the court on the grounds that Lu cannot "debate" with the two "secret witnesses" since she does not know them personally.
On the other side, Wang Chien-chuang, president of the Journalist, a weekly magazine, lodged a severe protest against the Taipei District Court for the exposure of the two "secret witnesses."

Wang said the two secret witnesses -- Tseng Chao-ming, a secretary at the Presidential Office, and Chen Shih-ning, who co-authored President Chen Shui-bian's book "The Son of Taiwan" -- have demonstrated the greatest possible courage by being willing to step forward to testify against a formidable rival in the form of the ROC vice president.
Wang said the exposure of Tseng and Chen's identity is the result of the plaintiff's -- the vice president's -- plan to undermine the effectiveness of the witnesses' testimonies.

It was learned that the Journalist became willing to allow Tseng and Chen to testify after Vice President Lu declared in early May that she would appear at a court debate involving her and "witnesses" if there were any.

The clash between Lu and the weekly began some six months ago when the Journalist published in its Nov. 16 issue an article that made the accusation that the vice president on Nov. 3 contacted "a senior member of the media" -- later revealed to be Yang Chao -- to spread a rumor in order to smear President Chen Shui-bian.
Lu argued that she never made the alleged call and sued the magazine for libel.

According to Lu's lawyers, the weekly showed "actual malice" in printing a "libelous" cover headline and story. The team also accused the magazine of alleging that Lu wanted to use the presidential scandal to "finish off" the president.

The Journalist claims that there is "sufficient reason" to believe in the accuracy of its report and that the magazine "went to great pains" to "reasonably" verify the facts before publishing the article.
Wrapping up Monday's hearing -- the seventh of its kind since last November, without any apparent results, judges of the Taipei District Court decided that another session be scheduled June 9.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOBACCO AND WINE BOARD SAYS IT'S PREPARING FOR COMPETITION

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Tobacco and Wine Board (TTWB) said Monday that it is preparing to develop market-oriented products to face up to the steep competition expected after the liberalization of domestic alcohol and tobacco production.

The Ministry of Finance last week announced the timetable for liberalizing alcohol and tobacco production, with the lifting of restrictions on local production occurring in three stages over two years, which is one year quicker than its original plan of lifting restrictions in four stages over three years.
According to the new timetable, the first stage will see the liberalizing of the production of rice wine, liqueur using fruits, and brews other than beer.

The second stage will see the liberalizing of the production of cooking wine; distillers such as whisky, brandy and vodka; and other liqueurs. The third stage will see the lifting of all remaining restrictions.
Chen Wen-kai, TTWB deputy director, predicted that a lot of local producers will pop up after the liberalization, especially in regions that produce fruits, rice or other cereals.
A lot of small breweries and distilleries will appear, but only a few will be able to become large-scale, Chen added.

Faced with the imminent competition, Chen said that he still has confidence in the board's products, pointing out that producing high quality alcoholic beverages is an art and a culture. He noted that producing alcoholic beverages is easy but that producing them on a large scale while maintaining a high level of quality is difficult.
The TTWB enjoys an edge over any of the potential newcomers because of its long history, strong capabilities, and rich experience, he added.
But Chen also admitted that the TTWB is bound to feel the impact of the liberalization as consumers will have more varied options.

Chen said the board will monitor the needs of the market in developing new products and adjusting the flavor of its present products in order to keep in tune with changing tastes as well as step up its marketing and distribution networks in the face of the expected competition.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 28.85 POINTS

Market turnover amounted to NT$27.17 billion (US$0.8 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 28.85 points to close at 4,985.11.
Despite a rebound in U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 5,012.14 and continued to go down due to a lack of buyers. The index fluctuated between 5,012.14 and 4,944.98 during trading.

A total of 0.92 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$27.17 billion (US$0.8 billion), a record low since December 27 last year and a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 1.19 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$36.77 billion (US$1.08 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with bank and insurance shares edging up 0.2 percent.

The other major categories posted losses, with construction stocks moving down the most at 2.5 percent, followed by cement shares at 2.2 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 2 percent, textile issues at 1.6 percent, foodstuff shares at 0.8 percent, pulp and paper issues at 0.7 percent, and electrical stocks at 0.5 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 416 to 103, with 73 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: EIGHT MEMBERS OF TMTC LABOR UNION LAUNCH HUNGER STRIKE

TEXT.P: Eight members of the labor union of Taiwan Motor Transport Co. (TMTC) began a three-day hunger strike Monday in front of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications building in order to highlight their "cause of justice."

Tsai Wan-hsiung, chairman of the TMTC labor union, and nearly one hundred union members renewed their protests Monday against the Transportation and Communications Ministry's policies on TMTC's privatization, with eight of the union members deciding to begin a hunger strike to further stress their cause.

Tsai said that the labor union is not at all against the company's privatization but that it is opposed to the nature of the policy which is resulting in many TMTC staff workers losing their jobs. The TMTC staff workers' rights of employment and survival should be firmly protected in the privatization process, Tsai stressed.
Meanwhile, officials from the Ministry of Transportation and Communications said TMTC's privatization will by no means be altered by any form of opposition.
Kuokuang Motor Transport Co. has already been established, mainly with former management and workers of TMTC, and the new company is scheduled to become operational July 1, the officials said.
They added that it is a pity some of those at TMTC do not appreciate the efforts of the ministry and the goodwill of its privatization policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were lower on Monday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for June moved down one point to close at 5,030, with 4,319 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for July lost 33 points to finish at 5,002, with 35 contract transactions, while December futures decreased 42 points to close at 5,012, with only one contract traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 5,031 for June, 5,035 for July, 5,054 for September, 5,054 for December, and 5,150 for next March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.
June TE futures moved down 1.4 points to close at 254.4, with 901 contract transactions, while July TE futures lost 1.4 points to finish at 251.75, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
June TF futures moved up 3.4 points to finish at 660.4, with 419 contracts changing hands. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN GETS TASTE OF TEXAS ON HOUSTON TRANSIT STOP
DOC.DATELINE: Houston, Texas, June 3 (CNA) (By Chen You-chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Visiting Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian got a taste of Texan hospitality Sunday on his historic transit stop in Houston.

Republican Tom DeLay, who represents a Houston area constituency and is the majority whip in the House of Representatives, hosted a lunch for Chen at Houston's Taste of Texas steak house and then took him to a professional baseball game.
After munching on a steak, Chen grinned with delight and showed a clenched fist to hundreds of cheering supporters as he emerged from the restaurant.

Chen, wearing a cowboy hat and a western-style bolo tie, showed off a pair of custom-made black eel-skin boots, inlaid with his initials and crossed with the flags of the United States and Texas. The boots were a gift from DeLay, the third-ranking Republican in the House.
Three other House members from Texas -- Republican Kevin Brady and Democrats Gene Green and Sheila Jackson Lee also attended the steak lunch meeting with President Chen.

Later, Chen and DeLay sat behind home plate at Enron Field, home of the Houston Astros baseball team who was playing the Los Angeles Dodgers. Chen, wearing an Astros baseball cap, stayed for five innings.
Chen waved to hundreds of flag-waving supporters from the local Taiwanese community who turned out to greet him and chanted "Taiwan, Yes" during the game.

Meanwhile, a smaller group of demonstrators, organized by the Greater Houston Supporting One China Alliance, waved mainland Chinese flags and chanted pro-one China slogans during the game. Police kept the two groups apart and did not report any scuffles.
In the evening, Chen hosted a dinner in honor of U.S. congressmen, overseas Chinese community representatives and members of his entourage.

Speaking on the occasion, Chen said despite mainland China's constant efforts to isolate Taiwan from the international community, the ROC and the 23 million people of Taiwan do not feel lonely because of the friendship of many U.S. congressional members.
For his part, DeLay said he is convinced that Chen's Houston transit stop can help boost substantive Taiwan-U.S. relations. Houston is Taipei' first sister city.

Noting that the ROC is an important country and democratic model in the Asia-Pacific region, DeLay said the common values shared by Taiwan and the United States would contribute to further growth in bilateral cooperation in the future.

DeLay said he had informed the U.S. Department of State of his plan to meet Chen during his Houston transit stop. The State Department has been supportive of his plan, DeLay said, adding that the State Department's attitude shows its support for Taiwan.
Chen arrived in Houston Saturday evening on his way back to Taipei after a five-nation diplomatic journey to Latin America, which took him to El Salvador, Guatemala, Panama, Paraguay and Honduras.

DeLay said he does not think that Chen's Latin American tour was provocative to mainland China. He stressed that the United States should treat the ROC with dignity and that cross-strait issues should be resolved by peaceful means.
DeLay further said Taiwan and the United States should strengthen military cooperation in order to maintain regional peace and stability.

On Sunday morning, Houston Mayor Lee P. Brown paid a courtesy call on Chen at the Double Tree Hotel. Texas Deputy Secretary of State Jeffery Cornner presented a Texas state flag and an honorary Texas citizen certificate to Chen Saturday night on behalf of the Texas state governor.

During a 50-minute talk with four U.S. congressmen and seven senior Taiwan business executives who are accompanying Chen on his current visit, Chen pledged to help promote Taiwan-U.S. trade. He also promised to push for the 2003 Joint Conference of the ROC-USA and US-ROC Business Councils to be held in Houston.
On his way to Latin America in late May, Chen also made a two-night transit stop in New York, making him the first sitting ROC head of state to visit the Big Apple.

Chen and his entourage will leave Houston late Sunday for home, ending his 16-day overseas trip, the second of its kind since Chen took office in the ROC's first democratic transfer of power between different political parties May 20, 2000.
