DOC.HEADLINE: DEMOCRATIZATION THE ONLY WAY TO REDRESS TIANANMEN INJUSTICE: MA

TEXT.P: Mainland China's democratization is the prerequisite to the success of redressing the 1989 Tiananmen Massacre, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday.

Ma said hopes are dim for present Beijing leaders to right the wrongs that the mainland Chinese authorities committed during the June 4 crackdown on student-led democracy protests in Tiananmen Square 12 years ago.

A Kuomintang stalwart, Ma said Taiwan has experienced similar political terrors such as the "Feb. 28 Incident" more than five decades ago, but the Republic of China government in recent years has tried to compensate the people affected by the tragedy, including offering public apologies and cash compensation through a democratic process.

Ma said that only in a democratic nation or society, when the government clearly makes a mistake that results in suffering of innocent people, it is possible for the government to admit its wrongdoing and have the affected people's names cleared through a democratic process.

Meanwhile, former mainland Chinese student dissident Wu'er Kaixi, who is now a citizen of the Republic of China, remembered the Tiananmen Massacre and ridiculed some political figures in Taiwan as clowns for their "strangely amiable sentiment" toward the Beijing authorities.

Wu'er Kaixi, who married his Taiwanese schoolmate from Dominican University in California in 1994, said certain Taiwanese political figures are making fools of themselves when they openly demonstrate support for Beijing leaders on certain cross-strait issues, mainly as a result of their unexplainable phobia of Beijing and illusions of mainland China's huge market potential.

The former student leader who fled to the United States after the 1989 military crackdown of pro-democracy demonstrators in Beijing, reminded the Taiwan public to cherish their "good fortune" of being able to live in a democratic society like Taiwan, where at least the government would not deal with its own people with tanks and machine guns.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MINISTER LEAVES FOR SHANGHAI TO ATTEND APEC MEETING

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi left for Shanghai Monday to attend a meeting of trade ministers of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.

Lin said prior to his departure for Shanghai via Hong Kong that he will hold bilateral trade talks with his counterparts from mainland China, the United States, Canada, Singapore, Australia, New Zealand, Japan and Mexico on the sideline of the June 7-8 APEC ministerial meeting.
Lin said he is scheduled to meet with Shi Guangsheng, mainland China's minister of foreign trade and economic cooperation, Tuesday to exchange views on APEC-related matters.
As for the proposal that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait sign an investment guarantee agreement, Lin said he will decide whether to discuss it with Shi based on the situation at the time.

This was Lin's first trip to mainland China since he assumed his current post in May 2000. The business executive-turned-minister traveled to the mainland several times during his service at a local auto manufacturing company.
Lin said he will take advantage of his current visit to tour major Shanghai city construction projects and meet with Taiwan businessmen there.
APEC, a 21-member regional economic forum dedicated to promoting free trade and investment, is one of the few international organizations which admits both Taiwan and mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD SUGGESTS SCRAPPING MINIMUM MONTHLY WAGE TO ADOPT HOURLY PAY

TEXT.P: It is better to scrap the minimum monthly wage and adopt an hourly minimum pay scale, an official of the nation's top economic planning agency said Monday.

Y. L. Liu, director of the Manpower Planning Department under the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), said that the minimum hourly wage should be set at more than NT$66 (US$1.94) per hour in line with the shortened working hours implemented beginning this year.

Liu made the remarks ahead of a planned meeting to be convened by the Council for Labor Affairs (CLA) to review basic wage issues later this month. Major labor and management groups have been invited to participate in the meeting.

CLA sources said that the council is planning to suggest that the minimum monthly wage be raised to NT$16,377 (US$480) from the current NT$15,840 (US$465), or an increase of 3.39 percent. The proposal will be presented to labor and management groups to be used as a reference for negotiations. The minimum monthly wage of NT$15,840 has been in effect for three years.

Foreign workers in Taiwan now receive pay in line with the minimum monthly wage. If the CLA's proposal of a 3.39 percent increase is passed, then employers as a whole will incur an annual wage increase of NT$2.06 billion (US$60.41 million) judging from the estimated 320,000 foreign laborers currently in Taiwan.
Liu, who will be a member of the planned review meeting, said that in view of the current economic slump, basic wages should not be raised further.
She noted that most other countries have adopted a minimum hourly wage and said that Taiwan should no longer base pay on a monthly minimum salary, but should adopt an hourly system.

She calculated that laborers used to work 48 hours a week, and that this will mean a minimum hourly wage of NT$66 if the monthly minimum is set at NT$15,840. As employers also have to pay for weekends, workers would get around NT$3,696 per week.

If a new system is implemented and a laborer maintains 48 working hours a week, the minimum monthly wage could be raised to NT$16,363. But if a worker works 42 hours a week, then the minimum monthly wage would be cut to NT$14,344.

The CEPD has proposed a minimum hourly wage before, suggesting that hourly pay should be raised to NT$74 per hour, but in light of the current economic slowdown, it no longer advocates this amount, but instead said it should be somewhere above NT$66 per hour.

DOC.HEADLINE: MACEDONIAN STUDENT HOPES TO CONTINUE HER EDUCATION IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: As diplomatic ties between the Republic of China and Macedonia flounder, a Macedonian student in Taiwan hopes that politics will not affect her studies.

Georgievska Liljana, who has been enrolled at National Pingtung University of Science and Technology, in southern Taiwan, for two years, is studying how to eradicate harmful insects in growing tomatoes.
Liljana, who is at the top of her class, hopes to bring what she learns in Taiwan back to her mostly agricultural country.
Liljana is one of many students who came to Taiwan under a scholarship program sponsored by the ROC government's International Cooperation and Development Fund.

The scholarship program has been in effect for more than three years and four students under the program have since returned home to the Solomon Islands, Haiti and Gambia to share what they learned in agricultural technology with their countrymen.
Liu Hsien-ta, president of the Pingtung university, said he hopes that nurturing young talent will complement the diplomatic efforts of the ROC.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT THINK TANK TO OFFER ECONOMIC PROPOSAL TO GOVERNMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 4 (CNA) (By Lilian Wu) (By Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Taipei, June 4 (CNA): P.K. Chiang, president of the National Policy Foundation, said Monday that the opposition Kuomintang think tank has drafted a package of economic and financial proposals for the Presidential Office's reference.

Responding to President Chen Shui-bian's initiative to convene an economic development council, the opposition KMT will offer a wide spectrum of trouble-shooting proposals on cross-strait economics and trade, upgrading industrial structure, improving the investment environment, reinforcing the finance sector, revitalizing the stock market and stimulating the job market.

Chiang said that the National Policy Foundation in the past months has sponsored a series of seminars on public affairs and economic subjects. The proposals are taken from conclusions of these discussions attended by specialists.

DOC.HEADLINE: 71.1 PERCENT OPPOSE ABOLISHMENT OF CAPITAL PUNISHMENT: SURVEY

TEXT.P: The majority of people in Taiwan do not favor abolishing the death penalty, according to the results of a public opinion poll released Monday.

The telephone survey of 1,213 adult residents randomly chosen from around the island, conducted by the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) from May 23-24, found that 71.1 percent of the respondents oppose a proposal to abolish the death penalty.
Only 11.7 percent said they "strongly supported" or "somewhat supported" ending capital punishment.
About 33 percent said they thought that ending the death penalty would help upgrade Taiwan's international image in human rights protection, while 45 percent said they thought otherwise.

Just over 51 percent of those interviewed said they would support the abolishment of capital punishment if "life imprisonment without the chance for parole" were to be included in the Criminal Code. Nevertheless, 37.4 percent still gave a thumbs-down to the proposal even under such conditions.

Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan said recently that the MOJ will push for the gradual abolishment of the death penalty over the next three years in line with President Chen Shui-bian's promise in his May 20, 2000 inaugural speech to better protect human rights.
Meanwhile, the same survey found that 59.9 percent oppose the proposal to legalize same-sex marriages and allow those couples to adopt children. Only 23.2 percent gave a thumbs-up to the proposal.
RDEC officials said the survey findings indicate that local people's attitude toward same-sex marriages remains conservative.

According to the officials, the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) has drafted two versions of a human rights protection law, both of which allow homosexuals to marry and adopt children based on a respect for their basic human rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: SALES IN TAIWAN'S MANUFACTURING SECTOR DOWN BY 3.82 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan manufacturing sector sales reached NT$1.819 trillion (US$53.4 billion) in the first quarter of this year, down 3.82 percent from the year-earlier level, according to statistics released Monday by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).

Local sales in the sector decreased significantly by 7.13 percent in the same period, causing a bigger impact on Taiwan's economy than the Asian financial crisis did in 1997-1998, MOEA officials said.

The statistics show that domestic sales in the nation's manufacturing sector accounted for 54.25 percent of the total, representing NT$987 billion, while the remaining 45.75 percent accounted for exports, representing NT$832 billion and an annual increase of 0.42 percent.
MOEA officials said that even during the two-year Asian financial crisis, the nation's annual manufacturing sales still registered growth of 5.59 percent and 2.48 percent, respectively.

The officials said the textile industry bore the brunt of the local economic depression, with sales decreasing by 14.05 percent, while the metal industry was down by 13.9 percent, vehicle sales were down by 12.84 percent, the machinery industry decreased by 2.38 percent and the electronic and chemical industries registered increases of 0.62 percent and 3.8 percent, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LAWMAKERS ACCOMPANY `COMFORT WOMAN' TO JAPAN

TEXT.P: Three Taiwan legislators accompanied a former Taiwanese "comfort woman" to Japan Monday to push for legislation of a special law to compensate Asian women who were forced into prostitution during World War II.

The elderly former "comfort woman," nicknamed A-Tao, has on many occasions come forward to recount her wartime ordeal of working at a Japanese military brothel in India. A-Tao, now in her late 70s, has been living in solitude since her return from India after the end of the war.

A-Tao will join her counterparts from South Korea and the Philippines in demanding that the Japanese government issue a formal apology for this wartime atrocity, publish all relevant historical documents and offer all surviving "comfort women" due compensation.

The three lawmakers accompanying A-Tao on her Japan trip are Yang Chun-ying, Kuo Su-chun and Hsiao Chin-lan, all of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT). Also accompanying A-Tao on the trip was Wang Ching-feng, a lawyer who has been helping collate available data about former Taiwanese "comfort women."

Wang said they will lodge a protest with the Japanese government over a soon-to-be-published history textbook for Japanese junior high school students that gives a whitewashed account of Japan's wartime role and atrocities, including its treatment of "comfort women."

The group will also join forces with "comfort women" and lawmakers from South Korea and the Philippines to lobby members of the upper house of the Japanese Diet to support a special bill on compensation for former "comfort women," Wang said.

According to Wang, the draft special bill has received the support of 80 Japanese upper house members from the opposition camp. "We hope to solicit support from at least 25 additional Japanese councilors so that the bill can be eligible for screening by relevant standing committees in the upper house," she said, adding that they will hold a news conference at the Japanese upper house in downtown Tokyo Tuesday afternoon to brief the Japanese press on their appeal and stance.

More than 200,000 women from South Korea, the Philippines, Taiwan, mainland China and other Asian countries were forced to work as sex slaves at brothels operated by the Japanese army during World War II. Japan has set up a private fund to offer financial compensation for surviving Asian "comfort women," but many of them have declined to accept the money, insisting instead that the compensation come from the Japanese government.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPUTEX TAIPEI 2001 KICKS OFF

TEXT.P: The 21st Taipei International Computer Show -- Computex Taipei 2001 -- kicked off Monday at the Taipei World Trade Center, attracting a record high of 1,071 firms from home and abroad to take part in the five-day event.

Leading local firms, including Acer, Twinhead, Asustek and Giga-Byte are among the 946 domestic participants, while international big names such as Intel and Microsoft are among the 125 foreign companies from 14 countries participating in the annual event, the third-largest of its kind in the world.
The total number of firms taking part in this year's Taipei computer show -- the largest-ever in its history -- is 4 percent up over the 2000 figure.

Companies from South Korea and Britain are attending for the first time, while the United States remains the leading foreign participating country with 26 firms displaying their products at the show, according to the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) and the Taipei Computer Association (TCA), the show's joint organizers.

CETRA Secretary-General C.P. Huang said this year's exhibitions are being held in 11 special zones, with the aim of showing the world that Taiwan's information industry has succeeded in gaining a place on the world stage.

TCA President J.F. Liu said the Taipei international computer show is drawing increased international attention from foreign buyers, proof of the local industry's development from its infancy to the current booming stage.

According to Liu, 2000 was a year of uncertainties for the local industry. The United States was still the largest overseas market for Taiwan-made products, absorbing 38 percent of the locally produced goods. Europe and Japan came in second and third, taking 28 percent and 12.8 percent, respectively, he noted.
Despite a global recession plaguing the world information industry last year, Taiwan exported NT$989.2 billion-worth of information industry products, up 14 percent over the 1999 level, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE TRADE MISSION ATTENDS COMPUTEX TAIPEI 2001

TEXT.P: A mainland Chinese delegation composed of more than 20 members from the information, telecommunications and bank industries were present Monday at the e21 Forum Taipei 2001 -- a sideline event of the 21st Taipei International Computer Show.

Liu Wenjie, vice chairman of the China Council for Promotion of International Trade and head of the mainland Chinese information-telecom industries promotion mission, said in an address at the forum that he was very happy to be in Taiwan and to explore bilateral cooperation In e-commerce development.

According to Liu, mainland China's cyber population topped more than 22.5 million in 2000. He noted that the number will grow fast in the near term, as mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin said in a recent international forum that the mainland will actively promote e-commerce to provide businesses with greater access to modern technology.
A member of Liu's delegation -- Legend Group President Yang Yuanqing -- has attracted special attention since his arrival in Taipei, although he did not take part in the forum.

Yang, who showed up at the opening of the computer show with a low-key attitude, said his visit to Taiwan is not only aimed at purchasing. He pointed out that he is also willing to cooperate with Taiwan firms to jointly explore the mainland Chinese and international markets and called on the Taiwan authorities to allow mainland Chinese capital to enter the local market.

Yang said his group -- made up of mainland China's largest computer firms -- maintains very close relations with Taiwan companies. He noted that Taiwan is the sole supplier of his group's PCs and the major supplier of its PDAs and motherboards.

DOC.HEADLINE: III SEES GREAT MARKET POTENTIAL FOR E-BUSINESS SOFTWARE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's small- and medium-sized industries (SME's) want to keep pace with Internet developments, according to a report from the Market Information Center (MIC) of the Institute for Information Industry (III).

The report says that these businesses expect to upgrade their operations with information technology. The rapid development of Internet technology and e-commerce has alerted local businesses and many of them are planning to deploy Enterprise Resources Planning and Supply Chain Management software packages.

With more businesses willing to invest in establishing e-business, MIC forecasts that the output of Taiwan's software industry in 2002 will reach NT$200 billion and will double by 2005 to reach NT$400 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: FISHERMEN SURROUND BARGE CARRYING GENERATORS FOR NUCLEAR PLANT

TEXT.P: A barge carrying two generator units for the island's fourth nuclear power plant was surrounded Monday by 60-odd fishing boats near Kungliao, Taipei County, location of the controversial plant.

The fishermen, who were protesting against the plant's construction, used their vessels to try to blockade a wharf at Kungliao to prevent the barge from unloading, but dispersed peacefully after an official of the nuclear construction site accepted a letter of protest from them and promised to relay it to the authorities.

The protesters claimed in the letter that the construction of the nuclear plant has contaminated the seas far beyond the 4.4-hectare limit around the wharf guaranteed by the nuclear power plant and demanded compensation.
Atomic Energy Council Chairman Ouyang Ming-sheng whose council is the country's supreme nuclear power watchdog promised to investigate the claims.

The state-run Taiwan Power Company (Taipower), which owns the fourth nuclear power plant, offered Kungliao fishermen a one-off payment of NT$215 million (US$6.71 million) in March, 1999, for the disruption to their livelihoods.

The two German-made generator units, designed to provide electricity to operate the nuclear reactor, were shipped to Kungliao from Keelung Harbor, where they had been stored for more than a year after construction of the plant was scrapped and later restarted.

With a combined weight of 83 tons, the two units were too heavy to be transported via land and had to be shipped by boat, as will the main generator, which weighs 600 tons, and the main reactor, which weighs more than 1,000 tons.
In anticipation of the fishermen's protest, the Coast Guard Administration dispatched about 20 patrol boats to escort the barge, in addition to 1,000 police at the wharf itself.
The shipping operation which began at 10 p.m. Sunday and was supposed to finish by 5 a.m. Monday, was delayed by three hours because of the protest.
In a related development, Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi failed to dissuade opposition lawmakers at the Legislative Yuan from cutting NT$3.17 billion from Taipower's budget.
The money was intended to compensate the plant contractors who suffered damages because of the government's U-turn in policy regarding the nuclear plant.
The government decided Oct. 27 last year to abolish the partly finished plant, but was forced by the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan to rescind its decision Feb. 14.

Opposition lawmakers demanded that the government officials responsible for the flip-flop to apologize before budgeting the NT$3.17 billion -- earmarked as compensation for the damage suffered by contractors during this period.

Lin said he was not a policy maker in the case and thereby is not in a position to apologize, but he added that the construction of the nuclear plant cannot resume without first settling the damage claims.
In order to facilitate the building of the nuclear plant, Lin urged the opposition leaders to support Taipower's budget, but his arguments were not accepted by the opposition lawmakers.

DOC.HEADLINE: CREDIT CARD TRANSACTIONS ON THE RISE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A government report released Monday indicates that local credit card transactions in the first quarter of this year rose 12.2 percent over the same period of 2000.
The report from the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics listed the value of credit card purchases during the January-March period at NT$191.6 billion.

Borrowing on credit cards in the first quarter also increased 42.5 percent to NT$20.8 billion, bringing the total figure of credit card borrowing to NT$218.8 billion, up 35.4 percent over the year-earlier level.
The number of credit cards in circulation as of the end of March totaled 19.19 million, up 30.5 percent over the same period of last year, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENTEROVIRUS EPIDEMIC ESCALATING IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The Taipei City Bureau of Health (BOH) said Monday that an enterovirus epidemic has been escalating in the city and urged the public to be aware of the situation.
The BOH said at a press conference that the peak period for the disease is generally from late May through mid-June.

The BOH cited data from the city's 19 major hospitals showing that 256 outpatients received treatments for enterovirus and another 15 patients were admitted to hospitals for the disease between May 6 and May 12.
The figures rose to 467 and 32, respectively, during the May 13-May 19 period, and further climbed to 686 and 46, respectively, during the May 20-May 26 period, the BOH said.

Data from doctors entrusted with reporting enterovirus cases by the Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the Cabinet-level Department of Health indicated that the average number of cases reported by Taipei city doctors has been increasing since March.

The CDC statistics show that the average reported cases during the May 6-May 12 period was 4.23 per doctor. The number climbed to 11.02 during the May 13-May 19 period and increased to 12.46 during the May 20-May 26 period, according to CDC figures.
The BOH said five primary schools and kindergartens in the city reported enterovirus cases during the May 20-May 26 period, and five reported the virus cases during the May 27-May 31 period.

The BOH has asked relevant health units to send officials to the reported schools and kindergartens to strengthen health education, as well as assist the schools and kindergartens in sterilization efforts and other related measures in a bid to prevent the epidemic from expanding.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSPORTATION MINISTER TO ATTEND ROC-SWEDEN ECONOMIC CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Transportation and Communications Yeh Chu-lan left Monday for Stockholm, Sweden, to attend a ROC-Sweden economic cooperation conference slated to begin June 8.
Yeh will be the first high-ranking ROC official to visit Sweden since the inauguration of President Chen Shui-bian's administration last year.

One of the main purposes of Yeh's visit is to learn from the European country's telecommunications industry, as Taiwan is expected to grant operation licenses in the second half of this year to enterprises dedicated to third-generation mobile telecommunications.
In the 17th ROC-Sweden Economic Cooperation Conference, Yeh will also speak on Taiwan's telecommunications policy in the new century.
She will later attend a meeting of the International Road Federation in France, during which she will have a chance to exchange opinions with her counterparts in France and other countries.
Yeh is also expected to inspect electronic toll systems on freeways in Sweden and France before returning home June 15.

Asked to comment on a plan by some employers of the government-owned Taiwan Motor Transport Co. (TMTC) to appeal to President Chen Shui-bian for their "employment rights" amid the company's imminent privatization and subsequent expected job losses, Yeh said the long-term losses of the TMTC have created a heavy burden for the nation's taxpayers and she asked members of the TMTC to support the company's privatization.
Eight members of TMTC's labor union began a three-day hunger strike Monday in front of the MOTC building in order to highlight their cause.

DOC.HEADLINE: CSF MAJOR ATTEMPTS SUICIDE OVER GRAFT CASES

TEXT.P: An officer in the Logistics Department of Headquarters of Combined Service Force (CSF) attempted suicide in a restroom of a statin on the Pan-Nan line of the Taipei Mass Rapid Transport (MRT) system Monday.

Police said that Maj. Chen Hsin-chao was rushed to National Taiwan University Hospital for emergency treatment after apparently taking rat poison, although doctors later said they were awaiting test results to ascertain exactly what kind of poison Chen took.

Chen left three letters -- one to his wife, one to Legislator Hsieh Chih-ta of the opposition New Party and one to the mass media -- but the police and Chen's wife refused to divulge details of the letter.

However, an unconfirmed source said that Chen said in his letter that he could no longer stand the pressure resulting from the many CSF corruption cases he has reported to the Control Yuan. The source quoted Chen's letter as saying that he did not want to become "a second Capt. Yin Ching-feng" a naval officer who was found dead and was allegedly involved in a naval arms procurement graft case.
Chen became the second CSF officer to attempt suicide since a CSF civil engineering graft investigation began in February.
Col. Tsai Wen-chung tried to kill himself in April after he was summoned by the investigation team comprising military and civil investigators and released on NT$100,000 bail.

More than 20 civil engineering contractors and military men, both retired and still in service, are said to have been involved in the graft case. Three contractors and two lieutenant colonels are still being detained for further investigation.

Meanwhile, a spokesman for CSF headquarters said that the CSF has been investigating the cases in accordance with the evidence and in a fair and just manner. He said the CSF headquarters will not shelter or conceal any of its personnel who break the law.
Col. Liu Ke-lin, director of the Logistics Department of CSF headquarters, said that he welcomes anyone who can provide any information about unlawful action of CSF personnel.
Gen. Hsieh Chien-tung, CSF commander-in-chief, has also instructed CSF investigative agents to examine any information provided by informers within and outside the CSF.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEVELOPMENT OF AEROSPACE INDUSTRY WILL REVITALIZE NON-TECH INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: The development of Taiwan's aerospace industry will revitalize the faltering non-technological industry sector in Taiwan, a government official responsible for the development of the island's aerospace industry said Monday.

David Chu, office director for the Committee for Aviation and Space Industry Development, said Taiwan's aerospace industry is solidly based after investment of NT$350 billion over the last decade, while it also boasts skilled workers trained by the island's only airplane manufacturer -- Aerospace Industrial Development Corp.

Pointing out that while the island began the manufacture of jet fighters at about the same time as Japan, Israel and Sweden, only Taiwan and Sweden are still active in this fiercely competitive market, Chu said this is proof of the competitiveness of the island's aerospace industry.

Many world-renowned firms such as Boeing and General Electric have transferred the manufacture of several components to Taiwan, which has brought the output of the island's aerospace industry from US$2.49 million in 1988 to an estimated US$4.16 billion this year, according to Chu.

Citing statistics prepared by the Japan Aviation Development Council, Chu said the average value of output is about 1.5 million yen per ton for the automobile industry, 70 million yen per ton for the computer industry, and 330 million yen per ton for the aerospace industry.

According to Chu, this means that the aerospace industry boasts the highest added-value for every ton of its product. A small screw manufactured for aircraft use could be valued at hundreds of times the cost of a similar screw for automobile use, he said.

Noting that the International Air Transport Association predicted a 28 percent increase per year in Asia's air traffic load in the near future, Chu said he sees bright prospects for Taiwan's aerospace industry.

The island's proposed lifting of a ban on visitors from mainland China by the end of the year will bring about one million mainland Chinese tourists to Taiwan this year, which represents at least 500 airplane flights, he went on.

Direct air service links with mainland China will bring an estimated 10 million mainland Chinese visitors per year to Taiwan, which will offer Taiwan's aerospace industry fertile ground for growth, said Chu.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FINANCE MINISTRY TAKES STEPS TO STIMULATE STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Ministry of Finance (MOF) announced three measures Monday to try to stimulate the local stock market, as the weighted index slipped below the psychological level of 5,000 on the Taipei Stock Exchange.
The three steps were described as follows:

-- Regulate share transactions by large shareholders and board directors and supervisors of listed companies so that their shares cannot be sold within six months of purchase, or three months longer than the originally fixed period; and
-- Relax restrictions on listed companies' transactions regarding their own shares.

The weighted index on the Taipei stock market, the market's key barometer, closed the day at 4,985.11, down 28.85 points over last weekend. Only 920 million shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$27.17 billion, a record low since last Dec. 27.
Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang attributed the poor market performance to local newspapers' "over-exaggerated" reports on mainland China's military exercises on Dongshan Island.
"To my knowledge," he told reporters, "the military exercises are routine and there is no need for investors to care about them."
The MOF also pointed out that as interest rates have been lowered to a record low, "it is a good time for investors to invest in blue-chip stocks."
The Securities and Futures Commission also released figures to show that foreign investors still have deep confidence in Taiwan's stock market.

The commission said that in the first five months of this year, net inflow of foreign capital to the stock market amounted to US$6.75 billion, bringing aggregate net inflow of foreign capital as of May 31 to US$36.2 billion.

The commission added that the net inflow of foreign capital on the Taipei Stock Exchange this year is expected to reach US$12 billion-US$15 billion, and added that foreign capital will account for 10.04 percent of the total value of the local stock market.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN THANKS U.S OFFICIAL FOR ENTERTAINING ROC PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Frank Hsieh sent a letter Monday to U.S. House of Representatives majority whip Tom DeLay to thank him for receiving President Chen Shui-bian during Chen's transit stops in the United States.
Hsieh said in the letter that DeLay's hospitality has promoted the ROC's status in the international community and boosted the understanding between the two countries.

He noted that Chen dispatched him at the head of an ROC delegation to attend U.S. President George W. Bush's inaugural breakfast prayer meeting in January and that during the visit, he met with many U.S. political heavyweights, of whom DeLay, a Republican from Hoston, was most concerned about ROC topics.
Hsieh praised DeLay for his concern over the good development of bilateral relations, despite pressure from Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ECONOMICS MINSTER IN SHANGHAI FOR APEC TALKS

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi said in Shanghai Monday that he will meet his mainland counterpart on the sidelines of a trade ministers' meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.

Lin, who arrived in Shanghai Monday for the annual APEC event, said that he is scheduled to meet mainland Chinese Minister of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation Shi Guangshen Tuesday for a 30-minute discussion.

The meeting will center on issues related to APEC, trade and economic exchanges between Taiwan and the mainland, Lin said, adding that if possible, he will also raise the issue of a cross-strait investment protection agreement that has yet to be signed.

Lin will hold similar meetings with trade ministers from Canada, Singapore, Australia and New Zealand, as well as with United States Trade Representative Robert B. Zoelick, to seek support for Taiwan's accession to the World Trade Organization.
It will be Lin's first meeting with his U.S. counterpart since the inauguration of U.S. President George Bush and his administration.

Lin said he will also explore the possibility of the establishment of a free trade area in the Asia Pacific region, or a regional trade area (RTA) among several countries in the region if a region-wide trade bloc is not feasible in the near future.

Lin would not disclose which states he will approach for the RTA talks, but an analyst said ASEAN is pursuing a similar trade bloc with mainland China, South Korea and Japan and that Taiwan is afraid of being shut out of it.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Tuesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The Ministry of Finance (MOF) announced three measures to bolster the sagging stock market as the weighted index fell below the psychologically important 5,000-point barrier.
The China Times:
The MOF announces new measures to halt stocks decline.
The United Daily News:
Taiwan to keep neutrality toward Beijing's bid to host 2008 Olympic Games.
The Liberty Times:
Breakup of ROC-Macedonian ties may be imminent.
The China Post:
New king crowned as riots rock Nepal.
The Taiwan News:
U.S. limiting military ties with mainland China.
The Taipei Times:
President Chen goes stepping out Texas-style.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, June 5, or the 14th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1723: Adam Smith, the Scottish political economist and philosopher, is born. His "Wealth of Nations" was the foundation of classical free-market economic theory.
1806: Louis Bonaparte, Napoleon's brother who fought with Napoleon in Italy (1796-1797) and Egypt (1798-1899), is declared king of the Netherlands.
1819: John Couch Adams, British mathematician and astronomer, is born. In 1845, he predicted to within 2 degrees the position of the planet Neptune, which was certified in 1846.
1883: British economist John Maynard Keynes is born. He proposed that high unemployment, being a result of insufficient consumer spending, could be relieved by government-sponsored programs.
1926: Chiang Kai-shek becomes commander-in-chief of the National Revolutionary Forces in China.
1940: German forces begin their attack on France. They occupied Paris on June 14.
1945: The supreme commanders from the United States, Great Britain, France, and the Soviet Union sign a statement in Berlin that divides Germany into four occupation zones under their respective controls.
1947: An Outer Mongolian cavalry battalion, aided by planes with Soviet insignia, attack Chinese troops at Peitashan in eastern Sinkiang.
1947: U.S. Secretary of State George Marshall announces his plan to help Europe recover financially from the effects of World War II.
1955: The Taiwan Provincial Teachers College is reorganized into National Taiwan Normal University.
1963: King Bhumibol Adulyadej and Queen Sirikit of Thailand arrive in the Republic of China for a state visit.
1963: British Secretary of State for War John Profumo resigns from his parliamentary seat and from his Cabinet position after admitting that he lied to the House of Commons about his association with the model Christine Keeler.
1967: The Six-Day War, which lasts for 132 hours and 30 minutes, breaks out between Israel and the neighboring countries of Egypt, Jordan, and Syria.
1968: Five years after the assassination of his brother, President John Kennedy, Senator Robert Kennedy is shot in the head and shoulder and dies at the Ambassador Hotel in Los Angeles. He was 42.
1972: The ROC severs diplomatic relations with Greece.
1973: Kaohsiung City becomes a sister city of Barranquilla in northern Colombia.
1976: A joint communique pledging close cooperation between Lesotho and the ROC is issued as Prime Minister Leabua Jonathan ends a five-day visit to Taipei.
1976: Gen. Carlos Manuel Arana Osorio, former president of the Republic of Guatemala, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1980: Taipei Mayor Lee Teng-hui, Tainan Mayor Su Nan-cheng, and Keelung Mayor Chen Cheng-hsiung leave on a goodwill tour to the United States.
1988: Kay Cottee sails into Sydney harbor, becoming the first woman to sail nonstop around the world alone.
1989: The Solidarity party defeats the communists in the first free Polish elections since World War I.
1989: U.S. President George Bush suspends government sales and private military exports to mainland China to protest the Chinese army's crackdown on student demonstrations in Beijing.
1996: President Lee Teng-hui appoints Vice President Lien Chan to serve concurrently as ROC premier. The Cabinet is reshuffled three days later.
1999: Yugoslav and NATO officers meet in Macedonia to discuss the withdrawal of Serb forces from Kosovo.
2000: The 20th annual Taipei International Computer Show kicks off in Taipei with over 1,000 domestic and foreign companies participating.
2000: Former ROC Premier Vincent Siew turns down an offer of a job as a senior adviser to President Chen Shui-bian.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are three things which a wise and good man holds in awe. He holds in awe the Laws of God, persons in authority, and the words of wisdom of holy men. A fool, on the other hand, does not know that there are Laws of God; he, therefore, has no reverence for them; he is disrespectful to persons in authority, and condemns the words of wisdom of holy men."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS TO REVITALIZE ECONOMY, UPGRADE INTERNATIONAL STATUS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian vowed to revitalize the floundering domestic economy upon his returned from a 16-day diplomatic journey Tuesday.

The feisty president said in a statement delivered at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport that he would immediately resume work to address domestic economic woes and revive consumer confidence in Taiwan's economic outlook.
Chen said his just-concluded overseas trip, which included state visits to five Latin American countries and high-profile transit stops in New York and Houston, was very fruitful.

Stressing that Taiwan must stand up and walk out of diplomatic isolation imposed by mainland China, Chen said his hectic diplomatic journey has helped increase the Republic of China's international visibility and publicize its democratic achievements.

"In the face of mainland China's diplomatic offensive against Taiwan, my overseas visit has helped the international community better understand the historic meaning and democratic value of the ROC's first-ever transition of power between different political parties last year," said Chen, the ROC's first president from the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Moreover, Chen said his visits to El Salvador, Guatemala, Panama, Paraguay and Honduras have further reinforced the ROC's diplomatic relations with its allies.
During his five-nation Latin America visit, Chen said he gave interviews to 11 international press organizations and that international media published more than 800 articles on his diplomatic tour.

"Even my brief transit stops in New York and Houston have attracted much international attention and prominent media coverage," Chen said, adding that his overseas trip marked a publicity coup amid Beijing's intensified diplomatic embargo against the ROC.
Chen went on to point out that democracy and economic vitality are Taiwan's major assets for engagements with the international society.

"We must use our democratic achievements to enhance engagements with countries around the world, use our economic vitality to attract investment and sustain economic growth, join regional organizations to upgrade our international competitiveness," Chen noted.
He recalled that his visit to El Salvador was climaxed with a summit meeting with six presidents, one vice president and a prime minister from the ROC's Central American allies.

During the meeting, Chen said, all of the ROC allies pledged support for our bids to become a non-regional member of the System of Central American Integration and a dialogue partner of the North American Free Trade Area.

Noting that regional alliances have gradually become a major feature of the global economic development trends, Chen said Taiwan must forge ties with as many regional organizations as possible to stay competitive in the world market.
Chen said the ROC must cash in on its ties with Paraguay to tap the Southern Common Market, also known as Mercosur, and develop relations with major South American countries.
Touching on his historic transit stops in New York and Houston, Chen expressed his gratitude for all the courtesies accorded to him by U.S. authorities.

Chen said the upgraded, dignified treatment he received during his transit stay in the two American cities not only embodied progress in the ROC-U.S. relations but also underscored U.S. respect for the 23 million people of Taiwan.
"We hope this precedent can be continued and become a model for constructive high-level interaction between our two countries in the future," Chen said.

Chen made a two-night transit stop in New York en route to Latin America and an overnight stopover in Houston on his way back to Taipei, making him the first sitting ROC head of state to set feet on the two major American cities in more than half a century.

Without taking any rest, Chen began to perform his official duty after return to Taipei. He held a lunching meeting with legislators from his Democratic Progressive Party Tuesday noon and is scheduled to meet with senior executives from state-run and private banks in the afternoon to discuss ways to increase lending to blue-chip companies and stimulate the sluggish domestic economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 79.95 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Tuesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 79.95 points to close at 5,065.06.
Market turnover amounted to NT$38.54 billion (US$1.13 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 79.95 points to close at 5,065.06.

The bourse opened at 5,016.26 and continued to go up due to three favorable measures taken by the Finance Ministry to boost stock prices. The index fluctuated between 5,065.06 and 4,991.5 during trading.

A total of 1.36 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$38.54 billion (US$1.13 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 0.92 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$27.17 billion (US$0.8 billion).

All the eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile issues moving up the most at 2.6 percent, followed by foodstuff shares at 2.3 percent, bank and insurance stocks at 2.2 percent, construction stocks at 1.8 percent, pulp and paper issues at 1.7 percent, electrical shares and cement stocks, both at 1.6 percent, and plastics and chemical shares at 0.5 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 449 to 72, with 71 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were generally higher on Tuesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for June moved up 64 points to close at 5,094, with 6,625 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for July rose 68 points to finish at 5,099, with 54 contract transactions, while September futures decreased 32 points to close at 5,021, with only one contract traded.
Next March futures fell one point to finish at 5,148, with two contracts changing hands. No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 5,030 for June, 5,031 for July, 5,053 for September, 5,012 for December, and 5,149 for next March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
June TE futures moved up 3.8 points to close at 258.2, with 1,218 contract transactions, while July TE futures rose 6.25 points to finish at 258, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
June TF futures moved up 10.4 points to finish at 670.8, with 767 contracts changing hands, while July TF futures increased 11 points to close at 670, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: ILAN TO SET UP 2ND ILLEGAL M'LAND IMMIGRANT DETENTION CENTER

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) said Tuesday that in order to relieve the crowded situation at detention centers for illegal mainland immigrants, it is planning to set up another center in Ilan, in northeastern Taiwan.
MOI officials said the second detention center to be located in Ilan will be converted from a veterans' home and will shelter mainly female illegal mainland immigrants.

The new detention center, with an area of about 1,700 pings (one ping is equal to 3.3 square meters), will be able to accommodate a maximum of 280 illegal immigrants. The present detention in Ilan can house up to 400 people.
Officials said that the inauguration of the second dentition center will depend on the situation of the police force, which will be responsible for the guarding of the illegal mainland immigrants.

In addition to the setting up of the second detention center in Ilan, the Bureau of Immigration and the National Police Administration have also decided to implement other measures to relieve overcrowding, such as enlarging the current detention centers and converting old army barracks into more detention centers.

The present Ilan detention center now houses 195 illegal mainland immigrants, while the Hsinchu detention center houses 471 and the detention center on the offshore island of Matsu houses 311 illegal immigrants, according to the Bureau of Immigration.
Mainland China last took back 201 of its illegal immigrants April 24.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICY IMPLEMENTATION VITAL TO ECONOMIC IMPROVEMENT: KAOHSIUNG CITY ADVISOR

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic environment can be improved and problems tackled only if economic and financial policies are fully implemented, said Kenneth Lin, director of the Bureau of Finance of the Kaohsiung City Government.

As an advisor to Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh, who is also chairman of the Democratic Progressive Party, Lin is well acquainted with the problems facing the economy of Taiwan. The scholar-turned-government advisor said he believes that through a common effort by the administration and the opposition parties, Taiwan's economic prospects can be improved.
Following are excerpts of an interview with Lin by Taiwan's Central News Agency reporter Vivian Wang:
Q: The new administration has taken up a series of economic reform measures, but not much effect has been seen. Why the stagnation?

A: The Democratic Progressive Party only came to lead the central government last year. Inexperienced as the DPP is, it failed to identify the problems of the old government and to clarify the possible negative repercussions of its actions before jumping into its new role. In the process of reshuffling the government, people of various backgrounds were trying to have a share of the limited resources, thus complicating the existing problems.

The previous administration, after 50 years of Kuomintang rule, was like a middle-aged or even an old man with deteriorating health. The basic infrastructure was not sufficient to support accelerated economic growth. In the long run, problems would emerge. To cover up its "sickness," the old administration was using "anti-biotic" and "cosmetic" solutions. The new administration, with the inherited liabilities, was not only unable to solve the problems but was also unfamiliar with the structure of the work that had been done before. The ugly face of a depressed economy was inevitably exposed to the public.

The new administration has mapped out a series of economic and financial policies to halt the economic downturn. President Chen Shui-bian has already made attracting investors, revitalizing the economy and creating jobs as major tasks of the government. Nevertheless, these policies have not been implemented.

Bureaucracy and self-consciousness of those in positions to act have delayed the implementation. A good example is the Kaohsiung economic and trade zone project evaluation report, which was submitted to the central government six months ago. There has still been no response from the government. It is very likely that the report will be sent from department to department for screening during the next one to two years.
The administrative red tape must be minimized and outdated regulations must be lifted.

Q: Is the confrontation between the administration and the opposition responsible for the problems in the economy? Can the proposed economic development council achieve its goal without reconciliation?

A: The self-consciousness of the administration while facing a blockade by the opposition parties was an important factor in economic problems not being solved in a timely fashion. In fact, the general public agrees, as do the opposition parties, that the economic situation must be improved.

In the Kaohsiung City Council, the DPP has only seven of the 43 seats. Although it was inevitable that the opposition would block certain moves by the DPP, many important policies were implemented after consensus was reached through good communication.
Since opposition parties share the same concern about Taiwan's economy, the administration is obliged to consult with them to work out a rescue package for Taiwan's economy.
Q: The government has asked local banks not to reduce their credit to traditional industries. Can these businesses, many of which are deeply in debt, be saved?

A: The government can only suggest that local banks support traditional industries as if it was a moral obligation. However, the banks are well aware that too many bad loans will threaten their own existence.

Since local banks, public as well as private, are sure to stay clear of being sucked into a deepening hole of debt, the government should have the central bank set aside a certain amount of capital to help bail out troubled industries. If the central bank can allocate NT$500 billion for a special credit program, the revolving capital can help traditional industries solve their immediate problems. (translated by Lillian Lin)
