DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SUPPORTS TAIWAN'S WTO ENTRY BEFORE CHRISTMAS: ECONOMICS MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, June 5 (CNA) (By Chi Chin-ling and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The United States supports the Republic of China's accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO) before Christmas this year, ROC Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi said in Shanghai Tuesday.

Lin made the remarks after a 45-minute meeting with new U.S. Trade Representative Robert Zoellick on the sidelines of a trade ministers conference at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.
During their talks, Zoellick was quoted as having told Lin that the current U.S. government attaches great importance to strengthening substantive relations with Taiwan.

Lin also quoted Zoellick as having said that the Bush administration would like to see early WTO accession by both sides of the Taiwan Strait as it would pave the way for cross-strait dialogue under the WTO framework.
Asked whether the U.S. supports delinking of Taiwan's WTO entry from mainland China's, Lin said they didn't touch on this issue.

Taiwan has finalized nearly all trade concession talks with major WTO members, while mainland China has yet to reach agreements with several major trading partners, including the United States, on its WTO accession terms.
As mainland China has insisted that it be admitted to the WTO ahead of Taiwan, the ROC has so far been unable to become a full member of the Geneva-based world trade regulatory body.

During Tuesday's meeting, Lin said he also exchanged views with Zoellick on other bilateral trade issues, such as intellectual property rights (IPR) protection and liberalization of Taiwan's telecommunications market.
Lin told Zoellick that the ROC's Legislative Yuan is screening a draft bill on the management of optical media products in line with WTO regulations to prevent commercial piracy.
"The legislation is expected to be completed during the next legislative session," he added.

In response to U.S. concern about Taiwan's progress in telecommunications market liberalization, Lin said the ROC's Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) has been working on several programs to realize the market-opening goal.

Lin further said his talks with Zoellick proceeded in a cordial, amicable atmosphere. Zoellick last visited Taiwan two years ago. During that visit, he met with then-Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian who is now the ROC president.

Lin arrived in Shanghai Monday to attend the June 7-8 APEC trade ministers meeting. APEC, a 21-member regional organization dedicated to promoting free trade and investment, is one of the few international bodies that admit both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
On the sidelines of the APEC meeting, Lin will also hold talks with his counterparts from mainland China, Canada, Singapore, Australia, New Zealand, Japan and Mexico.
Lin said his meeting with Shi Guangsheng, mainland China's minister of foreign trade and economic cooperation, will focus on APEC-related topics.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER U.S. DEPUTY ENERGY SECRETARY TO ATTEND ENERGY MEETING

TEXT.P: Former deputy energy secretary of the United States Ernest Moniz will lead a group of experts to attend an energy technology conference in Taipei next month, said Tsai Ching-yen, convener of a science and technology advisory group under the Executive Yuan.
Tsai, who is also a minister without portfolio, made the remarks when he briefed Premier Chang Chun-hsiung Tuesday.
Tsai said that the conference will discuss issues concerning energy policy, new energy sources, regenerated energy and electrical power generation.

The advisory group has eight domestic advisers, including Lee Yuan-tseh, Nobel laureate and president of Academia Sinica and Morris Chang, chairman of the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. and nine foreign advisers, including Moniz, Tsai said.

Tsai also reported that his advisory group will submit substantial proposals to push for five strategic industries -- application software, biotechnology, nano-technology, information and communications and semiconductor industries -- for Taiwan in November.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS DELEGATION TO VISIT EASTERN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: A delegation from the Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI) will become the latest Taiwan group to inspect the investment environment in eastern mainland China in recent years.

The 23-member delegation is scheduled to depart for Hangzhou Thursday. During their six-day stay in the mainland, they will visit Ningpo, Shaoxing, Yiyao in Jiangxu and Zhejiang provinces and have extensive talks with local officials before returning home June 12.
To understand the investment environment first hand, an economics official will also accompany the CNFI delegation for the visit.
Yeh Huei-ching, executive secretary of the Committee of Research and Development under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, will be with the group to learn the needs of Taiwan manufacturers.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT ASKS BANKS TO HELP FIRMS OVERCOME DIFFICULTIES

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian asked executives from 18 government and private banking institutions Tuesday to help local enterprises overcome their current financial difficulties.
Chen, who just returned from a five-nation trip to Latin America, made the appeal while meeting with bank executives at the Presidential Office during a tea party.
The president called on the bankers not to tighten financial support for well-operated enterprises at a time when the economic situation at home and abroad was turning worse.
Chen said that the government has been taking a more flexible monetary policy since last December to revitalize the economy, and added that the central bank has lowered discount rates six times.
Nevertheless, he said that the enterprises have often complained about the difficulty of getting access to loans from the banks.
Chen noted that the emphasis of the government's economic policy has been placed on promoting trade, attracting investors, stimulating the economy and creating jobs.
"As we are all in the same boat, I hope everyone of you will support the government's policy and help these enterprises obtain loans," he said.
Chen pointed out that his recent foreign trip was designed to promote diplomacy, and now that he has returned home, he will turn his attention to the economy.

The bank executives invited to the tea party included Bank of Taiwan President Ho Kuo-hua, Land Bank of Taiwan President Wei Chi-lin, Taiwan Cooperative Bank Chairman Lee Wen-hsiung and Chiao Tung Bank Chairman Liang Cheng-chin.

Ranking government officials present at the tea party included Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, Vice Premier Lai In-jaw, Executive Yuan Secretary-General Chiou I-jen, Minister of Finance Yen Ching-chang, Central Bank of China Governor Perng Fai-nan, Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan and Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman Chen Po-chih.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SPECIAL OPERATIONS FORCES CONDUCT TRAINING DRILL

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's special operations forces conducted a training exercise in mountain regions in central Taiwan Tuesday.

The exercise, code-named Wuhan drill, came at a time when mainland China's People's Liberation Army (PLA) is conducting a series of large-scale combined services exercises on its offshore Dongshan Island opposite Taiwan.
The Ministry of National Defense (MND) stressed that the Wuhan drill is part of the special operations forces' routine training programs and has nothing to do with the PLA's ongoing war games.

MND sources said the Wuhan drill was mainly designed to test the special operations forces' combat kills, including infiltration in forest areas and blast of mock radar stations in mainland China's southeastern coastal regions.
Since the MND began a troops reduction plan a few years ago, the Army's No. 862 Brigade has become the ROC's only special operations unit.
A company of troops of the brigade's No. 3 Battalion took part in Tuesday's training exercise in the Kukuan mountain region in the central county of Taichung, MND officials said.

All the participating troops had completed a 300 km obstacles-studded march in mountain areas before reaching the military's Liyang training field near Kukuan for the Wuhan drill designed to practice various mountain combat skills and tactics, MND sources said.
According to military sources, the ROC's special operations forces are good at fighting in mountain regions and also have many special combat expertise and strategies.

In the face of mainland China's intensified military threat against Taiwan, MND officials said the ROC armed forces are stepping up combat training in order to safeguard national security and maintain peace in the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT WATCHING FOR SIGNS OF DEFLATION: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: With all related indices showing slowness or a downturn in Taiwan's economy, the government is still reluctant to say that deflation is setting in, according to a government official.

Ku Ping-chen, a deputy section chief with the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS), said it would take another six months or so to determine whether deflation has begun.
Deflation -- cutting out inflation with a loss of potential output, rising bankruptcies and unemployment -- has rarely been achieved without pain.

According to DGBAS statistics, all figures indicating the consumer price index, prices of core commodities, wholesale prices, average prices for export products and average prices for import products have shown diminished growth or month-on-month drops during the first five months of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC NOT TO ACCEPT ANY ALTERNATIVE TO FULL TIES WITH MACEDONIA

TEXT.P: Taipei will not accept any alternative to its full diplomatic relations with Macedonia, said a spokeswoman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs Tuesday.

Responding to news reports that Skopje will opt to switch diplomatic recognition to Beijing while keeping its economic ties with Taiwan, foreign ministry spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue said Taipei will not settle for anything less than full diplomatic relations.

Press reports from Skopje said that the coalition government of Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski is trying to tread a fine line of forging ties with Beijing in exchange for Beijing's support at the United Nations' Security Council without discouraging Taiwan from delivering on its promise of generous aid.
Georgievski's Cabinet is supposed to discuss the diplomatic shift at a meeting Wednesday and could seal the fate of its ties with Taipei, although any decision must be ratified by the Congress.

Chang said Minister of Foreign Affairs Ting Hung-mao, who flew to Skopje May 30 in an 11-hour effort to keep Macedonia in Taiwan's fold, will return to Taipei Wednesday night and will be bracing for the worst.

Noting that the Balkan state has been engulfed in a fierce civil war against ethnic Albanian rebels, Chang said some of Georgievski's Cabinet members who are eager to enlist UN help to wipe out the rebellion are expected to ask for a diplomatic switch at Wednesday's meeting.

However, Chang said, Georgievski's Cabinet is not united in its approach toward Beijing, and there are conflicting indications coming out of Skopje. The ROC foreign ministry is not rushing to judgment on the issue; rather, it is watching developments closely.

Meanwhile, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung reiterated Tuesday what President Chen Shui-bian said in Houston on Sunday that much as his country valued its ties with Macedonia, the ROC will not maintain diplomatic relations at the cost of the nation's dignity.

Citing President Chen's just-concluded visit to five Central America states, the premier told the Legislative Yuan that the country is still an active member of the international community with or without the friendship of Macedonia, adding that the public should not lose confidence in the country even it is spurned by Macedonia.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS CHINESE AND FOREIGN INVESTMENT IN TAIWAN DOWN 20% IN JAN.-APRIL

TEXT.P: Overseas Chinese and foreign investments in Taiwan approved by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) in the first four months of this year decreased nearly 20 percent from the same period last year, according to MOEA statistics released Tuesday.
MOEA statistics showed that MOEA-approved overseas Chinese and foreign investments in the January-April period totaled US$1.527 billion, a year-on-year decrease of 19.58 percent.

In the first four months of this year, MOEA-approved Taiwan investments in the areas other than mainland China amounted to US$1.544 billion, an increase of 19.95 percent from the same period last year, MOEA figures revealed.
The figures also indicated that in the first four months of this year, MOEA-approved Taiwan investments in mainland China stood at US$807.864 million, a year-on-year growth of 9.98 percent.

The MOEA said the main reasons for the decrease of overseas Chinese and foreign investments in Taiwan are the high comparison basis resulting from the major telecommunication fixed-line industry investment cases in the first quarter of last year and the slowdown in the growth of the global economy.
MOEA statistics also showed that the number of MOEA-approved overseas Chinese and foreign investment cases in the first four months of this year decreased 4.37 percent from the same period last year.
While MOEA-approved overseas Chinese and foreign investments in Taiwan decreased sharply, the MOEA-approved Taiwan investments in foreign countries and mainland China kept on growing.
The MOEA said Taiwan's main investment areas are the British Virgin Islands, the Cayman Islands, the Bermuda area, the United States, Singapore and Hong Kong.
Taiwan's investment areas in mainland China mainly focus on the provinces of Jiangsu, Guangdong and Fujian, the MOEA said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROOKIE SOLDIER MAY DIE FROM MENINGOCOCCAL MENINGITIS

TEXT.P: A rookie army soldier at the Chengkungling military training center in the central Taiwan county of Taichung might have died from meningococcal meningitis earlier this month, health officials said Tuesday.
Lin Jui-hsin, director of the Bureau of Public Health of the Taichung city government, said Chiu Chieh-chiao, 21, is suspected of having died from the killer disease.

Chiu was rushed to the Chung Shan Medical College Hospital in Taichung May 31 for emergency treatment and was transferred to China Medical College (CMC) Hospital early June 1. He died three hours later that day.

Lin said doctors at CMC Hospital suspected that Chiu might have been infected with the killer virus. Doctors have sent Chiu's blood samples to the Center for Disease Control under the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) for analysis.
"The disease control center is expected to announce the true cause of the soldier's death after the examination results come out," Lin said.
A young woman in neighboring Changhua County was also confirmed to have died from the disease in May.

Against this background, military authorities have heightened alert over a possible outbreak of the terrible epidemic. Twenty-four soldiers at Chengkungling who had close contact with Chiu have been sent to CMC Hospital for observation.

Military authorities said the move was mainly a precautionary measure to prevent any spread of the disease that is caused by a virus that can spread through the respiratory tract and via airborne transmission.
DOH officials said there have been 28 confirmed cases of the disease throughout the island so far this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA GEARING UP TO BUILD EXHIBITION CENTERS: CETRA OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Although the 21st Taipei International Computer Show -- Computex Taipei 2001 -- has had a high-profile kick off, the authorities have voiced concern over mainland China's ambition to catch up with Taiwan in the exhibition industry.

A historic high of 1,071 firms from home and abroad are displaying their products at 2,183 booths during the five-day event that opened Monday. More than 10,000 people, including 7,000 foreign buyers, poured into the show on the opening day.

An official with the semi-official China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) said, however, that they are increasingly worried about the changing trends behind the splashy annual event, the third-largest of its kind in the world, in the face of stiff competition from mainland China.

The CETRA official in charge of exhibition affairs said mainland China is gearing up to promote its exhibition industry in Beijing and Shanghai. Pointing to the first Cebit Asia show slated for August in Shanghai, he said that more than 160 Taiwan-based computer firms, among 500 companies across the world, will take part in the fair.

Despite the fact that most of the local firms planning to participate in Cebit Asia are small- and medium-sized businesses, he warned that the trend of Taiwanese firms taking part in trade fairs in the mainland cannot be ignored.

According to the official, the Shanghai authorities, which will co-sponsor Cebit Asia with the Germany-based Hannover exhibition company, have the ambition of developing the city into the most popular exhibition site in Asia.

Although the official said that Cebit Asia is not expected to pose a threat to Computex Taipei within the next three or five years, the official noted that the mainland will eventually become a strong rival of Taiwan in the long run should it gain experience and fame.

As many experts from mainland China have also come to Taipei to attend this year's Computex Taipei in efforts to gain some first-hand experience, the CETRA official noted that relevant mainland authorities are building exhibition centers across the mainland, including one in Pudong which is designed to be the largest exhibition hall in Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HOPES DPP HAS MAJORITY IN LEGISLATURE AFTER ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that he hoped that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party would be the largest party in the legislature after the year-end elections so that he can work fully for the improvement of Taiwan's economy.
Chen made the remarks at a lunch he offered to DPP lawmakers after he returned home Tuesday morning from a 16-day diplomatic journey to Latin American countries.

Chen said during his Latin American tour that he will give top priority to addressing the country's economic problems after his return, since he had focused his efforts on national defense and relations with mainland China and other countries in the first year of his administration.
Chen's party accounts for just one-third of the 222 seats in the nation's legislature, and he has had a hard time working with the opposition-dominated Legislative Yuan.
Although Chen had said that the local economic plight was partly caused by a global slump, he also said he and the whole Cabinet should take full responsibility to improve the country's economy.

At Tuesday's lunch, Chen congratulated Lin Feng-hsi, Chang Chuan-tien, and Tsai Huang-lang, the newly elected DPP caucus conveners in the legislature, and said he hoped all the lawmakers can be re-elected in the year-end legislative elections.

Commenting on his just-concluded Latin American diplomatic journey, Chen said the dignified treatment he received from the countries he visited is actually their affirmation to Taiwan's long-term democratic and economic development. He said he realized that maintaining continued economic prosperity in Taiwan is the best way to link friendship with diplomatic allies and to fight against Beijing's intimidation against the island.
Chen urged all the DPP legislators to work hard with him for the good of Taiwan's economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INITIATES CUT IN GLOBAL TUNA OUTPUT

TEXT.P: Taiwan initiated Tuesday an overall cut in global tuna fish catches in an effort to reinvigorate tuna prices that have been continually dropping since 1999, according to sources from Taiwan's ocean-going fishing association.

Taiwan, one of the leading tuna-producing countries in the world, hosted an Asian regional meeting of the World Tunapurse Organization in Kaohsiung, with representatives from Japan, South Korea, Taiwan and the Philippines taking part.

A consensus on reducing operations of tuna boats and an across-the-board reduction in global tuna and skipjack output was reached after Tuesday's one-day meeting of the representatives from the major Asian tuna-producing countries.

The reduction in ship operations and catches went into immediate effect, said Tsai Ting-pang, director-general of the Tunapurse Business Committee of the Taiwan Ocean-going Tuna Fishing Association, who chaired the meeting.

Tsai said the global reduction consensus will be observed by all 12 members of the World Tunapurse Organization and will remain effective until July 14, when all member countries' representatives meet in Kaohsiung for a world conference to discuss follow-up plans to rev up the depressed prices.
He estimated that 30,000-40,000 metric tons of tuna and skipjack, or 20 percent of the global take, will be cut back in a month after the reduction consensus takes effect.

According to Tsai, the prices for tuna and ocean bonito in the international fish market averaged about US$900 per ton more than two years ago. The average price nose-dived to some US$260 per ton late last year before rebounding to around US$700 recently.

Worldwide, there are currently about 400 tuna and skipjack boats with a total annual production of about 2 million tons. Of the total, Taiwan's approximately 53 boats contribute some 250,000 tons, Tsai noted.

Hu Hsing-hua, fisheries administrator from the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture, who was also present at Tuesday's meeting, expressed hope that through the upcoming global meeting, major tuna-producing countries around the world will effectively exchange views and pool their wisdom to tackle the price issue, so as to help secure sustainable development of the global tuna industry.

Hu also expressed his admiration for Asian tuna fishing companies, which yield about 900,000 metric tons of tuna and ocean bonito annually, providing one of the most important sources of protein to people all over the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TO GIVE JOB TRAINING TO 100 YOUTHS FROM CENTRAL AMERICA
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, June 5 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Taipei, June 5 (CNA): In order to help the Republic of China's allies in Central America develop their economies, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will help train 100 youths from the ROC's five allies in the region, a MOEA official said Tuesday.
He said that Taiwanese companies in that region can also send its local workers to take part in the job training program offered by MOEA.

The official of the MOEA's International Cooperation Department said 100 youths from El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Costa Rica and Nicaragua will receive one year of training at factories in Taiwan.

The training program is aimed at helping young people from the ROC's Central American allies create new jobs, the official said, adding that the program was one of the concrete resolutions reached at the first meeting of economics ministers between the ROC and its Central American allies held in San Salvador on May 26.
He also called on Taiwanese investors who have already invested in Central America or will invest in the region to send their local workers to participate in the training program.

According to statistics compiled by MOEA, there are a total of 130 Taiwanese companies with total capital of US$353.53 million in the ROC's five allies in Central America. The major investments went to the manufacture of ready-made garment. Their investment were concentrated in El Salvador, Honduras and Nicaragua, the MOEA's official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT URGES PRESIDENT TO STABILIZE DOMESTIC SITUATION

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) spokesman Wang Chih-kang said Tuesday that the KMT affirms President Chen Shui-bian's efforts to enhance relations with foreign countries, but feels he should also make more effort to stabilize domestic affairs.
Wang made the remarks while commenting on Chen's return from an official trip to five Latin American countries.
"Internal affairs are the basis for engaging in diplomatic work," Wang claimed, adding that "diplomatic work would become easier if the internal situation were to be stabilized."

The KMT spokesman noted that Chen's foreign trip was "very hard" and that the KMT affirmed the results of his trip, but he went on to say that "the current diplomatic difficulties are mainly caused by the unstable domestic situation and the slowing economy."
Upon his return from Latin America, Chen stated at a news conference that he will from now on turn his attention to the economy.
In response, Wang said that "actions speak louder than words," and that the government should take effective measures to stimulate the economy immediately.

When asked whether the KMT will join the "economic development advisory committee" proposed by Chen late last month, Wang said that his party will evaluate it after the Presidential Office works out a concrete plan on the organization and function of such a committee.

He said that the KMT recently organized a series of symposia on the island's economic problems, and added that their conclusions, together with a "10,000-word proposal" made by KMT Chairman Lien Chan last December, will be presented to the Presidential Office and the Executive Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEDIA MISREPORTS SCALE OF MAINLAND CHINESE DRILLS: MND CHIEF

TEXT.P: Republic of China Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen said Tuesday the scale of mainland Chinese military drills on Dongshan Island off the coast of the mainland's Fujian Province is not as large as reported by local media.
Wu made the remarks while meeting the press after attending a forum on national defense technology.
Wu said the ongoing military drills are routine events and added that the ROC armed forces have been aware of situation since the drills began. He urged local people not to worry about the exercises.

Meanwhile, commenting on the death of a soldier at the Chengkungling military camp in central Taiwan suspected of having contracted meningococcal meningitis, Wu said the military has taken emergency measures, including quarantining 24 soldiers who had close contact with the dead soldier and testing their blood in order to contain any possible outbreak.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LAWMAKERS URGE EARLY ENACTMENT OF JAPANESE LAW ON RESTITUTION
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 5 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A group of female legislators from Taiwan called Tuesday for an early enactment by Japanese lawmakers of a law to expedite restitution for wartime "comfort women."

Opposition Kuomintang legislators Hsiao Chin-lan, Kuo Su-chuen and Yang Chiung-ying made the call during a meeting with Yukata Inoue, president of the Japanese Upper House, at the headquarters of the Japanese Diet, or parliament.

The Taiwan legislators, accompanied by Wang Ching-feng, a Taiwanese lawyer, urged Inoue to see to it that the Japanese Diet begins debating the compensation bill, jointly proposed by Japan's opposition Democratic Party, the Communist Party and the Socialist Democratic Party, so that it can be passed during the current session which ends June 29.

They also presented Inoue with a petition carrying the signatures of 155 legislators from Taiwan calling for an early enactment of related laws so that restitution for former wartime sex slaves from Taiwan can be carried out at the earliest possible date, as time is running out for the surviving women, all of whom are elderly.

The Taiwan delegates, who also included a former Taiwanese comfort woman known as Ah Tao, are scheduled to take part in an international meeting Tuesday evening on the issue of Japan's enslavement of Asian women during World War II.
Lawmakers and former wartime sex slaves from South Korea and the Philippines are also taking part in the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR TO ATTEND FINE ARTS SHOW IN VENICE

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will leave for Venice Thursday to attend the 49th Venice International Fine Arts Exhibition which opens June 10 for a five-month run.
Ma will attend the opening ceremony of the Taiwan Pavilion, which has been designed under the supervision of the Taipei Municipal Museum of Fine Arts.
The exhibition is held every two years and Taiwan has attended the event on four consecutive occasions.

During his 22-hour stay in Venice, Ma will meet with Venice Governor Giancarlo Galan and Venice Mayor Paolo Costa, as well as also visiting the show's Hong Kong, the United States, France and Singapore pavilions.
He is scheduled to return to Taipei June 10.
Lung Ying-tai, director of the Cultural Affairs Department under the Taipei city government, left Taipei for the Venice event Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND MINISTER PROPOSES DIRECT THREE LINKS WITH TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, June 5 (CNA) (By Chi Chin-ling and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Mainland China's Foreign Trade Minister Shi Guangsheng proposed to his Taiwan counterpart Tuesday the opening of "direct three links" between the two sides of Taiwan Strait.

Shi made the proposal during bilateral talks with Republic of China Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi on the sidelines of a trade ministers' conference of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, which is to open here Wednesday.
The direct three links refer to trade, postal and transportation links.

The meeting between Lin and Shi attracted much attention as it was the second time an ROC minister had been sent to mainland China to attend an international conference in recent years, following former Finance Minister Shirley Kuo, who led a delegation to an Asian Development Bank conference held in Beijing in 1989.

Asked whether the two touched on the issue of which Taiwan representative Beijing will invite to attend the APEC leaders' summit meeting in Shanghai in October, Lin said they did not discuss the matter.

Lin said he urged the Beijing authorities to further guarantee Taiwan's investments in mainland China in the face of increasing numbers of local businessmen investing in the mainland, noting that bilateral trade between the two sides of Taiwan Strait reached US$34 billion last year according to official ROC figures, while Taiwan investments in mainland China totaled US$1 billion in the first five months of the year, also according to official ROC tallies.

ROC Vice Economics Minister Chen Ruey-long, who was also present at the meeting, said that in the frequent economic exchanges between the two sides, it is natural that both sides should encounter problems related to trade and investment. He suggested to Shi that both sides establish a channel to further protect Taiwanese investments and intellectual property rights.
Chen said Shi did not respond directly, saying only that he "realizes the importance of the matter."
Chen also said their meeting focused largely on issues related to APEC and the World Trade Organization (WTO) and that they did not talk about the "one China" problem or WTO accession.

The vice minister said most APEC member countries hope the WTO can launch a new round of trade talks in the near future, while developing countries also think that if the new round of trade negotiations begins too late, it will have a negative impact on the world economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. TRADE OFFICIAL SUPPORTS ROC PRESIDENT'S ATTENDANCE AT APEC
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, June 5 (CNA) (By Chi Chin-ling & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: U.S. Trade Representative Robert Zoellick said in Shanghai Tuesday that it would be "constructive" for Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian to attend an informal leaders' meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum this autumn.

He made the remarks while answering questions at a news conference after talks with ROC Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi and mainland Chinese Trade Minister Shi Guangsheng, who were also in Shanghai for an APEC trade ministers' meeting.
Zoellick said he would be just as happy to help Taiwan join the World Trade Organization (WTO) as he was to help Taiwan enter APEC in 1991.
He noted that Taiwan must be proud of its achievements in democratic development over the past decade and added that he is happy to be able to help Taiwan join the WTO.

Asked whether he will help Chen to attend the APEC leaders' summit, Zoellick said: "In terms of the leaders, I believe there is always an effort to try to have the leaders take part. I certainly think that would be a constructive step."
Chen expressed his willingness to attend the APEC conference last month, but Beijing officials immediately rejected the idea.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC HAS NO STANCE ON BEIJING'S OLYMPIC BID: SPORTS OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taipei welcomes but has no preference for Beijing's bid to host the 2008 Olympics, a Taiwan sports official said Tuesday, in an apparent shift in stance away from favoring Beijing.

National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports Chairman Hsu I-hsiung said that the government has no preference for any of the five cities vying to host the games and will support for whichever city is chosen by the International Olympic Council (IOC) to host the games.
Hsu said IOC member Wu Ching-kuo, who recently publicly supported Beijing's Olympic bid, does not speak on behalf of the government of the Republic of China. Wu is the only IOC member from Taiwan.

However, Hsu's statement directly contradicts the government's stance, which was spelled out by President Chen Shui-bian at a news conference marking his first month in office last June 20. Chen said at the time that he supported Beijing's bid.

Noting that Beijing tried to prevent Taiwan officials from attending the just-concluded East Asian Games in Osaka using pass cards for "government officials," Hsu said there is no sign that Beijing has eased off in its attempts to insult the island on the international stage, despite Taipei's goodwill gestures.

Indicating his full respect for Wu's contributions to international sports, Hsu said he would prefer Wu to help the island enhance its visibility and protect its interest in international sports events rather that soliciting support for Beijing.

Hsu noted that his council granted NT$5.3 million (US$165,625) to Wu's office this year and suggested that Wu could help him ward off lawmakers' challenges to the fund in the Legislative Yuan by speaking out more aggressively on behalf of the island on international stage.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO OFFER ECONOMIC ADVICE TO AID RECIPIENTS

TEXT.P: In addition to financial aid, the Republic of China is to offer economic advice to its allies in the same way the United States helped the island some 50 years ago, an economic official said Tuesday.

Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman Chen Poh-chih, who had just returned from a visit to five ROC allies in Central America along with President Chen Shui-bian, said that Taiwan used to help its allies through financial or material aid, or through private sector investment, which he said have limited effectiveness.

Noting that Taiwan owes much of its current prosperity to the United States for its monetary aid and its advice on economic strategies during the 1950s, Chen said Taiwan will offer its allies the same benefits it got from the United States by sharing with them the island's experience in economic development.
He said one of Taiwan's allies, whose name he refused to reveal, has already agreed to take advice from Taiwan on economic policy along with financial aid.
This way, according to Lin, bilateral ties can be better boosted than simply by handing out money.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, June 6, or the 15th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1660: The Peace of Copenhagen is signed, ending a generation of war between Denmark and Sweden. The treaty delineates the two countries' common border, with Denmark regaining Fyn and Bornholm from Sweden.
1801: The Treaty of Badajoz is signed, ending the War of the Oranges between Spain and Portugal.
1884: The Vietnamese emperor recognizes the French protectorate under the Treaty of Hue.
1901: Sukarno, Indonesia's first president, is born. He led the country's independence movement against the Dutch colonists.
1916: Yuan Shih-kai dies at Hsinhua Palace in Beijing at the age of 58, and the republican form of government is restored. Yuan, who forced the Congress to elect him president on Oct. 6, 1913 and annulled the provisional constitution on May 1, 1914, proclaimed himself emperor on Dec. 1915.
1934: The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission is established to protect the interests of investors.
1944: Under the supreme command of U.S. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, around one million Allied troops in 4,000 ships disembark for the coast of Normandy, France to launch the largest military invasion in the world's history and begin the final campaign to defeat Nazi Germany.
1946: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek accepts General Marshall's proposal to issue a second cease-fire order, instructing government troops to halt "all advances, attacks and pursuits" during the 15-day armistice.
1961: Carl Gustav Jung, Swiss psychiatrist and founder of analytical psychology, dies in Switzerland at the age of 85. His works include "The Psychology of the Unconscious."
1967: Egypt closes the Suez Canal during the Six-Day Arab-Israeli War. The canal remained closed to international shipping for eight years.
1974: A three-year agreement on the exchange of science information is signed by the Republic of China and South Korea.
1976: Paul Getty, the American oil billionaire who made his first million by the time he was 22, dies in London at the age of 83. He amassed one of the world's largest fortunes through the oil business.
1978: The 7th Sino-American Conference on Mainland China draws 50 American and 38 Chinese scholars plus four observers from Hong Kong, Canada, the United States and South Korea. The main theme of the meeting is "Mainland China in the Post-Mao Period."
1981: Seven coaches of an overcrowded passenger train are blown off the tracks into the River Kosi in Nihar, India, killing some 3,000 people.
1988: In New York City, Davis Stern becomes the blower of the world's biggest bubble when he blows one measuring a record 15.24 meters in length.
1994: A Chinese airliner on a domestic flight from the tourist center of Xian crashes, killing all 160 people on board.
1994: An earthquake rocks Colombia, killing some 1,000 people and leaving thousands of others homeless.
1994: Mainland Chinese air pirate Chou Weichiang hijacks a Southern Airlines passenger plane to Taiwan.
1994: Premier Lien Chan pays the first visit by a high-ranking ROC official to Mexico in the 23 years since the two countries severed diplomatic relations.
1995: Japanese Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama and his ruling coalition agree to express "deep remorse" for Japan's acts of aggression in World War II.
1998: The United Nations Security Council votes to condemn both India and Pakistan for their nuclear weapons tests.
1999: Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski, leading a 59-member delegation, arrives in Taipei for a six-day official visit.
1999: The ROC bans meat, poultry and other agricultural products from Belgium in the wake of a dioxin contamination in that European country.
2000: The outgoing ROC representative in the United States, Stephen Chen, categorically denies a May 24 Washington Post report that Taiwan posses an intelligence threat to the United States.
2000: The acting chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, Lien Chan, says that the "mini three links" between the ROC's outlying islands and mainland China should serve a political purpose.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The highest class of men are those who are born with a natural understanding. The next class are those who acquire understanding by study and application. There are others again who are born by nature dull, but who by strenuous efforts, try to acquire understanding: such men may be considered the next class. Those who are born by nature dull and yet will not take the trouble to acquire understanding are the lowest class of people."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC WOES TAKE TOLL ON HAWAII'S TOURIST INDUSTRY
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 5 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's current economic slowdown has taken its toll on the tourism industry in Hawaii, sources in the travel industry said Tuesday.
Lu Wei-teng, president of the Taiwan Chamber of Commerce in Hawaii, said that 20 percent of ethnic Chinese in Hawaii operate tourism-related services.
"Taiwan's economic woes have seriously affected their business revenues, particularly after two major Taiwan carriers suspended their direct Taiwan-Hawaii flight services," Lu said.
With the Taiwan economy losing steam, Lu said, the number of relatively expensive United States-bound tour groups from Taiwan has declined steadily since the second half of last year.
As a result, Taiwan's EVA Airways took the lead in grounding its direct Taiwan-Hawaii flights early this year, and another Taiwan carrier, China Airlines (CAL), followed suit May 1.
Since then, Lu said, the number of Taiwan tour groups to Hawaii has dropped by more than 60 percent.

"In the past, Taiwan tourists could be prominently seen at major Hawaii tourist destinations. But now Taiwan tourists are a `rare species' in Hawaii. This trend has become ever more evident since CAL suspended its direct flight services," Lu noted.

According to Lu, Hawaii tour guides specializing in serving Taiwan tourists could serve an average of four Taiwan tour groups per month in the past. But now the number has fallen to less than two. Meanwhile, he said, the business turnover of such peripheral services as restaurants and gift shops has also plunged significantly

"And most depressing of all is that no end to the current plight is in sight," Lu said, adding that some Hawaii tourist services operators have switched their focus to attracting holidaymakers from mainland China and the U.S. mainland.
Travel sources said the number of Taiwan tour groups bound for the U.S. mainland has also dropped substantially.
The number of Taiwan students who have registered to attend short-term classes in the United States during summer vacation this year has declined 60 percent from the year-earlier level.

A local travel agent, who preferred to remain anonymous, said he helped arrange for 1,200 Taiwan students to attend summer classes in the United States in 1999. "The number fell to 1,000 last year and only 400 have registered for relevant study programs so far this year," he added.

Worse yet, he said, the depreciation of the New Taiwan dollar against the U.S. greenback has dealt yet another severe blow to travel agencies specializing in serving Taiwan tour groups. "We are bracing for the coldest summer this year," he lamented.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-HK AIR PACT TO BE EXTENDED TILL YEAR'S END
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, June 6 (CNA) (By Lu Chien-hui and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The existing aviation agreement between Taiwan and Hong Kong, which will expire June 12, will be extended to the end of this year, a spokeswoman for the Hong Kong Economic Development Bureau said Wednesday.
According to the spokeswoman, Taiwan and Hong Kong carriers involving in the aviation pact have unanimously agreed to the year-end extension.
The spokeswoman further said that as the arrangement is related to commercial agreements among all relevant airline companies, she would not make any comments on the issue.

Local media reports said the extension of the current Taiwan-Hong Kong air pact for six months would hinder Dragon Air's plan to open Taipei-Hong Kong flight services. At present, the Hong Kong carrier can only operate flights to the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung.
Under the present pact, Taiwan and Hong Kong can both allow their carriers to operate a total of 121 weekly flights between the two places.

At present, Taiwan's China Airlines can operate 105 flights per week, while EVA can only operate 16 weekly flights. Meanwhile, Hong Kong assigns 100 flights to its Cathay Pacific Airways and 21 flights to Dragon Air.
The current Taiwan-Hong Kong aviation pact was signed on June 12, 1996 and the two sides originally agreed to review the accord once every five years.

Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of Taiwan's Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China and has handled exchanges with Hong Kong and Macau since the two former colonies reverted to Beijing rule in 1997 and 1999, respectively, said last week that Taiwan looks forward to signing a new aviation agreement with Hong Kong on a reciprocal basis.

Nevertheless, Lin also said that as this will be the first time that Taiwan and Hong Kong will have held aviation rights talks since Hong Kong's reversion to Beijing rule and the ROC's implementation of a statute on relations with Hong Kong and Macau, the two sides need time to prepare for negotiations on a new accord. Therefore, Lin said, the extension of the current pact is a practical way to cope with the issue for the moment.

Despite the current cross-Taiwan Strait political stalemate, bilateral trade and economic exchanges have continued to grow. The demand for flight services between Taiwan and Hong Kong -- a major transit stop for cross-strait air traffic -- has been skyrocketing.

With more and more Taiwan investors and managers relocating to mainland China, the Taiwan-Hong Kong route has become one of the hottest and both EVA and Dragon Air have long desired to increase their flights on the route, airline sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 155.38 points to close at 5,220.44.

Encouraged by a surge in U.S. hi-tech share prices, the bourse opened at 5,229.38 and continued to go up due to the good performance of electronics stocks. The index fluctuated between 5,234.12 and 5,206.56 during trading.

A total of 2.3 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$79.87 billion (US$2.35 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.36 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$38.54 billion (US$1.13 billion).

All the eight major stock categories gained ground, with electrical stocks moving up the most at 3.5 percent, followed by foodstuff shares at 3.3 percent, construction stocks at 3.1 percent, bank and insurance shares at 2.8 percent, cement stocks at 2.1 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 2 percent, textile issues at 1.9 percent, and pulp and paper issues at 0.7 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 515 to 31, with 48 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: FACTORS UNFAVORABLE TO ROC-MACEDONIA FORMAL TIES STILL EXIST: MOFA

TEXT.P: Uncertainties still surround official diplomatic relations between Taiwan and Macedonia despite a motion tabled by Macedonian Foreign Minister Ilinka Mitreva to switch formal ties from Taipei to Beijing being vetoed Tuesday, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) sources said Wednesday.

MOFA spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue said that factors that are detrimental to the Republic of China "still remain" and that the ministry and the Taiwan liaison office in Macedonia are closely monitoring the situation for any new developments.

Macedonian Foreign Minister Ilinka Mitreva proposed in a motion at a Cabinet meeting Tuesday that Skopje switch its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in an effort to secure bigger support from mainland China.
The proposal, however, was vetoed by Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski on the grounds that it was against administrative process.

The Cabinet later decided that the issue be raised by President Boris Trajkovski for discussions and that the consensus reached at such discussions be brought to a future Cabinet meeting for further debate and a final decision.

Chang said that despite the fact that the volatile state of the Taipei-Skopje diplomatic relationship has "temporarily been relieved" by Georgievski's veto of Mitreva's proposal, factors unfavorable to Taiwan still exist, including President Trajkovski's relatively more unfriendly attitude toward the ROC and Macedonia's avid hope of enlisting United Nations help in ending armed conflict by Albanian rebels in Macedonia. Beijing is a member of the UN Security Council.

Chang noted that Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao and Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Chiu Jong-nan have done their utmost to keep Macedonia in Taiwan's fold. Tien cut short a Latin American trip to fly to Macedonia last week in a last-ditch effort to salvage the formal diplomatic ties, but his counterpart, Mitreva, refused to meet him, saying that Skopje was planning to sever formal relations with Taiwan.

Meanwhile, Minister Peter P.C. Cheng, Taiwan's envoy in Macedonia, said Wednesday that the Macedonian Cabinet's decision to submit the proposal to sever formal ties with the ROC to President Trajkovski was not making the thorny issue any easier, at least for Taiwan.
Cheng stressed that the ROC will not accept any alternative to full diplomatic relations with Macedonia.

The ROC and Macedonia established formal diplomatic ties on Jan. 27, 1999. However, they have never been completely smooth since being established, and Cheng, the ROC's ambassador to Macedonia, has not yet been able to present his credentials to the Macedonian president.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC HOPES TO SET UP HK-STYLE ANTI-CORRUPTION AGENCY: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday his administration intends to set up a special agency to crack down on official corruption and graft.
Chen made the remarks during a meeting with Bertrand de Speville, a former director of Hong Kong's Independent Commission Against Corruption.

Chen, who took office in the Republic of China's first-ever democratic transfer of power between different political parties in May 2000, said eradication of official corruption and shady links between politics and organized crime were his major campaign promise.
"Our people have great expectations of the establishment of clean politics," Chen said, adding that his administration has spared no efforts to reach that goal since its inauguration.
Chen said although his administration has achieved some results in this regard, there is still much to done to wipe out graft and corruption.
"Therefore, we hope to set up a Hong Kong-style independent agency to crack down on corruption," Chen told his guest.
For his part, Speville said anti-corruption agency should be put under direct jurisdiction of the highest executive to avoid involvement of too many political forces.
Speville further said integration of various anti-corruption units into an independent agency is necessary to upgrade operational efficiency.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARTIAN INVASION COULD HAPPEN AS EARLY AS 2007

TEXT.P: A Martian invasion could take place as early as 2007 -- but it will be Earth invading the Red planet, instead of the other way around, Canada's national broadcaster reported Tuesday.
The Canadian Broadcasting Corp. said researchers at the University of Florida are working to develop genetically altered plants they hope to plant in Martian soil.

A robotic gardener would scoop up, analyze and fertilize the red Martian soil in miniature greenhouses. These shelters would house germinating specimens of a common mustard plant known as the thale cress, the CBC said.

A common weed along roadsides and trails, the plant, also known as Arabidopsis thaliana, was picked for the project because of its short life cycle of about five weeks, its small average size of about 18 centimeters, and because its entire genetic structure has been mapped and sequenced, the CBC said.

Scientists will add marker genes from other species to make the plants glow in response to environmental stresses like drought, noxious soils, and extreme temperatures ranging from seven degrees Celsius during the day to minus 112 degrees Celsius at night.

If the project succeeds, the researchers said they hope it will spark more interest in the possibility of "terraforming" Mars -- engineering the planet's ecosystems to make them more suitable for living organisms from Earth.

The researchers are trying to secure a spot for their experiment on a NASA-sponsored Mars mission. The CBC quoted Rob Ferl at the University of Florida as saying he has no doubt the plants will survive on Mars.
When it happens, it will show that life that evolved on Earth can thrive on distant worlds and will set the stage for human colonization, the CBC quoted Ferl as saying.
