DOC.HEADLINE: ASIA-PACIFIC SLOWDOWN MAY PROMOTE REGIONAL STABILITY: U.S. ANALYST

TEXT.P: The emerging Asia-Pacific economic slowdown may well promote a more stable regional security environment and facilitate international cooperation, a senior American analyst said Tuesday.

Nicholas Berry of the Washington-based Center for Defense Information wrote in the CDI Asia Forum that regional economic downturns usually bring with them other adverse effects, such as protectionism, unbridled trade competition, and territorial or resource disputes, but the developing slowdown in the Asia-Pacific region might actually promote stability.

Evidence of an Asia-Pacific economic slowdown has become more apparent as the year has progressed, he noted. The economy of the United States, to which Asian economies send roughly an aggregate 25 percent of their exports, grew only 1 percent in the first quarter of 2001, and imports have remained below their September 2000 peak every month since. Overall, this has had a depressing effect on Asian economies.

In the first quarter, Taiwan's exports were down 11.3 percent, Thailand's down 10 percent, South Korea's down 9.9 percent, and Hong Kong's down 2.4 percent. Japan, whose economy seemed to be on the mend in 2000, also found its exports falling, culminating in a depressing 41.6 percent drop in April.

Mainland China has been the major beneficiary as other economies have dipped, said Berry. Its economy grew 7.5 percent in the first quarter of this year, only a slight decline from previous quarters. The mainland market of 1.3 billion people is the world's largest and can increasingly absorb foreign direct investment and exports.

The senior analyst said he is convinced that the combination of an overall Asia-Pacific regional economic slowdown and the surge in the mainland Chinese market reinforces some positive security trends.

"China's increasing integration into the Asia-Pacific economy furthers Beijing's interest in stabilizing the region's international relations. An aggressive, assertive China seeking hegemony would undoubtedly stimulate the formation of a large anti-China coalition led by the United States and would therefore jeopardize China's economic development," Berry wrote.
"Exports and foreign direct investments would greatly suffer in an uncertain, hostile environment," he added.

The more economies integrate, the greater the need for multilateral trade, investment and financial regimes to regulate that integrated economy. As a result, the World Trade Organization and the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum can be expected to play greater coordinating roles, he said.

In the Taiwan Straits, one of the potential hot spots for regional instability, economic integration between mainland China and Taiwan is growing, which may lead the two sides toward finding common interests in moderating their political relations, Berry said.

Moreover, he pointed out, the United States and Japan have new administrations that are well aware that economic performance will largely determine their life spans. Both, without provocation, are not about to designate Communist China as an enemy or restrict trade and investments, which would inflame security relations in the region.
"In terms of the level of military tensions in the region, economic troubles are producing a `pacific' fallout," Berry concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN HAS EVERY RIGHT TO TAKE PART IN APEC SUMMIT: OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, June 6 (CNA) (By Chi Chin-ling and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian has every right and obligation to take part in the informal leadership summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, said an ROC official Wednesday.

ROC Vice Economic Affairs Minister Chen Ruey-long, a member of the Taiwan delegation to an APEC trade ministers' meeting currently being held in Shanghai, said Taiwan, a formal member of APEC under the designation of "Chinese Taipei," has the right as well as the obligation to participate in all APEC activities and gatherings.

President Chen expressed his intention in May of taking part in the APEC informal leadership summit meeting scheduled to be held in Shanghai in October -- an idea which has received support from the United States.

In order to make this happen, Vice Economic Affairs Minister Chen Ruey-long said the "Chinese Taipei" delegation is trying its utmost during the APEC ministers meeting to gain support for the idea, adding that although it is "doing it quietly" in the face of opposition from Beijing.

Top U.S. Trade Representative Robert Zoellick said in Shanghai Tuesday that it would be "constructive" for ROC President Chen Shui-bian to attend an APEC informal leaders' summit in mainland China later this year.
"Taiwan participates as an economy in a different condition," said Zoellick, when he was asked about President Chen's request to attend the Shanghai summit.

"In terms of the leaders, I believe there is always an effort to try to have the leaders take part. I certainly think that would be a constructive step," he said during a press conference on the sidelines of the APEC trade ministers' meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN TO LECTURE IN ENGLAND, FRANCE, U.S.

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan is scheduled to leave June 10 for three-nation lecture tour of England, France and the United States, a KMT official said Wednesday.
Lien will be accompanied on the trip by his wife and Jason Hu, KMT deputy secretary-general.

Lien will deliver a keynote speech at England's University of Oxford on the first leg of his tour. He will then proceed to Paris, where he will receive a scholastic citation at the University of Paris.
He will then go to New York, where he will attend an academic forum sponsored by a U.S. think tank and meet with officials of the KMT's New York chapter.
Lien received invitations from the three academic institutes early this year but was unable to visit them previously due to his tight schedules and his recent hospitalization.
Lien was keen to make the trip as soon as possible as the year-end legislative and county magistrate elections will be held in December and Hu is running for the post of Taichung mayor.
Lien is expected to return to Taiwan at the end of June.

DOC.HEADLINE: N.T. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar was down NT$0.022 against the U.S. dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Wednesday, closing at 34.065.
The local currency opened Wednesday at 34.037 and was traded between 33.940 and 34.090.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$379 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. PORN STARLET COULD BE EXPELLED FOR STREAKING ON TAIPEI STREETS

TEXT.P: A Chinese-American porn starlet who has been streaking on Taipei streets could be expelled from Taiwan because of her "obscene and offensive" actions, Taipei police sources said Wednesday.

The smutty starlet, known as Kiko Wu, has already doffed her clothes in Taipei's bustling Hsimenting area and the Warner Village complex last month, as well as running around bare in scenic Tamshui, in a scheme designed to help boost sales on her pornographic Internet site, according to Chen Li-hui, a city councilwoman from the opposition Kuomintng.
In response to Chen's accusation, officials from Taipei City Police Headquarters said Wu could be dealt with according to the law and expelled if she "does it again."
According to Chen, Wu is indeed planning to "do it again" -- this time in front of Hsingtienkung, a famous temple dedicated to Kuankung located on busy Sunkiang Road.
Wu's barefaced cheek can be easily accessed on her Internet site, which also has pornographic pictures and VCDs for sale, as well as ads for porn workers, Chen noted.
Meanwhile, the police official said the local TVBS weekly magazine could also be prosecuted for publishing naked pictures of the chubby, diminutive woman.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTER TO MEET WITH FINANCE EXECUTIVES

TEXT.P: Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang and Central Bank of China Governor Perng Fai-nan are set to meet with executives of 20 financial institutions Thursday to work out measures to help local businesses obtain bank credit.

President Chen Shui-bian has called on banking institutions not to reduce credit to businesses in times of economic recession and upon his return Wednesday from Latin America, he invited 18 bank executives to discuss ways of helping local businesses weather the recession.
The executives took the opportunity to ask the administration to improve the financial environment.

A major concern of the bankers remains the administrative liability in granting credit. Under the current criminal code and administrative regulations, bank staff may be held liable for the bad debts of their clients, thus making them reluctant to extend loans.

Vice Premier Lai In-jaw said Tuesday that the Finance Ministry will give clear guidelines to all monetary institutions regarding the legal definitions of "proper loans" and "irregularities" within three days.

Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan, who was also present at the meeting between the president and the bank executives, said that the liability aspect is written into a revision of the criminal law and added that he will see to it that the revised act is approved by the Legislative Yuan as soon as possible.

According to Lai, the Bankers Association of Taipei also reached a consensus last week not to reduce credit to businesses operating normally and paying their interest regularly. Another condition is that loans obtained from local banks must not be transferred to businesses overseas.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAVY MAKES PUBLIC FRIGATE DEAL CLAUSES TO FACILITATE PROBE

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Navy has made public several clauses in a 1991 deal for six French Lafayette-class frigates to facilitate a probe into alleged fraud in the purchase, State Public Prosecutor-General Lu Jen-fa confirmed Tuesday.

Lu also said that he has asked Roger Hsieh, a national policy adviser to President Chen Shui-bian, to relay the declassified clauses to French National Assembly member M. Thierry Mariani so that he can help raise the issue in France's National Assembly.

The navy sent a message May 18 to the legal team of Thomson-CSF, which built the frigates, to the effect that it would declassify Article 17 on non-disclosure and Article 18 on gratuities and commissions and that it would await a reply.

Article 18 states that if the contractor breaches the provisions as to the payment of any commission, percentage, brokerage fee or contingent fee, the buyer shall have the right to deduct from the contract price an amount equal to that of the commission paid.
But Thomson-CSF did not express views on the declassification within two weeks of receiving the navy's letter, so the navy went ahead and released the two articles.

Hsieh, who accompanied Mariani on visits to related officials here two weeks ago, noted that France had refused to disclose related information on the purchase, citing the prohibitive clause in the contract.
Hsieh said that after the declassification of the two clauses, the most urgent task is to "protect Taiwan's interests."

Noting that a 10-year dateline for keeping records of the account will expire in six months, he said the navy should first raise the reimbursement issue with international arbitrators. If such a move fails, he went on, it could then "consider other means."

The 1991 contract, which was worth 16 billion French francs, was signed by the state-owned China Shipbuilding Corp. on behalf of the navy to cover up the fact that the frigates were being purchased by the military.

Allegations about huge commissions in the deal surfaced in Paris in 1996 after Edmund Kwan, who claimed to have brokered the deal, brought a suit in a Swiss court against Thomson CSF to claim his commission, followed by further reports in 1998 from Paris that 1 percent of the price -- or 160 million francs -- was divided among officials in Paris, Taipei and Beijing as commissions.

The frigate scandal has rocked the navy's arms purchase sector and has called renewed attention to the mysterious murder of a navy captain in charge of the arms purchase program in 1993, whose death was widely believed to have been related to his intention to blow the whistle on the corruption involved in naval arms purchases.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN VISITS HOSPITALIZED WIDOW OF LATE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian visited Wednesday the widow of the late President Chiang Ching-kuo, who is hospitalized with pneumonia at the Veterans General Hospital in Taipei.
According to the hospital director, Chen asked Chiang Feng-liang to rest and wished her a speedy recovery, whereupon the former first lady expressed her thanks to Chen for his concern.
Chiang was hospitalized with pneumonia May 25 and her condition after antibiotic treatment was described as "gradually stabilizing."

She was already known to be suffering from pulmonary neoplasm, but the hospital suggested that this should be disregarded on account of her old age and that treatment should concentrate on curing her pneumonia.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF TAIWAN PEOPLE STUDYING AT MAINLAND COLLEGES TOPS 3,000
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, June 6 (CNA) (By Peng Ssu-chou and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The number of people from Taiwan studying at mainland Chinese colleges has exceeded 3,000 in recent years with at least 1,700 still studying, a source with a mainland Chinese working group for the joint recruitment of freshmen said Wednesday.
Taiwan students mainly enroll in Beijing, Shanghai, Tianjin, Jiangsu, Fujian and Guangdong, the source said.
Most of the Taiwan students major in law, finance and accounting, Chinese medicine, Chinese literature, history and religion.

A Taiwan student studying at Beijing University said that most Taiwan students majoring in law, finance and accounting plan to engage in cross-strait trade activities after completing their studies. Most of the students majoring in Chinese medicine plan to go back to Taiwan to practice medicine, and most majoring in Chinese literature, history and religion plan to engage in research and teaching.
Since the first students from Taiwan went to a mainland Chinese college to study in 1987, the number of students traveling across the Strait has been increasing year by year.

Mainland Chinese authorities have set up joint recruitment offices with Hong Kong, Macau, Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, Fuzhou and Xiamen forming registration offices for Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau people. Meanwhile, some mainland Chinese colleges have opened their campuses for Taiwan people applying to audit and study on a course-by-course basis.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOLDIERS QUARANTINED AFTER OUTBREAK OF MENINGITIS

TEXT.P: An army battalion stationed at the Chengkungling base in Taichung County was quarantined Wednesday after one of its soldiers died from spinal meningitis Tuesday.

A spokesman for the army base said about 580 soldiers of the 3rd battalion under the 200th Motorized Infantry Brigade were ordered to remain in their barracks for 10 days as a precautionary measures to contain the contagious disease, meningococcal meningitis.

Soldiers who have been given medicine for the disease, but are otherwise free of any symptoms, will be allowed to do routine training, but will not be allowed to leave the base, an army spokesman said.
The action was taken after a soldier, Chiu Chia-chao, of the battalion died Tuesday in a nearby hospital from spinal meningitis, a flu-like disease that can be fatal if not properly treated.

Twenty-four soldiers were admitted to the Taichung General Military Hospital Tuesday after showing symptoms similar to those of the soldier who died, but subsequent blood tests showed that they were not infected. All of them except two were released from the hospital Wednesday, the spokesman said.

Military health officials sprayed disinfectant at the Chengkungling base Wednesday morning, paying specific attention to the living quarters of the deceased man. The deceased soldier's house in Kaohsiung was also disinfected since he had just been on furlough there three days ago.
The Ministry of National Defense said it has ordered that all service personnel be informed of the nature of the disease and how to avoid contracting it.
Chiu was suffering headaches, fever and a stiff neck -- symptoms of the disease -- but he didn't see a doctor, according to family members.

Chiu's father blamed the army for making his son exercise while he was sick and neglecting to treat him. He was also against efforts to disinfect his house, but relented after neighbors persuaded him.

Chiu is the second victim to succumb to the disease among 30-odd cases reported this year so far in Taiwan. There were 11 case in the previous year and nine cases in 1999 according to the Department of Health.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE DEMANDS DECLASSIFICATION OF FRIGATE CONTRACTS
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 6 (CNA) (By Bear Lee & Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan on Wednesday approved a resolution demanding the declassification of contracts on the nation's purchase of six Lafayette-class frigates from France.

The resolution, jointly raised by the opposition Kuomintang, the People First Party and the New Party, asked the Executive Yuan to declassify part of the contracts that do not involve national defense secrets.

According to the resolution, the Legislative Yuan will also establish a committee to facilitate the investigation, along with the cooperation of the French parliament, into the alleged fraud in the deal that totaled 16 billion French francs.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) had originally considered boycotting the formation of the legislative committee on the grounds that it might infringe on the power and operations of the special panel which is responsible for investigating the case and is led by State Public Prosecutor-General Lu Jen-fa.
However, DPP lawmakers did not vote against the bill, enabling it to pass unanimously.
Meanwhile, Lu said earlier in the day that the Navy has made public several clauses in the 1991 deal for six French Lafayette-class frigates to facilitate a probe into alleged fraud in the purchase.

Lu also said that he has asked Roger Hsieh, a national policy adviser to President Chen Shui-bian, to relay the declassified clauses to French National Assembly member Thierry Mariani so that he can help raise the issue in the assembly.

The Taiwan navy sent a message May 18 to the legal team of Thomson-CSF, which built the frigates, to the effect that it was preparing to declassify Article 17 on non-disclosure and Article 18 on gratuities and commissions and that it would await a reply.

Article 18 states that if the contractor breaches the provisions as to the payment of any commission, percentage, brokerage fee or contingent fee, the buyer shall have the right to deduct from the contract price an amount equal to that of the commission paid. But Thomson-CSF did not respond to the declassification within two weeks of receiving the navy's letter, so the navy went ahead and released the two articles.

Hsieh, who accompanied Mariani on visits to officials in Taiwan two weeks ago, noted that France had refused to disclose related information on the purchase, citing the prohibitive clause in the contract.

Hsieh said that after the declassification of the two clauses, the most urgent task is to "protect Taiwan's interests." Noting that a 10-year deadline for keeping records of the account will expire in six months, he said the navy should first raise the reimbursement issue with international arbitrators. If such a move fails, he went on, it could then "consider other means."

The 1991 contract, was signed by the state-owned China Shipbuilding Corp. on behalf of the navy to disguise the fact that the frigates were being purchased by the military. Allegations about huge commissions in the deal surfaced in Paris in 1996 after Edmond Kwan, who claimed to have brokered the deal, brought a suit in a Swiss court against Thomson-CSF to claim his commission, followed by further reports in 1998 from Paris that 1 percent of the price -- or 160 million francs -- was divided among officials in Paris, Taipei and Beijing as commissions.

The frigate scandal has rocked the navy's arms purchase sector and has called renewed attention to the mysterious murder of a navy captain in charge of the arms purchase program in 1993. His death was widely believed to have been related to his intention to blow the whistle on the corruption involved in naval arms purchases.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DEFENSE NOMINEES SUPPORT CALL FOR TAIWAN RESTRAINT

TEXT.P: While indicating their support for ensuring Taiwan's adequate defense, nominees for three senior Pentagon positions on Tuesday echoed calls for Taipei to show restraint in order to help maintain stability across the Taiwan Strait.
Douglas Feith, nominated to be Undersecretary of Defense for policy, said that the United States should "provide the support (for Taiwan)...and help keep the situation there secure."

At the same time, he told the Senate Armed Services Committee that Washington should also "work on cooperating with them (Taiwan) to make sure that Taiwan's own position doesn't become a destabilizing element in the area."
Another nominee, Peter Rodman, concurred. He said that the United States "is not looking for a crisis with China over Taiwan."
"The Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) reflects the American commitment," he said, "but I think our objective is to deter a crisis."
Rodman is assistant Secretary of Defense-designate for international security affairs and in that capacity, he will be responsible for reviewing Taiwan's arms requests.
Jack Crouch, a third nominee to testify before the Armed Services Committee hearing, also said that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should use caution.
President George W. Bush wants to "speak clearly on the subject," he said, so that both parties, particularly mainland China, know about the U.S. commitment to peace and stability in the region.

"But on the other hand," he said, "I think it would be wrong to try to artificially solve that problem or to create stresses between those two states." Crouch has been nominated to be assistant Secretary of Defense for international security policy.
The nominees were echoing the views expressed by Senator John Warner (R-VA), chairman of the Armed Services Committee.
When questioning the officials-to-be during their confirmation hearing, Warner said that he strongly supports the TRA and the engagement of U.S. armed forces in the Taiwan Strait if necessary.
On the other hand, he cautioned Taiwan officials against creating "additional stresses" across the Taiwan Strait.

Reflecting the views of many members of Congress, Warner said that implicit in the TRA is "the obligation of the Taiwanese elected persons and others who are in official positions to restrain their rhetoric and their action."
Feith, Rodman and Crouch are all expected to be confirmed by the Senate.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG CITY COUNCILOR INDICTED FOR LIBEL

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung City Councilor Chen Chun-sheng was indicted Wednesday for libel after an audio tape used by him two years ago to corroborate his accusation of adultery against former Kaohsiung City Mayor Wu Den-yih was determined to be a fake.

Chen, who ran for a seat on the city council on the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) ticket in the 1998 election, used the tape to support his accusation that Wu, who was running for reelection as city mayor, was having a secret affair with a woman.

Chen won a city council seat in the election. He said the tape contained intimate conversations between Wu and his "anonymous mistress." Chen said the tape was given to him by a stranger who picked up the conversation while listening to his CB radio.
Wu denied the accusation and filed a complaint at the prosecutors' office before he lost his reelection bid to DPP candidate Frank Hsieh by a narrow margin of 4,565 out of 770,000 votes cast.

A prosecutor from the Kaohsiung Prosecutors' Office said Wednesday that forensic experts from Taiwan's Bureau of Investigation and a laboratory in the United States determined the voice on the tape did not match that of Wu and that very small background noises appeared to indicate where the tape had been edited.
As a result, the prosecutor said he indicted Chen on one count of "aggravate libel" under the Election and Recall Law for smearing a candidate with the intent to damage his chance of being elected.
Wu said Wednesday Chen was not acting alone and that prosecutors should expose Chen's accomplice.

Wu remind the prosecutor that a professor from National Taiwan University -- identified only by her family name of Chiang -- who called herself a voice expert and vouched for the authenticity of Chen's tape should be investigated as a suspected accomplice.
Speaking in Hualien Wednesday, Chen said he doubted the results of the tests conducted by the foreign laboratory on the tape and asked why it should take two years to complete such an easy job.
He vowed to cleared his name during the trial.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA CONSIDERING EASING RESTRICTION ON HI-TECH FOREIGN WORKERS

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) plans to loosen restrictions to allow more overseas workers with skills in information technology to work in Taiwan, council officials said Wednesday.
The Employment and Vocational Training Administration under the CLA has completed discussions on a draft amendment concerning the implementation of the Employment Services Law.

Under the amended statutes, the requirements for foreign workers skilled in information technology hired by domestic enterprises will no longer be restricted to those who hold masters' degrees and have at least one-year working experience or those who hold bachelor degrees and have at least two-year working experience as stipulated in the current Employment Services Law.

The amended version of the Law also states that hi-tech workers sent to Taiwan need not apply for a work permit in advance if they will stay in Taiwan for less than 30 days for projects dealing with agreements on technology transfer or after-sale training or services.
If they will stay in Taiwan for 31 days to 90 days, however, they will still need to apply for a work permit in advance, according to the amended law.

CLA officials said that to prevent hi-tech workers from taking advantage of the eased restrictions and overstaying in Taiwan, the CLA will consider setting a limit on the number of yearly entries permissible for each worker.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO OFFER ADVICE ON ECONOMY TO GOVERNMENT

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will present the government a set of suggestions on ways of boosting the faltering economy as a gesture to support President Chen Shui-bian's call to "fight for the economy," a KMT official said Wednesday.

P. K. Chiang, executive director of a KMT think tank, the National Policy Foundation, said his party has already prepared a list of recommendation for the government to show that the KMT is supporting the government's effort to halt the economic slowdown.
The recommendations, "An Analysis and Remedy based on Taiwan's Experience for the Current Economical Problems," will be presented to the government on June 12.
Chiang presented the paper to the party's Central Standing Committee for review on Wednesday.
Among the 13 recommendations released to the media after Wednesday's meeting, several were measures that the party had advocated earlier.
One such recommendation was that a coalition government be formed with the head of the majority party in the legislature appointed premier who would in turn be responsible to the legislature.

Another KMT recommendation is to call the National Unification Council into session and to reconfirm the island's understanding reached in 1992 with Beijing on the "one China," principle -- that there is only one China, with the definition of which being subject to different interpretations by Taipei and Beijing.

Notable among the other recommendations are breaking free from ideological burdens and respecting career bureaucrats; and relaxing limitations on direct transportation links with mainland China, beginning with shipping links and cargo, followed by air traffic and passengers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, June 7, or the 16th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1329: Robert I, king of Scotland known as "Robert the Bruce," dies at the age of 55. He defeated Edward I of England, crowned himself king and went on to win Scottish independence from England in the Battle of Bannockburn in 1314.
1712: Philadelphia bans the import of slaves.
1893: Indian leader Mahatma Gandhi's philosophy of passive resistance begins when he is thrown off a segregated train in Pietermaritzburg, South Africa, where he had lived for 21 years.
1905: Norway declares its independence from Sweden.
1909: Jessica Tandy, American actress, is born in England. She became the oldest person to receive an Oscar at the age of 80 in 1990 for her role in "Driving Miss Daisy."
1916: Li Yuan-hung becomes president of the Peking (Beijing) government, after Yuan Shih-kai's death due to illness the previous day.
1933: The League of Nations refuses to recognize the Japanese puppet state of "Manchukuo" (State of Manchuria).
1939: King George VI and Queen Elizabeth cross from Canada into America to become the first British monarchs to visit the United States.
1973: The Far East Senior League baseball play-offs open in Taipei.
1973: General John D. Ruan, chief of staff of the U.S. Air Force, arrives in Taipei for a two-day visit.
1973: The first Sino-Korean Cement Manufacturers Amity Conference opens in Taipei.
1974: A memorandum to strengthen economic ties between the Republic of China and Saudi Arabia is signed by Sheik Mahmond Talba, deputy minister of commerce and industry, and Wang Yi-ting, director-general of the Chinese Board of Foreign Trade.
1975: The last two U.S. combat aircraft based on Taiwan are pulled out.
1976: Dr. Arthur J. Barsky, founder of the International Rehabilitation Center for Disabled Children, arrives in Taipei to discuss establishing a rehabilitation center for Southeast Asia.
1979: The ROC Cabinet names Dr. James Soong director general of the Government Information Office.
1981: Taipei Mayor Lee Teng-hui leads a 10-member delegation to the United States to attend the annual meeting of American city mayors.
1982: Israel mounts major air and ground attacks against Beirut, Tryre and Sidon on the second day of its invasion of Lebanon to destroy the Palestine Liberation Organization.
1983: The Legislative Yuan approves the Firearms Control Law during its third reading, tightening controls on the manufacture, possession or use of firearms and other weapons. Punishments for violating the law are to range from 7 years to life imprisonment.
1989: A Surinam Airways DC-8 on a flight from Amsterdam crashes near Paramaribo's international airport, killing 169 of the 182 people on board.
1995: President Lee Teng-hui of the Republic of China arrives in the United States for a reunion at his alma mater, Cornell University.
1996: At his first press conference as vice president and premier, Lien Chan indicates that the ROC has not ruled out the possibility of the two sides of the Taiwan Straits exchanging visits by high-ranking officials. He also emphasizes the need to reopen channels to allow cross-strait talks.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui announces that the ROC will donate US$300 to help Kosovar refugees rebuild their homes.
2000: A Taiwan hospital reports the first case of Costello Syndrome, a debilitating genetic disease that causes a host of physical abnormalities.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are nine objects which a wise man aims at. In the use of his eyes, his object is to see clearly. In the use of his ears, his object is to hear distinctly. In the expression of his look, his object is to be gracious.
"In his manners, his object is to be serious. In what he says, his object is to be sincere, In business, his object is to be earnest. In doubt, his object is to seek information. In anger, his object is to think of consequences. In view of personal advantage, his object is to think of what is right."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. WANTS NO CHANGE IN TAIWAN'S REPRSENTATION AT APEC SUMMIT

TEXT.P: The United States expects no changes this year regarding the rank of the official who represents Taiwan at the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) summit, the White House said Wednesday.

Condelezza Rice, the National Security Adviser, said during a press conference that the United States traditionally supports the notion of Taiwan being represented at the APEC summit by its highest level economic official.

However, U.S. Trade Representative Robert Zoellick said in Shanghai after meeting with Taipei's Economic Minister Lin Hsin-yi on Tuesday that it would be a "constructive step" if Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian were invited to attend this year's summit.
Asked about the seemingly different stance between the trade representative and the State Department, Rice said the president doesn't expect any changes regarding who represents Taiwan at the summit.
President Chen said recently that he hopes to meet with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin at the APEC summit in October in Shanghai, but Beijing rejected the idea immediately.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FOREIGN TRADE SLIDES SHARPLY IN MAY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign trade posted a substantial drop in May as a result of floundering economies at home and abroad, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) reported Thursday.

Taiwan exported US$10.17 billion worth of products and services in May, representing a whopping 22.6 percent decrease from the same month the previous year and marking a new low in terms of growth since February 1998, MOF officials quoted customs statistics as indicating.

Meanwhile, the country's imports of products and services in May amounted to US$8.95 billion, marking an even more alarming drop of 29.6 percent over the previous May's level and representing the largest slide since March 1999.
Taiwan's trade surplus for the month of May was US$1.22 billion, the MOF officials added.

They estimated that both Taiwan's export and import trade will register double-digit negative growth over the next few months before possibly beginning to register "slight growth" by the end of this year if the global economy turns for the better.

The total value of Taiwan's exports for the first five months of this year was 9.5 percent less than the figure for the same period in 2000, with exports of electronics products and information and telecommunications products dropping 8.3 percent and 13.6 percent, respectively.

Meanwhile, the total value of the island's imports for the January-May period this year was 15.2 percent less than the figure for the corresponding period the previous year, with imports of agricultural and industrial products and capital equipment dropping 14.9 percent and 18.8 percent, respectively.
MOF officials estimated that Taiwan's exports will pick up steam next year when the world economy is expected to recover to an average growth rate of 4 percent.

Several mammoth government-initiated investment projects totaling some NT$810 billion in value are expected to help attract capital from abroad and contribute to stimulating the domestic economy and investment, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, MAINLAND MARITIME RESCUE CENTERS MAINTAIN CLOSE CONTACT

TEXT.P: Despite their political differences, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have maintained close contacts and cooperation in maritime disaster relief operations, a local emergency rescue expert said Thursday.
Yin Liu-sheng, secretary-general of the Taipei-based Chinese Search and Rescue Association (CSRA), made the remarks at a seminar maritime search and rescue operations.

Yin said maritime mishaps and disasters have often happened in waters near Taiwan, Hong Kong and mainland China. "Emergency rescue units in the three areas have traditionally maintained close contacts and cooperation in disaster relief operations based on humanitarianism," he noted.

Under current law, the Taipei Rescue Coordination Center (RCC) under the Executive Yuan and the military's Rescue Coordination Center cannot make direct contacts with mainland China's official disaster relief agencies.

"As a result, the private CSRA has helped mediate cross-strait maritime emergency search and rescue operations over past years," Yin said, adding that the CSRA has taken part in more than 100 such cross-strait disaster relief missions and saved hundreds of lives.
Yin further said that communications channels among Taiwan, Hong Kong and mainland Chinese emergency rescue units have consistently operated smoothly and efficiently .

"The three parties have traditionally cooperated closely whenever air or maritime disasters happen in their nearby regions," Yin said, adding that search and rescue operations in the Taiwan Strait have all followed humanitarian principles.

Speaking on the same occasion, Chen Yen-hung, chairman of the navigation department of National Taiwan Ocean University, said an average of maritime disasters occur in waters surrounding Taiwan annually.

Chen said there is still ample room for Taiwan to upgrade its capability in handling major maritime disasters. In addition to purchasing advance search and rescue facilities, Chen said, Taiwan should intensify manpower training to upgrade their professional expertise and skills.

"As maritime recreational activities will become ever more popular and yachting business may soon be further liberalized, maritime disasters are expected to rise. We must beef up our emergency disaster relief capabilities to cope with new challenges," he urged.

The seminar was co-sponsored by the Ministry of National Defense and the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, with the participation of representatives from various government and private emergency search and rescue organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 67.09 points to close at 5,153.35.

Affected by a decline in U.S. share prices, the bourse opened at 5,172.69 and continued to go down due to profit-taking selling pressure. The index fluctuated between 5,177.47 and 5,126.3 during trading.

Only one of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with plastics and chemical stocks moving up by 0.6 percent.

The other major categories posted losses, with bank and insurance shares moving down the most at 3.1 percent, followed by foodstuff shares at 1.8 percent, textile issues at 1.3 percent, pulp and paper issues at 1.2 percent, electrical shares at 1 percent, construction stocks at 0.9 percent, and cement stocks at 0.8 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 384 to 124, with 80 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MINISTER PROTESTS BEIJING'S 'UNFRIENDLY' GESTURE
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, June 7 (CNA) (By Chi Chin-ling and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi has formally lodged a protest to Beijing because organizers for the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in mainland China failed to call him by his honorific when they invited him to the meeting in March.
Lin said calling him "Mr. Lin" instead of "Minister Lin" was a slight to both him and the ROC and was evidently intended to "dwarf the international status of the ROC."

Lin, who is currently in Shanghai taking part in a trade ministers' meeting under the framework of APEC, said he handed the protest letter to his Beijing counterpart, Shi Guangsheng, mainland China's minister of foreign trade and economic cooperation Tuesday to protest what Lin called an unfriendly gesture in the invitation to the meeting that Beijing sent him in March.

Lin said it is unacceptable to both him and the ROC that Beijing addressed him only as "Mr. Lin." As a full member of APEC, Taiwan, under its formal designation is "Chinese Taipei," is entitled to equal treatment and protocol as all other APEC member economies, he said.
Lin said Beijing's affront was hegemonic and belligerent and runs counter to APEC practice.
Copies of the protest letter were sent to the APEC secretariat and all other APEC member economies for reference, Lin said.

According to Lin, Beijing, the host of this year's APEC trade ministers meeting and the APEC leadership summit, made public in March a list of names from APEC member economies to be invited to the meeting scheduled to open in Shanghai June 6. Lin was not included on that list.

Almost at the same time, Lin received a "notification" from Beijing official Wang Guangnan, who chaired this year's APEC senior officials meeting, about the APEC trade ministers meeting slated for June 6-7. Lin was addressed as "Mr. Lin."

Lin and the ROC government expressed their dissatisfaction to Beijing authorities about the matter in March. There was no response from the mainland until mid-May when Beijing's trade minister sent Lin a formal invitation to the meeting. The title "Minister Lin," however, was still missing from the invitation.

According to Lin, the government had considered boycotting the June 6-7 trade ministers meeting as a protest to Beijing's unfriendliness. The government later decided to let Lin go to maintain the tradition of harmony at APEC meetings and to allow Taiwan the chance to have its voice heard on the international stage.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CHANG INSPECTS OFFSHORE DEFENSE OUTPOST OF MATSU

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung made an inspection tour of the Republic of China's frontline island of Matsu Thursday to underscore his concern about general developments at the offshore defense outpost.
This was Chang's first trip to Matsu, which lies closer to mainland China than to Taiwan, since he assumed the premiership last October.
During a visit to Matsu port facilities, Chang reaffirmed the government's determination to continue promoting the direct "mini three links" program.

As part of its efforts to show goodwill toward mainland China, the ROC opened its two outlying defense outposts of Kinmen and Matsu for direct trade, mail and shipping links with mainland China's Xiamen and Mawei port cities, commonly known as the "mini three links" program, at the beginning of this year.

Chang said although Beijing has been reluctant to throw full support behind the Taiwan-initiated program, the ROC government will not waver on its determination to substantiate its "open-door" policy toward mainland China in a gradual manner.
Mainland China has so far approved direct Kinmen-Xiamen and Matsu-Mawei shipping services only on a case-by-case basis.
Chang said the current ROC government will use sincerity to defuse decades-old cross-strait animosity and replace conflict with dialogue.
In the company of local government officials and legislators, Chang inspected several community development projects on the offshore island.

Chang also toured Chinpi Village, which is known for its preservation of a number of traditional southern Chinese-style houses and artifacts. The village hosted an international seminar on community design and development last month, which brought together many architecture and community development experts from Asia-Pacific countries.
Chang lauded local government officials for their efforts to preserve traditional cultural heritage and develop tourist resources over past years.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CHANG HOPES LEGISLATURE WILL ATTEND EMERGENCY MEETING

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung Thursday morning made a number of calls on Wang Jin-pyng, president of the Legislative Yuan, and faction chiefs of opposition parties, to try to arrange an emergency meeting to screen and pass bills which failed to be approved before the legislature went into recess.
The fifth session of the fourth legislature concluded at midnight Thursday with only 42 bills passed and dozens of other still outstanding.

At the morning meeting with Wang, Chang said that several bills -- those involving financial reforms in particular -- are vital to the government's economic stimulus programs. He hoped that political parties in the Legislative Yuan could reach consensus and convene an emergency meeting during the recess to approve the bills.
Chang asked the president of the Legislative Yuan, who is a member of the majority Kuomintang (KMT), to try to get all parties to agree on the emergency meeting.
If a consensus is reached, an emergency meeting could be called either by the Legislative Yuan or at the request of the president, Chang said.
The Legislative Yuan can call an emergency meeting if one-fourth of its 225 members sign a petition.
Wang said that he favors a meeting called by the president, although how the meeting should be convened needs to be agreed upon by all parties.
He said that the process would be more proper and reasonable if the president called the meeting and that bills would be screened more efficiently.

Chang, accompanied by Vice Premier Lai In-jaw and Secretary-General Chiou I-jen of the Executive Yuan, later called at the offices of party factions of the KMT, the New Party, and the People First Party. He also met with members of the Non-Party Alliance and the Cross-Party Association, asking their support to allow bills with priority to be approved at an emergency meeting.

The administration is especially concerned about the bank holding company bill, financial reconstruction fund management provisions, and the revision of the insurance law, which are important to an overall financial reform program.

Minister of Finance Yen Ching-chang said that these bills are essential in the revitalization of Taiwan's monetary system. The early approval and implementation of the reform program is important, said Yen, adding that the finance ministry has made reform a major theme in promoting investment in Taiwan to those in Europe.

DOC.HEADLINE: DESPITE JOBLESS RATE, WORKERS STILL NEEDED IN SEVERAL SECTORS

TEXT.P: Despite Taiwan's rising unemployment, the country's overall workforce is still currently some 200,000 short of actual demand, officials from the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Thursday.

Lin Tsung-ming, director-general of CLA's Employment and Vocational Training Administration, urged the Taiwan public, particularly job seekers, to readjust their values to allow them to make the most of job opportunities that arise.

Lin quoted the latest CLA survey results as indicating that currently there are about 44,000 openings in government agencies of all levels, while the mammoth government-initiated investment projects totaling some NT$810 billion in value are poised to provide some 54,000 work opportunities islandwide.

In addition, he said, the government's emergency employment plan will need about 10,000 personnel, while local employment service centers as a whole have about 54,000 job vacancies available, plus more than 70,000 work opportunities are available from private-run human resource centers islandwide.

Meanwhile, the CLA is pondering measures to open Taiwan's high-technology market wider to foreign nationals so as to help beef up Taiwan's hi-tech development and ease the shortage of labor, Lin said.

CLA Vice Chairman Kuo Chi-jen said the plan -- designed to recruit high-caliber white-collar workers from aboard -- will help solicit foreign investments to Taiwan, consequently helping to increase job opportunities locally. The plan, if approved, will be applicable to all qualified individuals from abroad, including mainland China, Kuo added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 24 CREWMEN OF TAIWAN FISHING SHIP RESCUED

TEXT.P: Twenty-four crewmen of a Kaohsiung-registered fishing ship were rescued when their ship sank in the Indian Ocean Thursday morning.

Kaohsiung fishing association radio said that the "Chinhungda No.1" began to take on water due to a damaged hull and subsequently sank in the Indian Ocean. The radio alerted nearby fishing vessels to come to the rescue.
Two Taiwanese and 16 mainland China fishermen as well as six others of different nationalities were rescued in a life raft.
The 200-ton deep-sea tuna fishing ship departed from Kaohsiung Harbor in March.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FOREIGN CURRENCY RESERVES TOTAL US$ 110.63 BILLION AS OF MAY
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 7 (CNA) (By Lilian Wu) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Taipei, June 7 (CNA): Taiwan's foreign currency reserves totaled US$110.63 billion as of the end of May, a decrease of US$1.01 billion from the previous month, the first monthly drop this year, an official from the Central Bank of China (CBC) said Thursday.
The figures is also down by US$2.48 billion compared with last May's US$113.12 billion, a decrease of 2.2 percent, the CBC official said.

Taiwan's foreign currency reserves totaled 111.65 billion as of the end of April. Although the figures for May showed the first fall of this year, they represented an increase of US$3.89 billion as compared with that of the end of 2000, the official said.
The official attributed the decrease to the depreciation of new Taiwan dollar and the CBC sales of U.S. dollars to intervene in the local forex market.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPEAN BANK PRESIDENT PRAISES STRENGTH OF TAIWAN ECONOMY
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 7 (CNA) (By Lilian Wu) (By Edward Chen) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Taipei, June 7 (CNA): Jean Lemierre, president of the European Bank of Reconstruction Development (EBRD), called on Minister of Finance Yen Ching-chang Thursday to exchange views on the financial and monetary situation in Taiwan.

Yen told local media after meeting with Lemierre that the European banker believed that Taiwan's economy is strong. Lemierre highly praised the reform being carried out by the Ministry of Finance on financial and monetary issues and described them as a "very good policy" which will help lure foreign investment.
Yen quoted Lemierre as saying that Taiwan, with its abundant foreign currency reserves and no burden of foreign debt, had a very strong economy in comparison with Japan and South Korea.
The European Bank of Reconstruction Development has issued NT$26 billion in banking bonds in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL REVEALS TAIWAN PEOPLE'S VISION OF THE FUTURE

TEXT.P: The majority of people in Taiwan look forward to seeing Taiwan become a just, safe and orderly society 20 years from now, but many of them are not optimistic about Taiwan's future, according to the results of an opinion poll released Thursday.
The survey of 1,096 randomly chosen Taiwan residents aged 18 or over was conducted by the CommonWealth magazine from May 18-24 to explore local people's vision of Taiwan in 2020.
The poll found that 55.7 percent of the respondents expect Taiwan to become a Singapore- or Japan-like society known for their fair, secure and orderly living environments by 2002.

About 32 percent said they hope Taiwan becomes a clean, beautiful place like Switzerland over the next two decades; 31 percent said they would like to see Taiwan become a competitive, high-tech powerhouse like Silicon Valley in the United States; and 29.4 percent said they hope Taiwan can develop into a North European-style country with comprehensive social welfare services.

Nevertheless, survey results showed that many Taiwan people lack confidence in the island's future. Only 30 percent said they think that Taiwan would be better off over the next 20 years, while 55.4 percent said they foresee a deterioration of Taiwan's living quality.

Asked about things that Taiwan must do most urgently now, survey respondents cited upgrading national competitiveness (32.3 percent), improving government operational efficiency (32.2 percent), raising educational quality (31.8 percent), improving environmental quality (30.7 percent), and narrowing the wealth gap (29.4 percent), in that order.

As for priority tasks for Taiwan in 2020, the respondents mentioned beefing up national competitiveness (30.4 percent), upgrading educational quality (27.2 percent), improving the living environment (26.6 percent), and promoting friendly interaction between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait (26.2 percent), in that order.

Meanwhile, 65.8 percent said they look forward to seeing the two sides of the Taiwan Strait co-exist peacefully and cooperate reciprocally by 2020; 35.9 percent said they hope to see the two sides conduct full-fledged engagements and allow direct "three links"; 23.7 percent said they prefer to see the status quo remain; 15.3 percent said they would like to see the two sides unify by 2020; and 12.4 percent said they expect to see Taiwan declare independence.

Asked whether Taiwan can realize its goal of creating a just, clean and secure living environment for sustainable development over the next 20 years, 44.7 percent said they are optimistic about the prospect; 35 percent said they are pessimistic; and 20 percent didn't answer the question.

The poll also found that 47.2 percent of the respondents believe that Taiwan stands a chance of becoming a model for Chinese societies around the world if all local people make concerted efforts over the next 20 years; but 35 percent said they don't think Taiwan has this potential.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUNDER OF CHILDREN'S HEARING FOUNDATION DIES OF CANCER

TEXT.P: Joanna Nichols, founder of the Children's Hearing Foundation (CHF) in Taipei, died of cervical cancer at Veterans General Hospital in suburban Taipei Thursday at the age of 47.

Nichols, an American-born woman who married a Taiwanese businessman and had lived in Taiwan for the past 23 years, founded the CHF in 1996 to help local hearing-impaired children to escape from their worlds of quiet and enter the world of speech and communication.
Through her dedicated efforts, the foundation has become Asia's largest teaching service organization for hearing-impaired children. More than 1,000 Taiwan kids have benefited from its services.

The foundation offered free instruction in the Auditory-Verbal (A-V) approach, a therapy, or specially designed teaching method to help children with all degrees of hearing impairment to develop the ability to listen and to use verbal communication within their own families or communities.
Nichols and her husband decided to introduce the A-V approach to Taiwan after successfully using it to help their seriously hearing-impaired daughter develop listening, speech and language abilities.
The foundation has set up well-appointed classrooms in Taipei and Kaohsiung to offer young children one-on-one A-V teaching, all free of charge.
Nichols, who could speak fluent mandarin Chinese and Taiwanese dialect, is survived by her husband and two daughters.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, June 8, or the 17th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
632: Mohammed, Arab prophet and founder of Islam, dies in Mecca at the age of 62. At the age of 40, he began to preach as God's prophet of Islam as the true religion. Mohammed established a theocratic state at Medina after 622 and began to convert Arabia to Islam.
1809: British-born American writer and Revolutionary leader Thomas Paine dies in New York at the age of 72. He wrote the pamphlet "Common Sense" in 1776 arguing for American independence from Britain. In England, he published "The Rights of Man" (1791-1792), a defense of the French Revolution.
1810: German composer Robert Alexander Schumann is born. He is known particularly for his song cycles, piano works, and symphonies. A leading romanticist and a noted critic, he encouraged Chopin and influenced Brahms.
1845: Andrew Jackson, the seventh president of the United States, dies at the age of 78. As a general in the war against the British, he defeated British forces at New Orleans in 1815. As president, he opposed the Bank of America and increased presidential powers.
1916: British biologist Sir Francis Crick is born. Along with James D. Watson, he proposed a spiral model -- the double helix -- for the molecular structure of DNA. He shared a 1962 Nobel Prize for advances in the study of genetics.
1921: Suharto, former president of Indonesia, is born.
1928: The National Revolutionary Army, led by commander Chiang Kai-shek, conquers Beijing in its Northern Expedition, formally ending the civil war in China.
1940: The German battle cruisers Scharnhorst and Gneisenau sink the British aircraft carrier Glorious and the destroyers Ardent and Acasta in the Arctic Sea. At least 1,500 men are lost from the three ships.
1941: Israeli military leader and politician Moshe Dayan loses his left eye while serving in the British army when his telescope is shot by French troops under the Vichy regime during World War II. Dayan later directed the 1956 Sinai campaign and the 1967 Six-Day War.
1942: Japanese submarines and aircraft attack Australia, striking at Sydney and Newcastle.
1945: The government of the United States declares that in accordance with the Joint Declaration of the Cairo Conference, Korea is permitted to gain independence.
1948: Yu Yow-renn is nominated the Control Yuan's first president under the new Constitution of the Republic of China.
1969: U.S. President Richard M. Nixon meets the leader of South Vietnam on Midway Island and announces the withdrawal of 25,000 U.S. troops from Vietnam.
1973: The Federation of Asian Women's Associations opens its 6th general meeting in Taipei.
1973: Generalissimo Franco hands over Spain's premiership to Luis Carrero Blanco and remains as head of state.
1976: Wu Chien-hsiung and S.S. Chen, members of the ROC's Academia Sinica, win the U.S. National Medal of Science.
1976: The Fifth Sino-American Conference on mainland China opens in Taipei with nearly 100 scholars and experts from both countries participating.
1980: The ROC-Indonesian Cultural and Economic Association is established in Taipei.
1981: A 23-member delegation of the Japanese National Defense Association headed by Zenshiro Shiina arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1983: Taylor Wang becomes first Chinese-American astronaut.
1987: ROC Premier Yu Kuo-hua arrives in Singapore for a five-day visit as the guest of Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew. Yu also called on Singapore President Wee Kim Wee and other government officials.
1987: The governor of the ROC's Central Bank of China, Chang Chi-cheng, announces that the ROC's foreign exchange reserves have exceeded US$60 billion.
1995: Lee Teng-hui becomes the first ROC president to visit the United States, angering Beijing.
1996: Mainland China conducts a nuclear test explosion at the remote Lop Nor test site in northwestern Xinjiang Province.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui receives a delegation headed by Burkina Faso National Assembly Speaker Traore Melegue.
2000: Doctors at the Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in Kaohsiung carry out a successful 12-hour liver transplant operation, giving Wu Feng-ying, 50, a section of liver donated by her son, Lin Yun-ju, 24.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Men who, when they see what is good and honest, try to act up to it, and when they see what is bad and dishonest try to avoid it as if avoiding scalding water: Such men I have known and the expressions of such principle I have heard."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, M'LAND CURATORS MEET OVER 2,500-YEAR-OLD BRONZE ARTIFACTS

TEXT.P: Museum curators from across the Taiwan Strait are meeting in Taipei this week to bring together an assumed complete collection of 2,500-year-old bronze relics that were unearthed early last century and have been kept separately in Taiwan and mainland China since 1949.

After two years of contact between Taipei's National Museum of History and Henan Museum in northern mainland China, curators from Taiwan and the mainland have compiled and published a new catalogue of more than 100 bronze artifacts from the tomb of Prince Zheng who died more than 2,500 years ago during the Epoch of Spring and Autumn, which lasted approximately from 722 to 484 B.C.
It is the first time that curators and historians from both sides of the Taiwan Strait have worked together to produce a catalogue.

In addition to publishing the catalogue, the National Museum of History is also hosting the "Cross-Strait Symposium on the Bronze Artifacts from the Tomb of Prince Zheng in Xinzheng" for the purpose of presenting the results of their research.

Zhang Wenjun, director of Henan Museum, who is leading an archaeological team from Henan Province to take part in the symposium, said Prince Zheng's bronze relics, which have been separated for more than 50 years, can now finally "be reunited," thanks to the publication of the 216-page catalogue, which has not only served as a cross-strait bridge of friendship between people, but also as a starting point for more productive cross-strait cooperation in the new millennium.

Henan Province, with a continuous cultural heritage of eight thousand years, is located in the Central Plains of mainland China. Numerous archaeological sites mark the more than 20 dynasties that ruled in the region. The rich history and abundant artifacts enrich the mysterious charm of this prosperous land.

Over the past century, archaeological work in the province at numerous ancient sites and tombs has led to the discovery of more than 1 million artifacts reflecting the splendid cultural development and politics of the various historical periods of the region.

The Kingdom of Zheng, established by Prince Zheng during the Spring and Autumn Period in the Xinzheng area of Henan, lasted for 390 years before perishing at the hands of the Kingdom of Han in 375 B.C.

In 1923, many bronze relics from the Spring and Autumn Period were discovered at the tomb of Prince Zheng in Xinzheng. This discovery came five years before the first archaeological excavation in mainland China, at Anyang, Henan Province in 1928.
Although the bronze artifacts were not excavated in accordance with archaeological practice, the discovery was the only one to occur before 1928 where all the artifacts were kept together.

In 1927, the first catalogue relating to the discovery was published by director Guan Baiyi of Henan Museum. Because the site of the discovery was well-known and easily accessible, the bronze artifacts found there became the standard reference in research into bronze artifacts of the Spring and Autumn Period.

The collection of more than 100 relics has experienced two long distance journeys due to two wars in the first half of the 20th century. During the second journey, one portion of the collection was moved to Taiwan in 1949, while the other remained in mainland China. The two portions of the collection have remained separated since then.

The Xinzheng bronze artifacts from Prince Zheng's mausoleum, including wine pots, cooking vessels and musical instruments, inherit the solemnity and strength of the West Zhou Period and express the fairness and liveliness of the Spring and Autumn and the Warring Periods, according to Director Zhang.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESSMAN CALLS ATTENTION TO PLA'S RECENT MILITARY MANEUVERS

TEXT.P: U.S. Rep. Mike Pence (R-Ind.) on Wednesday called his congressional colleagues' attention to the recent military maneuvers by Communist China that "appear to threaten Taiwan."
Speaking on the House floor, the radio talk show host-turned congressman said: "Let China hear that in this Congress, we will stand with those who will stand for liberty."
He pointed out that the People's Liberation Army's response to nearly every political development seems to be to increase its military posture.
"I wonder, Mr. Speaker, what is the People's Republic of China afraid of," Pence asked.

"To my knowledge, during the modern era, there has never been a credible threat to the security of mainland China. The amphibious military training maneuvers currently underway are similar to 1996 exercises that resulted in a missile launch aimed at the Taiwan Straits," he pointed out.
The newly elected congressman reminded his colleagues that the United States responded to those live missile-firing exercises by deploying aircraft carrier battle groups to the region.
"Now, as then, the United States is committed to stability in the region," he emphasized.
"The threatening nature of these recent maneuvers and their proximity to Taiwan challenges the territorial stability of the island and the long-term peace of the region," Pence said.
The U.S. congressman then urged his colleagues to join him in monitoring the conduct of the Communist Chinese military in the coming weeks.
