DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTER SOLICITS SUPPORT FOR SPECIAL LEGISLATIVE SESSION

TEXT.P: Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang called on the Legislative Yuan Friday in order to solicit support for convening a special session so that several bills crucial to financial reform can be passed into law as early as possible.

The Legislature ended its most recent session Wednesday with a backlog of bills, including several key bills related to financial reforms. The next session is not scheduled to open until mid-September.
Yen, accompanied by Tsai Huang-liang, party whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, reaffirmed the importance of the six bills concerning financial reforms.

He said that with the support of the Legislature, the banking law has been revised and a bill on the merger of financial institutions has been signed into law, but he added that the six bills, including those concerning bill finance management, the establishment and management of a financial rehabilitation fund, and regulations concerning financial holding companies, have yet to be passed into law.
The setting up of a financial rehabilitation fund is aimed at helping banks write off mounting bad loans.
Yen said that the six bills are of major and far-reaching importance to the nation's overall economic development and social progress, and are crucial to luring foreign investment to the island.
Yen, who is due to travel to Europe later this month to solicit investment, said failure to pass the bills would have a harmful impact "beyond imagination."
He said that consultations on the six bills has been completed in the legislature and that they are now only waiting to be passed into law.
He urged legislators from across the political spectrum to support the convening of a special session to facilitate the early passage of the six bills into law.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were higher on Friday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for June moved up 85 points to close at 5,240, with 8,605 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for July rose 70 points to finish at 5,230, with 129 contracts transactions, while September futures increased 56 points to close at 5,232, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TTAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 5,155 for June, 5,160 for July, 5,176 for September, 5,167 for December, and 5,209 for next March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
June TE futures moved up 5.95 points to close at 269, with 1,950 ccontracts transactions, while July TE futures rose 4.15 points to finish at 267.95, with 37 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
June TF futures moved up 5.2 points to finish at 673.6, with 603 contracts changing hands, while July TF futures increased 11 points to close at 672.4, with only one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PILGRIMS MAKE 1ST DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT VOYAGE VIA KINMEN

TEXT.P: The direct "mini three links" program set yet another record Friday when a group of pilgrims from Taiwan's Yunlin County sailed across the Taiwan Strait directly to mainland China's Xiamen via this frontline island of Kinmen.

The 363-member pilgrimage group sailed from the southern Taiwan port of Kaohsiung via a ferry boat to Kinmen early in the morning, and the boat continued its voyage to Xiamen with the same passengers aboard after a two-hour transit stop at Kinmen's Liaolo port.

This was the first time that Taiwan residents were allowed to made a direct voyage to mainalnd China via the Republic of China-held offshore defense outpost since the opening of the direct cross-strait "mini three links" at the beginning of this year.

The pilgrimage group was organized by the Taoist Chupao Temple in Mailiao, Yunlin County. Wei Jung-hui, head of the temple's management commission, said the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), approved the group's application for a direct cross-strait voyage via Kinmen on an experimental basis.

The Chupao Temple is dedicated to a live-saving deity known as Paosheng. An icon of the folk deity worshipped in the temple was taken from Fumei Temple in Chuanzhou in the southeastern mainland province of Fujian to Mailiao 290 years ago.

"We have organized the pilgrimage group to accompany the icon to make a visit to its home temple in Chuanzhou," Wei said, adding that all pilgrims were excited at making the maiden direct voyage from Taiwan to the mainland via Kinmen. "The direct shipping service has allowed us to halve travel time and cost," he added.
The group will make a similar direct voyage from Xiamen to Kaohsiung via Kinmen after wrapping up its current five-day pilgrimage and sightseeing trip on June 12.

As part of its efforts to show goodwill toward mainland China, the ROC government opened its two outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu for direct trade, mail and shipping links with mainland China's port cities of Xiamen and Mawei in Fujian province Jan. 1.

This "mini three links" program was originally designed to benefit only Kinmen and Matsu residents. But the ROC government has decided to gradually expand the scope of its implementation to pave the way for eventual opening of full-fledged direct cross-strait "three links."
Friday's historic direct voyage from Kaohsiung to Xiamen via Kinmen for religious purposes was part of the MAC's plan to expand the role of the "mini three links" program, government sources said.

Beijing has been reluctant to throw full support behind the ROC-initiated "mini three links" program. For the past six months, it has approved applications for direct Kinmen-Xiamen and Matsu-Mawei voyages only on a case-by-case basis. And only a few group of mainland visitors have so far made direct voyages from Xiamen or Mawei to the two ROC offshore defense outposts.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKS AS EIGHTH BEST PLACE IN WORLD TO START BUSINESS: FORBES
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 7 (CNA) (By Jennifer Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has been ranked by Forbes magazine as the world's eighth best place to start a business.

In its latest survey of the investment climate in major economies around the world, Forbes wrote in its latest issue that the United States tops all nations around the world as the best place to start a business, followed by Singapore and Hong Kong.

The top 15 best nations or areas within which to start a business were found to be the United States, Singapore, Hong Kong, Ireland, Britain, Belgium, Australia, Taiwan, Finland, the Netherlands, Germany, Japan, Sweden, Spain and Malaysia, in that order, according to the Forbes survey.
In terms of business start-up costs, Britain topped the list with the lowest costs, while Taiwan ranked sixth in the world and first among all Asian nations and areas surveyed.

In terms of capital acquisition, the United States topped the list as the easiest place in which to acquire capital and funds, while Hong Kong finished at the top of the list among Asian nations and areas. Taiwan ranked 11th in the world in this field, while mainland China ranked 21st.

On the issue of taxation of personal income, Singapore, Hong Kong and Mexico tied for 1st with a personal income tax rate of zero percent, while Taiwan ranked 18th overall. Germany, with a prohibitive personal income tax of 49 percent, finished far down the list in this category.

The Forbes survey found the United States to be the world's most competitive country in terms of business, followed by Singapore, which topped all Asian countries and areas. Taiwan was ranked as the 18th most competitive in terms of business while Poland finished at the bottom of the list.

On the average number of days spent on red tape to obtain a business license, Australia demonstrated the highest efficiency, with only three days required. In Taiwan, obtaining a business license requires 46 days on average, compared with Hong Kong's 41 days, Singapore's 36 days, Japan's 50 days and mainland China's lengthy 110 days. The worst country in this area was found to be Italy, where at least four months are required on average, according to the magazine.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMMUNIST CHINA SAID TO HAVE TEST-FIRED NEW CRUISE MISSILE

TEXT.P: Communist China test-fired a new air-launched cruise missile (ALCM) for the first time last month, the Washington Times reported Friday, quoting unnamed U.S. intelligence officials.
The paper called the weapon "Beijing's answer to the ship-launched U.S. Tomahawk (cruise missile)." It is mainland China's first land-attack cruise missile.

The report quoted officials familiar with the test as saying that the ground-hugging, air-to-surface missile was launched from a B-6 bomber and that the test was deemed successful by U.S. defense and intelligence agencies.
The missile is believed to be capable of carrying a 1-ton high-explosive or nuclear warhead to an unknown range, according to the report.

Military analysts said mainland China has been working secretly on the new weapon, which is an extended-range version of the C-802 anti-ship cruise missile. The missile is said to be powered by a turbojet engine and is expected to have a range of at least 170 kilometers.

Richard Fisher, a specialist on the Chinese military with the private Jamestown Foundation, told the paper that the new ALCM will have a "substantial range" and will be fitted with television-camera precision guidance.

Fisher said that the new missile has been dubbed variously the "Hong Niao," meaning "Red Bird," and "Chang Feng," or "Long Wind." The missile is said to be a hybrid of three missiles: the Russian Kh-55 cruise missile, the Tomahawk -- obtained clandestinely from the United States -- and a cruise missile purchased from Israel.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP URGES TAIWAN PUBLIC `NOT TO BE FOOLED' BY BEIJING

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu urged the Taiwan public Friday not to be "confused," or "fooled," by Beijing's leaders on issues of the "one China" policy and the PLA's increased deployment of missiles targeting Taiwan.

According to a recent report, Beijing has said that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can start talking about mainland China's removal of missiles away from the coastal province of Fujian if Taiwan "returns to the `one China' framework."

Commenting on the report, Lu said that if the "one China" referred to by Beijing is the People's Republic of China, the truth of Beijing's hegemony and bellicosity toward Taiwan is even more threatening than real missiles.

Lu called for the Taiwan public not to be "confused" by the reports. Instead, she said, Taiwan's people and government should be firm on its stance. "The Fujian missiles will not take a toll on Taiwan's economy," she stressed.

It was reported that mainland Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Zhang Yuxi said Thursday that as long as Taiwan recognizes the "one China" principle, the two sides can talk about virtually "everything," including the issue of missile deployment.
Lu said Zhang's reported remarks could be a reaction to her continual calls over the past several months urging Beijing to remove its threatening missiles aimed at Taiwan.
According to Lu, Beijing used the "one China" principle as a "shield." But if by "one China" Beijing means the PRC, the motive is far more threatening that missiles, she pointed out.
Lu added that she believes the 21st century will be "a century of peace when no wars should be allowed to occur."

DOC.HEADLINE: N.T. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.012 against the U.S. dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Friday, closing at 34.053.
The local currency opened Friday at 34.029 and was traded between 34.029 and 34.085.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$343.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARENTS RECEIVE DIPLOMA ON BEHALF OF DEAD SON

TEXT.P: The parents of the late Taipei High School freshman Lee Hao-wei received an honorary diploma Friday awarded to Hao-wei posthumously in recognition of the boy's courage and bravery two years ago when he saved two junior high students from drowning.

A good swimmer since childhood, Hao-wei leapt into a swollen river in suburban Taipei to save two male students who were close to drowning. He became exhausted and drowned when trying to save a third victim.
Hao-wei's parents attended what would have been their son's commencement and received the diploma presented by the principal of the high school.

An emotional senior Lee, who was invited by the school to make a speech to the commencement ceremony, said that both he and his wife were sad on the special day, but even more pleased to be able to remember Hao-wei's selflessness toward his fellow men.
Lee said the two students that Hao-wei saved have visited the Lee home frequently, which has helped he and his wife feel less lonely.

In recognition of the young man's great sacrifice, the government last year placed a memorial tablet to Hao-wei in the Martyrs Shrine -- the top spiritual mausoleum of select citizens who are considered to have made invaluable contributions to the nation and the people by sacrificing their own lives -- making him the youngest person to be remembered at the national tomb.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAY STOCK EXCHANGE TAX REVENUE SETS RECORD LOW

TEXT.P: Local stock exchange tax revenue in May totaled NT$4.3 billion, setting a record low for this year, according to statistics released Friday by the Ministry of Finance (MOF).
The statistics also show that land tax revenue fell to NT$4 billion in May, setting a new low since December, 1990.

Hsu Kuo-chung, director of the MOF's Statistics Department, attributed the drop in tax revenue to the recession in the local real estate market and stock exchange, noting that many people are renting accommodation rather than buying homes, which has affected land tax revenue.

As for the local stock exchange, he went on, both transaction volume and value also shrank in May, with transaction value averaging just NT$51.1 billion per day and dealing a heavy blow to the stock exchange revenue.

The national tax revenue totaled NT$224.6 billion, a decrease of 2.4 percent compared with the level of the previous year, of which the stock exchange tax revenue fell by 53.4 percent, the business operation tax fell by 8.2 percent and the land tax fell by 44.4 percent. Income tax, however, increased by 8 percent.
Other tax incomes were broken down as follows:
-- Import/export duty revenue totaled NT$7.9 billion, a decrease of 15.9 percent;
-- income tax revenue reached NT$103.4 billion, an increase of 8 percent; and
-- business operation tax revenue amounted to NT$40.1 billion, a decrease of 8.2 percent.

The fiscal 2001 tax revenues had accumulated to NT$659.5 billion as of May, a decrease of 6.1 percent compared with the year-earlier level, of which central government tax revenues reached NT$470.7 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANCER REMAINS TAIWAN'S TOP KILLER: DOH

TEXT.P: Cancer remained the top killer in Taiwan last year, with a total of 31,554 people dying from various forms of the disease, the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) said Friday.

It is the 19th consecutive year that cancer has topped the list of causes of death in Taiwan. In 2000, one local citizen died from a malignant tumor every 16 minutes and 39 seconds on average, compared to every 17 minutes and 38 seconds a year earlier.
And as Taiwan's population ages, DOH officials said, the number of people who died from kidney ailments also increased significantly last year, although fewer people died from hypertension.

Among the various forms of cancer, lung cancer claimed the largest number of lives last year, followed by liver cancer, colorectal cancer, stomach cancer, breast cancer, cervical cancer, oral cancer and prostate cancer, in that order.
For men, liver cancer was the number one killer in 2000, but lung cancer accounted for the largest number of malignant tumor-related deaths among women.

Compared with the 1999 figures, the annual growth rates of lung and liver cancer-related deaths dropped in 2000, but the fatalities from oral cancer, prostate cancer, ovarian cancer and pancreatic cancer all grew at a rate of more than 10 percent.
According to DOH statistics, the average age of local men who died from cancer last year was 65.15 years, slightly older than the average age of 64.44 years for women.

Stroke came in second on the top 10 killers list, followed by heart disease, accidents, diabetes, liver ailments, kidney disease, pneumonia, suicide, and respiratory diseases, including bronchitis and asthma.

While the death tolls from cancer, stroke, diabetes and suicide continued to rise last year, the casualties from heart disease, accidents, chronic liver ailments, pneumonia and bronchitis all dropped from the year-earlier levels.
The death toll from heart disease has declined steadily for the past eight years and pneumonia fatalities have fallen continuously over the past two years.

A noteworthy development was that tuberculosis made the top 10 killers list for local men for the first time last year. Meanwhile, a total of 1,214 children aged between one and 14 died last year, with 39.21 percent of them killed by accidents. Accidents also accounted for more than 60 percent of deaths among adolescents and young adults.

DOH tallies also show that the life expectancy of local people increased further last year, with that for men reaching an average of 72.63 years and the average life span for women surging to 78.3 years.
Since the national health insurance program was launched in 1994, male life expectancy has extended by 2.7 years and female life expectancy has risen by 2.2 years.

A total of 124,481 people died last year, translating into a death rate of 561.12 out of every 100,000 people, slightly lower than the 1999 level. A major cause of the higher 1999 death rate was the devastating 9-21 earthquake that claimed more than 2,400 lives around the island.
Although suicides overall did not post any significant growth, the number of people over the age of 65 who took their own lives increased sharply.
Meanwhile, the infant mortality rate continued to decline, with an average of five newborns dying each day last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FABIAN SOCIETY FOUNDED

TEXT.P: A political alliance in the spirit of Britain's "Fabian Society" was formed Friday by a dozen founding members, including two chairmen of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and a former justice minister.
The Fabian Society, a society formed by British intellectuals in the late 19th century, exerted an important influence over the government of the time.
Former DPP chairmen Shih Ming-teh and Hsu Hsin-liang, former Justice Minister Liao Cheng-hao and 10 others served as the conveners of the alliance, dubbed "The Mountain."

A declaration titled "We Only Have This Home," was read at the formal launch of the alliance. Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, legislators across the party spectrum and several government officials were on hand to greet its opening.

The declaration notes that current political figures lack the habit of reflecting on their power and adds that the current government is the result of a political changeover under a democratic system, of which the public harbors great hope and expectations.

But one year after the inauguration of the Chen Shui-bian administration, the public is disappointed as it sees no national direction but only lust for power and political scheming and maneuvering for the short-term interests of politicians, according to the declaration. The public does not see any efforts being made to establish a system of checks and balances, but only political figures trying to shirk their responsibilities, it says.

Chief convenor Shih, an incumbent legislator, said that he suggested to Chen March 20, 2000 after Chen's victory in the presidential election that he should form a majority alliance in the legislature. He later suggested that Chen address squarely the worsening economic situation and again expressed the hope that the government should stick to the Constitution and form an alliance government through party-to-party negotiation. None of his suggestions were accepted, he noted.
Shih said that he and others from various walks of life have therefore decided to step forward to advocate rationality and to try to point the way toward national development.
Hsu stressed that the biggest crisis facing Taiwan is "the determined efforts to do something in total disregard of a system, the right direction or objective reality."
Saying that Fabian Society charted the direction of Britain in the late 19th century, "The Mountain" alliance added that it hopes to follow suit in Taiwan.

In addition to Shih and Hsu, alliance secretary-general Jaw Shau-kong and spokeswoman Sisy Chen, other conveners include Schive Chi, former vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, former vice presidential candidate Wang Chin-feng and art professor and director Stan Lai.
Chen said that in future, the alliance will present their suggestions on national affairs as its main pedestal and will complement this by taking part in local politics.

She said the participants come from all walks of life, including those who have departed or partially retired from politics, as well as some who have never been involved in politics, who are participating because they want to contribute something to their "only home." They will constantly remind themselves that they will not serve as the tool of any political power, she added.
Chen said the alliance will recommend to the public good candidates of all political persuasions in the year-end legislative and county and city chief elections.
But among the 12 participants of the alliance, only Shih and former minister Liao are likely to run in the elections.
Chen said that the aim of the alliance is not to form a group for political power, but to provide a rational view and "commend excellent political figures."

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT TO VISIT CORNELL UNIVERSITY
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 7 (CNA) (By David Wang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui will return to his alma mater Cornell University for a private visit June 26-28, according to a Thursday press release from the university.

The press release said that Lee, who received his Ph.D. in agricultural economics in 1968, will visit his granddaughter, who is also studying at the university, although it added that details of the visit are still being processed.

The university also confirmed that in order to pay tribute to Lee as "an outstanding alumni," Cornell will announce the establishment of the Lee Teng-hui Institute for Scientific Research during his visit.
Cornell also set up in 1994 a Lee Teng-hui Professorship of World Affairs to pay tribute to Lee, then ROC president, using US$2.5 million donated by Lee's friends in Taiwan.
Lee is scheduled to travel to Ithaca, New York via Los Angeles June 24.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT HAS HIGH EXPECTATIONS FOR KMT: PARTY SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: Former President and Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lee Teng-hui still has high expectations for the party, KMT spokesman Wang Chih-kang said Friday.

Wang also said that a Thursday meeting between Lee and KMT Chairman Lien Chan was conducted in a good atmosphere, and he quoted Lee as telling Lien that "although there have been some misunderstandings, they are all in the past."

According to Wang, the meeting was the first between the two men since Lien's release from a two-week hospital stay. The KMT spokesman added that Lee had phoned Lien several times to express his concern during that time and that Lien thought it necessary to thank Lee following his recovery and prior to leaving Sunday for a trip to Europe.

Regarding Lee's remarks in a recent magazine interview that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will win 85 seats in parliament in the election slated for December and that it will form a majority alliance in the legislature with another 35 lawmakers who share the DPP's ideals, Wang said the comments can serve as encouragement to the opposition parties.
"Lee's remarks should remind all the opposition parties that they should continue to seek progress and win public confidence," Wang noted.
But he stressed that the KMT would also control a majority of seats in the Legislative Yuan should it win 85 seats in the year-end election and cooperate with other parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNET CAFE OWNERS FORM ASSOCIATION FOR SELF REGULATION

TEXT.P: Local Internet cafe owners have formed an association that will establish self-regulatory guidelines, it was reported recently.

The association was formed in response to the fact that Internet cafes and online gaming are booming in Taiwan, and like everywhere else in the world, the authorities find it difficult to supervise their operations.

Initiators of the association said that some Internet cafes use pornography and gambling to lure customers, not only damaging the image of the sector as a whole but also threatening the normal operations of the business.

Since the authorities have failed to work out any measure to regulate the business, the association plans to invite lawyers and software houses to jointly set up a screening group. Internet cafes which can fulfill the requirements of the group will be issued a certificate.
The screening group will check on the facilities, including emergency exits and non-smoking areas, as well as juvenile protection enforcement at the Internet cafes.

A survey conducted by the Taipei city government shows that 34 percent of the people polled said that they, their friends or their relatives have visited Internet cafes, 53 percent of whom go to play online games.
Although about half of those polled said they would welcome the establishment of more Internet cafes, almost everyone spoke of the urgency of finding ways to eliminate their negative impact.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INDUSTRIAL LEADERS VISITING MOSCOW
DOC.DATELINE: Moscow, June 7 (CNA) (By Chang Hung-kuang & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A group of Taiwan hi-tech firm executives are currently in Moscow on a fact-finding tour with an eye to seeking trade partners in Russia.
The group, led by Industrial Technology Research Institute President Chintay Shih, visited academic facilities to seek opportunities to tap into Russian technology to promote Taiwan's industry.
The 30-odd strong delegation, which arrived in Moscow in two groups May 25 and May 30, is also expected to explore the possibility of developing Taiwan's Russian market, according to Shih.

He said Russia is well known for its basic scientific research, while Taiwan is very sensitive to trends in the world market. If the two sides can supplement each other with their respective strengths, it would serve the interests of both, Shih pointed out.
Shih and his delegation will leave Moscow Sunday to return to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPUTEX 2001 COMPUTER SHOW ENDS WITH HIGHER ATTENDANCE FIGURES

TEXT.P: The 21st Taipei International Computer Show -- Computex Taipei 2001 -- wrapped up Friday following a five-day run at the Taipei World Trade Center.

The show attracted a total of 23,306 foreign buyers this year, up 1.94 percent over the 2000 level, according to the semi-official China External Trade Development Council (CETRA), the organizer of the annual event.
According to CETRA tallies, Japanese buyers outnumbered visitors from other countries and were followed by those from the United States, South Korea, Hong Kong and Singapore.

CETRA officials said information application and wireless communication technology made up the majority of products at the show. The 22nd Taipei International Computer Show is slated to be held June 3-7 next year at the same venue.

DOC.HEADLINE: MALAYSIAN PARLIAMENTARIANS VISIT KINMEN

TEXT.P: A five-member Malaysian parliamentary delegation led by Wira Abu Seman, chairman of the Malaysian Parliament's Law and Foreign Relations Committee, visited Kinmen Friday.
They first called at Kinmen County Hall and were welcomed by Weng Ting-wei, secretary-general of the Kinmen County Government.

They were briefed on the Republic of China's system of military government during the time of conflict with mainland China and the transfer of administration to civilians of Kinmen and Matsu in November 1992. They also were informed of the opening of Kinmen's tourist market, as well as the ROC government's implementation of the "mini three links" with mainland China from the beginning of this year.
The "mini three links" refers to direct trade, transportation and postal service from the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu to certain destinations across the Taiwan Strait in Fujian province.
Beijing has taken a lukewarm attitude toward the "mini three links," but has stopped short of prohibiting mainland people from engaging in trade with people on Kinmen and Matsu.

Accompanied by county government officials, the delegation visited several scenic spots, a museum commemorating the artillery battle across the Taiwan Strait in 1958 and the famous Mashan Observation Post.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S MILITARY THREATS CANNOT FORCE ROC TO NEGOTIATING TABLE: MAC

TEXT.P: Mainland China's military threats and saber rattling cannot force the Republic of China to the negotiating table, a mainland affairs official said Friday.

Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, was responding to Beijing's claim that if Taiwan were to accept the so-called "one China" principle, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait could negotiate the removal of guided missiles deployed in mainland China's Fujian province, which lies opposite Taiwan.
Lin told a routine news conference that mainland China's military threats and attempts to catch Taiwan in a "rhetorical trap" are unacceptable to ROC citizens.
As far as cross-strait affairs are concerned, Lin said, goodwill, moderate talks would be more constructive and productive than rude, belligerent rhetoric.

"Previous experiences showed whenever mainalnd China tried to intimidate Taiwan in an unfriendly manner or with live-fire war games, such practices had consistently drawn backlash from the people of Taiwan," Lin noted.
In his view, Lin said the Hong Kong media hype on mainland China's ongoing routine military exercises on Dongshan Island off the Fujian coast might be counterproductive.
Lin further said it is regrettable that mainland China has so far not taken any concrete actions in response to Taiwan's continued expression of a great amount of goodwill toward the mainland.
Lin pointed out that since Taiwan and mainland China remain divided over the "one China" definitions, the two sides should sit down to discuss the issue.

Despite Beijing's snub of Taiwan's olive branches, Lin went on, the ROC government will not waver in its determination to boost cross-strait exchanges under the premise that Taiwan's security will not be compromised.

Among others, Lin said, the MAC is considering allowing products that have been shipped from mainland China's Xiamen and Fuzhou ports to Taiwan's Kaohsiung Harbor to be airlifted to Southeast Asian countries under the current framework of cross-strait offshore transshipping services.
Taiwan still bans direct cross-strait transport links. But it allows cross-strait offshore transshipping services to meet the demand of a large number of Taiwan investors in mainland China.

Under current cross-strait offshore transshipping regulations, mainland goods can be shipped directly to Kaohsiung for transshipment to third countries. Those products are banned from clearing customs or entering Taiwan.

At the request of Taiwan investors in mainland China, Lin said, the MAC is planning to allow combined sea-air transshipment services under the current cross-strait offshore transshipping framework in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMERICAN PRODUCTS TO FEATURE AT TAIPEI INTERNATIONAL FOOD SHOW

TEXT.P: American foods will be showcased at the 2001 Taipei International Food Show June 14-17 at the Taipei World Trade Center, the American Institute in Taiwan said Friday in a press release.

A 46-booth American food pavilion, organized by the institute's Agricultural Trade Office, will offer a variety of dishes from rice and Mexican food to seafood and blueberries. Many other foods common to those in Taiwan will also be featured like soybeans, soy milk and tofu.
There will also be a series of special seminars presented by the exhibitors.
Taiwan is the fifth largest market in the world for U.S. food and agricultural products.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN REMINDS BUSINESSES OF MAINLAND INVESTMENT RISKS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reminded local businesses Friday that they should not ignore possible risks while launching investment projects in mainland China.
Chen issued the caution during a community reach-out tour of Taoyuan County, some 40 kilometers south of Taipei.

Chen said some myths are prevailing in the local business community. Those myths include that mainland China is the only ideal investment destination and that opening of direct transport links across the Taiwan Strait is the only cure for Taiwan's current economic woes.
"While we should not overlook mainland China's development potential, we should also avoid turning a blind eye to possible perils or traps in its overall investment climate," Chen cautioned.

Noting that Taiwan's sustainable economic development over past decades lies in its enterprises' brilliant adaptability and their diversified business operations, Chen said local business people should not disregard Taiwan's own economic vitality.

"I'm convinced that with ambition, vision, ingenuity and concerted efforts of the private and public sectors, we would be able to revitalize our economy and even turn a new page in our economic development in the years ahead," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: BI AND WBSROC TO JOINTLY PROMOTE GLOBAL WILD BIRD PROTECTION

TEXT.P: Birdlife International (BI) and the Wild Bird Society of the Republic of China (WBSROC) announced Friday at the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture that they will jointly promote a global wild bird protection scheme dubbed "e-birds."

BI expert Richard Thomas and Liao Shih-ching, president of the WBSROC, said during the announcement that the e-bird activities will include a children's painting contest, a Web site design contest, a computer drawing contest and an exhibition on the conservation of the black-faced spoonbill and migrant birds, which will run until November.
In addition to Taiwan, more than 40 countries around the world will take part in the global wild bird protection activities.

According to the BI's official publication, one out of every eight bird species is threatened with extinction, while in the past 500 years, a total of 128 wild bird species has become extinct and more than 460 species will become extinct by 2100.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR TAIWANESE TOURISTS KILLED IN LANDSLIDES IN GUANGXI PROVINCE
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 8 (CNA) (By Edward Chen) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Taipei, June 8 (CNA): Four Taiwanese tourists were killed when their hotel was buried in a landslide triggered by heavy rains in Shuolong, Guangxi province in southern mainland China, near the border with Vietnam, mainland media reported Friday.
The reports said that two other Taiwanese tourists were injured.

The victims were part of a 60-member Taiwanese travel group from Taichung City which is currently on an eight-day tour of the Kueilin-Guangxi border area in Guangxi province, a spokesman for their travel agency said.
According to a mainland Chinese official report, landslides and flooding triggered by torrential rains have killed at least nine people and left 10 missing in southern China.

The official report confirmed that four Taiwanese tourists were listed among the victims. They were Hsu Ming-teh, Lin Ai-oh, Chen Feng-chin and Hsu Chuan-chuan. The two wounded were Lai Sheng-kun and Wang Yu-nu.

The report said that the group went to Tashin County, 200 kilometers south of Nanling, the capital city of Guangxi province, to visit the famous Tehtien waterfall and spent a night at nearby Tehtien Villa.

The report said that heavy rain since Tuesday had caused landslides and floods which buried the hotel. All communications have cut and officials in charge of flood and disaster-relief activities have been rushed to the scene.

DOC.HEADLINE: WARM-UP GAMES OF WORLD CUP BASEBALL TOURNEY TO BE HELD IN TAICHUNG

TEXT.P: The pre-tournament warm-up games of the 2001 World Cup Baseball Tournament for Taiwan, Cuba, Italy and Japan will be held in Taichung Nov. 1-3, organizers said Friday.
The original plan only lists Taipei, Kaohsiung and Chiayi as the sites for the World Cup matches.

Through the efforts of Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Tsai Ming-hsien (Taichung), officials from the Council for Physical Fitness and Sports, the Chinese-Taipei Baseball Association and the Education Bureau of the Taichung City Government agreed to hold the warm-up games in Taichung.
The November events will the first time for Taiwan to sponsor a World Cup baseball championship.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MEDICAL TEAM TO VISIT HONDURAS

TEXT.P: A Taiwan medical team will visit Honduras later this year or early next year for charity treatment, Legislator Chiang Yi-wen said Friday.

Chiang, who visited the Latin American country with President Chen Shui-bian recently, told reporters that the medical team will be organized by herself and Chang Chin-chien, the attending physician for Chen's wife from National Taiwan University Hospital.
Members of the team will consist of doctors from National Taiwan University Hospital and Catholic hospitals, she added.
According to Chiang, many people in Honduras are jobless and are poor and the cardinal in that country supports the idea of dispatching a medical team from Taiwan for charity work.
She said that the medical team will leave for Honduras either at the end of this year or early next year for a stay of one to two weeks.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN TOURS COPPER FACTORY, VOWS TO BETTER THE ECONOMY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that his vow to revive Taiwan's economy is no slogan and the government will live up to its promise.

Stressing that the opening of direct trade, transportation and postal links across the Taiwan Strait is not the only way out of Taiwan's current economic slowdown, Chen said that the government must display its full determination to the public. He urged local businesses not to underestimate Taiwan's own economic clout by cashing in on the mainland Chinese market.

"Of course mainland China is a promising market, but Taiwanese firms should not overlook the potential risks while deciding whether or not to invest there," he said, pointing out that "flexibility and diversification are the cornerstone of the stable developments of Taiwan's industries."
The president made the remarks during a visit to S&T Copper Industries Co. Ltd. in Yangmei near Taipei, the first stop of his one-day tour to local factories.
Saying that he was very touched by the strong ambition and vigor of local enterprises, Chen praised S&T Copper Industries for its important contribution to the island's industrial development.

With its advanced technology and comprehensive after-sale services, S&T Copper Industries has successfully transformed itself into Asia's leading copper plaque maker and the world's second-largest, despite the fact that Taiwan must import all of its copper, Chen said.

Lauding S&T Copper Industries' spirit of "breakthrough, renovation, and superior performance," he said that those are the values and principles of the so-called "knowledge-based economy," at a time when the country's industries are facing a critical juncture of rapid transformation.

Chen later paid a visit to nearby China Motor Corporation, where Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-i once served as a manager and was labeled as "Taiwan's Lee Iaccoca" by the local business community for his remarkable reforms of the company.

Comparing Taiwan to a small sports car, Chen said the country's future is bright as long as local industries pursue continued diversification and technology upgrading. He hailed China Motor as a good example which has created a new image for Taiwan's car industry.

The president further pointed out that he has full confidence in Lin, particularly because of his success in injecting a new lease on life into the ailing China Motor. Describing Lin's success as "no accident," he thanked Lin for leaving the highly-paid post in China Motor and devoting himself to the country.
"Reforms take time," Chen said, voicing his strong belief that Lin will do a good job in his current post if he is given a little more time and support.
The president also hailed Lin's performance in the recently-concluded ministerial meeting of the Asia -Pacific Economic Cooperation forum held in Shanghai.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANG JIN-PYNG SPEAKS ON EXTRAORDINARY SESSION OF LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: The president of the Legislative Yuan said Friday that the law-making body should not call for a special session to discuss bills that failed to pass in the regular session.
Instead, Wang Jin-pyng said that it would be more appropriate for the president to initiate the action with a specific purpose.

In an interview with Taiwan's Central News Agency, Wang said the Legislative Yuan remains passive in arranging an extraordinary session for fear that it might be misinterpreted as "an extension" of the fifth session.

"It is not proper for the Legislative Yuan to initiate the convention of an extraordinary session for the purpose of screening bills, and even when such a meeting is called at the request of the president, it is better to specify the purpose," Wang said.

The fifth session of the fourth legislature concluded at midnight Thursday. The next session will open in September. Since several bills which the administration considers urgent to the government's economic stimulus programs were still outstanding, the Executive Yuan hopes that an extraordinary session will be called during the summer recess to have the bills approved.

Although the Legislative Yuan can also call an extraordinary session if a petition is signed by one-fourth of its members, Wang said that without the consensus of all parties, the effort would be in vain.

An extraordinary session may also be called by the request of the president, but Wang said the Presidential Office has not made any such request to the Legislative Yuan. He believes that Premier Chang Chun-hsiung should ask President Chen Shui-bian to make the first move instead of having the Legislative Yuan take the initiative.

The Legislative Yuan has had its most turbulent days in the past year. The ruling Democratic Progressive Party is a minority and the opposition parties -- the Kuomintang (KMT), the People First Party, and the New Party -- are very diversified in their positions and opinions.

The public has been critical of the Legislative Yuan because of its inefficiency and the breakdown of coordinating between members and political parties. Wang said that one reason for the Legislature's weakness is the seemingly routine quarrels that break out on issues that are often trivial. This and the lack of coordination between parties is the main reason important bills have failed to be screened during the regular session.

Wang said that the ruling party's faction in the Legislature, the DPP, should be taking a responsible position for advancing the agenda even though it only came to power a little over a year ago and is inexperienced in many ways.
A new legislature will be elected at the end of this year and it is generally expected that none of the political parties will achieve an absolute majority.

Regarding the forming of a coalition government for political stability, Wang said most legislators, including quite a few DPP members, advocate negotiations on a party-to-party basis, although there has been speculation that the DPP is trying to recruit legislators of other camps to attain a legislative majority.
Wang said that there would always be speculation of this nature, but he personally doubted the possibility of an exodus of KMT legislators after the election.
"It is a very insecure expectation to base a political party's stability on the splintering of other parties," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DRUG TRAFFICKER EXECUTED

TEXT.P: A Taiwan drug trafficker known locally as one of the most infamous kingpins was executed Thursday night at the Taipei Prison, five years after he was arrested and escorted back to Taiwan from Thailand, police said.

Lee Yi-hsiung was the first drug trafficker who was put to death under the execution order signed by Minister of Justice Chen Ting-nan after Chen announced on May 20 the planned policy of scrapping the death penalty within three years.

Lee began drug trafficking between Taiwan and Thailand in 1986 when nearly one-sixth of the narcotics smuggled from Thailand to Taiwan came through Lee's channel, police said, adding that Lee had accumulated more than NT$1 billion (US$29.42 million) from trafficking until his arrest.
Lee was caught in May 1996 at a Thai village bordering Myanmar in a joint action carried out by Taiwan and Thai police. He was soon escorted back to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO OFFER 230,000 JOBS, SAYS CLA CHAIRWOMAN

TEXT.P: The central government will offer some 230,000 job opportunities in the coming months, said Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Chairwoman Chen Chu Friday.
Chen made the remarks while exchanging views with Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yu Cheng-hsien on the worsening jobless situation in that county.

As Kaohsiung County has topped the unemployment rating among the counties and cities for two consecutive months, Chen agreed to provide 2,000 emergency jobs for Kaohsiung County residents from the "Hope Project for Employment" for middle-aged and older jobless workers.
At the request of the county government, she also agreed to appropriate more funds for vocational training.

Chen noted that the central government will take various steps to provide some 230,000 job opportunities in the coming months as a way to counter the soaring jobless rate, which surpassed 4 percent in some counties and cities.
But she expressed the hope that the unemployed workers would be willing to take the first job that they find, rather than hold out for a better position.
"If the jobless workers are not willing to find work, the government's efforts will be in vain," Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR MEETS WITH VENICE GOVERNOR FOR COOPERATION
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, June 8 (CNA) (By Victor Lai) (By Tong Fang & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Venice, June 8 (CNA): Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou called on Venice Provincial Governor Giancarlo Galan shortly after his arrival in Venice Friday morning to exchange views on how to strengthen cooperation and exchanges between Taipei and Venice.
Lin Chi-cheng, ROC representative to Italy, accompanied Ma on his call to Galan.
Galan said that he has agreed with Ma's proposal to set up an artist exchange center and student exchange program in Taipei and Venice, respectively, to strengthen cultural interchanges.
Ma also extended an invitation to Galan to visit Taipei and Galan accepted the invitation with pleasure.

Meanwhile, Lin Chi-cheng, the ROC representative to Italy, proposed that Taipei set up direct air links with Venice. Galan described Lin's proposal as "very constructive" and said that he will submit the proposal to the local legislative branch and the central government for approval.
Later in the day, Ma also called on Venice Mayor Paolo Costa.
Ma presided over the opening ceremony of the Taiwan Pavilion at the 49th Biannual Venice International Fine Arts Exhibition which will run until November from June 10.
In addition to Taipei, more than 30 countries around the world are taking part in the five-month exhibition.
Ma is expected to return to Taipei Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND AFFAIRS COUNCIL TO ORGANIZE MEDIA MISSION TO U.S.

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) will organize a media mission to visit U.S. think tanks this month to understand more about American policy toward mainland China and Taiwan.
MAC Vice Chairman Lin Chong-pin told reporters Friday that the mission will consist of senior reporters covering mainland Chinese affairs and news about the development of cross-strait ties.
He said the mission will leave Taipei June 10 and visit New York, Washington and San Francisco for 12 days, adding that he will serve as advisor to the mission.

In addition to visiting important think tanks, Lin said that members of the mission will exchange views with American China experts, such as John Holden, Jerome Cohen, James Lilley and Robert Scalapino.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Four Taiwan tourists were killed and two injured in mudslide disaster in Guangxi.
The China Times:
The 2002 government budget would see a 2.6 percent decrease from this year's level.
The United Daily News:
Four Taiwan tourists buried alive by mudslides in southwestern mainland province of Guangxi.
The Liberty Times:
Subsidies for the elderly are not listed in the 2002 budget plan.
The China Post:
Attackers kills 8 children at Japanese school.
The Taiwan News:
Man attacks school in Japan, kills 8.
The Taipei Times:
KMT claims Lee-Lien rift has healed.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED NOT TO SET TRADE BARRIERS AGAINST TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan would feel more at ease in relaxing restrictions on mainland China-bound investment if Beijing is willing to make a public promise not to adopt unfair trade barriers against Taiwan companies, a senior official said Saturday.

Chen Po-chih, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), made the remarks while attending a seminar on Taiwan-U.S.-mainland China economic and financial relations in the era of new economy.

Chen said whenever Taiwan exports a large amount of certain products to mainland China, Beijing authorities tend to ask Taiwan-financed firms on the mainland to switch their orders for those items to mainland manufacturers or impose unfair administrative barriers to force Taiwan entrepreneurs to set up production lines on the mainland.
In Chen's view, this unfair trading phenomenon is not expected to stop after both sides of the Taiwan Strait are admitted to the World Trade Organization (WTO) in the near future.
Chen explained that Taiwan will join the WTO as a developed economy while mainland China will enter the world trade regulatory body as a developing economy.
Logically, Chen said, developed economies should assist developing countries in economic development by offering them preferential treatment.

"But this practice usually would give developing countries opportunities to impose unfair trade barriers. And Taiwan still cannot afford to do so because its per capita national income is the lowest among all developed countries," Chen said.
The Republic of China's top economic planner said he hopes all developing countries would refrain from abusing their power to create unfair market competition.
At present, Chen said, Taiwan's overall investment in mainland China accounts for 1 percent of the island's gross domestic product (GDP).

"As Taiwan still has a 2 percent excess savings rate, its mainland investment would not have a serious impact on the island's domestic capital supply. When the outbound investment ratio exceeds 2 percent of its GDP, Taiwan's domestic investment and economic development would be affected," he noted.

Chen further said Taiwan-U.S.-mainland China trade interdependence has grown and deepened steadily. "As mainland China has gradually become an important part of the global supply network, any political conflict in the region would certainly result in adverse economic impact," he explained.

According to Chen, the relocation of Taiwan's personal computer production lines to mainland China would not only hinder Taiwan's own economic development and high-tech industries but would also affect the U.S. computer industry which relies heavily on Taiwan's OEM (original equipment manufacturing) services.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SENATOR: CHEN'S VISIT TO U.S. 'DESERVES RESPECT'

TEXT.P: U.S. Senator George Allen (R-Va.) said Thursday that Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian's historic visit to the United States last month "deserves the notice and respect of the U.S. Senate."

Addressing the Senate floor, Allen pointed out that President Chen became the second democratically-elected president in Chinese history a little over a year ago, "and his election was certainly a milestone in Taiwan's continued adherence to democracy and freedom."
The newly elected senator stressed that "Congress has long supported democratic development around the world, and Taiwan is no exception."
He called today's Taiwan a notable model of rapid and successful democratic reform as well as an important U.S. trading partner that has maintained amicable ties with the United States for decades.

"What may not also be known is that Taiwan imports over 1.6 times as many goods from the United States as does the People's Republic of China. (Therefore) Taiwan is a vital economic partner for the United States," Allen noted.

He said Taiwan's economy offers its people one of the highest standards of living in Asia, including universal education, excellent medical care, and a well-developed social welfare policy. Moreover, Taiwan's Constitution guarantees full political freedoms and basic human rights to all citizens.
"As Taiwan continues its democratic development, President Chen and the people of Taiwan deserve our most sincere praise for their exemplary adherence to individual liberty and freedom," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: RELATIVES OF DECEASED TAIWAN TOURISTS RUSHING TO GUANGXI

TEXT.P: A total of 13 relatives of the four tourists from Taichung City who were killed in a landslide in the southwestern Chinese province of Guangxi Friday are on their way to the scene to help handle affairs in the aftermath of the tragedy.

The heart-broken relatives departed from Taichung at 7 a.m. for Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in northern Taiwan, where they took a plane to Hong Kong, from where they are scheduled to take another flight to Guangxi Province, arriving in the provincial capital at around 8:15 p.m.

From Nanning, the family members of the victims will then be taken by bus to the Detian waterfall resort in Shuolong township where the four members of a 60-member Taichung Travel group were buried alive at around 5:15 a.m. Friday while sleeping in their ground-floor rooms of the resort building they were staying at for the night.
Another two group members received injuries in the landslide triggered by torrential rains in the region over the past several days.
The heavy rains have caused landslides and mud flows which have been blocking traffic to the mountainous Shuolong area close to the Vietnamese border.
The other members of the Taichung Travel group escaped the sudden landslide unharmed as they were sleeping in rooms located on higher floors of the resort building.
Some of the tourists walked for more than two hours to Shuolong township for help after the landslide as all traffic routes were blocked and all communication channels were down by then.

At present, 56 of the tourists from Taiwan, including the two who were injured, are temporarily being lodged at a guest house run by the adjacent Daxin county government. The shocked tourists have not yet decided whether they will continue their scheduled eight-day Guilin-Guangxi tour.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, June 9, or the 18th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
68: Nero, emperor of Rome, stabs himself in the throat with a dagger and dies at the age of 31. His early reign was dominated by his mother, Agrippina the Younger. He had his mother and wife murdered, and he may have set the Great Fire of Rome in 64. His cruelty and irresponsibility provoked widespread revolts which led to his suicide.
1672: Peter I, Russian emperor known as "Peter the Great," is born. He extended Russian territory around the Baltic and Caspian shores, reformed the administration of the state, and founded St. Petersburg as a new capital.
1870: Charles Dickens, British writer known for his tales of Victorian life and times, dies at the age of 59. Immensely popular both then and now, his works include "The Pickwick Papers," "Oliver Twist," and "David Copperfield."
1898: The Ching court signs an agreement with Britain under which Hong Kong is leased to Britain from China for a period of 99 years.
1902: West Point graduates celebrate the 100th anniversary of their alma mater.
1916: Robert McNamara, American industrialist, is born. He was defense secretary during the Vietnam War, and president of the World Bank from 1968 to 1981.
1928: The ROC's Academia Sinica is established with Tsai Yuan-pei as its first president.
1940: The king and prime minister of Norway order their troops to stop fighting at midnight, surrendering to the Nazis.
1951: The judgment of the Nuremberg court is fulfilled in the United States as the noose slips over the head of the last Nazi condemned by the Nuremberg tribunal to hang for "crimes against humanity." In all, 24 of Hitler's top men were accused on a number of different counts. Twelve men, including Nazis Hermann Goering and Joachim von Ribbentrop, were given the death penalty.
1959: The United States launches the George Washington, the first nuclear submarine with Polaris missiles.
1967: Israel seizes the Golan Heights on the fifth day of war with Syria, Egypt, and Jordan.
1973: Lt. Gen. Richard M. Hoban, vice-commander of the US Air Force Logistics Command, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1974: Barbados Deputy Prime Minister Cuthbert Edwy Talma arrives in Taipei accompanied by his wife for a six-day visit.
1975: The Republic of China terminates its diplomatic relations with the Republic of the Philippines as Manila recognizes the mainland Chinese communist regime.
1976: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo changes four of eight ministers, three ministers of state and the secretary-general of the Executive Yuan. New ministers named are Walter Fei, finance; Lin Chin-sheng, communications; Wang Tao-yuan, justice; and Chang Feng-shu, interior.
1982: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo praises US President Ronald Reagan's call for a campaign to promote democracy and consign communism to the "ash heap of history."
1986: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs agreed to use the name "Chinese Taipei" when participating in the women's World Cup basketball championships in Moscow in August.
1989: In mainland China, show trials of the leaders of the demonstrations in Tienanmen Square begin in Beijing.
1991: Mount Pinatubo, a volcano northwest of Manila that had been dormant for more than 600 years, erupts and forces the evacuation of US troops from their airbase nearby.
1995: ROC President Lee Teng-hui delivers a speech titled "Always in My Heart," at his alma mater, Cornell University.
1996: Thailand celebrates the 50th anniversary of the coronation of King Bhumibol Adulyadej.
1996: Mainland China releases dissident Ren Wanding after seven years in prison for his role in the 1989 democracy demonstrations.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew appoints Yang Chao-hsiang, former vice minister of education and current chairman of the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission, to succeed Lin Ching-chiang as education minister.
1999: The Macedonian Embassy in the Republic of China is formally inaugurated in Taipei to facilitate bilateral exchanges.
2000: Republic of China Representative to Russia Chang Wen-chung confers a medal upon Oleg Lobov, head of the Moscow-Taipei Economic and Cultural Coordination Commission, in recognition of his contributions to Taipei-Moscow relations.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If you do not study poetry, you cannot make yourself agreeable in conversation. If you do not study the arts, you will lack judgment and taste."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN TELLS GRADUATES `SKY'S THE LIMIT'
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, June 9 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian told graduates during a commencement at National Sun Yat-sen University Saturday that "the sky's the limit" and that "one should never restrict oneself to boundaries set by others."

Addressing a full-house, Chen told a story about a drunken man who lost his key on the road home at night to metaphorically express that imposing restrictions on oneself is a pity. When the man in the story discovered he had lost his key, he began looking for it but failed to find it as he only searched the part of the road illuminated by a streetlight when in fact the key lay in the darkness just beyond the reach of the light.

Chen used another metaphorical story to urge graduates not to be pessimistic. In this story, a farmer watching from the banks of the Hudson River the launch of America's first steamship expressed his skepticism about the modern invention by saying "I don't think it will ever sail." When the steamship did in fact set sail successfully and began moving quickly along the river, the old man responded by saying that "I don't think it will be able to stop."

In order to urge the new graduates to never lose sight of their original aspirations, Chen conveyed yet another story, this one having once been told by the Republic of China's founding father Sun Yat-sen.

In this story, a laborer managed to buy a lottery ticket by using all of his savings. He hid the lottery ticket in the bamboo pole that he used to make his living as a punt pusher. One day, when he found out that he had won the grand prize, he became so excited that he threw the bamboo pole into the sea thinking that now that he was rich, he would no longer need it. Gone with the bamboo pole where the laborer's lottery ticket and his hopes.

Chen pointed out that the bamboo pole is similar to one's original ideals and the lottery ticket represents the hopes and desires for fame and fortune. He said that the pursuit of fame and fortune is not necessarily bad, but one should never lose sight of one's original ideals in the actual pursuit.

During the commencement ceremony, Chen bestowed the university's "Diligence Award" on two of the new graduates -- Chen Chu, chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs, and Su Chia-chuan, magistrate of Pingtung County. Both stalwarts of Chen's Democratic Progressive Party received their master's degree from National Sun Yat-sen University's Institute of Public Affairs Management.

DOC.HEADLINE: DECEASED GRADUATE AWARDED DIPLOMA POSTHUMOUSLY

TEXT.P: National Chengchi University (NCU) on Saturday awarded a diploma posthumously to an ethnic Chinese student from Malaysia who died two days ago in a landslide tragedy.

NCU President Cheng Jui-cheng said at a commencement ceremony that although Chung Wei-chieh, a senior in the university's Public Administration Department, has passed away, he deserves to receive the diploma in recognition of his years of effort and study.

Chung, accompanied by his parents, his girlfriend and her mother, was driving a compact car on a mountain road linking Taipei to the northeastern county of Ilan Thursday when a rock fell onto his automobile during a landslide. All five people in the car were killed in the tragedy.
Cheng said Chung's abrupt death has saddened many people. "He had been a diligent student. He was fully qualified to receive a bachelor's degree," he added.
The school reserved a seat for Chung at the commencement. A diploma and a bachelor's degree robe and hat were placed on the empty seat in memory of the deceased graduate.
Three of Chung's sisters and his uncle, who flew to Taipei from Malaysia Friday to handle affairs in the aftermath of the tragedy, attended the commencement on his behalf.
His elder sister said their parents had been proud of Chung's academic achievements and had thus especially traveled from Malaysia to Taiwan to attend his commencement.

The NCU's administrative division will help arrange a funeral for Chung. The bodies of Chung and his parents will be cremated in Taipei and his siblings will then bring the ashes back to Malaysia for burial.
The university has also opened a special postal savings account, No. 19580601, to receive donations from local residents to help Chung's family.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S SOVEREIGNTY CLAIM OVER TAIWAN NOT LEGALLY GROUNDED: LIN
DOC.DATELINE: Ilan, eastern Taiwan, June 9 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Beijing's unilateral claim of sovereignty over Taiwan is not grounded in any international law, a Republic of China diplomat said Saturday.

Lin Chin-ching, chairman of the Association of East Asian Relations, a quasi-official body in charge of relations between Taiwan and Japan, said Japan returned Taiwan to the ROC government after World War II and made the Taiwan Area, which also includes the offshore islands of Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu, part of the ROC territory.

The Beijing authorities, which have ruled the Chinese mainland since 1949 after a Chinese civil war, have not governed the Taiwan Area for a single day in history, Lin said, adding that their sovereignty claim over Taiwan at present is not legally supported by any article of the international laws.
Lin, formerly the top ROC representative in Japan, made the remarks during a speech at a seminar Saturday on the Prospects of Asia held at Fuo Kuang University in Ilan City.

Quoting historical facts, Lin said that in the Cairo Declaration signed on Dec. 1, 1943, by the leaders of the Allied countries, the return of Manchuria, Taiwan and the Pescadores (Penghu) was promised to the Republic of China, founded by Dr. Sun Yat-sen in 1911. The People's Republic of China was not even established until 1949, he noted.
On Oct. 25, 1945, Taiwan was formally returned to the ROC government by Japan, leading to the designation of the date as "Taiwan Retrocession Day" -- a national holiday until recent years.
In the Treaty of Peace between the ROC and Japan signed in Taipei in 1952, Japan evidently underlined the fact of its return of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinman and Matsu to the ROC government, Lin added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXTRA LEGISLATIVE SESSION REQUEST SHOULD COME FROM PRESIDENT: WANG

TEXT.P: Any request to convene an extraordinary session of the Legislative Yuan would come more appropriately from the president rather than from the Cabinet or lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, the speaker of the Legislative Yuan said Saturday.
Wang Jin-pyng, president of the Legislative Yuan, made the remarks in an exclusive interview with the CNA.

He noted that the Executive Yuan has requested an extraordinary legislative session in order to screen and pass bills which did not have the opportunity to be passed into law before the Legislature went into recess.
However, he pointed out that the Executive Yuan should ask the president to make a formal request to the Legislative Yuan for an extraordinary session.

The fifth session of the fourth Legislature concluded at midnight Thursday with only 42 bills being passed and dozens of others -- those involving financial reforms in particular -- still outstanding.
Premier Chang Chun-hsiung on Thursday morning made several calls on Wang and faction chiefs of the opposition parties in the Legislative Yuan in a bid to arrange an extraordinary session.

According to the Republic of China Constitution, there are two ways of convening extraordinary sessions of the Legislative Yuan -- either by a petition signed by at least one quarter of the 225 members of the Legislative Yuan or by a request from the president.

The issue of how the extraordinary session should be convened has been a focus of attention in recent days. The legislative alliance of the opposition camp has decided to discuss the issue next Monday.

Basically, the extraordinary session would be an extension of the Legislative Yuan's fifth session, Wang said, adding that he wondered whether the DPP caucus' signature-seeking move would gain support from the opposition alliance.

Wang insisted on his position that the president ask the Legislative Yuan to convene an extraordinary session, saying that the process will be more proper and reasonable and that bills will be screened more efficiently if the president calls for such a session.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPENING OF TAIWAN PAVILION AT VENICE EXPO MARRED BY ROW
DOC.DATELINE: Venice, June 8 (CNA) (By Tony Fang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The opening of a Taiwan pavilion at the 49th Biennial Venice International Fine Arts Exhibition was marred Friday by a row between the Venice city government and a local labor union.
The ceremony was originally scheduled to start at 5 p.m. Friday. Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou flew to Venice earlier in the day especially in order to preside over the Taiwan pavilion's grand opening.
The ceremony, however, was delayed by three hours because the planned site for the ceremony was occupied by members of a local oarsmen association.
The Italian labor organization regards the site as its own turf and feels any activities held there must first receive its consent.

To vent its anger at the Venice city government's approval of Taipei's application for staging an open-air pop concert at the site, the association stationed a boat in the area early in the morning and then mobilized its members to converge on the region to block any activities.

Italian police initially tried to persuade the union members to leave, but to no avail. After difficult negotiations between Venice city officials and union executives, the opening ceremony finally started after a three-hour delay.

However, a popular Taiwan rock band, led by singer-songwriter Chen Sheng, was still barred from performing on a specially designed stage. The band, which arrived in Venice Thursday, was forced to perform on the sidewalk of a nearby street.

Taipei Mayor Ma expressed his strong dissatisfaction with the Venice municipal authority's failure to resolve the problem of what he called the Italian labor union's unreasonable demonstration, which seriously hindered normal operations of the Taiwan pavilion.
Lung Ying-tai, director of the Bureau of Cultural Affairs of Taipei City Hall, said she was disappointed by the Venice city government's lack of operational efficiency.
Taiwan has participated in the biennial Venice arts show for many years. The 2001 exhibition will formally kick off June 10 and last through November.

DOC.HEADLINE: DGBAS CHIEF RULES OUT POSSIBILITY OF TAX RAISE

TEXT.P: Despite its financial difficulties, the government is unlikely to raise tax rates or levy any new taxes at the moment, a senior official said Saturday.
Lin Chuan, director-general of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS), made the remarks in a call-in radio talk show.

Lin said the government has consistently faced a NT$100 billion (US$2.94 billion) shortfall in its budget. "And Taiwan's current economic slowdown has further cut into the government's tax revenues," he noted.

Even so, Lin said, the possibility of the government raising tax rates is almost nil. "The domestic political reality would hinder any attempt to raise tax rates at the moment," the budget chief observed.
Lin went on to say what the government can do at present is to restructure the country's taxation scheme and rationalize overall taxation system.

In fact, Lin said, Taiwan has lowered, not raised, taxes in recent years. For example, the integration of personal and business income taxes and the lowering of business tax have cost the national coffers by NT$100 billion and NT$50 billion, respectively.
Asked whether government employees would get a pay raise next year, Lin said he couldn't answer the question until after the Legislative Yuan passes the relevant budget plan.
In reality, Lin said, the Central Personnel Administration has so far not come up with any plan to adjust the pay scale for civil servants and military servicemen.
As for the long-talked-about proposal to offer a NT$3,000 monthly subsidy to those aged over 65, Lin said the results of a government opinion poll show that proponents outnumber opponents.
"The DGBAS will respect the Cabinet's decision on whether to put the elderly subsidy proposal into practice," Lin said. The proposal is one of President Chen Shui-bian's campaign promises.
Lin further said the DGBAS is endeavoring to substantiate the "zero growth" budget principle to prevent continued swelling of government expenditure and curtail waste of public funds.

DOC.HEADLINE: THAI, TAIPEI ZOOS SIGN MEMORANDUM TO PROMOTE EXCHANGES OF ANIMALS
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, June 8 (CNA) (By Kuo Fang-chih and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Board of the Zoological Park Organization of Thailand and the Republic of China's Taipei Zoo signed a memorandum Friday to promote the exchange of animals between the two countries.
The signing ceremony was held in the lobby of the Board of the Zoological Park Organization of Thailand.

Sampan Panpat, a member of the Thai organization, and Chen Shan-lin, chief of the secretariat of the ROC representative office in Thailand, signed the memorandum on behalf of their respective countries.
Following the signing ceremony, the Taipei Zoo donated three Borneo orangutans to the Thai side, while the Thai side donated five sarus cranes and two greater hornbills to the Taipei Zoo.

Speaking at the ceremony, Chen thanked Krase Chanawong, a Thai minister without portfolio, and the Board of the Zoological Park Organization of Thailand for their efforts in pushing for the exchange of animals between the two countries. He said he believes further bilateral exchanges of animals will continue in the future.

In his speech at the ceremony, Sampan extended his gratitude to the Taipei Zoo for its donation. He said that through the Thai government's animal exchange programs with foreign countries, Thailand can expand the number of animal species at zoos around the country without having to spend a lot of money.
The Board of the Zoological Park Organization of Thailand comprises of five zoos in different locations around the country. The 60-year-old Dusit Zoo, located in Bangkok, has more than 1,500 animals.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE UNLIKELY TO RESUME WITHIN 3 YEARS: NP LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: New Party Legislator Elmer Fung, who is a leader of the New Alliance for Democratic Reform, said Saturday that it is unlikely that a resumption in cross-Taiwan Strait negotiations will be seen in the next three years.
He made the remarks while addressing a symposium in Taipei on "Presenting a Conscientious Suggestion to A-bian (President Chen Shui-bian)."
"As cross-strait relations have fallen into a freezing winter," Fung said, "I believe the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will not be able to resume negotiations anytime in the next three years."
The legislator noted that the on-going mainland Chinese military exercises on Dongshan Island "are mainly directed against the forces who support independence for Taiwan."

He went on to say that "President Chen has a very clear pro-independence inclination," adding that if war were to break out across the Taiwan Strait, Chen would have to bear most of the responsibility.

Negotiations between Taiwan and mainland China came to a standstill in July 1999 when then ROC President Lee Teng-hui redefined the cross-strait relationship as a "special state-to-state relationship."
