DOC.HEADLINE: MOST TAIWAN PEOPLE UNCONCERNED ABOUT BEIJING'S MILITARY EXERCISES: POLL

TEXT.P: Most people in Taiwan do not believe that Beijing will invade Taiwan in the next one or two years despite the frequent military exercises by mainland China, a survey showed Sunday.

The poll, conducted by Focus Survey Research Corporation, found that people asked about China's military exercises on the southeastern coast of the mainland mostly felt that there was nothing to worry about. Sixty-five percent said the war games would not impact the future of Taiwan.
Thirty-one percent, however, said they were concerned about the future of Taiwan. The remainder said they had no opinion on the subject.

The survey also found that up to 77 percent who responded do not think that Beijing will invade Taiwan in the next one or two years. Fewer than 10 percent believe Beijing will invade Taiwan in the next one or two years.

Asked about President Chen Shui-bian's attitude toward mainland China after his first year in office, some 47 percent said the president should maintain his approach toward cross-strait matters. Nearly 20 percent said the president should be tougher and 11 percent said the president should make more concessions toward the mainland.
The poll also found that the public supported Chen's recent five-nation trip to Latin American which included two stopovers in the United States.
Some 62 percent said that the trip helped raise the international profile of Taiwan, while 21 percent said it had no bearing on the issue.
About 54 percent were satisfied with his recent performance after his overseas trip; 37 percent said that they were not satisfied, and the rest said they had no opinion.
The poll surveyed those over 20 years old in Taiwan June 7-8 and respondents were contacted at random. The sample size was 1,023, with a margin of error of 3.06 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP SHOULD NOT PIN HOPES ON DIVISION OF OPPOSITION: WANG JIN- PYNG

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) should pin its hopes for a steady government on union with other parties instead of on the division of the opposition, said Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng.

In an exclusive interview with Taiwan's Central News Agency, the Kuomintang speaker of the legislature cast doubt over the prediction by former KMT chairman Lee Teng-hui that some 35 non-DPP legislators will switch their political support to the DPP if the ruling party increases its seats from 67 to 85 in the year-end elections.

Wang said it is difficult to estimate how many seats the DPP can win in the year-end elections, but non-DPP legislators who flirt with the idea of switching political affiliation should take into account whether they would be accepted by the DPP, what benefits they will get from the switch and how they should conduct their election campaigns in the future.

The basis of democracy is the cooperation between parties through negotiations and dialogue, a concept which is more reliable than seeking the support of independent legislators through exchanges of political benefits.

A ruling party which lacks the majority support at the legislature should cement their grip on power by forming a coalition with other parties, rather than by wishful thinking of the break-up of the opposition, Wang said.

He said the government and the ruling DPP should be partially to blame for the lack of efficiency of the Legislative Yuan in the last session which saw many urgent bills concerning the public interest mired in partisan bickering.

Wang said the DPP administration lacks the experience in shepherding their bills through the legislature and the DPP caucus at the Legislative Yuan often fails to consult thoroughly with its own party members and does not act in unity.

Recalling that former KMT vice premiers Hsu Li-teh and Liu Chao-shiuan often stayed at the Legislative Yuan to see party-sponsored bills going through the legislature when their party had a majority, Wang said the DPP government leaders appeared at the legislature during only the last few days of the legislative session.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARTY AFFILIATION LESS IMPORTANT IN YEAR-END ELECTIONS: SURVEY

TEXT.P: About 51 percent of Taiwan's eligible voters will gauge the capabilities and morals of candidates over their party affiliation in the legislative and local government elections slated for December, a recent survey has found.

According to the results of a telephone survey conducted by a consulting firm June 7-9, only 7 percent of the respondents will consider candidates' party affiliation in the year-end legislative elections.
Regarding the question of who should be held responsible for Taiwan's current political instability, some 21 percent said that "all parties concerned should be held accountable."

Around 12.3 percent think that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) should assume the responsibility for the country's present political situation, while 9.2 percent and 8.9 percent said President Chen Shui-bian and the Legislative Yuan are responsible. Some 5.2 percent and 4 percent are of the opinion that the leading opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the Executive Yuan are to blame.

As to the question of whether cooperation between Chen and former President Lee Teng-hui will help stabilize Taiwan's present political situation, 42 percent said they disagreed with that hypothesis, ahead of the 28 percent who thought cooperation could help.

At the same time, 34.9 percent said they think that cooperation between the KMT and the People First Party (PFP) will help stabilize the country's political situation, in contrast to 38.5 percent who disagreed with the view.
The DPP and the PFP were supported by 24.2 percent and 21.4 percent of respondents, respectively, while 12.8 percent and 24.9 percent backed the KMT or said they were neutral, the survey showed.

Lawmaker Chao Yung-ching said the survey results are very interesting and called for all political figures to realize that every one of them, including lawmakers, should take responsibility for Taiwan's current political disorder.

Chao said he believes that the "Lee, A-bian system" and the "KMT-PFP alliance" will increasingly take shape and probably lead to a competition between the two major camps. He urged the public to "open their eyes wide" to check whether there are "under-the-table deals being made by influence peddlers."

Lawmaker Chou Hui-ying said the results of the survey should serve as an alarm to all lawmakers preparing to take part in the December elections, as "candidates' personal capabilities are more important regardless of their party affiliation" to the majority of voters.
The sample size of the survey was 1,006, with a margin of error of 3.1 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIBERALIZATION OF TAIWAN COMMUNICATIONS INDUSTRY NEARING COMPLETION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's telecommunications industry will contribute NT$63.1 billion to the gross domestic product GDP) each year for the next five years after the telecommunications industry finishes its liberalization, an official of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) said Sunday.
Taiwan is scheduled to complete liberalization of its telecommunication sector in the second half of this year.

The official said that the MOTC is expected to open the market for G-3 cellular phones to the private sector and an international phonetic transmission business in the second half of the year, thus completing the liberalization of the nation's communications industry.
In order to make good on a promise made to the World Trade Organization (WTO), the MOTC has been liberalizing the telecommunications industry during the past few years.

Capital investment of local telecommunications industries will increase an average of NT$118.3 billion every year and contribute NT$63.1 billion to the annual GDP and create 77,216 new job opportunities in the next five years.

Statistics compiled by the Directorate General of Telecommunications under the MOTC show that the telecommunications industry has contributed NT$54.7 billion to the GDP per year during the past four years since the cellular phone was first introduced in Taiwan in 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMANIAN MINISTER OF COMMERCE AND INDUSTRY ARRIVING FOR VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Panama June 9 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Panamanian Minister of Commerce and Industry Joaquin Jacome Diez is expected to arrive in Taipei Sunday for a visit.

While in Taiwan, Jacome will hold a press conference at the Far Eastern Department Store Wednesday to introduce Panamanian-made products to Taiwan's customers. He will preside over the opening ceremony of the Panamanian Pavilion at the 2001 Taipei International Food Exhibition Thursday.
A total of 25 Panamanian manufacturers and traders are taking part in the 2001 food exhibition which will run June 14-17.

He will also call on Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi and visit the Board of Foreign Trade under the economics ministry, the semi-official China External Trade Development Council and an industrial complex in Tainan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA'S MISSILES NO.1 THREAT TO TAIWAN: LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: Guided and ballistic missiles deployed by mainland China targeting Taiwan pose the largest threat to the island within the next few years, a lawmaker said Sunday.

Parris Chang, a lawmaker of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and a military strategist, said the Republic of China's armed forces must further strengthen their air defenses and anti-missile capabilities.

Citing an assessment by the U. S. Department of Defense, Chang said an invasion of Taiwan by mainland China's amphibious units will be "the most dangerous and least possible option for Beijing," as the mainland's has several alternatives to use force against Taiwan, including blocking Taiwan's shipping lanes and ports and launching large-scale missile attacks.

Chang also stressed that Taiwan's top priority is to upgrade its monitoring and telecommunications technologies, as it takes time for the island to acquire advanced anti-missile equipment. With efficient early-monitoring facilities, Taiwan can improve its interception capabilities and improve its combat readiness.
Chang made the remarks at a seminar on Taiwan's security, which was attended by a dozen local experts and analysts.

Wu Ming-jie, a defense analyst, said mainland China will not resort to military attacks against Taiwan before 2010. He pointed out, however, that Taiwan cannot afford to risk ignoring its national defense.
Despite the fact that no war will break out in the Taiwan Strait, a strong national defense is still one of Taiwan's bargaining chips in cross-strait interaction, he noted.
J. H. Su, a U. S.-based researcher, suggested Taiwan build a military force strong enough to repel mainland China in the face of its repeated military threats against the island.

As the mainland has a comfortable advantage in the number of weapons and troops over Taiwan, Taiwan should seek to upgrade the quality and efficiency of its arms and military personnel and facilities, he added.

T. Y. Pan, an assistant professor at the Ching Yun Institute of Technology, proposed that Taiwan should iron out strategies to counter mainland China's saber-rattling based on ways which could end Beijing's ambition for hegemony and to stop its infiltration into Taiwan's "stable but complex" political structure.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, June 11, or the 20th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1727: George II of England accedes to the throne following the death of his father, George I, the first Hanoverian king of England.
1864: Richard Strauss, German composer, is born. He is known chiefly for his symphonic poems, such as "Don Quixote," and his operas, including "Salome."
1880: Jeannette Rankin, American reformer, pacifist, and politician, is born. A leader in the women's suffrage movement in Montana, she later was elected as a U.S. House of Representatives and was the only legislator to oppose American involvement in both world wars.
1898: A reform movement, initiated by Kang Yu-wei and Liang Chi-chao, gains the sympathy of Emperor Kuang Hsu but meets with strong opposition from the Empress Dowager Tzu Hsi. The movement came to an inglorious end after only 100 days.
1922: Li Yuan-hung resumes the presidency following the resignation of Hsu Shih-chang as president of the Peking government.
1940: Italian dictator Benito Mussolini declares war on the Allies.
1947: China protests to the Soviet Union against its invasion of Sinkiang.
1955: Twenty-two years of Liberal rule ends in Canada with the federal election victory of the Progressive Conservatives, headed by John G. Diefenbaker'.
1955: Horrified spectators witness the Le Mans racetrack in France become a scene of carnage when one of the cars competing in the 24-hour Grand Prix loses control and plunges into the grandstand, killing 85 people and injuring 200 others.
1963: Buddhist monk Quang Duc sets fire to himself in Saigon to protest the South Vietnamese government's treatment of Buddhists.
1968: The National Taiwan University Hospital announces that its first kidney transplant operation, performed on May 27, was successful.
1969: Soviet and communist Chinese troops clash on the Sinkiang border.
1972: Chen Ta-ching assumes the office of defense minister of the Republic of China.
1974: The opening ceremony of the 20th Asian Film Festival is held in Taipei and is presided over by Fredrick F. Chien, director-general of the Government Information Office. Nearly 400 performers, directors and producers attend the festival.
1976: China Airlines signs a US$86.4 million loan agreement with an international banking syndicate led by Citibank for the purchase of one Boeing 747SP, one 747, and three 737s.
1979: John Wayne, veteran Hollywood star, dies at the age of 72. Known as "Duke," the American actor played tough heroes in cowboy movies such as "Stagecoach," "Red River" and "True Grit," winning an Academy Award for his role in the latter.
1980: President Chiang Ching-kuo promulgates an order to resume in December the election of additional central parliamentarians, suspended Dec. 16, 1978 when the United States announced the severance of diplomatic relations with the Republic of China.
1981: A strong earthquake rocks Iran, killing more than 1,000 people and destroying the town of Golbaf in Kerman province.
1983: Zhu Jianhua, an athlete from mainland China, breaks the men's high jump record by clearing 2.37 meters.
1989: Michael Chang, 17, an ethnic Chinese American, beats Stefan Edberg of Sweden and becomes the youngest-ever winner of the French Open tennis championships.
1993: President Lee Teng-hui receives former Philippine President Corazon Aquino.
1995: International Business Machines of the United States purchases and merges with the Lotus corporation after investing US$3.52 billion.
1999: The United States, Japan, Korea, Taiwan and the European Union sign a new, multilateral joint statement on semiconductors designed to ensure fair and open global trading in the chips industry.
1999: The Chinese-Taipei taekwondo team returns to Taipei from the 1999 World Taekwondo Championships in Canada with two gold and four bronze medals.
2000: Officials from 30 Asian-Pacific cities reach an agreement at "the 2000 Asia-Pacific Cultural Summit" in Taipei to establish a mechanism for the promotion of cultural exchanges.
2000: An earthquake measuring 6.7 on the open-ended Richter scale hits the central Taiwan county of Nantou, injuring 16 people.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If you are considerate to others, you will win the hearts of the people. If you are trustworthy, men will trust you. If you are diligent, you will be successful in your undertakings. If you are generous, you will find plenty of men who are willing to serve you."

DOC.HEADLINE: CHANCE TO ADJUST BASIC WAGE SLIM: CLA

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) is not in favor of an upward adjustment in the basic wage this year in view of the sluggish domestic economy and rising unemployment rate.
CLA officials said the chances of an increase in the basic wage this year are slim considering the added financial burden it would impose on employers of foreign laborers.

As local workers generally receive salaries higher than the basic wage, the impact of an upward adjustment on them would be limited. However, as the basic wage is the standard for more than 320,000 foreign workers currently in Taiwan and is set as the reference for insurance premiums, their employers have expressed great concern about an upward adjustment.

CLA Vice Chairman Kuo Chi-jen said that as an increase in the basic wage would put an added burden on Taiwan businesses in a period of economic sluggishness, an appropriate time for an increase will not come before at least the end of this year.

Chen Sheng-hsien, director of the CLA's Department of Labor Standards, said that the review of a basic wage adjustment for this year has not yet been finalized and that the CLA hopes the labor and the management can first consult with each other and discuss the issue.

Although the Council for Economic Planning and Development has proposed a downward adjustment, Chen said that the basic wage has only either remained the same or been adjusted upwards over the years and that the CLA is unlikely to propose a downward adjustment this year.

Each year since the inauguration of the CLA in 1987, the basic wage has either remained the same or been adjusted upward, with the latest increase coming in 1997. The basic wage was increased to NT$15,840 (US$465) that year and has remained the same since.

Labor officials said the CLA had originally planned to invite labor and business groups to meet in early June to discuss the issue of adjusting the basic wage. If no conclusion is reached within three months of the start of such consultations, the CLA will then convene a basic wage review committee to renew discussions, the officials added.

They pointed out that the meeting has for all intents and purposes been scrapped as the chairwoman of the CLA, Chen Chi, has said that this is not the appropriate time to discuss an adjustment in the basic wage.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP LAWMAKER CALLS FOR NEW MEASURES TO END CHAOS IN LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan should improve its inter-party consultative mechanism and raise the minimum number of legislators needed to form a caucus in order to put an end to chaos in the legislature, an opposition lawmaker said Monday.

Chou Hsi-wei, convener of the People First Party (PFP) legislative caucus, said outdated and unreasonable legislative regulations are to blame for the legislature's chaos and low operational efficiency.
"To improve the situation, the regulations governing the formation of party caucuses in the legislative assembly should be revised to cap the rapid increase of those groups," Chou said.

Under current regulations, five like-minded legislators can form a caucus in the legislature, far lower than the minimum figure required in other countries. For instance, the minimum number is 5 percent of the total number of legislators in Germany, at least 15 lawmakers in France and 20 legislators in South Korea.
In Taiwan's legislature, six political parties and groups are currently eligible to send representatives to attend inter-party consultations.
The six groups are the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), the Kuomintang, the PFP, the New Party, the Non-Partisan Alliance and the Cross-Party Alliance.

At present, an individual lawmaker must muster the support of at least 30 colleagues to present a legislative bill for discussion in the assembly, but political parties and alliances are exempt from this requirement and can freely initiate bills.

"And this is the root cause of disorder and chaos in the legislature," PFP legislative whip Chou claimed, adding that the legislature should raise the minimum number of legislators needed to form a political alliance to 5 percent of the total or at least 11 members.

"By so doing, we may be able to limit the proliferation of legislative caucuses and prevent a handful of lawmakers to sabotage rules of the game and hinder smooth operations of the assembly," Chou explained.

In addition, Chou said the legislature should also revise current regulations to prevent any single legislator from blocking the assigning of legislative bill to the steering committee for inclusion into meeting agenda or to relevant standing committees for first reading.

Moreover, Chou said, the legislature should also set a deadline for legislative caucuses of ruling and opposition parties to forge a consensus on some controversial bills. "If they cannot reach a consensus within the deadline, those bills should be put up for a vote in the legislative plenary session," he suggested.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTER SOLICITS SUPPORTS FOR SIX BILLS CRUCIAL TO REFORMS

TEXT.P: Minister of Finance Yen Ching-chang on Monday again solicited the support of legislators to convene a special session to pass six outstanding bills crucial to financial reform.

Yen was referring to the financial holding company bill, the bill on the establishment and management of financial rehabilitation and others which were left outstanding after the latest session of the Legislative Yuan, which ended in the middle of last week.

Yen said that the opening of Taiwan's financial markets is inevitable, adding that many international financial groups have become bigger and have begun entering other fields, and if the financial holding company bill cannot clear the legislature, then domestic financial institutions cannot compete with international financial groups.
Yen also said that if the financial rehabilitation fund is not established to help write off the mounting bad debt of local financial institutions, the problem will not be solved.
Yen said the problem needs to be handled urgently, noting that if the situation continues for another year, the government will have to pay extra costs of between NT$9 billion and NT$10 billion.

Yen urged the support of legislators and stressed that after passing the six key bills, if the national financial situation is still in poor shape, then it will be the responsibility of the executive branch.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MEDIA GROUP ARRIVES IN NEW YORK
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 11 (CNA) (By C. L. Tseng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A 15-member delegation of journalists from the Republic of China arrived in New York Monday to visit prestigious U.S. think tanks to get first-hand information about their views on relations across the Taiwan Strait.
Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, is accompanying the group on its current U.S. visit.
Lin said the visit is designed to offer opportunities for Taiwan journalists covering cross-strait affairs to interact with U.S. scholars and experts in relevant fields.

"We are hopeful that the visit will help our journalists better understand American China hands' views on the development of cross-strait relations and U.S. policies toward the two sides of the Taiwan Strait," Lin said.

Meanwhile, Lin said the MAC also hopes that the visit will help Taiwan journalists expand their vision and enhance the depth and scope of their reporting to facilitate the formation of a consensus among Taiwan people on cross-strait policy.
In addition to New York, the media delegation will also visit several U.S. cities, including Washington, D.C. and San Francisco.

The U.S. think tanks the group plans to visit include the National Committee on U.S.-China Relations, the Council on Foreign Relations, the Brookings Institution, the Cato Institute, the American Enterprises Institute, the Center for National Policy, the Center for Strategic and International Studies, and the Heritage Foundation.
During its 12-day visit, the delegation will meet with such noted U.S. China affairs experts as John Holden, Jerome Cohen, James Lilley and Robert Scalapino.

The group will also pay a visit to Richard Bush, chairman and managing director of the American Institute in Taiwan, a semi-official organization authorized to handle ROC-U.S. exchanges in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: CATHAY AND DRAGONAIR TO COMPETE ON MAINLAND AND TAIWAN ROUTES

TEXT.P: Hong Kong's Cathay Pacific and Dragonair will be allowed to compete on most routes to the mainland following a deal with Beijing that will liberalize Hong Kong's long-standing "one airline, one route" policy, media reports in Hong Kong said Monday.

According to a report carried in the South China Morning Post, the agreement, signed in March but still unannounced, is believed to be part of a deal between the two Hong Kong carriers to begin directly competing on major Taiwan and mainland routes.

At present, only one designated carrier, Dragonair, has the right to service mainland destinations from Hong Kong. But under the terms of the new agreement, Hong Kong will be able to grant destination rights on most mainland routes to a second airline, significantly expanding the frequency and number of mainland destinations to which Hong Kong carriers are allowed to fly.
Under the terms of the deal, Beijing will automatically approve Hong Kong's carrier selections on any route, the report quoted a source close to the negotiations as saying.

The new agreement, it said, lays to rest Hong Kong's 50-year-old "one airline, one route" policy on competition by giving the Hong Kong government the option to allow the two carriers to compete head-to-head on passenger services to certain routes if demand justifies it.
The government made its first moves to alter the policy last year when it approved Dragonair's application to launch cargo services to Dubai, Amsterdam and Manchester.

"The government is now following a policy of progressive liberalization in air services," the source was quoted as saying, adding that Hong Kong's overall economic expansion was the dominant theme in government policy.
Dragonair gained the right to fly to mainland destinations in April 1990 when Cathay acquired a stake in the fledgling airline and decided to abandon its mainland schedule in favor of Dragonair.
It is believed that, in exchange for granting Dragonair's wish to compete on the lucrative Hong Kong-Taipei route, Cathay will be allowed to resume mainland services.
The source said it was the government's policy to "protect competition, not the competitors."

The source said it was understood that Dragonair's application to service Taipei would be looked at on the basis of whether the route needed additional capacity, rather than on protecting the existing carriers.

A date for Dragonair to begin servicing Taipei will depend largely on when a new agreement can be reached, as the existing five-year deal between Hong Kong and Taiwan is set to expire June 12. (Stanley Cheung)

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL SURGEON REPORTS PROGRESS IN TREATING SPINAL CORD INJURIES

TEXT.P: Progress has been made in the treatment of those suffering from spinal cord injuries, a surgeon from Taipei's Veterans General Hospital said Monday.
More than 50 patients with spinal cord injuries are now undergoing treatment, Cheng Hung-chih, neural surgeon at the hospital said. Many of the patients have regained some motor function, he said.

Cheng's team, working with Swedish researchers, have been using micro-surgical techniques and a cocktail of regenerative drugs to reconnect severed or damaged spinal cords. He is currently researching injuries to the lower part of the spinal cord and has reported initial progress.
Four of the patients who were paralyzed from the waist down and one from the knees down have been able to walk again, Cheng said. He also said that their incontinence has greatly improved.

Cheng said that for those patients who are not so seriously injured, he will use a special glue to help the regeneration of neural cells, but if the injury is old or more substantial he will have to transplant neural cells from other parts of the body to repair the injured spinal cord.
Cheng delivered his reports on his experiments on animals and his neural regeneration techniques at a two-day international seminar on biomedical technology which opened at the Grand Hotel Monday.

He said that among his patients is TV actor Chao Hsueh-huang, who sought his aid four months after a serious car accident in mainland China. Chao is now undergoing rehabilitation to his hand, Cheng said.

Media reports have said that first lady Wu Shu-cheng, who was paralyzed from the chest down since she was hit and run over by a car in 1985, is very interested in Cheng's research. She has expressed the hope to be able to stand up again after treatment.
Cheng said, however, that a medical team would have to examine the first lady's situation before he could recommend treatment.
Cheng said that his experiments on people will be complete by September.

The ideal situation would be for the patients to make a full recovery, he said, but added that much would depend on the location of their spinal cord injuries, the seriousness and the time since their injuries occurred.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL'S SECOND A-340 PLANE TO JOIN SERVICE

TEXT.P: The second A-340 passenger aircraft ordered by China Airlines (CAL) was delivered last Saturday and will join the service between Kaohsiung and Hong Kong from Tuesday.
CAL has ordered five A-340 planes, and the first has been in service on the Taipei-Manila and Taipei-Hong Kong routes since last April.
The last three A-340s will be delivered in June, July and October.
A CAL spokesman said Monday that from July 1, the A-340 planes will also operate on the long-distance routes to Frankfurt, Rome, New Zealand and Australia.

DOC.HEADLINE: THAI WORKERS TO SEE PAY CUT FROM JULY

TEXT.P: Foreign blue-collar workers in Taiwan will endure pay cuts from July amid the island's current economic woes, sources close to the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Monday.

The sources said the CLA has negotiated with major labor exporting countries on the reduction of salaries for foreign laborers with a view to helping local employers cut production costs and tide them over their current business difficulties.

Under the CLA-proposed new salary calculating formula, the sources said, local employers will be allowed to integrate boarding and accommodation payment into the government-sanctioned basic wage for foreign workers.

At present, local employers have to pay NT$2,500 (US$73.53) to NT$4,000 in boarding and accommodation fees for each legally hired foreign worker per month, in addition to paying the minimum wage of NT$15,840 (US$465).
CLA sources said Thailand has agreed to the proposal in principle. Therefore, the sources said, some 140,000 Thai workers in Taiwan will be subject to the new salary calculating formula from July.

Thailand has been the largest source of foreign laborers working in the local manufacturing and construction industries. Under the new measure, the sources said, local employers would be able to save an estimated NT$350 million in salary payments a month.
Meanwhile, the CLA reportedly will also negotiate with other labor exporting countries, including Vietnam, Indonesia and the Philippines, on the new formula in the near future.
The sources said the CLA is hopeful that the new measure can be applied to all foreign workers in the construction and manufacturing sectors as well as to foreign housemaids and caretakers.

Nevertheless, CLA officials said that because of different national situations of major labor exporting countries, the negotiation results with Vietnam, Indonesia and the Philippines remain uncertain. Citizens from these three countries mainly work as housemaids and caretakers in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FOREIGN CURRENCY REVENUES FROM JANUARY-MAY EXPORTS DOWN

TEXT.P: Foreign currency revenues from Taiwan's exports in the first five months of this year totaled US$59.448 billion, down 5.6 percent from the same period in 2000, according to Central Bank of China (CBC) statistics released Monday.

The foreign currency expenditures for the island's imports during the January-May period were listed at US$52.361 billion, decreasing 8.8 percent and resulting in a five-month surplus of US$7.087 billion.
A CBC official attributed the decline in foreign currency revenues and expenditures to the decrease of exports and imports owing to the global economic sluggishness since early this year.

Foreign currency revenues and expenditures resulting from May's exports and imports stood at US$12.188 billion and US$10.821 billion, down 6.2 percent and 8 percent respectively compared with last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: HAITIAN MINISTER TO ARRIVE FOR WEEKLONG VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 11 (CNA) (By Victor Lai) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Taipei, June 11 (CNA): Haitian Minister of Agriculture, National Resources and Rural Development Sebastien Hilaire will arrive in Taipei Tuesday at the head of a five-member delegation for a weeklong visit to the Republic of China, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs official said Monday.
While in Taipei, the group will call on Chairman of the Council of Agriculture Chen Hsi-huang, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Lan Chih-min and other government officials.
They will also visit the National Palace Museum, the Taoyuan District Agricultural Improvement Station, and other cultural and economic establishments in Taiwan.
In addition, they will attend an opening ceremony of the 2001 Taipei International Food Show scheduled to be held at the Taipei World Trade Center on June 14-17.
The Haitian delegation is expected to depart for home June 18.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO HONOR LEGISLATURE CONSENSUS ON EXTRAORDINARY SESSION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will honor a consensus of all political parties and initiate a special session of the Legislative Yuan, government spokesman Su cheng-ping said Monday.

The opposition parties -- the Kuomintang, the People First Party, and the New Party, agreed in a coordination meeting earlier that day that an extraordinary session will be convened during the summer recess upon the request of the president.

Concerned in particular about financial reform bills still outstanding following the recent end of the legislative session, Chen called Premier Chang Chun-hsiung Sunday to discuss the feasibility of the Legislative Yuan arranging an extraordinary session.

Tsai Huang-liang, secretary-general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) parliamentary caucus, said that the DPP caucus had gathered signatories from one-quarter of the legislators necessary for a petition.
Chang, well aware that consensus will be needed to have the bills approved, called Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng to seek his assistance in coordinating the opinions of all the parties.

Wang said that convening an extraordinary session is a constitutional matter and that the legislature should exercise it only in time of great urgency. In the past 50 years, only three extraordinary sessions have been convened -- in 1951 and 1952 for issues relating to the post-war peace agreement with Japan, and on Jan. 30 this year to address complications arising from the fourth nuclear power plant project.

DOC.HEADLINE: SNG CARS AND CREW TO BE INCLUDED INTO CONSCRIPTION LIST: MND

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) is considering seeking the right to requisition satellite broadcasting (SNG) vehicles owned by private television stations, along with their crews, during crisis periods or times of war, military sources said Monday.
The new plan is needed "to meet future warfare requirements and beef up Taiwan's civilian defense and mobilization mechanisms," according to the sources.

According to the sources, relevant MND departments are drafting amendments to the existing regulations governing military requisition of vehicles to pave the way for the requisition of SNG vehicles and crews from private TV stations "to support wartime news reporting and the transmission of combat information."

In the initial stage of the plan, the sources said, the military will begin to requisition SNG vehicles and crews when the country's armed forces enter a standoff with enemy forces, known in the military's preparedness scale as "Situation II."
"We have come up with the proposal in view of changing warfare strategy and developments in our domestic media industry," said an MND official.

The official said the military has consistently made "civilian mobilization operations" a major training item in the annual "Han Kuang" combined services exercises in recent years in order to upgrade civilian defense functions.

"As part of our efforts to upgrade the Taiwan armed forces' psychological warfare capability, the MND invited U.S. psychological warfare specialists to watch this year's Han Kuang drills and assess our combat capability," the official said.

At the end of the exercises, the official said, the U.S. experts suggested that the MND requisition SNG vans and crews from private TV stations to "assist in wartime news reporting and the transmission of warfare information."

The official said the military is now endeavoring to learn more about satellite broadcasting technology and relevant expertise. "We'll learn from the U.S. experience," he said, adding that the MND is also studying whether the requisition of private SNG vehicles would involve issues of satellite channel control.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA DENIES SETTING UP FOREIGN RELATIONS WITH BOLIVIA

TEXT.P: A spokeswoman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) categorically denied Monday local press reports that the Republic of China will set up diplomatic relations with Bolivia.
Local press reports had quoted opposition Kuomintang Legislator Lee Hsien-jen as saying that the ROC and Bolivia will establish diplomatic relations "soon."

Last October, it was also reported that the ROC was to establish diplomatic relations with Bolivia when the Legislative Yuan's subcommittee was deliberating on government's confidential budget. Lee's report attracted particular attention in light of the ROC's disintegrating ties with Macedonia.
Paraguay is the sole ROC diplomatic ally in South America and President Chen Shui-bian paid a state visit to the country May 30.
The ROC maintains semi-official relations with Bolivia and has a facility there with the official title of "The Commercial-Consular Office of the Republic of China in Bolivia."

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA MAPS OUT MEASURES TO DEAL WITH MACEDONIA SITUATION

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has worked out a series of measures to deal with the daily-worsening Macedonian situation, a MOFA official said Monday.

MOFA spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue said that in addition to advising Republic of China government officials, their dependents and overseas Chinese in Macedonia to be safety-conscious, MOFA will monitor developments there closely.
MOFA will also monitor the development of ROC-Macedonia relations, which may be decided at a Macedonian Cabinet meeting Tuesday, she added.
Answering questions from reporters, Chang said that the overall situation in the Macedonian capital of Skopje was still stable although some areas were said to be unstable.
The ROC embassy in Skopje also informed Taiwan reporters covering news in Macedonia to avoid going out at night.

The embassy has also mapped out a series of emergency measures to cope with the daily-worsening situation in the tiny European country. These measures cover the protection of government officials, their dependents and overseas Chinese, as well as their evacuation.
Chang said that the ROC embassy in Skopje has close contacts with the embassies of the United States, France, Italy and Greece and has no plans to withdraw from Skopje at the moment.

She further pointed out that although Western countries believe that the current conflict between ethnic Albanian rebel forces and government forces will not develop into an all-out conflict in Macedonia, the factional conflict has not only had a physiological impact but has also put great pressure on Macedonia's newly formed coalition Cabinet.

The proposal to normalize Skopje-Beijing relations, likely to be proposed again at Tuesday's regular Cabinet meeting, comes a week after Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski turned down a proposal to normalize Skopje-Beijing relations made by Foreign Minister Ilinda Mitreva.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL TAIWAN UNIVERSITY RANKED BEST LOCAL SCHOOL IN SURVEY

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University (NTU) in Taipei has been ranked the best public university in Taiwan in eight out of nine academic disciplines, according to a newly released survey.
The only discipline in which NTU failed to come top is communications, in which National Chengchi University -- also in Taipei -- was ranked best.
National Tsinghua University in Hsinchu was named between second and fourth in the nine disciplines and second overall.

Among the nation's private universities, Fujen University was ranked the best, taking either first or second place in the disciplines of humanities, law and politics, communication, management, and science.
Soochow University in Taipei and Tamkang University in Taipei County took second and third places among private universities.

However, more than 75 percent of 1,100 professors interviewed in the survey recommended that freshmen give preference to their desired field of study over the rank of the university when deciding where to study.

The survey, conducted by a private publishing company and carried in its "Survey of Universities in Taiwan," also shows that electrical engineering, law, foreign languages, medical science and information engineering, are the top five choices of most graduates from junior high schools.
The survey was aimed at helping freshmen to make the best choice of university in relation to their field of study.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN DRIVERS URGED TO GET TAIWAN-ISSUED LICENSES

TEXT.P: Taipei's Office of Motor Vehicle Inspection said Monday that foreigners and mainland Chinese who make long stays in Taiwan must change their driver licenses to Republic of China-issued driver licenses if they want to drive in the Taiwan area, the sources said.

The office made the call in view of the fact that some mainland Chinese in Taiwan show their mainland China-issued driver's licenses when stopped by police and have no international license or ROC-issued driver's license.
The office also claimed that some foreigners in Taiwan wantonly violate traffic rules because they feel that police usually let them go whether they have a license or not.

The office said that foreigners and mainland Chinese who want an ROC license must first gain attestations from their government's representative office and then present their home country-issued license, together with a Chinese-language translation, a valid certificate of physical examination, their certificate of residence, their passport and two photographs, together with an application form.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN RED CROSS DELEGATION TO VISIT XIAMEN

TEXT.P: A 32-member delegation of the Kinmen Red Cross Association led by Chairman Wang Shui-chang will make a direct journey from Kinmen to the mainland Chinese port of Xiamen Tuesday to meet with their Xiamen counterparts for discussions on cooperation.
The discussions will center on humanitarian assistance in disasters at sea, the exchange of medical personnel and ways to cooperate in prisoner exchanges.

Wang said that criminal activity has escalated as interaction between the people of Kinmen and Fujian has become more frequent since the Jan. 1, 2001 establishment of the "three mini links" between the ROC-held offshore Kinmen and Matsu islands and the ports of Xiamen and Mawei.

In order to cope with the increasing demands for assistance in repatriating mainland prisoners detained by the Taiwan authorities and vice versa, Wang said his mission will consult with its Xiamen counterpart to work out measures to deal with the situation and a cooperation plan to render humanitarian assistance in the event of maritime disasters.
He expressed hope that future cooperation between his association and the Red Cross Association in Xiamen will lead to a peaceful and friendly bridge between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
The delegation will call on various Red Cross chapters in Fujian Province, as well as local offices in charge of Taiwan affairs.
The delegation members will also hold a symposium with members of the Kinmen ethnic association in Xiamen before returning to Kinmen June 18.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMA COMMERCE AND INDUSTRY MINISTER ARRIVES FOR WEEK-LONG VISIT

TEXT.P: Panamanian Minister of Commerce and Industry Joaquin Jacome Diez arrived in Taipei Monday for a week-long visit.
An official from Taiwan's Board of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said that Jacome will attend the opening ceremony of the 2001 Taipei International Food Show June 14.
Panama has sent a 25-member delegation to participate in the four day exhibition.

In order to help Latin American countries promote their agricultural products and foods, the show's organizing committee has set up a Central and South American Pavilion comprising nine countries, including Panama, at the show, the official said.
Jacome will also hold a press conference Wednesday at a local department store to introduce Panamanian products to the people of Taiwan.
He will also call on government officials, including Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi, as well as visiting various economic establishments before leaving for home Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT BEGINS EXCHANGING VIEWS WITH DPP LEGISLATORS

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian began meeting with legislators from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Monday to exchange views on pressing domestic problems.
During the meeting with 14 DPP legislators, Chen stressed the importance of forming a coalition government after December's legislative elections.

Admitting that it will be nearly impossible for the DPP to gain half of the legislative seats in the forthcoming elections, Chen expressed hope nevertheless that the DPP will become the largest party. The party at present controls just one-third of the seats in the legislature.
In order to establish a stable majority in the Legislative Yuan, the president pointed out the need to recruit the support of opposition legislators who share the political ideals of the DPP.
However, he went on, legislators connected with "black gold" will not be targeted by the DPP for recruitment into a coalition government.
Regarding the "economic development advisory committee" he proposed last month, Chen noted that the most urgent problem facing Taiwan today is the economy.

He said that as the present economic issue is not simply an economic problem, but a problem of confidence and even a problem of politics, he hopes to set up the committee "to restore the people's confidence and to stabilize the political situation."
According to the president, the proposed committee will be a mechanism designed for consultation, will not become a permanent organ and will not infringe on the present constitutional system.
Chen is scheduled to continue to meet with other DPP lawmakers on five more occasions on June 14, 18, 21, 28 and July 2.

DOC.HEADLINE: REMAINS OF FOUR TAIWAN TOURISTS TO BE RETURNED FROM MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The remains of four Taiwan tourists killed in a landslide caused by torrential rain in Guangxi Province June 8 will be brought home from mainland China Tuesday.

An official with the Taiwan Affairs Office in Nanning, Guangxi, said that the local travel agency that handled the tourists eight-day visit had reached an agreement on compensation with the bereaved families who rushed to the scene from Taiwan June 9.

He said that the compensation for each dead tourist was about 100,000 renminbi -- 80,000 renminbi for the loss of life, 15,000 renminbi for the transportation of the remains and 4,500 renminbi for the loss of belongings.

The four dead were members of a 60-member tourist group from Taichung organized by the Tajung travel agency. They were Hsu Chuan-chuan, 51; Chen Feng-chin, 38; Hsu Ming-teh, 56; and his 53-year-old wife Lin Ai-ou.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOTED OPERA STAR PERFORMS TO PACKED HOUSE IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Celebrity tenor Placido Domingo charmed a Taipei audience Monday night at a packed National Concert Hall.
In a brief news conference before the concert, the Spanish-born tenor said he was glad to visit the island again and perform for the local audience.
In order to protect his voice, the tenor refused to answer journalists' questions.
Accompanied by the National Symphony Orchestra conducted by Eugene Kohn, the tenor gave a recital of many beautiful melodies from operas such as Otello, Wintersturme and The Merry Widow.
Although only 2,000 people were able to get into the sold-out concert, his performance was televised live to an audience of a further 60,000 people packed into the plaza outside the concert hall.
After capping his performance with five encores, the soloist walked from the hall to greet the crowd outside and led them in a chorus of a Chinese folk song.
Domingo, who arrived in Taipei Sunday from Tokyo, will go on to Beijing to join fellow tenors Luciano Pavarotti and Jose Carreras for a concert in front of the Forbidden City.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MILITARY OFFICERS ATTENDING U.S. WORKSHOP
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, D.C., June 11 (CNA) (By Jay Chen & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: A group of 20 Republic of China military officers and two civilian experts are in Washington, D.C. to attend a two-week workshop designed especially for them.
The officers also called at the Pentagon to exchange views with officials of the U.S. Department of Defense.

The seminar, which is sponsored by the War Strategic and International Research Center, a U.S. think tank, is being held at Georgetown University, with lecturers coming from the White House, the Department of Defense (DOD) and the Central Intelligence Agency.

The lecturers include Torkel Patterson, senior official in Asian affairs at the National Security Council, Zbignien Brzezinsky, former national security adviser under the Carter administraton, former Under Secretary of Defense Walter Slocombe and Richard Bush, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) as well as several China hands.

The participants visited the Pentagon and held a symposium with DOD officials. They will call at the headquarters of the Pacific Military Command in Hawaii later this week. Last week, they held talks with congressional aides on military and foreign relations.

The program is said to have been proposed by former DOD Deputy Assistant Secretary Kurt Campbell and received support from Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian and then-Premier Tang Fei when Campbell visited Taiwan last June.
Led by Maj. Gen. Lin Yu-pao, deputy commander of an F-16 squadron stationed in Hualien, the delegation members were picked by Gen. Tang Yao-ming, chief of the General Staff.

Yang Nien-chu and Ting Su-fan, civilian wartime strategy experts, are also taking part in the two-week long workshop, the first of its kind since the two nations suspended diplomatic relations in 1978.
The U.S. government also offered a similar workshop at Harvard University for ranking military officers from mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRENCH BANK UNVEILS ITS FIRST ASIAN BRANCH IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Cetelem, a banking company of the French banking group BNP Paribas, unveiled Monday its first Asian branch in Taipei.
The opening ceremony was held at a local hotel and attended by dozens of representatives from domestic enterprises.

Cetelem's main business is loans and credit cards and its services emphasize the establishment of the concept of "family financial management," allowing short-, medium- and long-term family consumer expenditure to be budgeted.
Cetelem officials said the bank will work with Taiwan families' disposable income to help improve their financial management.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Tuesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Opposition alliance wants President Chen to request holding of a Legislative Yuan special session.
The China Times:
President Chen says if the Democratic Progressive Party emerges as the largest party from the year-end elections, the victory will trigger fundamental structural changes in major opposition parties.
The United Daily News:
The opposition alliance reaches a consensus on the convening of an extra legislative session.
The Liberty Times:
The opposition alliance backs special legislative session with conditions.
The China Post:
Economic advisory committee is open to every party: President Chen.
The Taiwan News:
McVeigh execution serves justice, says Bush.
The Taipei Times:
Opposition agrees to extra legislative session.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, June 12, or the 21st day of the fourth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1809: Pope Pius VII, originally Barnaba Gregorio Chiaramonti, who was forced to crown Napoleon Bonaparte emperor in 1804, excommunicates him.
1917: King Constantine of Greece abdicates in favor of his son, Prince Alexander.
1924: George Bush, the 41st president of the United States, is born. Before becoming president, the Republican politician served as U.S. ambassador to the United Nations and China, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, and vice president under Ronald Reagan.
1929: Anne Frank, the Dutch Jewish schoolgirl and wartime diarist, is born in Germany. In hiding from the Nazis, she wrote her famous diary before being taken to her death in a German concentration camp in March 1945 at the age of 16.
1931: As part of their crackdown on bootleggers, Chicago police arrest Al "Scarface" Capone, the Italian-born American gangster who ruled the Chicago underworld with an iron fist, charging him with 5,000 offenses under America's Prohibition laws.
1938 China's Yellow River ruptures a dike, killing some 150,000 people.
1944: Chinese communist leader Mao Zedong announces that he will support Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of China's National Military Council, in the War of Resistance Against Japan.
1947: Chinese troops recapture Peitashan in Sinkiang Province from Mongolian troops which are aided by the Soviet Union in their invasion of the northwestern province of China.
1964: South Africa's Nelson Mandela and seven others are sentenced to life imprisonment.
1973: China Airlines inaugurates night flight services between the Taiwan cities of Taipei and Kaohsiung.
1975: A judge rules that Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's landslide victory in 1971 was invalid becuase civil servants illegally aided her campaign.
1976: Juan Maria Bordaberry, president of Uruguay, is overthrown and replaced by Alberto Demichelli.
1978: A strong earthquake rocks Miyagi prefecture in Japan, killing 38 people and injuring more than 1,000 others.
1978: Kuo Mojo, a Chinese communist writer, dies in Beijing at the age of 86.
1979: American Bryan Allen pedals his way across the English Channel in a human-powered aircraft to win a US$185,000 prize.
1979: Mohammed Ali Khoguir, charge d'affaires of the Saudi Arabian Embassy in the Republic of China, presents US$100,000 to National Chung Hsing University to establish a graduate school of Arabic.
1980: Tsiang Yen-si, secretary-general of the Kuomintang, cables condolences to Yasuhiro Nakasone, secretary-general of the Japanese Liberal Democratic Party, on the death of Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira.
1982: The 16th Ministerial Conference on Economic Cooperation between the ROC and the Republic of Korea ends, with both countries pledging to cement closer cooperation in trade and technology.
1987: Britain's Conservative Party leader Margaret Thatcher, who in 1979 became the first woman ever to hold the office of British prime minister, is elected for the third time. She served in the post for over 11-and-a-half years, longer than any other British prime minister in the 20th century.
1987: Jean-Bedel Bokassa, former emperor of the Central African Republic, is sentenced to death for crimes committed during his 13-year rule.
1987: The ROC's Democratic Progressive Party leads its supporters in a demonstration outside the Legislative Yuan building in Taipei to protest against the National Security Law. In an ensuing clash with members of the Anti-Communist Patriotic Front, who support the National Security Law, several members from both sides are injured.
1991: In a referendum, the people of Leningrad vote by 55 percent to 43 percent to change the name of their city back to St. Petersburg.
1991: Boris Yeltsin beats five communist rivals in the country's first-ever democratic elections to become president of the Russian republic.
1998: The Japanese economy is in recession for the first time since the 1974-75 fiscal year.
2000: The 2000 World Congress of Information Technology kicks off its three-day session in Taipei with 1,500 experts and scholars from 80 countries around the world participating.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If a thing is really hard, you may pound it and yet it will not crack; if a thing is really white, you may besmirch it, and yet it will not become black."

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN TO ADDRESS OXFORD SCHOLARS ON ROC MAINLAND CHINA POLICY
DOC.DATELINE: London, June 12 (CNA) (By Mark Ou and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan is slated to deliver a speech at Oxford University Tuesday evening on the ROC ruling party's mainland China policy.

In an advanced copy of his speech, Lien said that the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has avoided embracing the so-called 1992 consensus of "one China, separate interpretations" between Taipei and Beijing even as Beijing decided in a turn-about last year to accept it for the first time since 1995.
Lien called that consensus "rare" and "the only political compromise on the most difficult sovereignty issue" that had finally led to years of bilateral dialogue.
In another adjustment, Lien said, Beijing has shifted its claim that "Taiwan is a part of China" to "Taiwan and the mainland are both parts of one China."

Meanwhile, he added, although the DPP has not declared Taiwan independence, it has denied the "1992 consensus" and has stressed that "unification is not the only option" while failing to clearly outline what option the government is in favor of.
This has led to Taipei being the side that has "closed the door," he said.

Lien also questioned claims that the Taipei-Beijing relationship is "stable." Instead, he called it "a cold but still peaceful stalemate" that has deepened the ideological, emotional and political gap between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
However, he said that bilateral economic and cultural exchanges have been helpful in stabilizing political, military and diplomatic struggles between the two sides.

The ideal of "democratic unification" that the KMT represents has also served as a check on the DPP administration's mainland China policy and has helped stabilize the Taiwan Strait situation, he added.

Lien urged both the ROC and the mainland Chinese governments not to close their doors on each other. He advised against further stimulating cross-strait ideological conflicts merely because of a worsening of Beijing-Washington relations in order to avoid developing toward a cold war situation.

After his speech at Oxford, Lien is slated to proceed to Paris where he will receive a scholastic citation at the University of Paris. He will then head to New York, where he will attend an academic forum sponsored by a U.S. think tank before returning to Taiwan at the end of June.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL FINDS CONSCRIPTS HAVE LOW CONFIDENCE IN CONSCRIPTION FAIRNESS

TEXT.P: The majority of local conscripts are afraid of serving in the military and have low confidence in the fairness of the conscription system and the military's internal management, according to the results of a survey released Tuesday.

The survey was conducted by Sun Min-hua, a psychology professor with the military-run Fuhsingkang College, on selected conscripts in various military branches, units and areas around the island. Sun sent out 3,300 copies of a questionnaire and collected 3,028 valid replies.

Poll results showed that 55 percent of the respondents said they have been fearful of serving in the military; 50 percent said they believe that if their parents were wealthy and powerful, they would not have been drafted into the military.
Meanwhile, 40 percent said they think that they would be treated better and would have been dispatched to "better" military units if their parents had lobbied relevant military authorities.
"This kind of thinking is shared by roughly the same percentage of parents of conscripts," Sun said, quoting the results of a separate survey conducted almost at the same time.

According to the poll, 37 percent of the draftees who responded to the questionnaire said they dislike mandatory military service; 25 percent said they admire those who do not need to fulfill compulsory military service; 21 percent said they think that fulfilling compulsory military service is a waste of time; and 23 percent said they are fed up with life in the barracks.
Only 23 percent said they agree with the idea that the current one-year-and-10-month mandatory term of military service is a necessary process for each healthy man.
Most noteworthy was that a measly 15 percent said they think that the current conscription system is a must in terms of maintaining national survival.
Analyzing the survey findings, Sun said the majority of conscripts generally hold a negative attitude toward the existing mandatory military service system.
Nevertheless, Sun said, the poll also found that some conscripts feel that the training they receive during their years in the military will be conducive to their future careers.
Some respondents even said they think that fulfilling mandatory military service is an honor or that military service is an alternative form of training, according to the survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN EXCHANGE RATES
