DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 5.06 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Tuesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 5.06 points to close at 5,266.24.
Market turnover amounted to NT$68.02 billion (US$2 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH URGED TO INSIST THAT BEIJING RELEASE DETAINED AMERICANS

TEXT.P: A conservative American magazine Monday urged U.S. President George W. Bush to state publicly that it will be politically and morally impossible for him to attend a regional economic summit in Shanghai this October if Beijing continues to hold even a single American political prisoner at that time.

The Weekly Standard wrote in an editorial in its latest issue that two weeks ago, following a long round of high-profile diplomacy, the Bush administration finally achieved what it thought was an acceptable entente with Beijing regarding the downed U.S. EP-3 surveillance plane.

The weekly magazine noted that on June 1, with the EP-3 still squatting on a Hainan runway, President Bush announced his intention to renew Beijing's normal trade relations status for another year just as every U.S. president has done since 1980.

Bush urged Americans to believe that bilateral commercial ties are indispensable, "if we are to promote American values of transparency and accountability and ensure that the Chinese government adheres to the rule of law in its dealings with its own people as well as with the international community."

But, the editorial said, the president did not explain how it is that with the United States having so guaranteed vigorous trade with Communist China for more than 20 years, "that said country nevertheless remains a virtual wasteland where such `American values' are concerned. Nor did the president explain why he should feel liberated to make public his `normal trade relations' decision merely by China's promised return of a ruined plane."

"We would have expected George W. Bush, in accordance with his own stated principles, to care rather less about this piece of machinery and rather more about certain other, priceless American resources held captive by Beijing," the editorial said.

The magazine was referring to the fact that, for several month, Beijing's Ministry of State Security has been detaining -- and refusing to provide more than superficial information about -- a half dozen U.S. citizens and permanent residents.
President Bush cannot seriously hope to maintain `normal' relations with Communist China so long as Beijing is conducting a terror campaign against selected visiting Americans, it said.
The magazine urged the Bush administration to make the release of these Americans its very highest China-policy priority at the moment.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL SHOWS MOST AMERICANS OPPOSED TO U.S. COMMITTING TO ROC'S DEFENSE

TEXT.P: An opinion poll released Monday indicates that a majority of Americans are opposed to the United States making a commitment at the present time to defend Taiwan if mainland China attacks with military force.

The poll, published by the Pew Research Center and Council on Foreign Relations, has found that only 26 percent of respondents said they are in favor of a U.S. commitment while 64 said they are opposed.

The survey also shows that 19 percent of respondents think of Communist China as "an adversary" while 51 percent consider Beijing "a serious problem, but not an adversary." Another 22 percent said they view mainland China as "not much of a problem."

Morton H. Halperin, senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations, told a press conference that the figures demonstrate that an expected "spike" in U.S. public opinion against mainland China has not materialized.

Despite tensions between Washington and Beijing caused by the EP-3 incident, the sentiment on the part of some Republican officials that mainland China has become "U.S. enemy No.1" has not been picked up by the general public, he said.

A similar poll conducted in March 2000 showed that 17 percent of respondents thought of mainland China as an adversary while 44 percent said the country was only a serious problem. The respective figures for a similar survey carried out in June 1999 were 18 percent and 53 percent.

The latest poll shows that 51 percent of those surveyed believe that mainland China's emergence as a world power will pose a major threat to the United States, 30 percent think it is a minor threat, and 10 percent think it's not a threat.
On the question of whether the United States should come to Taiwan's defense, the figures appear to bear out the general public's aversion to U.S. armed intervention abroad.

Even among Republican supporters, only 36 percent of respondents said they think the United States should commit at this time to defending Taiwan if it is attacked by the mainland, while 53 percent said they are opposed to such a commitment.
Among Democratic voters, 70 percent of those surveyed said they are against such a commitment while 21 percent said they are for it.
Of those questioned who regard Communist China as an adversary, 41 percent said they think Washington should make the commitment now, while 52 percent said it shouldn't.

The lack of support for such a commitment comes after a recent remark by President George W. Bush that the United States would do "whatever it took" to help Taiwan defend itself should it come under attack by the mainland.
The latest poll was conducted over the telephone between May 15 and 28, with a total of 1,468 adults being interviewed.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened low but closed higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 5.06 points to close at 5,266.24
Affected by a decline in U.S. stocks prices, the bourse opened at 5,247.42 and fluctuated between 5,298.69 and 5,244.74 during trading.

A total of 1.92 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$68.02 billion (US$2 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.42 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$49.23 billion (US$1.45 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with bank and insurance stocks moving up the most at 1.3 percent, followed by foodstuff shares at 1 percent, and construction stocks at 0.3 percent. Cement stocks remained unchanged.

The other major categories posted losses, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 1.3 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares at 0.5 percent, and electrical stocks and textile issues, both at 0.4 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 250 to 231, with 110 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were higher on Tuesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for June moved down 44 points to close at 5,245, with 6,312 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for July lost 45 points to finish at 5,240, with 244 contract transactions, while September futures decreased 44 points to close at 5,246, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 5,289 for June, 5,285 for July, 5,290 for September, 5,290 for December, and 5,250 for next March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.
June TE futures moved down 3.7 points to close at 270, with 1,526 contract transactions, while July TE futures lost 3.55 points to finish at 269.6, with 53 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
June TF futures moved up 4.6 points to finish at 683.2, with 608 contracts changing hands, while July TF futures increased 5 points to close at 681, with five contracts traded.
September TF futures rose 4.6 points to finish at 675.8, with six contracts changing hands.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. REP SUSPECTS ALLIES WERE INVOLVED IN U.S. OUSTER FROM UNHRC

TEXT.P: The U.S. Congress will withhold US$250 million in United Nations dues owed by the United States in retaliation for America's ouster from the U.N. Human rights Commission earlier this year, Rep. Henry Hyde (R-Ill.) said over the weekend.

Hyde told some 300 activists and politicians at the fourth Chicago Conservative Conference that, as chairman of the House International Relations Committed, he hs been trying to find out whether some of America's European allies were among those who voted the United States off the U.N. human rights panel.
"The State Department bureaucrats are withholding the facts, but I suspect some of our European allies may have been involved," Hyde said, adding that he has a list of suspects.
The Republican congressman from Illinois suggested that "maybe we should move the U.N. headquarters to Beijing."

"It is nothing less than ironic that our place on the U.N. Commission was taken by Sudan -- an irony that boggles the mind. But the ministers I meet, on the issues of Northern Ireland or North Korea, ask that we stay engaged. They seem to want to poke us in the eye with one hand and stroke us with the other," he said.
The congressman said that although he did not co-sponsor a bill in the House of Representatives to pull the United States out of the United Nations, he would vote for the legislation.

Hyde also pledged that the United States will remain involved in foreign affairs. He said threats from Communist China, North Korea, Russia and rogue Middle Eastern states are among his highest priorities as chairman of the House International Relations Committee.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MISSION IN MACEDONIA ON HIGH ALERT: MOFA

TEXT.P: The situation in Macedonia is calm after the Macedonian government and ethnic Albanian rebels declared a cease-fire, and the Republic of China will not withdraw its mission from the Balkan country at the present time, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.

MOFA spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue said however that the ROC's mission is on high alert and that it has worked out a contingency plan. She added that the ROC and other countries are in fact closely watching to see whether the truce will hold.
Reports said some international airliners have suspended their flights to Skopje, the capital of Macedonia, due to the tensions in the Balkan country.

Chang said that in addition to personnel at the ROC mission and their dependents as well as some Taiwan businesspeople, the ROC mission has also alerted ROC reporters covering news in the country to refrain from going outside at night.

The mission has also worked out a contingency plan, including the protection and withdrawal of ROC personnel and the withdrawal of the ROC mission as well as the handling of mission property if necessary.

Asked if the ROC will take the next step and withdraw its mission if the situation deteriorates and fighting intensifies, Chang said that the foreign missions based in the tiny Balkan country have been keeping in close contact with each other and have been monitoring the situation.

But as the United States, France, Italy and Greece have not pulled out their embassy staff and so far are not prepared to withdraw, the ROC mission is not expected to do so, although it has made full preparations and is on the highest alert.

Chang also touched on the formal diplomatic relationship between the ROC and Macedonia, which is teetering on the brink of being severed after Foreign Minister Ilinka Mitreva recently said that Macedonia should switch diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.
The foreign minister proposed in a motion during a Cabinet meeting last Tuesday to sever ties with the ROC in an effort to secure bigger support from mainland China.
The proposal, however, was vetoed by Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski on the grounds that it was against administration process.

The Cabinet later decided that the issue be raised by President Boris Trajkowski for discussions and that the consensus reached at such discussions be brought to a future Cabinet meeting for further debate and a final decision.

Chang noted that the ministry understands that the Macedonian president has not yet held such discussions over the past days and that the ROC is still trying to learn if the issue will be put on the agenda at a regular Cabinet meeting Tuesday night.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SCHOLAR URGES MAINLAND CHINA TO STOP ARMS EXPANSION
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 11 (CNA) (By C.L. Tseng and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Noted American China expert Jerome Cohen on Monday urged mainland China to stop its arms expansion as this could prevent an arms race with Taiwan from happening.

During a seminar at the Council on Foreign Relations, a New York-based think tank, Cohen told a 15-member delegation of journalists from Taiwan that Washington should make it clear to Beijing that a continued arms build-up is not in the interests of mainland China, Taiwan nor the United States.
He said that if mainland China can exercise more restraint in this area, then the United States can consider not selling Taiwan more weapons next year.

Cohen also urged leaders in Beijing to try engaging in exchanges with the Republic of China's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the same manner that they have already been reaching out to the Republic of China's opposition parties.

He suggested that if "face" is a problem, Beijing could begin by inviting DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh -- who also sports the less politically sensitive title of Kaohsiung mayor -- to visit mainland China.

Cohen said that he hopes even more that ROC President Chen Shui-bian can visit mainland China, adding that Taiwan can also invite Beijing officials to visit the island to further increase mutual understanding.

With regard to Chen's recent transit stopover in New York on his way to Latin America for a state visit to several ROC diplomatic allies in the region, Cohen said that the American people have the right to listen to what the leaders from each side of the Taiwan Strait have to say.

He criticized former U.S. President Bill Clinton's policy of not welcoming ROC presidents to visit the United States. Calling the Taiwan Strait issue the "most dangerous issue for the United States," he said that the American people have the freedom to understand international situations but that the previous U.S. administration did not give them the chance.

He said that he had helped arrange for a video conference between Chen and people in the United States last year for the very purpose of letting the U.S. public understand the "truth" about the situation in the Taiwan Strait.
He added that he hopes the next time Chen visits the United States, the U.S. government will agree to let the ROC president speak with the American people.

The journalists attending the seminar, led by Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the ROC Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, are scheduled to call on other U.S. think tanks in order to gain a deeper understanding of the opinions within U.S. political and academic circles regarding cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR EARLY RESUMPTION OF ROC-THAI ECONOMIC MEETING

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday he is hopeful that the suspended annual economic consultative meeting between the Republic of China and Thailand can be resumed as early as possible to further boost bilateral trade and cooperation.
Chen made the pitch while meeting with a group of Thai senators, who are currently on a goodwill visit to Taipei.

Chen told his guests that despite the absence of diplomatic ties, substantive ROC-Thai relations have been close and cordial. For instance, he said, about 150,000 Thai nationals are legally working in Taiwan, accounting for 50 percent of total overseas Thai workers and making Thailand Taiwan's No. 1 source of foreign laborers.
As of the end of last year, Chen said, direct Taiwan investment in Thailand had reached US$10.33 billion, making the ROC the third largest foreign investor in the Southeast Asian country.

In addition, Chen said, two-way trade amounted to US$5.3 billion last year, with Thailand posting a trade surplus of about US$200 million. Moreover, ROC nationals made 650,000 visits to Thailand in 2000.

"All these figures point to the cordiality of our relationship," Chen said, adding that in view of brisk bilateral trade, the two countries should resume regular ministerial-level trade and economic consultative conference, which has been suspended since 1991.

Chen went on to say that the ROC government has consistently encourage its entrepreneurs to invest in Southeast Asian countries, particularly members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN). So far, he said, Taiwan business people have poured more than US$40 billion into the region.

"Against this backdrop, we hope Thailand can support our bid to take part in ASEAN activities and forge a regular dialogue mechanism with this important regional organization," Chen said, adding that the ROC also needs Thailand's support for its bids to join the World Trade Organization, the World Health Organization and other major international bodies.
Chen further said he looks forward to seeing senior ROC and Thai officials exchange visits more frequently for mutual benefits.
Meanwhile, Chen lauded Thai workers for their diligence and contribution to Taiwan's infrastructure construction and economic development.
"I hope labor officials from both countries can jointly work out measures to cut brokerage fees for Thai nationals intending to work in Taiwan," the president added.
For their part, the visiting Thai senators said the ROC has played an important role in the international community and Southeast Asian region.
"We'll be very pleased to see the ROC take part in ASEAN activities as an observer," said Wiboon Shamsheun, the first vice chairman of the Thai Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
Shamsheun told President Chen that he and his colleagues also support the upgrading of official exchanges between the two countries.

In addition to booming commercial exchanges, Shamsheun said ROC and Thai peoples also have close blood ties. "We appreciate the huge Taiwan investment in Thailand to help spur our economic development and we are also grateful that the ROC government has allowed our people to work in Taiwan," he added.

Other members of the Thai delegation included Wittaya Masayna, vice chairman of the Thai Senate Science, Technology and Energy Committee, and Wichai Krongyuth, spokesman for the Thai Senate Education and Culture Committee.

DOC.HEADLINE: TELECOMS SECTOR EXPECTED TO BECOME IMPORTANT GDP CONTRIBUTOR

TEXT.P: The Directorate General of Telecommunications has forecast that when the telecommunications market is fully liberalized in the second half of this year, the telecoms sector will contribute NT$63.1 billion in terms of gross domestic product (GDP) annually over the next five years.

As a part of its commitment to gaining access to the World Trade Organization, the Republic of China's Ministry of Transportation and Communications has accelerated the liberalization of telecommunications market in recent years.

The Directorate General of Telecommunications plans to increase its capital investment by an average NT$118.32 billion annually over the next five years, and these investments will help boost the nation's GDP and create over 77,000 new jobs.

After the government opened the mobile phone and paging businesses to the private sector in 1997, the number of mobile phone users in Taiwan increased from 1.49 million at the end of 1997 to 16.06 million in September 2000.
It is expected that the development of fixed net and third generation mobile phones will further advance the telecommunications sector.

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar was down NT$0.012 against the U.S. dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Tuesday, closing at 34.065.
The local currency opened Tuesday at 34.018 and was traded between 34.018 and 34.080.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$273 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS, OFFICIALS URGE PUBLIC TO FIGHT BACK AGAINST SEX CRIMES

TEXT.P: A group of legislators and government officials on Tuesday urged the public to fight back against sexual assaults by reporting suspects who fit the descriptions of at-large criminals and by following a series of measures to prevent becoming victims of sex crimes.
Opposition Kuomintang legislators Pan Wei-kang and Yang Chiung-ying announced the physical characteristics and modus operandi of five still-at-large sexual offenders at a press conference.

Also in attendance were Deputy Commissioner Lin Kuo-tung of the Criminal Investigation Bureau under the National Police Administration and Executive Secretary Lin Tse-ling of the Interior Ministry's Sexual Abuse and Family Violence Prevention Committee.

According to police statistics, the great majority of the cases of sexual assault occur between people who already know each other -- relatives, neighbors or close acquaintances -- or happen as date rape. Figures show that over 90 percent of the offenders in these cases over the past decade have been convicted.
Statistics also showed that over half of the victims are between the ages of 12 and 18, and that most of the crimes occur in residential areas.
The National Police Administration recommended that preventive measures should be taken to avoid becoming victims of sex crimes.
These measures include forming the habit of keeping doors closed at night and allowing friends to stay only in the living room when visiting at night.

People should take care that they are not followed in situations that could be dangerous, and if they feel uncomfortable with a stranger -- as in an elevator -- they should avoid the situation and seek out groups of people.

The administration also said that keeping a cellular phone on hand at all times for emergency calls is a good idea, and calling taxis through radio dispatch is better than waving them down on the street.
Police said that people should filter job placement ads carefully and refrain from accepting drinks or food during interviews.

One technique to get out a situation that seems to be turning dangerous is to find some way to buy time, police said. Telling a would-be rapist that you are pregnant or have a contagious disease could give a potential victim enough time to escape, officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT REAFFIRMS HOPE TO ATTEND APEC LEADERSHIP MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 12 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed his hope to attend the unofficial leadership meeting of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum scheduled for October in Shanghai, a leading Japanese newspaper said Tuesday.
Chen made the remarks when he received Shigeaki Hazama, chairman of the Sankei Shimbun, at the Presidential Office Monday.
The president said that as an APEC member and a national leader, it is his obligation and responsibility to attend the regional meeting.

President Chen also said that he looks forward to meeting with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin and exchange views with him on direct trade, postal and transportation links between Taiwan and mainland China and other issues.
The president said that if the leaders on both sides of the Taiwan Strait use wisdom and creativity to promote exchanges, problems regarding cross-strait issues could be solved.
He also said that the three priorities for the government will be improving the domestic economy, bettering cross-strait ties and the promotion of democratic reform and the crackdown on corruption.

On the year-end legislative elections, the president said that his ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) could become the largest party, although it may not be able to win half of the seats in the lawmaking body, but that it would cooperate with others that share the same ideals as the DPP.
The president also said that he intends to form a coalition government centered around the DPP.

DOC.HEADLINE: TZU CHI DONATES BONE MARROW TO M'LAND 86TH TIME

TEXT.P: The medical center of Taiwan's largest charity organization will again donate bone marrow to patients in mainland China, the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation announced Wednesday.
This will be the 86th time the foundation has donated bone marrow to patients on the mainland and the first time to Suzhou, Jiangxu province.
The bone marrow, to be flown from Hualien, eastern Taiwan, Wednesday early morning, is expected to arrive at Suzhou Hospital at midnight after a 20-hour trip.
Two local TV stations, one Hong Kong TV station and two Suzhou TV stations will air live coverage of the transportation process and the transplant procedure.

Since the foundation set up a bone marrow data center seven years ago, it has donated bone marrow 280 times to 15 countries and has made 85 donations to mainland China from 1997 to the end of May this year. The foundation has donated bone marrow to recipients in eight mainland China cities and provinces, including Beijing, Shanghai, Hangzhou, Chengdu, Guangzhou, Tianjin, Wuhan, and Hainan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA CHAIRMAN OFFERS ADVICE ON MAKING INVESTMENTS IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Taiwan businessmen should focus on expanding their sales into the mainland Chinese market when making investment there, said China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) Chairman Shea Jia-dong Tuesday.
He made the remark while addressing a symposium on creating business opportunities in mainland China, held at the Taipei World Trade Center under the auspices of CETRA.
With the upcoming entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) by the mainland and Taiwan, Shea said that Taiwan businessmen should focus on exploring the domestic market on the mainland.
To do this, he said, businessmen will need to have effective sales networks and should be well informed of tax law and business management in mainland China.
An accountant from the Tzecheng Accounting Office, Lu Shu, told the symposium that with the mainland's WTO entry, Beijing will repeal over 500 laws and implement many new laws and regulations.
She urged investors from Taiwan to understand fully regulations on the mainland's taxation system, and added that the best way to do this would be to hire qualified attorneys or accountants.

DOC.HEADLINE: U. S. MILITARY WORKSHOP VERY HELPFUL: ROC OFFICERS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 11 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A Republic of China military officer who is attending a two-week workshop in Washington, D.C. said Monday that the lecture program is very valuable and helpful to all participants.
The officer, who preferred anonymity, said that due to the Beijing-imposed diplomatic embargo against Taiwan, the ROC military has had few chances to develop cooperative ties with other countries.

"The current workshop is designed to help expand our military officers' vision and enhance their understanding of the latest international trends, U.S. policies toward Taiwan and mainland China, as well as the latest information on new military concepts," the officer explained.
In addition, the officer said, the workshop is expected to help boost exchanges of military personnel between Taiwan and the United States.

A total of 18 ROC military officers, most of them colonels, and two civilian experts are taking part in the workshop, organized by the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS), a Washington-based think tank.
Among the participants was Major General Lin Yu-pao, deputy commander of an F-16 squadron stationed in the eastern Taiwan county of Hualien.
It was believed to be the first time in many years that such a large number of Taiwan officers have traveled to the United States to attend a military workshop.

"As the lectures cover diverse subjects and all lecturers have rich experiences, the workshop is very useful to us," the officer said, adding that the lecture topics included U.S. policies toward Northeast Asia and Southeast Asia, U.S. security strategy, U.S. crisis management, global security trends, U.S. global challenges and U.S. military exchanges with the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
The workshop is being held at Georgetown University, with lecturers coming from the White House, the Department of Defense and the Central Intelligence Agency.

The lecturers include Torkel Patterson, senior official in Asian affairs at the National Security Council, Zbigniew Brzezinski, former national security adviser under the Carter administration, former Under Secretary of Defense Walter Slocombe and Richard Bush, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), as well as several China hands.
The participants visited the Pentagon Monday where they held a symposium with senior Pentagon officials in charge of Asia-Pacific security affairs and missile defense programs.

They will fly to Hawaii Wednesday to visit the U.S. Pacific Command, the last event of the two-week lecture program. Last week, they held talks with congressional aides on military and foreign relations.

Former U.S. Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense Kurt Campbell, who is now vice chairman of the CSIS, reportedly took the initiative to organize the workshop for ROC military officers. The proposal received the support of ROC President Chen Shui-bian and then-Premier Tang Fei when Campbell visited Taiwan last June.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAYOR MA MAKES 100TH BLOOD DONATION

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou made his 100th blood donation Tuesday, urging the public to roll up their sleeves to respond to blood donation enthusiastically.
Ma, who referred to himself as a "blood horse," made his 100th blood donation at noon at the Taipei Main Station of the Taipei Rapid Transit System.

As of the end of December last year, there are 5,030 in the Taiwan area who have made more than 100 blood donations. Of them, 907 are Taipei citizens, accounting for 18 percent, according to statistics released by the Taipei Blood Donation Center.
Later, the blood donation center sent Ma a photo album showing the mayor's past donations.

DOC.HEADLINE: 17 MAINLAND BRIDES GO HOME BY SAILING DIRECTLY FROM KINMEN

TEXT.P: Seventeen mainland Chinese brides who were married to residents in the Republic of China-held frontline island of Kinmen went back to mainland China Tuesday, sailing directly across a small part of the Taiwan Strait.

It was the first time that mainland brides have been allowed to visit their mainland families via a direct voyage from Kinmen to the southeastern mainland port city of Xiamen since the direct "mini three links" program was implemented at the beginning of this year.

As part of its efforts to show goodwill toward mainland China, the ROC opened its two offshore defense outposts of Kinmen and Matsu for direct trade, mail and shipping links with mainland China's Xiamen and Mawei ports, known as the "mini three links" program, on Jan. 1.

Beijing has been reluctant to throw its full support behind the program and has so far only approved applications for direct Kinmen-Xiamen and Matsu-Mawei voyages on a "group in, group out" and case-by-case basis.

Mainland Chinese brides were originally not covered by the "direct sailing" measure. After strenuous efforts by opposition New Party Legislator Lee Chu-feng, mainland authorities finally agreed to allow the 17 mainland brides to make homecoming visits by sailing directly on an experimental basis.
Kinmen, which lies far closer to mainland China than to Taiwan, now has about 300 mainland Chinese brides, but only three of them have obtained permanent residency.

Most other brides have to return to the mainland once their short-term visitor visas expire. In the past, they had to travel to Taiwan first and then back to the mainland via Hong Kong or Macau, wasting much time and money. With the opening of direct shipping services from Kinmen to Xiamen, each homecoming mainland bride can save about NT$15,000 (US$441.18) in transportation fees.

The mainland brides, accompanied by their spouses and other family members, took the Kinmen County Government-run ferry boat "TaiWu" from Liaolo Port early in the morning. They were all smiles when they boarded the ship on their way to Xiamen.

Also aboard the ship was a delegation of the Kinmen Red Cross Society, a 35-member tour group and 80-plus individual passengers. The33-member Red Cross Society delegation will visit its Xiamen counterpart and meet with mainland officials to discuss ways to promote bilateral humanitarian and cultural exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SHOULD PLAY 'DOUBLE DETERRENCE ROLE': SCHOLAR
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 11 (CNA) (By C. L. Tseng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The United States is not expected to help mediate the resumption of regular dialogue between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, a U.S. scholar said Monday.

John Holden, president of the National Committee on U.S.-China Relations, a private, non-profit organization dedicated to promoting U.S. exchanges with Taiwan, mainland China and Hong Kong, made the remarks while meeting with a 15-member delegation of journalists from Taiwan.
Holden said he doesn't think that the United States should adopt a "strategic ambiguity" approach in its policy toward cross-strait affairs.

In his view, Holden said, the United States should instead adopt a "double deterrence" strategy, deterring mainland China from using forces against Taiwan and simultaneously deterring Taiwan from declaring independence.
Holden further said he doesn't think that the United States is capable of serving as a mediator in cross-strait disputes.
Touching on future Taipei-Washington-Beijing relations, Holden said stable U.S.-mainland China ties would benefit Taiwan.

He predicted that U.S.-mainalnd China ties would gradually improve between June and October this year. Moreover, he said, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are likely to be admitted to the World Trade Organization before the end of this year. Against this backdrop, he said he does not rule out the possibility that Beijing resumes talks with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEDIA TYCOON-LEGISLATOR BOWS OUT OF LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: A local media mogul and legislator who was poised to change Taiwan's political landscape by trying to form a new political party with several independent lawmakers, announced Tuesday that he will not run for another term as legislator.

In a formal written announcement, Wang Ling-lin, an opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislator who owns at least two television news channels and a broadband cable TV network in Taiwan, said he would not take part in the year-end legislative election so as "not to further stir up the already chaotic politics in Taiwan."

Wang expressed appreciation to the KMT for its support over the past 12 years during which Wang served three consecutive terms as a KMT lawmaker. He also said he would turn down any invitation from any other political parties or groups to represent them in the year-end legislative election.

Although Wang made no mention of a new political party that he was reportedly forming and rumored to be called the "Justice Party," local political observers speculated that he quit the plan as a result of widespread accusations that the party would be formed by several "black-gold" figures -- legislators linked to corruption or organized crime -- an accusation that scared away some potential participants and consequently led to Wang's failure to recruit enough hopefuls to form the new political group.
Wang said that from now on, he will devote all his time and attention to his media group so as to allow it "to make more valuable contributions to society."
Meanwhile, independent Legislator Lo Fu-chu said the "Justice Party" will be established as planned, probably in July, despite Wang's absence.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD GIVES SPEECH AT OXFORD UNIVERSITY
DOC.DATELINE: London, June 12 (CNA) (By Mark Ou and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan gave a speech Tuesday at Oxford University in the United Kingdom in which he focused on Taiwan's economic and political situations and the future of his party.

In a speech titled "Think of Future Perils With Nothing to Hide" and made in his capacity as head of Taiwan's largest opposition party, Lien described Taiwan as "sick" because of internal factors rather than as a result of external threats as had been a problem in the past.

Over the past year, Taiwan has encountered serious economic difficulties and a confidence crisis. With noticeable falls in the country's economic growth, investment projects, export volume and the stock market, the people of Taiwan have experienced rising unemployment and have seen the value of their assets shrink.

As for the confidence crisis, Lien said, all past surveys have shown that Taiwan residents are dissatisfied with the performance of the government led by the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and that the local business community is pessimistic about Taiwan's deteriorating economic prospects.

Such a severe lack of public confidence in the government will produce a tremendous adverse effect on national development, he noted, adding that non-economic factors, such as the government's failure to follow normal constitutional practices and its failure to improve Taiwan's relations with mainland China are the critical reasons behind Taiwan's present economic slowdown.
Shifting the focus of his analysis to the political front, the KMT chairman used the term "three-sphere minority government" to explain Taiwan's current political woes.

According to Lien, "three-sphere minority" refers to President Chen Shui-bian's election by only 39 percent of Taiwan's voters last year, the ruling DPP's control of only one-third of the seats at the Legislative Yuan and Premier Chang Chun-hsiung's "cavalier" formation of a Cabinet without negotiation with the majority parties.

He said that the DPP's minority in these three areas has resulted in a majority for the opposition in the government's legislative branch and an executive branch formed by a minority party, producing tremendous difficulties for the DPP in trying to carry out its policies and sparking declining public confidence in the government.
On cross-Taiwan Strait ties and Taiwan's national status, Lien criticized the government for its failure to recognize the "1992 consensus" reached between Taipei and Beijing in that year.

He said the current pro-independence government's refusal to accept the "1992 consensus" has shut the doors for continued bilateral negotiations and has left its mainland China policies "hanging in the air."

Describing present Taiwan-mainland China relations as "at a severe impasse," Lien voiced his hope that the KMT, with the support of a vast majority of the Taiwan people, will exercise its role as a stabilizer between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and as a "tugboat" in the DPP's drawing up of its policies toward mainland China.

Lien said he hopes that the KMT's efforts will help build a "cold but peaceful" climate between Taiwan and the mainland and prompt the two sides to learn how to co-exist peacefully before accomplishing the long-expected "win-win" goal for both sides.

Speaking of the KMT's reforms, Lien said that the party is seeking to achieve internal democratization, purification and streamlining to win greater pubic backing. He stressed that the KMT will try to lead and unite the country with the people who share its ideals and aspirations.

In addition to taking Taiwan's interests as the KMT's top priorities, the KMT chief emphasized that the party will also be open to mainland China and the world to recruit all kinds of talent, regardless of ethnic background.
Britain is the first stop on Lien's current "academic journey," which will also take him to Paris and New York.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDUSTRIAL SECTOR AFFIRMS PROPOSED ECONOMIC ADVISORY PANEL: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Around 74 percent of the island's industrial sector affirms the establishment of an economic development advisory committee proposed by President Chen Shui-bian last month, according to the results of a survey released Tuesday.
The survey was conducted by the Chinese National Federation of Industries among 143 representatives of the federation between May 25 and June 7, with a response rate of 68 percent.

Fifty-three percent of the respondents said that the committee would be "helpful" to the improvement of the country's long-term development and management environment, while 21 percent said it would be "somewhat helpful." Twenty percent termed it as "of no help whatsoever."

The respondents said that the committee should give its top priority to the "investment environment and economic problems," followed by "the prospects for industrial development," "labor conditions and regulations," "opening of cross-Taiwan Strait economic and trade exchanges," "the financial market and order" and "resolution of the unemployment problem."

Regarding the improvement of the investment environment, they proposed that the government increase the number of public construction projects, enhance fundamental development, improve administrative procedures, raise administrative efficiency, encourage research and development through tax incentives, stabilize foreign exchange rates and reduce investment restrictions.

Chen told a group of legislators from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party Monday that the proposed advisory committee will be designed as a consultation mechanism that will not infringe on the constitutional system.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASHES OF TAIWAN TOURISTS KILLED IN MAINLAND CHINA BACK HOME
DOC.DATELINE: CKS International Airport, Taoyuan, June 12 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The ashes of four Taiwan tourists killed last Thursday when their hotel was buried in a landslide triggered by heavy rain in Guangxi, southern mainland China, were brought back to Taiwan Tuesday by their families.

The four victims, identified as Hsu Ming-teh, Lin Ai-oh, Chen Feng-chin and Hsu Chuan-chuan, were part of a 60-member Taiwan travel group from the central Taiwan city of Taichung that was on an eight-day tour of Guilin, a famous scenic spot in Guangxi, a Zhuang ethnic autonomous region.
It was also reported that members of the group should have been accommodated in a different hotel altogether, but the travel agent in Guangxi mistakenly arranged for them to stay in the doomed hotel.
The surviving members are scheduled to return to Taiwan Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: `INTEL TEACH TO THE FUTURE' REACHES TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An "Intel Teach to the Future" plan dedicated to combining computer technology with education to raise students' interest in learning has reached Taiwan.

In a ceremony held Tuesday in Taipei, the Republic of China Ministry of Education, National Normal University and Intel Taiwan jointly announced that the project will begin in Taiwan in July, aimed at training 10,000 "e teachers" in primary and junior high schools islandwide within two years.

Addressing the occasion, Education Minister Ovid Tzeng took a recent distant conference in which he participated as an example, saying that with the invention and application of state-of-the-art technology, teachers and students have wider and faster access to knowledge and Internet-related activities.
Tzeng offered his appreciation to Intel for the U.S.-based company's efforts to help promote information technology and related education in Taiwan.

According to an Intel Taiwan spokesman, under the "Intel Teach to the Future" project, Intel plans to invest US$100 million to train some 400,000 primary and junior high school teachers from 20 selected countries around the world before 2002.

So far, the project has already begun in the United States, Britain, France and Germany, and is being carried out satisfactorily. Similar programs are expected to kick off soon in Taiwan, Japan, India and mainland China, the spokesman said.

If the project is successfully implemented in Taiwan before 2002, 5 percent of Taiwan's primary and junior high school teachers will be "e teachers," who will in turn teach at least 300,000 primary school pupils and junior high students with e-knowledge and related technology, said Prof. Wu Cheng-yi from National Normal University.

Before the 10,000 teachers are actually "taught" to be "e teachers," said Wu, some 200 "seed" lecturers will be cultivated first under the Intel project. These "seed" lecturers will mainly be trained in skills including how to make presentations via computer, Internet writing and editing, as well as basic Internet graphic design, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER TO TAKE PART IN WORLD FORUM IN U.S.

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao has been invited to take part in a World Forum Conference to be held in Denver, Colorado June 21-22 and to deliver a speech, sources from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.

MOFA spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue said the conference is being organized by the American Enterprise Institute (AEI), an American think-tank considered to be an institute that shares many of the beliefs and viewpoints of the George W. Bush Administration today. Vice President Dick Cheney used to be a board director of the AEI and his wife is an AEI adviser on education problems.
Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council has worked with the AEI and maintains close acquaintance with Cheney.

A former AEI director-general is Undersecretary of State for Arms Control and International Security John Bolton, who is a staunch supporter of the ROC and believes Taiwan should be allowed to be a formal member of the United Nations, according to MOFA sources.
It was learned that Lien Chan, chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, has also been invited to take part in the conference, which will bring together opinion leaders and world political leaders.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-JAPAN GOAL SHOULD BE ASIAN PEACE: ROC REPRESENTATIVE
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 12 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Representative to Japan Lo Fu-chuan said in Tokyo Tuesday that upholding peace and stability in Asia should be the goal of developing the relationship between Japan and Taiwan.
Lo, a scholar-turned-diplomat, made the statement while speaking at a gathering organized by the Japan Mass Media Research Institute.

In his speech, titled "Taiwan-Japan Relations During the New Era," Lo reported Taiwan's economic and democratic achievements, the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations and the outlook for Taiwan's relations with Japan.

He said that Taiwan has no intention of taking a hostile attitude toward mainland China, but stressed that it must possess sufficient defensive military power, as Beijing is reluctant to renounce the use of force against Taiwan.
Lo noted that the main pillar of Japan's foreign policy is based on its alliance with the United States, while Taiwan's relationship with Japan is also connected with the same pillar.
"At the start of the new century, common efforts to safeguard the peace and stability of Asia should be the goal of the Taiwan-Japan relationship," he said.

Lo added that ROC President Chen Shui-bian held talks with more than 20 U.S. congressmen in New York and Houston on his way to and from an official visit to five Latin American countries recently and voiced his hope that the Japanese government will follow the Bush administration's flexible posture toward Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC NEEDS TO TAKE STEPS TO ACQUIRE SUBMARINES: U.S. OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 12 (CNA) (By Jay Chen & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: A senior White House official told a group of middle-ranking officers from Taiwan recently that the Taipei government should take steps toward acquiring submarines.

Torkel Patterson, who is in charge of Asian affairs for the National Security Council, noted that the Bush administration reversed the policy of previous administrations and agreed in April to provide Taiwan with eight diesel-electric submarines.
However, he noted that the U.S. government will not pressure the Netherlands and other makers of such submarines to provide Taiwan with blueprints of the submarines.
The United States has not manufactured submarines of the type it agreed to sell Taiwan for more than 40 years.
According to the Taiwan officers, who began a two-week training course in Washington June 4, Patterson made the remarks while answering questions from the officers last week.
He reportedly said that the Bush administration gave Taiwan an opportunity to improve its anti-submarine capability, and added that "Taiwan has to pick up the ball ... to make it happen."

If Taiwan decides to acquire the submarines, he pointed out that the defense industry will be able to help Taiwan attain the goal and went on that Taiwan must first decide how to compile a purchase budget.
At the same time, the Defense Weekly says in its current issue that the manufacturers who could make submarines for Taiwan may alter the competition for submarine exports permanently.
A Connecticut-based naval analyst was quoted as saying that the capital from Taiwan may lead to the emergence of a new industry to manufacture conventional submarines in the United States.
The weekly said that by 2018, 12 countries, including Taiwan, Turkey, Singapore and South Korea, will have procured 38 conventional submarines carrying a total value of US$127 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: HAKKAS CELEBRATE FORMING OF CABINET-LEVEL COUNCIL OF HAKKA AFFAIRS

TEXT.P: A group of Hakkas, one of the major ethnic groups in Taiwan, gathered Tuesday at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall to celebrate the soon-to-be-formed Cabinet-level Council of Hakka Affairs.
An opening ceremony for the council is scheduled to be held Thursday.

Political dignitaries of the ruling and opposition parties, including Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou attended the gathering and extended their congratulations.
Chang thanked the Legislative Yuan for its full support that resulted in the smooth establishment of the council.
He said that the setting up of the council is aimed at conserving plural cultures and languages, as well as striving for a channel to give the Hakkas' a voice.

Wu Poh-hsiung, vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang and a heavyweight among Hakka people, also spoke at the gathering to voice his hope that the council will give full play to conserving Hakka language and culture.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA COMMENTS ON MACEDONIAN MOVE ON TIES WITH ROC

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Ministry spokesperson Chang Siao-yue said that the Macedonian cabinet meeting Tuesday heatedly debated whether to restore Skopje's diplomatic relations with Beijing.
She said that the meeting decided to entrust the president to formulate a consensus on the issue through discussions with leaders of various political parties.
According to Chang, the issue was presented to the cabinet meeting for debate by Foreign Minister Ilinka Mitreva.
Macedonia established diplomatic relations with Taiwan in January 1999. Restoration of its relations with Beijing would automatically end its formal ties with Taipei.

ROC Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao recently visited Skopje to try to save Taipei's ties with the fragile Balkans republic. However, he stressed that Taipei would not compromise its dignity in exchange for the ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S III MAKING INROADS INTO MAINLAND'S INTERNET MARKET

TEXT.P: The Institute for Information Industry (III), one of the pushers behind Taiwan's flagship information technology industry, has begun relocating operations to mainland China, apparently attracted by the mainland's huge cyber market potential.

In its first ever cross-strait exposition of electronics market vision and cooperation which opened in Shanghai Tuesday, the III has successfully played the role of "matchmaker," enabling TBCommerce, Taiwan, an affiliate of the U.S.-based TBCommerce, and the China Internet Incubation Center (CIIC), an operation under mainland China's Ministry of Science and Technology, to tie up for closer cooperation.
This tie-up marks the first cooperation agreement that the III has successfully pushed to achieve after the institute decided to make inroads into mainland China.

Under the cooperation program, TBCommerce, Taiwan, TBLink, and Shanghai Internet Incubation Investment Co. (SI3), the executive operation of CIIC, will share equally the establishment funds of a new company which will target mainland China's e-commerce as a major market.

The III, SI3 and TBCommerce also co-sponsored a forum meeting in Shanghai Tuesday as a sideline to the e-commerce exposition. The forum was participated in by trade officials, scientists and researchers, as well as leaders in the IT industry across the Taiwan Strait.
TBCommerce, which has actively tried to edge into mainland China's Internet market in recent years, is mainly comprised of American-Chinese talents who have worked at AT&T and Bell Laboratory.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONCERNED ABOUT PRC'S REPORTED ARMS SUPPLY TO CUBA

TEXT.P: Communist China has reportedly been delivering military equipment to Cuba, James Kelly, U.S. assistant secretary of state for East Asian affairs, told a House subcommittee Tuesday.

Kelly, however, did not offer any more details when testifying before the House International Relations Subcommittee on East Asia and the Pacific because, he said, he needed more information before he could comment on the matter further.

The senior State Department official said he is looking into reports by the Washington Times that at least three arms deliveries have arrived in Cuba from mainland China over the past several months. "We're very much concerned with this PLA (People's Liberation Army) cooperation and movement of military equipment into Cuba," he said.

Trent Lott, the Senate minority leader, said that he wants answers about the shipments. "If it is true, I think that is a very bad sign for China. I think it's a violation of a lot of understandings that probably are in place," he added.

Meanwhile, Rep. Dana Rohrabacher (R-Calif.), a member of the House International Relations Committee and a consistent critic of Beijing, said he believes the Communist Chinese "appear to be trying to position themselves to have leverage over the United States throughout the world."

"Whether it's in Cuba or whether it's in the Panama Canal or whether it's in the South China Sea, Communist China is trying to have an iron grip on areas that are strategically important to the security of the United States and the Western democracies," the congressman pointed out.
Rohrabacher added that Beijing's efforts to establish a supplier relationship with Fidel Castro is "totally consistent with the Communist Chinese belligerence towards the United States in general."

"I think that the new (Bush) administration should make it clear to the Communist Chinese that they are either going to be our friends or they are going to be treated as our adversaries and our potential enemies. If they are going to be our friends, they have got to start acting like our friends," he said.

"Supplying weapons to Castro to put pressure on us is not what a friend would do. If they continue to move in that direction, there will be economic as well as political and military consequences," he warned.

U.S. officials told the Washington Times that the arms shipments to Cuba could lead to economic sanctions against Beijing. U.S. law requires the imposition of economic sanctions on any nation or company that gives lethal military assistance to a nation designated as a state sponsor of terrorism.
But Philip Reeker, a spokesman for the State Department, said the department has not yet determined whether sanctions are required in this case.
