DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, June 13, or the 22nd day of the fourth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
323 BC: Alexander the Great, king of Macedonia who came to the throne at the age of only 20 and conquered Persia, Egypt, Babylon, Central Asia and part of India, dies in Babylon at the age of 33 upon his return from India.
1774: Rhode Island becomes the first American colony to ban the importation of slaves and to assure their freedom.
1842: Queen Victoria becomes the first British monarch to travel by train when she takes a trip from Slough to Paddington.
1865: Irish poet and playwright William Butler Yeats is born. The dramatist was the co-founder of the Abbey Theater in Dublin and won the Nobel Prize for literature in 1923.
1893: The first women's golf championship is held at Royal Lytham in Britain and is won by Lady Margaret Scott.
1900: A group of volunteer soldiers known as the Boxers go on the rampage through Beijing in protest against the "foreign devils" who have such a hold on their country. Popular discontent with internal misgovernment and anti-foreign sentiment aroused by the unequal treaties combined to spark what becomes known as the Boxer Uprising.
1931: Dr. Shibasaburo Kitazato, noted Japanese bacteriologist, dies of a stroke at the age of 78.
1944: London comes under attack as Hitler lets loose a devastating new weapon on the city. The so-called V1 flying bomb, or "doodle bug," as it has been nicknamed, is a long-range device that can be launched safely from within enemy territory.
1951: United Nations troops capture Pyongyang, capital of North Korea.
1956: Communist China's Premier Zhou Enlai requests a meeting with the U.S. Secretary of State John Foster Dulles. His request is rejected.
1956: The last British troops leave the Suez Canal Zone, ending 75 years of British rule in Egypt.
1971 Geraldine Brodrick gives birth to nine babies in Australia, one of the few recorded instances of nonuplets.
1973: Gen. Frederick C. Weyand, commander-in-chief of the U.S. Army in the Pacific, arrives in Taipei for a two-day visit.
1978: President Chiang Ching-kuo, in an interview with Edward W. Scripps II, director of the Scripps-Howard Newspaper in the United States, warns that the Chinese communists are trying to push the United States to the brink of war with the Soviet Union.
1978: Pu Chung-chiang, 10, labeled as the "fastest boy in the world" by the press, receives a silver medal from the ROC Ministry of Education in distance races in the United States.
1982: Saudi Arabian King Khalid ibn Abul-Aziz dies and is succeeded by his brother Prince Fahd.
1987: Republic of China Premier Yu Kuo-hua, in a statement made after returning from Singapore and learning of violent protests outside the Legislative Yuan, says the government's determination to implement constitutional democracy will never change, but unlawful acts will be dealt with in accordance with the law.
1989: Beijing orders the arrest of the leaders of the pro-democracy demonstrations in Tiananmen Square.
1989: Russian President Mikhail Gorbachev and West Germany's Chancellor Helmut Kohl agree that East and West Germany should be reunited.
1994: The Foreign Ministry of North Korea announces it is withdrawing from the United Nations' International Atomic Energy Agency and will no longer permit U.N. nuclear inspectors into the country.
1996: Copper prices tumble around the world after Sumitomo Corp. says it has lost an estimated US$2.6 billion over 10 years due to unauthorized copper trade.
1998: Lucio Costa, Brazilian architect who planned the Brazilian capital Brasilia, dies at the age of 96.
1999: The fifth Taiwan-Poland Economic Cooperation Conference opens in Taipei with trade officials and business leaders from both countries taking part.
2000: The United States Senate passes a resolution in recognition of Stephen Chen, the Republic of China's representative to the United States, for his distinguished service.
2000: Microsoft Chairman Bill Gates praises Taiwan's companies as a key that "made things happen" in the growth of the global computer industry over the past 25 years.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who is austere in his look, but a weakling and a coward at heart -- is he not like one of your small, mean people? Is he not like a sneaking thief or a cowardly pickpocket?"

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 56.53 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Wednesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 56.53 points to close at 5,209.71.
Market turnover amounted to NT$75.52 billion (US$2.22 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-BORDER HEROIN TRAFFICKING RING BUSTED

TEXT.P: A cross-border drug trafficking ring involving three Taiwan men and two "traffickers" from Singapore and Malaysia was busted by Taipei law enforcement authorities Tuesday night.
Three bags containing a total of two kilograms of high-grade heroin with a street value of over NT$10 million were seized.

In a joint operation between the Taipei City Police Headquarters and the Criminal Investigation Bureau under the directive of Taipei district prosecutor Liu Cheng-wu, police locked their focus on two Taiwan drug dealers, identified as Chiu Ching-chung and Tsao Yung-hsing, whom police found out were scheduled to close a drug deal at Mingchuan East Road and Chungshan North Road at around 8 p.m. Tuesday.
Chiu and Tsao were spotted making the deal at the expected location before driving away in a Mercedes Benz with bags believed to contain drugs.
After being chased by police for a couple of blocks, Tsao got out of the Mercedes and was nabbed with two big bags of heroin.
After another frenzied chase toward the western side of downtown Taipei, the police were able to stop the Mercedes and nab Chiu with the other bag of heroin.

Meanwhile, also acting on a tip, the Taipei police and investigators raided a hotel on Shuangcheng Road where they arrested Ang Lai Sin, a Singaporean, and Chaw Kok Lim, a Malaysian, who were about to check out of the hotel and leave Taiwan. The police discovered NT$1 million in cash in one of their luggage bags, apparently part of the payment that they received from Chiu and Tsao.
According to Ang and Chaw, a Taiwan man surnamed Yang handed them the money right after they closed the "deal" on the street.
According to police investigations, the cross-border drug smuggling ring has trafficked high-grade heroin from Malaysia to Taiwan several times over the past several months.

The police also found out that Ang used to be an ace ten-pin bowler who was selected to represent Singapore's national team in 2000. He later withdrew from the team after he was diagnosed to have intestinal cancer.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 56.53 points to close at 5,209.71
The bourse opened at 5,270.16 but began to go down due to a decline in semiconductor share prices. The index fluctuated between 5,318.71 and 5,205.03 during trading.

A total of 2.18 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$75.52 billion (US$2.22 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.92 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$68.02 billion (US$2 billion).
Two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with bank and insurance stocks moving up the most at 0.4 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 0.1 percent.

The other major categories posted losses, with electrical shares moving down the most at 1.5 percent, followed by construction stocks at 1.4 percent, textile issues and plastics and chemical shares, both at 1.3 percent, foodstuff shares at 0.7 percent, and cement stocks at 0.5 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 284 to 206, with 99 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN PITCHES FOR HIGH-LEVEL EXCHANGES WITH MANILA

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that the absence of bilateral diplomatic relations between the Republic of China and the Philippines should not hinder exchanges of visits by high-ranking officials from the two sides.

Chen made the remarks while meeting with Antonio Basilio, new chairman of the Manila Economic and Cultural Office, which is authorized by the Philippine government to handle exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.
Noting that Taiwan and the Philippines are close neighbors, Chen said the absence of formal diplomatic relations has not hampered the development of substantive relations between the two countries.

For instance, Chen recalled that former ROC President Lee Teng-hui met with his then-Philippine counterpart, Fidel Ramos, during a transit stop at Subic Bay in 1994 on his way to Indonesia for an unofficial visit.
Chen pointed out that there is still ample room for Taiwan and the Philippines to boost bilateral exchanges and cooperation in the economic, trade, cultural and educational fields.

The president told his guests that the ROC government has consistently encouraged Taiwan entrepreneurs to invest in Southeast Asian countries, particularly members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN).
In his view, Chen said the Philippines can be a good investment destination and springboard for Taiwan business people to tap into the vast Southeast Asian market.
However, direct Taiwan investment in the Philippines remains limited for various reasons, including worsening public order there.

Chen said it takes only 45 minutes to fly from the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung to the Philippines. "It would be a pity if our two countries could not further upgrade substantive exchanges," he noted.
With the Philippine political situation gradually stabilizing, Chen said he is hopeful that substantive ROC-Philippine relations will from now on make headway smoothly.

More than 92,000 Philippine nationals are now legally working in Taiwan. Chen said that although there have been some unpleasant labor-management squabbles involving Philippine workers, most Philippine laborers are generally diligent.
"We appreciate their contribution to helping boost our economic development over the past years," Chen said, adding that the ROC will continue keeping its door open to Philippine workers.
In addition, Chen said Taiwan will also encourage its people to invest in the Philippines or vacation there in order to help enhance bilateral exchanges.
Chen said he also hopes that ROC-Philippine relations will enter a new stage during Basilio's term of office.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were generally lower on Wednesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for June moved down 52 points to close at 5,193, with 8,148 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for July lost 50 points to finish at 5,190, with 653 contract transactions, while September futures decreased 52 points to close at 5,194, with one contract traded.
December futures increased 4 points to finish at 5,250, with one contract transaction, while next March futures increased 43 points, with only one contract traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 5,245 for June, 5,240 for July, 5,246 for September, 5,246 for December, and 5,206 for next March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.
June TE futures moved down 4.05 points to close at 265.95, with 1,622 contract transactions, while July TE futures lost 3.3 points to finish at 266.3, with 60 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
June TF futures moved up 1.8 points to finish at 685, with 796 contracts changing hands, while July TF futures increased 3 points to close at 684, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: FPG TOPS IN REVENUE, PROFITS AMONG LOCAL BUSINESS GROUPS: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) recorded revenues totaling NT504.5 billion (US$14.76 billion) last year to top all domestic business groups in Taiwan for the second consecutive year, according to a survey released Wednesday.

Business Weekly, which conducted the survey of the top 100 business groups in Taiwan, said that the FPG also made it to the top of the list for 2000 in terms of after-tax profits, at NT$74.4 billion (US$2.176 billion).

FPG's revenue in 2000 increased by NT$120 billion from the previous year, mainly because of its Formosa Petrochemical Corp. and its Mailiao power plant in Yunling, southwestern Taiwan, with both helping to contribute more than NT$60 billion.
FPG officials estimated that after the full development of its petroleum products this year, total annual revenues are expected to increase by NT$100 billion to over NT$600 billion.
Following the FPG in terms of total revenues were Lin Yuan Group, Shin Kong, Acer, Evergreen, Philips Taiwan, Tatung, Koo's, Yulon and Far Eastern, in that order.
One of the survey's noteworthy points is that Evergreen made it into the top 10 list for the first time while President Enterprises was squeezed out of that exclusive club.

In terms of profits, FPG was also tops, accumulating NT$74.4 billion (US$2.176 billion) last year, followed by the group headed by Robert Tsao, chairman of United Microelectronics Corp., which recorded total profits of NT$58.6 billion (US$1.714 billion).
Rounding out the top 10 list of most lucrative groups were Walsin Lihwa, China Steel, Evergreen, Asustck Computer, Acer, Tatung, Delta Electronic, and Pacific Electric Wire & Cable, in that order.
Meanwhile, two information technology companies demonstrated their high potential through their stunning growth last year.
Hou Hai Precision Industry recorded total revenues of NT$103.3 billion, up 68 percent from the previous year, with its ranking leaping to 18th overall from 30th a year earlier.
Via Technologies recorded total revenues of NT$35.4 billion, up a stunning 178 percent from the previous year, jumping in rank from 131st overall in 1998 to 50th in 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET-LEVEL HAKKA AFFAIRS COMMITTEE TO BECOME OPERATIONAL

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Committee for Hakka Affairs (CHA) is expected to become operational Thursday after eight months of preparation, sources from the Executive Yuan said Wednesday.

Lawyer Fan Kuang-chun, who is a national policy adviser to the president, will be the first chairman of the CHA, which has been established to strengthen services to the nation's Hakka population -- one of the most important branches of the Chinese people whose ancestors emigrated from mainland China to Taiwan hundreds of years ago.
Roughly one-sixth of Taiwan's 23 million people are Hakkas.

Premier Chang Chun-hsiung offered his appreciation to the Legislative Yuan Wednesday for the legislature's passage of related statutes allowing the establishment, operation and budget of the long-awaited committee.
The Hakkas constitute an important sector of Taiwan culture and are part of the foundation from which Taiwan's "economic miracle" was created, Chang noted.

A cocktail party was scheduled to be held at Grand Hotel Wednesday evening to mark the establishment of the committee, with Vice President Annette Lu and Premier Chang Chun-hsiung delivering keynote speeches.
President Chen Shui-bian will address a formal ceremony Thursday marking the inauguration of the committee.

The Hakkas are Chinese whose ancestors lived in "Chung Yuan," or "China proper," comprising Hebei, Henan, Shaanxi, Shanxi and some parts of other provinces in central and northern China. They gradually migrated to southern China and emigrated to Southeast Asia and other parts of the world during national upheavals since the fourth century.
The Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission in Taipei estimated in 1992 that there were about 34 million overseas Chinese at that time, one-third of whom were Hakkas.

The Hakkas are noted for their persistent adherence to traditional Chinese customs and values, such as patriotism, loyalty, hard work, endurance, love of freedom, and resistance to alien aggression and influence. In addition, they look upon themselves as people of high social status, which is why they do not assimilate well into the local community and are called "guest people" wherever they live. "Hakka" means "guest family" in mandarin Chinese.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL PALACE MUSEUM DIRECTOR ON HIS VISIONS OF NEW CENTURY

TEXT.P: One year after being appointed director of the National Palace Museum in Taipei, Tu Cheng-sheng, a scholar of history and philology, is giving a new orientation to the symbol of "China's 7,000-year legacy."
In Tu's vision, the museum's collection of art treasures should "unite with the new Taiwan," he says.

In an interview with CNA, Tu said that the museum, with its valuable art treasures "evacuated" from mainland China in the late 1940s, has in the past been a sensitive political symbol. Since he assumed the directorship last year, he has been trying to place more emphasis on the museum's mission as an institution of academic research as well as art education. He also expects to inject "the new vigor of Taiwan" into the establishment.

A specialist in the social history of ancient China, cultural history, and medical history, Tu was a visiting scholar of the School of Oriental and African Studies, University of London, from 1992-1993 and director of the Institute of History and Philology of Academia Sinica from 1995-2000. Constantly invited to international seminars and symposiums, Tu is very keen on international cooperation projects.

From the diversified subjects of the exhibitions, one can have a glimpse of the difference in style between the 57-year-old museum director and his predecessors. Famous paintings on loan from Spain's Gala-Salvador Dali Foundation were shown at the special exhibition hall library from Jan. 20 to April 20. An exhibition featuring portraits of the land and people by contemporary Taiwanese painter Li Mei-shu (1902-1983) is on display from May 5 to Aug. 5. Another special exhibition -- "The Land and Its People - Active Figures in the History of Taiwan During the Ching Dynasty" focuses on biographies of historical figures related to Taiwan.

Tu said that in the past years, selected items of the museum's collection were loaned to museums in the United States and France for special exhibitions. Museums in other countries are also interested in sponsoring such exhibitions. The next international cooperation project is expected to be realized in 2003 in Germany.

The National Palace Museum has reached an agreement with the German federal art museum in Bonn after long years of negotiations to loan selected items to the German museum for a special exhibition. The German parliament has adopted a resolution to provide legal guarantees for the loaned objects.

Tu said that in return, museums in Germany will loan selected items of their collections to the National Palace Museum. Museums in Vienna are also interested in co-sponsoring exhibitions of their collections in Taipei.

Stressing the educational function of the museum, Tu said that the museum is organizing academic activities to make it a "classroom of art and culture." In line with current exhibitions, symposiums are being held. In the past two months, for instance, there has been a symposium featuring the calligraphy and seal carving of Wang Chuang-wei (1909-1998), a conference on the theme of poetry and literature in Chinese art, and an international symposium on archives of the Ching Dynasty and research on the history of Taiwan.

Tu said that a large-scale international conference on Mongolian culture is scheduled for October, when the museum will present a special exhibition. In 2002, the museum will organize an international conference on East Asia's early modern artistic history, with the participation of specialists from the United States, Japan and South Korea. The conference will be co-sponsored by the National Taiwan University and Academia Sinica.

In addition to academic activities, Tu said that he hopes the museum can also become closer to the people. The museum is giving regular lectures on various themes and the Children's Program, using educational games and activities to help children learn about Chinese culture and history, is a popular community program in Taipei.

The museum has also made contemporary Taiwanese artists a major theme of its special exhibitions. Tu said the annual Centennial Exhibition will feature one representative figure of Taiwan's artistic history in the past century. This year, Li Mei-shu (1902-1983), a pioneer of Western-style painting in Taiwan, is commemorated with an exhibition of his landscapes and portraits.
"While preserving its heritage, the museum must explore new dimensions," Tu said, adding that he hopes the vigor of Taiwan will enrich the treasures of the museum.

DOC.HEADLINE: 6 BILLS TO HELP LURE FOREIGN INVESTMENT: FINANCE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang said Wednesday that if six bills crucial to financial reforms can clear the Legislative Yuan, they will have the potential to lure at least US$5 billion-worth of foreign capital to Taiwan.
Yen made the remarks at a public hearing on his recent overseas visit to woo foreign investment. The hearing was convened by Legislator Lai Shyh-bao of the opposition New Party.

Yen has lobbied for the convening of an extra session of the legislature to pass the six bills, including a financial holding company bill and regulations on the establishment and management of a financial rehabilitation fund. The six bills are among a backlog of bills left outstanding by the recently completed legislative session.
Yen said that he will pitch for domestic financial reforms when he travels to Europe to lobby for foreign investment later this month.
He noted that the establishment of a financial fund will help write off mounting bad debts, while the financial holding companies bill will enable financial institutions to diversify to other fields.

He said that foreign institutional investors have great interest in Taiwan's financial market and information technology industries, adding that in the first five months of this year, foreign investors have pumped in US$5.2 billion.

He also said that foreign investors are concerned about transparency in Taiwan's financial market, and that if he can provide information on the island's financial reforms, it will be very attractive to foreign investors.
He predicted that between January this year and June 2002, net increase of foreign capital inflow will be no less than US$20 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: N.T. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar was down NT$0.312 against the U.S. dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Wednesday, closing at 34.377.
The local currency opened Wednesday at 34.025 and was traded between 34.009 and 34.440.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$692.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MAN DONATES BONE MARROW TO MAINLAND CHINESE WOMAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan's biggest charity, the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, was instrumental Wednesday in enabling a 26-year-old Taiwan man to donate 1,305 c.c. of bone marrow for transplant to a woman in mainland China.

Doctors at the foundation's medical center in Hualien, eastern Taiwan, extracted the bone marrow from the donor early in the morning for immediate delivery to Suzhou in the eastern mainland province of Jiangsu for the transplant operation.

Four Tzu Chi volunteers started the 15-hour journey to deliver the bone marrow from Hualien to Suzhou via Taipei, Hong Kong and Shanghai immediately after the soft, fatty, vascular tissue was extracted from the donor.

The bone marrow was scheduled to arrive at a Suzhou hospital at 10 p.m. Wednesday, where a medical team will transplant the tissue to the 21-year-old mainland woman, who suffers from acute leukemia and needs the bone marrow transplant to survive.
This was the 86th Tzu Chi-mediated bone marrow donation to mainland China. The foundation has so far mediated 280 cross-border bone marrow donations to 15 countries around the world.

As part of its efforts to encourage bone marrow donations for transplant, the foundation arranged for two Taiwan, one Hong Kong and two Suzhou TV stations to make live broadcasts of the bone marrow extraction, the transportation process and the transplant procedure.
"It's the first time that the foundation has given live coverage of the whole donation and transplant process with a view to encourage organ donation," said a Tzu Chi spokesman.

The spokesman said mainland Chinese people are even more conservative than their Taiwan counterparts in their attitudes toward organ donation. "Mainland medical professionals have often sought our assistance in matching compatible bone marrow donations with suitable recipients," he added.
As of the end of May, the Tzu Chi foundation's bone marrow databank had collated information about 217,250 prospective bone marrow donors, making it the largest databank of its kind in Asia.

The foundation just made its 14th bone marrow donation to South Korea last Saturday, extracting bone marrow from a 30-year-old local man for transplant to a 29-year-old South Korean musician, also a leukemia patient.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA KEEPING CLOSE WATCH ON DEVELOPMENTS IN MACEDONIA: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Republic of China mission in Macedonia has no plans to evacuate strife-torn country for the moment as the situation in the Balkan state's capital, Skopje, remains largely calm, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Wednesday.
MOFA spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue told a routine press conference that the ROC mission in Macedonia has finalized a comprehensive contingency plan, but will not implement it -- at least for the moment.
"The mission is closely monitoring the situation there and will decide whether to evacuate based on the developments in the internal fighting in that country," Chang said.

Touching on the formal diplomatic relationship between the ROC and Macedonia, Chang said the Macedonia Cabinet has yet to reach a consensus on the proposal to sever ties with Taipei in favor of Beijing.

"The Macedonian Cabinet remains divided over ties with the ROC and Macedonian President Boris Trajkovski has yet to call a meeting with the leaders of major political parties to discuss the issue," Chang said.

She pointed out that the conclusion of Macedonia's Cabinet meeting on Tuesday was that their president will have to convene a meeting with leaders of major political parties in the near term to discuss the issue.
"We will wait and see," Chang noted.
However, Macedonian government spokesman Antonio Milosovski announced Tuesday that the country has indeed decided to normalize relations with mainland China.
Torn by a conflict with ethnic Albanian insurgents, Milosovski said, Macedonia must weigh the goodwill of Beijing, one of five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council.
According to Chang, though, Milosovski's remarks only reflected his party's stance and each Macedonian political party has its own view on the issue.
Until Macedonia makes a final decision, Chang said MOFA will not comment on remarks made by delegates of the various Macedonian political parties.

Noting that Macedonia's political situation is very complicated and the fighting between Macedonian government troops and ethnic Albanian rebels has continued rising, Chang said uncertainties still surround ROC-Macedonian ties.

"The ROC mission there is stepping up efforts to contact all major Macedonian poltiical parties to seek their support," she said, adding that the ROC will do its utmost to safeguard ties with the European ally with no compromise on national dignity.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-BOLIVIA RELATIONS IMPROVING, SAYS ROC REPRESENTATIVE
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, June 13 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Substantive relations between the Republic of China and Bolivia have been improving steadily, ROC Representative to La Paz Chang Wen-hsiung said Wednesday.
In an interview with CNA, Chang said that the "present environment is favorable for restoration of the two countries' diplomatic relations, but the move is unlikely in the near future."
Some newspapers in Taiwan had wrongly reported that restoration of ROC-Bolivia ties "is imminent," speculation that was immediately denied by the ROC Foreign Ministry.
Although the Bolivian media reported the speculation from Taipei, the Bolivian government did not bother to respond.
Chang said that "Bolivia is basically very friendly toward the ROC. Although it has diplomatic relations with mainland China, it maintains goodwill with the ROC in cultural and other areas."

Formal relations between the ROC and Bolivia were severed in July 1985 following La Paz's recognition of the Beijing government. The semi-official "Commercial-Consular Office of the ROC" was established in October 1990 to handle bilateral substantive relations.
Office personnel are accorded the preferential treatment given to staff members of international organizations, including exemption from taxation and service of diplomatic parcels.
Chang said that a trade mission organized by 10 large Bolivian companies is scheduled to visit Taiwan later this year to explore new markets in Taiwan.
The idea of dispatching the trade mission was raised by the Bolivian side when ROC Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission Chairwoman Chang Fu-mei visited La Paz in March of this year.
As exchange of visits by the two countries' officials and parliamentarians is frequent, Chang said that mutual understanding between the two countries has been strengthened.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEROIN RING BUSTED

TEXT.P: Police busted an international drug ring Tuesday in Taipei, arresting five suspects and seizing three packages of two kilograms of heroin with a street value of NT$10 million, police announced Wednesday.

The Taipei police authorities said that they were able to break the case following more than one month of surveillance after a tip-off from informants. They said a large number of police were mobilized Tuesday night after learning that several drug traffickers were making a deal in downtown Taipei.

According to police, Chiu Ching-chung, 48, and Tsao Yung-hsing, 49, two masterminds of an international drug ring which uses foreigners to sneak unlawful drugs into Taiwan, were caught red-handed during a deal in the Chungshan district.
Tsao was arrested by police while Chiu ran away. Chiu threw three packages of drugs from his car while being chased and finally intercepted by several police cars on Huanho North Road.

Acting on the two men's statement, police arrested Yang Chia-i, 43, a third member of the ring who had just done a deal in a restaurant in Chilin Road. Yan confessed to be an acquaintance of Tsao and said he was lured by Tsao to do "downstream" errands for him.

During the same time, another group of police detained a pair of men of the ring, Chao Kuo-lin 38, from Malaysia, and Hung Lai-sheng from Singapore, at a hotel on Shuangcheng Road. Police seized drugs tied to their bodies and NT$1 million from the two men, who admitted to selling drugs.
Initial police investigation shows that the drug ring is controlled by a Malaysian men, who uses high pay to hire people like Hung to carry illegal narcotics into Taiwan.
Hung claimed to be suffering from cancer and to be a former representative of a Singapore national bowling team.

DOC.HEADLINE: R.P. PRESIDENT LAUDS CHINESE-FILIPINOS FOR ROLE IN NATIONAL DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Philippine President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo lauded the Chinese- Filipino community Wednesday for its contribution to the country's development as she formally turned over a copy of the newly signed Administrative Naturalization Act of 2001 to community leaders.

In her remarks at the turnover ceremonies, the president said the naturalization act is another step taken by the government to strengthen the unity between Filipinos and the Chinese-Filipinos who have opted to join the mainstream of Philippine society.
"Unity as a theme is being used by the administration as a strategy to achieve progress, stability and a bright future for our country," the president said.
The new law will provide Filipino citizenship to qualified and deserving aliens who were born in the Philippines and have resided in the country since birth.

"I ask the new citizens and the Filipino-Chinese to contribute their utmost to the government and the nation," the president said, shortly before turning over a copy of the new law to officials of the Chinese-Filipino Business Club (CFBC) led by its president, Dante Go.

During the occasion, the president also thanked the CFBC for its contribution of 1 million pesos for the relatives of soldiers and policemen who have died or were injured in the ongoing operations against the Abu Sayyaf in Basilan.
The president also called on the community to help the government in its fight against crime syndicates in urban areas, like those who are involved in kidnapping, drug trafficking and prostitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMANIAN AMBASSADOR TO ROC SAYS BILATERAL TIES SOLID

TEXT.P: Panamanian Ambassador to the Republic of China Jose Antonio Dominguez said Wednesday that the friendship between the two countries is solid despite tie-damaging rumors.

Dominguez said at a ceremony to promote Panamanian products that the opinions of certain pro-Beijing people in Panama against ROC President Chen Shui-bian's recent state visit to that country do not represent the opinion of the entire nation.
In fact, he added, bilateral ties have "never been as solid as they are now."
He stressed that mainland Chinese investments in Panama are purely commercial in nature, and that ROC-Panama relations will not be affected by such investments.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PEOPLE EXPECTED TO LIVE TO 75

TEXT.P: People in Taiwan had a life expectancy of 75 years on average in 2000, which ranks 39th in the world and is the same as for developing nations, according to statistics prepared by the Ministry of the Interior.
Vice Minister of the Interior Lee Yi-yang said Tuesday the life expectancy is 72 years for Taiwanese men and 78 for women.
Citing statistics gathered by the Council for Economic Planning and Development, Lee said world life expectancy is 65 years, with 64 years for men and 66 for women.
Japanese, living an average of 81 years, have the longest life expectancy in the world. Mainland Chinese, with a life expectancy of 71 years, ranked 88th in the world, according to Lee.

DOC.HEADLINE: ADULT EDUCATION SYMPOSIUM HELD IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A symposium on adult education on both sides of the Taiwan Strait began in Taipei Tuesday and is scheduled to run for three days, according to its organizers.

The symposium, hosted by an Taiwan association for adult education, has brought together adult education workers from Shanghai, Xinjiang province, Macao and Taiwan. The attendants will exchange views on the adult education programs and chart a path for the future.
In addition to discussions, the attendees will tour several education facilities around the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: US OFFICIAL WEIGHS IN ON CROSS-STRAIT ISSUES

TEXT.P: A senior U.S. official said Tuesday that the central question in the relationship between mainland China and Taiwan is how to shift the focus from a cross-strait military balance to finding ways to resolve differences.
James Kelly, assistant Secretary of State for East Asia and the Pacific, said that the answer lies in three areas.

"A combination of political dialogue, economic cooperation and mutual understanding offers the prospect that both sides will find they have increased interests in common and therefore increasing reasons to find practical ways to resolve their differences," he said.
The first priority for both Beijing and Taipei should be the resumption of direct dialogue, he said in a written statement submitted to the House Asia and Pacific Subcommittee.
"But we would like to see not just a start but real accomplishments in cross-strait dialogue," he said.
On the question of mutual understanding, the official said that both sides "need to have a better understanding of the other side and what it seeks from a closer relationship.
"In particular, we have urged the PRC to shift from seeking to put pressure on -- even intimidate -- Taiwan and instead appeal to the people of Taiwan," Kelly said.
"Beijing needs to explain to Taiwan the benefits of a closer relationship rather than the perils of a more distant one," he added.
He also urged Beijing not to ignore the government of President Chen Shui-bian and to instead "offer a case that is attractive" to Taipei.
The written statement is part of Kelly's testimony before the subcommittee during a hearing held to discuss U.S. policy on the East Asia and the Pacific region.
Kelly stressed the U.S. commitment to seeing a peaceful resolution of differences across the Taiwan Strait.

"The abiding interest of the United States is that differences be resolved peacefully," he said. "This interest lies behind the commitments undertaken in the three (joint) communiques (signed with Beijing) and it is at the heart of the Taiwan Relations Act."
On the question of Beijing's and Taipei's accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO), Kelly reiterated U.S. support for mainland China's entry "as soon as China is ready to meet WTO standards."
"Taiwan, of course, is also ready for membership in the WTO, and we expect both to enter, hopefully, this year," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S., PRC WILL NOT FIGHT OVER TAIWAN, SAYS SINGAPORE'S LEE
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, June 13 (CNA) (By Sherman Wu & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Singaporean Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew, who concluded his visit to mainland China Wednesday, said that the United States and the People's Republic of China will not fight each other over Taiwan.
He made the remarks while meeting with Singaporean reporters.
Lee said that mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin told him during their talks that Beijing wants to maintain friendly relations with Washington.
Therefore, Lee said that he believes the U.S. and the PRC will not fight each other because of the Taiwan issue.

He also said that the recent mid-air clash between a mainland Chinese jetfighter and a U.S. reconnaissance plane over the South China Sea had not escalated the tension of the two countries' relations.
Lee added that both Beijing and Washington are expected to use self restraint in case of future accidents.
He noted that the stability of Beijing-Washington relations will be instrumental to continued economic growth in the Asia-Pacific region.
Lee told reporters that the issue concerning U.S. military activities in Singapore was not discussed in his talks with Jiang.

He said that Singapore stated to mainland China when they normalized their relations in 1990 that Singapore would continue sending military personnel to Taiwan for training and the U.S. military would be allowed to use Singapore bases.
"These are in line with the interests of Singapore," he pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: TREMOR ROCKS NORTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Northern Taiwan was rocked by an earthquake measuring 6.3 on the open-ended Richter scale Wednesday evening, according to the Central Weather Bureau.
The quake occurred at 9:18 p.m. and the epicenter was located 63 kilometers east of Suao, Ilan County, at a depth of 54.2 kilometers below the surface of the sea.
The tremor measured four in Ilan City and Nanao and three in Taipei City and Hualien City. No damages were reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC WILL RESPECT MARKET MECHANISM ON FOREX RATES

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of China (CBC) said Wednesday that the CBC will respect the market mechanism and let foreign exchange rates be decided by the supply and demand on the market.

The CBC made the remark in response to the sharp depreciation of the new Taiwan dollar against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Wednesday, triggered by forecasts made by some domestic and foreign research institutions that the local currency had further room to depreciate.
The local currency closed at 34.377 against the greenback Wednesday, a sharp decrease of 0.312 from the closing level of the previous trading session.

Hsu Chung-yi, deputy director of the CBC's Foreign Exchange Department, urged those research institutions that make predictions to be cautious, saying the foreign exchange market is very sensitive to financial information.

Hsu said that presently the forecasts for the trend of the local currency's exchange rate with the U.S. dollar made by various research institutions are quite different. He urged the public not to be taken in by rumors, calling for the public to pay more attention to financial information before trading in the market.
He also cited official statistics that should bring confidence to the public about the local currency.

Official statistics showed that Taiwan's balance of international payment is in good condition with the first quarter of this year registering a surplus of US$5.666 billion. The island's foreign trade in the first five months of this year recorded a surplus of US$4.894 billion, much more than the US$1.837 billion of the same period last year, the figures showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC EMBASSY'S STRONGLY-WORDED STATEMENT ON SKOPJE-TAIPEI TIES
DOC.DATELINE: Skopje, June 13 (CNA) (By Kuo Wu-huan & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Embassy in Skopje issued a strongly-worded statement Wednesday against the unfriendly remarks on Taipei-skopje relations made by Macedonian government spokesman Antonio Milososki on June 12.
According to foreign wire reports, the Macedonian government spokesman said that Macedonia will normalize relations with Beijing and diplomatic relations with the ROC will automatically be severed.

The ROC Embassy said in the statement that it deeply regrets that the decision of the Macedonian government has seriously harmed not only the dignity of the Republic of China and its people but also the amicable relations and bilateral cooperation between the two countries."

As a result, it added, that should the bilateral relationship between the Republic of China and the Republic of Macedonia be suspended, the government of the ROC will seriously consider undertaking the ensuing measures:
-- The ROC-Macedonia Economic Development Fund, worth US$10 million will be revoked;
-- The Economic Reconstruction Program in the Balkans, worth US$29 million, which includes the project for the construction of the Skopje bypass, worth US$20 million, will be terminated;.

-- The ROC government shall request the Macedonian government to immediately pay back the disbursed US$12 million granted via the Small and Medium Sized Enterprises credit line and rendered by the International Cooperation Development Fund;
-- The construction of the Free Economic Zone in Skopje, worth US$11.55 million, will be ceased;
-- The second phase for a vocational training course of 100 Macedonian youth, worth US$1.5 million, will not be organized;
10. The ROC investment in mushroom production, raising broiler chickens and plastic bag production in Macedonia will be terminated immediately; and
11. All remaining donations such as scholarships to Macedonian youths to study Chinese in Taipei and technical training courses will be canceled.
The ROC Embassy reiterated its firm stance that "neither changes in the political relations nor other substitute proposals concerning the relations between the two countries are acceptable."
"The detrimental consequences in the relations between the two countries will be borne solely by the Macedonian side," the statement added.

DOC.HEADLINE: THAI, VIETNAMESE LABOR WAGES, BROKERAGE FEES TO BE LOWERED

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council for Labor Affairs (CLA) announced Wednesday that it has arrived at a consensus with the Vietnamese representative office in Taiwan that will lead to lower wages and lower brokerage fees for Vietnamese workers in Taiwan.

According to the CLA, Vietnam has agreed to follow a similar agreement between the CLA and Thailand to deduct room and board fees from workers' pay, which would lead to approximately NT$2,500 (US$73) to NT$4,000 (US$116) less in monthly wages.
The new scheme will go into effect July 1 for Thai workers but will only affect new contracts. No starting date has been set yet for the agreement with Vietnam.

To compensate for the lower income, the CLA said that labor brokers in Taiwan have agreed to lower the high brokerage fees that foreign laborers usually pay in advance for the chance to work in Taiwan, where the guaranteed minimum wage of NT$15,840 (US$461) per month is higher than what they could earn elsewhere in Hong Kong or Singapore.
According to the CLA, labor brokers in Vietnam have also agreed to lower their management service charges by 5 percent to 7 percent.
Foreign laborers often take out high-interest loans to pay for brokerage fees and have to work one to two years before being able to pay off the debt.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
TAIWAN RATTLED BY STRONG QUAKE

TEXT.P: A strong earthquake measuring 6.2 on the open-ended Richter scale rocked eastern Taiwan at 10 35 a.m. Thursday, 12 hours after a similar tremor of magnitude 6.3 struck in an adjacent area Wednesday evening, according to Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reports.

The tremor, which lasted for more than 20 seconds, was detected about 19.6 kilometers east of the eastern township of Suao, Ilan County, at a depth of 10.4 kilometers beneath the surface of the sea, CWB seismologists said.
No immediate casualties were reported as of press time, although some telephone lines in eastern Taiwan were interrupted.

The temblor had an intensity of 5.0 in Ilan City and Taipei, 4.0 in the counties of Hsinchu and Taoyuan in northern Taiwan, and 2.0 in Tainan County in southern Taiwan and on the offshore island of Penghu located southwest of Taiwan proper.
The seismologists said that Thursday morning's tremor was an isolated earthquake and not any aftershock of Wednesday's earthquake.

As of 11 30 a.m. Thursday, damage reports included the collapse of an outer wall surrounding a building in downtown Taipei, and the collapse of the ceiling in a waiting room at Taipei's Sungshan Airport and also at the Ministry of Finance office. No one has been reported injured at any of these locations.
The Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. announced a 1-hour halt in all train services in order to carry out a safety check in the wake of the tremor.

It remained unclear at the time of this report whether the semiconductor manufacturing companies located at the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park -- "Taiwan's Silicon Valley" -- in northern Taiwan were affected by the temblor.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, June 14, or the 23rd day of the fourth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past
1645 Parliamentary troops under the leadership of Oliver Cromwell inflict a heavy defeat on Prince Rupert's Royalist forces at Nasby in the English Midlands, scoring a decisive Parliamentary victory in the Civil War.
1777 The US Congress adopts the "Stars and Stripes" as the official flag of the United States.
1789 After drifting an incredible 3,500 miles in an open boat, English Admiral Captain Bligh and 18 royal crew members, cast adrift from the HMS Bounty, eventually reach the island of Timor in the East Indies.
1838 Yamagata Aritomo, Japanese soldier and twice prime minister, is born. He played a major role in turning Japan into a formidable military power.
1894 After displaying the first commercial motion-picture machine at the World's Colombian Exposition in 1893, Thomas Alva Edison's company presents the first sports-related movie on boxing.
1900 The first Grand Prix, or international car race, takes place in Paris.
1920 In China, war between the Chihli and Anhwei warlords breaks out. Tsao Kun of the Chihli faction and Chang Tso-lin of the Fengtien faction join forces to fight against Tuan Chi-jui of the Anhwei faction.
1936 Chang Tai-yen, a noted scholar of Chinese literature, dies in Soochow at the age of 67.
1940 German troops march into Paris, and the flag of Nazi Germany, bearing the swastika, is hoisted up the Eiffel Tower.
1941 President Franklin D. Roosevelt orders the freezing of all German and Italian assets in the United States.
1943 The Battle of West Hupeh ends with Japanese troops driven back to their previous positions.
1949 Bao Dai is installed as president of Vietnam.
1952 The Nautilus, the first nuclear-powered submarine, is put on public display in the United States.
1955 The Republic of China and the United States sign an agreement in Washington on the peaceful use of nuclear energy.
1964 In the ROC, the NT$3.2 billion multipurpose Shihmen Dam is dedicated.
1971 The Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Communications is inaugurated in Taipei.
1973 A 10-member Chinese national judo team headed by Mao Ming-chu leaves for Lausanne to take part in the 8th world championships.
1974 Vice Premier Hsu Ching-chung and Deputy Premier Cuthbert Edwy Talma of the Barbados sign a joint communique in Taipei announcing the extension of the Sino-Barbados agricultural technical cooperation agreement.
1975 More than 500 Chinese poets and Dr. Jeno Platthy, chairman of the Organizing Committee of the Third World Congress of Poets, gathered in Taipei to celebrate Chinese Poets Day and pay homage to poet Chu Yuan of the period of Spring and Autumn Annals.
1978 A technical cooperation agreement between Saudi Arabia and the Republic of China is signed.
1979 President Chiang Ching-kuo appoints Huang Shao-ku and Hung Shou-nan as president and vice president of the Judicial Yuan, respectively, following unanimous approval by the Control Yuan.
1982 Argentine troops surrender to the British commander of land forces in the Falklands, marking the end of a six-week conflict that cost 254 British and 750 Argentine lives.
1982 President Chiang Ching-kuo visits the Saudi Arabian Embassy in Taipei to extend his condolences over the passing of King Khalid ibn abdul Aziz.
1989 Former governor of California and US President Ronald Reagan is knighted by Queen Elizabeth II.
1992 Ronald Freeman, vice president of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, visits the ROC to discuss Sino-European trade and financial relations.
1997 Vice President and Premier Lien Chan announces that the government will establish a Ministry of Culture.
2000 U.S. President Bill Clinton sends his greetings to the participants in the 24th annual Joint Business Conference of the U.S.-ROC (Taiwan) and ROC-U.S.A. Business Councils, which kicks off in Taipei.
Confucius' lesson of the day "Your meek men of respectability, are they who unmercifully destroy all sense of moral sentiment in man."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 90.52 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Thursday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 90.52 points to close at 5,119.19.
Market turnover amounted to NT$46.49 billion (US$1.37 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL FINDS 45% OF POLICE OFFICERS HAVE INTENTION OF CHANGING JOB

TEXT.P: The majority of local police officers feel a great amount of job stress, while almost half of them have intention of switching professions, according to the results of an opinion poll released Thursday.

The survey was conducted from June 1-8 by the office of opposition Kuomintang Legislator Tina W. K. Pang with a view to understanding the living conditions of local police personnel. Pan sent out 1,300 copies of a questionnaire and collected 1,150 valid replies.

Poll results showed that 92.43 percent of the respondents said they feel police work entails a lot of stress; 91.74 percent described police work as toilsome; 87.83 percent said police work is dangerous; 80.43 percent said their work has affected their family lives; and 62.61 percent said they have often been scolded by their superiors or have faced unreasonable demands.

While 38.52 percent said they feel that being a police officer is a decent job, 45.57 percent said they don't think so. Meanwhile, 35.39 percent said they are satisfied with the salaries and welfare benefits for police officers, but 43.48 percent said they think otherwise.
About 73 percent said they tend to feel frustrated by major disciplinary incidents or charges involving police officers.

According to the survey, 44.87 percent said they often have thoughts about leaving the police force; 63.3 percent said they would immediately resign from their current post if they were offered a different job with similar pay; 32.43 percent said they would give a thumbs-down if any of their relatives intended to marry a police officer; and 28.96 percent said they would not support a family member's plan to join the police force.
Asked about Taiwan's public order situation over the past year, 80.42 percent said they feel that the crime rate has risen steadily.

Survey respondents also cited "improving the current police work-holiday system" as the assistance they most need. This was followed by rationalization of the pay scale, public recognition, the support of superiors, improvement in weapons and crime-fighting equipment, opportunities for on-the-job training, and psychological counseling services, in that order.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 90.52 points to close at 5,119.19

Affected by a decline in U.S. hi-tech stock prices, the bourse opened at 5,179.4 and continued to go down due to an earthquake that shook Taiwan in the morning. The index fluctuated between 5,200.5 and 5,091.52 during trading.

A total of 1.39 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$46.49 billion (US$1.37 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 2.18 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$75.52 billion (US$2.22 billion).

All of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with bank and insurance stocks and electrical shares moving down the most, both at 2 percent, followed by plastics and chemical stocks and foodstuff shares, both at 1.3 percent, cement stocks at 0.7 percent, pulp and paper issues and construction stocks, both at 0.6 percent, and textile issues at 0.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 405 to 100, with 78 stocks remaining unchanged.
