DOC.HEADLINE: ONLY MINOR DAMAGE REPORTED AFTER STRONG QUAKE

TEXT.P: Only minor cases of damage in eastern and northern Taiwan have been reported by Thursday afternoon after an earthquake measuring 6.2 on the open-ended Richter scale struck northeastern Taiwan at 10 35 a.m., the Cabinet-level Disaster Prevention and Relief Center (DPRC) reported.
Vice Premier Lai In-jaw, who is the DPRC director-general, called for the Taiwan public not to panic over the disaster.

Lai, however, reminded his fellow countrymen to be on high alert for any future quakes that may rock the island as seismologists at the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) have warned that aftershocks of Thursday's 6.2 tremor are very likely to occur in the following three to four weeks.

The tremor, which lasted for more than 20 seconds, was detected about 19.6 kilometers east of the northeastern township of Suao in Ilan County, at a depth of 10.4 kilometers beneath the surface of the sea, according to CWB seismologists.

It was the second strong quake to rock Taiwan in 12 hours, following a similar temblor of magnitude 6.3 in an adjacent area Wednesday evening. No damage was reported as resulting from Wednesday's quake.

The CWB earthquake experts said Thursday's strong jolt was very similar to the one that occurred at about the same time of day at around the same location seven years ago. In that quake, one person was killed and two were injured while 25 houses were reported to have collapsed.

As of press time Thursday, three people were reported injured in the greater Taipei area, where the quake had an intensity of 5.0. All three people, in Yungho City, Hsinchuang City and Panchiao City, respectively, were injured by falling objects during the earthquake. Their injuries are not life-threatening, according to National Fire Administration reports.

Meanwhile, six cases of damage to property, also in the greater Taipei area, have been reported, including a fire that ignited at an electricity transmission station on Chuangching Road. The fire was extinguished after just 10 minutes. Also, ceramic tiles were reported to have fallen from a festooned archway of the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, and a glass wall at a local bank reportedly cracked during the quake.

Other reported cases of damage included the collapse of an outer wall surrounding a building in downtown Taipei, and the collapse of the ceiling in a waiting room at Taipei's Sungshan Airport and also at the Ministry of Finance office. No one has been reported injured at any of these locations.

In eastern Taiwan, no casualties were reported as of press time, although some telephone lines were interrupted. Fallen rocks were reported on the highway linking Suao and Hualien, as well as on the Central Cross-island Highway, but traffic has not been disrupted.

Those using roads in eastern Taiwan have been warned against possible landslide, particularly in mountainous areas, in the wake of the two strong earthquakes, and because of the monsoon season, which has been battering the island with heavy rains.

Thursday's quake, which has been preliminarily labeled as an isolated one from Wednesday's temblor, had an intensity of 5.0 in Taipei and the eastern city of Ilan, 4.0 in the northern counties of Hsinchu and Taoyuan, 3.0 in the counties of Nantou, Taichung, Hualien and Keelung, and 2.0 in Tainan County in southern Taiwan and on the offshore island of Penghu located southwest of Taiwan proper, according to the CWB.

The state-run Taiwan Power Co. reported that there has been no damage to any of its power stations or electricity supply systems around the island and that there has been no disruption in services except for a minor two-minute skip at a power relay stop in central Taipei.

None of the semiconductor manufacturing companies located at the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park -- "Taiwan's Silicon Valley" -- in northern Taiwan were affected by the temblor, according to the industrial park administration.

Trains run by the Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. resumed normal services at around 12 30 p.m. after a two-hour halt in all train services for the purpose of carrying out a safety check in the wake of the earthquake.

DOC.HEADLINE: 70 PERCENT OF POLICEWOMEN SATISFIED WITH CURRENT JOB POLL

TEXT.P: The majority of local female police officers are satisfied with their current job, but many of them worry about the difficult balancing act between work and family life, according to the results of an opinion poll released Thursday.

The survey of randomly selected policewomen, conducted by opposition People First Party (PFP) Legislator Chin Hui-chu in connection with the advent of Police Day, found that 70 percent of the respondents said they are content with their present job.
Chin sent out a total of 1,082 copies of a questionnaire early this month and collected 750 valid replies from female police officers from around the island.

Eighty percent of the respondents said their families are supportive of their job; but more than 60 percent confessed that they often worry about their inability to balance their work and family life.
Other worries cited by survey respondents included work stress and personal safety.

Meanwhile, 50 percent said they feel a great amount of job stress; nearly 40 percent said they are worried about difficulties getting promotions or changing to other police positions; and 73 percent said they feel that their capabilities are more likely to be overlooked than those of their male counterparts.
Nearly 80 percent of female police officers also said they feel that they are more likely to face sex discrimination in seeking promotions than their male counterparts.
About 64 percent said they have either often or occasionally thought about switching to other professions.

Analyzing the survey findings, Chin said police work is tough, complicated and capricious, and that police officers often endure a lot of unseen hardships in fighting crime and maintaining law and order.

"Moreover, female police officers have often faced an even greater amount of job stress than their male counterparts," Chin said, adding that relevant government authorities should pay more heed to women police officers' feelings, rights and welfare services.

DOC.HEADLINE: WASHINGTON-BEIJING DISCORD COULD EXPLODE OVER TAIWAN U.S. EXPERTS

TEXT.P: A simmering conflict between the United States and mainland China resulting from unresolved military and diplomatic issues could soon explode over the status of Taiwan, two U.S. experts on China have warned in an analysis.

Writing in the latest issue of "Foreign Affairs," former U.S. Assistant Secretary of Defense Kurt Campbell, who is now director of the International Security Program at the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS), along with Derek Mitchell, senior fellow for the CSIS Asia Program, noted that although the standoff between the United States and China over the collision of a U.S. surveillance plane and a Chinese fighter in April ended peacefully, there are still unresolved military and diplomatic issues, which could bring greater discord to the relationship in the future.

In their view, Washington's official relationship with Beijing on the one hand and its unofficial relationship with Taipei on the other represents perhaps "the most complex foreign-policy balancing act" in the world today.

At stake are a number of core U.S. foreign policy goals the promotion of democracy; the preservation of U.S. credibility; loyalty to traditional allies and friends; the engagement and integration of an emerging power into the international system; and the maintenance of peace and stability in Asia as a whole. The interplay and potential conflicts among these various goals make the Taiwan Strait an unpredictable, and therefore dangerous place, they wrote in the bimonthly magazine.

Moreover, Taiwan's recent democratization has undermined the "one China" principle and has made the prospect of conflict increasingly likely. Compounding the problem is the deep division within the U.S. foreign policy elite over how to maintain the increasingly fragile peace in the Taiwan Strait.
"Perhaps nowhere else on the globe is the situation so seemingly intractable and the prospect of a major war involving the United States so real," they said.

The current situation in the Taiwan Strait -- the escalating tensions, the lack of meaningful dialogue and the increasingly hostile rhetoric -- suggests that the U.S. approach to the region requires a wholesale review. In the end, Mao Zedong's oft-quoted warning about the need for patience in addressing the issue of Taiwan is perhaps more relevant today than when Mao first uttered it, they wrote.

"Thus, the best option for the United States is to help create incentives that will encourage both Taipei and Beijing to maintain the undefined status quo -- a middle ground between reunification and independence. Each side dislikes the current situation for its own reasons, but for both it is the best choice among unhappy alternatives," they said.

They noted that the United States must use its diplomatic skill and military muscle to dissuade China from continuing its coercive course regarding Taiwan and persuade it to pursue a more constructive and conciliatory approach. Meanwhile, Washington should seek ways for Taiwan to participate in the international community while accepting the inevitable limitations of its indeterminate status.

At the same time, the United States must continue prudent contingency planning and maintain an active military presence in the region to sustain deterrence. It should also consider a more active diplomatic role to help facilitate future cross-strait discussions on political, military and other issues, they suggested.

Campbell and Mitchell said that for the past two decades, the essence of U.S. policy in the Taiwan Strait has been to preserve peace and stability in the region while indefinitely deferring the ultimate resolution of the problem. This approach has led to 20 years of prosperity and the proliferation of commercial contacts between Taiwan and the mainland.

"Yet today's stability shows unmistakable signs of strain. Unless both sides of the strait act creatively, Washington may find that the future it sought to postpone has already arrived," they concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO COMPROMISE ON NATIONAL DIGNITY, SAYS MOFA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has launched a last-ditch campaign to salvage diplomatic relations with Macedonia as part of the Macedonian government mulls restoring formal ties with Beijing, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Thursday.
The ROC will do its utmost to safeguard ties with the civil war-torn Balkan ally, but with no comprise on national dignity, said MOFA spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue.

At a news conference held Thursday following a strongly worded statement on the volatile Skopje-Taipei ties Wednesday by the ROC Embassy in Macedonia, Chang stressed that the ROC has tried its best to secure formal diplomatic ties with Macedonia based on principles of national interest and national dignity.
Chang declined to confirm whether the statement made on Wednesday was an "ultimatum" to Macedonia concerning the uncertainties surrounding the bilateral relations between the two countries.

She only said that the Macedonian Cabinet has yet to reach a consensus on a proposal to sever ties with Taipei in favor of Beijing. "The Macedonian Cabinet remains divided over ties with the ROC and Macedonian President Boris Trajkovski has yet to call a meeting with the leaders of major political parties to discuss the issue," she added.

It the statement issued Wednesday, the ROC Embassy in Skopje said that it deeply regrets that the decision of the Macedonian government to normalize relations with Beijing has seriously harmed not only the dignity of the ROC and its people but also the amicable relations and bilateral cooperation between the two countries.

As a result, should the bilateral relationship between the ROC and Macedonia be suspended, the government of the ROC will seriously consider undertaking measures to suspend, cease or nullify financial aid and all other bilateral cooperative programs that Taiwan has promised Macedonia.

DOC.HEADLINE: N.T. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar was down NT$0.018 against the U.S. dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Thursday, closing at 34.395.
The local currency opened Thursday at 34.274 and was traded between 34.199 and 34.445.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$471 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN CALLS FOR HAKKA CULTURAL RENAISSANCE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday he is hopeful that the newly inaugurated Council for Hakka Affairs will join forces with other relevant government agencies to push for a renaissance of Hakka culture.

"I also look forward to seeing Taiwan become a world hub for Hakka cultural heritage inheritance and resurrection through concerted efforts of the new council and relevant public and private organizations," Chen added.
The president made the remarks during a speech delivered at the new Cabinet-level council's inaugural ceremony. The establishment of the council realized one of Chen's campaign promises.

He pointed out that the inauguration of the new commission reflects local society's respect for cultural diversity and underscores the government's determination to substantiate the constitutional spirit of equality.
"The legislation of the statute governing the structure of the Hakka council also marked a critical step in maintaining our pluralistic democratic system," Chen noted.
The president went on to say that he admires Hakka people's can-do spirit and down-to-earth working attitude.

"And their courage, perseverance and devotion to pursuing justice and fairness had been fully reflected in their fight against the corrupt Ching dynasty and Japanese invasion in modern Chinese history," Chen explained.

Chen recalled that during his stint as Taipei mayor, he took the lead in setting up a municipal Hakka culture foundation, a Hakka culture hall and a Hakka arts and crafts demonstration center as part of his efforts to bolster revival of obscure Hakka cultural and artistic heritage.

Chen said he hopes the new Hakka council will pool the wisdom and resources of Hakka associations at home and abroad and even non-government international organizations to enable people around the world to appreciate the beauty of Hakka culture and art.

In view of Taiwan's imminent accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO), Chen said the council should also join forces with other relevant government agencies to help local Hakka farmers transfer to other lines of business. WTO entry is expected to have a serious impact on Taiwan's agricultural sector and Hakkas form a large share of the island's farming population.
Roughly one-sixth of Taiwan's 23 million people are Hakkas -- one of the most important branches of the Chinese people whose ancestors emigrated from mainland China to Taiwan hundreds of years ago.
Chen has appointed Fan Kuang-chun, a national policy adviser to the president and a noted attorney, as chairman of the new Hakka council.

The Hakkas are Chinese whose ancestors lived in "Chung Yuan," or "China proper," comprising Hebei, Henan, Shaanxi, Shanxi and some parts of other provinces in central and northern China. They gradually migrated to southern China and emigrated to Southeast Asia and other parts of the world during national upheavals since the fourth century.
The Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission in Taipei estimated in 1992 that there were about 34 million overseas Chinese at that time, one-third of whom were Hakkas.
The Hakkas are noted for their persistent adherence to traditional Chinese customs and values, such as patriotism, loyalty, hard work, and resistance to alien aggression and influence.

In addition, they look upon themselves as people of high social status, which is why they do not assimilate well into the local community and are called "guest people" wherever they live. "Hakka" means "guest family" in mandarin Chinese.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SAYS PARTY COOPERATION IS REQUIRED

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Thursday that party cooperation is required if no party gains half of the Legislative Yuan seats in December's legislative elections.
He made the remarks in an interview with Serge Berthier and Laurent Malvezin, publisher and general manager of the Hong Kong-based "Asian Affairs" quarterly.
Chang noted that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) policy is to seek cooperation from the opposition camp after the upcoming elections.
However, he said that the targets for cooperation have not been fixed yet, because some uncertain factors remain.
The premier quoted President Chen Shui-bian as having stated that the DPP will recruit opposition legislators who share the political ideals of the DPP to form a coalition government.
On the development of cross-strait relations, Chang admitted that no major breakthroughs have been made.

But he pointed out that bilateral relations have been stabilized as the allegations that the DPP is a party that pursues Taiwan independence and that a DPP government would mean a war with mainland China have been proven groundless.

Regarding whether the government will resort to a public plebiscite to resolve the issue concerning the future of the island's fourth nuclear power plant, Chang said that the government's basic principle is to resolve controversial issues through public plebiscite.
He added that the government has already forwarded the draft of the Public Plebiscite Law to the Legislative Yuan for deliberation and enactment.

On the steps for stimulating the sluggish economy, Chang said the government will do its utmost to keep this year's real growth rate above four percent through expansion of public projects and increase of the employment rate.
He also said that efforts will be placed on the development of new industries to ensure continued economic development in the coming three to five years.
The English-language "Asian Affairs" plans to focus its summer issue on Taiwan affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARTIES TO DISCUSS FORMATION OF ECONOMIC ADVISORY COMMITTEE

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office confirmed Thursday that all political parties have been invited to participate in a meeting Sunday to further discuss the proposed formation of a presidential advisory committee on national economic development.

According to the Presidential Office, Presidential Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun invited representatives from various parties to attend the coordination meeting to listen to their opinions on such details as the mission, organization and methods of operation for the committee.

Yu and Vice Premier Lai In-jaw are slated to preside over the meeting, which will be attended by representatives from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, the opposition Kuomintang, the People First Party and the New Party, as well as the independent alliance and the supra-party alliance.

The idea to form such an advisory committee was proposed last month by President Chen Shui-bian, who pledged to chair the committee himself to solicit the opinions of experts and scholars on how to reform the nation's sagging economy and plan for the island's future economic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: 82 MAINLAND FISHERMEN TEMPORARILY GO ASHORE NEAR PINGTUNG

TEXT.P: Eighty-three mainland Chinese fishermen on a floating hostel were temporarily forced ashore on Thursday after their ship ran aground off Pingtung in southern Taiwan.

The Coast Guard Administration reported that the ship, the Changyi No.10, that houses the 83 mainland fishermen, ran aground 40 meters off Tungkang, Pingtung, around 5 a.m. and that the hull had taken upwards of 80 centimeters of water and was in danger of sinking.

The Coast Guard Administration and firefighters in Pingtung, upon learning the news, sent patrol boats and rescuers who used mooring rope to tie secure the vessel, and the mainland fishermen were able to swim to shore with assistance.
According to the mainland fishermen, the sea was rough early Thursday morning, which broke the mooring ropes. The ship then drifted toward shore.

The mainland fishermen were placed in a security check center before they were sent back in the afternoon to other floating hostels. There are estimated to be more than a score of the hostels anchored off Tungkang.
The floating hostels are usually converted from old, dilapidated ships, and mainland fishermen are confined to the cramped space in the ships when they are not operating at sea.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MILITARY OFFICERS TO VISIT U.S. PACIFIC MILITARY COMMAND
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 13 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A spokesman for the U.S. Pacific Command headquartered in Hawaii confirmed media reports Wednesday that a group of mid-ranking military officers from the Republic of China will visit the establishment.

The spokesman told CNA that the U.S. Pacific Command authorities will give a 45-minute briefing Thursday to the 20-member group of military officers from Taiwan on its structure, operations and missions.

The spokesman said the arrangement is neither rare nor the first of its kind, noting that an ROC general was also given a similar briefing during an April visit. The briefings given to other visitors, such as business and community leaders or political figures, have the same content, he explained.

The group of ROC military officers have been attending a training program sponsored by the Washington-based Center for Strategic and International Studies in the United States over the past two weeks. While there, they also visited relevant government agencies such as the Department of Defense.
Taiwan media have reported that the ROC military officers, led by Air Force Maj. Gen. Lin Yu-pao, will fly from the U.S. mainland to Hawaii Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF TAIWAN TOURISTS TO TURKEY ON RISE
DOC.DATELINE: Ankara, June 14 (CNA) (By C.H. Kuo and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Tourist arrivals from Taiwan to Turkey totaled 5,073 during the first five months of this year, ahead of 2,392 from mainland China, Turkish Tourism Ministry spokesman said Wednesday.

The spokesman added that if the current trend continues, the number of Taiwan tourists visiting Turkey is expected to grow several-fold this year. A total of 3,873 tourists from Taiwan visited the country last year, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP AIMS TO WIN 60 SEATS IN LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS: PFP CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong said in a recent interview with the Asian Wall Street Journal that each of the three main political parties in Taiwan aims to win at least 60 seats in the year-end legislative elections.
In the interview, published Thursday, Soong said that if his party were to win more than 60 seats in the 225-member legislature, it would be considered by the party to be a major victory.
He speculated that no single major party is likely to win as many as 85 to 90 seats, and that no party is likely to fall below less than 40.

Regarding ongoing talks of cooperation between the PFP and the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) in the election, Soong said that the two parties have certain overlapping interests and share the same belief in a 1992 consensus with Beijing that there is only "one China" but each side is free to interpret "one China" in its own way.
Regarding the new U.S. administration's policies toward Taiwan and mainland China, Soong said that he believes the Bush administration is friendlier toward Taiwan than was the Clinton administration.
However, he urged the United States to focus not only on helping to enhance Taiwan's defenses through arms sales but also on helping to encourage mainland China to come to the negotiating table.

He also warned that mainland China might use the Taiwan issue to distract its people from its own internal economic problems, adding that a framework to preserve peace in the Taiwan Strait should be created.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILL NOT OPEN TO MAINLAND CHINESE AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS RASHLY

TEXT.P: Taiwan will not rashly open its market to mainland Chinese agricultural products after both sides of the Taiwan Strait enter the World Trade Organization (WTO), a top agricultural official said Thursday.

Lin Kuo-ching, vice chairman of the Council of Agriculture (COA), said that any increased opening to mainland products will have to be done through negotiation on an equal footing with the mainland, based on the principles of national security and the impact on domestic industries.
Lin noted that Taiwan's relationship with the mainland will not be quite the same as with other countries after WTO accession, expected at the end of the year.
He added that although the indirect trade in agricultural products across the Taiwan Strait will move toward WTO norms after entry, it will not conform completely with WTO norms.
He said Taiwan's opening of agricultural products to the mainland will still follow existing mainland policy and will be carried out through negotiation.

Meanwhile, during an intra-agency meeting convened by the COA to review the result of the "mini three links" -- direct trade, postal and transport links -- between Kinmen and Matsu islands and the mainland ports of Xiamen and Mawei after six months' implementation, the two offshore islands asked for more openness to mainland agricultural products.
Kinmen and Matsu representatives requested opening up to an additional 152 agricultural products from the mainland, but the COA would only agree to two of them.
Lin said that no matter what channels mainland China uses to get its agricultural products into Taiwan, a risk is posed to the nation's quarantine system.

Kinmen and Matsu representatives lamented that even after the links, legal trade is still basically "small-scale," while smuggled agricultural products continue to find their way into Taiwan via the two islands.

The COA decided to ask the Ministry of Finance to step up a crackdown on smuggling and to work out control measures to stem the illicit sending of mainland China agricultural products from Kinmen and Matsu to Taiwan proper.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT READY FOR DPP PLOY TO SPLIT OPPOSITION IN LEAD-UP TO ELECTION

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) dismissed allegations Thursday that former party Chairman Lee Teng-hui will stump for Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidates in the year-end legislative and city hall elections.

Chao Shou-po, director of the KMT's Organization and Development Department, said the allegations, supposedly spread by DPP sources, are a ploy to alienate Lee and the KMT rank-and-file, adding that the KMT is well-prepared to counter what he described as "a political gambit."

As a retired KMT leader, Chao said, Lee should be willing to stump for KMT candidates rather than DPP rivals, but he stressed that the KMT will not browbeat former party leaders who opt to quit politics into canvassing voters.

Chao made the comments after Thursday's China Times said that Lee, who has moaned about the KMT's shift from the line laid down by him toward more centrist policies, will throw his weight behind DPP candidates in the year-end election to protest the KMT's change of direction.

Lee has already aired his dissatisfaction with his hand-picked heir -- Lien Chan -- in a book penned by Japanese author Fuyuko Kamisaka earlier this year and has often been quoted by his cronies as finding fault in private with the KMT's political line under Lien.

The local press quoted "sources" as assuring DPP President Chen Shui-bian earlier this month that up to 35 KMT and independent lawmakers will switch their support to Chen, as long as his DPP can win 85 seats at the Legislative Yuan in the election.

In the latest sign heralding Lee's forthcoming breakup with the party which helped him ascend to the presidency of the country, the China Times said that Lee will join Chen Saturday in the inauguration ceremony of a pro-DPP group named "Peishe," or North Society.

Chao tried to gloss over the prospects that Lee could appear together with Chen, saying that it is "nothing unusual" for Lee to meet his successor at a "social gathering" and that "outsiders" should not read too much political overtone into the event.
Chao further said that Lien has called on Lee quite often recently in a friendly atmosphere and has maintained close, but unpublicized, contact with his political mentor.

Noting that many KMT members protested to the party headquarters and demanded Lee's expulsion from the party upon reading Thursday's press reports, Chao denounced the allegations as a DPP political ploy to drive a wedge between the KMT and its former leader.
Chao said he did not know what exact assurance Lee made to Chen, but claimed that by no stretch of imagination could 35 lawmakers defect to back the DPP.
Nevertheless, he went on, the KMT will do its utmost to maintain its majority in the legislature in the forthcoming election.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REPRESENTATIVE TO KOREA DONATES DROUGHT AID
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, June 14 (CNA) (By Chiang Yuan-chen & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Representative to South Korea Lee Tsung-ju has donated 2 million won(US$1,800) to help Korean farmers stricken by a drought, a Korean newspaper reported Thursday.
The Seoul-based Tongyap Ilbo (East Asia Daily News) published a list of 30 donors.

South Korea is facing its worst drought in a century, with rainfall down by one-third from "previous levels." Many farms have turned to desert because of the lack of water and the South Korean government and various civic groups have launched a fundraising campaign to help farmers buy water pumps.

Lee, who assumed his post only recently, donated the contribution through the paper and after accepting the donation, Choi Kyu-chol, the newspaper's editor-in-chief, said that Lee is the first foreign envoy stationed in the country to answer his paper's drought aid appeal.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC PLANNERS DECIDE TO RESTRICT HIRING OF FOREIGN CARETAKERS

TEXT.P: Council for Economic Planning and Development Vice Chairman K.C. Lee said Thursday that the number of foreign caretakers must be restricted in the future to allow local workers to become the mainstay behind the welfare industry.

Lee said after a inter-ministerial meeting that a decision was made to impose such restrictions, but that the degree of restriction and what standards are to be used will be decided by the Council of Labor Affairs.
He added that the roughly 100,000 foreign caretakers in Taiwan are often illegally put to work in production jobs instead of staying at home to take care of the people they were hired to look after.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI INTERNATIONAL FOOD EXPOSITION OPENS

TEXT.P: The 11th Taipei International Food Exposition opened at the Taipei World Trade Center Thursday, with more than 500 firms from Taiwan and foreign countries participating.
Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu and several foreign envoys were invited to address the opening ceremony.

Lu inspected major pavilions at the exhibition, accompanied by Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi, Council of Agriculture Chairman Chen Hsi-huang, and China External Trade Development Council Chairman Shea Jia-dong.
She struck a gong to open a special corner for exhibitors from nine Central and South American countries that maintain formal ties with Taipei.
Other foreign exhibitors are from the United States, France, Canada, Austria, South Korea, Australia, Germany and Chile.
The exposition will run for four days until June 17.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT CONTINUES EXCHANGING VIEWS WITH DPP LAWMAKERS

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian is optimistic that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will be able to get 85 Legislative Yuan seats to become Taiwan's largest party in December's legislative election.
He told legislators from the ruling party that he based his optimistic estimate on discussions with DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh and other DPP officials.
The DPP currently controls only one-third of the seats in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan.
Chen exchanged views with the DPP legislators for three hours on issues concerning the island's political and economic developments as well as social welfare.
It was the second time Chen has met with DPP legislators since June 11. He will continue meeting the other DPP lawmakers in four groups over the next few weeks.
According to DPP Legislator Chang Ching-fang (Taipei County), Chen promised to help campaign for the party's candidates during the election period with the aim of winning 85 seats in the election.
During the meeting, Chang said, some DPP legislators asked Chen not to seek cooperation with lawmakers who have been tainted with "black gold" allegations.
At the same time, Chen admitted to the legislators that he met with former President Lee Teng-hui early this month, while denying speculation about a plan to form a "Chen-Lee cooperative alliance."

He said that Lee's recent remarks favoring the DPP to win 85 seats in the upcoming election were made out of Lee's "sense of mission" to see the emergence of a stable majority in the legislature after the election.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS OFFICIAL RETURNS FROM MAINLAND CHINA VISIT

TEXT.P: Lin Wen-yuan, vice chairman of the Commission of National Corporations, returned to Taiwan Thursday after an inspection tour of mainland China.

Lin, who led Taiwan Sugar Corporation (Taisugar) Chairman Chien Ping-tsai and other Taisugar executives on the nine-day visit, said the delegation toured Shanghai, Hangzhou, Qingdao and Beijing, where they met with local private enterprise heads. He added that he did not meet with high-ranking officials during his stay in Beijing.

Lin said that whether national corporations will invest in the mainland will hinge on the government's policy. But as Taisugar currently has a market in the mainland for its butterfly orchids, the corporation wanted to inspect the mainland market.

Chien said that this is the second year that Taisugar's butterfly orchids have been exported to the mainland, saying that more than 10,000 orchids were sold in Beijing last year and nearly 20,000 were sold in Shanghai.
Taiwan's butterfly orchids are popular in the mainland because of their high quality and good looks, Chien said, adding that Taisugar will increase sales and provide services to related industries.
He added that whether or not Taisugar will invest in the mainland will depend on Republic of China government policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HAS NO FIXED IDEA ABOUT COOPERATIVE PARTNERS: CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has no set idea with which political camp to forge a "coalition government" following the December legislative elections, party chairman Frank Hsieh said Thursday.

Hsieh said the DPP does not have a set position on the issue. No matter whether legislators are viewed as pro-former President Lee Teng-hui or whether they are considered to be in the camp of Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, he noted, all political parties might be the DPP's potential partners.

But Hsieh stressed that such individuals must first join the DPP as formal party members subject to party discipline. If they are a separate group of people, they should form a political party so as to allow the DPP to cooperate with them in a party-to-party pattern, he added.
The aim of forming a "coalition government" would be to create a majority government capable of stabilizing the country's political situation, he went on.

The DPP chief made the remarks in a speech delivered at National Sun Yat-sen University on the much-talked about "coalition government" following the legislative election slated for December. The ruling party currently holds only one-third of seats in the Legislative Yuan.

Hsieh also predicted that the DPP and the main opposition Kuomintang will each grab 80 seats in the year-end election, while the People First Party will garner 35 seats and the New Party and independent lawmakers will take about 30 seats altogether.

As to widespread rumors that an addition 35 lawmakers will join forces with the DPP following the election if the ruling party manages to gain 85 seats, he claimed that the figure of 35 is a fiction. If the DPP gains a good result in the year-end polls, such a move would be unnecessary, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT DEALING WITH MEMBERS' ANGER WITH FORMER CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Officials of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Thursday they were aware of growing anger among the party grassroots with former party Chairman Lee Teng-hui and were watching the situation carefully.

The officials acknowledged that the KMT Central Committee had received many phone calls from the party's grassroots-level members demanding Lee's expulsion from the party for supposed "improper remarks" regarding the KMT and its chairman, Lien Chan.

Moreover, Lee's plan to appear Saturday with President Chen Shui-bian at a ceremony to mark the establishment of "Peishe" or North Society, a pro-DPP group, has heightened the discontent among the KMT's grassroots, which was said by KMT administrative personnel to be escalating.
Because the KMT's 16th party plenary meeting is due to take place in July, the Central Committee is watching the anti-Lee sentiment closely for possible impact on the 100-year-old party.

Lee, who is still a controversial figure despite having quit politics, was reluctant to step down as KMT chairman after the party's humiliating defeat in the 2000 presidential election. However, a large crowd of furious party members forced him to resign as the party head after several days of violent protests in front of KMT headquarters.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO DECIDE BY MONDAY WHEN TO ASK FOR EXTRA LEGISLATIVE MEET

TEXT.P: A party whip of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Thursday that it will be certain by Monday when President Chen Shui-bian will ask the legislature to convene an extra meeting.

Lin Feng-hsi made the remarks after the legislature ended its latest session with a backlog of bills outstanding, including six bills said to be crucial to financial reform. The ruling party has over the past days been lobbying for the support of the legislators for an extra session.

Vice Premier Lai In-jaw and Secretary-General to the President Chiou I-jen visited the legislature to communicate with the opposition camp on the 18 bills that the Executive Yuan hopes to give priority for legislative clearance.

Lin said that the opposition camp basically "is not opposed to" most of the 18 bills and only have some reservations about four of them, including a government bond bill and regulations governing the crackdown on corruption.
He added that "the situation is generally optimistic," and it should be clear by Monday when the president will ask the legislature to hold an extra session.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE RUNNERS ARRIVE IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A 23-member mainland Chinese delegation arrived in Taipei Thursday to take part in an unprecedented cross-Taiwan Strait long-distance race as part of a campaign for mainland China's bid to win the right to host the 2008 Olympic Games.
The delegation consists of sports officials, reporters and runners, including Li Xiaoshuang, a gymnastic gold medalist and table-tennis gold medalist Qiao Hung.
The event is being organized by the Hope Foundation headed by Taiwan's Olympic bronze medalist Chi Cheng.
The runners from Taiwan and mainland China will start from the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in Taipei June 17.
They will then proceed to Kaohsiung and eight mainland Chinese cities -- Shenzhen, Ningpo, Hangzhou, Shanghai, Wuxi, Nanjing, Qingdao and Beijing.
The 40-member Taiwan delegation will return to Taipei July 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN INVESTMENTS IN PHILIPPINES TOTAL US$313.83 MILLION IN Q1
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, June 14 (CNA) (By Philip Liu and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Foreign investment poured into the Philippines in the first quarter of this year, according to a Philippine Ministry of Trade and Industry report released Thursday.

During the January-March 24 period, the Philippine government approved 16.094 billion pesos (US$313.83 million)-worth of foreign investments that will create 2,097 job opportunities, according to the report.

Minister of Trade of Industry Manuel Roxas said the new investments can be broken down into 6.128 billion pesos for the export manufacturing industry, 1.168 billion pesos for new information technology enterprises and 8.798 billion pesos for enterprises that intend to expand their investments.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOWNSHIP HEAD SENTENCED TO LIFE IMPRISONMENT FOR CORRUPTION

TEXT.P: The head of a rural township near the epicenter of the disastrous Sept. 21, 1999 earthquake was given a life sentence Thursday for corruption during the post-quake reconstruction.

Wu Chao-feng, magistrate of Chungliao rural township in Nantou County, was sentenced to two concurrent life terms, in addition to a fine of NT$22 million (US$647,000) and a lifelong ban on running for public office.
Chungliao was leveled by the 7.3-magnitute quake and Wu was accused for rigging public bidding processes for post-quake reconstruction projects in exchange for kickbacks.

A judge of the Nantou District Court said in his verdict that Wu is particularly culpable for doing the opposite of what he was elected to do by pursuing his personal greed for profit without giving any consideration to public welfare.
Wu's illegal gains, totaling more than NT$2 million (US$58,823) should be returned to the Chungliao township government, according to the verdict.

Pai Hwa-poh, a technician at the Chungliao township government who pleaded guilty in a plea bargain, offered to return his share of the illegal gains and testify against Wu in the trial. He was handed a jail term of two years and 10 months.
All but six of the other 18 co-defendants, mainly contractors who offered Wu bribes to obtain the projects, were given prison terms varying from seven years and 10 months to 10 months.

Wu, who was briefly detained for investigation last year, was released for medical reasons afterward and continued his duties as magistrate. He was not present at the courtroom Thursday when the sentences were read.
A Nantou county government official said Wu would be relieved of his job in accordance with the rules after the verdict was served to the country government.

DOC.HEADLINE: WOULD-BE POLITICAL GROUP ASSERTS ITS INDEPENDENCE

TEXT.P: A political group to be inaugurated Saturday solemnly declared its independence from any political group Thursday after local reporters claimed it will be a think tank of President Chen shui-bian.

Wang Mei-shiou, one of the organizers of the Peishe, or North Society, said the group is not intended to be the think tank of any particular person, although she admitted that it will be closely associated with President Chen Shui-bian and former President Lee Teng-hui.

She said the group has invited Chen and Lee, but no other political leaders, to attend its Saturday inauguration ceremony because the two leaders share the group's goals for reinforcing the identity of Taiwan.
Wang said the group, whose members consist of lawyers, doctors academic and cultural leaders, will enhance Taiwan's identity through cultural activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICAL BARRIER HINDERS CROSS STRAIT HIGHER LEARNING EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: Cross-Taiwan Strait higher learning exchange programs are escalating, although the political atmosphere across the Taiwan Strait is still at a low ebb.

Educators from Sinkiang, Honan, Santung and Jiangxi, who are currently taking part in a two-day seminar on adult education at National Taiwan Normal University along with local education officials, expressed hope that cross-strait educational exchange programs will not be hindered by political barriers.
Liu Chun-yuan, curator of Soochow University in Taipei, recalled that his university began its exchange program with universities in mainland China with some trepidation three years ago.

"We started our exchanges step by step," Liu said, adding: "Now we hold exchange programs with many universities in mainland China, including Soochow University in Suzhow, Peking University, Xiamen University and others."
In addition to jointly holding seminars and conducting cooperative research on economics, "we have been carrying out exchanges of professors and student programs," Liu said.

Soochow University in Suzhou sends visiting professors to the Chinese Language Department of Soochow University in Taipei every semester, while law professors have also been on exchange visits, he pointed out.

In terms of student program exchanges, Liu said, students from Soochow University topped the leading four at the national college student debate contests sponsored by mainland TV channels two years ago. The good performance of Taiwan students in the debate contest attracted attention from mainland students, he went on.

Speaking on the education exchanges, Chen Wei-chao, president of National Taiwan University (NTU), said that his school has been implementing educational exchanges with universities in the mainland through the international educational organization and other academic organizations.
NTU maintains educational exchanges with the Peking University, Nanjing University, Fudan University, Tsinghua University in Beijing and the University of Science and Technology of China.

NTU and Tsinghua University in Hsinchu have jointly held biannual seminars on biochemical technology and information technology and the Internet with universities in mainland China, as well as universities in Hong Kong, South Korea and Japan, Chen said.

He said that NTU has also carried out exchange programs with members of Pan-Pacific College Alliance, which comprises some 30 universities from mainland China, the United States, Canada, Australia and New Zealand.

In addition, he went on, every university will select a potential young teacher to take part in the exchange program for professors in the summer vacation. NTU will host a seminar for those students pursuing their doctoral degrees next summer, he added.

Chan Shih-hung, president of Yuan Ze University, said that his university has already planned to open an educational promotion department in mainland China but has been forced to halt because the Ministry of Education objected to the program on the grounds that the university has violated Taiwan's mainland policy.
Chan stressed that the university wished to upgrade its international image through the international educational exchange.

Yuan Ze University has entered into academic exchange programs with Tsinghua University in Beijing, Peking University, Shanghai Jiaotong University and Hefei Science and Technology University, Chan said.

He said the university is cooperation with Peking University to computerize ancient Chinese rare books, with Shanghai Jiaotong University on wireless communications systems, with Xian Jiaotong University on automatic control systems and with Tsinghua University in Beijing on micro machines.
In addition, Yuan Ze has also sent professors and students to participate in seminars in mainland China, Chan said.
National Central University has maintained intensive exchange programs of professors and students with universities in the mainland, according to Liu Chao-han, president of the university.

At present, he went on, a professor of history from the mainland is doing a research study on the development of local media, while at the same time, the university receives mainland Chinese educational groups every week.

TAIWAN JOB SEEKERS EYEING OPPORTUNITIES IN MAINLAND CHINA (I)

TEXT.P: Facing global as well as local economic sluggishness, Taiwan's employment market has recently begun to notice the effects of a "mainland China fever." The island's job seekers seem to be feeling the importance of the transition toward globalization, and mainland China -- where the same language is spoken and people are of the same race -- has become the choice for their move toward that globalization.

Since the end of last year, Taiwan started experiencing a new mainland fever that was unlike two earlier waves, which were respectively led by World War II veterans returning to their home provinces and traditional industries looking to cash in on the lower labor wages in mainland China.

This most recent wave of mainland fever appears to be across-the-board -- from the high tech industry to the medical industry and even the real estate industry, the education sector and franchise service sectors are riding the wave.
What is even more unique is that this latest fever has spread from the industries to the job seekers, bringing about the never-before-seen rush to find employment in the mainland.

According to a study by 104 Job Bank, a noted local Internet company that tracks employment trends, the number of people willing to work in mainland China reached a new high for 2000 in December, while as of February this year, as much as 64 percent of the respondents to a new study expressed interest in working in the mainland.

According to its recent study, 25.1 percent of the 15,000 respondents expressed "very strong" willingness to work in mainland China, while 39 percent expressed a "strong" willingness. Of those who expressed such willingness, 30.6 percent said that their main consideration was their optimism toward the mainland market, while 24.5 percent said that there would be more opportunities for advancement and more room to put their skills into play.
Meanwhile, another online study shows that Shanghai has replaced Taipei as the first choice for Taiwan's job seekers, another indication of the mainland employment fever.

Compared to local industries, which earlier on had already determined that the entire world would be their market and embraced international trade, Taiwan's employment population seems to have only begun to explore this transition to globalization since being hit by the recent wave of global and domestic economic slump. Mainland China -- often called the "world's fastest-developing country" -- has become the obvious choice for local workers thinking of taking their first step away from the island.

Chien Lee-feng, an information science researcher at Academia Sinica who often travels between Taiwan and mainland China, said that the mainland market is growing in importance internationally. It is like Taiwan three decades ago, where opportunities are everywhere, not like the present-day Taiwan where the economy has reached a stage of maturity and cannot follow the linear explosive growth of the past.

Taiwan is inherently limited in its economic development because of its land size and the fact that it is an island. However, Chien said that Holland, which shares a similar lack of natural resources, can serve as a model of economic progress for Taiwan. (MORE)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN JOB SEEKERS EYEING OPPORTUNITIES IN MAINLAND CHINA (II)

TEXT.P: In Holland, juniors or seniors in college must study abroad for a year to broaden their global perspective. After graduation, it is not unusual for them to work in another country. Chien noted that he once knew a student who came from Holland to Taiwan for his year abroad. That student's three brothers each work in a different country.
The fact is, once Taiwan and mainland China join the World Trade Organization (WTO), Taiwan's job market will be faced with major changes, and "stepping out" can be said to be a certain trend.

Chan Wen-nan, director of the Institute for Information Industry's Market Intelligence Center, warned that because top talent from all over the world -- including mainland China -- will come to Taiwan after WTO accession and compete in the local job market, the island's existing work force must be prepared by thinking of themselves as workers who are not limited by national boundaries. Heading across the Taiwan Strait to work in mainland China is one of the possible choices in terms of location.

Faced with this situation, some of the people who are planning to work in mainland China are full of ambition. Take Mr. C., for example. He recently quit his job and is ready to work for his masters in economics at Duke University. He plans to head straight to Shanghai after receiving that degree because he is strongly attracted to what he says is a market of unlimited potential, considering that mainland China is about to enter the WTO and is sure to attract a mass influx of global financial experts after the financial market is liberalized.

Ms. Liao Li-chuan, 28, is currently working in Beijing as a marketing manager. She is from Taiwan and has been there for nearly a year. She believes that it really does not matter which country she goes to because, she says, anywhere abroad is good experience. She says that although some people might think that working in mainland China is the same as working in Taiwan because of the common language and ethnic heritage, in fact, the work ethic, the mindset and behavioral norms are completely different.
Chien agrees, pointing out that compared to Taiwan, workers in mainland China have less work ethic, while "a boastful culture" is more prevalent there.

Faced with this wave of mainland fever, experts are quick to remind job seekers to brush up on their professional knowledge and skills. 104 Job Bank President Yang Chi-kuan points out that the job market in mainland China is most in need of high-level managers at this time. For freshmen who are just starting out, the opportunities are close to nil. He urged first-time job seekers to find work that will be helpful to their own personal growth so that they can build up their experience.

Chien suggests that for those who are ready to go to mainland China, the "shortest distance from Taiwan to mainland China is through Silicon Valley." That is, those who have studied or worked in Silicon Valley are seen as "gold-plated" and stand a better chance of stepping into the mainland job market.
More important, however, says Chien, is that anyone who wants to work in mainland China must first possess a global perspective and abundant work experience.

Summing up the Taiwan worker's employment opportunities, Chien says: "To the right of Taiwan is the Pacific Ocean, which directly connects to Silicon Valley. To the left of Taiwan is the Taiwan Strait, which directly connects to mainland China. If you're not afraid of water, when you go to the right, you reach Silicon Valley. To the left, and you get mainland China. The employment opportunities for the Taiwan people have `never been better.'"

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WTO ENTRY MAY LEAD TO LOSS OF DUTY REVENUE

TEXT.P: A Ministry of Finance (MOF) official said Friday that Taiwan is estimated to lose duty revenue of NT$27.97 billion (US$822 million ) in the coming four years if it gets World Trade Organization (WTO) entry this year.
According to the official, the tariff will also be cut by an average 3.1 percent from the present 8.2 percent.
Both Taiwan and mainland China are poised to enter the WTO this November and the MOF is conducting an evaluation of the effect of the changing tariffs.

Upon WTO entry, tariffs on agricultural products will fall from the current 20.02 percent to 13.18 percent, tariffs on industrial products will fall to 4.22 percent from 6.03 percent, while tariffs on other products will fall to 5.64 percent from 8.2 percent.
The MOF official said it is hoped that the amendment of the Customs Import Duty and Tariff Law will be passed by the Legislative Yuan soon.
