DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, June 16, or the 25th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1654: Queen Christina of Sweden abdicates in favor of her cousin, Charles Gustavus.
1858: Gustavus V, the Swedish monarch who reigned for 43 years, is born. He kept Sweden neutral through both world wars.
1869: Charles Sturt, the English explorer who explored much of Australia, dies at the age of 74.
1890: American comedian Stan Laurel is born in England. With Oliver Hardy, he formed the first great comedy team of the talking film era. Their works include "The Music Box," "Hog Wild," "Way Out West," "The Flying Deuces" and "A Chump at Oxford."
1922: China's Chen Chiung-ming revolts against Dr. Sun Yat-sen, bombarding the presidential office on Kuanyingshan in Canton. Sun escapes from the office at night and reaches the naval headquarters at Chuhai aboard the warship "Chuyi."
1924: A school-opening ceremony is held at China's Whampoa Military Academy, presided over by superintendent Chiang Kai-shek.
1928: China's Sinkiang Province pledges allegiance to the Nationalist government after Chiang Kai-shek resumed the Northern Expedition on April 7.
1935: President Franklin D. Roosevelt's "New Deal" legislative package is passed by the House of Representatives. The Social Security Bill is aimed at tackling America's severe economic problems.
1941: Roosevelt orders the closure by July 10 of all German consulates in the United States.
1944: Chinese Expeditionary Forces capture Kaimaing in northern Burma.
1948: The first air hijacking occurs when Chinese bandits attempt to take over a Cathay Airways Catalina aircraft. The crew fight back and the aircraft crashes, killing all but the leader of the hijackers.
1953: A total of 75 F-84 G Thunder jet fighters, the first batch of military equipment to be provided to the Republic of China by the United States, arrive at an ROC air force base in Tainan, southern Taiwan.
1961: Rudolf Nureyev, the 23-year-old Russian dancer who was the star of the Leningrad Ballet, asks for political asylum in France.
1963: Valentina Tereshkova of the Soviet Union blasts off in Vostok 6 to become the first woman in space.
1969: Earl Alexander of Tunis, a British field marshal during World War II, dies at the age of 78. He directed the British troop evacuation from Dunkirk, France, and led maneuvers in Burma, North Africa and Italy.
1972: Guatemalan President Carlos Arana Osorio arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1974: Gen. John W. Voge Jr., commander-in-chief of the U.S. Air Force, arrives in Taipei for a two-day visit.
1975: China Airlines inaugurates a Boeing 747 jumbo jet service to Los Angeles.
1976: ROC Premier Chiang Ching-kuo inspects cadets of the Military Academy on its 52nd anniversary.
1977: Leonid Brezhnev, general secretary of the Soviet Communist Party, is elected chairman of the Presidium (the Politburo), succeeding Nikolao Podgorny.
1977: Werner von Braun, a German-born American rocket pioneer, dies at the age of 65. He designed the German V1 and V2 rockets and later worked as director of the U.S. Army team that put the first American satellite, Explorer I, into space in 1958.
1982: The 11-member ROC Goodwill Mission of Mayors, led by Mayor Jackson C.T. Yang of Taipei, leaves for a 20-day visit to the United States.
1987: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes the revision of regulations governing foreign exchange, authorizing the Executive Yuan to suspend all foreign exchange controls. Resumption of controls would require the consent of the Legislative Yuan.
1992: U.S. President George Bush and Russian President Boris Yeltsin agree in a summit meeting in Washington to slash their strategic weapons arsenals by about two-thirds by 2003.
1999: Thabo Mbeki becomes president of South Africa, succeeding Nelson Mandela.
2000: A new shortened work-week program, allowing Taiwan's workers and employers to work 84 hours every two weeks instead of the former 96 hours, is passed overwhelmingly at the legislature.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "With plausible speech and fine manners will seldom be found moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S OUTBOUND INVESTMENT GROWS 40%

TEXT.P: Taiwan's outbound investment in the first five months of this year grew nearly 40 percent over the same period of last year, according to statistics released Friday by the Investment Commission of the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
The statistics show that Taiwan's outbound investment totaled US$2.124 billion during the January-May period, a year-on-year increase of 39.5 percent.
During the period, Taiwan's investment in mainland China amounted to US$1.068 billion, a year-on-year growth of 33.18 percent, the figures show.
However, overseas Chinese and foreign investment in Taiwan decreased 19.65 percent to US$2.159 billion.
Taiwan's net capital outflow reached US$930 million for the period, the highest level since the Republic of China's central government moved to Taiwan in 1949.
According to the Investment Commission, globalization has prompted Taiwan businessmen to increase their investments abroad.

Although officials of the Ministry of Finance and the Ministry of Economic Affairs will soon embark on investment-soliciting tours abroad, the effects will not become evident until later, according to commission officials, who stressed that only stability in the domestic investment climate and sound cross-Taiwan Strait relations can effectively attract foreign investment to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL FINDS MANY CAREER WOMEN WORRY ABOUT LOSING JOBS

TEXT.P: The majority of local women think that Taiwan's unemployment rate will surge further to set yet another record and many of them worry about losing their jobs, according to the results of an opinion poll released Saturday.
The telephone survey of 1,109 randomly selected women aged between 20 and 45 was conducted from June 6-8 by the women's affairs department of the main opposition Kuomintang.

The survey results show that 80.1 percent of the respondents said they think Taiwan's jobless rate will hit another peak in the future and that 47.4 percent of them said they are worried about losing their jobs.

Forty-one percent said they are dissatisfied with their present jobs; 34.4 percent said they are now in the "process of changing careers and have yet to land a new job;" 78.5 percent said they feel that it has become more difficult to find a job than it was a year ago; and 65.1 percent said they have dropped their idea of changing jobs in consideration of Taiwan's current economic woes.

Meanwhile, 34.3 percent said they would be willing to go to mainland China to work at their employers' request and 42 percent said they would agree to allow their husbands or boyfriends to work in mainland China.

According to the survey, 46.2 percent said classified advertisements in newspapers are their main channel for seeking jobs; 18.5 percent said they mainly rely on the assistance or recommendation of friends and relatives; and 15.8 percent said they rely on the Internet.

About 29 percent said they would lower their job terms if they could not easily find new work; 20.4 percent said they would cut their daily spending; 16.5 percent said they would expand their "job seeking channels;" and 14.7 percent said they would then pursue advanced studies or sit various professional examinations.

The poll found that the civil service and teaching are the professions local women most like to undertake; followed by financial services, the information industry, the travel service, the restaurant service, the medical profession, traditional manufacturing industries, the mass media services, skin care and hair styling services, and international trade, in that order.

Things that women most fear to encounter in job seeking are falling prey to criminal rings; entering companies that are in financial straits; failing to get any pay; and joining groups specializing in illegal "pyramid" selling scams.

The survey respondents also cited several major hindrances to landing jobs, including a sharp decrease in job openings, a reluctance to take jobs incompatible with one's career expectations or personal qualifications, unreasonable pay scale, and local employers' unwillingness to recruit newcomers or those lacking in experience.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN URGES BEIJING TO FOCUS ON ECONOMY
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, June 15 (CNA) (By Tzou Ming-jhie and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's main opposition leader Lien Chan urged mainland China Friday to abandon military rivalry with Taiwan in favor of "win-win" bilateral economic exchanges.

Lien, who is chairman of the pro-unification Kuomintang, said after receiving an Outstanding International Politics Award from the University of Paris that Taiwan continues to hope for the steady development of the mainland Chinese economy and democratic politics, although the two have been on opposite sides of the fence for the past few decades.

He said that he is optimistic that most people in mainland China are far more interested in their livelihoods and welfare than they are in communism because the mainland has already slowly amassed approximately 20 years of reform experience.

As long as the communist leadership does not make any major policy mistakes, Lien speculated, the domestic gaps in political, social and economic power in mainland China will be filled in as time goes by.

However, he warned that if Beijing is unable to resolve the poverty gap between coastal and inland areas and the problems of corruption, then mainland China might adopt an even more confrontational approach to foreign policy in order to channel domestic unrest into nationalism.
This could lead to military conflicts in Northeast Asia, the Taiwan Strait and the South China Sea, Lien added.

He told the approximately 50 political scholars and China experts in the audience that European nations such as France should take on the "moral mission" to help mainland China transform into a democratic nation in order to assure world peace and economic prosperity.
Lien is slated to leave for New York Sunday to continue his three-city visit that has so far included London, where he delivered a speech at Oxford University.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE ECONOMICS MINISTER TO SOLICIT U.S. INVESTMENT
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 15 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu is scheduled to lead an official delegation to New York to solicit investment from the United States.

Lin and his group, to be comprised of officials from Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) agencies in charge of investment, high-technology industrial development and trade affairs, are scheduled to visit the New York area June 24-26 to meet with executives of U.S. hi-tech firms for business talks, in addition to holding a Taiwan investment workshop.

The 12 delegates will include officials from the Industrial Development Bureau, the Industrial and Investment Center, the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park Administration, the Telecommunications Industrial Development Committee, the Information Technology Development Committee, the Precision Machinery Development Committee, the High-Definition Television Development Committee and the Biotechnology Development Center.
Lin's group will also be joined by officials from the China External Trade Development Council at the workshop.
The delegation is then scheduled to proceed to Boston to continue its investment-promotion tour.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. HOUSE REPRESENTATIVES WARN OF MAINLAND CHINESE THREAT

TEXT.P: Two members of the U.S. House of Representatives warned Americans Thursday of the threat posed by mainland China.

Rep. Tom Tancredo (R-Colo.) told the House that the United States faces two significant threats: the People's Republic of China, and massive uncontrolled immigration into America, both legal and illegal.

"China is a threat to the United States and can be identified as such as a result of analyzing China's history and its most recent actions," the congressman claimed. "China is a nation with a very long history of aggressive behavior; that behavior is often activated by grievances, both actual and perceived."

Tancredo further claimed: "It is motivated by a sort of raging nationalism that finds expression in expanding its borders in xenophobia. I believe that the best way to successfully deal with China is to understand these realities and to fashion a foreign policy accordingly."

Another important understanding for Americans with regard to mainland China, he went on, "is the fact that China believes itself to be our number one enemy. They look at us as their enemy. There is absolutely nothing we can do by way of appeasement that will ever change this reality."

Although Beijing has already acquired Hong Kong and Macau through more peaceful mechanisms, they are now preparing for Taiwan to follow suit, peacefully or otherwise. Beijing has embarked upon the construction of three missile bases along the coast to threaten Taiwan. And six days ago, the mainland launched a military drill involving an attack of amphibious vehicles and landing craft on an island near Taiwan, said Tancredo.

He added that Beijing's capability to deliver nuclear weapons to targets including Los Angeles and many other cities in the United States has been perfected by the application of advanced technology that has been both purchased and stolen from the United States.

Rep. Walter Jones (R-N.C.), meanwhile, quoted Adm. Dennis Blair, the commander of U.S. forces in the Pacific, as telling Congress last March that "China's ongoing missile buildup opposite Taiwan is destabilizing, and will lead to a U.S. response unless halted."

Agreeing with Rep. Duncan Hunter (R-Calif.) on the need for missile defenses, the congressman said: "To ensure that we have the freedoms that we enjoy, we must continue to invest in a missile defense system."

DOC.HEADLINE: ICSB CONGRESS TO BEGIN SUNDAY

TEXT.P: A reception will be held Sunday in Taipei to kick off the 46th Congress of the International Council of Small Businesses (ICSB), organizers said Saturday.
President Chen Shui-bian will give a speech at the formal opening ceremony Monday.

Founded in 1956, the ICSB is an important international organization for small businesses. The main purpose of the organization is to study and review issues concerning small businesses in order to promote their sound global development.
Taiwan was permitted to use its formal national name to form ICSB's Republic of China branch in 1999.
The 46th ICSB congress is jointly sponsored by ICSB-ROC and ROC Small Business Association. Participants will discuss new challenges and solutions for small businesses in the "new era."

Four plenary meetings, 24 panel discussions and four seminars will be held during the four-day congress and Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi will give a lecture on ROC government policy regarding small businesses.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI-WASHINGTON RELATIONS CORDIAL: ROC REPRESENTATIVE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 15 (CNA) (By C.L. Tseng and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Channels of communication between Taiwan and the United States have been relatively smooth and the Bush administration's attitude toward Taiwan has been positive, the Republic of China's representative to the United States said Friday.
Chen Chien-jen told a delegation of journalists from Taiwan that bilateral relations are cordial, stable and firm.
In terms of strategic security, Taiwan hopes the United States will provide even more resources and also lend the island greater support in the international community, he added.
Chen said that Taiwan is not against improved Beijing-Washington relations, but cautioned that Taiwan's interests must not be harmed in the process.
Meanwhile, American China expert Larry Wortzel told the journalists that the responsibility for resuming dialogue with Taipei falls on Beijing.
Wortzel, who is director of the Heritage Foundation's Asia Policy Center, said that Beijing should stop circumventing Taiwan to negotiate with Washington.
He urged Beijing to try approaching the elected leader in Taiwan to create opportunities for dialogue.

Wortzel said that U.S. congressional support for Taiwan is widespread and that the new U.S. administration differs from the Clinton administration in that it treats Beijing, rather than Taipei, as a "troublemaker."

DOC.HEADLINE: 4,000 TAIPEI RESIDENTS RUN TO BACK BEIJING'S OLYMPIC BID

TEXT.P: Some 4,000 Taipei residents joined professional athletes from both Taiwan and mainland China Saturday in road run relays aimed at fostering support for Beijing's bid to host the 2008 Olympic Games.
The cross-Taiwan Strait relays will take place in 10 cities in Taiwan and mainland China over 15 days and are expected to attract the participation of an estimated 30,000 people.

Following a kick-off race in Taipei, the runners are scheduled to travel to the southern Taiwan city of Kaohsiung later Saturday, where another race will be staged. They will then proceed to the mainland Chinese cities of Shenzhen, Ningbo, Hangzhou, Shanghai, Wuxi, Nanjing, Qingdao and finally Beijing, according to the race sponsors.
The International Olympic Committee is scheduled to vote July 13 to decide whether Beijing, Toronto or Paris will be chosen to host the games in 2008.

A 23-member mainland Chinese delegation arrived in Taipei Thursday to take part in the two legs of the road race to be held in Taiwan. Members of the delegation included Li Xiaoshuang and Li Dashuang, two brothers who are both Olympic gold medalists in gymnastics, Lu Lin and Qiao Hong, both of whom are formerly Olympic gold medalists in swimming.

Although veteran Taiwanese athlete Chi Cheng -- who earned the nickname "the flying antelope" for breaking records at world track and field events -- stressed in her capacity as one of the sponsors of the race that the cross-strait run is purely sporting in nature, local politicians and activists did not lose the opportunity to promote their political causes.

While supporters of the opposition New Party placed propaganda banners along the streets through which the runners were scheduled to pass, activists from the Independence Party voiced their opposition to the race.
Riding on their "Democracy Tank," the Independence Party supporters shouted "No to China's United Front," and "Oppose China's scheme to localize Taiwan in the guise of the cross-strait relays."

DOC.HEADLINE: `TOM BEAR' ADOPTED AS MASCOT OF 2001 WORLD CUP BASEBALL TOURNEY

TEXT.P: The 34th World Cup Baseball Championship will be held in Taiwan in November and the mascot adopted for the event is "Tom Bear," a reference to the Formosan black bear.
A large "Tom Bear" in baseball uniform was unveiled in Taipei City Saturday to formally start the publicity for the championship.

The unveiling ceremony was attended by Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, Chinese-Taipei Baseball Association President Peng Cheng-hao, officials from the Council for Physical Fitness and Sports and local star professional players.
Ma said that baseball is Taiwan's favorite sport, but noted that the fans have been disappointed by the sport's decline in the past few years.
He expressed the hope that hosting the World Cup will help improve the local level of baseball and help the realization of building a "big-egg" baseball stadium in Taipei.
The World Cup will be held in Taiwan from Nov. 6 through Nov. 18, with 16 countries participating. The games will be played at four baseball grounds simultaneously.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC'S U.N. BID NOT `HUMBLE PLEA' BUT DIGNIFIED PROTEST: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that the Republic of China's bid to join the United Nations is not a "humble plea," but rather a dignified protest against the U.N.'s discrimination against the 23 million people of Taiwan.

In a speech delivered at a seminar on Taiwan's U.N. bid, Chen said the U.N.'s submission to the repressive Beijing regime's blackmail to deny democratic Taiwan's membership application has seriously violated the organization's own founding purposes and ultimate goals.

Noting that several U.N. members, such as Liechtenstein, Andorra, Kiribati and Seychelles, have populations similar to that of the ROC's National Taiwan University (NTU) and that their annual national budgets are even less than that of NTU, Chen asked: "What legitimate reasons does the U.N. have to reject the ROC's entry?"
With its outstanding economic achievements and smooth democratization, Chen said, the ROC is better qualified for a U.N. seat than many current members.

Chen said the ROC ranks 21st in terms of population, 20th interms of national gross product, 25th in terms of per capita national income, 14th in terms of its annual two-way trade and third or fourth in terms of its information-technology industry production.

"Therefore, we think it's our undeniable basic right to take part in the U.N.," Chen stressed, adding that since the U.N. is dedicated to promoting world peace, social progress and better standards of life under freedom, it should not have yielded to the pressure of a repressive country like communist China to shut out Taiwan.

"By launching its U.N. bid, the ROC is not making a humble plea to the international community. It is instead lodging a painful protest against the U.N.'s discrimination, in its capacity as a sovereign, democratic country," Chen explained.
He further said the ROC has consistently promoted its U.N. bid with dignity and confidence to underscore the common aspiration of Taiwan's 23 million people for international justice.

Chen reaffirmed his administration's determination to continue pushing for Taiwan's U.N. bid. He also said that even if the U.N. denies the ROC's legitimate right to join the body, the ROC will continue to fulfill its obligations as a member of international society to promote world progress in various fields.
The ROC, a U.N. founding member, has been shut out of the world body since 1971, when the U.N. gave the China seat to mainland China.

With the assistance of its diplomatic allies, the ROC began to ask the U.N. six years ago to review the exceptional situation faced by Taiwan and to work out measures to let Taiwan's voice heard in the world body. The ROC's bid, however, has been consistently shot down by Beijing and has failed to make the agenda of the annual U.N. General Assembly for the past six years.
Chen said the ROC will not be daunted by these defeats and will continue its pursuit of a U.N. seat with courage and perseverance.

Emphasizing that diplomatic work needs concerted efforts of the private and public sectors, Chen said he is hopeful that all domestic political parties and groups will pool their wisdom and resources to push for the ROC's U.N. bid and break the Beijing-imposed diplomatic embargo against Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ROC-MACAU AVIATION ACCORD TAKES EFFECT
DOC.DATELINE: Macau, June 16 (CNA) (By C.H. Jen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A new aviation agreement between the Republic of China and Macau was formally signed in Macau Friday and took effect immediately.
Air Macau Chairman Gu Tiefei and Tsui Yung, president of the Taipei Aviation Industry Association (TAIA), signed the accord on behalf of the Macau and ROC governments, respectively.
Taiwan and Macau signed their first five-year air pact in 1995, which expired at the end of last year. The two sides began to negotiate a new accord in the second half of last year.
After lengthy talks, Air Macau and the TAIA initiated a new agreement Nov. 24, 2000 and the draft accord was recently approved by their respective government agencies.
Under the new pact, the total number of seats on Macau-Taipei and Macau-Kaohsiung flights will increase from the previous 28,200 per week to 36,200.
The new agreement will remain valid for five years. Air Macau and Taiwan's EVA Airways and TransAsia Airways will jointly operate the Taipei-Macau and Kaohsiung-Macau routes.

Taiwan-Macau air routes are regarded as "special" routes because Macau is now a special administrative region under Beijing's rule and relevant government officials from both sides took part in the negotiations as advisers to the two intermediary bodies.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OFFICERS CONCLUDE TWO-WEEK STUDY TOUR IN U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 15 (CNA) (By Neil Lu & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: A group of Republic of China military officers and scholars concluded a two-week tour of the United States Friday with a visit to the U.S. Pacific Command in Hawaii.
The officers and scholars visited Washington and Hawaii to exchange views with their American counterparts on a broad range of issues through arrangements made by a U.S. strategic study institute.
This was the first such military personnel exchange since Washington-Taipei diplomatic relations were severed in 1979. The group was headed by ROC Air Force Maj. Gen. Lin Yu-pao.

Yang Nien-tsu, a professor from National Sun Yat-sen University and a member of the ROC group, told CNA that the main purpose of the trip was to enhance Taiwan's understanding of American politics and culture and their policy-making procedures.
He said that the tour was not connected with military cooperation or training, but described it as an "important milestone" for bilateral exchanges of military personnel.
Yang termed the trip "very successful" and expressed the hope that Taiwan and the United States will evaluate the results and continue to support such military personnel exchanges.
During their visit to the U.S. Pacific Command, the Taiwan visitors heard a briefing on the command's organization, function, mission and responsibilities.
They were scheduled to leave for home Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEASIDE SCHOOL GIVES DIPLOMAS IN COMMENCEMENT HELD IN SEA
DOC.DATELINE: Kungliao, Taipei County, June 16 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Eight graduates from the Fulien Primary School and three pupils of the school located at the easternmost point of Taiwan snorkeled Saturday across a 1,000-meter wide bay to receive their diplomas and certificates of "the brave."

The children all finished the 1,000-meter bay crossing within 20 minutes and obtained their certificates from Taipei County Deputy Magistrate Lin Wan-yi, who awaited them at the other side of the bay.

Principal Chen Jui-chih, who swam with the graduates and pupils during the bay crossing, said the special method of commencement is aimed at "leading the children closer to the sea and encouraging them to become more capable of making a living as seaside-residing people." All the pupils from the primary school are from families which make their living from fishing or aquaculture.

Chen said he feels proud that under the guidance of swimming coach Chang Feng-dah, most of the graduates of the school, weighing an average 30 kilograms, are capable of towing alone a 100-kg drowning person to the shore.
The seaside Fulien Primary School was not the only school to hold an unconventional commencement.

The Atayal-tribe Fushan Primary School in Taipei County's mountainous township of Wulai is scheduled to hold an exceptional commencement Sunday in a "rite of passage or accrescence" -- a ritual event during which 12- and 13-year-old children are taught how to hunt, fish and weave as they become adults.
Meanwhile, the Homei Primary School in Kungliao Township on Taiwan's northeast coast -- another seaside school -- is scheduled to hold a sub-aqua commencement Tuesday.

The graduates will dive into the sea and swim to undersea abalone shelves where they will distribute abalone fry and other fish fry and then swim to a marked point in the sea where their principal will be waiting with their laminated diplomas.
Baby abalone is a prime ocean crop of the Homei community, a fishing village embraced by deep blue water in which coral reef fish and plants are both abundant and magnificent.
All the school's 110-odd children, including the 2001 graduates, come from families supported by the fishing industry, so none are strangers to the sea.

The Homei school began to hold underwater commencements in 1999, an exceptional graduation method initiated by Principal Lai Lien-kung, which has been favorably received by the graduates and their parents ever since.
On Thursday, the Pitou Primary School will give diplomas to its 2001 graduates, six of whom will climb the Pitou lighthouse as part of the commencement ceremony.
The lighthouse, located at the northernmost point of Taiwan proper, was opened to the public only recently, despite having been operational for more than 100 years.
Before receiving their diplomas at the lighthouse, the graduates will first embark on a sail boat which will take them for a short cruise along the reef coast around the island's northernmost tip.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT AGAIN URGES EU TO OPEN OFFICE IN TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, June 15 (CNA) (By P. C. Tang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The European Parliament (EP), the legislative arm of the 15-member European Union (EU), has again urged the union to set up a representative office in Taiwan, EP sources said Friday.

According to the sources, EP members have expressed their hope in a resolution passed on Wednesday that they look forward to seeing the EU open representative offices in selected countries in Southeast Asia, Latin America, the Middle East and Muslim areas to reinforce the union's presence and status in those regions.
Among Southeast Asian countries, the resolution said, the EU should especially set up footholds in Taiwan, the EU's 14th largest trading partner, and Singapore, the EU's 15th trading partner.

Meanwhile, the EU passed another resolution Thursday, calling for strengthening of EU-Asia dialogue. The resolution supports increased engagements between South and North Korea and resumption of regular dialogue between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

In addition, the resolution demanded that the EU and its member countries grant visas to the Republic of China president and other senior ROC officials to enable them to make private visits to EU countries.

According to a World News Digest report on March 19, Denmark, an EU member, has decided not to grant a visa to ROC President Chen Shui-bian, the winner of the 2001 Prize for Freedom presented by the Liberal International.
Denmark's decision will dampen President Chen's hope to receive the award in person in Copenhagen in November this year.

The Liberal International (LI), a London-based organization which groups major liberal political parties in countries around the world, is scheduled to hold its annual meeting in the Danish capital Nov. 9-10 when the freedom prize will also be presented. President Chen's Democratic Progressive Party is an LI member.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS, LAWMAKERS SUGGEST FORMING `SHADOW CABINET' BEFORE ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: A group of scholars and lawmakers recommended Saturday that each political party should form a "shadow Cabinet" prior to the year-end legislative elections, to let the public know who might be members of a new coalition government.

In a seminar organized by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) think tank the National Policy Foundation, Chinese Culture University Political Science Department Director Yang Tai-shun pointed out that some coalition governments in Europe actually work against democratic principles because the people are unable to predict what the government's makeup will be after an election.

Sometimes, he added, the reality turns out to be very different from the people's original expectations. Therefore, he suggested that having a shadow Cabinet will help bridge the possible gap between expectation and outcome.

Predicting that none of the major parties will be able to win a majority of the seats in the upcoming election, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Lin Cho-shui described the forming of a coalition government as a foregone conclusion.

He said that if the DPP -- which currently holds less than one-third of the seats in the KMT-dominated legislature -- cannot claim a legislative majority, then "naturally" the Cabinet will have to be formed with another party.
The establishment of such a coalition government would temporarily resolve the problem of political instability that has been troubling the current minority government, he said.
However, only when the ruling party is able to claim a two-thirds majority can it reform the entire system, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRED MEDIA WORKERS PROTEST GROUP'S MAINLAND CHINA VISITS
DOC.DATELINE: CKS International Airport, June 16 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Some 30 former employees recently laid off by a local paper gathered at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport Saturday to protest alleged "investment tours" to mainland China by one of the group's subsidiaries.

Claiming their dismissal violates the Labor Standards Law, the protesters, who formerly worked for the China Times newspaper, protested tours to the mainland by two delegations from the Commercial Times that they alleged were to investigate the possibility of investing there.

Facing the protesters, Wang Shang-wen, deputy editor-in-chief of the Commercial Times and one of the delegation members, said the Commercial Times had organized several delegations to visit the mainland since the beginning of this year in response to readers' demands that the paper provide more information about mainland Chinese business affairs.
Wang denied that the purpose of the visits is to invest there and pointed out that the trips are absolutely nothing to do with the dismissal action by the group's management.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
KMT URGES PARTY MEMBERS TO SHOW SOLIDARITY TO AVOID SPLINTERING

TEXT.P: An official of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) on Sunday urged all party members to rally behind the KMT to avoid splintering.

KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng made the remarks after reports said an alliance between President Chen Shui-bian and former President Lee Teng-hui is forming after both attended the inauguration of a pro-independence academic group the previous day.

The presence of Lee, a former KMT chairman before stepping down shortly after the KMT lost the presidential election in March 2000, is widely expected to give political backing to Chen because of their common approaches and concepts on relations across the Taiwan Strait. Observers also say that Lee's passion for Taiwan nationalism is another important factor in his decisions.

Lee also said in his address to members of the newly formed "North Society" that although the political landscape has changed after the transfer of power from the KMT to the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) after the presidential election, there is "still one who has yet to recognize the mainstream opinion of the public."
Lee stopped short of naming "the one," although it is widely believed that he was referring to Lien Chan, current KMT chairman.
Asked about a possible Lee-Chen alliance for the crucial year-end elections, Lin said the KMT hopes its members will be calm, rational and more tolerant in the face of developments.

Lin said that he talked with Lien, who is currently visiting France, over the phone Saturday to brief him on the domestic political and economic situation, during which Lien expressed the hope that all party members would show solidarity, so that those who try to drive a wedge between KMT members would not be successful.

On calls from KMT grassroots members to revoke Lee's KMT membership because of his recent remarks, Lin said that there are 900,000-plus KMT members and every one of them is entitled to his own view. He urged all members to be calm and rational.
Asked if Lee would face disciplinary action if he decided to stump for candidates from the ruling DPP or other political parties, Lin said that he would not comment on speculative questions.

Lin also appealed for economic and political figures to devote more time to the nation's economy instead of politics. He said the emphasis now should be on the quality of life for the people of Taiwan. The issues of unification with mainland China and Taiwan independence are not currently in the forefront, he said.
Lin also asked those concerned with Taiwan's future not to let Taiwan become engulfed in money politics, which he said would be detrimental to Taiwan's democratic development.
Lin also asked voters to make wise decisions in the year-end elections so that qualified candidates will be elected to serve the people.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT HELPS CLEAN UP STREAM, MUM ON POLITICS

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui joined environmentalists in cleaning up a stream near his Taipei residence Sunday, but was tight-lipped about the political speculation surrounding his public appearances Saturday with President Chen Shui-bian at the launch of a pro-independence group.

Surrounded by a group of environmentalists and journalists, Lee, wearing a leisure shirt, picked up garbage with a pair of long tongs along the Waishuanghsi stream, in Shihlin district, where he lives. He also painted over graffiti on nearby walls.

Speaking at the beginning of the high-profile activity, Lee said he has always been willing to join his neighbors in cleaning up the neighborhood around his house, adding that he hoped his participation in the effort would inspire the public to take better care of their neighborhood and homeland.

Lee, however, brushed asides questions from journalists about his political shift toward supporting President Chen Shui-bian and the rift between himself and his Kuomintang (KMT) chairman successor, Lien Chan, stressing that he would rather stick to his clean-up work than to make political statements.
Lee joined president Chen in attending the inauguration of a pro-independence group in Taipei Saturday which fueled speculation that Lee is breaking ranks with his party.
The speculation was further boosted by Lee not inviting Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who is the highest-ranking elected public official of the KMT, to join him in Sunday's event.
Although Lee was quoted as saying that he preferred to keep the activity a non-political one, observers interpreted it as a gesture by Lee to distance himself from the KMT.

Ma spent Sunday morning presiding over a ceremony to honor 154 elementary school students who had excelled in their studies. He said he was not in any way offended by not being invited to the clean-up activity. He said that his schedule was fully booked by other public appearances on Sunday and that he could not have squeezed in the activity.

The mayor down played the political consequences of Lee's appearance with President Chen Shui-bian at the launch of the pro-independence group called the "North Society" Saturday, saying it is not unusual for a former president to join his successor in public events and the incident should not be interpreted as a rift between Lee and the KMT.

DOC.HEADLINE: BIOGRAPHY OF FORMER PRESIDENT BECOMES HIT IN JAPAN AND TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Both Chinese and Japanese versions of a biography of former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui have become hot sellers in the two countries, showing that many have an interest in the life and times of "Mr. Democracy."

Japanese historian and novelist Fuyuko Kamisaka, the author of the book entitled "President Inside the Tiger's Mouth -- Lee Teng-hui and Tseng Wen-hui," organized a news conference Sunday in Taipei to thank the public, as the Chinese version of the book has hit the best-seller list just one week after its publication.
The book was originally published in Japan and later released in Taipei. In Japan, the book went to a second printing only two weeks after going on sale.
The book, through interviews with Tseng, Lee's wife, depicts post-war Taiwan history and the political life and times of the former first couple.

Tseng attended the news conference to congratulate Kamisaka. Tseng said she has known Kamisaka for more than 20 years and praised her as a good historian and writer who has won many awards in her own country.
Tseng said the book is based on fact and that Kamisaka had visited Taiwan more than 10 times to do research.
Kamisaka said that she planned to write the history of post-war Taiwan 15 years ago, and she finally decided that the story could be best told through the eyes of the former president and his wife.
The book sold briskly when it was first released in Japan, a phenomenon that Kamisaka attributed to the interest of the Japanese people in Taiwan and their affection for Lee.

The book was released at the time that Lee was seeking medical treatment in Japan, a visit that caused some controversy. The Japanese government was divided on whether to issue a visa to Lee in the face of mainland China's strong objection. Beijing considers Lee a separatist who does not want unification with mainland China.
Lee's strong criticism of the Japanese government also made many Japanese interested in reading the book, according to Kamisaka.
Peng Ming-min, senior adviser to President Chen Shui-bian, said that when Lee was president, he always felt strongly about leading Taiwan toward being a modern and democratic country.
Peng said that there were a number of things that Lee could not comment on while he was president, but now he can speak more freely, as is borne out in the book.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD URGES PARTY MEMBERS TO FACE CHALLENGES WITH CLEAR MINDS

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan told party members Saturday to broaden their vision and be rational when faced with challenges. Lien said this would be an important step for the party in the future.

In a written statement to the 12th congress of the party's Huang Fu Hsing Committee, Lien said that he realizes that the KMT's defeat in last year's presidential election is still painful for some and that he understands those who have contacted him with suggestions. Lien said he was aware of those who sought to "take strict measures to deal with matters and people which have caused the party's loss of power."

Lien said he realizes that the request is a reflection of love by many loyal party members but stressed that "the party authorities must weigh the issue rationally from many aspects." He called on all party members to face the coming challenges with a clear mind and to leave history to make its own judgments of the party's doings.
Lien said the KMT is a broad-minded party and that all party members should be visionary and rational when challenged by confrontation and resentment to help the party rebuild its strength.
Lien is currently visiting France, the first stop of his current "academic tour" which will also take him to London and New York.

Many grassroots KMT members have demanded that party authorities revoke the party membership of former party chairman and president Lee Teng-hui for his recent display of support for President Chen Shui-bian of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party, who defeated the KMT's Lien in the 2000 presidential election.

Although strong pressure to send Lee packing is coming from the KMT's rank-and-file, no formal motion has been put forth in the Huang Fu Hsing Committee's congress. KMT Vice Chairman Chiang Chung-ling and Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng took part in the gathering.

KMT lawmaker Ting Shou-chung, who also attended the congress, said Lee's resorting to "local content" to garner public backing for Chen goes against the present mainstream public aspirations for sound economic development and a harmonious ethnic integration as well as a stable social order and peaceful relations with mainland China.

"An 80-year-old retired man is unable to decide for the people which is the mainstream public opinion," Ting said, adding that the KMT should deal with Lee in compliance with the party's disciplinary rules if he causes a split within the party or stumps for candidates of other parties in the coming elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROTEST ADDS POLITICAL SENSE TO RACE FOR BEIJING'S OLYMPICS BID

TEXT.P: The second leg of a long-distance run held on both sides of the Taiwan Strait to highlight Beijing's bid to host the 2008 Olympic Games ran into trouble on Sunday in Kaohsiung with runners being greeted by shouts of protest from a pro-independence group.

The "Beijing Olympics, Chinese pride" race, began its second leg in Kaohsiung City Sunday morning, with fanfare rivaling the first leg of the race in Taipei Saturday, not because of the number of runners but because of a protest by a pro-independence group, the Taiwan Independence Party.

In addition to the dancing and singing marking the event, the protesters contributed to the spectacle by blaring anti-Beijing slogans through microphones near the starting line of the race and turned the sporting event into a political show.

Cordoned off from the starting line by police, the protesters waved placards saying, "Taiwan Independence," "Opposed to one China," and "Why is Beijing's Olympic bid of any concern to Taiwan?" The protesters also stamped on a Chinese flag to show their contempt for Beijing.

The ceremony was also attended by players from the President Lions professional baseball team. They signed autographs for fans and joined hundreds of runners, including 23 from mainland China, in the five-kilometer race.

The race will next move to Shenzhen, Southern China on Monday and seven other mainland Chinese cities afterward to demonstrate the solidarity of Chinese on both sides of the Taiwan Strait in supporting Beijing's Olympic bid.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT WARNS PARENTS OF THE DANGERS OF ILLEGAL DRUGS
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 17 (CNA) (By Maubo Chang) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Taipei, June 17 (CNA): Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu called on parents Sunday to spend more time with their children and educate them on the dangers of illegal drugs.
Lu made the remark while addressing an anti-drug rally sponsored by the Hsinchuang City branch of the Lion Clubs International.

"We have to rid society of drugs like marijuana, amphetamines, ecstasy and heroin -- which damage physical health -- but we must also target those influences in society that can act as a poison to the minds of our young people, like spreading vicious rumors, for example," Lu said.
Lu reminded parents to spend more time with their children during the summer vacation to prevent them from becoming involved with illegal drugs and being tempted to view pornography.

Lu put the final tile on a 120-meter "anti-drug wall" that contains 1 million mosaic tiles. Those who organized the construction of the wall will apply to the "Guinness Book of Records" for certification of a world record.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO HELP OFFSHORE ISLANDS DEVELOP TOURISM

TEXT.P: The government will redefine its goal for tourism development of offshore islands so that each of them will have its distinctive feature, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) said Sunday.

MOTC officials said that they will redefine Kinmen as the epitome of southern Fujian provincial culture and landscape and historical sites of important battles with mainland China. Matsu will be developed into the epitome of eastern Fujian province and as a frontline outpost.

Green Island is to be a marine and holiday center with a human rights memorial park. Orchid Island will be a Yami tribe cultural center and example of a rain forest. Hsiaoliuchiu will emphasize its Liuchiu Island reef.

The officials said the ministry will start planning the aspects of transportation, accommodation, tourism packages, administrative coordination and the work with travel operators to devise attractive tourism packages.

MOTC officials noted that offshore islands have played important roles in the nation's defense, politics and economy over the past decades, but their roles have diminished over tine and now they all hope to develop tourism to stimulate their sluggish economies.

They said that Kinmen and Matsu, formerly two frontline outposts opposite the mainland, have seen stationed troops, the lifeline of their economy, drop sharply after the government implemented the policy of streamlining the military.

Orchid Island is the hometown of the Yami tribe. Penghu, Green Island, Hsiaoliuchiu used to be the strongholds of the fishing industry, but their development has declined because of depleted fishing resources.

But officials noted that the offshore islands have encountered different problems in developing tourism basically because they fail to offer attractive tourism packages and their prices are also high, hindering the development of tourism.

They noted that Penghu is swept by strong winds all year round, which affects tourism. They also said the supply of water and electricity is still insufficient and the accommodation and restaurants tend to center in Makung, but upscale hotels are limited and the service quality is unstable. Public transportation facilities are also lacking in Penghu.
They said that Kinmen, though being defined as a frontline park, still has much work to do to extend the whole area into a national park.
In addition, some scenic spots along the coastline are still controlled by the military and could not be put into full use, resulting in gaps between planning and reality.
Matsu, because of its steep terrain and military needs, does not have enough space to develop tourism. Local residents also lack the experience in running tourism businesses.

Green Island started to develop tourism a decade ago and now the tourism industry has replaced agriculture and fishing as the lifeline of the local economy. But the influx of tourists has posed environmental pressures and steep competition. The supply of water and electricity is also not sufficient to meet the needs of all the tourists.

Hsiaoliuchiu, which lies off Pingtung in southern Taiwan, is said to have yet to reach consensus on developing tourism. Its tourism activities are not diversified enough, and some of the public facilities are left idle because of lack of proper management.
Orchid Island has seen its infrastructure lagging. Local people also have no confidence in the government's plan to establish a national park and related facilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUANG YU-CHEN SECOND IN APITA LADIES GOLF TOURNEY IN JAPAN
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 17 (CNA) (By Lilian Wu) (By Mike Chang and Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Tokyo, June 17 (CNA): Taiwan's women's veteran golfer Huang Yu-chen carded a two-under-par 70 Sunday with a three-day total of 214 to share second place with four Japanese players at the Apita Circle and Sunkus Ladies Open Golf Tournament held at Chifu, Chifu Prefecture.
Midori Yoneyama of Japan shot a three-under 68 to complete an 11-under 205 total to lead the field.
Another Taiwan player, Tseng Hsiu-feng, shot a four-over 76 to finish with an eight-over 224 to rank 44th.
The tourney was held at the Green Nakatsugawa Golf Club in Chifu City, Chifu Prefecture.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIGITAL GAPS SEEN IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan lags developed countries in digitization and noticeable gaps exist between Taiwan's urban and rural areas and between the rich and poor, the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) reported Sunday.

Citing an assessment made by an international information industry organization, the CEPD said Taiwan's spending in Internet content technology was only 4.8 percent as a ratio to the country's gross domestic product in 1999, far lower than 8.9 percent in the United States and 7.1 percent in Japan posted in the same year.

There is a difference of 61.3 percentage points in computer ownership rate between Taiwan's wealthiest and the poorest families in 1999. At the same time, differences between the two groups in mobile phone ownership and Internet access rates also reached 67.1 percentage points and 40 percentage points, respectively.

In terms of urbanization, a gap of 30.8 percentage points in family computer ownership exits between Taiwan's urban and rural areas, while the gap in mobile phone ownership rates and Internet access rates was 23.7 percentage points and 18.1 percentage points, respectively.

In terms of regions, Taiwan's northern region posted the highest ratio in family computer and mobile phone penetration rates, which were 28.7 percentage points and 21.7 percentage points ahead of the island's eastern region. The divide in Internet connection rates was 12.4 percentage points.

To reduce the digital gaps among Taiwan's regions, the CEPD said information industry-related infrastructure facilities and expertise must be further upgraded on the island, in addition to a set of comprehensive rules and systems.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT CLARIFIES STATEMENT WHICH SOUNDED LIKE DIG AT KMT

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui clarified Sunday that a statement made by him the previous day was not a jab at his successor within the Kuomintang.

At an ceremony marking the launch of the Chinese-version of "President Inside the Tiger's Mouth," a biography penned by Japanese writer Fuyuko Kamisaka, Lee said when he blamed people yesterday for being oblivious to public opinion, he is referring to "some persons" instead of "one person."

Local media quoted Lee as saying in a speech at the inauguration of a pro-independence group Saturday that there is a person who is still ignorant of public opinion, resisting people's desire for a stable country and disrupting the ushering in of a new era.

Lee's statement caused an uproar among the Kuomintang rank-and-file who believed it to be a dig at their chairman, Lien Chan, in light of Lee's previous disapproval of the party's line under Lien. Many party members, therefore, have demanded the expulsion of Lee from the Kuomintang.
Lee refused to be pinned down Sunday morning by journalists. But he apparently tried to defuse the situation by modifying his intent.

The former KMT chairman has made no secret of his grievance against Lien. In the book "President Inside the Tiger's Mouth," Lee was quoted as blaming Lien for forcing him to step down from the job as KMT chairman after Lien lost the presidential election, although Lee made an all-out effort to stump for Lien.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST TAIWAN-RUSSIA FORUM TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI IN OCTOBER

TEXT.P: The first Taiwan-Russia forum concerning bilateral economic affairs is expected to be held in Taipei in October, according to officials of the Taipei-based Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER).
A Taiwanese delegation led by TIER President Wu Rong-i was in Moscow in the last few days to fix the date for the forum.

The delegation, which arrived in Moscow on June 12, has visited many Russian officials responsible for science, economics, trade, and energy affairs, as well as members of the Taiwanese Chamber of Commerce in Moscow to exchange views on how to enter the Russian market.
Members of the Taiwan delegation also include Chen Wu-hsiung, chairman of the Petrochemical Industry Association of Taiwan, the vice president and several researchers of TIER.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD VISION HEAD HAILS TAIWAN CHILDREN'S CONTRIBUTION

TEXT.P: World Vision International President Dean Hirsch hailed Sunday the contribution made by Taiwan children to global relief operations and spoke with a group of 17 local children.
In a news conference sponsored by World Vision Taiwan, Hirsch praised the enthusiastic participation of Taiwan children in international assistance missions for poor children across the world.

In response to a question of how local children could help children of those countries plagued by war, Hirsch suggested Taiwan children can hold parades to voice their protests against war or they can write letters to United Nations Secretary-General Kofi Annan to let their voice be heard should war break out in the Taiwan Strait.
He also suggested that local parents should talk with their children about issues related to AIDS, alcohol addiction and drugs to help them build healthy concepts toward those problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD CONVENTION OF SMALL BUSINESSES OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 2001 annual convention of the International Council of Small Businesses (ICSM) will open in Taipei Monday with some 500 entrepreneurs from 50 countries participating.
In the meeting, Economic Minister Lin Hsin-i of the Republic of China will deliver a speech on the government's policy to help small and medium enterprises.

Discussions at the meeting will center on the challenges facing small businesses in the world and on the tactics to deal with them, said Day Sheng-tong, president of the Council of Small and Medium Enterprises in the Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SEVERS DIPLOMATIC TIES WITH MACEDONIA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China broke off diplomatic relations with Macedonia Monday after the Balkan state made its intention clear that it would establish formal ties with mainland China.

Chang Siao-yue, spokeswoman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), said the ROC regretted that Macedonia had decided to switch diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing and that the ROC will immediately close its embassy in the Macedonian capital of Skopje.

Chang also said the ROC will terminate all cooperation projects with Macedonia, which are estimated to be worth more than US$140 million, and recall all its diplomatic personnel and technical assistance experts in the country.
David Lin, director of MOFA's Department of European Affairs, summoned Vera Modanu, Macedonian charge d' affairs, to convey the ROC's decision and its stance, Chang said.
The Macedonian national flag, which flew at the entrance of the foreign ministry in Taipei, was also removed to signify the official severance of diplomatic ties between the two countries.
Peter Cheng, the ROC minister to Macedonia, presented an official letter of protest to the Macedonian government in Skopje to express the ROC's dissatisfaction over its decision.

Media reports have said that Macedonian Foreign Minister Ilinka Mitreva, who has insisted on an early resumption of diplomatic ties with mainland China, arrived in Beijing Monday and would immediately contact mainland officials on the resumption of ties.

Chang said that since the formation of a coalition government in Macedonia on May 13, the ROC learned that contacts between mainland China and Macedonia were increasing. The foreign ministry was aware that the situation was not favorable, but it did its best to maintain ties as long as possible, Chang said.
Chang said the ROC embassy in Skopje will officially close and stop all operations Monday. All personnel in the embassy will leave Macedonia "as soon as possible."

Chang said that after the severance of ties with Macedonia, the Vatican will become the only ally of the ROC in Europe, but that the foreign ministry will continue to promote relations with European countries.

She noted that Beijing has tried every means to squeeze the ROC diplomatically over the years, but the ROC government and people will continue to actively promote diplomatic ties with other countries in a pragmatic manner.
The ROC and Macedonia established diplomatic relations in January 1999. But the civil-war torn country also wants to gain mainland China's support in dealing with ethnic Albanian rebels.
