DOC.HEADLINE: OLYMPIC FLAME TO REACH TAIWAN IF BEIJING HOSTS 2008 GAMES: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Olympic flame -- the light of spirit, knowledge and life, and a herald of peace -- will be arranged to be carried in Taiwan if Beijing succeeded in winning the right to host the 2008 Olympic Games, a mainland Chinese sports official visiting Taiwan said Monday.

Che Xiangdong, deputy director of the liaison department under Beijing's All-China Sports Federation, said Taiwan will be included in the flame relay during the opening ceremonies of the 2008 Olympics if Beijing hosts the Games.

Che, at the head of a 23-member group of mainland Chinese athletes in Taiwan since last week for the cross-strait "Beijing Olympics, Chinese pride" race, made the remarks at Kaohsiung's international airport Monday morning before leaving for Hong Kong, where athletes from both sides of the Taiwan Strait will proceed to Shenzhen to continue the 10-city, 15-day relay run.
Soliciting support from the Taiwan public, Che said in Asia, the Koreans and Japanese have hosted the Olympic Games, so why can't the Chinese?

A group of Taiwan athletes, led by veteran Taiwanese athlete Chi Cheng -- who earned the nickname "the flying antelope" for breaking records at world track and field events -- also boarded the same plane bound for Hong Kong to join the mainland Chinese athletes to continue the cross-strait relay run, which will take place in Shenzhen, Ningbo, Hangzhou, Shanghai, Wuxi, Nanjing and Qingdao before arriving in Beijing on June 30.
Some 4,000 Taipei residents joined the cross-strait athletes in a kick-off race in Taipei Saturday to highlight Beijing's bid to host the 2008 Games.

The race was partially disrupted on Sunday in Kaohsiung by noisy demonstrations from the Independence Party riding on their "democracy tank," shouting, "No to China's united front," and "Oppose China's scheme to localize Taiwan in the guise of the cross-strait relays."

Cordoned off from the starting line by police, the Independence Party activists waved placards saying, "Taiwan Independence," "Opposed to one China," and "Why is Beijing's Olympic bid of any concern to Taiwan?"

DOC.HEADLINE: SEVERANCE OF MACEDONIA TIES NOT TO AFFECT WORK IN EUROPE: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The severance of diplomatic ties with Macedonia will not affect the Republic of China's diplomatic work in Europe, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Monday.

The official, who preferred anonymity, made the remarks after the MOFA formally announced the breakup of relationship with the Balkan state which has decided to resume official ties with mainland China.

The official said although some people are concerned that the breakup of ROC-Macedonia ties would mark a serious setback to Taiwan's efforts to expand its diplomatic frontiers, the severance would not hinder the MOFA's work in Europe.
The ROC had regarded Macedonia as a bridgehead to forge economic and diplomatic relations with Southeastern European countries since it established diplomatic ties with Macedonia in January 1999.

"Over the past two-plus years, we have devoted much energy to assist Macedonia in national development," the official said, adding that the severance of bilateral ties mainly resulted from changes in Macedonia's domestic situation, particularly its worsening ethnic confrontation, not from any deficiencies or faults on the ROC's part.

In reality, the official said, many former Soviet-bloc countries in eastern and southeastern Europe are fully aware of the ROC's financial aid to Macedonia and its strenuous efforts to promote pragmatic cooperative projects with that country.
"Our efforts have achieved some results," the official explained, adding that substantive relations between the ROC and European countries have continued to grow in recent years.
"In addition to upgrading relations with major West European countries, we have also managed to improve our ties with southeastern European countries in the past few years," the official added.

He went on to say that the MOFA staff will not be daunted by Macedonia's switch of diplomatic allegiance and will even redouble efforts to break the Beijing-imposed diplomatic isolation against Taiwan.
With the severance of ties with Macedonia, the ROC now has only one diplomatic ally in Europe -- the Vatican City.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK MARKET TUMBLES

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (Taiex) took a tumble Monday over pessimistic forecast of third-quarter profits by major local semiconductor manufacturers.
The Taiex weighted price index, the market's key barometer, lost 88.11 points from last week's finish to close at 5,070.52 points, on a market turnover of NT$31.35 billion (US$922.06 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT SCHEDULED TO LEAVE FOR CORNELL NEXT SUNDAY

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui is scheduled to leave for the United States next Sunday to visit his alma mater, Cornell University, sources from Lee's office said Monday.

Lee, who received his Ph.D. in agricultural economics in 1968 from Cornell, is visiting his alma mater mainly to attend a ceremony marking the establishment of the Lee Teng-hui Institute for Scientific Research in the prestigious university during his visit.
Cornell also set up a Lee Teng-hui Professorship of World Affairs in 1994 to pay tribute to Lee, then president of the ROC, using US$2.5 million donated by Lee's friends in Taiwan.
Lee is scheduled to travel to Ithaca, New York via Los Angeles June 24.
This will be the second time that Lee will have visited his alma mater. He visited in May 1995 when he made a lecture there during a landmark visit to the United States by any ROC head of state.

In June 1995, Beijing unilaterally suspended official cross-strait dialogue, known as the "Koo-Wang talks," which was initiated in Singapore in late April 1993, to show Beijing's anger with Lee's U.S. tour, which it considered as a move to promote Taiwan independence.

In addition to suspending the regular cross-strait dialogue, Beijing conducted several rounds of missile tests and military exercises in the Strait during the following months to try to intimidate Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TUVALU PRIME MINISTER IN TAIWAN FOR FIVE-DAY VISIT

TEXT.P: The prime minister and his wife from the Republic of China's south Pacific ally of Tuvalu arrived in Taipei Monday for a five-day official visit.
Prime Minister Faimalaga Luka is expected to meet with President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Chang Chun-hsiung for talks during his stay in Taiwan, officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said.

Luka is also scheduled to visit the Taiwan Tuna Fishing Association headquartered in the southern port city of Kaohsiung to gain a better understanding of the Taiwan tuna fishing industry, which maintains close links with Tuvalu's fishery industry.
In addition to visiting the fishing association, Luka is also scheduled to have a health check at National Taiwan University Hospital in Taipei, according to foreign ministry officials.
Tuvalu, a Southwest Pacific nation composed of nine islands with a population of around 10,000, established formal diplomatic relations with the Republic of China in 1979.
Taiwan fishing boats operating in Tuvalu's territorial waters is the major commercial activity between the two allies.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND DENIES DEVELOPMENT OF MEDIUM-RANGE BALLISTIC MISSILES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) categorically denied Monday that the military is developing medium-range ballistic missiles.
The MND made the denial in response to a newspaper report that the Republic of China military is secretly developing medium-range ballistic missiles under a program code-named Tiching.
"The media report is not true. The military has absolutely not made any plans or research into this," the MND said in a press release.

The ministry stressed that news reports concerning the development of new weaponry systems should be based on formal press releases issued by the MND's Office of Military Spokesman or explanations by identified MND officials.

The MND also expressed regret that many recent military news reports were sheer speculation. "As military news reports could affect national security, public morale and the ROC's international image, we hope that local media will refrain from giving misleading, speculative reports on military events or arms development plans," the MND news release said.

The mass-circulation United Daily News quoted unidentified military sources Monday that the ROC military is developing ballistic missiles with a range of 1,000-2,000 kilometer for defensive purposes in the face of mainland China's growing military threat. Mainland China has deployed more than 300 M-class guided missiles in Fujian province, which is opposite Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, June 18, or the 27th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1155: Frederick I "Barbarossa" is crowned Holy Roman Emperor by Pope Adrian IV.
1812: The US Congress approves a declaration of war on Great Britain over trade restrictions.
1815: British and Prussian forces under the command of the Duke of Wellington and Field Marshall Gerhard von Blucher finally defeat France's Napoleon Bonaparte in a bloody battle at Waterloo, in Belgium. The total number of casualties on both sides is estimated to be 62,000.
1900: With the anti-foreign Boxer Rebellion already under way in China, the Empress Dowager Tzuhsi of the Ching court orders all foreigners executed.
1927: Chang Tso-lin, head of the separatist Fengtien Army in China's northeast (Manchuria), sets up a military government in Beijing and declares himself marshal.
1928: Amelia Earhart, a 30-year-old American aviator, becomes the first woman to fly across the Atlantic when the tri-engine plane "Friendship," in which she is a passenger, lands at Burny Port.
1940: Charles de Gaulle, founder of the Free French, makes a radio appeal from London urging his fellow countrymen to continue to resist the Germans.
1942: The United States formally begins its Manhattan Project, the manufacturing of the first atomic bomb.
1944: Changsha, capital of China's Hunan Province, falls to invading Japanese troops who violate the Geneva Protocol by using poison gas in battle.
1944: US Vice President Henry Wallace visits China.
1950: Chen Yi, former top administrator of Taiwan Province, is executed for sedition.
1953: South Korea releases 26,000 North Korean prisoners of war.
1960: US President Dwight D. Eisenhower arrives in Taipei for a state visit.
1965: Typhoon Dinah hits eastern Taiwan, killing more than 100 people and injuring over 200.
1965: Air Vice Marshal Nguyen Cao Ky vows to militarily defeat the Viet Cong after assuming office as premier of South Vietnam.
1973: A four-member delegation headed by Liu Kuo-tsai, vice president of the Legislative Yuan, leaves for Tokyo to attend the 14th council meeting of the Asian Parliamentarians Union.
1975: Prince Faisal Musaid is beheaded in Riyadh for the assassination of Saudi King Faisal on March 25.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives Dr. Robert M. Lumiamsky, president, and Dr. Gordon B. Turner, vice president, of the American Council of Learned Societies.
1979: US President Jimmy Carter and Soviet President Leonid Brezhnev sign the Strategic Arms Limitation Talks (SALT) documents in Vienna.
1980: General Jose Dolores Herrera, El Salvador's ambassador to the ROC, presents his government's Gold Medal of Great Achievements to General Kao Huei-yuan, defense minister, Admiral Soong Chang-chih, chief of the general staff, General Wang Sheng, director of the General Political Warfare Department, and General Wang Yung-shu, director of the National Security Bureau.
1981: The Executive Yuan appoints Dr. Yen Chen-hsing, president of National Taiwan University, as chairman of the Atomic Energy Council.
1982: Republic of China Premier Sun Yun-suan instructs government agencies to study the feasibility of setting up a free trade zone in Taiwan.
1986: Chang Tung-sheng, a noted ROC wrestler known as the "Master of Wrestling," dies of cancer at the age of 76.
1987: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo appoints Admiral Soong Chang-chih (Sung Chang-chih) as the new ambassador to Panama.
1993: Japanese Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa loses a crucial no-confidence vote and dissolves parliament to trigger snap elections in July.
1997: Pol Pot, the fugitive Cambodian Khmer Rouge leader, surrenders to his former comrades.
1999: Florencio Marin, Belize minister of the sugar industry and local government and Latin American affairs, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
2000: The opposition Kuomintang passes a party reform package that includes provisions for the popular election of its party chairman following a nationwide party membership verification and registration process.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is really a bad situation when a man simply eats his meals without applying his mind to anything at all during the whole day. Are there no such things as gambling and games of skill? To do even one of those things is better than to do nothing at all."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK INDEX CLOSES LOWER

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (Taiex) took a tumble Monday, with the benchmark weighted price index losing 88.11 points from last week's finish to close at 5,070.52.

Market turnover shrank to NT$31.35 billion (US$922.06 million) as many market players stayed on the sidelines over market uncertainty. A total of 97.93 million shares changed hands during the four-and-half-hour trading session.

The market opened weak as United Microelectronics Corp., one of Taiwan's leading microchip makers, issued a pessimistic forecast of its second- and third-quarter profits. Selling pressure was particularly heavy in the semiconductor sector.
The Taiex weighted price index opened at 5,132.52 points and fluctuated between 5,052.25 and 5,132.6 during the bearish trading session.

All of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with electronics shares registering the largest loss of 2.1 percent; followed by financial issues at 1.3 percent, textile issues at 1.2 percent, paper and cement issues both at 0.9 percent, foodstuff stocks at 0.7 percent, plastics issues at 0.6 percent, and construction stocks at 0.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 408 to 104, with 75 others remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: INT'L SEMICONDUCTOR ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT CONFAB OPENS IN TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Kenting, southern Taiwan, June 18 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Eighth International Semiconductor Environment, Safety and Health Conference opened Monday at the Howard Resort in the southernmost scenic city of Kenting with specialists from five major semiconductor industrial associations around the world participating.

Topics to be discussed during the three-day workshop include PFC measurement and control, chemical management, reclaiming and recycling, safety and health management, environmental management, risk management, fire protection, and waste management and minimization, said officials from the Taiwan Semiconductor Industrial Association (TSIA) which is hosting the conference.

Specialists from the world's top five semiconductor industrial associations, named ESIA, JEITA, KSIA, SIA and the host TSIA, will share their research papers and exchange views on the industry during the conference, TSIA officials said.

It is the first time that the International Semiconductor Environment, Safety and Health Conference has been held in Taiwan. The previous ones were sponsored alternately by related associations in Europe, the United States, Japan and Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market closed lower Monday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for June moved down 61 points to close at 5,088, with 3,352 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for July lost 65 points to finish at 5,092, with 2,222 contract transactions, while September futures slid 61 points to close at 5,089, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 5,149 for June, 5,157 for July, 5,150 for September, 5,206 for December, and 5,205 for next March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, both closed lower from last week's levels.

June TE futures moved down 4.33 points to close at 258, with 846 contracts transacted, while July TE futures lost 4.4 points to finish at 258.5, with 441 contracts traded. And September TE futures dropped 4.3 points to close at 257.95, with one contract recorded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

June TF futures moved down 8 points to finish at 672, with 240 contracts changing hands, while July TF futures fell 7 points to close at 673, with 73 contracts transacted. Meanwhile, September TF futures also declined 8 points to close at 664.6, with two contracts changing hands.
In contrast, December TF futures edged up 2.2 points to close at 670.2, with 13 contracts traded. And TF futures for next March fell 20 points to finish at 670, with 10 contracts transacted.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATORS NOT SURPRISED BY SEVERANCE OF ROC-MACEDONIA TIES

TEXT.P: Legislators across the party spectrum said Monday that they are not surprised by the severing of diplomatic ties between the Republic of China and Macedonia as the basis for both nations to establish ties was "shaky" from the start.

Legislator Trong Chai of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said that he was not optimistic about the diplomatic relations between the ROC and Macedonia since the two established ties in January 1999, especially because Macedonia has been torn by civil war.

The Balkan nation will naturally tilt toward mainland China diplomatically because it needs its support in the United Nations for sending peacekeeping forces to the nation to help it deal with ethnic Albanian rebels, Chai said.

He also said that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs spends around NT$13.7 billion (US$400.58 million), or half of its budget, to assist more than 20 allies, and urged the government to rethink its diplomatic policy, especially given mainland China's growing economic might.

His colleague Lin Feng-hsi of the DPP said that though the ROC made last-ditch efforts to salvage its diplomatic relations with Macedonia, the severance of ties was inevitable, adding that the public should try to understand the situation.

Legislators from the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), People First Party (PFP), and New Party urged the government not to engage in "money diplomacy" in a bid to increase the "number of the allies," which currently stands at 28 after severing ties with Macedonia.

Legislator Lee Sen-zong of the KMT said that it is unfortunate to sever ties with Macedonia and expressed the hope that the ruling DPP government would continue to make efforts to cement ties with allies.

Another KMT legislator, Lee Shang-ren, said it is right for the foreign ministry to take the preemptive move by announcing the severance of diplomatic ties after media reports said that Macedonian Foreign Minister Ilinka Mitreva had arrived in mainland China Monday for talks with mainland officials.
He said that the ROC will at least maintain its national dignity, adding that if Taiwan had not done so, it would lose esteem in the eyes of other nations.

He said that the government should not let other countries make irrational requests for assistance, and that the foreign ministry should also do what it can to have the aid money given to Macedonia returned.

Legislator Chou Hsi-wei of the PFP said that it was predictable that the two countries would sever ties sooner or later. He also said that it is right for the foreign ministry to take the initiative to announce the breaking up of ties.
Chou said that the focus of diplomatic works should be exchanges between nations, and "the increase in the number of allies" should not be the focus of the efforts.

Legislator Levi C. Ying of the New Party said that it is time to review the necessity to keep the number of diplomatic allies for the sake of "vanity," especially at a time when Taiwan is not as rich as it used to be.

DOC.HEADLINE: N.T. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar was down NT$0.009 against the U.S. dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Monday, closing at 34.379.
The local currency opened Monday at 34.299 and was traded between 34.299 and 34.435.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$486.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT SPORTS EXCHANGES FREQUENT BUT CONFINED BY POLITICS
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 18 (CNA) (By David Hsu) (By Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Taipei, June 18 (CNA): Athletes from both sides of the Taiwan Strait have put aside political differences and are holding a long-distance race on Taiwan and China that has been put off since 1997.
Taiwan runners headed to the city of Shenzhen in mainland China Monday to continue the 10-leg run which is highlighting Beijing's bid to host the 2008 Olympic Games.

Initiated by Chi Cheng, bronze medal winner in the 80-meter low hurdles in the 1968 Mexico Olympics and currently board chairman of the Hope Culture and Education Foundation, the long-distance run is considered a gesture of brotherhood aimed at creating a more friendly atmosphere for cross-strait exchanges.

Since the Olympic committees in Taipei and Beijing first reached an agreement in 1989 to promote exchanges under the framework of the International Olympic Committee, athletes, coaches, referees and sports officials from Taiwan have made 60,000 visits to mainland China. However, visits to Taiwan by their mainland counterparts were less than 3,000 in 12 years.
Frequent exchanges have helped promote understanding and cooperation between sports officials and athletes, but the atmosphere of cooperation is still overshadowed by ideological conflicts.

In many international events, political confrontation has been obvious as Taiwan's sports officials and athletes were not granted the same privileges as other participants, and Taiwan has been forced to compete under the name Chinese-Taipei -- a name satisfactory to Beijing.

Cross-strait tensions have interrupted what should have been non-political sports exchanges in the past. The long-distance run on both sides of the Strait, for example, was first held in 1992 and participant and organizers hoped the run could be held every year. The second run was held in 1993, but no subsequent events were held until 1997. The third run was held that year, but political disagreements again spilled over into the exchanges and the run was suspended until this year.

After 1997, no event was planned because cross-strait relations had turned sour with former President Lee Teng-hui pronouncing his "state-to-state" model for China-Taiwan relations. Beijing finally agreed to holding the recent race after the name of the run was proposed as "Beijing Olympics, Chinese pride."

Sports officials and coaches have been willing to put aside political considerations and are well aware of the prowess of China's athletes. Taiwan coaches in weightlifting, basketball and swimming have taken their athletes to mainland China for training. Some athletes in gymnastics have even paid their own way to continue training on the mainland.
As baseball is becoming more popular in mainland China, some professional baseballers in Taiwan are looking for opportunities on the other side of the Strait.

A group of mainland sports officials visited Taipei in early May to attend the fourth cross-strait sports exchange symposium. A memorandum of agreement was signed and both sides are looking forward to improving the political atmosphere.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. URGED TO PLAY MORE ACTIVE ROLE IN CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday it is a common hope of the 23 million people of Taiwan that the United States will play a more active role in relations across the Taiwan Strait.
"We hope that the United States will play the role of a stabilizer, balancer, peace messenger and mediator in cross-strait relations," Chen said.

The Republic of China president made the remarks while meeting with John L. Holden, president of the National Committee on U.S.-China Relations, a non-profit private American organization dedicated to promoting U.S. exchanges with Taiwan, mainland China and Hong Kong. Holden is currently on a visit to Taipei.

Chen, who took office in the ROC's first-ever democratic transfer of power between different political parties in May 2000, said a democratic Taiwan would certainly contribute to Taiwan Strait peace and Asia-Pacific stability.
Likewise, Chen said, a democratic mainland China would also be conducive to peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait and the entire Asia-Pacific region.
While Taiwan has become an open, pluralistic, democratic society, Chen said, mainland China still has a long way to go to democratization.

Noting that democracy means respecting the people's choice, Chen said the people of Taiwan have every legitimate right to decide whether to accept the Beijing-proposed "one country, two systems" unification scheme.

Chen told his guest that both incumbent U.S. President George W. Bush and his predecessor, Bill Clinton, have said Taiwan's future and any change to its status quo must respect the free choice of the people of Taiwan. "This is a manifestation of democracy," he noted.

Therefore, he continued, it is not up to mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, but rather up to the people of Taiwan, to decide whether the "one country, two systems" would be an acceptable unification scheme.

Chen said he has on numerous occasions extended olive branches to mainland China since his inauguration more than a year ago. "We absolutely do not want to see cross-strait relations become a zero-sum game," he stressed.

In his view, he said, one of the most important obstacles to a resumption of cross-strait dialogue lies in a lack of mutual trust. "Without dialogue, the two sides lack mutual understanding and even have many mutual misunderstandings," he went on.

With a view to minimizing misunderstandings and forging rapprochement, Chen said, the two sides should sit down to talk on every topic of mutual concern and interest. "Only by so doing can we break the lingering cross-strait political limbo," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS, TRAVEL INDUSTRY QUESTION PREMIER'S PLEDGE ON TOURISM

TEXT.P: A group of legislators, scholars and tourism industry representatives at a Monday seminar questioned the likelihood of opening up Taiwan to mainland Chinese tourists by July as Premier Chang Chun-hsiung pledged last year.

Opposition Kuomintang legislator Ting Shou-chung noted that the government has yet to complete any preparations for receiving mainland tourists and has so far failed to set up related measures such as visa regulations.

Instead, he charged, the government is using the possibility of opening up tourism to mainland China as a bargaining chip, which he said might not be enough incentive for mainland China to allow its people to visit.
Opposition New Party legislator Lai Shyh-bao urged both sides of the Taiwan Strait to "give up their ideologies" and truly consider the benefits of opening up exchanges between the two peoples.

Wang Chih-han, vice chairman of the Chinese Cross-Strait Travel Association, which was set up in 1999 by over 100 local travel agencies to promote bilateral private-sector exchanges, said that many of the related measures and details must be worked out through dialogue.
He added that because he believes the two sides show no signs of resuming negotiations, Chang's pledge to open up Taiwan to mainland tourists is "certain" to fizzle.

He went on to say that although would-be mainland tourists are curious about such local scenic spots as Sun Moon Lake and Mount Ali, they still cannot compare in terms of vista to some of the more famous scenic areas in mainland China. He warned that if the tourists are disappointed by what they see in Taiwan and go home to tell about it, the consequences will be "serious."
Therefore, he recommended that Taiwan should focus on presenting "sightseeing spots" such as modernized farms and the National Palace Museum instead.
Wang also noted that the cost of a seven- to 10-day visit in Taiwan would be around US$2,000, which is about US$1,000 more than mainland tourists are used to spending elsewhere in Southeast Asia.

Meanwhile, Shih Hsin University Department of Tourism Director Chen Szu-lun urged the domestic travel industry to plan for the long term because the island's current tourism resources can only attract mainland visitors in the short run.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNEMPLOYMENT EXPECTED TO HIT RECORD HIGH IN MAY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment rate is expected to hit a record high in May, despite government measures to increase the number of temporary contract workers in local government administrations.
Preliminary figures compiled by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) show that the jobless rate could break the 3.96 percent high posted in April.

A DGBAS official attributed the rise to seasonal reasons, such as the large number of new graduates entering the job market, coupled with declining export orders and a reduction in the growth of both exports and imports.

Although the government has worked out programs to stimulate domestic demand, the official said, most of the programs are not yet implemented and will not help reduce the number of people out of a job in May.
The unemployment figure is not expected to dip until the economy turns around, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT REAFFIRMS SUPPORT FOR FREE TRADE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that the Republic of China will continue to support free international trade and further boost bilateral commercial exchanges with countries around the world.
Chen made the remarks in a keynote speech delivered at the opening of the 46th World Congress of the International Council of Small Businesses (ICSB).

Chen said it is of great significance that the 46-year-old ICSB is holding its first world congress of the 21st century in Taiwan, where small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) form the backbone of the economy.
Noting that SMEs in both advanced and developing countries have grown rapidly since the 1980s, Chen said SMEs have become an important integral part of the global economy.

In the past few decades, Chen said, SMEs have contributed greatly to tax revenue increases, job openings, technological innovation and production value. "All these are common features of economic development in the United States, Germany, Italy and Taiwan in recent decades," he observed.
Chen went on to point out that the 1997-98 Asian financial crisis allowed the world to better understand the advantages of SME-driven economies.

In comparison with other Asian countries, Chen said, Taiwan emerged relatively unscathed from the crisis. "As adaptability, flexibility and competitiveness are critical to the survival of SMEs, the SME-driven Taiwan economy has been more adaptable to the changing climate and more capable of coping with adversity," he noted.
With the arrival of the knowledge-based economy, Chen said, innovation is crucial not only to industry and corporations but also to individuals.

"To a certain extent, innovation and learning have become an equivalent to corporate growth," Chen said, adding that while the new trend has posed great challenges to SMEs, it has also offered them opportunities to "march toward yet another peak."

As SMEs will continue to play a pivotal role in future economic development, Chen said the ROC government has updated its regulations to assist SMEs in upgrading their production and management, and has joined forces with local governments to improve services to SMEs.
Stressing that market opening is essential to SME development, Chen said the ROC will never waver in its support for free trade and market liberalization.

In addition, he said, the ROC has been endeavoring to offer SMEs easier access to major technological research and development programs to facilitate their innovation and upgrading of competitiveness.

Chen said his administration has also made "investment, the economy and Taiwan's well-being" its three top policy goals and is determined to do its utmost to attract investment to create more jobs and revitalize the sluggish economy.

Chen further encouraged the 500-plus SME executives, policymakers and scholars from 50-odd countries around the world to present their valuable opinions on future SME challenges and development strategies during the four-day ICSB congress.

DOC.HEADLINE: END OF TAIPEI-SKOPJE TIES WILL NOT AFFECT ROC-EUROPE TIES: MOFA

TEXT.P: The suspension of diplomatic relations between the Republic of China and Macedonia will not affect the ROC's efforts to improve relations with European countries, an official from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Monday.
The remark followed an earlier MOFA announcement that the ROC had suspended diplomatic relations with Macedonia, although Skopje and Beijing had still not yet normalized relations.

According to the MOFA official, all the nations of Europe are well aware that the ROC has strived to help Macedonia, so the cutting of ties will not affect the ROC's efforts to improve its relations elsewhere in Europe.

Taipei established diplomatic relations with Skopje Jan. 27, 1999, making Macedonia not only the ROC's second diplomatic ally in the European region but also a bridgehead for the ROC to expand its diplomatic and economic relations with the rest of Europe.

The official pointed out that relations between the ROC and European nations have improved very much during the past few years and added that in addition to upgrading its relations with major West European nations, relations with East European nations have also improved.

He said that all the cooperation projects the ROC has implemented in Macedonia in the past two-and-a-half years have yielded some effects in East European countries, which he said indicates that the suspension of Taipei-Skopje relations was not because "we did not do well in Macedonia."

DOC.HEADLINE: SENEGAL PRESIDENT TO VISIT ROC

TEXT.P: Senegal President Abdoulaye Wade is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan June 30 for a five-day state visit during which he will call on Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian and visit various local infrastructure developments.

Wade and his wife will be accorded an official welcome with full military honors, as well as a state banquet. The two presidents will exchange views on issues regarding bilateral relations, future cooperation and the international situation, followed by the signing of a joint communique.

Accompanied by his foreign minister, minister of equipment and transportation, minister of fisheries and minister of SMEs and trade, Wade will also visit the Taichung Experimental Farm, the Taipei World Trade Center and the Nankang Science Park.
Wade last visited Taiwan in October 1996 as an opposition leader. He was elected president in March.
The Republic of China and the Republic of Senegal resumed diplomatic relations in 1996 following a hiatus that began when the West African nation switched diplomatic recognition to Beijing in 1971.
Taiwan provides assistance to Senegal in agricultural skills training, road and irrigation infrastructure construction and industrial zone development.

DOC.HEADLINE: APEC REPRESENTATIVES TO ATTEND CONFERENCE IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Officials, scholars and industry representatives from 21 Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum members are slated to arrive in Taipei July 24 to take part in a four-day conference on bridging "the digital divide."

According to the Board of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the recommendation that Taiwan, under its official APEC name of Chinese Taipei, should host the conference, titled "Transforming the Digital Gap into Digital Opportunities," has already garnered favorable responses from the various APEC members.
The digital divide has been described as the imbalance between rich and poor countries in terms of their people's access to computer education and information technologies.
Mainland China, which is also a member of APEC, has agreed to appoint both official and civilian representatives to attend the conference, which will be organized by the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOTED FORENSIC SCIENTIST EXAMINES REMAINS OF MURDER VICTIMS

TEXT.P: Noted Chinese-American forensic scientist Dr. Henry Lee examined Monday the remains of a Taiwan couple who were murdered more than a decade ago.
Lee examined the bodies of Wu Ming-han and his wife at the Institute of Forensic Medicine under the Ministry of Justice with a view to helping solve a controversial criminal case.

Lee, who retired from the post of commissioner of the Public Safety Department of the U.S. Connecticut State Government last year, told a press conference after preliminary examinations that Wu's skull had more than 10 knife wounds.
Asked whether the wounds were left by the same knife or several different knives, Lee said he would need to conduct a further microscopic examination before arriving at a conclusion in that regard.
Lee also said he would need to examine the knife or knives allegedly used in the murder of the Wus to determine whether there was any correlation between the tool and the wounds on the bodies.

"Without the alleged murder weapon or weapons, I couldn't draw any conclusion simply by examining the remains of the murdered couple," Lee explained, adding that if necessary, he would be willing to assist in solving the riddle surrounding the couple's tragic deaths.
Lee arrived in Taipei Sunday at the invitation of the Institute of Forensic Medicine, which had been asked by the Taiwan High Court to examine the remains.

Three men were convicted of murdering the Wus and were given death penalties by the Supreme Court. On the trio's special petition, the Supreme Court ordered the Taiwan High Court to re-try the case last May upon the revelation that the police may have used torture to elicit confessions, while the case itself is widely regarded to have been built on the flimsiest of circumstantial evidence.
Meanwhile, military sources said Monday that the military has uncovered a kitchen knife which was allegedly used in the murder of the couple at their home in Hsichi, Taipei County.

During his stay in Taipei, Lee will meet with officials of the Ministry of Justice and the National Police Administration, as well as members of the Taiwan Forensic Medicine Society, to discuss improvements in Taiwan's forensic examination system.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINATRUST BANK RANKED BEST IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Chinatrust Bank was ranked as the best Taiwan bank in 2000 for a second consecutive year in a survey released Monday by a local academic association.

Chiao Tung Bank came second in the survey by the non-profit Chung Hwa Money and Banking Association, followed by China Development Industrial Bank, United World Chinese Commercial Bank and the International Commercial Bank of China.

The survey ranked 36 banks whose shares are either traded on the securities exchange or on the over-the-counter market, based on their financial health, credit standing, management ability, profitability, scale and growth.
The association converged their performances in the five categories into a standard score that was then used as a basis for the rankings.
In the first quarter of this year, the survey said, Chiao Tung Bank outperformed the Chinatrust Bank to top the list.

Meanwhile, the Medium Business Bank of Kaohsiung District, Chung Shing Bank, Bank of Overseas Chinese, Taitung Business Bank, Tainan Business Bank, Taichung Business Bank and Pan Asia Bank were ranked as the poorest-performing seven banks in 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF CHAIRMAN URGES TAIPEI, BEIJING TO FOCUS ON SUBSTANTIAL ISSUES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China said Monday that the two sides should communicate more instead of maintaining the current stalemate, and talk more about substantial issues than prerequisites to resuming stalled dialogue.

Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu said at an SEF board of trustees meeting that leaders in both Taipei and Beijing must develop greater vision and more rational attitudes if a breakthrough is to be achieved.
The SEF is a semi-official organization that is empowered by the government to handle relations with mainland China in the absence of official ties.
Koo said that President Chen Shui-bian has already stressed numerous times the importance of resuming dialogue on the normalization of bilateral relations.

However, he lamented that not only have relations failed to improve, greater competition in the diplomatic arena and the ever-changing international situation have made them more complicated and worrisome than ever.

Just as mainland China was able to achieve formidable achievements in economic growth over the past 20 years because it set aside the "shackles of ideology" and made conscientious efforts to face the issues that came up, so can cross-strait relations improve in the same manner, Koo said.

Because that improvement cannot possibly be based on military intimidation or diplomatic embargoes, he continued, the two sides should focus on greater communication as well as substantial issues in order to gradually build up mutual trust.

He added that just as the rest of the world is pursuing peace and security and taking up negotiation in place of confrontation, Taipei and Beijing -- despite their differences -- are no different when it comes to a desire for peace and security.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA REVOKES 645 PERMITS FOR EMPLOYERS OF FOREIGN WORKERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) has revoked 645 employment permits for employers of foreign workers following a labor inspection conducted in the first five months of this year, according to statistics released Monday by the CLA.

The CLA began hiring foreign labor inspectors in November last year and of 23,693 foreign workers spot-checked during the January-May period, 2,065 cases were reported to the police for further investigation as to whether either the employers or the employees had violated labor regulations.

Of the reported cases, 1,112 were ascertained by the police as having violated labor regulations, 94 percent of which were in the household caregiver category, with cases in the manufacturing and construction category making up the remainder.
Around one-third of the violations found each month involved the assignment of foreign workers to jobs not specified in their labor agreements.
Of the 645 employers deprived of their permits to hire foreign workers, 606 were employers of household caregivers and 39 were bosses in the manufacturing and construction sectors.
The CLA also revoked 724 work permits for foreign workers during the January-May period, 630 of which were for household caregivers and 94 of which were for manufacturing and construction workers.
Meanwhile, the CLA also revoked the licenses of two labor brokerage companies, suspended the operations of six such companies, and issued fines against a further 245 labor brokerages.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN REAFFIRMS `MIDDLE-OF-THE-ROAD' POLICY
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 17 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Chairman Lien Chan of the Kuomintang (KMT), the Republic of China's largest opposition party, said here Sunday that his party will never deviate from its "middle-of-the-road" policy.
Lien, who arrived in New York from Paris that afternoon for a private visit, made the remarks at a dinner given in his honor by supporters in the local Chinese community.
Lien told about 1,000 Chinese community representatives that the 107-year-old KMT is "a broad-based party dedicated to developing Taiwan into a humane, secure and refined society."
"The KMT will continue its efforts to promote ethnic harmony in Taiwan and will unswervingly oppose any attempt to instigate or aggravate ethnic confrontation," Lien said.
He further stressed that the KMT will reach out to the grassroots people to win their hearts and minds with its devoted services and forward-looking policy proposals.
Lien, also a former ROC vice president, noted that many countries around the world have been troubled by religious, regional or ethnic conflicts due to misjudgments of the situation.
"Their erroneous judgments have also resulted in retrogression of their democratic developments," Lien said, adding that he would not want to see such a scenario in Taiwan.

The KMT ruled Taiwan for more than 50 years until it lost to the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the presidential election of March 2000, although it still controls a comfortable majority in the Legislative Yuan.
Lien criticized the current DPP government for what he said is its failure to respect the ROC constitutional system and normal party political principles.

"The minority DPP government's failure to respect constitutional provisions concerning Cabinet formation and operations has resulted in domestic political chaos and has hindered Taiwan's economic recovery," Lien lamented.
New York is the last leg of Lien's current three-country trip, which has already taken him to London and Paris.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA TRYING TO REVIVE TAIWAN'S AGRICULTURE VIA STRATEGIC ALLIANCE

TEXT.P: The local agricultural sector has been riding a tidal wave of strategic alliances within the sector since Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture Chairman Chen Hsi-huang advocated reviving Taiwan's agriculture through such alliances.

A COA official said that although such alliances were common in the earlier days of the Republic of China, most of the agricultural sector has neglected the essential knowledge needed to create strategic alliances.

The ideal stems, he went on, from the concept of the "post-industrialized society" advocated by sociologist Daniel Bell in the 1970s, who described how Western economically developed countries employed the service industry to boost the production industry.

According to Chi Schive, dean of Taiwan's Institute of Financial Research and Training, the post-industrialized society was based on "knowledge" and "creation value." He added that human society developed from agricultural society, to industrialized society, computerized society and to the current stage of "knowledge-based" society.
Agricultural society uses the land to produce small quantities of agricultural products, while knowledge-based society uses ideas and creative concepts to produce many products, said Schive.
Creation plays a very important role in the development process of the knowledge-based society, he added.

He pointed out that Taiwan is now transforming into a knowledge-based society and that the country's agricultural and manufacturing sectors have yielded to pressure resulting from entering into the "post-industrialized society."

As a result, the unemployment rate in both the agricultural and manufacturing sectors have soared to record highs, he went on, adding that the COA is trying to help the farming sector transfer to new industry so as to "avoid being eliminated."
He expressed regret that the farming industry has generally failed to capture the "real meaning" of the agricultural strategic alliance.

Lee Chien-chuan, deputy chairman of the COA, said that the local farming sector does not understand the true meaning of the agricultural strategic alliance, believing instead that agricultural strategic alliances connect local farming associations.
He described the real meaning of an agricultural alliance as connecting farmers with consumers through the marketing system, using standardized packaging, administration and classification.
Lee added that out-dated thinking in the agriculture sector will hinder the development of such an alliance.

Noting that the mission of the COA is to build an agricultural image for Taiwan but not to build a localized ideology for local farming products, Lee said that the government should implement a complete set of regulations to govern the sanitation, quality and pesticide control of the nation's farm products.
Meanwhile, Schive called on the government agencies concerned to take measures to help farmers move into other industries to cope with the impact of Taiwan's imminent World Trade Organization entry.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN ASKS FOR EXTRAORDINARY SESSION OF LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Executive Yuan formally asked President Chen Shui-bian Monday to request the Legislative Yuan to convene an extraordinary session.

The request, delivered to the Presidential Office, capped two weeks of political wrangling between the ruling and opposition parties over whether a special session is necessary and which bills should be put on its agenda.

Su Tzen-ping, director-general of the Government Information Office, said the request was submitted to the president after Premier Chang Chun-hsiung spoke to Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng to put the final touches to an understanding that six finance-related bills will be debated during the special session.

The Executive Yuan had originally listed the passage of 18 bills as badly needed in order to streamline the country's financial market, but negotiations between the political parties at the legislature saw the list whittled down to six bills.

The extraordinary session, slated to take place from June 27-28, will be preceded by a social gathering of lawmakers on June 26, when they are supposed to exchange views on how to proceed with the session debates.

Under the Constitution, the country's lawmakers gather for two regular sessions each year, one which lasts from February to May and the other from September to December. Extraordinary sessions might be held at the request of the president.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA TO HELP FARMERS ENTER SERVICE INDUSTRY
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan County, southern Taiwan, June 18 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) plans to earmark an annual budget of NT$900 million to assist 10,000 farmers each year to transfer to the service industry.
The plan has been drawn up in a bid to cope with the impact on domestic agriculture of Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO), according to an agriculture official.

Chen Chien-pin of the Farmers Service Department under the COA, said the council will first pass a "one agricultural-and-fishery-based recreation park per township" plan for 30-40 townships within the year to integrate agricultural and fishery industries, recreational facilities, cultural activities and scenic spots in specially constructed parks.

Besides coping with the impact of Taiwan's WTO entry on domestic agriculture, the plan is also designed to help farmers create a "second channel" of income, Chen added. Taiwan's farmers are expected to be particularly hard-hit when WTO membership forces the government to reduce tariffs and open its market to foreign agricultural products.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Tuesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The ROC cuts diplomatic ties with Macedonia and cancels all cooperative and aid programs.
The China Times:
President Chen dismisses political hype of ethnic issues as 'immoral.'
The United Daily News:
The ROC breaks off diplomatic ties with Macedonia over the Balkan state's decision to resume relationship with Beijing.
The Liberty Times:
The ROC terminates ties with Macedonia and cuts all aid programs to the Balkan state.
The China Post:
Taiwan cuts ties with Macedonia.
The Taiwan News:
Taiwan severs relations with Macedonia.
The Taipei Times:
Taiwan severs ties with Skopje.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FARMERS SHOULD PREPARE FOR NOVEMBER WTO ENTRY: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung asked the Council of Agriculture to make all necessary preparations in the run-up to the accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO) as Taiwan is very likely to join the world trade regulatory body this November.
The premier made the remarks while on an inspection tour of the council Tuesday, adding that WTO entry will have a significant impact on farmers in Taiwan.
He said the council will have to work closely with the farmers and keep in close communication with them so that both could face the challenges ahead together.
The premier also said the impact on Taiwan of agricultural products smuggling will be as great as the smuggling of guns and drugs, and that the council must find a way to deal with the problem.

In addition, he said that as this is the rainy season, the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the council should take measures to guard against possible mudslides, especially in areas affected by the September 1999 earthquake in central Taiwan that killed over 2,000 people.

The premier also touched on the reforms of farmers associations, adding that he hopes related regulations of financial rehabilitation funds can be cleared in an extraordinary meeting of the Legislative Yuan.

The establishment and the management of the fund will help write off the mounting bad loans in Taiwan's financial institutions, especially in the grassroots institutions, such as the farmers associations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REQUESTS EXTRAORDINARY LEGISLATIVE SESSION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's formal request for the Legislative Yuan to convene an extraordinary session to discuss pressing financial bills was delivered and received Tuesday.

At the urging of the Executive Yuan, Chen asked the legislature to reconvene and debate six bills during the special session, which Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said might be held prior to June 27, depending on the outcome of a meeting slated for Wednesday between the legislative caucuses of the various parties.

The Executive Yuan had originally listed the passage of 18 bills as necessary measures to streamline the country's financial market, but negotiations between the party caucuses saw the list whittled down to six.

Under the Constitution, the country's lawmakers gather for two regular sessions each year, one lasting from February to May and the other from September to December. Extraordinary sessions may be held at the request of the president, or after a vote by more than 25 percent of the legislators.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL PLASTIC TYCOON URGES TAIWAN TO ACCEPT `ONE CHINA' PRINCIPLE

TEXT.P: Formosa Plastics Group Chairman Wang Yung-ching said Tuesday that Taiwan should accept mainland China's "one China" principle out of consideration for its mutual benefits at this critical moment of development for the entire Chinese race.

One of Taiwan's wealthiest and most influential entrepreneurs, Wang said at a seminar on biotechnology and health care that there is no hatred between Taiwan and mainland China, and that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should treat each other with parity as both come from the same roots.

Wang warned that with the economic gloom and rising unemployment facing Taiwan today in part due to the mass migration of local manufacturers to the more production-friendly mainland China, the future for Taiwan lies in biotechnology -- but only if the system is sound and the political environmental is stable.

He said that the current social disorder and political problems are even worse than the corruption of the Kuomintang era 40 years ago, when Taiwan began receiving aid from the United States that helped develop a local industrial base.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 30.54 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground Tuesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 30.54 points to close at 5,039.98.
Market turnover amounted to NT$32.34 billion (US$940.7 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT POLL SHOWS SUPPORT FOR ADDING 'TAIWAN' TO PASSPORTS

TEXT.P: The majority of Republic of China citizens support the proposal to add the word "Taiwan" to ROC passports to distinguish them from the PRC's, according to the results of an opinion poll released Tuesday by a government agency.

The Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission publicized the results of the June 5-6 survey after President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that the proposal would certainly be implemented because it has received majority popular support.

The commission's survey of 1,068 randomly selected adult residents found that 52.8 percent of the respondents were either "very supportive" or "supportive" of the proposal to add "Taiwan" at the end of the ROC's English national title printed on the cover of the passport to avoid confusion with mainland China's national tile, "People's Republic of China."
In contrast, 45.7 percent gave a thumbs-down to the proposal, with 22.4 percent voicing strong opposition.
Analyzing the survey findings, commission officials said the president's decision to go ahead with the proposed addition of the word "Taiwan" to the ROC passport is not unfounded.
Meanwhile, 60 percent of the respondents to a similar poll conducted by the mass-circulation United Daily News earlier this month also supported the proposal.
A recent telephone survey by TVBS cable television company also found that 56 percent of those interviewed gave a thumbs-up to the proposal.
The legislative caucus of the pro-unification opposition New Party, however, voiced strong opposition to the proposal, claiming that the move was a trick to signify pro-independence sentiments.

Levi C. Ying, the New Party legislative whip, told a news conference that if the Cabinet and the Presidential Office insist on putting the proposal into effect, the New Party would take every possible measure to block its implementation.

"The measures could include demanding the minister of foreign affairs to deliver a report to the Legislative Yuan, boycotting the passage of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' budget plan and seeking a constitutional interpretation by the Council of Grand Justices," Ying explained.

Other New Party legislators, including Elmer Fung and Cheng Lung-shui, echoed Ying's views at the news conference, alleging that the proposed addition of "Taiwan" to the ROC's English national title would be tantamount to changing the country' formal designation and in stark violation of the ROC Constitution.
They urged the president to refrain from triggering a new round of debate on the sensitive "independence or unification" issue at this time of domestic economic hardship.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT RECEIVES NICARAGUAN PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Tuesday reaffirmed the long-standing relations between the Republic of China and Nicaragua when he received Enrique Bolanos Geyer, a candidate from the ruling party for the November presidential election in the Central American nation.
President Chen said he was happy to meet with Bolanos again. This is the third time that Bolanos has visited the ROC. His previous two visits came in 1998 and 2000.

The president noted that the two nations have always maintained close and solid relations, adding that Nicaraguan President Arnoldo Aleman visited the ROC for Chen's inaugural ceremony in May 2000, and that Chen had led a delegation to visit Nicaragua in August 2000.
The president also expressed his appreciation for Nicaragua's staunch support for the ROC in the international community.

Chen said that Nicaragua will hold its presidential election on November 4, and he hoped Bolanos, who will represent the Nicaraguan ruling party, the Liberal Constitutional Party, would win. Chen lauded Bolanos' wisdom and rich experience in politics.
Chen also told Bolanos that opinion polls can only be relied on for reference and that the outcome of the vote is impossible to predict.
Chen cited his own experience as an example to say that during the presidential election last year, public polls only put him in second or third place among the three major candidates.
Bolanos, a former Nicaraguan vice president, arrived in Taiwan Monday. He will leave Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE MODERATE QUAKES RATTLE TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Three moderate earthquakes struck southeastern Taiwan Tuesday within the span of half an hour, seismologists at the Central Weather Bureau said, but there were no immediate reports of injuries.
A section of the Southern Cross-Island Highway was blocked by falling debris. The tremors measured 5.2, 4.4 and 5.3 on the Richter scale, respectively.
The first temblor struck at 1:16 p.m. with its epicenter 5.5 kilometers east of Litao Village in Taitung County, at a depth of only 3 kilometers.
The second earthquake followed at 1:34 p.m., 6.5 kilometers northeast of Litao and 6.6 kilometers deep.
The third came at 1:43 p.m., located 8.8 kilometers northeast of the village. It was also 3 kilometers in depth.
The earthquakes struck only days after a series of strong quakes hit northeastern Taiwan last week. A temblor registering 6.2 on the Richter scale rocked Ilan County last Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL SHOWS PEOPLE SATISFIED WITH PRESIDENT'S DIPLOMATIC PERFORMANCE

TEXT.P: The majority of people in Taiwan are satisfied with President Chen Shui-bian's performance during his recent five-country diplomatic visit to Latin America, according to the results of a poll released Tuesday by a government agency.

The survey, conducted by the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission from June 5-6, also found that nearly 60 percent of the respondents support Chen's proposal to set up a new economic advisory committee under the Presidential Office to help address Taiwan's current economic woes.

According to the commission's telephone survey of 1,068 adult residents, 54.5 percent of those interviewed were generally content with Chen's performance during his May 21-June 5 diplomatic journey which took him to El Salvador, Guatemala, Panama, Paraguay and Honduras. Only 15.6 percent said they were dissatisfied with Chen's performance during the tour.

Meanwhile, 62.8 percent said they thought that the president's overseas trip would either be "very helpful" or "helpful" to the Republic of China's foreign relations, while 20.7 percent said they thought otherwise.

During Chen's Latin America trip, Chen outlined a new "five noes" policy on handling relations with mainland China, including the importance of the recent U.S. approval of a robust arms sale package to Taiwan. He also said that his historic transit stops in New York and Houston on his way to and from Latin America were not aimed at provoking Beijing; Taiwan would never be a pawn in any country's chess games; and relations across the Taiwan Strait are not a zero-sum game.
However, the latest government poll found that only 32 percent said they were aware of Chen' new "five noes" policy, while 67.8 percent said they had no knowledge about it.
Still, 55.7 percent said they agreed with Chen's "five noes" policy, while 12.2 percent gave a thumbs-down to the policy.

During Chen's two-night transit stop in New York, he urged U.S. banks and financial service groups to forge strategic alliances with their Taiwan counterparts for investment in mainland China and other parts of the world.
The poll found that 55.6 percent supported this proposal, but 14.9 percent disapproved of the idea.
Asked about their opinions on Chen's plan to form a cross-party economic advisory committee, 59.8 percent said they support the proposal, while 17.1 percent were against the plan.
As for the new advisory board's possible effect, 51.6 percent said they thought that the new body would help resolve Taiwan's present economic plight, but 17.9 percent said they thought otherwise.

The same survey further found that 52.8 percent of the respondents were either "very supportive" or "supportive" of the proposal to add "Taiwan" at the end of the ROC's English national title printed on the cover of the passport to avoid confusion with mainland China's national tile, "People's Republic of China."
In contrast, 45.7 percent gave a thumbs-down to the proposal, with 22.4 percent voicing strong opposition.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, June 19, or the 28th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1566: King James I of England and VI of Scotland is born in the Scottish capital of Edinburgh. The son of Mary Queen of Scots, he succeeded Elizabeth I as the first Stuart king of England. His belief in the divine rights of kings and his attempts to keep the peace with Spain led to the English Civil War.
1623: Blaise Pascal, French philosopher and mathematician, is born. Among his achievements are the invention of an adding machine and the development of the modern theory of probability.
1885: The Statue of Liberty arrives in New York as a gift from France.
1924: The "Red Army" of the Chinese communists takes Lungyen and other towns in an attempt to establish a military base in western Fukien province in southern China.
1935: The British government overrides the Treaty of Versailles signed at the Paris Peace Conference in 1919 by agreeing to allow Germany a massive increase in its naval strength.
1944: The Japanese fleet attacks US ships protecting a landing at Saipan, resulting in considerable air and sea losses for Japan.
1953: Julius Rosenberg, 35, and his wife Ethel, 37, having been convicted by the United States of passing atom bomb secrets to the Russians, are sent to the electric chair at Sing Sing prison.
1956: American industrialist Thomas John Watson dies of a heart attack in New York at the age of 82. He became president of the company that later became International Business Machines Corporation (IBM) in 1924. Under Watson's leadership, it became one of the world's most successful corporations.
1960: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek and US President Dwight D. Eisenhower issue a joint communique pledging that their governments will "continue to stand solidly behind the Sino-US Mutual Defense Treaty in meeting the challenge posed by the Chinese communists in this area."
1960: Prior to US President Dwight D. Eisenhower's departure from the ROC, mainland China attacks Kinmen with 88,978 shells. Ordered to retaliate, ROC artillery units destroy eight coastal guns, seven fortifications, and four ammunition depots on the mainland.
1961: An 1899 agreement by which Britain is responsible for overseeing Kuwaiti foreign policy is terminated, making Kuwait a fully independent nation.
1964: Chiang Meng-lin, chairman of the ROC Joint Commission for Rural Reconstruction, dies of liver cancer in Taipei at the age of 79.
1974: Korean National Assembly Speaker Chung Il Kwon and a party of 15 arrive in Taipei for a four-day visit at the invitation of Premier Chiang Ching-kuo.
1974: The Chinese national women's basketball team leaves for Seoul to participate in the 5th Asian women's championship tournament.
1975: The Republic of China and Saudi Arabia sign an agreement to strengthen economic and technical cooperation.
1975: The Chinese Pacific Economic and Cultural Center and the Philippines Far East Trade Promotion Center sign an agreement to exchange offices to promote bilateral trade, tourism and other relations.
1976: The US Manufacturers' Hanover Asia Consortium loans US$80 million to the China Steel Corporation.
1983: Li Xiannian becomes mainland China's first president since 1969.
1989: The Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Task Force of the ROC announces the government's plan to simplify procedures for the relocation of Hong Kong and Macau citizens in Taiwan and to provide assistance for their emigration to a third country.
1992: The ROC resumes diplomatic relations with Niger.
1992: The ROC Legislative Yuan approves the Law on Foreign Futures Contracts, to take effect in January 1993.
1994: Wu Lihung, Hu Zehan and Yu Aiquin, who were found guilty and sentenced to death by a court in mainland China's Hangchow for killing 24 tourists from Taiwan at Qiantaohu in Chekiang province, are executed by firing squad.
1997: William Hague is chosen as the youngest-ever leader of Britain's Conservative Party.
1999: Prince Edward of Britain marries Sophie Rhys-Jones, a public relations executive, in a ceremony at Windsor Castle.
2000: Fifty-eight mainland Chinese were found suffocated in a truck container at an English port. They died during the trip from Belgium to Britain.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 30.54 points to close at 5,039.98.
The bourse opened at 5,073.35 and fluctuated between 5,089.57 and 5,030.51 during trading.

A total of 1.09 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$32.34 billion (US$940.7 million), an increase from the previous trading session, which saw 979.31 million stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$31.35 billion (US$922.06 million).

Four of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with plastics and chemical stocks moving down the most at 1.4 percent, followed by electrical shares at 1.1 percent, construction stocks at 1.0 percent and cement issues at 0.3 percent.

The other major categories posted gains, with pulp and paper shares moving up the most at 1.7 percent, followed by foodstuffs and bank and insurance stocks, both at 1.2 percent, and textile issues at 0.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 297 to 189, with 104 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. ANALYST ADVOCATES REFUSING NORMAL TRADE RELATIONS FOR CHINA

TEXT.P: A renowned American expert on China Monday urged the U.S. Congress not to grant Communist China permanent normal trade relations. Steve Mosher, who was the first U.S. social scientist to study in rural mainland China, stressed that "one of the best ways for America to help Beijing prepare for war with the U.S. and Taiwan and continue to wage war against its own people, is to renew normal trade relations with China."

"Despite prompts from President George W. Bush to renew normal trade relations with China, the U.S. Congress must have the courage to do otherwise," said Mosher, president of the Population Research Institute, an organization dedicated to ending human rights abuses in mainland China.

Mosher pointed out that a prevalent misconception, promoted by those who rely heavily on Beijing and foreign investment in mainland China, is that economic prosperity accomplished through free trade will usher in a new age of democracy in mainland China.

"This paradigm may hold true in a democracy, but in China the exact opposite is happening. The sad fact is that under Beijing's one-party dictatorship, democratic freedoms have never and will never follow on the heels of free trade," he said.
Mosher also warned that "China is currently expanding the range of its autocratic reach both internally and abroad. Funding for China's hegemonic expansion comes from foreign trade.

"Without normal trade relations, Beijing's commitment to a unilateral military buildup, and to strengthening domestic campaigns which violate the basic human rights of the people of China, simply would not be possible," he said.
Mosher urged the U.S. Congress to oppose normal trade relations with Communist China, all Americans to boycott goods made in mainland China, and foreign investors to pull out of the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: N.T. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar was down NT$0.024 against the U.S. dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Tuesday, closing at 34.403.
The local currency opened Tuesday at 34.326 and was traded between 34.326 and 34.430.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$326.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURE MAY NEED NT$ 120 BILLION FOR RESTRUCTURING AFTER WTO ENTRY
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 19 (CNA) (By David Hsu) (By Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Taipei, June 19 (CNA): The Executive Yuan needs to set aside NT$120 billion in its budget planning for the next four years to restructure the agricultural sector after Taiwan enters the World Trade Organization (WTO), said Chen Hsi-huang, chairman of the Council of Agriculture.

As the agricultural sector may be one of the hardest hit sectors, the agricultural official said that the Cabinet is required to use its reserve fund to help farmers to endure the impact if membership in the world trading body is realized before the end of this year.
In the next three budget years, he suggested that NT$30 billion should be set aside each year as compensation to farmers whose operations have succumbed to lower-priced imports.

Premier Chang Chun-hsiung told the Council of Agriculture to prepare Taiwan's agricultural sector for the impact WTO membership will have on Taiwan. All member states of the WTO are required to liberalize their markets and to lift both tariff and non-tariff barriers. He said that Taiwan is likely to be admitted to the WTO this November.

Premier Chang declined make any promises regarding financial support, but emphasized that it was important for the government to keep open communication channels with the agricultural sector, and farmers personally, to that they would be clear on government policy.

Together with the Board of Foreign Trade and agricultural associations, the council has organized a series of symposiums for farmers to advise them of the government's measures to minimize the loss to the local agricultural sector.

An agricultural official estimates that the impact of the WTO may danger the livelihood of some 10,000 farmers. An urgent task is to provide vocational training to those in farming so that they may find employment in other sectors should they be forced out of their current profession.

The Council of Agriculture has set aside NT$900 million from its fiscal 2000 budget for job training programs for farmers. However, the restructuring program will not be easy, considering the high percentage of elderly in the agricultural sector.
A report by the Council of Agriculture shows that more than 30 percent of the operators of small farms are over 65, and senior citizens account for 14 percent of the overall agricultural population.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIAN AVIATION AUTHORITIES SUSPEND CHARTERED FLIGHTS TO BALI

TEXT.P: Mandarin Airlines will suspend its charter flights to Bali, Indonesia starting June 21 after negotiations over aviation rights between the Republic of China and Indonesia hit a snag, the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said Tuesday.
Mandarin Airlines had received approval in February for the chartered service between Kaohsiung, in southern Taiwan, and Bali, Indonesia.

But the CAA said that as talks with its Indonesian counterpart hit turbulence, flights were to have been stopped from July 1. However, Indonesia notified Mandarin Airlines on Monday that air routes were decided on a case-by-case basis and that Mandarin would have to cancel its service earlier than the original deadline.
Mandarin Airlines had been notified in May that starting from July, chartered plane service would no longer be approved.

The CAA said that Indonesia had agreed to allow Taiwan's China Airlines (CAL) and EVA Airways to fly the Taiwan-Bali route while with chartered flights by another two Taiwan airlines, -- Mandarin Airlines and UNI Airways Corp. On the other hand, two Indonesian airlines have cooperated with CAL and EVA by sharing their flights.
UNI Airways, however, said that their two flights every week have not been affected.

The CAA said that negotiations broke down mainly because its Indonesian counterpart wants to half the number of flights by Taiwan and scrap the current cooperation system and approve two Indonesian airlines with a smaller passenger capacity to fly the routes.
Negotiations between Mandarin and the Indonesian aviation authorities are expected to resume in August. Regular flights between the two countries remain unchanged.
Meanwhile, the sudden cancellation of Mandarin's chartered service to Bali has caused complaints by travel agents in Kaohsiung.

The travel agents said that they were given short notice that service would be canceled on June 21 and that this is not enough time to adequately reorganize tours to Bali. They also say that if the tours are called off, they stand to lose double the money they were paid by passengers for the trips due to compensation to them.

In a meeting between Kaohsiung travel agents and Mandarin Airlines representatives, Mandarin Airlines official Chen Hung-ta stressed that after being notified in May that its Kaohsiung-Bali flight would be suspended, it has made every effort to strike a deal with the Indonesian authorities. But Mandarin Airlines officials say that they were caught by surprise by the sudden change.

Chen said that the airlines is also a victim, and that canceling the route has cost the company money and made many customers unhappy. The airline will work on alternative flight options and will distribute a coupon worth NT$3,000 to other southeast Asian destinations for those affected by the cancellation.
