DOC.HEADLINE: FM HOPES DIPLOMACY CAN BE TOPIC FOR CROSS-STRAIT TALKS

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao said Tuesday that the Republic of China will not be daunted by mainland China's endless diplomatic offensive against it and hopes that diplomacy can be a topic for future bilateral talks.

Tien made the remarks during a tea party with a group of reporters covering diplomatic affairs. It was also the first time that Tien has met the press since the ROC announced the breakup of its diplomatic ties with Macedonia Monday.
The minister said the ROC took the initiative to sever diplomatic relations with Macedonia mainly to maintain its national dignity and sovereign status.
In the face of "various inevitables," Tien said, the ROC could not sit idly by to await "insults by other people."

Tien further said that even though mainland China has never hesitated to block the ROC's "breathing space" in the international community, the ROC would never be daunted by the mainland's diplomatic embargo.
"We'll face all challenges bravely," Tien said, adding that so long as opportunities present themselves, the ROC will never miss a chance to forge diplomatic ties with other countries.
Nevertheless, Tien said he still hopes that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can sit down to talk on a range of topics of mutual concern.
"Certainly, we hope that diplomatic issues can be included on the agenda for future cross-strait talks," he explained.

Touching on the choice of new diplomatic allies, Tien said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will review "relevant qualifications" of prospective candidates more carefully in the future, particularly their domestic political stability, their strategic importance in regional geopolitics and the cost the ROC would have to pay for diplomatic recognition.

In view of Taiwan's economic slowdown and its people's increasing concern about financial aid to other countries, Tien said, MOFA will also exercise more prudence in committing aid to prospective diplomatic allies. "We'll make commitments in proportion to our own financial resources," he said.

Noting that humanitarian aid and economic assistance remain essential to maintaining diplomatic relations with Taiwan's allies, Tien said MOFA will endeavor to make the ROC's foreign aid system and procedures "more transparent and institutionalized."

"We have sent a draft bill on international cooperation and development to the Legislative Yuan for screening and approval with a view to ensuring transparency, openness and institutionalization in our foreign aid operations," Tien explained.
Meanwhile, he went on, MOFA has no intention of asking Macedonia to repay financial aid already given by the ROC. "We have never had such an idea," he stressed.
The minister also clarified that the total amount of ROC financial assistance to Macedonia over the past two-and-a-half years is "not as big" as the figure reported in the press.

"Many foreign aid programs are kept secret. But I want to stress that the actual amount of our aid to Macedonia was less than the figure speculated by the press," he said, adding that many planned aid or cooperative programs had not been put into force. "With the severance of diplomatic ties, our cooperative programs with Macedonia have all been scrapped," he added.

The political scientist-turned-minister was scheduled to leave for the United States later in the day to attend a seminar on world affairs to be held in Colorado. The seminar is being organized by the American Enterprise Institute, a noted U.S. think tank. During the four-day forum, both Tien and U.S. Vice President Dick Cheney will deliver speeches at a panel session.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAGAZINE EDITOR CALLS FOR U.S. TO STOP APPEASING BEIJING

TEXT.P: The United States should use its foreign policy to help bring about the peaceful transformation of Beijing's dictatorship into a democracy like the one in Taiwan, according to a former Reagan administration official.

Writing in the latest issue of the Weekly Standard, William Kristol, publisher and editor of the conservative magazine, said that although certain forms of U.S. engagement with Communist China may well be justified, the goal of American foreign policy should encourage Beijing to change peacefully from a dictatorship to democracy.
"This is a project worthy of a great power. It would require a foreign policy of military strength, political boldness, and moral clarity," Kristol said.

However, he noted that the idea may not be endorsed by liberal newspapers like The New York Times, which carried an editorial "China Viewed Narrowly" last Sunday, saying the United States needs "a realistic China policy" and "a balanced approach to trade, diplomacy and geopolitics." The paper is worried that the Bush administration has been focusing too much on military issues rather than keeping them in perspective.

Kristol said the New York Times would prefer that military issues not impede "active engagement with China on economic and arms control issues." But Beijing routinely agrees to and then routinely breaks various nonproliferation agreements. And the former is something the Bush administration is already pursuing vigorously, and apparently successfully, with the completion of negotiations for Beijing's accession to the World Trade Organization.

"It's hard to see what the Times is fretting about -- except that we have not yet subordinated U.S. foreign policy in its entirety to the goal of making the Chinese dictators blissfully happy," wrote the former professor of politics at the University of Pennsylvania and Harvard's Kennedy School of Government.

Kristol said, "That's the point. The Times, to be fair, is faithfully echoing the American business and foreign policy establishments. They don't simply want a policy of economic engagement. They want us to avoid any activities in the strategic, political, or diplomatic spheres that might offend Beijing.

"So economic engagement becomes an excuse for appeasement. We accede to Beijing's wishes and limit our contacts with democratic Taiwan. We don't make a fuss about the detention of American citizens. We turn a blind eye to Beijing's weapons proliferation abroad and human rights abuses at home," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT COMPETITION TO GET FIERCER: SEF OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The two sides of the Taiwan Strait will enter an era of "structural competition" and their competition will become increasingly intense in the future, an official with the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said Tuesday.
SEF Deputy Secretary-General Yen Wan-chin made the remarks during a seminar on cross-strait peace, organized by the Peacetime Foundation.

Yen's comments followed SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu's statement on Monday that he was worried that cross-strait relations have become even more complicated and delicate. Koo is the ROC's top negotiator with mainland China in the absence of official contacts.
Yen pointed out that both cross-strait relations and the general international strategic environment are at a critical juncture of structural changes.
Against this background, Yen said, cross-strait relations would increasingly be characterized by mutual "structural competition."

"At present, cross-strait relations are in a state of steady change. Once they enter the era of 'structural competition,' their race in economic, social and political reforms as well as social order would become ever fiercer," Yen said, adding that the people of Taiwan should face this reality in long-term cross-strait interaction.
Yen stressed that Taiwan hopes both sides of the Taiwan Strait can develop and grow in a peaceful environment. "We hope to keep dynamic balance in cross-strait interaction," he added.

In his view, Yen said that as a small peace-loving power, Taiwan must understand how international powers or super powers operate. "We must pay prices, must have strategy and prudently deal with variables and invariable in cross-strait ties from a pragmatic angle."
Speaking on the same occasion, Legislator Chien Hsi-kai of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, said he earnestly hopes that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can sign a peace agreement by 2008.
Chien, also chief executive of the Peacetime Foundation, said as Beijing is seeking the right to host the 2008 Olympic Games, now is a good time to promote the signing of a cross-strait peace accord.
Noting that the Peacetime Foundation is pursuing "fair and just treatment," Chien said the foundation does not want to see the two sides of the Taiwan Strait trapped in an endless, costly arms race.

"Arms races would threaten peace and cause a retreat in cross-strait relations," Chien cautioned, adding that the Peacetime would join forces with other private organizations to push for the signing of a cross-strait peace pact by 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHIEF MEETS WITH U.S. THINK TANK MEMBERS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 18 (CNA) (By David Tseng and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan met with several members of major U. S. think tanks Monday and agreed with them that stability in the Taiwan Strait is of utmost importance to both Taiwan and mainland China.

Lien reached the consensus during a meeting with Winston Lord, former assistant secretary for East Asian and Pacific Affairs and Donald Zagoria, a senior researcher with the Foreign Policy Research Institute, who visited Lien at his New York hotel to exchange opinions on issues of mutual concern ranging from the political situation in Taiwan to the country's legislative and local government elections slated for December.
KMT Deputy Secretary-General Jason Hu and former Republic of China Representative to the United States Stephen Chen were also present on the occasion.

Lord was described as being "very concerned" about Lien's viewpoints of the George W. Bush administration, while Lien was quoted as telling Lord and Zagoria that he believes Washington's policy toward Taiwan is consistent and stable and that mainland China will keep a close watch on the coming elections in Taiwan.

He was also quoted as pointing out that mainland China must be closely monitoring the government of President Chen Shui-bian in the run-up to the year-end elections and that Taiwan must pay heed to how Beijing will react to the poll results.

Lien flew into New York Sunday from Paris on the third and final leg of a three-country "academic journey" in his capacity as head of Taiwan's prime opposition party. He also visited the United Kingdom and gave a speech at Oxford University.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAMBASTES MAGNATE'S ADVOCACY OF `ONE CHINA'

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) ridiculed Formosa Plastics Group Chairman Wang Yung-ching Tuesday for his call for the government of Taiwan to accept the "one China" principle.

At a press conference called to respond to Wang's "one China" advocacy, Tsai Huang-lang, a DPP party whip at the Legislative Yuan, said Wang's "rather absurd" call apparently ignores national security and national interest of Taiwan and its people.
Wang made the call out of solely personal business considerations and paid little heed to existing political reality across the Taiwan Strait, Tsai noted.

Tsai argued that the relocation of Taiwan businesses to mainland China, the opening of direct trade, travel and transportation links across the Taiwan Strait and the so-called "one China" policy are actually three different issues that are not necessarily logically linked.
Beijing's intentional linking of those issues is a deliberate attempt to make things difficult for Taiwan and thus create additional tension between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Tsai added.

Tsai continued that Taiwan has never demanded prerequisites on the development of cross-strait relations and pointed out that President Chen Shui-bian has on many occasions stressed that cross-strait issues, including the "one China" issue as well as the "three direct links" issue, can all be discussed on a basis of equality.

Tsai noted, however, that Beijing has never eased off on its schemes to suppress Taiwan in the international community, exemplified by Macedonia's recent switching of formal diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing under Beijing's influence. Taiwan cannot accept the "one China" principle under these circumstance, Tsai said.

He also said that while warmly beckoning Taiwan businesses to the mainland, the Beijing authorities continue to turn a deaf ear to Taiwan's request for the signing of accords aimed at protecting Taiwanese investments in mainland China. Because of this, the government cannot feel happy about letting Taiwan businesses go to the mainland without restrictions, he said.

Tsai added that if Wang, one of the most influential business tycoons in Taiwan, is really concerned about Taiwan's future, he should play a different role in cross-strait relations and use his personal clout to urge the Beijing authorities to accept the fact of the Republic of China's legal and sovereign existence and resume cross-strait dialogue based on equality.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMCHAM CONCERNED ABOUT TAIWAN INVESTMENT CLIMATE

TEXT.P: Members of the American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in Taipei expressed their concern about Taiwan's investment climate when they visited Republic of China Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi Tuesday.
In return, Lin promised that the government is determined to improve investment conditions so as to lure more foreign investors.

The AmCham members also expressed opinions about Taiwan's energy liberalization, intellectual property protection rights and environmental protection. They said they hope Taiwan will provide them with better business climate, with more transparency and closer to the norms of international business regulations and customs.
The eight-member AmCham delegation was headed by Richard Vuyistke, AmCham Taipei executive secretary.

Regarding energy liberalization, Vice Economics Minister Chen Ruey-long said that the delegates were concerned about the privatization of state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. and Taiwan Power Co. and whether the bidding system for the equipment and materials procurement for the state-run corporations corresponds with international regulations.

They also expressed concern regarding the progress of intellectual property rights protection and whether prosecutors' investigation and search rights are affected by the return of the search and detention rights to the court.
The delegates were also concerned about the possible levying of a surcharge on soil and underground water upon manufacturers by the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PHARMACEUTICAL INDUSTRY EYEING MAINLAND CHINESE MARKET

TEXT.P: A delegation composed of representatives of more than 30 Taiwan-based pharmaceutical firms has paid a visit to mainland China in search of investment opportunities in that promising market, industry sources said Tuesday.

A Taiwan Pharmaceutical Industry Association (TPIA) spokesman said that the delegation, the largest-ever of its kind, was warmly received by officials with the State Drug Administration -- mainland China's highest authority in charge of the management of its pharmaceutical industry -- during its visit.
Several Taiwan pharmaceutical makers are highly interested in edging into the mainland Chinese market following the recent trip, the official said.

Despite the fact that those Taiwan pharmaceutical investors who have already entered the mainland have not yet turned a profit with their investments there, the official said that the mainland's 1.2 billion population still constitutes a very attractive market for the Taiwan industry.
The scale of Taiwan's medical market is worth around NT$80 billion each year, with local pharmaceutical makers grabbing only 30 percent to 40 percent of the total, according to the TPIA official.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT RUN FOR BEIJING'S OLYMPIC BID HELD IN SHENZHEN
DOC.DATELINE: Shenzhen, Guangdong, June 19 (CNA) (By Chang Chun-yu & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: More than 1,000 runners from mainland China and Taiwan took part in the Shenzhen leg of a "cross-Taiwan Strait run" Tuesday in support of Beijing's bid to host the 2008 Olympic Games.
It was the third leg of a 10-city event designed as a publicity stunt to help Beijing win the right to host the games. Other competing cities are Paris and Toronto.
The run kicked off in Taipei June 16 with the participation of some 4,000 runners, followed by the second leg held in Kaohsiung June 17.
The runners were scheduled go to Ningbo Wednesday and then proceed to Hangzhou, Shanghai, Wuxi, Nanjing, Qingdao, with the climax ending in Beijing June 30.
The Taiwan delegation is headed by Olympic medalists C.K. Yang and Chi Cheng and world taekwondo champion Chen Yi-an is among the members.
The three-kilometer Shenzhen run also included teams organized by local enterprises.

Zhang Caizhen, vice president of the All-China Sports Federation, said that the run "demonstrates the common wish of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait" and added her belief that "it will bring about constructive results for cross-strait exchanges."

DOC.HEADLINE: BRAZILIAN IN CUSTODY BATTLE ENTERS TAIWAN WITH ROC ENTRY PERMIT

TEXT.P: Brazilian orphan Iruan Eugui Wu, a five-year-old at the center of a custody battle between his Brazilian and Taiwanese relatives, entered Taipei Tuesday with a Republic of China entry permit.
Wu's relatives in Taiwan can now apply for a legal residence permit for the child while they attempt to override Brazilian law by keeping the child here.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs issued an ROC passport for Wu Yi-hua, as he is known by his Taiwanese relatives, on May 27. The passport identifies Wu as an overseas Chinese, which means he cannot enter the country without an entry permit and must still apply for residency rights here.

The child, accompanied by his uncle Wu Hou-yen and opposition Kuomintang Legislator Lin Yi-shih, left for Hong Kong Tuesday morning and reentered Taiwan later in the day after being issued with the relevant documents.

Mentioning the custody fight, Lin admitted that the status of his Brazilian grandmother's guardianship of Wu remains unchanged and that she has been legally named as the boy's official guardian. Lin expressed hope that the issue will be resolved through the courts or negotiations between his Taiwanese relatives and Brazilian relatives.

The child's father, who was the captain of a Taiwanese fishing vessel, took him back to Kaohsiung County in southern Taiwan from his home in Brazil to visit his Taiwanese relatives in March, but died of a heart attack 11 days later. Yi-hua was then taken into the care of Wu's younger brother, Wu Hou-yen.

The move sparked a dispute over the guardianship rights between his Taiwanese relatives and his maternal grandmother, Rosa Leocia Ergui, who is demanding that the child be returned to his home on the grounds that the boy's father himself appointed her guardian for the child before a Brazilian court three years ago following the death of his Brazilian mother, Marisa Tatiane Ergui Tavares.

However, the boy's uncle in Taiwan has been seeking the ROC government's assistance in ignoring the Brazilian court ruling and forcing the boy to stay in Taiwan "to receive an education in accordance with the will of his father."

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT ECHOES PLASTICS TYCOON'S `ONE CHINA' ADVOCACY

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Tuesday echoed a local business tycoon's call for Taiwan to accept the "one China" principle, claiming that Chinese on both sides of the Taiwan Strait will benefit only when they reconcile.

Coming out in support of Formosa Plastics Group Chairman Wang Yung-ching, Lee Cheng-tsung, a KMT party whip at the Legislative Yuan, called for the Chen Shui-bian government to seriously assess the "one China" policy at this critical moment of development of cross-strait relations.

Lee stressed that the KMT has for long advocated that Taiwan openly recognizes the so-called "1992 consensus" of "one China, separate interpretations" and that this stance remains the KMT's set policy as far as cross-strait relations are concerned.

He criticized the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) for "never giving a thought" to the "1992 consensus." Because of that, he said, the administration has failed to score any points in efforts to ease off the cross-strait stalemate, consequently dragging down Taiwan's economy -- a fact underlined by Wang's remarks Tuesday that "Taiwan's current social disorder and political turmoil are even worse than during the corruption of the KMT era."

Noting that since the DPP took the helm of the government one year ago, it has led the country to greater economic strain, more serious social disorder and much higher unemployment, Lee said the DPP should pay heed to Wang's words rather than simply "rebuffing the opposition parties."
He reiterated that only when Taiwan recognizes the "1992 consensus" can the two sides of the Taiwan Strait resume dialogue at an early date.

KMT Legislator Ho Chih-hui, who is a former KMT party whip, also called for the DPP to observe what he claimed is the "mainstream" opinion of the Taiwan public. "Only when both sides of the Taiwan Strait return to the "1992 consensus" can the cross-strait impasse start to thaw," Ho said.

DOC.HEADLINE: `ASIA-PACIFIC CULTURAL CITIES' ACTIVITIES TO BE UNVEILED IN JULY

TEXT.P: A series of cultural activities introducing the beauty of Taiwan's culture will be unveiled in mid-July, with 18 domestic counties and cities, as well as 20 foreign cities participating, organizers said Tuesday.

The activities, titled "2001 Asia-Pacific Cultural Cities" and sponsored by Taipei city hall, will include cultural exhibitions, an "Asia-Pacific cultural cooperation meeting," a children's art festival and an international poetry and music festival.
The organizers expect that representatives of 20 cities from the United States, South Korea, Japan, Israel, Indonesia, the Marshall Islands, Fiji and Vietnam will be present at the occasion.
Six magistrates and mayors of the 18 domestic counties and cities, including Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, will also attend the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ARMY TO CONDUCT LIVE TEST-FIRING OF PATRIOT MISSILES

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Army will conduct live test-firing of American-made patriot missiles in southeastern Taiwan June 20, 21, 22 and 26, a military spokesman said Tuesday.

Ministry of National Defense (MND) spokesman Huang Sui-sheng said that the remodeled Patriot II missiles will be launched from Chiupeng base, Pingtung County, by the 25th Company of the Patriot Missile Battalion.

He noted that the live test-firing will be conducted only if the weather permits and added that the exact time of the firing will be kept confidential, while the results will be made public afterward.

The military and the Civil Aeronautics Administration have prohibited civilian aircraft from entering airspace below 90,000 feet over the region and boats from entering the waters covering southeastern Taiwan, Green Island and Orchid Island in the mornings of the four days of testing.
According to the test-firing schedule, targets will be fired from the mountains of Chengkung Township, Taitung County, which will be intercepted by the Patriot missiles.

As this will be the first live test-firing of this type of Patriot missiles outside the United States, relevant U.S. personnel will be stationed at observation posts at Chiupeng base and on Green Island to analyze the results.
The MND spokesman said that the results of the test will be made public so that the public can see the results of the training of the missile battalion.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT THANKS TUVALU FOR SUPPORTING ROC'S U.N. BID

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian received visiting Tuvalu Prime Minister Faimalaga Luka at the Presidential Office Tuesday.

Chen expressed gratitude to Luka for Tuvalu's long-time support of the Republic of China's bid for membership in the United Nations and also expressed hope that the ROC's long-dreamed-for rejoining of the U.N. will be realized in the near future.

In return, Luka promised that he will do his best to further upgrade relations between the two countries and reiterated that Tuvalu will continue to support the ROC and speak for Taiwan in international organizations.
Luka arrived in Taipei Monday for a week-long visit, his third to the Republic of China. He visited Taiwan in 1990 and 1995.

The ROC head of state congratulated Luka on assuming the post of prime minister in February and on Tuvalu becoming the 189th member of the U.N. last September. "We share your joy and pride," Chen said.

Chen said that bilateral relations between the ROC and Tuvalu are very cordial since the two countries established diplomatic relations in 1979. He thanked Tuvalu for its long-time support of the ROC cause in the international community.

Chen said that according to U.N. principles, Taiwan should not receive such unfair treatment and added that the ROC is the only country to be excluded by the U.N. "We admire very much your becoming a U.N. member," he said.
Luka for his part thanked the ROC for offering technical assistance and helping train young Tuvalu talent, which has greatly helped Tuvalu implement economic development projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: INCLUDING `TAIWAN' IN ROC PASSPORTS STILL BEING STUDIED: MOFA

TEXT.P: A spokeswoman for the Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday that whether the name "Taiwan" will be included in ROC passports is still being studied.
Chang Siao-yue made the comment after ROC President Chen Shui-bian voiced his support Monday for including "Taiwan" on the country's passports.
She noted that any change to the format will be based on convenience and practicability rather than on political considerations.
The move to insert "Taiwan" in ROC passports has already encountered some opposition from in Taiwan, while Beijing also expressed its opposition Tuesday.

According to Chang, MOFA's preliminary idea is that the Chinese name for the ROC on the passports will remain unchanged, with "Taiwan" being added in English, although consensus had not been reached as to whether it will also appear on the cover.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT NOT AGREEABLE TO FPG CHAIRMAN'S `ONE CHINA' CALL

TEXT.P: The government of the Republic of China has never shunned and will not shun the "one China" issue, although the issue itself has been defined and acknowledged differently by all parties concerned, government spokesman Su Tzen-ping said Tuesday.

Su said the government's stance on cross-Taiwan Strait relations is that both sides should shelve the sovereignty dispute until such time as a "favorable" atmosphere is nurtured to allow both sides to jointly tackle the "one China" problem.

However, he pointed out that the vision of "one China" espoused by Wang himself in newspaper reports and books in the past as a "Chinese confederation" comprised of mainland China, Taiwan and Hong Kong, is a concept unacceptable to Beijing.
However, officials from the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said unequivocally that the MAC is not agreeable to Wang's "one China" advocacy.
MAC officials said the ROC government has always been open-minded toward the "one China" issue and has always believed that this issue must be tackled.

Most of all, they said, both sides should first shelve the sovereignty dispute until such time as a productive atmosphere can be nurtured to allow both sides to work together to solve the "one China" issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC NAVY URGED TO REFUND COMMISSIONS PAID IN WARSHIP SALES

TEXT.P: A lawmaker urged the Republic of China Navy Tuesday to try to retrieve money from a Swiss bank after press reports said that Swiss authorities have frozen an account suspected of containing illegal gains of a wanted Taiwan arms broker.

Legislator Lee Ching-hua said the navy should attempt to claim the 250 million Swiss francs stashed in a Credit Suisse account owned by the son of Taiwan arms broker Andrew Wang, as the money is believed to be commission paid in the 1991 purchase from France of six Lafayette-class frigates.
According to the terms of the purchase contract, the navy is entitled to reclaim any money later found to have been paid in the form of commission for the deal.

Lee also prodded the navy to take legal action to secure evidence collected by a French Court presiding over the trial of former French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas, who was indicted for approving the sale of the six frigates to Taiwan after receiving bribes from state-owned oil company Elf, which had lobbied for the deal on behalf of the frigate builder, Thomson-CSF.

In a news conference, Lee displayed the address and pictures of a house allegedly owned by Wang in the United States and asked law enforcers to go after the arms broker who is also wanted by police for questioning in connection with the suspicious death of a navy captain in 1993.
Lee said the navy, if necessary, should ask for arbitration in Switzerland to get back the money.

Meanwhile, National Policy Adviser to the President Roger Hsieh also called on the government to contact the authorities in France and Switzerland to reclaim the money and to find out which Taiwan officials and politicians, if any, received kickbacks in the deal.
Hsieh made the call one day after Wang's bank account with Credit Suisse in Switzerland came to light.

The German-language Swiss paper Sonntags Zeitung reported Sunday that the account, opened under the name of Bruno Wang, a young Asian man, came to the attention of the authorities after the 250 million Swiss francs (US$142 million) were transferred in April. The banking authorities moved to freeze the account after discovering that its holder is the son of Andrew Wang.

Wang, who acted as Thomson's agent in Taiwan, has brokered many arms sales to Taiwan. He escaped the island on Dec. 20, 1993 after learning that police wanted to question him in connection with the mysterious death of Captain Yin Ching-feng, who was the head of the navy's weapons procurement department and was preparing to blow the whistle on massive arms procurement corruption just before he was found dead.

Taiwan ordered the six frigates from France in 1991 at a price of US$2.8 billion but was alarmed to find in 1996 that the price had been inflated with about US$500 million-worth of commission, which was prohibited under the contract.

Although Taiwan is entitled to a refund of any commission under the contract, all investigative and legal actions taken by the Taiwan authorities have been proved fruitless thus far, partly because of the absence of diplomatic ties between Taipei and Paris.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP DEBATES PROS AND CONS OF COOPERATION WITH FORMER KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Democrative Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers were divided Tuesday on whether they should cooperate with former Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lee Teng-hui in the year-end legislative elections.

Legislator Shen Fu-hsiung said during a debate presided over by DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh that cooperation with Lee would alert the KMT establishment to the displeasure among its native Taiwanese supporters and curtail its shift toward the People First Party, another opposition party, which would not be in the best interest of the DPP.

He wondered how many of Lee's former cronies will follow Lee's lead in defecting from the KMT, given the fact that many of them have already accepted nomination as KMT candidates in the year-end election.
Another of his concerns, said Sheng, is an overlap of Lee's supporters and DPP supporters that could split the DPP vote.

He estimated that Lee's followers might win 12 seats at the most in the legislature, but that the DPP might lose three of four seats as a result, which would mean that cooperation with Lee would add no more than eight seats -- not enough to help the ruling party gain control of the legislature.
The DPP at present controls 67 seats in the 220-seat Legislative Yuan.

Julian Kuo, a pro-DPP political science professor at Soochow University, supported Shen's view, saying that cooperation with Lee would underline the DPP's "native Taiwanese" nature, limit its shift toward the political middle road and downgrade the year-end election into a battle between native Taiwanese and non-native Taiwanese.

However, Legislator Chuo Jung-tai said an alliance with Lee would boost the party's chances of winning in the election and widen the party's support base, so long as care is taken to play down Lee's pro-Taiwanese stance and keep a distance from Lee's followers, who he said are closely associated with gangsters and business tycoons.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESDIENT STRESSES IMPORTANCE OF UNITY AND HARMONY

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian Tuesday stressed the importance of unity and harmony between the ruling and opposition parties in the battle against the current economic woes.
Chen made the remarks while speaking at a regular meeting of the nine-man policy coordination committee at the Taipei Guest House.
He described the unity and harmony of the ruling and opposition parties as the "most important factor" for resolving the current economic problems.
Chen expressed his appreciation for all the parties for dispatching delegates to last Sunday's preparatory meeting for a proposed economic development advisory committee.

If all parties will support the advisory committee and work out a consensus on the development of the island's economy, he said, the government will do its utmost to carry out the agreed-upon projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP HOSPITALIZED WITH MUSCLE SPASM

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu was hospitalized Monday for acute muscle spasm, sources with the Presidential Office's Public Affairs Department said Tuesday.

Lu felt a twinge of lumbago Monday when she was about to leave her house to go to the office. She was rushed to the National Taiwan University Hospital and diagnosed as suffering from acute muscle spasm, probably as a result of stress, the sources said.
The sources said doctors suggested that Lu stay in hospital to recuperate and her secretaries canceled all her activities prior to Thursday.
President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Chang Chun-hsiung visited Lu Tuesday evening to wish her a speedy recovery.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTIVISTS TO PROTEST AGAINST FPG CHAIR'S 'ONE CHINA' CALL

TEXT.P: Pro-independence party supporters said they would demonstrate in front of the headquarters of the Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) Wednesday to protest against FPG Chairman Wang Yung-ching's call for Taiwan to accept Beijing's "one China" principle.

Hsu Ching-sung, executive officer of the Taipei headquarters of the Independence Party's, said about 100 members of the party are expected to gather in front of the FPG headquarters located on Tunhua North Road Wednesday afternoon to show their strong disapproval of Wang's call, which they said ignores national security and the national interest of Taiwan and its people.

In a keynote speech to a symposium on biotechnology and health care Tuesday, Wang lashed out at the government's inability to tackle the economic woes and called for support for Beijing's "one China" principle. Wang said the Chinese on both sides of the Taiwan Strait will benefit only when they reconcile.

Commenting on the Independence Party's planned demonstration, FPG officials said Taiwan is a democratic country where the people's freedom of speech is well protected under the Constitution. They said everybody in the country should respect the opinions of others even though different political parties harbor different ideologies and stances.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK MARKET CONTINUES LOSING STREAK

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (Taiex) continued its losing streak Wednesday, with the benchmark weighted price index dropping 10.34 points to close at 5,029.64.
Market turnover totaled NT$30.54 billion (US$898.24 million) in thin trading.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONSERVATIVES SUPPORT NATIONAL MISSILE DEFENSE SYSTEM

TEXT.P: Accusing Russia and Communist China of arming rogue states with weapons of mass destruction, more than 50 U.S. conservative leaders have expressed their support for President George W. Bush's efforts to establish a national missile defense.

In a June 18 letter to President Bush made public Tuesday, the conservative leaders, headed by David A. Keene, chairman of the American Conservative Union, also urged scrapping the Anti-Ballistic Missile (ABM) Treaty of 1972, claiming that it has been rendered obsolete by technology and changing world events.

"We, the undersigned, thank you for your unwavering commitment to provide an effective ballistic missile defense for the United States, its forces overseas and allies. We agree that we can no longer safely allow our country and interests to remain unprotected against this real and growing threat," they wrote.

The conservative leaders told President Bush: "Your leadership is deeply appreciated in ending at the earliest possible time our present vulnerability to blackmail, coercion or attack from rogue states -- and from countries like Russia and China that are, among other things, arming those nations with ever more dangerous missiles and weapons of mass destruction."

"This vulnerability is, of course, the by-product of the nearly 30-year-old Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty signed with a country, the Soviet Union, that ceased to exist 10 years ago. The ABM treaty prohibited the United States from developing and deploying effective national missile defenses. Today, such an accord is clearly a threat to our 'supreme interests.'" the letter said.

"Accordingly, under the ABM treaty's terms, we have the right to withdraw from that pact. We urge you without further delay to give notice of our intent to do so, clearing the way for us to begin deploying missile defenses six months from now," the conservative leaders said.

They concluded by saying that the United States cannot affort to remain undefended, and that they share President Bush's confidence that the United States can build and deploy a robust, global missile defense system.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SUCCESSFULLY TEST-FIRES PATRIOT MISSILES

TEXT.P: The Republic of China military test-fired three of its U.S.-made Patriot missiles Wednesday at an army base in the southern Taiwan county of Pingtung.
Military sources said all of the missiles successfully downed dummy targets fired from Green Island, off the coast of Taitung in eastern Taiwan.
It was the first time that the anti-missile defense system has been test-fired outside the United States.

The Ministry of National Defense kept secret the test-firing schedule, but had tightened security at the Chiupeng army base in recent days. Private cable television stations, however, managed to broadcast footage showing exhaust trails from a Patriot missile.
Army sources said the three Patriot missiles were fired between 9:12 a.m. and 9:30 a.m. to intercept drones fired from Green Island.
U.S. military officers and engineers from Patriot manufacturer Raytheon Co. and its subcontractor Lockheed-Martin Co. reportedly were present at the Chiupeng army base to witness the tests.

The ROC military has acquired three sets of modified air defense systems (MADS), known as "Patriot PAC-2 plus" or the upgraded version of the Patriot missile system the United States used in the Persian Gulf War in 1991.
The Patriots are defensive missiles intended to intercept high-altitude incoming missiles. Military experts said MADS are capable of partially destroying ballistic missiles.
The three sets of MADS have been deployed in northern Taiwan to protect the heavily populated greater Taipei area in the face of mainland China's mounting military threat.
Mainland China has deployed more than 300 M-class guided missiles in its southeastern province of Fujian, which lies close to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPUTER ASSOCIATES NO. 1 INTERNET SECURITY SOFTWARE PROVIDER

TEXT.P: A new International Data Corporation (IDC) research report ranks Long Island, N.Y.-based Computer Associates International, Inc. (CA) as the world's leading provider of Internet security software for the second year in a row.

The report, titled "Worldwide Internet Security Software Market Forecast and Analysis, 2001-2005," indicates that security is "now considered the most important Web site attribute." It suggests that a variety of factors will expand the Internet security software market from approximately US$5.1 billion in 2000 to over US$14 billion in 2005.

IDC's findings underscore the strength of CA's eTrust product family of security solutions. The unmatched breadth and seamless integration of the eTrust product family -- which includes access control, certificate management, risk assessment , attack detection, and loss prevention -- enables management teams to defend, administer access, and ensure the management and security of complex eBusiness environments.

The IDC report confirms CA's position as the global security software leader, said Barry Keyes, vice president in charge of eTrust solutions at CA. "That leadership is, and will continue to be, based on CA's ability to deliver greater security manageability with decreasing total cost of ownership," he said.
IDC is recognized as one of the market leaders in providing research and analysis to eBusiness executives, IT professionals, IT suppliers, and services suppliers.
Founded in 1976 by its current chairman, Charles Wang, CA serves organizations in more than 100 countries.
