DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LAWMAKER DEMANDS EXPULSION OF FORMER PARTY CHAIRMAN LEE TENG-HUI

TEXT.P: A senior member of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) proposed Wednesday that former KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui be expelled from the KMT in light of Lee's recent apparent alliance with the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and allegedly helping to form a new political group that is poised to greatly affect the year-end legislative elections.

Speaking at a KMT Central Standing Committee meeting, Hung Hsiu-chu proposed the expulsion of Lee, who is also the former president of the Republic of China, from the KMT because "Lee betrayed and has been heartless and unjust to the party."
"Even if the party has yet to decide whether to expel Lee from the party, he has already been ousted from everyone's heart," Hung said.

Noting that Lee's recent deeds and remarks have caused an uproar among the KMT rank-and-file, Hung called for the KMT Evaluation and Discipline Committee to look further into the matter. "The party decision-makers should not turn a deaf ear and condone Lee's improper behavior any longer," she added.

Commenting on discussions made in the meeting concerning Lee's alleged formation of a new political group with DPP and other party cronies, KMT spokesman Wang Chih-kang said the issue will be discussed further after the return to Taiwan of KMT Chairman Lien Chan who is currently visiting New York.

Meanwhile, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, a KMT stalwart, said Lee's expulsion is a "hypersensitive" issue which should be handled with extra care. "Any party member who intends to express his or her opinions should at the same time bear the principle of process in mind," Ma said.

Commenting on Formosa Plastics Group Chairman Wang Yung-ching's call on Tuesday for the government of Taiwan to accept mainland China's "one China" principle, Ma said as far as he knows, only the KMT accepts and recognizes the "1992 consensus" of "one China, separate interpretations," which is also what Wang was referring to.
Ma said the Chinese communists on the mainland have continuously stressed the importance of the "1992 consensus," but have been intentionally oblivious to the "separate interpretations."
By comparison, Ma said that the ruling DPP does not altogether recognize the "1992 consensus."
Ma said both Beijing and current rulers in Taiwan should readjust their attitude and mentality toward the "one China" issue in cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI STOCK MARKET REMAINS WEAK

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (Taiex) continued its losing streak Wednesday due to a loss of investor confidence.

The Taiex weighted price index, the market's key barometer lost 10.34 points to close at 5,029.64. It was the third consecutive day that the market lost ground as many players kept on the sidelines over market uncertainty.
Market turnover shrank further to NT$30.54 billion (US$898.24 million) amid slow trading, with about 1 billion shares changing hands during the four-and-half-hour trading session.
The market opened lower at 5,038.89 points and hovered in a narrow range between 5,025.08 and 5,074.09 throughout the trading session.
Of the eight major stock categories, only cement stocks posted a gain of 0.8 percent; textile issues remained unchanged; and all other sectors lost grounds.
Losers outnumbered gainers 264 to 213, with 117 remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS TYCOON EXPLAINS 'ONE CHINA' REMARKS

TEXT.P: Formosa Plastic Group Chairman Wang Yung-ching said Wednesday that when he said that Taiwan must accept the "one China" principle, he meant that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should be able to give separate interpretations of the principle on an equal footing.

Wang was trying to dispel some of the concern raised by his address at a biotech meeting the previous day when he said that Taiwan should embrace the "one China" principle to help break the current economic slump. He also criticized the government for "being even more chaotic than it was 40 years ago."
The remarks by Wang, dubbed the "management guru of Taiwan," raised eyebrows at the meeting and has sparked heated debate in the news media.

Trying to cushion some of the impact, Wang said that his remarks about the "one China" principle conform with the "one China, separate interpretations " consensus reached between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in 1992.

As for the government "being more chaotic," Wang also explained that previous administrations under the Kuomintang (KMT) were more efficient in implementing their policies because the KMT was the dominant political party. He said that currently, however, things have become more complicated, with various political parties and different viewpoints. He also said that the Democratic Progressive Party, as a ruling party, should have the determination to overcome current problems.
Wang, who has had several major projects blocked by the government's "go slow" policy, said that investing in the mainland is an unstoppable trend.
Under the "go slow" policy, Taiwan businessmen are barred from investing in infrastructure projects on the mainland, and are forbidden to invest more than US$50 million in any other project in China.

The Taiwan-language daily "China Times" reported that Wang will travel to Beijing later this month to establish branch hospitals of the Chang Kung Memorial Hospital. Wang dismissed the report but said that the mainland has welcomed him with open arms to build hospitals in China.
The reports said that Wang is planning to invest in Beijing, Xiamen, and Fuzhou to establish hospitals with 11,000 beds.

Wang's previous trip to the mainland in September of last year was to inspect the investment environment for raw materials purchases for the petrochemical industry. He also scouted for possible sites to build the hospitals, the report said.

Meanwhile, an official in charge of mainland policy said that it is "impossible" to accept the "one China" principle as defined by mainland China, as it has "grossly ignored the existence of the Republic of China."

Chen Ming-tung, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, said that Beijing's "one China" principle is "three-pronged" rhetoric, meaning that there is only one China in the world, Taiwan is a part of that China, and that the People's Republic of China is the only legitimate government of China in the world.
"There is no room for the existence of the Republic of China under that definition, and we can't accept or agree with it," Chen said.
Chen stressed that President Chen Shui-bian has repeatedly said that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should sit down to talk over the issue of "one China," and increase exchanges and dialogues.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVITED TO TAKE PART IN FIRST AFRO-ASIAN GAMES

TEXT.P: Taiwan has been invited to take part in the first Afro-Asian Games slated to be held Nov. 3-11 in New Delhi, India, sources from the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee (CTOC) said Wednesday.

The committee is planning to field Taiwan contestants to compete in all of the eight categories of the newly-established Afro-Asian Games. Participants will come from all parts of Africa and Asia, CTOC officials said.
The eight categories of competition are: Aquatics (swimming and diving), track-and-field, boxing, football, hockey, shooting, tennis and weightlifting.
It is too early to know how many countries will be sending athletes to the Games, CTOC officials said.

In related news, the Cabinet-level National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports (NCPFS) has recently approved a 30-athlete group from Taipei City to represent Taiwan in five competition categories of the 33rd International Children's Games (ICG) to be held in Hungary in August this year.
It will be the first time for Taiwan athletes to take part in any ICG competitions.

NCPFS officials said Taiwan is interested in playing host to the ICG in the future, adding that Joze Sater, chairman of the headquarters of the ICG, will be invited to Taiwan in September to gain further understanding of children's sports activities and related physical fitness programs in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, June 20, or the 29th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1597: Dutch navigator and Arctic explorer William Barents dies at sea at the age of 47. He led several expeditions in search of the Northeast Passage.
1863: West Virginia becomes the 35th state of the United States.
1887: The longest railway bridge in Britain and the second over the River Tay in Scotland is opened.
1895: The Japanese government in Taiwan founds the "Taiwan Hospital" in Taipei, which later became the National Taiwan University Hospital.
1902: Prior to the outbreak of the Russo-Japanese War in 1904, the Japanese supreme wartime office establishes the "General Headquarters of Military Service in Manchuria" and appoints Gon Oyama, former joint chief of staff, as its commander-in-chief.
1909: Errol Flynn, the American actor who specialized in swashbuckling and war hero roles, is born in Tasmania. He appeared in such films as "The Adventures of Robin Hood," "Captain Blood," and "The Sea Hawk."
1940: At the request of Japan, France closes the railway between Yunnan Province and Vietnam, cutting transportation links between Vietnam and China.
1940: The French government requests an armistice with Italy.
1960: American Floyd Patterson knocks out Sweden's Ingmar Johansson to become the first boxer to regain the world heavyweight title.
1960: Mali gains independence from France.
1963: The United States and Russia agree to establish a hotline telephone link.
1964: A China Air Transport (CAT) passenger plane crashes near Fengyuan in Central Taiwan on its way from Makung to Taipei, killing more than 50 aboard, including movie industry tycoon Loh Yun-tao, who is visiting Taiwan to attend the 11th Asian Film Festival.
1967: Muhammad Ali, originally Cassius Marcellus Clay, the American boxer who won the world heavyweight title in 1964, is sentenced to five years in prison and fined US$10,000 for refusing to be conscripted into the armed forces.
1974: Dr. Amade M. Yuzon, president of the United Poets Laureate International, arrives in Taipei to attend a meeting celebrating Chinese Poets' Day.
1976: A six-man delegation led by artist-poet Wang Lan leaves for Seoul to attend the Asian Artist Conference and a plenary meeting of the Asian Arts Center.
1978: The Republic of China is listed the 25th-largest trading country in the world by the International Monetary Fund.
1979: American TV reporter Bill Stewart is gunned down by Nicaraguan National Guardsmen as he walks toward a roadblock with a white flag in one hand and his official yellow press card in the other.
1982: The Directorate General of Telecommunications (DGT) opens the first public data switching service in the Republic of China.
1984: Some 70 miners are killed in the Haishan coal mine disaster in northern Taiwan.
1990: South Africa's Nelson Mandela gets a ticker-tape welcome in New York.
1992: Czech and Slovak leaders decide to split Czechoslovakia into two nations, one for Czechs and one for Slovaks. The Czech Republic and Slovakia formally came into existence on Jan. 1, 1993.
1997: Russia pledges to stop targeting Japan with nuclear missiles.
1999: Boris Yeltsin presents U.S. President Bill Clinton with recently declassified Russian reports relating to the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.
2000: Hans Muench, a German doctor in the Nazis' Auschwitz death camp is given immunity from trial at a French court because of his senility.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Of all people in the world, young women and servants are the most difficult to keep in the house. If you are familiar with them, they forget their position, but if you keep them at a distance, they are discontented."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were lower on Wednesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for June moved downwards 46 points to close at 5,036, with 3,533 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for July dropped 31 points to finish at 5,052, with 4,781 contract transactions, while September futures dropped 32 points to close at 5,051, with three contracts traded. Next March futures dropped 98 points to close at 5,040, with nine contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 5,082 for June, 5,083 for July, 5,083 for September, 5,139 for December, and 5,138 for next March.
Electronics (TE) and Financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were generally lower.

June TE futures moved down 1.5 points to close at 256.00 points, with 784 contracts transacted, while July TE futures dropped 1.85 points to finish at 255.65 points with 983 contracts changing hands. Next March TE futures dropped 1 point to finish at 258 points with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
June TF futures moved down 2.8 points to finish at 675.2, with 337 contracts changing hands, while July TF futures dropped 1.6 points to finish at 680, with 386 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC CONTINUES OFFERING SCHOLARSHIPS TO MACEDONIAN STUDENTS

TEXT.P: Despite the severance of diplomatic ties, the Republic of China will continue offering scholarships for Macedonian students to study in Taiwan, Minister of Education Ovid Tzeng said Wednesday.

The ROC government currently offers scholarships to five Macedonian students who are studying at local universities, Tzeng said, adding that the measure will not be suspended simply because of the break-up of diplomatic relations between the two countries.

In line with the principle of separating international academic exchanges from the general international political situation, Tzeng said the ROC has consistently maintained academic exchanges with many non-diplomatic allies.
The ROC government now offers each Macedonian student NT$15,000 (US$441.18) in living subsidy per month, in addition to NT$70,000 in tuition fees.
"In all, we spend about NT$1 million a year supporting Macedonian students' study programs in Taiwan. The amount is not large, but the scholarship program is of great significance," Tzeng said.

Noting that Macedonia is an old, civilized country and has a rich cultural heritage, Tzeng said the ROC has come to better understand ancient Greek culture through its engagement with Macedonia over the past two-and-half years.

Tzeng said although Macedonia switched its diplomatic allegiance from Taipei to Beijing earlier this week, the ROC will continue academic and cultural exchanges with the Balkan state and offer its students scholarships to study in Taiwan. Nevertheless, Tzeng said the Ministry of Education will study on a yearly basis whether to adjust the number of Macedonian students qualified for ROC scholarship.

DOC.HEADLINE: N.T. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.003 against the U.S. dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Wednesday, closing at 34.4.
The local currency opened Wednesday at 34.386 and was traded between 34.379 and 34.421.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$313 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MAKES INSPECTION TOUR OF OFFSHORE ISLAND OUTPOSTS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian made an inspection tour of the Republic of China's frontline island group of Matsu Wednesday to see for himself combat preparedness and economic development projects there.
Chen also took advantage of the trip to wish the officers and men stationed at the offshore defense outposts a happy Dragon Boat Festival, which falls on Monday.
It was Chen's second journey to Matsu since he took office in the ROC's first-ever democratic transfer of power between different political parties in May 2000.

On his last trip, Chen inspected several islets of the Matsu island group, including Nankan, Peikan, Tungyin and Liantao. During Wednesday's tour, Chen focused his itinerary on areas he did not visit last time, such as Chukuang and Kaoteng.
Chen was accompanied by Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen, Chief of the General Staff Tang Yao-ming and several other senior military officers.

He first visited Hsichu Island where he was briefed on military defense measures in the area. He then paid a visit to the Chukuang village government office to get first-hand information about several grassroots community development projects. Chen also toured an ancient Taoist temple.
He then traveled to Tungchu Island to inspect various military installments and personnel training programs. He also visited a remodeled residential community and a primary school.
Chen ended his tour in Kaoteng, the Matsu group island closest to mainland China. The island covers an area of 1.42 square kilometers and is 8.9 kilometers from the mainland at its closest point.

Chen expressed his gratitude for the devotion of the officers and men stationed on the islet and encouraged them to continue their dedicated service to the country before he left for Taipei on a military helicopter.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MUNICIPAL HOSPITALS LAUNCH COMMUNITY ELDERLY CARE PROGRAM

TEXT.P: The Taipei Municipal Yangming Hospital inaugurated the first community elderly care service center in Taipei Wednesday to provide medical services to aged handicapped people living alone.

Statistics compiled by the Taipei city government indicate that in Taipei alone there are some 43,000 aged handicapped citizens, including a large number of Alzheimer's patients. Many of these people are living without company and the service center will locate them and offer them assistance, according to a hospital spokeswoman.

The spokeswoman noted that two other municipal hospitals in Taipei -- Jen Ai and Ho Ping -- will also set up similar service centers. In this way, the health authorities in Taipei expect to organize a medical network for senior citizens in need.

The service center will be staffed by doctors, nurses, social workers, rehabilitation medical personnel and data management staff. They will first make home visits to aged handicapped people to assess their needs, then arrange for them to receive assistance such as medical care or household assistance.

A study conducted by the Chinese Association for Human Rights has revealed that elderly care is a weak point in Taiwan, as many elderly people unable to take care of themselves are actually living alone.
With 10 percent of Taiwan's population over the age of 65, Taiwan is facing many problems related to the aged population and medical authorities have been urged to take note of this development.
The Yangming Hospital spokeswoman said her hospital hopes to first serve the 4,200 aged handicapped people living in the Shihlin district, where the hospital is located.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET URGED TO SET TIMETABLE FOR OPENING DOOR TO MAINLAND TOURISTS

TEXT.P: A group of legislators from both ruling and opposition parties urged the government Wednesday to set a timetable for opening Taiwan's door to tourists from mainland China.

The lawmakers made the call at a public hearing held at the Legislative Yuan, with the participation of legislators, tourist industry representatives and officials from the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).

Legislator Wang To of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Premier Chang Chun-hsiung stated clearly in the legislature last year that the government would begin to allow mainland people to make sightseeing visits to Taiwan from July 1, 2001.

"The premier's promise is certain to break as the MAC is not expected to complete a preliminary planning report until the end of this month," Wang claimed, adding: "How could a premier easily back off his promise?"
In response, MAC Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tung said the government has not wavered on its determination to open Taiwan's door to prospective mainland tourists.

"In an effort to ensure travel quality and avoid any adverse impact on national security and public order, we must work out a comprehensive plan and hope to discuss with mainland China some practical issues before the new open-door policy is put into effect," Chen explained.
He ensured lawmakers that the MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, would finalize a blueprint at the end of June. "By then, I can't divulge any details of the plan," he added.

Noting that implementation of the new open-door policy needs interaction between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Chen said all relevant Republic of China government authorities are stepping up efforts to forge contacts with mainland China.
"Both sides should show goodwill and sincerity to tackle all issues related to the opening of Taiwan to prospective mainland Chinese tourists," Chen stressed.

Legislators present at the hearing, including Wang, Chiu Chui-chen of the People First Party and Chen Horng-chi of the Kuomintang, were generally not satisfied with Chen's remarks and demanded the DPP government set a timetable for opening the door to mainland holidaymakers.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ARMY SUCCESSFULLY TEST-FIRES THREE PATRIOT MISSILES

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Army successfully test-fired three U.S.-made Patriot missiles Wednesday in the first test-firing of the anti-missile defense system ever conducted outside the United States.

Immediately upon learning of the success, President Chen Shui-bian, who was inspecting military installations on the offshore island of Matsu, wired a message of congratulations to the personnel who participated in the exercise.
The drill took place in the morning without prior announcement by the Ministry of National Defense, and the results were released later in the day by the Army General Headquarters (AGHQ).

According to the AGHQ, two of the missiles were fired consecutively from Chiupeng army base in the southern Taiwan county of Pingtung to intercept a target missile launched from Green Island, off the coast of Taitung in eastern Taiwan.
Another Patriot missile was then fired to intercept a target drone aircraft.
All three missiles successfully downed their targets.
Military sources said that it is standard procedure to fire two Patriots to intercept a single incoming missile in order to increase the probability of success.

U.S. military officers, as well as engineers from Patriot manufacturer Raytheon Co. and its subcontractor Lockheed-Martin Co., reportedly were present at Chiupeng army base to witness the tests and to assist the ROC Army in evaluating and analyzing the results.

By 1997, the ROC military had completed the deployment of three batteries of Patriot missiles in northern Taiwan to protect the heavily populated greater Taipei area against the 300-some M-class guided missiles that mainland China has deployed across the Taiwan Strait.
The model acquired by the ROC Army is known as the Modified Air Defense System, or MADS. It is an upgraded version of the configuration used by the U.S. Army in the Persian Gulf War of 1991.

Military sources said that a team of U.S. experts was very impressed by the performance of the ROC Patriot missile batteries during a combat readiness evaluation in July 1998 and after conducting a study the following year to determine the feasibility of allowing the test-firing to take place in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT SYSTEM `UNWORKABLE:' DPP LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: The government has been running under a "Lee-A Bian" system for the past year and facts have proved that such an alliance is unworkable, a senior member of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) claimed Wednesday.

Chang Chun-hung alleged that the "Lee-A Bian" system -- supposed to describe an alliance between former President Lee Teng-hui and incumbent President Chen Shui-bian -- was "in fact unofficially declared" upon the inauguration of the government May 20, 2000. Chang also said that events of the past year have proved that the new government is unable to function at all in internal affairs.

Chang made the remarks at a seminar sponsored by the DPP in the face of the alleged formation of a political group by Lee, who is said to be seeking to lure members from the prime opposition Kuomintang, the DPP and the independent camp to take part in the legislative elections planned for December under the slogan of "localization."

The lawmaker also expressed skepticism that the alleged "Lee Group" can effectively cooperate with the DPP, as potential supporters of Lee and the DPP are largely overlapping, which would only lead to a split of the vote in the elections. He predicted that the DPP will garner as much as 40 percent of the seats in the 225-member legislature in the year-end elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: QUANTA IN NO HURRY TO INVEST IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Quanta Computer Chairman P.L. Lin said Wednesday that his company, Taiwan's leading notebook computer firm, is expected to put out 1.15 million units in the second quarter of this year, with 420,000 produced in June alone, a record single-month high.
Lin made the remarks at a shareholders meeting. He also said that Quanta is technology oriented and is in no hurry to invest in mainland China.

Quanta has projected its business revenue for the whole of this year at NT$13.1 billion, up 58 percent over the 2000 level. Pre-tax profits have been estimated to surpass the NT$10 billion mark for the first time to hit NT$10.2 billion, with after-tax profits forecast at NT$9.97 billion and earnings per share at NT$4.74.

DOC.HEADLINE: LATIN AMERICAN TRADE FAIR BEGINS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: An exhibition of Latin American products began in Taipei Wednesday, with high-ranking Republic of China officials, trade leaders and ambassadors of the ROC's Central and South American allies presiding over the opening ceremony.

Firms from Nicaragua, Panama, Paraguay, Honduras, Belize, Costa Rica, the Dominican Republic, Guatemala, and El Salvador participated in the trade fair jointly organized by the ROC foreign and economics ministries, which will last until June 26.

With cheerful Latin American dance and music raising a curtain in a local mall, the opening ceremony reached its climax when ROC Vice Foreign Minister Lan Chih-min, Vice Economics Minister Chen Ruey-long, Far East Group President Douglas Hsu and ambassadors of the ROC's nine Central and South American allies jointly inaugurated the exhibition with a traditional Latin American opening ceremony.

Lan said the organization of the trade fair derives from an idea of Vice President Annette Lu, who made a diplomatic tour of Central America last year and suggested that Taiwan organize such trade shows to promote the local sale of products from the ROC's Latin American allies.
The main items on show, which will also be exhibited elsewhere in Taiwan, include coffee, cigars, mate, black tea, wine, dried fruit, leather and textile products.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TO HOST INTERNATIONAL KIWANIS ANNUAL CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: Taipei will host the 2001 annual conference of International Kiwanis from June 23-26, an organizer said Wednesday.
President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu will deliver speeches at the opening and closing ceremonies, respectively, said Wu Hui-wan, head of the Republic of China Kiwanis club.
Taipei was chosen over Sydney and other contestants five years ago to host the 2001 Kiwanis annual conference, which will be the group's first in Asia.

The U.S.-originated group has always held its annual conference in North America in its 86-year history except for once in Austria and once in France, a fact that Wu said adds extra significance to the conference in Taipei.
Noting that nearly 10,000 Kiwanians will gather in Taipei for the conference, Wu called it a valuable opportunity for Taiwan to boost its visibility on the international stage.

During the conference, both the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Taipei city government will hold receptions for the Kiwanians, while the ROC Kiwanis club will field three dragon boat teams in the June 25 international dragon boat race organized by the Taipei city government, Wu said.
Founded in 1915 in Detroit with the aim of promoting community service, Kiwanis has developed into an international organization with 315,000 members in more than 71 nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET APPROVES ROC-DOMINICAN REPUBLIC COOPERATION ACCORD

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan approved at its weekly meeting Wednesday an extension of the Republic of China-Dominican Republic Industrial Technical Cooperation Agreement for another two years.
The two-year accord, which expired Nov. 4, 2000, was extended for another two years at the request of the government of the Dominican Republic, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs official said.

The Dominican Republic recommended modifying Article 8 of the accord that states: "The accord will automatically extended for another two years once it expires unless either of two parties presents a written document to terminate the accord three months before the expiration of the accord," the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMBASSADORS TO ROC VISIT KINMEN

TEXT.P: A delegation of 15 ambassadors to the Republic of China and their families visited the front-line island of Kinmen Wednesday as a part of the Taipei city government's efforts to promote Taiwan culture.

Accompanied by Lee Ping, deputy director of Taipei's Bureau of Cultural Affairs, the foreign emissaries toured various historical military sites that are now open to the public in the form of a war memorial national park.

The group also visited some of the island's historically preserved buildings and traditional villages, which are reminiscent of Fujian-style designs that feature swallow-tailed roofs and enclosed courtyards.

Paraguayan Ambassador Ceferino Adrian Valdez said on behalf of the other members of the group that Kinmen is "truly a beautiful island renowned for its historical battlefields and sorghum liquor, where the people's warmth can be felt deeply."

According to Lee, foreigners in the past generally think of the capital city of Taipei as the sole representative of Taiwan culture. By inviting the ambassadors to take part in the two-day tour of Kinmen, he said he hopes to introduce them to Taiwan's other cultural traditions and promote further cultural exchanges.
Kinmen is one of the 18 domestic counties and cities that will be participating in a series of "2001 Asia Pacific Cultural Cities" activities to be held in Taipei next month.

Also joining in the cultural exhibits, which include a children's art festival and an international poetry and music festival, will be representatives from 20 foreign cities in the United States, South Korea, Japan, Israel, Indonesia, the Marshall Islands, Fiji and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS TO WAGE CLEAN ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that the government will do its utmost to wage clean legislative and county magistrate elections in December.
He made the remarks while meeting with members of the legislative group known as the "Reform Society" headed by opposition Kuomintang Legislator Chen Hsueh-sheng.

The president said that he will play a dual role in the upcoming elections by campaigning for candidates of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and trying to eradicate "black gold" and vote-buying.
He noted that the elections, the first since the DPP took over the government in May 2000, are deeply connected with the island's future political stability and economic and social developments.
During the meeting, the president echoed Chen Hsueh-sheng's view that "for the sake of the welfare of the people of Taiwan, we should pay more attention to the economy than to politics."
He said this was the reason he proposed establishing a cross-party "economic development advisory committee" to help resolve the pressing economic problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: ICSB WORLD CONFERENCE CONCLUDES IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 46th World Conference of the International Council for Small Businesses (ICSB) concluded in Taipei Wednesday after some 500 participants from 55 countries spent three days to discuss how to cope with the challenges posed by the new era.
The conference began Monday at the Taipei International Conference Center and President Chen Shui-bian gave a speech at the opening ceremony.
The 46th World Conference of the ICSB was jointly sponsored by the Republic of China Small Business Association and the ICSB-ROC.

Four plenary sessions, 24 concurrent sessions and four workshops were held during the three-day conference. Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu delivered a lecture Wednesday on ROC government policy regarding small businesses.

Founded in 1955, the ICSB is an important international organization for small businesses. It is committed to a free exchange of ideas, experience and programs through education, research, publications and conferences among its members for the sound development of small businesses worldwide.
It was the first time the world conference had been held in Taiwan. The ROC joined the organization in 1999 under its own name.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CULTURAL AFFAIRS DIRECTOR TO VISIT SHANGHAI

TEXT.P: Taipei Cultural Affairs Bureau Director Lung Ying-tai is slated to leave for Shanghai Friday for a week-long visit during which she will speak on Taipei's cultural development and survey Shanghai's cultural facilities.
Lung said that she will address the issue of Taipei's cultural development Saturday at the opening ceremony of a comparative study seminar on the cultures of the two cities.
The following afternoon, she is scheduled to deliver a public speech titled "Invisible Cities: Taipei and Shanghai" at the Shanghai Municipal Library.
On both occasions, she said, she will outline her vision of Taipei's future cultural development and present her opinions on cultural exchanges.

Praising the international flavor of some of the cultural facilities Shanghai has built in recent years, Lung said that she will also visit the Shanghai Opera House and various local museums to study their management for Taipei's future reference.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC GOVERNMENT SPOKESMAN LEAVES FOR EUROPE

TEXT.P: Government Information Office (GIO) Director-General Su Tzen-ping left Taipei for Europe Wednesday to explain the Republic of China government's policy toward mainland China.

The trip will take Su to Germany, Belgium and France, where he will visit major think tanks and media organizations to exchange views with researchers and journalists on the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
The GIO chief made a similar trip to the United States recently. He is scheduled to return to Taipei June 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO TIMETABLE SET FOR OPENING UP TAIWAN TO MAINLAND CHINESE TOURISTS

TEXT.P: The government is assessing and projecting the timing of opening up Taiwan to mainland Chinese tourists, but it does not have a set timetable for implementation of the plan, a ranking government official said Wednesday.

Speaking at a news conference at the Government Information Office, Chiou I-yen, secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, said that relevant government agencies will complete the assessment and projection of the plan as scheduled by the end of June, but added that no fixed timetable for its implementation has been worked out.
According to Chiou, a timely completion of the assessment does not mean that the government will be able to implement the plan as scheduled on July 1.

Dismissing speculation that the government might have shifted from its original stance of implementing the plan, Chiou reiterated that the matter requires bilateral negotiations with mainland China and that this does not mean the government has failed to honor its promise.

Without prior negotiations between the two sides, many problems which could arise from Taiwan's opening up to tourists from the mainland could pose a serious threat to social order and local law enforcement authorities, he noted.
As an example, he asked which mainland agencies the Taiwan authorities should approach if tourists from the mainland should break away from a package tour or overstay their visas in Taiwan.

Chiou claimed that the Democratic Progressive Party-led government has never eased its efforts to promote cross-Taiwan Strait relations since its inauguration May 20 last year. Describing the adoption of a more open policy toward mainland China as a set government policy, he said the government will continue its efforts despite a cool response from the mainland Chinese side.

Over the past year, he went on, the government has steadily brought in new measures to improve Taiwan-mainland ties, pointing as an example to the opening of the "mini three links" between the Republic of China-held Kinmen and Matsu islands and two ports in mainland China's Fujian Province opposite Taiwan at the beginning of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE YUAN TO HOLD EXTRAORDINARY SESSION JUNE 26

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan has decided to convene an extraordinary session From June 26-27 to deliberate six financial bills, a legislative spokesman announced Wednesday.

It was also decided at a coordinated meeting between the legislative caucuses of the various parties that a conversation meeting will be held June 22 to finalize the details of the agenda for the special session.

Both the ruling and opposition parties failed to reach consensus on whether Premier Chang Chun-hsiung should attend the upcoming special session -- as demanded by the opposition -- in order to make a report or answer intepellations.

President Chen Shui-bian formally Tuesday requested the Legislative Yuan to convene an extraordinary session to deliberate six pressing financial bills with the aim of boosting the country's financial strength.
The ruling and opposition lawmakers will consult again Thursday to decide whether Chang should be summoned to report to the special session.
It was also decided at the meeting that a plenary session will be held every Thursday to deliberate the bills scheduled for debate at next regular legislative session that begins in September.

Under the terms of the Constitution, the Legislative Yuan gathers for two regular sessions each year -- from February to May and from September to December. Extraordinary sessions may be held at the request of the president or after a vote in favor by more than 25 percent of the legislators.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FIRST LADY TO CHRISTEN EVERGREEN FREIGHTER IN JAPAN

TEXT.P: Republic of China First Lady Wu Shu-chen is slated to depart for Osaka Thursday to preside over a christening ceremony in Kobe the following day for a new freighter to be launched by Taiwan's shipping giant Evergreen Marine Corp.
Wu will preside over the ceremony at the invitation of Evergreen Group Chairman Chang Jung-fa, who serves concurrently as a senior adviser to ROC President Chen Shui-bian.
Evergreen Marine Corp. is the second-largest container operator in the world.
Wu will be accompanied by Deputy Presidential Secretary-General Chen Che-nan, Presidential Public Affairs Office Director Ms. Kuo Yao-chi and some of Wu's friends and relatives.
She is also expected to visit Osaka's Universal Studio and shop for the first daughter's upcoming September wedding.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC JOINS SYNDICATED LOAN TO DOMINICAN REPUBLIC
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 19 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China signed an agreement in Washington Wednesday to join the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB) in extending a US$28 million loan to the Dominican Republic.
The agreement was inked by Loh Ping-cheung, secretary-general of the International Cooperation and Development Fund under the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and IDB President Enrique V. Iglesias.
A separate loan agreement between the ROC and the Dominican Republic was signed by representatives of both governments immediately afterward.
ROC Representative to the United States Chen Chien-jen was invited to witness the signing ceremony.

Under the lending arrangement, the ROC will provide 17 percent, or US$4.6 million, of the total sum, while the IDB will come up with the remainder to help the Dominican Republic modernize its parliamentary system and cement its democracy.

The ROC was asked by the IDB to help it grant the loan one year ago and although Taipei is responsible for providing only a small part of the loan, the deal would have been difficult to organize if Taipei had not made its 17 percent contribution, a Taipei official claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: STATE-RUN FIRMS POST SLIM REVENUE IN FIRST FIVE MONTHS OF 2001

TEXT.P: The economic slowdown has bitten into the revenue of Taiwan's 12 state-run firms, which posted combined pre-tax profits of just NT$75 million (US$2.34 million) in the first five months of this year, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) disclosed Wednesday.

Nine of the 12 firms, including the Taiwan Power Co., which used to be the government's milk cow, have sunk into the red. The three firms that kept the state-owned sector's head above water are Chinese Petroleum Corp., with pre-tax profits of NT$4.88 billion, Taiwan Salt Industrial Corp., with pre-tax profits of NT$338 million and Taiwan Water Supply Corp., with pre-tax profits of NT$134 million, according to the MOEA.
The nine loss-making firms have run up a total deficit of NT$1.73 billion, which has driven down the state-owned firms' overall revenue to a paltry NT$75 million.
In May, only Chinese Petroleum Corp. and Taiwan Salt Industrial Corp. managed to register profits of NT$380 million and NT$69 million, respectively, according to the MOEA.
In an effort to reverse the declining trend, the MOEA is said to have worked out an action program to curb these firms' expenditure and boost their performance.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT VOWS TO END STRAINED CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said on this ROC-controlled offshore island Wednesday that weapons are not the only way to secure the nation.
He also reiterated that the government will continue to try to reopen deadlocked cross-Taiwan Strait talks.

The president made the remarks while lunching with members of the ROC armed forces stationed on the Matsu island group. Chen, accompanied by Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen and Chief of the General Staff Gen. Tang Ming-yao, arrived on Matsu to inspect the defenses there and to wish a happy Dragon Boat Festival to military personnel stationed there.
Chen pointed out that under the stimulus of nationalism, Beijing, in addition to endeavoring to keep Taiwan off the international stage, refuses to renounce the threat of force to take Taiwan.
Chen also said that without compromising national security, the government will gradually review and relax the current cross-strait trade policy based on the law and the spirit of reciprocity.

He added that the Executive Yuan is reviewing problems arising from the Jan. 1 implementation of the "three mini links" between the ROC-held islands of Kinmen and Matsu and the ports of Xiamen and Mawei in Fujian Province.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET APPROVES ROC-MALAWI MEDICAL COOPERATION ACCORD

TEXT.P: The Cabinet approved at its weekly meeting Wednesday a Republic of China-Malawi Medical Cooperation Agreement proposed by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).
A MOFA official said that the agreement will not only strengthen bilateral relations but will also promote medical cooperation between the two countries.

The ROC government has sent medical groups to help the African country run its Central Hospital at the request of the Malawi government, the official said, adding that the good performance of the group has paved the way for the two countries to work out the latest agreement, which was inked Feb. 16, 2001 in Malawi by ROC Vice Foreign Minister Wu Tzu-dan and Malawi Minister of Health Aleke K. Banda.

Under the agreement, the ROC will send a medical delegation to help run its Central Hospital in Mzuzu City while the Malawi government will provide operational funding, other expenses, offices and dormitories for the delegation.
The ROC government will take charge of payroll, round-trip air tickets, insurance and vehicles for the delegation, while the Malawi government will send medical personnel to Taiwan for training.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESS LEADER PREDICTS CONTINUED ECONOMIC SLUMP THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: A local business tycoon predicted Wednesday that Taiwan's economy will not recover this year judging from the United States' recent economic performance.

Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce and of Chinatrust Commercial Bank, made the remarks during a regular meeting of a trade promotion association in Taipei.

Koo said that during a stopover in the United States while accompanying President Chen Shui-bian on his diplomatic tour of Central and South America in May, he had a chance to exchange viewpoints with American experts about U.S. economic prospects, and was told that the U.S. economy will only recover in the fourth quarter of this year at the earliest.

Koo said Taiwan's economy depends greatly on the U.S. economic performance and usually reflects the American economic situation, although six months afterward. He predicted therefore that there is no chance that Taiwan's economy will improve in the rest of this year and estimated that Taiwan's economy may recover gradually after the middle of next year.

He added that the United States has adjusted its economic recovery forecast from the third quarter to the fourth of this year, with some predicting that the recovery will not come until the first quarter of next year.

According to statistics compiled by the ROC Finance Ministry, Taiwan's imports and exports began to decline sharply earlier this year, with some months even suffering double-digit declines from the year-earlier levels.

Referring to ties with mainland China, Koo emphasized that it is very important that Taiwan maintain peaceful relations with mainland China, as its economic development depends heavily on the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC OFFICIAL ISSUES SIX-POINT STATEMENT ON CROSS-STRAIT TIES
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 20 (CNA) (By Tseng Chun-liang & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Lin Chong-pin issued a six-point statement in San Francisco Wednesday to reaffirm Taipei's position on the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
Lin had just concluded a tour of major U.S. think tanks at the head of a delegation composed of Taiwan reporters covering mainland Chinese affairs.

He issued the statement to counter Beijing's three-point stance that "there is only one China in the world, both the mainland and Taiwan belong to one China, and China's sovereignty and territory are indivisible."
Lin's six-point statement is as follows:
1) Beijing has softened its tone, but it should also change its actions;
2) ROC President Chen Shui-bian continues to display his sincerity toward Beijing with more constructive suggestions;
3) We hope Beijing will respond with concrete action;
5) As Beijing's statement could be interpreted as an annexation of Taiwan, it is considered unfavorable to Taiwan's status during future cross-strait negotiations; and
6) Beijing should resume the cross-strait negotiations that it shelved unilaterally by it, because the exchange of words through the airwaves alone cannot remove mutual distrust.
Lin expressed the hope that Beijing will take concrete actions in response to Taipei's goodwill posture.

He described such desirable actions as allowing Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) Chairman Wang Daohan to visit Taipei, ceasing its boycott against Taipei's participation in non-governmental international organizations and resuming exchanges between ARATS and its Taiwan counterpart, the Strait Exchange Foundation.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF FOREIGN LABORERS DIPS IN MAY

TEXT.P: The number of foreign laborers in Taiwan dipped in May as the government's policy of curbing their numbers to ease soaring local unemployment began to bite.
The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) under the Executive Yuan said Wednesday that there were 328,800 foreign laborers in Taiwan as of the end of May, 512 less than month-earlier level.
However, a breakdown of the statistics shows that foreign caregivers bucked the overall trend by increasing by 1,364 to 14,019, although the pace of increase in this sector also slowed down.
Foreign maids also registered a minor increase of 186 to 8,737.
The number of foreign construction workers decreased by 512 to 31,928, mainly because of a government decision to freeze their numbers in major public projects.

The Taiwan authorities began putting the brakes on the introduction of foreign laborers last September after the unemployment rate started to increase. The local jobless rate hit a record high of 3.96 percent in March.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS TYCOONS OPPOSE SHRINKING OF FOREIGN WORKFORCE

TEXT.P: Several local business tycoons Wednesday opposed the government's planned shrinking of the foreign workforce and urged the government to understand the plight of bosses whose factories have closed amid the economic slump.

The tycoons, including Wang Yu-tseng, chairman of the Rebar Group, and Kao Ching-yuan, head of the President Group, voiced their opposition at a business association's monthly meeting that was also attended by Chen Chu, chairman of the Council of Labor Affairs, Taiwan's highest government body in charge of labor policy making.

Chen first delivered a lecture on the government's labor policy during which she expressed her opposition to freezing the Labor Standard Law as suggested by some domestic businessmen in reaction to the economic slowdown, claiming that the law provides fundamental protection to laborers.
She suggested that pension funds should be increased in order to enable most laborers to receive a pension.

Wang opposed Chen's suggestion, saying that the government should emphasize instead the stable implementation of its labor policy and should not increase laborers' retirement funds in the midst of the economic slump, or even more enterprises would not be able to afford to continue.

Kao suggested that the government increase instead of reducing the number of foreign workers, claiming that although the CLA has said there are presently 320,000 foreign workers on the island, less than half of them are involved in the manufacturing industry.
Kao urged Chen to make sure the CLA formulate the best labor policy possible in consideration of the real situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE THAN 100 TIBETANS TURN THEMSELVES IN FOR ROC CITIZENSHIP

TEXT.P: A total of 113 Tibetan adults, who used fake passports to enter Taiwan in previous years, have turned themselves in to Taiwan police authorities in the hopes of obtaining permanent residence in Taiwan, sources from the Ministry of the Interior said Thursday.

The 113 Tibetans, who used phony Indian or Nepalese passports to enter Taiwan after 1993, are expected to be granted permanent residence in Taiwan soon under a special relief program that was made possible after the Dalai Lama, the Tibetan exiled spiritual leader, made an appeal to President Chen Shui-bian in April.

The Dalai Lama appealed to Chen for help to those Tibetans who have been living in Taiwan over the past years without identification and consequently were deprived of benefits such as health insurance and work opportunities.

The Tibetans, some of whom have already married local ROC citizens, however, would first be charged with violations for either overstaying their visas or holding fake travel documents to enter Taiwan, officials from the National Police Administration said.

The Tibetans turned themselves in over the past two days under a guarantee by Chueh-An Tsering, chairman of the Tibet Association in Taipei, a private organization established to handle Tibetan affairs and relations with Taiwan.
Currently, there are basically two groups of Tibetans residing illegally in Taiwan, depending on their dates of arrival.

For those who came before 1993, they mainly arrived from refugee camps in India with travel documents obtained with the help of the Cabinet-level Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission. Most of them have now overstayed their visas.
Those who came after 1993 purchased fake passports at costs ranging from NT$3,000 to NT$30,000 from organized crime gangs in their refugee camps in India or Nepal.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. STATE DEPARTMENT CALLS TAIWAN'S PATRIOT TEST-FIRING ROUTINE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 20 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: U.S. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said Wednesday that Taiwan's test-firing of Patriot missiles was routine.
"Like any military, the Taiwan military routinely tests its weapons," Boucher said in response to a media query about Patriot missile test-firing at a southern Taiwan army base Wednesday.
To his knowledge, Boucher said, what Taiwan test-fired was a modified air defense system (MADS) that was derived from the U.S. Patriot system.

"It's primarily an anti-aircraft weapon, although it has some capability against lower-tier missile threats," Boucher said, adding that reporters should turn to the Taiwan military for any details of the test-firing.
Asked whether the Patriot test-firing would accelerate missile buildup around the Taiwan Strait, Boucher said he didn't think so.
"Facilitating a missile buildup? No," he said.

Boucher further said Taiwan bought the MADS from the United States. "It's derived from the U.S. Patriot system. I don't know the exact nature of the technology, but certainly it's associated with one of our systems."
Boucher said the MADS sale was in line with a U.S. commitment to furnishing Taiwan with defensive weapons to safeguard its security.
"We have always said we'll provide Taiwan with the wherewithal to meet its legitimate defensive needs, and any sales are within that context," he stressed.

The U.S. Department of Defense didn't comment on the latest Taiwan test-firing of Patriot missiles. A spokesman for the Pentagon's International Security Cooperation Agency said that no U.S. military servicemen took part in the Taiwan Patriot test-firing.
But the spokesman added that the U.S. Army's Patriot Project Office sent civilian staff members to observe the Taiwan test-firing.
Taiwan's military test-fired three of its U.S.-made Patriot missiles Wednesday. The tests reportedly hit two airborne targets -- a dummy missile and a dummy airplane.
It was the first time that Patriot missiles were test-fired outside the United States. Taiwan authorities said the tests were conducted with Washington's blessing.

DOC.HEADLINE: WEATHER BUREAU CLOSELY MONITORING TROPICAL STORM CHEBI

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau is closely monitoring the development of tropical storm Chebi which is gaining strength and is heading in a west-northwesterly direction toward the Bashi Channel from the Philippines.
Bureau meteorologists said they should know on Friday whether Chebi, now packing winds of up to 100 kilometers an hour, will pose a threat to Taiwan.

If the tropical storm continues to travel on its current path, it may spare Taiwan and head directly toward the South China Sea around the weekend, but if it changes course northward, it will then threaten Taiwan, the weathermen said.
Chebi, the second tropical storm this year with the potential to affect Taiwan, is traveling at 19 kilometers an hour and was located some 720 kilometers east of Taiwan as of Thursday noon.
It is expected to gain strength within the next 24 hours, the meteorologists said.
They added that occasional thunder showers are expected in mountainous areas islandwide in the next two days and temperatures will remain high, with a possibility of a high of 36 degrees Celsius.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK INDEX FALLS BELOW 5,000 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (Taiex) continued its losing streak Thursday, with its benchmark weighted price index sliding 44.76 points to close at 4,984.00.
Nevertheless, market turnover increased to NT$41.74 billion (US$1.23 billion) with active buying by bargain hunters.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP HOTEL MANAGER CALLS FOR EARLY OPENING OF TOURISM TO MAINLANDERS

TEXT.P: The chairman of the Taiwan Visitors Association on Thursday urged the government to speed the lifting of restrictions on mainland tourists visiting Taiwan to give the local tourist industry a much-needed shot in the arm.

Yen Chang-shou, who is also the president of the Ritz Landis Taipei hotel, called for the government to stop making opening Taiwan tourism to mainland Chinese visitors a "political bargaining chip" in the development of the cross-strait relations.

One of the top hoteliers in Taiwan and the chairman of the Landis Group of Hotels and Resorts, Yen called for related government agencies to handle the issue on business considerations, rather than political, or consider it as some kind of favor to the mainlanders or the local hotel and restaurant operators.

He added that when mainland China opened its tourism markets to Taiwan visitors, there were no "conditions." Hong Kong enjoys prosperity by operating a successful tourism industry which has set no any restriction, he said.

Yen, the only man in Asia to become president of an American Express operation with just a high school diploma, made the call during a national transportation and communication conference Thursday hosted by the government.

In response to Yen's complaint, Chou Chi-sheng, deputy director of the Economic Affairs Department of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said the issue of opening the Taiwan tourism market to mainland Chinese visitors is not and will not be a "political bargaining chip."
The MAC is Taiwan's top official agency responsible for formulating policies toward mainland China.
Chou, however, noted that for the sake of maintaining the quality of local tourism, officials from both sides should meet and talk ovr the issue before concrete measures are mapped out.

Premier Chang Chun-hsiung announced Oct. 20 that visitors from mainland China will be able to take leisure trips to Taiwan beginning June 2001 as part of the ROC government's efforts to address the cross-strait impasse.
The plan, nevertheless, has apparently not been implemented and it remains unknown when will it begin.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC PLANS TO RAISE MAINLAND INVESTMENT CEILING

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) will consider easing restrictions on the ceiling for mainland China-bound investment and allowing direct investment across the Taiwan Strait, a senior official said Thursday.
"These are the tasks high on the MAC's future work agenda," MAC Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said at a public hearing on the Republic of China government's current "go slow" mainland investment policy.

In the face of mounting calls for the government to open direct cross-strait "three links" and ease mainland investment restrictions, Tsai said the gap is actually not large between the government's stance and the business community's desire.
Nevertheless, Tsai said drastic liberalization of cross-strait commercial exchanges, including investment, would have a profound impact on the Taiwan economy in the short term.
In her view, Tsai said the existing "no haste, be patient" mainland investment, adopted by the previous Kuomintang government, is not unreasonable.
"Otherwise, it would not be likely that 40,000 to 50,000 Taiwan companies have so far invested in mainland China," Tsai said.

As future Taiwan investors on the mainland would mostly be large, high-tech and publicly listed companies, Tsai said, the MAC will study the feasibility of raising the maximum amount of each mainland China-bound investment project. At present, the cap is set at US$50 million (US$1.47 million).
Meanwhile, Tsai said the MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, will also work on a plan to allow direct cross-strait investment.

Until now, all mainland China-bound investments must be made via a third place. "The indirect measure is mainly aimed at protecting our investors' interests in view of systematic incompatibility between the two sides," Tsai explained.
With mainland China gradually improving its economic and financial systems, Tsai said, the MAC has made "direct investment" a key subject for study.

In preparation for allowing direct cross-strait investment, Tsai said, Taiwan must adopt a more flexible accounting supervision system to ensure transparency and avoid double taxation on capital gains remitted from mainland China.
"To sum up, the MAC will join forces with other relevant government agencies to adjust our mainland investment policy to minimize interference with local businesses' investment activities," she said.

During the public hearing organized by opposition New Party Legislator Lai Shyh-bao, Tsai also said the MAC has almost finalized a plan to allow foreign financial institutions to invest in Taiwan's sluggish real estate market.

"We have almost completed all preparatory work. We are now awaiting the Legislative Yuan to pass an amendment bill to the existing Land Law to provide a legal basis for the entry of foreign institutional investors into our property market," Tsai explained.
Once the new market-opening framework is established, Tsai said, the government will also allow mainland institutional investors to invest in Taiwan's property market.
Nevertheless, Tsai urged local land developers not to have unrealistic expectations of the possible bonanza that mainland investors may bring to Taiwan's recession-hit real estate market.
"Mainland China is known to be good at policy manipulation and has consistently imposed strict restraints on capital flow," Tsai cautioned.

Touching on the government plan to open the door to mainland Chinese tourists, Tsai said this policy remains unchanged. "The MAC is scheduled to finalize a blueprint by the end of June, but will not set a timetable for the implementation of the new open-door policy," Tsai said, adding that cross-strait coordination and consultations are necessary before opening Taiwan's door to mainland tourists.
Speaking on the same occasion, Legislator Lai and noted economist Ma Kai both voiced support for the establishment of a special economic zone for direct cross-strait trade and transportation links.
Lai and Ma said the establishment of the special economic zone would help pave the way for full-fledged liberalization of cross-strait trade and economic links.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, June 21, or the first day of the fifth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1788: The US Constitution comes into effect.
1852: Friedrich W.A. Froebel, the German educator who established the first kindergarten in 1837 at Blankenburg, dies at the age of 70.
1900: Battles rage in both Beijing and Tientsin after Empress Dowager Tzuhsi of the Ching court declares war on Great Britain, Germany, Russia, France, the United States, Japan, Italy and Austria.
1905: Jean-Paul Sartre, the French philosopher, novelist, dramatist and critic who propounded the philosophy of existentialism, is born.
1908: Russian composer Nikolai Rimski-Korsakov dies at home in St. Petersburg at the age of 64. He was best known for his orchestral piece "Scheherazade" and the opera "The Golden Cockerel."
1919: Twenty-seven vessels of the German fleet interned at Scapa Flow in Scotland's Orkney Islands are scuttled by their crews.
1931: Chiang Kai-shek leaves for Nanchang, Kiangsi province, to assume command of a campaign to suppress communists.
1942: Troops of Germany's General Rommel take 25,000 Allied prisoners at Tobruk on the Libyan coast.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek extends a 15-day cease-fire order to June 30. He had accepted on June 6 General Marshall's proposal to issue a second cease-fire order, instructing government troops to halt "all advances, attacks, and pursuits" during the 15-day armistice.
1970: Sukarno, founder and former president of the Republic of Indonesia, dies at the age of 69.
1976: A 36-member Republic of China delegation to the 22nd Asian Film Festival returns to Taipei from South Korea after winning nine awards.
1979: Premier Sun Yun-suan calls on free nations to assume moral responsibility for Indo-Chinese and mainland Chinese refugees and to take effective action immediately.
1981: Francois Mitterrand's socialists gain a landslide victory in the second ballot in general elections in France.
1982: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo calls on the nation's agricultural experts to work out concrete measures to expand agricultural development in the country.
1984: ROC Premier Yu Kuo-hwa orders an investigation into the cause of the Haishan coal mine disaster.
1990: A strong earthquake rocks northwestern Iran, killing some 25,000 people and injuring tens of thousands of others.
1990: The ROC Council of Grand Justices announces that senior parliamentarians should terminate their responsibilities by Dec. 31, 1991.
1992: Li Xiennien, former president of mainland China, dies of illness in Beijing at the age of 83.
1993: An ROC-US agreement for technical cooperation in the field of environmental protection is signed in Washington, D.C.
1996: Leaders of the European Union reach a deal to end the mad cow crisis with Britain.
1997: Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the ROC Straits Exchange Foundation, is invited by the mainland's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait to attend the ceremony marking the transfer of Hong Kong's sovereignty to mainland China at midnight on June 30.
1999: The ROC formally joins the International Council for Small Business (ICSB), becoming the 11th chapter of the world trade body.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui describes US$300 million-worth of aid pledged to Kosovar refugees as "the chance of a thousand years," and urges the public to have empathy as well as a broader mindset.
2000: US Representative Benjamin A. Gilman (R-NY), chairman of the House International Relations Committee, submits Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian's May 20 inaugural address for insertion in the congressional record.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If a man after 40 is an object of dislike to men, he will continue to be so to the end of his days."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK INDEX FALLS BELOW 5,000-POINT BARRIER

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (Taiex) continued its losing streak Thursday partly because of weak performance in the semiconductor sector.
The Taiex weighted price index, the market's key barometer, fell below the psychologically important 5,000-point barrier to close at 4,984.88, marking a loss of 44.76 points from Wednesday's finish.

Market turnover increased to NT$41.74 billion (US$1.23 billion) as bargain hunters jumped into the market to buy certain blue-chip stocks. A total of 1.27 billion shares changed hands during the four-and-half-hour trading session.

The market opened higher at 5,044.2 points, but soon weakened on drops in prices for two major microchip manufacturers -- Taiwan Semiconductors Manufacturing Corp. and United Microelectronics Corp. Many DRAM stocks also lost ground amid heaving selling. The Taiex index fluctuated between 4,965.86 and 5,066.17 points throughout the trading session.

Of the eight major stock categories, plastics and chemical stocks posted an average gain of 1.6 percent and cement stocks edged up 0.6 percent. The remaining six categories all lost ground, with foodstuffs moving down 0.5 percent; textile issues dropping 0.3 percent; electronics issues sliding 1.3 percent; paper stocks shedding 0.9 percent; construction issues falling 0.4 percent; and financial issues plunging 0.8 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 297 to 178, with 116 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S MISSILE TEST NOT INTENDED TO PROVOKE CHINA: CBC

TEXT.P: Canada's national broadcaster said Thursday that Taiwan's successful Patriot missile tests were in no way intended to be provocative to mainland China.
The U.S.-built missiles, which came to prominence during the 1991 Gulf War, were fired from the Pingtung military base at drones fired from a mountain.
The test-firing was conducted while China was carrying out war exercises, according to the Canadian Broadcasting Corp.
Communist China considers the island to be a breakaway province, and is irritated by U.S. arms sales to Taiwan.
The CBC said Taiwan believes that over the next decade, mainland China will add to the 800 missiles already aimed at the island.
The Patriots are defensive missiles intended to shoot down incoming missiles. Taiwan purchased 200 of the missiles, which are upgraded models of those used to combat Iraq's Scud missiles.
The military has deployed the missiles around the capital, Taipei, but has never fired one on Taiwanese soil, the CBC said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures markets closed lower Thursday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for July moved down 62 points to close at 4,990, with 7,865 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for August gained two points to finish at 4,988, with 14 contracts traded. September futures lost 50 points to close at 5,001, with four contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 5,052 for July, 4,986 for August, 5,051 for September, 5,093 for December and 5,040 for next March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, both closed lower.

July TE futures moved down 3.35 points to close at 252.3, with 1,563 contract transactions, while August TE futures lost 3.4 points to finish at 253, with three contracts traded. September TE futures moved up 1.05 points to close at 256, with one contract traded, and TE futures for next March lost 0.5 points to finish at 257.5, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
July TF futures moved down 6.4 points to finish at 673.6, with 536 contracts changing hands, while TF futures for next March increased 19.2 points to close at 672.4, with 11 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
