TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar was down NT$0.056 against the U.S. dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Thursday, closing at 34.456.
The local currency opened Thursday at 34.376 and was traded between 34.376 and 34.500.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$817.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC'S NEW REPRESENTATIVES TO RUSSIA, GERMANY SWORN IN

TEXT.P: New Republic of China representatives to Russia and Germany, Charles King and Hu Wei-chen, respectively, were sworn in Thursday in Taipei and both men promised to further strengthen the nation's ties with the two countries.
King, who graduated from National Taiwan University, has served as vice foreign minister, ambassador to South Korea, Foreign Ministry adviser, and representative to Germany.

Hu, who graduated from National Chengchi University, has served as consul-general of the ROC's consulate-general in Johannesburg, director of the Foreign Ministry's Department of Protocol and deputy secretary-general of the National Security Council.
Vice Foreign Minister Wu Tzu-dan presided over the oath-taking ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHANGING WORK SCHEDULE `TOUGH JOB': CLA

TEXT.P: Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) officials said Thursday that "it will be a very tough job" to change the current 84-hour bi-weekly working schedule to a 44-hour per week schedule as proposed by President Chen Shui-bian.

The president reiterated his proposal when he met with a group of opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislators a day earlier. Chen said that the ruling and opposition parties had originally reached consensus on the 44-hour work-week and in the end, it was the 84-hour bi-weekly working schedule that cleared the legislature "quite by accident."

In view of the current economic slump, Chen also said that if the ruling and opposition camps can agree to his view in a proposed economic advisory meeting scheduled for August, then he hopes the new legislative session in September will revise the law to delay the implementation of the work schedule for two years and change it to 44 hours per week.
Chen Shen-hsien, director of CLA's Department of Labor Affairs, said that changing the work-week will involve views from labor and management, ruling and opposition parties.
He pointed out that making the changes will be very difficult if there is no consensus reached on the president's proposal.
Chen noted that the issue caused confrontation between labor and management last year and resulted in political chaos.

But he also said that in view of the global economic developments, the Basic Labor Law needs to be amended. He stressed that the law must provide more leeway so as to give more room for consultation between labor and management in various fields.
He also said that the goal of the Basic Labor Law is to upgrade the country's competitiveness and that anything that is beneficial to both labor and management could be discussed.
Meanwhile, the three main opposition parties concurred that the adjustment of working hours is not a solution to the current economic problems.

KMT party whip Lee Cheng-chung noted that the 84-hour bi-weekly system was implemented Jan. 1 this year. It is "not appropriate" that the government should think of changing it to a 44-hour week when the new system has been in effect for less than six months.

According to Lee, "a poll" shows that 25.2 percent of the people think that the exodus of businesses is the main reason for the rising unemployment, 24 percent feel that the jobless problem is a result of the world economic slump and only 1.7 percent think it is caused by the shorter work week.

He also claimed that the number of foreign laborers introduced last year increased to 320,000 and added that it is "unreasonable" for foreign laborer numbers to increase at a time of domestic economic sluggishness.
Lee offered his opinion that the current economic woes have been caused by a lack of sound financial and economic policies on the part of the government led by Democratic Progressive Party.

Chou Hsi-wei, party whip of the People First Party (PFP), echoed Lee's words, saying that the government should come up with an overall solution and should not try to apply "simple political maneuvering" to address the economic woes.
Chou said that the adjustment of the work-week should respect market mechanisms and be agreed upon by labor and management.
The PFP will try to understand more about the work schedule, pay, economic competitiveness and the views of labor and management, he added.

Legislator Lai Shyi-bao of the New Party also said that shortened working hours are not directly related to economic woes and that the president is trying to put the blame on shortened work hours, which is "unfair" to laborers.

Lai urged the president to present more substantial data and figures to convince the legislators that increased work hours will help stimulate economy and upgrade business competitiveness, "otherwise, the president's idea will not get support from the opposition legislators."

DOC.HEADLINE: LEADING INDICATORS FOR MAY CONTINUE DOWNWARD TREND

TEXT.P: Taiwan's business conditions may not be able to recover in the third quarter as expected, as leading indicators for May soon to be made public by the government reveal 16th consecutive monthly falls in all seven categories.

The May leading indicators to be released next week by the Cabinet-level Council of Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) show that figures for export volume, the stock market weighted index, the average monthly work hours and wholesale price indexes all registered drops.
As those indicators serve to reflect business conditions in the coming three to six months, economists said that the local business climate is not very likely to recover in the coming months.

The economists, however, pointed out that this current wave of recession has lasted for 17 months, longer than the latest expansion period of 13 months (from December 1998 to January 2000). They also noted that this is the first time in Taiwan that an economic expansion period has been shorter than an economic contraction period.

DOC.HEADLINE: `HEALER' CLAIMING SUPERNATURAL POWERS CONVICTED OF FRAUD

TEXT.P: Taipei District Court ruled Thursday that a mainland Chinese woman claiming to have supernatural healing powers is guilty of fraud and of practicing medicine without a license.
Zhang Ying, who arrived in Taiwan with her locally born husband last December, was sentenced to 14 months in prison.

She has been barred from leaving the island since January, pending an end to the investigations that began when prosecutors were alerted to her claims that she can "see through bodies" to diagnose diseases and that she can "snatch pills" out of thin air.
Between Dec. 28 and Jan. 5, nearly 10 "patients" were led to believe that she had supernatural powers and sought medical treatment from her for a fee.
She was indicted April 10 along with Hsieh Szu-tao, a local woman who helped introduce patients to Zhang.

The bill of indictment stated that Zhang simply hid a pinch of powder containing Chinese medicine ingredients in the palm of her hand or under a table during her "treatment" sessions. In a sleight of hand trick, the prosecutors said, she would then rub the powder into a pill.

DOC.HEADLINE: VINTAGE WARSHIPS CONDUCT LIVE-FIRE DRILL TO MARK 60TH ANNIVERSARY

TEXT.P: Three of the Republic of China's vintage Gearing-class destroyers conducted a rare live-fire exercise near Pengjia Yu Islet off the northeastern Taiwan coast Thursday to mark the 60th anniversary of their commissioning into service.
As Pengjia Yu lies just 75 nautical miles southwest of the disputed Tiaoyutai Islands, the ROC Navy has seldom conducted live-fire drills in the area.

The Navy General Headquarters (NGH) said Thursday's drill was mainly designed to demonstrate the three warships' strong combat capabilities even after so many long years of service and had nothing to do with any sovereignty disputes.
However, the ROC military has stationed officers, men and radar stations on Pengjia Yu and the navy regularly ships military supplies and daily necessities to the islet.

The three U.S.-made destroyers -- Chienyang, Yunyang and Chengyang -- were built in the 1940s. After they retired from the U.S. naval service, they were sold to the ROC and have been helping defend Taiwan's security for about 30 years.

Despite their age, naval sources said, the three warships are still in good condition and perform well. They all sailed at a speed of 20 knots during the Pengjia Yu exercise. The flotilla steamed in formation and flexed their muscles in the half-day drill, firing anti-submarine rockets, decoy rockets, Phalanx rapid fire guns, 76 mm rapid fire guns and many other types of ammunition.
At the end of the drill, the flotilla cruised around Pengjia Yu to pay tribute to officers and men stationed on the small island.
The navy arranged for a group of journalists to cover the flotilla's live-fire drill with an aim of showing the local public the aging warships' strong combat capabilities.
The three destroyers are armed with standard missiles, MK46 torpedoes, Phalanx guns and many other types of rapid fire guns. They can sail at a maximum speed of 33 knots.

The ROC Navy now has seven Gearing-class destroyers whose combat capabilities have been beefed up greatly under a "Wuchin No. 3" mid-life upgraded program. Naval sources said the seven upgraded destroyers can continue their services for 10 to 15 years.
Military sources further said that the seven aging destroyers will continue their services no matter whether the ROC would purchase Kidd-class destroyers or not.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FIRST LADY ARRIVES IN OSAKA FOR THREE-DAY PRIVATE VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 21 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Republic of China First Lady Wu Su-chen flew into the Japanese city of Osaka Thursday for a three-day private visit.

On hand at Kansei International Airport to greet Wu's arrival were ROC Representative to Japan Lo Fu-chen and Director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Osaka Lo Kun-chan, as well as a representative of the Evergreen Group in Japan.

Wu's visit came at the invitation of Evergreen Group President Chang Jung-fa. She will preside Friday over a christening ceremony at Kobe dockyard for a giant container ship to be launched by Taiwan's Evergreen Marine Corp.
She is also scheduled to attend a cocktail reception sponsored by the Japanese shipbuilder after meeting with the Japanese press.
Wu is also expected to go shopping for her daughter's upcoming wedding.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIR OUTLINES TAIWAN'S CURRENT WOES IN CNN INTERVIEW
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 20 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian's failure to follow the previous Kuomintang government's policy toward mainland China has made cross-Taiwan Strait relations more severe than ever, KMT Chairman Lien Chan said in an interview with CNN Wednesday.

Lien, who is now on a private visit to New York, claimed that Chen's disregard of the KMT-initiated National Unification Guidelines and the 1992 "one China, separate interpretations" consensus has hindered any progress in cross-strait relations since Chen took office in the ROC's first-ever democratic transfer of power between different political parties in May 2000.

Lien went on to say to that the linger cross-strait political limbo has not only weakened Chen's approval rating but has also resulted in deterioration of cross-strait relations, a loss of investor confidence, a Taiwan stock market slump and overall economic slowdown.
In addition to uncertainty in cross-strait relation, Lien said another reason behind Taiwan's current plight lies in Chen's failure to respect the ROC's constitutional spirit.

Lien pointed out that Chen's current administration is basically a minority government as his Democratic Progressive Party controls barely a third of seats in the legislature. In contrast, the KMT controls more than half of legislative seats. Lien said Chen's administration has had a hard time coming to terms with the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan.

Lien, a former ROC vice president, finished third in Taiwan's 2000 presidential election. Asked whether he would run again in the 2004 election, Lien said both the KMT and he himself will make a decision when the time is right.

Touching on Taiwan's test-firing of three U.S.-made Patriot missiles Wednesday, Lien said the testing schedule has long been planned and was not designed to provoke mainland China. Mainland China's military is now conducting a series of combined services drills in its offshore Dongshan Island near Taiwan.
Lien is scheduled to travel to Colorado Thursday to attend a world forum organized by noted U.S. think tank American Enterprise Institute.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN E.U.'S 12TH-LARGEST TRADE PARTNER IN FIRST QUARTER
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, June 21 (CNA) (By Tang Ping-chun and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan was the European Union's 12th-largest trading partner in the first quarter of this year, according to statistics released Thursday by Eurostat, the statistical office of the European communities.

The statistics show that exports from the E.U.'s 15 countries to Taiwan in the first quarter reached a combined value of 3.3 billion euros, while their imports from Taiwan totaled 6.5 billion euros, representing a trade surplus for Taiwan of 3.2 billion euros.

In the same period, the E.U.'s 11 largest trading partners were the United States, Switzerland, Japan, mainland China, Norway, Russia, Poland, Czech Republic, Hungary, Turkey and Canada, in that order.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO MAKE EFFORTS TO CARE FOR ABORIGINES: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Thursday that Taiwan's current financial situation is not in good shape, but the government will make efforts to take care of the country's aborigines "as best as it can."
The premier made the remarks when he addressed a two-day aborigine conference that focused on bridging the gap in the living standards between Taiwan's aborigines and non-aborigines.
He also urged the aborigines to fight for their own destiny and to make every effort to upgrade the dignity of their tribes and continue their cultural heritage.
Representatives from government agencies, legislators and chiefs of Taiwan's 55 aboriginal villages and townships took part in the conference that ended Thursday.
The participants discussed issues related to raising the average income, improving employment opportunities, increasing educational levels and increasing aborigines' life expectancy.

The premier said that "respecting aborigines and helping them improve the quality of their lives" is a world trend and he expressed hope that all can work together toward realizing the goal of bridging the gap between Taiwan's aborigines and non-aborigines.

According to the recently formed Council of Aboriginal Affairs, the average monthly income of non-aboriginal households is NT$87,000, or 2.3 times that of aboriginal households, which only earn an average of NT$38,087. The jobless rate among aborigines is 7.55 percent, or 2.6 times that of non-aborigines.
Up to 60 percent of aborigines have less than junior high school-level education, all of which show that there is an enormous gap in the living standards between aboriginal and non-aboriginal people.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOBEL LAUREATE URGES TAIWAN TO BAN LANDMINES

TEXT.P: Visiting Nobel Peace Prize laureate Tun Chanareth urged Taiwan Thursday to ratify a law banning landmines in order to prevent further civilian injuries from accidental contact.

Chanareth said at a press conference that the law is necessary because the Republic of China is not a U.N. member and therefore ineligible to join some 130 countries in signing a 1997 international treaty in Ottawa against landmines.
According to U.N. estimates, about 110 million landmines still exist in the world, with over 100,000 of them located on the frontline ROC-held islands of Kinmen and Matsu.

Chanareth was scheduled to visit Kinmen Friday to listen to a military briefing on the island's mine-clearing efforts. He will then participate in a series of activities the following day aimed at helping the public experience how it feels to be confined to a wheelchair.

A Cambodian ex-soldier who lost both his legs in 1982 when a landmine exploded while he was patrolling with his troops near the Thai border, Chanareth is a goodwill ambassador of the International Campaign to Ban Landmines.
A coalition of more than 1,000 non-governmental organizations in over 60 countries, the campaign and its director Jody Williams were also co-recipients of the 1997 Nobel Peace Prize.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVERGREEN GROUP SAID TO INCREASE INVESTMENT IN PANAMA
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, June 20 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Evergreen Group is to increase its investment in Panama, according to a report in a local newspaper.
The paper reported that new investment projects will include the second stage expansion of an Evergreen container terminal at Colon, a hotel and a business center.

Evergreen Group Chairman Chang Jung-fa made the decision to expand his investments in Panama during a meeting with Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso when he accompanied President Chen Shui-bian on a visit to Panama last May, according to the paper.

Evergreen has already invested US$100 million to build a container terminal at Colon and the second-stage expansion will be financed with a further US$80 million. The paper said no date had been fixed for construction of the hotel and business center.

Chang is member of the Advisory Council of the Panama Canal and he has proposed that the Panama Canal's locks should be widened to 50 meters and lengthened to 310 meters in order to accommodate ships bigger than the "Panamax" class and increase the revenue of the canal.
The Evergreen Group has a commercial fleet of 130 ships and this year will increase by 13 new ships. The majority are registered in Panama.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE ECONOMICS MINISTER TOURS U.S. TO WOO INVESTORS

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu left Thursday for the United States at the head of a delegation seeking to attract more U.S. investment to Taiwan's high-tech sector.

The delegation, composed of officials of the ministry's Industrial Development Bureau and Industrial Development and Investment Center, together with several industrial park administrators, will visit U.S. firms involved in biotechnology, wireless telecommunications, computer science, precision machinery and high definition video products in San Diego, New York, Boston, and San Francisco. It will also hold several trade seminars in these cities.
Lin and the delegation are expected to leave the United States July 1. The tour forms part of the ministry's comprehensive investment promotion project focused on foreign countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT TO VISIT HIS U.S. ALMA MATER
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 20 (CNA) (By David Wang & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui will visit his alma mater -- Cornell University -- from June 26-28 to preside over the dedication of a scientific center named after him, according to Cornell University sources.
According to a press release issued by the Ithaca, New York university, Lee will arrive June 26 to a reception from a group of his supporters and local Taiwanese community leaders.
He will officiate at the inauguration of the Lee Teng-hui Institute for Scientific Research the following day and leave the university June 28.

Lee, who earned a doctorate in agricultural economy in 1968 from Cornell, last visited the university in 1995 while serving as ROC head of state. The trip, conducted in the full glare of publicity, led to a political storm because of Beijing's bitter protest against Washington's decision to allow Lee to enter the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO FURTHER DEVELOP CKS AIRPORT

TEXT.P: Chiang Kai-shek International Airport no longer enjoys advantages over other regional airports and the government should take action to upgrade the airport's facilities and capabilities, aviation industry sources said Thursday.
This was the consensus reached during the first National Transport Conference held in Taipei and attended by representatives of major local aviation companies.

Stressing that the government should fully develop the airport into a competitive facility, China Airlines (CAL) Chairman Y.N. Lee urged the government to "link the airport with nearby transport networks."

As international civil aviation organizations have decided to adopt routes in the Shanghai International Flight Information Zone instead of the A1 route within the Taipei International Flight Information Zone where CKS airport is located, Lee noted that the Taiwan airport no longer has advantages over others in the region.
The CAL executive also called on the airport authorities to improve the airport's facilities in the face of the imminent entry of the new A380 airplanes into the global civil aviation market.
Echoing Lee's view, EVA Airways Chairman C.C. Su also urged the government to do its best to quickly upgrade CKS airport facilities and improve its transport links with nearby traffic networks.

According to Su, CKS airport is only marginally better than those in the Philippines and Indonesia in terms of airport facilities. He noted that CKS airport had only one highway link to serve its capacity of eight million passengers per year and that it still has only one highway link now when its handling capacity has grown to 11.5 million passengers annually.

C. J. Wang, an engineer with a local construction company, said that the airport's capacity will become saturated by 2006 and that its facilities will become seriously insufficient by 2021. He contended that the airport should be expanded to tackle the increasing number of travelers.

Scholars and experts attending the conference also said that there is no need for the government to build an international airport in central or southern Taiwan, because a trip from central Taiwan to CKS airport will be much shorter with the completion of the planned high speed railway.

Judging the matter from the viewpoint of international travel, there is a difference of only one minute between a trip departing from CKS airport and one departing from central Taiwan, he pointed out.

Both Lee and Su agreed that the need for Taiwan's international travelers can be sufficiently met by only one international airport because of the island's small size and that the government should better develop CKS airport.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY 3,000 FACTORIES CLOSE DOWN IN FIRST FIVE MONTHS OF 2001

TEXT.P: Nearly 3,000 factories have closed down in the first five month of this year, an increase of 70 percent compared with the year-earlier level, according to statistics compiled by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics.
Meanwhile, the number of the newly-established factories reached 1,640 during the five-month period, compared to the growth of 2,200 registered for the same months of last year.
In May alone, the number of newly established factories in Taiwan increased by 276, a decrease of 50 percent from the year-earlier level, according to same statistics.
The statistics show that a total of 289 factories closed down in the same month, a slight increase from a year ago.

Meanwhile, financial and economic sector officials predicted that Taiwan will post a 4.2 percent unemployment rate in May. However, the exact rate was expected to be announced by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN LABORER WAGES, BROKERAGE FEES TO BE ADJUSTED

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council for Labor Affairs (CLA) announced Thursday that it has arrived at a consensus with the Indonesian representative office in Taiwan that will lead to lower brokerage fees for Indonesian workers in Taiwan.

According to the CLA, Indonesia has agreed to follow a similar agreement that exists between the CLA, Vietnam and Thailand to deduct room and board fees of between NT$2,500 (US$73) and NT$4,000 from workers' pay, which would then be compensated by lower brokerage fees that the workers have to pay to work in Taiwan.
Their actual wages -- legally guaranteed to be a minimum of NT$15,840 -- will therefore not be affected, CLA officials said.

According to the CLA, brokers in Taiwan have already agreed to lower their brokerage fees by NT$10,000, while brokers in Indonesia have yet to decide on a figure, although they are expected to lower their fees by approximately NT$20,000-NT$30,000 per person.
Indonesian workers each pay approximately NT$60,000 to their brokers in Taiwan and another NT$60,000 to their brokers in Indonesia.
At the earliest, the new fee scales will be put into effect in August, the officials added.
Foreign laborers often take out high-interest loans to pay for brokerage fees and have to work one to two years just in order to be able to pay off the debt.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL ATHLETE NAMED TO 2001 INTERNATIONAL HALL OF FAME
DOC.DATELINE: Hangzhou, June 21 (CNA) (By Chang Tsun-yu & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Taiwan Olympic medalist Chi Cheng left for New York Thursday, where she will be cited as an honorary member of the "2001 International Scholar/Athlete Hall of Fame" at a presentation ceremony at Rhode Island University in New York Friday.
Chi will be the first Asian woman and the second Asian to be honored with such a title. The first Asian to get the honor was Yasutaka Matsudaira, a famous volleyball coach.
Chi was one of 20 scholars and athletes selected by a screening committee of the biannual International Scholar/Athlete Hall of Fame for her contribution to promoting athletic activities.
Other noted figures to have received the award include Pierre de Coubertin, father of the modern Olympiad and former U.S. presidents George Bush and Gerald Ford.

Chi, who is presently in the mainland Chinese city of Hangzhou at the head of a Taiwan delegation taking part in a cross-Taiwan Strait relay in support of Beijing's bid to host the 2008 Olympic Games, will return to mainland China June 27 to take part in the Qingdao leg of the relay.
The Hangzhou event was the fifth leg of a 10-city event designed as a publicity stunt to help Beijing win the right to host the games. Other cities competing to host the games are Paris and Toronto.

The run kicked off in Taipei June 16 with some 4,000 runners from both sides of Taiwan Strait participating, followed by the second leg in Kaohsiung June 17. They then proceeded to Shenzhen, Ningbo and Hangzhou, and will continue on to Shanghai, Wuxi, Nanjing and Qingdao, with the final leg in Beijing June 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PC GIANT TRYING FOR NEW LOOK IN 3 YEARS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's PC giant Acer Inc. announced its new business direction Thursday and said it expects to see its revenues reach NT$150 billion (US$4.4 billion) and reap profits of NT$15 billion within three years.

Acer officials said the company is turning from manufacturing to marketing and services provision, making e-business the company's new core sector. They added that the company will also form a mainland China operation headquarters to develop that huge market.
"Acer wishes to be the pioneer of the knowledge-based economy in the Greater China area," the officials said.
Acer Group Chairman and CEO Stan Shih said that in the past, Acer seized microprocessor-based opportunities and became the pioneer of Taiwan's information industry.
Over the years, he went on, Acer has created many new information technology businesses, established successful business models and has led the high-tech revolution in Taiwan.

In the face of poorer performance last year, however, Shih said his company's reorganization has already shown results and that the transformed Acer will go from being a technological innovator to a user-centric service provider.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2001 TAIPEI DRAGON BOAT RACE KICKS OFF

TEXT.P: The 2001 Taipei International Dragon Boat Race will kick off Friday, with a record high of 116 teams from home and abroad taking part in one of the Chinese calendar's principal annual festivals.

Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will also captain a team composed of municipal officials in the competition, which will be celebrated on the Tachia section of the Keelung River through June 25, the day of this year's Dragon Boat Festival.
In addition to water-borne events, the Taipei city government also arranges many land-based activities to mark what is perhaps the most colorful festival of the year and is certainly the wettest.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRAZILIAN TO COME TO TAIWAN TO FIGHT FOR CUSTODY OF GRANDSON

TEXT.P: The Brazilian grandmother of a boy born to a Brazilian mother and a Taiwanese father will arrive in Taiwan on June 24 to seek to regain his custody, the boy's Taiwanese uncle, Wu Huo-yien, said Thursday in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan.

Wu said from his Kaohsiung home that he has written a letter in Chinese to Rosa Leocadia Dasilva, the grandmother, to express his welcome but to reiterate that he has no intention of giving her back her grandchild, five-year-old Iruan Wu, who he has kept in Taiwan since he arrived to visit his Taiwanese relatives at the beginning of this year.
The letter will be relayed to Dasilva by the Brazil Business Center, the country's representative office in Taiwan, which has arranged her trip to Taiwan.
Wu said he is willing to greet Rosa at the airport but cannot do so because the Brazil Business Center has kept him in the dark about the exact time of her arrival.

Claiming that his brother intended to have Iruan schooled and raised in Taiwan, Wu said he will do his utmost to realize his brother's will but will not block "the grandmother's right to visit the child."
He expressed hope that the dispute over Iruan's custody can be resolved amicably.
The boy, whose mother died three years ago, was officially put into the custody of his grandmother by his Taiwanese father through a Brazilian court.

The fight for the child's custody stemmed from the sudden death of Iruan's father during the visit to Taiwan. Iruan's grandmother asked for the child to be returned to her after learning that Wu had died, but Wu's brother refused, saying he wanted to raise his nephew.
The Dasilva was seen on local television several weeks ago appealing tearfully for the child's return from his Taiwanese relatives, all of whom were strangers to the boy.
The geographic distance between Brazil and Taiwan, the absence of diplomatic ties between them and the language barrier have complicated the dispute all the more.
The boy's uncle promised to go out of his way to make Dasilva's stay in Taiwan as comfortable as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: LABOR LEADERS OPPOSE ANY MOVE TO LENGTHEN WORK-WEEK

TEXT.P: It is the government's vacillations rather than the two-hours shorter work-week which has prompted the exodus of local firms, said two labor leaders Thursday amid reports that the government is drumming up support for a 44-hour work-week.

Lin Huei-kwung, chairman of the Chinese Federation of Labor and Huang Ching-hsien, chairman of the Taiwan Confederation of Trade Unions, voiced their protest, in the strongest terms, against any attempt to reinstate the 44-hour work-week, which was phrased out at the beginning of this year.

Huang said the government should not pin its hopes of revitalizing the economy on lengthening the work-week while there are many ways to boost industry, such as ensuring sufficient water and electricity supplies and more efficient administration.
The labor leader, who is also a national policy adviser to the president, said the government's policy flip-flops are the real culprit behind the economic slowdown.

Lin Huei-kwung warned the government not to make the country's seven million laborers into scapegoats for the island's faltering economy, saying there is no evidence that the shorter work-week is the main cause of the exodus of local industry.
Exploiting the workforce to save the economy is a futile attempt that will only widen the gap between rich and poor on the island and plunge the workers further into misery, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE FISHERMAN SHOT ABOARD TAIWAN FISHING BOAT
DOC.DATELINE: Johannesburg, June 21 (CNA) (By Chang Jer-hsiung & David Hsu)

TEXT.P: A mainland Chinese fisherman aboard a Taiwan fishing boat was shot and wounded by the ship's chief engineer last Sunday near the Indian Ocean island of Madagascar, officials of the Taipei Liaison Office in Cape Town said Wednesday.
The mainland fisherman, identified as Zhu Donghui, was shot by Chen Shui-lung of Taiwan early June 17 for "unknown reasons," the dispatch said.

Zhu was taken to a South African hospital the next day by a helicopter of the South African maritime rescue team with the help of the Taipei Liaison Office in Cape Town, the officials said, adding that Zhu was in stable condition.
The 700-ton deep sea fishing vessel "Chin Hsing" left the southern Taiwan port of Kaohsiung for the Indian Ocean in December 2000.
All other crewmen were reported to be safe and the vessel was reported to be on its way back to Taiwan, and is expected to return to Taiwan in 20 days.
Officials of the Fishery Administration under the Council of Agriculture said that once the ship returns to Taiwan, they will further investigate the incident.
Chen was put in detention aboard another fishing ship that is also on its way back to Taiwan.
It was reported that Chen not only shot Zhu but also set fire to instrumentation aboard the vessel before being subdued by other crewmen.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Taiwan's jobless rate breaks 4 percent as the economic prospects remain gloomy.
The China Times:
MAC Chairwoman Tsai says the government is considering allowing direct investment in mainland China.
The United Daily News:
The Ministry of Finance is planning tax cuts to stimulate economy.
The Liberty Times:
Many private schools may be forced to close due to difficulties in recruiting students.
The China Post:
Government to study further easing of mainland-bound investment.
The Taiwan News:
Severed heads found on isle not of U.S. hostage.
The Taipei Times:
Navy puts itself to test in live-fire drill.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BEGINS TO BRACE FOR TYPHOON CHEBI

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung on Friday instructed related government agencies and the private sector to heighten vigilance against the approach of typhoon Chebi, which is certain to bring torrential rains and strong winds to Taiwan.

The Central Weather Bureau issued land and sea warnings Friday on the approach of Chebi, the second typhoon to threaten Taiwan this year. The storm is gaining strength and is heading in a north-northwesterly direction toward the Bashi Channel from the Philippines.

A central disaster contingency center under the Ministry of the Interior was set up Friday, under the leadership of Minister-without-Portfolio Chen Chin-huang, to oversee preparation work islandwide against the typhoon.

According to bureau meteorologists, as of Friday noon, Chebi was centered 430 kilometers southeast of Oluanpi, the southernmost tip of Taiwan. With a radius of 200 kilometers and packing winds of up to 100 kilometers an hour, Chebi is moving north-northwesterly toward the Bashi Channel at a speed of 21 kilometers per hour.
With its strength increasing, Chebi is expected to affect southern and eastern Taiwan beginning midnight Friday or from the small hours of Saturday, weathermen said.
They warned that torrential rains are expected in mountainous areas islandwide in the next two days and temperatures will remain high, with a possibility of a high of 36 degrees Celsius.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORT ORDERS, INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTION INDEX DECLINE IN MAY

TEXT.P: Export orders and the industrial production index showed unusual decline in May, the Ministry of Economic Affairs reported Friday.

Ministry officials said that export orders totaled US$11.5 billion, down 13.96 percent from the same time last year. Barring seasonal factors, the decline was the largest since export orders were first recorded in 1981.

Export orders in May declined by US$1.87 million, or down 13.96 percent, from the same time last year. Officials said that the May decline was precipitated by the continued fall of semiconductor prices and the continued poor demand for information and electronic products.

Among export items, all but machinery products recorded a decrease from the same time last year. Major export destinations also showed an overall decline. For example, exports to the United States declined by US$660 million, down 15.34 percent; exports to Hong Kong dropped by US$220 million, down by 9.07 percent; exports to Japan down by US$210 million, down 14.4 percent; exports to Europe dropped by US$550 million. down by 25.13 percent.
Meanwhile, the industrial production index fell for the third consecutive month since March, including the manufacturing sector which was down by 9.91 percent.

The industrial industry index was down 8.2 percent from the same time last year. It is estimated that the industrial production index in the first five months was down 5.29 percent from the same period last year.

Ministry officials noted that it was unusual for the industrial production index to fall for three months in a row. Affected by a slump in the world economy, the uncertain future of the information and electronics sectors, and more conservative domestic demand, the decline in the manufacturing industry has widened every month, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE INVESTIGATING POSSIBLE BOGUS KIDNAPPING

TEXT.P: A Taiwan man allegedly kidnapped in mainland China and subsequently released is under suspicion of masterminding a ploy to bilk money out of a Taiwanese friend who was also abducted in the same incident.

A Taiwanese manager of a U.S.-based metal company, surnamed Chen, and his close friend, surnamed Kao, were taken by three mainland Chinese men on Sunday in the southern city of Shenzhen, police sources said Friday.

According to Chen, the kidnappers wanted 500,000 (NT$2.09 million) renminbi in ransom. But while Chen was held in a fishing boat, Kao was released and instructed to return to Taiwan and pick up a ransom from Chen's family of HK$10 million (NT$44.21 million).
Angry and anxious, Chen's family asked Kao whether the ransom was negotiable. Kao said he would do his best to "talk to the gangs."
Kao told Chen's family that he had purchased a round-trip ticket and had to return to mainland China. He said that Chen's life could be at risk if he was not back in Shenzhen by Thursday afternoon.

Chen was released and returned to Taiwan safely late Thursday evening via Hong Kong after Kao was paid NT$280,000 by Chen's family. Kao was picked up by police in Taiwan before he could board a flight to the Hong Kong.

Police are questioning the veracity of Kao's claim that he was acting under the sole instruction of his kidnappers and are looking closely at his statement to see if Kao was actually working with his captors to extort money from Chen's family.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK MARKET DROPS FURTHER

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost more ground Friday, with the weighted price index dropping 80.54 points to close at 4,904.34.
Market turnover also fell from Thursday's level to NT$36.76 billion (US$1.08 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: CAMBODIAN NOBEL LAUREATE PRAISES ROC'S DEMINING EFFORTS

TEXT.P: Visiting Cambodian Nobel Peace Prize laureate Tun Channareth lauded the Republic of China military's efforts Friday to clear landmines from the frontline island of Kinmen.

Channareth flew to Kinmen from Taipei early in the morning in the company of senior executives of the Taipei-based Eden Social Welfare Foundation to see for himself demining operations at the ROC's offshore defense outpost.

Channareth, an ex-soldier who lost both his legs in 1982 when a landmine exploded while he was patrolling with his troops near the Thai border, first visited the state-owned Taiwan Power Co.'s Tashan power plant where he was briefed on the company's achievements in demining land nearby.
Channareth then toured six previous minefields near a temple in Hsiputou village. The landmines in those regions had all been cleared by a British demining firm.

Channareth recognized the ROC's efforts to demine its outlying islands. As Kinmen still has many minefields, Channareth suggested that the ROC seek the U.N. demining task force's assistance in clearing all remaining Kinmen minefields.
According to Channareth, the U.N. task force offers free demining services and its senior engineers can help teach ROC military servicemen demining technology and expertise.
"Seeking U.N. assistance, you will be able to save much money," Channareth said.
Until now, the ROC has employed foreign companies to assist in demining its offshore defense outposts.

Channareth also urged Taiwan to pass a law banning landmines to prevent further civilian injuries from accidental contact. Channareth said the legislation is necessary because the ROC is not a U.N. member and therefore ineligible to join some 130 countries in signing a 1997 international anti-landmine convention in Ottawa.

Huang Huang-hsiung, a member of the watchdog Control Yuan who was also visiting Kinmen to inspect its demining operations, told Channareth that he would help push for enactment of an anti-landmine law in Taiwan.
To his knowledge, Huang said the ROC's Ministry of National Defense, the Kinmen County Government and Taiwan Power Co. have gradually carried out various demining programs.

With the opening of Kinmen for sightseeing and direct "mini three links" with mainland China's port city of Xiamen, Huang said, the ROC military has attached great importance to demining certain Kinmen areas and adopt necessary supporting measures to facilitate demining operations and ensure the offshore island's security.

According to U.N. estimates, about 110 million landmines still exist in the world, with over 100,000 of them located on the ROC-held frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu, both of which lie far closer to mainland China than to Taiwan.
Channareth, now a goodwill ambassador of the International Campaign to Ban Landmines (ICBL), said he looks forward to seeing Kinmen become a landmine-free island.

Channareth flew back to Taipei after concluding his Kinmen visit in the afternoon. During his Taiwan visit, Channareth will take part in a series of activities aimed at helping the public understand the hazards of landmines and experience how it feels to be confined to a wheelchair.
The ICBL is a coalition of more than 1,000 non-governmental organizations in over 60 countries. The campaign and its director, Jody Williams, were also co-recipients of the 1997 Nobel Peace Prize.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, June 22, or the 2nd day of the fifth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1757: George Vancouver, the British explorer after whom Canada's Vancouver Island and Vancouver are named, is born.
1815: Napoleon Bonaparte of France abdicates for the second and last time after his defeat at the battle of Waterloo.
1893: Thomas Francis Bayard presents his credentials as U.S. ambassador extraordinary and plenipotentiary to Great Britain, becoming the first actual American ambassador after more than a century of ministers carrying out diplomatic representation.
1906: U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt sues John D. Rockefeller's Standard Oil Company for operating a monopoly.
1910: Paul Ehrlich, the German bacteriologist and immunologist who won the 1908 Nobel Prize for physiology with Elie Metchnikov, announces he has discovered the definitive cure for syphilis.
1933: German Chancellor Adolf Hitler outlaws both the Communist Party and the National Peoples Party, permitting only one political party -- the National Socialist German Workers Party or Nazi Party -- thus beginning a Nazi dictatorship.
1936: Chen Chi-tang rebels in Canton, China.
1937: Joe Louis becomes the heavyweight boxing champion of the world. He holds the title for nearly 12 years until his retirement in March 1943. The powerful American fighter successfully defended the title for a record 25 fights.
1940: The French formally surrender to Germany when Gen. Charles Huntziger of France signs terms of surrender with Germany at Compiegne, in the same railroad car in which Gen. Foch had received the German surrender in 1918.
1941: Germany invades the Soviet Union, commencing Adolf Hitler's "Operation Barbarossa."
1941: Italy and Romania declare war on the Soviet Union.
1947: Outer Mongolian troops, aided by planes bearing Soviet insignia, renew attacks on Chinese troops at Peitashan in eastern Sinkiang Province.
1956: Republic of China Air Force jet fighters shoot down four Chinese communist MiG-17s and damage two others over Matsu, an ROC-controlled island in the Taiwan Strait.
1965: Japan and South Korea sign a treaty in Tokyo establishing diplomatic relations.
1977: Gen. Hu Lien, former deputy commander-in-chief of the ROC Army and ROC ambassador to South Vietnam, dies of a heart attack at the age of 71.
1979: U.S. President Jimmy Carter signs into law the "Taiwan Relations Act" in order to resume arms sales to the ROC following the break of diplomatic ties.
1987: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo receives Prime Minister Ezekiel Alebua of the Solomon Islands.
1987: Fred Astaire, one of America' best-loved entertainers, dies at the age of 88. He co-starred with Ginger Rogers, Judy Garland, Lesley Caron and Audrey Hepburn in musicals including "Top Hat" and "Shall We Dance?"
1987: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes the revision of the Law on Negotiable Instruments, retroactively abolishing criminal penalties for over 30,000 people convicted of issuing bad checks before January 1987.
1989: Seven students involved in the Tiananmen Square protests in Beijing are executed after televised "show trials."
1991: The ROC gains admission to the Central American Development Bank.
1995: British Prime Minister John Major resigns as head of the ruling Conservative Party in order to conduct a party leadership election.
1999: The second Asia-Pacific technology conference opens in Taipei with over 100 fund managers from around the world gathering to discuss developments in the region's high-tech industry with the heads of high-tech companies from Taiwan, Hong Kong, Singapore, Japan, South Korea and Thailand.
1999: The Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission releases a draft of the ROC's first white paper on maritime policy to stress ROC sovereignty over the disputed Spratly and Tiaoyutai islands.
2000: Taiwan's computer giant Acer Group has recently begun participating in the "Oxygen Alliance" project led by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) in the U.S. The alliance is a five-year project aimed at making computers more widespread and less physically intrusive.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is not right to refuse to enter public service. For if it is wrong to ignore the duties arising out of the relations between the members of a man's family, how is it right for a man to ignore the duties he owes to his sovereign and country?"

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK MARKET LOSES MORE GROUND

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost more ground Friday amid heavy selling in the electronics sector on gloomy market prospects.
The benchmark TAIEX weighted price index fell 80.54 points to close at 4,904.34.
Market turnover shrank to NT$36.76 billion (US$1.08 billion) as investors were reluctant to buy. A total of 1.14 billion shares changed hands during the four-and-half-hour trading session.

Of the eight major categories of stocks, three posted gains, with plastics and chemical issues moving up by an average of 0.9 percent; construction issues up 0.8 percent; and paper stocks up 0.1 percent.

The remaining five categories all dropped from Thursday's levels, with cement issues falling 0.9 percent; foodstuffs slid 0.6 percent; textile stocks edging down 0.3 percent; electronics issues plunging 2.2 percent; and financial stocks tumbling 1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 331 to 169, with 99 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXTRAORDINARY LEGISLATIVE SESSION TO BE HELD JUNE 26-27

TEXT.P: Legislators confirmed Friday that an extraordinary session of the Legislative Yuan will be held June 26-27.
But legislators in an official meeting Friday had mixed reactions about whether to invite Premier Chang Chun-hsiung to report and field questions at the special session.
Opposition legislators want the premier to report on the current economic situation, why the six financial bills need to be passed as quickly as possible and the effect of their passage.

The Legislative Yuan ended early this month with a backlog of outstanding bills, including six bills that the Cabinet said are crucial to the ongoing financial reforms. As the next session will not begin until September, the Cabinet has since lobbied for the convening of the provisional session to pass the bills, which include a financial holding company bill.

Legislator Chou Hsi-wei of the opposition People First Party said that the provisional meeting will convene only because of economic problems and the premier should explain the relationship between the six bills and the economy.
Legislators Kuo Su-chun, Hsiao Chin-lan, and Chiang Yi-wen of the Kuomintang questioned whether the financial holding company bill would only help certain companies.

Legislator Lai Shyi-bao of the New Party said that the amendment to the public bond bill is important, but is not included in the six bills, and he said the premier should report on this in the extraordinary session.

Legislator Tsai Huang-liang of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party expressed the hope that his colleagues would put away ideological differences and work toward passing the six financial bills for the development of the nation.
A procedural committee in the legislature later decided the agenda for the first day meeting June 26, which will have the premier reporting in the afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: CASES OF DOMESTIC VIOLENCE INCREASE SHARPLY

TEXT.P: Reported cases of domestic violence in Taiwan have increased dramatically over the past several months, women's welfare activists said Friday.

Acting on police requests, courts around the island issued a total of 9,941 protection orders between July 2000 and April 2001 aimed at protecting women who were physically battered by men in the house, said officials from the Association for the Promotion of Women's Rights during a public hearing marking the enactment of the Domestic Violence Prevention Act some two years ago.
The number of protection orders issued during the July 2000-April 2001 period nearly doubled the figure reported for the same period of the previous year, association officials said.

Meanwhile, according to a survey by the association, only about 113 "batterers" have been ordered to receive medical examinations, health checks and related education under a program called the Batterer Treatment Program that was initiated by the Department of Health two years ago.

Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Wang Li-ping, who was also present at the hearing, said it is worrisome that the number of assailants, mostly husbands, who are taking part in the treatment program is proportionally much less than that of the people who were physically hurt.

In addition, Wang noted, the efficiency of the Batterer Treatment Program is doubtful as even some personnel in charge of the program in several medical institutions do not exactly know what it is they are expected to do.

Meanwhile, the Bureau of Social Affairs under the Taipei City Government reported Friday that the bureau's hotlines set up for victims of domestic violence received nearly 5,000 calls for help during the first five months of this year, a noticeable jump from some 2,000 posted for the same period last year.

Bureau Director Chen Chiao-mei said the sharply increased number of emergency calls for help indicated that domestic violence is on the rise as a result of various reasons, including the floundering economy, rising unemployment and the decline in social order.

Chen pointed out, however, that the nearly 5,000 calls included calls made by the "batterers" themselves, who accused the bureau of "intervening" in their own business at home and called the bureau "to leave them alone."

DOC.HEADLINE: SURVEY SHOWS PROFESSIONALS STILL IN HIGH DEMAND
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 22 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo) (By Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Taipei, June 22 (CNA): A survey conducted by the manpower resources Web site CTCareer indicates that professionals in IT engineering, finance and securities, business administration and marketing are still in high demand on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

CTCareer has recently joined with the manpower resources Web site in mainland China -- ChinaHR -- to offer information on job opportunities. An analysis of job opportunities posted on the two Web sites shows that managers with MBA degrees are offered the highest salaries plus bonuses and allowances among all the employed population.

The highest-paid professions in mainland China are business managers, securities analysts, IT engineers and marketing specialists; in Taiwan, the jobs with the highest income include IT engineers, financial analysts, marketing specialists and computer science research personnel.

The survey shows that employees of the computer and Internet sectors topped the list of high-income groups on both sides of the Taiwan Strait before the burst of the Internet bubble. The highest paid sectors now are medical instruments, telecommunications, and electronics -- areas still related to high technology.

Although the average annual income of the employed in Taiwan is 3.5 times of that in mainland China, Taiwan's job seekers are interested in opportunities across the Strait, especially in business administration.
According to CTCareer, the average annual income of the employed in Taiwan in 2000 was NT$502,488; in mainland China, the amount was equivalent to NT$147,390.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, HK, M'LAND CHINA SCHOLARS HOLD SYMPOSIUM ON CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: Scholars and analysts from Taiwan, Hong Kong and mainland China discussed cross-strait relations in a just concluded symposium in Hong Kong, a Hong Kong daily reported Friday.

Ming Pao Daily News reported that the participants mainly discussed the "one China" issue, the consensus reached between the negotiators from two sides of the Taiwan Strait in 1992, economic exchanges of both sides of the Taiwan Strait and the year-end elections in Taiwan.
The report said that the symposium, held June 19-20, was not open to the public and mainland China scholars had repeated the stance of the mainland.

Mainland participants included Zhang Nianchi, director of the Shanghai-Taiwan Research Institute; Xu Shiquan, director of the Institute of Taiwan Studies of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences. Taiwan scholars included former Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Chang King-yu; Yen Chien-fa, director of the department of mainland affairs of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP); Wu Jui-kuo, special assistant to People First Party Chairman James Soong; and Chang Jung-kung, director of the Department of Mainland Affairs of the Kuomintang.

Sources said that director reaffirmed China's stance that resumption of the cross-strait dialogue should be based on the 1992 consensus, adding that "one China" principle will be the condition for resuming cross-strait relations.

While Yen of the DPP reaffirmed President Chen Shui-bian's words on the gradual integration of economic and cultural relations between the two sides before they can discuss future political integration, adding that the current cross-strait policy will be to maintain the status quo.
The reports quoted an unnamed source as saying that the symposium was basically discussions on theory and was not an attempt to announce government policies.
But observers said that given the background of the participants, the conclusions reached at the meeting could have an effect on Taipei and Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures markets closed lower Friday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for July moved down 25 points to close at 4,965, with 5,636 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for August lost 50 points to finish at 4,938, with 16 contracts traded. September futures lost 34 points to close at 4,955, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 4,990 for July, 4,988 for August, 4,989 for September, 5,031 for December and 4,978 for next March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, both closed lower.

July TE futures moved down three points to close at 249.3, with 1,346 contract transactions, while August TE futures lost three points to finish at 250, with three contracts traded. September TE futures moved down three points to close at 253, with four contracts traded, and TE futures for next March lost 3.5 points to finish at 254, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
July TF futures moved down 2.4 points to finish at 671.2, with 486 contracts changing hands, while TF futures for next March lost 5.4 points to close at 667, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: N.T. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.022 against the U.S. dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Friday, closing at 34.434.
The local currency opened Friday at 34.427 and was traded between 34.427 and 34.499.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$582.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MANGOES TO MAKE INROADS INTO SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: Confident of the quality of their produce, fruit farmers in Tainan County are preparing to export mangoes from southern Taiwan to Singapore, sources from the Tainan County Farmers Association reported Friday.

An initial 500 metric tons of fresh mangoes from Tainan County are expected to be shipped to Singapore from June 30, with the quantity eventually being increased to some 1,000 metric tons when the current season ends, said Tainan County Magistrate Chen Tang-shan, who was presiding over a mango promotion held at the farmers' association headquarters.

According to association officials, Tainan County fruit farmers have some 7,800 hectares of land under mango cultivation, from which some 99,000 metric tons of mangoes are expected to be harvested this year.
Harvest season for mangoes in southern Taiwan begins around early June and lasts for about two months.
The Tainan County Farmers Association began to export fresh mangoes to Hong Kong in 2000 and the fruit was favorably received, association officials said.
Mangoes from Tainan County constitute about 80 percent of Taiwan's entire exports of this fruit, they noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIVE TAIWAN BUSINESS TYCOONS ON FORBES BILLIONAIRE LIST
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, June 22 (CNA) (By Sherman Wu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Five Taiwan business tycoons were ranked among a 2001 world billionaire list published Thursday by Forbes magazine.

Lin Yuan Group Chairman Tsai Wan-lin, the richest man in Taiwan with assets totaling US$3.8 billion, was ranked in 104th place on the 538-member list, ahead of 174th-placed Formosa Plastics Group Chairman Y.C. Wang with total assets worth US$2.7 billion, and 198th-placed Hou Hai Precision Industry Chairman Terry Kuo with assets worth US$2.3 billion.
C.F. Koo of Koo's Group and Barry Lam of Quanta Computer were placed in 363rd and 452nd spots, respectively, boasting assets of US$1.4 billion and US$1.1 billion, respectively.

Affected by a sluggish Taiwan stock market over the past year, assets of the five top business leaders all shrunk. Tsai suffered the largest loss of 43 percent over the 2000 level of US$6.7 billion, while Wang also saw a 37 percent fall in the value of his assets.
Fourteen entrepreneurs from Hong Kong and one from mainland China also made the list.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FIRST LADY CHRISTENS EVERGREEN VESSEL IN KOBE
DOC.DATELINE: Kobe, Japan, June 22 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China First Lady Wu Shu-chen presided Friday over a christening ceremony for a new container ship for Taiwan's Evergreen Group in the southwestern Japanese port city of Kobe.

The ceremony was held at the Mitsubishi Heavy Engineering dockyard, where the vessel was built. The 78,000-ton container ship, named Ever Eagle, rumbled down the slipway after Wu smashed the traditional bottle of champagne across its bows.

Chen Che-nan, deputy secretary-general to the president, ROC Representative to Japan Lo Fu-chuan, Evergreen Group Chairman Chang Jung-fa and many other dignitaries from Taiwan and Japan attended the new freighter's christening and launch ceremony.

The Ever Eagle is the 28th container ship that Mitsubishi has built for Evergreen Group, which operates the world's largest container shipping fleet. It is also the largest and most advanced container vessel that Mitsubishi has ever constructed.
Wu arrived in Kobe Thursday for the ceremony at the invitation of Evergreen Chairman Chang and was scheduled to return to Taipei Saturday.
It was Wu's second private trip to Japan since her husband Chen Shui-bian assumed the ROC presidency in May 2000.

Wu, who has been confined to a wheelchair since being paralyzed in a car accident 16 years ago, gave an interview to the Japanese business daily Sankei Shimbun shortly after her arrival in Kobe in which she said she has suffered heavy stress since her husband took office in the ROC's first-ever democratic transfer of power between different political parties.

Nevertheless, she went on, she also feels proud that her husband became the ROC's youngest president through a democratic election. "I hope that my husband will redouble his efforts to help Taiwan win dignified status in the international community," she said.

Wu was run over by a car one day after her husband was defeated in a county chief election in 1985. "The incident is a painful memory, but I have never been daunted by any adversity. I tend to face realities with an optimistic attitude. I don't like to indulge myself in old memories and always set my eyes on the future," she explained.

The Sankei Shimbun also published an article in its Friday issue titled "First Lady in a Wheelchair." The article said Wu's straightforwardness and sense of humor have won her high popularity among the people of Taiwan.
The paper is scheduled to publish details of Wu's interview in early July.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP LU RELEASED FROM HOSPITAL

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu was released from National Taiwan University Friday.
The vice president was rushed to the hospital June 18 and admitted with emergent muscle spasm.
Lu expressed her hope Friday that President Chen Shui-bian and other government leaders "will take care of themselves for the sake of the nation."
She said that she was also given a thorough physical checkup, the results of which show that her health is better than many people of her age.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH COURT UPHOLDS ARMS BROKERS' SENTENCES

TEXT.P: A high Court upheld Friday jail terms handed down by a lower court to an arms broker and his former navy contact for bribing navy officers in 1993.
The Taiwan High court upheld the 14-month sentences for arms broker Cheng Cheng-kuang and former navy captain Liu Shu, in addition to one-year deprivation of political rights for each of them.
It was the fourth review of the case since it was sent back by the Supreme Court to the Taiwan High Court for further review.
Neither of the defendants were present in the courtroom to hear the sentences, which can still be appealed within ten days.

Cheng, a Taiwan representative for Italy's Fincantieri shipbuilder, was charged with offering bribes through Liu to a group of navy officers in 1993 in exchange for a contract to sell the navy a spy ship at a price of NT$1.24 billion.
The ship, described in relevant documentation as "an oceanographic research ship" was actually designed for gathering military intelligence and was christened the Takuan after being delivered.
The bribery came to light as a result of a navy probe into the mysterious death in 1993 of a captain who was responsible for the navy's weapons procurement.
Liu retired from the navy before the case was unearthed and worked as Cheng's aide.
A retired navy deputy commander-in-chief and five middle-ranking navy officers have been arrested and given various prison terms in connection with the scandal.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO TIMETABLE FOR TAIWAN OPENING TO MAINLAND CHINESE TOURISTS: MAC

TEXT.P: The opening of Taiwan's doors to mainland Chinese tourists will hinge on interaction between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, a senior mainland affairs official said Friday.

"We'll not set a timetable for implementing the new open-door policy. When mainland people are allowed to make sightseeing trip to Taiwan will depend on cross-strait interaction," said Deng Chen-chung, a vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).
Deng pointed out that the direct "mini three links" program launched early this year can serve as a reference for other cross-strait opening measures.
Because of Beijing's reluctance to throw its full support behind the "mini three links" program, Deng said, Taiwan has encountered many difficulties implementing the program.

"Therefore, we must exercise more prudence in opening our doors to prospective mainland tourists," Deng said, adding that as allowing mainland people to make sightseeing trips to Taiwan will involve far more complicated issues than the implementation of the "mini three links" program, cross-strait interaction is very important.
"The new open-door policy presents many problems, such as entry quotas, emergency incident handling, law enforcement and handling of rule-breaking incidents," Deng explained.
Against this backdrop, he went on, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should enter discussions to ensure the new policy's smooth implementation.
Deng further said the Republic of China government will exercise great flexibility in cross-strait interaction and engagements.

He also said that the MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, will study the feasibility of allowing Taiwan companies to directly investment in mainland China. At present, cross-strait investment must be made via a third place.

"When the overall climate and conditions reach maturity, including mainland China's commitment to protecting Taiwan investors' legitimate rights and interests, we'll allow direct cross-strait investment," he said.

Touching on the mainland's protest over the ROC military's test-firing of U.S.-made Patriot missiles Wednesday, Deng said the tests were part of a routine weaponry testing program and had no other purpose.
Deng also clarified that MAC Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen didn't oppose Formosa Plastics Group's (FPG's) new investment projects in mainland China.

According to local press reports, FPG Chairman Wang Yung-ching's recent slam on the government's cross-strait policy was mainland a backlash on Tsai's opposition to FPG's mainland invesmtent applications.

Deng said the reports were not true. "During a recent mainland invesmtent projects screening meeting, Tsai only suggested that the FPG present more detailed information about its new mainland investment projects, including capital sources, management plans and profitability forecast," he explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2001 KIWANIS ANNUAL CONFERENCE KICKS OFF IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 2001 annual conference of Kiwanis International will kick off in Taipei Saturday, in which around 10,000 Kiwanis members from around the world will take part.
President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu are slated to attend the formal opening and closing ceremonies in Linkou, suburban Taipei, Sunday and Tuesday, respectively.

Speaking at a welcome party for foreign participants of the conference at the Taipei International Conference Center, Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Wu Tzu-dan said the Republic of China has long spared no efforts to promote humanitarian activities around the world. As a constructive member of the international community, the ROC is also committed to helping developing countries pursue peace and prosperity, he said.

For instance, he said, the ROC government has sent agricultural technology and medical missions to help many countries improve their rice and vegetable cultivation and to help eradicate disease. The Taipei authorities also provide vocational training to help those countries develop their small- and medium-sized businesses, he went on.

In addition, Wu said, the ROC also cooperates with the Asian Development Bank, the European Bank of Reconstruction and Development and the Inter-American Development Bank to offer multilateral financial and technical assistance to needy countries.

Stressing that it is very important to build mutual trust and parity to create a better world, the vice foreign affairs minister said Taiwan needs international backing and friendship and he voiced his hope that "foreign friends" can extend their support to Taiwan.
Kiwanis International is the only one of the world's four major non-governmental organizations in which Taiwan can participate under its formal national title of the ROC.

After five years of efforts, Kiwanis International finally approved Taipei's application to sponsor this year's annual conference, the first of its kind in Asia since the organization's establishment in 1915.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OFFICIALS TO ATTEND AEI WORLD FORUM
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 21 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Several senior Republic of China officials are slated to attend the 20th American Enterprise Institute World Forum beginning Friday to explore various economic, social and security issues facing the world community today.
The ROC delegation includes opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien, Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao and ROC Representative to the United States Chen Chien-jen.
Lien was invited because he formerly served as ROC vice president.

Also attending the traditionally informal annual meeting are senior U.S. officials including Vice President Dick Cheney, Deputy Defense Secretary Paul Wolfowitz and Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan, as well as heads of major international corporations and government officials from other nations.
The three-day forum is chaired by former U.S. President Gerald Ford, who established the forum in 1982 and hosts it annually in Beaver Creek, Colorado.
Lien, Chien, Wolfowitz and former U.S. Ambassador to mainland China James Lilley are scheduled to co-chair a small group discussion session on U.S.-Asia exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN ARRIVES IN DENVER FOR AEI-SPONSORED WORLD FORUM

TEXT.P: Republic of China opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan arrived in Denver Thursday to attend the world forum sponsored by the American Enterprises Institute (AEI) from June 22-June 25, KMT sources said Friday.
Joe Rogers, deputy governor of Colorado State, played host at a tea party in honor of Lien shortly after his arrival.

Lien visited Brown Palace Hotel, where Dr. Sun Yat-sen, founder of the Republic of China, stayed during the Wuchang uprising of Oct. 10, 1911. The hotel is considered by the KMT as being of historical significance.

Lien, who was invited to the AEI forum because he is a former ROC vice president, was presented with a baseball by Rogers, while representatives of the KMT's Chicago Chapter later presented him with a memorial plaque.

In addition to Lien, the ROC delegation to the AEI forum includes President of the Control Yuan Frederic Chien and Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao. The three-day discussion will be chaired by former U.S. President Gerald Ford.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FINANCE MINISTER TO SEEK EUROPEAN INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: Republic of China Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang is scheduled to depart Saturday at the head of a delegation of local finance and high-tech industry leaders for a 10-day tour of major European financial centers.
Yen is slated to host investment seminars in London, Amsterdam, Frankfurt, Zurich and Paris to explain the ROC government's financial reform efforts.
He expressed optimism that the six financial reform bills to be debated at an upcoming extraordinary legislative session while he is in Europe will be passed.
He added that the recent lackluster performance of the local stock market is only a "temporary phenomenon" and will not interfere with his mission to attract additional foreign investment.

Vice Finance Minister Sean C. Chen is scheduled to follow up with a similar trip to Singapore, Hong Kong and Tokyo from Sept. 10-14, while Yen will head for Boston, San Francisco and New York Sept. 20-26.

According to the Ministry of Finance, foreign institutional investors from the United States account for 36 percent of all foreign investment in the local stock market, while another 18 percent come from Japan, Hong Kong and Singapore.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. OFFICIAL SUPPORTS CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE WITH NO PRECONDITIONS

TEXT.P: Echoing the position taken by the Republic of China government, a senior U.S. official said Thursday that Taiwan and mainland China should resume dialogue without preconditions.

Torkel Patterson, senior director of Asian affairs at the National Security Council, said that ROC President Chen Shui-bian "has followed the correct path" because he has been open to discussion with Beijing.
"I don't think there needs to be any preconditions for dialogue between the two sides," Patterson added in answer to a reporter's question related to the stalemate between Taipei and Beijing.

This is believed to be the first time a Bush administration official has openly expressed support for Taipei's position that no preconditions be set for cross-strait dialogue but it was not known whether he was following the official government line on the issue.

Beijing has insisted that Taipei recognize the "one-China" principle before any talks can restart, while Chen's government says the question of "one China" can be an item on the agenda, but not a precondition.

Patterson also reiterated the long-standing U.S. position of not mediating between the two sides. "I'd encourage both sides to meet and discuss but the U.S. will not try to get involved in the process," he said.

On a trip to mainland China by President George Bush scheduled for October, Patterson said that Bush will try to establish good channels of communication with his mainland Chinese counterpart, Jiang Zemin.
At the same time, he said, Bush will be straightforward in expressing his views on Taiwan and human rights.

Bush is expected to visit Beijing after attending an Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum summit in Shanghai. His first trip to Asia since becoming president will first take him to Japan and South Korea, major U.S. allies in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO INVESTMENT IN MAINLAND CHINA AT PRESENT: TSMC CHIEF

TEXT.P: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corporation (TSMC) Chairman Morris Chang said Friday that his company is not planning to invest in mainland China as the government has not yet lifted its ban on mainland-bound investment by local hi-tech industries.

Although conditions exist in mainland China to make possible six-inch silicon wafer manufacture, Chang said TSMC is not planning to invest there within the next three or five years because his company needs 12-inch silicon wafers and because of the current government ban on hi-tech investment in the mainand by Taiwan firms.

Noting that other industries may have different reasons for investing in the mainland and that he is not in a position to comment in this regard, Chang, however, said that the government should remove its restrictions and he stressed that market mechanisms should be respected.
The TSMC head made the remarks during an interview with local and foreign reporters.

In the face of fierce competition from mainland China and Taiwan's deteriorating investment climate, Chang asserted that professional talent is the foundation for Taiwan's economic progress and that the government must take action to improve the country's overall conditions, ranging from adequate water and electricity supplies to upgraded living standards, in order to keep local talent at home.
"In essence, the government must transform Taiwan into an advanced country if it is to achieve this goal," he noted.

Speaking of his career, Chang said he has not yet thought of retiring and stressed that TSMC is a team infused with professional elite. He likened the ties between TSMC and its clients to the dynamics of a "big family" and attributed the company's success to technology, service and good customer relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TZU CHI MEDICAL CENTER TAKES TWO MORE BONE MARROW DONATIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Hualien County, eastern Taiwan, June 22 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Buddhist Tzu Chi Medical Center completed two separate bone marrow-drawing operations Wednesday and Friday and rushed the marrow to hospitals where two foreign leukemia sufferers are awaiting transplant surgery.
As of Friday, there have been 283 marrow donations conducted by the Tzu Chi Medical Center. Of these, 169 are in the international donation category.
The two recipients of the most recent marrow donations are a 34-year-old Japanese man and an 11-year-old Thai boy.
Hirakazu Kanemori, the Japanese recipient's doctor, flew to Hualien Wednesday to receive the marrow, which was donated by a 28-year-old Taiwan woman.
This is Kanemori's second marrow transplant case and he said that judging by the great success of the first, he is confident that he will smoothly complete the second.

The marrow donor for the Thai boy is a 31-year-old Taiwanese bus driver who told volunteers at the Tzu Chi Medical Center that he would like to "adopt" the Thai boy if he is given the chance to meet the boy after he recovers from the transplant surgery.

DOC.HEADLINE: COSTA RICAN AMBASSADOR HOSTS FESTIVAL TO MARK 60 YEARS OF ROC TIES

TEXT.P: Oscar Alvarez, Costa Rican ambassador to the Republic of China, hosted a "Latin Night" Friday to mark 60 years of diplomatic relations between Taipei and San Jose.
More than 60 dignitaries, including ranking ROC government officials such as Judicial Yuan Vice President Cheng Chung-mo and other foreign envoys stationed in Taiwan, took part in the event.
Alvarez thanked the enthusiastic participation of Taiwan friends and voiced his deep hope that bilateral ties between the two countries will last forever.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SOY SAUCE MAKERS SAY PRODUCTS SAFE

TEXT.P: Two Taiwan soy sauce makers Friday shrugged off British warnings that some of their products may contain levels of cancer-causing chemicals above safety standards.
