A spokesman for Wan Jia Shian Brewery Co., one of Taiwan's largest soy sauce manufacturers, said the company has improved its soy sauce production process and product quality in recent years to meet international standards.
The spokesman said more than 80 percent of their soy sauce products are produced by brewing and that fermented soy sauce is free of any 3-MCPD -- a chemical that can cause cancer if taken daily.

British health officials began removing 22 brands of soy sauce across the country Thursday after a warning from the Food Standards Agency (FSA) that they contained levels of 3-MCPD above safety guidelines.
The brands were imported from Thailand, China, Hong Kong and Taiwan. Products of two Taiwan firms -- Wang Jia Shian and Kimlan Foods Co. -- were included in the list.
The Wan Jia Shian spokesman said the company didn't have any sales agent in Britain. "We must check to determine whether those products were produced at our plants in Taiwan or the United States."

The spokesman said soy sauce products produced in Taiwan were mainly for domestic sales and exporting to Japan and Singapore. "All of our products have consistently been sent to the Hsinch Foodstuff Industry Development Institute for inspection before they hit market shelves to ensure that our product quality meets international standards," he explained.
Over the past 20 years, the spokesman went on, all soy sauce products produced by the company's U.S. plant have also met U.S. safety standards.

At present, countries around the world have different requirements for 3-MCPD levels. The 15-member European Union has set a very stringent requirement of "no more than 0.01 parts per million (ppm)" to be implemented next year. The current U.S. requirement is 0.1 ppm.
In Taiwan, the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) is planning to require soy sauce makers to keep 3-MCPD levels below 0.1 ppm from July 2002. The current requirement is no more than 1 ppm.

Noting that only soy sauce produced through the process of hydrolysis may contain levels of 3-MCPD, the Wan Jia Shian spokesman said such products only account for a very small portion of the company's overall output.
Moreover, he said the company has also taken measures to minimize 3-MCPD levels in its products made through the hydrolysis process.
He added the company is expanding its plants in Taipei and Pingtung counties to produce fermented soy sauce which is free of any 3-MCPD level.

Another Taiwan soy sauce maker, Kimlan Foods Co., said the samples tested by the British Food Standard Agency could have come from its mainland Chinese plant, where their products had traceable levels of 3-MCPD. The company stressed that it has already stopped such production there, adding that the products available in Britain might be inventory products.
"We have shifted focus to production of 3-MCPD-free soy sauce by brewing," a Kimlan spokesman said.

Meanwhile, Chen Shu-kong, director of the DOH's Bureau of Food Sanitation, said his bureau has advised local soy sauce makers to gradually reduce the levels of 3-MCPD. "We will be moving to internationally accepted standards," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN UNEMPLOYMENT RATE INCREASED IN MAY TO 4.22 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan unemployment rate surged to a new record high of 4.22 percent in May, which is a historic high for any May and any single month, economics officials said Friday.

Because of the increasing number of firms that have closed or downsized, the jobless population surged from 385,000, or 3.96 percent, in April to 411,000, or 4.22 percent, in May, according to officials from the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics.
The figures are the highest ever since the government began to compile unemployment figures in 1978.
The May figures brought the average monthly jobless population in the first five months of this year to 374,000 and threatened to push the unemployment rate to 4.1 percent for the whole year.

A breakdown of the unemployed population found that people with senior high school-level education registered the highest unemployment rate of 4.65 percent, followed by those with a junior high school-level education, at 4.59 percent.
The figures might contradict a long-held belief that higher education is a key to job security, according to analysts.
An analysis by age shows that unemployment is most rampant among people aged between 15 and 24, with 9.38 percent of them out of a job, followed by those aged between 25 and 44, at 4.87 percent.
The seriousness of the situation is also indicated by an ever-longer unemployment period for these out of work, which lengthened from 25.5 weeks on average in April to 25.7 weeks in May.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL SCIENCE COUNCIL APPROVES GENETIC MEDICINE RESEARCH PROJECT

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level National Science Council formally approved a three-year, NT$7.48 billion (US$217 million) project Friday to kickstart a national program on genetic medicine research.

The move is part of a Republic of China foray into genetic technology research under the leadership of Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, a Nobel Chemistry laureate who heads the nation's highest research institution.

The project, which is scheduled to begin next year, will focus on the genetic diagnosis and genetic treatment of diseases such as hepatitis-B, the establishment of a domestic genetic database, the impact of genetic technology on law, ethics and society, and the nurturing of related talent to promote faster domestic research advancement in biomedical technology.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIA LISTS CHINESE LANGUAGE AS COURSE CHOICE IN HIGH SCHOOLS
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, June 22 (CNA) (By Sherman Wu & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: The Indonesian Ministry of Education has decided to list mandarin Chinese as a foreign language course selection in Indonesian senior and junior high schools, the Lianhe Zhobao newspaper said Friday.

The paper quoted Indoinesian Education Ministry officials as reported that in order to upgrade the quality of Chinese language teachers, the ministry has decided that teachers must be university graduates in Chinese Language or equivalent, or must have passed the sixth grade of national examinations in Chinese language.
Several noted universities in mainland China currently offer Chinese language courses via correspondence through a cooperation agreement with local universities.

Experts from Guangdong have already sponsored five seminars on the cultivation of Chinese language teachers in several Indonesian cities and more than 1,000 local teachers have graduated from the seminars. Experts from Beijing are also expected to come to Indonesia to help with teacher training.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT CALLS FOR VISA FOR ROC PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The European Parliament passed a resolution June 14 that calls for European Union members to grant a visa to the president of the Republic of China for a private visit, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) reported Friday.
The appeal was included in a series of measures passed by the European Parliament, according to a MOFA press release.

The resolution said conflict-avoidance and the maintenance of peace, such as encouraging dialogue between mainland China and the ROC, should be one of the political pillars of future Asia-European conferences.
Therefore, the resolution calls for the European Council and European Union member states to grant visas to the ROC president and government officials to facilitate their trips to EU member states.
In a separate resolution on the same day, the European Parliament also reiterated a call for the opening of an EU representative office in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Taiwan's exports and industrial production continue downward streaks while jobless rate rising.
The China Times:
Jobless rate reached all-time high of 4.22 percent in May as all business sectors were affected by economic slowdown.
The United Daily News:
DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh took the initiative to meet with former President Lee Teng-hui to discuss possible cooperation in year-end elections.
The Liberty Times:
Typhoon Chebi to sweep southeastern Taiwan today.
The China Post:
Typhoon Chebi to strike today, warn meteorologists.
The Taiwan News:
Unemployment hits all-time high of 4.22 percent.
The Taipei Times:
MAC denies halting Formosa Plastics Group's mainland investment projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, June 23, or the third day of the fifth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1537: Spanish explorer Pedro de Mendoza dies at sea on his way back to Spain from Argentina. He headed an expedition to explore South America, during which he reached the Rio de la Plata area of Argentina and founded Buenos Aires.
1683: William Penn, the English Quaker and advocate of civil and religious liberty, signs a treaty with chiefs of the Lenni Lenape tribe under an elm tree at Shakamaxon, Philadelphia, in a bid to guarantee peace for his colony.
1757: British troops under Robert Clive defeat the Nawab of Bengal, Siraj-ud Dawlah, at the Battle of Plassey, thereby making possible the British annexation of Bengal.
1848: Adolphe Sax, French instrument maker, is granted a patent for the saxophone, a wind instrument in various sizes with a single-reed mouthpiece and a curved conical metal tube.
1894: British monarch Edward VIII is born. He abdicated in order to marry the divorcee Mrs. Simpson and took the title Duke of Windsor.
1894: Alfred Kinsey, the American zoologist and sociologist best known for his studies of human sexuality and his books "Sexual Behavior in the Human Male" and "Sexual Behavior in the Human Female," is born.
1912: Alan Mathison Turing, British mathematician and computer expert, is born. He pioneered the Turing machine, which greatly advanced computer development.
1914: The Kuomintang is reorganized as the Chinese Revolutionary Party in Tokyo, with Dr. Sun Yat-sen elected director-general.
1922: Republic of China Foreign Minister Wu Ting-fang, who is concurrently governor of Kwantung Province, dies of illness in Canton at the age of 81.
1952: The four characters "Wu Wang Tsai Chu," an ancient saying that translates as "Do Not Forget National Humiliation in Times of Peace and Security" are inscribed on a huge stone at Taiwushan on ROC-controlled Kinmen. The inscription is based on the handwriting of President Chiang Kai-shek.
1956: Col. Gamal Abdel Nasser, a man who stands as a symbol of Arab nationalism from the Atlantic Ocean to the Persian Gulf, is elected president of Egypt.
1969: President Chiang Kai-shek nominates Gen. Chen Ta-ching as governor of Taiwan.
1975: The First Television Conference of the Cultural and Social Center for the Asian and Pacific region opens in Taipei with more than 47 delegates from South Korea, Hong Kong, the United States, the Philippines, Thailand, Kuwait, Australia and the ROC attending.
1975: The Chinese delegation to the 21st Asian Film Festival returns from Jakarta with seven awards.
1980: Sanjay Gandhi, son of Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi and next in line for political power, is killed in an airplane crash.
1983: The U.S. Supreme Court rules that Congress cannot veto presidential decisions.
1985: An Air India Boeing 747 jet en route from Canada explodes off the Irish coast, killing all 329 people on board.
1987: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes the National Security Law during the Period of National Mobilization for Suppression of the Communist Rebellion. After the law becomes effective, the Emergency Decree in Taiwan and the Pescadores (Penghu) is lifted.
1991: The International Monetary Fund agrees to offer associate membership to the Soviet Union.
1995: American microbiologist Jonas Edward Salk dies in California at the age of 80. The medical pioneer developed the first effective killed-virus vaccine against polio in 1954.
1999: The ROC and the Republic of Panama sign a press cooperation agreement in Taipei to step up bilateral relations.
2000: ROC Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao meets with Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski, agreeing to strengthen exchanges of ranking officials as a way to further enhance substantive ties between the two countries. ROC-Macedonia diplomatic ties ended less than a year later when Macedonian pro-Beijing forces gained the upper hand in the nation's coalition government and transferred diplomatic recognition to Beijing.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who withdraws himself from the world for no other reason than to show his personal purity of motive is one who breaks up one of the greatest ties in the foundation of society. A good and wise man, on the other hand, who enters the public service, tries to carry out what he thinks to be right. As to the failure of right principles to make progress, he is well aware of that."

DOC.HEADLINE: SKIRTS OF TYPHOON CHEBI SWEEPING THROUGH SOUTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Typhoon Chebi, which had intensified from a tropical storm over the past few days and was packing winds of up to 155 kilometers per hour Saturday, was expected to sweep across the southern tip of Taiwan later in the day, according to the Central Weather Bureau (CWB).

Chebi, the second typhoon to threaten Taiwan this year, was expected to storm across the Taiwan Strait and make landfall near Fuzhou in the southeastern mainland Chinese province of Fujian by midnight, bureau meteorologists said.

Inspecting operations at the CWB and at a Cabinet-level central disaster contingence center, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung called for residents in low-lying areas in southwest Taiwan to heighten vigilance against possible sudden inundations of sea water, as Chebi brought torrential rains and heavy seas to the island and its surrounding waters.

Chang also instructed related government agencies to render every possible help to Tungkang-based fishing boat Chingchingfa No. 16, which had lost contact in the open seas off the northern Philippines, after sending an SOS to the Tungkang Fishermen's Association late Friday.

In addition, Chang said, some 3,000 mainland Chinese fishermen and laborers are currently taking shelter in fishing boats anchored at seaports around the island because of the typhoon. He instructed relevant government agencies to take good care of them.

According to the weathermen, as of Saturday noon Chebi was centered 90 km south of Taiwan's offshore island of Penghu. With a radius of 200 km and packing winds of up to 165 kph, the weather system was moving north-north west at a speed of 25 kph.
Bearing the brunt of Typhoon Chebi were the southern counties of Tainan, Kaohsiung, Pingtung, the eastern counties of Hualien and Taitung, as well as the offshore islands of Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu.

Flights to and from the southern and eastern cities and the offshore islands were canceled, the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) reported. Most of the international flights were not affected, although Kaohsiung-Phnom Penn flights and Kaohsiung-Macau flights were rescheduled some two hours earlier, according to CAA sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FINANCE MINISTER TO SEEK EUROPEAN INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: Republic of China Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang departed Taiwan Saturday at the head of a delegation of local finance and high-tech industry leaders for a 10-day tour of major European financial centers.

Yen said prior to departure that the group will host investment seminars in London, Amsterdam, Frankfurt, Zurich and Paris to introduce Taiwan's financial market and to welcome additional foreign investment in the island.

He said that he has already scheduled one-to-one side-meetings in London with the investment representatives of 17 large international funds, while nearly 200 other investment representatives are also attending the same seminar.
Yen pointed out that the Taiwan financial market's ability to weather the Asian financial storm several years ago is testimony that it is comparatively stable and worth investing in.
He added that he will also explain the ROC government's financial reform efforts at the seminars.

Touching on President Chen Shui-bian's recent proposal to consider giving the economy a shot in the arm through tax cuts, Yen said that such an economy-stimulating measure is often used elsewhere in the world.
However, he added that it will require the Legislative Yuan's cooperation to amend related laws, as well as further coordination and discussion with other government agencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FISHING VESSEL TRAPPED IN STORM CONDITIONS

TEXT.P: A Taiwan fishing vessel that lost power and began taking on water in northern Philippine waters radioed for help Friday evening, prompting the Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs to request emergency assistance from the Philippines.
According to Foreign Ministry officials, Philippine navy and coast patrol ships were still waiting to mount a rescue mission as of Saturday morning due to the adverse weather conditions.
The northern Philippines and southern Taiwan had taken a battering from Typhoon Chebi.

According to the ROC military rescue center, an ROC vessel was dispatched to the vicinity of the Chingchingfa No. 16's last reported coordinates but was unable to find the vessel, which also could not be picked up by radar.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-PRESIDENT TO VISIT CORNELL UNIVERSITY
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 22 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Some 700 overseas Chinese in the eastern United States will welcome former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui at a reception upon his arrival at Ithaca, New York, on June 26.
Lee is scheduled to arrive in Los Angeles June 24 for a two-day stay and then fly to Ithaca, where he will visit his alma mater, Cornell University.

It will be Lee's second visit to Cornell. He last visited in 1995 for the inauguration of a "Lee Teng-hui professorship" when he was still president of the ROC -- a visit that incurred a strong protest from Beijing, which saw the visit as a move to publicize Taiwan independence.

Reception organizers said that because Lee is now a private citizen, the preparations for his visit have been completed much more easily than for his previous trip, as U.S. officals were under less pressure from Beijing to restrict Lee's activities.

Lee is scheduled to deliver a lecture at the reception and Cornell University President Hunter R. Rawlings III is expected announce at a luncheon June 27 the formation of a "Lee Teng-hui Science Research Center" on campus.
Lee will also visit his granddaughter-in-law, who is now studying at Cornell. He is scheduled to fly to Los Angeles June 28 and to return to Taiwan July 2.

DOC.HEADLINE: YOUNG CANCER PATIENTS LEAVE FOR `LOVE' TRIP TO SOUTH KOREA

TEXT.P: Seven young Taiwan cancer patients left for a specially arranged visit to South Korea Saturday to convey the "love" and concern of the people of Taiwan to South Korean schoolchildren suffering from various forms of cancer.

The seven youngsters -- Lin Chia-sheng, Wei Li-jung, Hsu Wei-ling, Hsieh Shu-jung, Chen Hsun-fang, Lu Chien-yi and Kuo Wei-chi -- were all recipients of a special global award dedicated to encouraging people to love their lives.

The five-day trip is being organized by the Chou Ta-kuan Culture Foundation with a view to encouraging local young cancer victims to pass on their personal experiences in fighting cancer to their South Korean counterparts, said founder Chou Chin-hua.
Interior Minister Chang Po-ya met with Chou and the seven child cancer patients before their departure and praised the children's courage in facing adversity and standing up to help foreign friends.
Chou founded the Chou Ta-kuan Foundation in memory of his son Ta-kuan, who died at the age of 10 in May 1997 from a rare form of cancer known as Rhabdomioparcoma.
During the group's South Korean visit, Chou said, the Korean version of a collection of poems written by his son during the last eight months of his life will be launched.

Ta-kuan wrote a total of 42 poems in his hospital bed in which he described the physical and mental ordeals he endured in his struggle for survival. The themes of the poems range from portrayals of doctors and nurses to descriptions of documents diagnosing his conditions to odes to life, health and freedom. The Chinese edition of the collection remains high on the local best-sellers' list.

Chou said royalties from the Korean edition will be donated to a South Korean foundation dedicated to helping child cancer patients, as well as to South Korea's Central 119 Rescue Team, which helped rescue a child in Taiwan's Nantou County in September 1999 following the disastrous 7.6-magnitude earthquake of Sept. 21.

In support of the special travel program, the Taiwan branch of U.S. Federal Express Corp. donated 1,000 model aircraft to the Chou Ta-kuan foundation for presentation to sick South Korean schoolchildren.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN MPS DELIGHTED TO HAVE IMPACT ON BEIJING

TEXT.P: A Canadian member of parliament who led a cross-party coalition to rescue a Falun Gong practitioner from the mainland Chinese authorities said Saturday: "It is reassuring to see that by raising awareness and embarrassing rogue governments, we can have some impact."

Zhu Ying, a student of Montreal's Concordia University, was arrested in Guangzhou May 10 and kept incommunicado for 33 days. She was freed after waves of support from Canada pressured the mainland government to let her return to Canada. She arrived back in Montreal June 21.
Zhu told a press conference Friday that her detention was a nightmare in which she was kidnapped, interrogated, threatened and mentally tortured by state security officials.

Scott Reid, a Canadian Alliance Party MP of Ontario set up the cross-party pressure campaign to release Zhu along with Concordia University Student Union, the Canadian Federation of Students, Amnesty International and other NGOs.

On May 31, Reid organized a joint news conference with other MPs to call for her release and they also sent a letter to mainland Chinese Ambassador Mei Ping requesting a meeting to discuss Zhu's case.

With 80,000 Canadians having signed a petition in support of Falun Gong practitioners in mainland China, Zhu vowed to dedicate herself to the release of all fellow practitioners detained in the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: QUANTA POISED TO GROW BIG

TEXT.P: Despite a slump in the market, Taiwan-based Quanta Computer has been undergoing an extensive boost in production and personnel this year, with the aim of replacing Japan's Toshiba as the world's largest notebook maker.

Quanta estimates that it will reach nearly full production capacity during the third quarter and ship approximately 4.2 million notebook computers this year, a 60 percent increase from the 2.5 million units it shipped last year.
Quanta Chairman Lin Pai-li said that his company plans to hire 1,000 people at a job fair later this month in response to its production expansion and technical research advancement requirements.
The large-scale mass hiring sets Quanta apart as one of the few companies in Taiwan that are growing rapidly despite the sluggish overall economy.

Envisioning that PCs of the future will be merely "cubes" sitting in a room while in constant communication with cellular phones or PDAs -- making it unnecessary even to carry around notebook computers -- Lin said that Quanta is also exploring the field of telecommunications.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CULTURE OFFICIAL VISITS SHANGHAI
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, June 23 (CNA) (By Liao Chen-yi and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taipei City's top culture official called Saturday for all Chinese, regardless of where they live, to get rid of the "Opium War complex" that has plagued them with a sense of inferiority and humiliation for decades.

Lung Ying-tai, director of the Bureau of Cultural Affairs under Taipei City Hall, who arrived in Shanghai Friday for a nine-day "city cultural exchange" visit, urged the Chinese to free themselves from the "psychological nightmare" of the last century so as to allow them to explore the much wider horizons of international cultural assimilation.
Writer-turned-official Lung is on her first visit to mainland China since she assumed her post a couple of years ago.

Speaking at a symposium on comparisons between city cultures of Shanghai and Taipei held at Shanghai Normal University, Lung said Taipei's solid economic power and well-educated citizens are the city's advantages over Shanghai.
The facts that Taipei never experienced any type of "cultural revolution" and "suffered no cultural faults or isolation," gives it another competitive edge over Shanghai, Lung claimed.
She went on, however, that the spate of "inflow" into Shanghai in recent years of "Taiwanese cultural, economic and creative elite," is a worrisome trend to the Taiwan authorities.
Lung urged residents of Taipei and Shanghai to "cooperate" while remaining "competitors," so that people from both cities can create their own strengths through benign competition.

Lung, who lived in Germany as a scholar and writer before being invited by Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou to return to Taipei to become an official in 1999, was also a columnist for the Shanghai-based Wen Hui Bao daily for three years prior to 1999.

Her crisp comments, particularly a 1998 short story titled "Alas! The Shanghai Men," which has been translated into English by the BBC, have made her one of the most popular Chinese-language writers in Shanghai, Hong Kong and Singapore.

At the invitation of the Wen Hui Bao and Shanghai Normal University, Lung, a graduate of Taiwan's National Cheng Kung University who obtained a doctorate in literature in Europe, delivered a keynote speech to the international academic symposium on the city cultures of Shanghai and Taipei.

Lung said she is visiting Shanghai mainly to "knock on the door" of Shanghai and to see for herself whether the largest and most prosperous city in mainland China is ready to assimilate culturally with other peoples and cities in the Asia-Pacific region.

As Taipei City's "International Village of Arts" festival is set to open in August, Lung said she will invite some Shanghai artists to visit Taipei for the event to pave the way for future exchanges of artists from the two cities.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUS HIJACKER IN STANDOFF WITH TAIPEI POLICE

TEXT.P: Taipei police SWAT teams were mobilized Saturday as a man claiming to have a "judicial grievance" took a tour bus and its passengers hostage at gunpoint and demanded to meet with Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan.

The hijacker also asked to see Environmental Protection Administrator Hau Lung-pin, who handled a similar crisis in 1998 when he talked a man holding 26 bus passengers at knifepoint for over two hours into surrendering to police.

Chen and Hau both rushed to the city's Chung Ching North Road, where the hijacker had brought the bus to a halt, but remained behind the scenes to allow the police to continue attempting to engage the hijacker in communication.

As of 5 p.m., after a nearly three-hour standoff, police had still been unable to determine how many hostages were aboard the bus because all the curtains were drawn and the hijacker refused a cellular phone offered to him.
All communication was being carried out via handwritten signs that were held up to the bus windows and the hijacker had not revealed himself, instead relying on a female hostage to read the notes.
Little was known about the hijacker, other than that he claimed to be from Miaoli County in western Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT INSPECTS DISASTER RELIEF CENTER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian made an inspection tour of an inter-department disaster relief center at the National Fire Administration (NFA) to show his concern about damage caused by typhoon Chebi.
Chen said he appreciates the devotion of staff of various government disaster relief agencies in their efforts to help minimize typhoon-related damage and human casualties.
He reminded relevant central government agencies and local-level governments that although the typhoon was gradually moving away from Taiwan, it might still bring heavy rain to the island.
"We should pay heed to the possibility of flooding in low-lying areas after the typhoon," Chen said.

The president also ordered relevant government agencies to pool their resources and join forces with the Philippines to rescue a Taiwan fishing boat, which had lost contact since sending out a distress call in northern Philippine waters Friday evening.

The Tungkang-based Chingchingfa No. 16 radioed for help after it lost power and began taking on water. According to Foreign Ministry officials, Philippine navy and coast patrol ships were still waiting to mount a rescue mission as of Saturday morning due to the adverse weather conditions.
The northern Philippines and southern Taiwan had taken a battering from typhoon Chebi.

According to the ROC military rescue center, an ROC vessel was dispatched to the vicinity of the Chingchingfa No. 16's last reported coordinates but was unable to find the vessel, which also could not be picked up by radar.
Typhoon Chebi hit southern and southeastern Taiwan and the offshore island of Penghu Saturday with strong winds and heavy rain.

Preliminary government tallies showed that a 45-year-old man in Chengkung, Taitung County had gone missing after a plastic raft he and five other men were boarding capsized offshore. The five other men were rescued.
Meanwhile, a 72-year-old man in the southern port city of Kaohsiung was injured by a falling shop billboard. He was later reported to be in stable condition after medical treatment.
The typhoon also caused a blackout to more than 37,400 households in the Kaohsiung area and landslides were reported on some mountain highways.
The Central Weather Bureau, which forecast that Chebi would make landfall near Fuzhou in southeastern mainland China early Sunday, was expected to lift a land typhoon warning later Saturday.
Airline flights to and from Taiwan's southern and eastern cities and offshore islands were canceled due to the typhoon, but international flights were generally unaffected.

DOC.HEADLINE: JIANG ZEMIN DESCRIBED AS DECISION MAKER ON TIANANMEN

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin Was one of the core members of the leadership group behind the 1989 military crackdown on student demonstrators in Tiananmen Square, according to the mainland's former de facto envoy in Hong Kong.

Xu Jiatun, former director of the Xinhua News Agency's Hong Kong Branch, was quoted Saturday by the local English-language iMail as saying that Jiang, who was Shanghai party chief at the time of the crackdown, was called to Beijing and was involved in the decision-making in the days leading to the bloody June 4 massacre of student demonstrators in which hundreds were murdered.

Xu reportedly said Jiang was put in charge of daily business in the Secretariat of the Central Committee, the party's nerve center, before the military's killing spree, even though he was still nominally only secretary of the party's Shanghai municipal committee.

Jiang, then a member of the decision-making politburo, was elevated to membership of the Politburo's Standing Committee (PSC). It was in his new roles as a member of the PSC and chairman of the secretariat that Jiang was involved in the handling of the crackdown, Xu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: `FAST 30' CAMPAIGN AIMS AT RAISING NT$ 100 M FOR THE NEEDY

TEXT.P: In what has become an annual tradition, a "fast to help" drive to give participants the experience of feeling hunger and prompt them to make generous donations to the needy, is scheduled to kick off in Taipei July 1.

This year's annual 30-hour fast, also sponsored by World Vision Taiwan (WVT), is aimed at raising NT$100 million (US$2.9 million) to help war-torn and famine-stricken people in 13 countries and 24 areas around the world, including Kenya, Mozambique, Kosovo and El Salvador, said WVT Executive Director Tim Shao.
Shao said this year's "Fast 30," the 12th of its kind, carries the theme of "live simply and help generously."

Despite the current floundering economy in Taiwan, he added, affluent Taiwanese people can still easily help people in need simply by treating themselves to one less feast at a restaurant or by not going to a movie and donating the money saved.
Just NT$30 is capable of buying food for a child in Ethiopia for two months, while NT$50 is capable of providing relief packages for a four-member family in war-torn Kosovo, Shao noted.
Shao said that for many previous participants, "Fast 30" is a fond memory.

Eighty-one-year-old grandfather Yin Chi-shan, who has taken part in the annual "Fast 30" drive every year since 1992, said he enjoys the program, which actually helps himself while helping other people.
Noting that fasting for 30 hours poses no problem for him, Yin called for more young people to join him to support the program.

The 2001 "Fast 30" drive is scheduled to run until Sept. 30. During the period, 750 supporters will experience their 30-hour fasts on a train which will travel around the island July 28-29 to solicit more support for the drive.
WVT, one of Taiwan's major charity organizations, has sponsored "Fast 30" for the past 11 years, in addition to sponsoring other relief and medical aid activities in many countries around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI BUS HIJACKING STANDOFF ENDS WITH NO INJURIES

TEXT.P: A nearly four-hour standoff between Taipei police and two husband-and-wife bus hijackers ended Saturday evening when SWAT teams stormed the bus and rescued the 13 hostages on board.
No one appeared to have been injured in the process and police said that guns wielded by the two hijackers turned out to be fake.

The standoff came to an end quickly when Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan acquiesced to the hijackers' demands by appearing in the dense crowd of rubberneckers that had gathered at the scene. A woman stepped off the bus and rushed toward Chen to deliver a petition of grievance. The contents of the petition were not immediately known.

Seconds after the woman left the bus, SWAT teams detonated two flashbangs to disorient the remaining hijacker still aboard the bus and shattered a window to attract his attention. Other policemen swarmed in from the other side and took control of the situation.
The incident began at around 2 p.m., when the hijackers forced the tour bus they were on to come to a stop and then demanded to meet with Chen.

They also asked to see Environmental Protection Administrator Hau Lung-pin, who handled a similar crisis in 1998 when he talked a man holding 26 bus passengers at knifepoint for over two hours into surrendering to police.
Chen and Hau both rushed to nearby police precincts but remained behind the scenes to allow the police to continue attempting to engage the hijacker in communication.
For over three hours, police had been unable to determine how many hostages were aboard the bus because all the curtains were drawn and the hijackers refused a cellular phone offered to them.

All communication had to be carried out via handwritten signs that were held up to the bus windows and the hijackers had not revealed themselves, instead relying on a female hostage to read the notes.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAVY RETAINS LAWYER TO HANDLE WARSHIP KICKBACK SCANDAL: NGHQ

TEXT.P: The Navy General Headquarters (NGHQ) said Saturday it has commissioned a lawyer to protect its legitimate rights in a kickback scandal involving its purchase of six French-made Lafayette-class frigates 10 years ago.

The NGHQ issued the statement after French judicial authorities said Friday they had launched an investigation into the payment of illegal commissions in France to grease the wheels of the warship sale to Taiwan in 1991.
French defense contractor Thomson-CSF sold the six frigates to the Republic of China Navy for 16 billion French francs (about US$2.8 billion).
According to the terms of the purchase contract, the ROC Navy is entitled to reclaim any money later found to have been paid in the form of commission for the deal.

French judicial authorities decided to probe the frigate commission scandal after the discovery by Swiss authorities of a bank account containing 250 million Swiss francs (US$142 million), which press reports there said was linked to a vast corruption scandal at the French oil giant Elf.

The investigation also followed remarks by former French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas, who told a newspaper this week that US$500 million in commissions were paid for the frigate sale and that the money went to "personalities -- political and otherwise, in France and elsewhere."
Dumas also said the commissiomns should never have been paid because the contract had already been drawn up and agreed upon.

The frigate sale -- in which Elf officials were paid by Thomson-CSF to procure support for the deal -- is one of several cases under investigation in the many-tentacled scandal involving the former state-owned French oil company. Dumas was last month sentenced to six months in jail for receiving gifts paid for by Elf as part of its lobbying effort.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT SHOULD LEARN FROM PRIVATE ENTERPRISES: PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou County, Central Taiwan, June 23 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that the government should learn from private enterprises and "join them in doing many things."

Chen made the remarks while attending a double ceremony to celebrate both the Yu Chih primary school's 100th founding anniversary and the inauguration of its new premises following reconstruction made necessary by the Sept. 21, 1999 earthquake.
Chen first presided over a ribbon-cutting ceremony to unveil a monument built to commemorate the post-quake reconstruction of the school.
The reconstruction project was jointly sponsored by the Ministry of Education, the China Times, Winbond Electronics Corp. and Walsin Lihwa Corp.

Speaking at the ceremony, Chen stressed the importance of education and children to the development of the nation, saying that the reconstruction is not only the creation of a physical environment but also the reconstruction of "a room for humane concerns."

In addition to thanking the private enterprises involved for their assistance in the reconstruction, Chen particularly praised their spirit and said the government should learn from private enterprises' efficiency.

After listening to a recital of poems and watching a traditional folk dance performance, Chen cut a birthday cake with a 95-year-old alumni of the school to celebrate the school's 100th founding anniversary.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
INTERNATIONAL KIWANIS ANNUAL CONFERENCE OPENS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: International Kiwanis opened its 2001 conference in Taiwan Sunday, beginning with a carnival at the plaza in front of the Taipei City Hall.
The carnival, organized by the Republic of China Kiwanis club, featured dragon dancing performed by a group of disabled in wheel chairs, folk dancing, and other folk entertainment.

Wu Hui-wan, the head of the ROC Kiwanis club, said that so far, some 4,000 Kiwanians from around the world have descended on the island for the meeting. Most of them are visiting the island for the first time.
She said she hoped the three-day conference will offer the conference-goers from abroad a rare chance to experience the culture of Taiwan.
The International Kiwanis 2001 conference will formally begin Monday in a stadium in Taoyuan County. President Chen Shui-bian is slated to deliver a speech at the opening.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON CHEBI CAUSES LOSSES OF NT$ 130 MILLION TO AGRICULTURAL SECTOR

TEXT.P: Typhoon Chebi caused losses worth more than NT$136 million to the local agricultural industry after sweeping through southern and southeastern Taiwan Saturday, the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture reported Sunday.

According to initial estimates by the council, damage to the agricultural and farm sectors in six countries have topped NT$136 million as of Sunday noon, including NT$135 million worth of damage to agricultural and farm products, and NT$1 million and NT$900,000 worth of damage to paddy fields and livestock.

Southern Pingtung County and southeastern island county of Penghu suffered the largest losses of NT$45.3 million and 43.6 million respectively, followed by Kaohsiung County with NT$37.9 million, the council said, adding that Tainan County, Taitung County and Hualien County also suffered minor damage.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESCUERS FIND NO TRACE OF CREW OF MISSING FREIGHTER

TEXT.P: Rescuers in southern Taiwan on Sunday found an oil slick and three life buoys in the sea where a Belize-registered freighter, the Guang Yuan, issued a mayday signal the previous day.

But rescuers, bracing strong winds and incessant rains brought about by typhoon Chebi, said they have found no trace of the 22 mainland fishermen aboard the freighter. The search will continue despite the treacherous weather conditions, they added.

The life buoys marked Guang Yuan were found along the coast between the mouth of the Tsengwen Creek and old Kuohsin Harbor, while helicopters detected an oil slick five nautical miles south of Tsengwen Creek.

The 4,200-ton freighter, carrying 5,300-tons of gravel, was 1.8 nautical miles off Anping Harbor Friday afternoon, but could not enter the harbor because of the low tide, and temporarily anchored to wait for the next high tide the following day.
But as typhoon Chebi hit southern Taiwan Friday night, Kaohsiung Harbor prohibited ships from entering or leaving the harbor because of the high winds and seas.
Port authorities contacted captain Zhou Wenchao of the Guang Yuan Saturday to see if everything on the ship was all right and were reassured about the situation.

But typhoon Chebi, passing through Tainan quickly Saturday afternoon, whipped up rough waves off Anping Harbor. Anping Harbor received a call for emergency assistance from the Guang Yuan at 3:30 p.m. Saturday, and failed to receive further response when it tried to contact the freighter at 3:55 p.m.
The coast guard sent patrol boats and the navy also immediately sent vessels to join the search, but no survivors have been found.
Anping Harbor said that the Guang Yuan, carrying a heavy load of grovels, could have been seriously affected by high waves and could have sunk quickly.

Anping Harbor is the supplementary harbor of Kaohsiung. Currently, about five or six freighters that ply international routes moor in Anping Harbor every month, but tugboats and professional guides have to depart from Kaohsiung to lead the vessels into the harbor.

Kaohsiung Harbor is now planning to build four tugboats and station one in Anping Harbor after they are completed in July or August. In addition, a professional guide will also be stationed in Anping Harbor.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LEADER MEETS US VICE PRESIDENT AND OTHER POLITICAL LEADERS
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 23 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan met with United States Vice President Dick Cheney at a symposium in Beaver Creek, Colorado Saturday while on a visit to the United States.

Lien also exchanged views with U.S. Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan and other U.S. political leaders at the World Forum called by the American Enterprise Institute, a Washington-based think tank.
But both Lien and the U.S. political leaders he met had no comment on the nature of their discussions.
The former Republic of China (ROC) vice president also gave a five-minute speech on Asia-Pacific security and Taipei-Beijing ties during a panel discussion on U.S. engagement in Asia.

Lien said the consensus reached in 1992 between Taipei and Beijing on "one China" -- that there is only one China with its definition varied between the two sides -- is the key to reopening dialogue across the Taiwan Strait.
The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), whose party charter calls for an independent Taiwan, has turned it back on the consensus since it was swept into power one year ago, Lien said.

The DPP's deliberate vagueness on the island's ties with mainland China has reinforced Beijing's long-standing mistrust of it and made it wary of President Chen Shui-bian's calls for peace and detente with Beijing.
Fredrick Chien, president of the ROC Control Yuan, and James Lilley, the former U.S. ambassador to Beijing made introductory remarks at the discussion.
U.S. Deputy Secretary of Defense Paul Wolfowitz, who was a co-chairman of the discussion, was notably absent from the symposium.
Saturday's discussion was closed to the media and its participants refused to reveal the contents of the meeting in line with the ground rules of the forum.

ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao will give a speech Sunday at another panel discussion on global and regional security which will bring together many U.S. leaders including Vice President Dick Cheney.
The three-day forum on international issues will close on Sunday. It has brought together political leaders around the world. This is the 20th time it has been held.
Lien will leave Colorado for San Francisco Sunday morning, while Tien will head for San Francisco later that day on his way back to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST COMMERCIAL BANK TO APPLY TO OPEN OFFICE IN MAINLAND

TEXT.P: The First Commercial Bank is planning to apply to the government in the coming days to open an office in Pudong, near Shanghai, after the Ministry of Finance publishes measures to allow such practices.

The finance ministry is to announce measures Tuesday allowing local banks to open offices in mainland China and the First Commercial Bank will file an application with the ministry following its formal announcement Tuesday.
The aim of the bank's plan to open a Pudong office in mainland China is to gather first-hand information and to serve Taiwan business people there, bank officials said.
The finance ministry will make a final decision on the bank's application within two months.

The Executive Yuan has already approved measures that qualify the following banks to apply for government permission to set up branches or offices in foreign countries or areas: the Bank of Taiwan, the Land Bank of Taiwan, the Taiwan Cooperative Bank, Hua Nan Commercial Bank, Chang Hwa Commercial Bank, the United World Chinese Commercial Bank, Chinatrust Commercial Bank and the International Commercial Bank of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: COAST GUARD YET TO PINPOINT LOST FISHING BOAT

TEXT.P: Rescue ships from the Coast Guard Administration have yet to pinpoint the location of the Pingtung-based Ching Ching Fa No. 16 fishing boat which lost power in waters northeast of Luzon Island when Typhoon Chebi was sweeping across southern Taiwan and the Bashi Channel.

Cutters belonging to the Coast Guard Administration in Kaohsiung tried to search for the ill-fated fishing vessel, but torrential rains and strong winds forced them to return to Kaohsiung Harbor Saturday after failing to pinpoint the vessel.
The U.S. Navy has also sent helicopters to help search for the 41-ton fishing boat, a spokesman for the government's Disaster Contingency Center under the Ministry of the Interior said.
Skipped by Chen Shui-fa, the vessel with six crew members radioed for help when the vessel was hit by Typhoon Chebi.
The was one Filipino and four Indonesians on board.

DOC.HEADLINE: COUPLE DETAINED BY PROSECUTOR FOR HIJACKING TOUR BUS

TEXT.P: The couple who hijacked a tour bus Saturday along the freeway leading to Taipei have been detained by a prosecutor Sunday for further questioning after preliminary interviews by police.
Police said that Chang Wen-liang and his wife, Chuang Pao-yun, appeared to be mentally unstable. Their discussions wandered wildly in diverse directions while answering questions from the police.

Investigators speculated that the two commandeered the tour bus to underline their grievances against the government over three separate incidents. One was that the couple said that a prosecutor failed to question men who had allegedly beaten their son. Another was a dispute over water and electricity bills. The couple also said that they had requested a copy of their land title documents but had been refused and they thought that this was unfair.

Although the couple brought with them stacks of court documents and copies of their written complaints filed with various government agencies, police were baffled by their erratic writings, one investigator said.

The couple boarded a Kaohsiung to Taipei tour bus at Chubei, in Hsinchu County on Saturday morning. The man then brandished a pistol converted from a toy while the bus was near Chungli, Taoyuan County. He demanded that the driver go the office of the Ministry of the Interior in Taipei.
One of the 14 passengers taken hostage called police on his mobile phone.
Police surrounded the bus and the two hijackers refused to get off, demanding to see the minister of justice to submit a written complaint.
After a four-hour standoff, police stormed the bus and arrested the couple. Nobody was hurt in the incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGENTS UNCOVER DRUG TRAFFICKING RING; SEIZE 55 KG OF AMPHETAMINES

TEXT.P: Agents of the Criminal Investigation Bureau Sunday uncovered a drug trafficking ring and discovered 55 kilograms of amphetamines in Hsinchu.
A spokesman for the bureau said that the drug trafficking ring was run by Peng Tsun-fung, a gang leader whose activities covered areas ranging from Hsinchu to Keelung.
Peng, along with his family and other gangsters in the Hsinchu area, has illegally smuggled drugs into Taiwan from the mainland by using fishing boats and bamboo rafts.
Preliminary estimates by police say that the ring has so far brought over 1,000 kilograms of amphetamines into Taiwan.

In order to control the drug supply in Taiwan, Peng sent his son to mainland China to set up a drug supply center, police said, adding that his brother and his nephew acted as go-betweens for Taiwan and the mainland to pick up and arrange for transportation and storage of the drugs.

The bureau uncovered a drug trafficking ring run by Lin Lien-sheng and his family and discovered 30 kilograms of amphetamines at the Patoutze Fishing Port near Keelung last April. Lin had obtained the drugs from Peng's ring, police said.
Chen Tai-hung, a shipowner and a follower of Peng, built hidden compartments into six holds of a fishing boat in May to store the drugs, police said.
The boat took advantage of Typhoon Chebi to navigate directly to Fuzhou in mainland China and brought back the drugs hidden in the modified holds to Naliao Fishing Port near Hsinchu.

The anti-drug police unit under the command of Prosecutor Wu Tsung-kuang of the Panchiao Prosecutor's Office discovered 55 packages or the equivalent of 55 kilograms of amphetamines in a secret hold under the bulwark of the ship Sunday morning.
Police then took into custody six suspects including Peng in Hsinchu.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MEDALIST INDUCTED INTO US HALL OF FAME
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 23 (CNA) (By J.J. Huang and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan Olympic medalist Chi Chen was formally inducted into the Hall of Fame for excellent athletics and scholarship at Rhode Island University in New York Sunday.

Speaking at the induction ceremony, the bronze medal winner in the 80-meter hurdles at the 1968 Mexico summer Olympics said she deemed the induction a great honor which will encourage her to do more in physical education and to serve as a model for young athletes.
Chi said that she has devoted her whole life to dispelling the stereotyped view of Chinese athletes as "people with strong limbs but poor heads," but admitted that little progress has been made.
Chi is the first Asian woman and the second Asian inductee to the hall after the famous Japanese volleyball coach Yasutaka Matsudaira was vote in.
Chi was one of 20 scholars and athletes selected by a screening committee of the biannual International Scholar/Athlete Hall of Fame for her contribution to promoting athletic activities.

After a brilliant career as a female sprinter on the field which has seen her competing in 154 international events and winning 153 medals, Chi was elected a legislator for three consecutive terms and is a member of the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee.
She was inducted into the Hall of Fame with 19 others from around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE OF 22 MAINLAND CREW OF MISSING FREIGHTER FOUND

TEXT.P: One of the 22 mainland Chinese crew of a missing freighter has been rescued, it was reported Sunday.

A Belize-registered, 4,200-ton freighter was reported missing Saturday afternoon off Anping Harbor, Tainan, after it sent a distress signal to harbor authorities amid high winds and seas brought about by Typhoon Chebi.
The Coast Guard Administration sent helicopters and the navy also sent vessels to search the area, but only found an oil slick and three life buoys without any trace of the missing crew Sunday.

But fisherman Hsu Tsung-ming of Chiayi County, while operating in area between Chiayi and Yunlin, found a mainland fisherman, Chu Liwu, caught in the oyster beds near Waishantingchou, off Yunlin County.

Chu, 33, was still conscious when he was rescued. He suffered from multiple bruises and was mildly dehydrated. He was rushed to the hospital for emergency treatment. Doctors said that he had multiple cuts on both feet, but is otherwise uninjured.
The coast guard learned that another crew member of the missing freighter may have been picked up by a passing foreign ship and is in the process of confirming the report.
Meanwhile, the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) informed its mainland counterpart about the continued search for the missing crew of the freighter Sunday.

The SEF sent a message to the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) that despite the treacherous weather conditions the search operations will continue, and will inform it about the result later.
The SEF and ARATS are two separate bodies set up by Taipei and Beijing respectively to deal with civilian exchanges in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT LEAVES FOR U.S. TO VISIT ALMA MATER

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui left Taiwan for the United States to visit his alma mater, Cornell University, Sunday evening.

During his stay in the U.S., Lee will attend the dedication of a scientific center named after him and visit his granddaughter, Huang Yi-ning, who is currently studying at Cornell. He will also meet with overseas Chinese and his supporters.

The former ROC president, who earned a Ph.D. in agricultural economics in 1968 at Cornell, will attend the inauguration of the Lee Teng-hui Institute for Scientific Research, which is dedicated to nano-technology research.

Lee will arrive in Los Angeles Monday and will be welcomed by ROC Representative to the United States Chen Chien-jen. After a one-night stay in Los Angles, Lee and his entourage will take a chartered plane Tuesday to Ithaca, New York, where Cornell is located.
Lee will attend a welcoming party Tuesday night, and meet with around 300 overseas Chinese.
On Wednesday, Cornell University will host a ground-breaking ceremony for the institute, and use a computerization to show what the finished structure will look like.

Cornell will also arrange for Lee to take a tour of the Cornell campus, where he last visited as the president and delivered a resounding speech in 1995. Lee will attend a private dinner given in his honor by the president of the university, Hunter R. Rawlings III.
Lee will take a chartered plane to Los Angles June 28 and meet with his supporters there before concluding his visit July 1 and returning to Taiwan July 3.
Lee, who originally planned to return to Cornell University April 30, postponed his trip because he went to Japan to have a checkup of his heart in late April.

DOC.HEADLINE: IS DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT SHIPPING A BOON FOR TAIWAN PORTS?

TEXT.P: Taiwan shipping companies are eagerly awaiting the opening of direct links between mainland China and Taiwan, but a recent assessment by the government shows that increased commerce will come with a cost.

According to the report made by the Institute of Transportation under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC), Keelung, Taichung and Kaohsiung harbors will face stiffer competition from mainland China with the establishment of direct shipping ties across the Taiwan Strait regardless of whatever advantages resulting from the new openness.
The assessment forecasts that by 2004, direct cross-strait shipping will save as much as NT$1 billion in transshipment fees for Taiwan shipping companies should the links be opened.

The institute made the forecast on the grounds that direct Taiwan-mainland shipping will save transshipment costs of US$100 for each TEU (twenty-foot equivalent unit) containers and that the number of cross-strait transshipment TEUs will increase to 1 million units in 2004.
The three international ports of Keelung, Taichung and Kaohsiung on Taiwan's west coast will benefit most by the opening of direct cross-strait shipping, the institute said.

Keelung Port in northern Taiwan is expected to handle a much larger number of cross-strait transshipped containers because it is located closer to Fuzhou Port in mainland China's Fujian province and to those northward other than Fuzhou. In addition, Keelung Port's harbor duties are cheaper than those ports in neighboring Japan and South Korea.

Taichung Port in central Taiwan has the potential to integrate different levels of industries on both sides because of its vast hinterland and comprehensive loading, unloading, warehousing and distribution and processing facilities following the linkage, according to the assessment.

Kaohsiung Port in southern Taiwan, the world's fourth-largest container port, will move a step closer toward its goal of transforming into a shipping hub through direct cross-strait shipping, as the MOTC is also actively streamlining the port's operation.

However, the institute pointed out that in addition to the government's policy to open up, the possibility of making profits will be the major element for local shipping firms while considering whether or not to cash in on the cross-strait routes.

Should actual profits be less than expected, it will be hard to attract Taiwan-based shippers to operate cross-strait shipping, it noted, adding that direct shipping between the two sides will become a unilateral opening to the mainland Chinese side and produce a greater negative impact on Taiwan's shipping industry.

As cross-strait negotiation has been suspended since 1996, the institute proposed that the private sectors of Taiwan and mainland China take the initiative to conduct bilateral negotiations. According to its assessment, private organizations of the two sides can sign cooperative pacts under the supervision of respective overseeing authorities to serve as the foundation for direct cross-strait shipping in the initial stages.

DOC.HEADLINE: 41 TAIWAN CYCLISTS RETURN TO KINMEN BY SHIP DIRECTLY FROM XIAMEN

TEXT.P: Forty-one cyclists from Taiwan, Kinmen and Matsu led by Legislator Tsao Er-chung of the opposition Kuomintang returned to Kinmen Sunday by ship directly from Xiamen after ending a weeklong cycling tour in China.

The group of 18 cyclists from Taiwan, 20 from Matsu and three from Kinmen were aboard the Minchu No. 1 which sailed directly from Matsu to Mawei port in Fujian Province June 18. They rode along with 20 mainland cyclists traveling the 370 kilometer journey from Mawei to Xiamen.

Tsao said that his delegation, including five female cyclists, has traveled from Mawei, Putien, Zhuanzhou and Xiamen with the aim of improving the "mini three links," which has connected Xiamen and Mawei ports in Fujian Province and the Republic of China-held offshore islands of Kinmen and Matsu since Jan. 1, 2001. The event was also staged to help Beijing's bid to host the 2008 Olympic Games.
"We were very happy to accomplish the historical gathering," Tsao said.
Tsao also expressed the hope that their cycling activities will further expand the scope of interchanges between Kinmen, Matsu and Xiamen and Mawei.
Cyclists from Taiwan rode bikes around Kinmen Sunday afternoon before taking a plane back to Taiwan proper.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRAZILIAN GRANDMA MEETS WITH GRANDSON

TEXT.P: The Brazilian grandmother of a five-year-old boy at the center of a high-profile custody battle was reunited with the orphaned child in Tainan, southern Taiwan Sunday evening.

Rosa Leocadia Dasilva Ergui vowed to fight to bring the child, Iruan Ergui Wu, or Wu Yi-hua in Chinese, who was born to a Taiwanese father and a Brazilian mother, back to Brazil. The grandmother and the boy were shown on television in a long embrace.
The child returned to Taiwan with his father three months ago but the father died shortly after and the child has since lived with his uncle, Wu Hou-yuan in Chiehting Village, Kaohsiung.

Mrs. Ergui, accompanied by Adir Ferreira, the five-year-old boy's Brazilian uncle, arrived In Taiwan Saturday. They and Paulo A.P. Pinto, director of the Brazil Business Center, as well as their lawyer, Hsu Wen-ping, earlier arrived at a hotel in Tainan to have a meeting with Wu Sunday afternoon. The meeting was arranged by Legislator Lin Yi-shih of the opposition Kuomintang.

Hsu explained that in accordance with ROC civil law, Mrs. Ergui is the sole legal guardian of the boy, whose father gave guardianship of the boy to Rosa before he returned to Taiwan. The mother of the child died several years ago.
But the meeting soured when Rosa Ergui saw that Wu didn't bring along the child. She even said in exasperation that she felt that the Wu family was without warmth and were being cold-blooded.
She tearfully said that she had brought along with her the love and concern for the boy for the past five years, as well as many of the gifts and letters from children of Brazil.

Wu was accompanied by Legislator Lin when he arrived for the meeting. Lin said that they had wanted to greet Rosa Ergui at the airport, and had hoped that she and the child's Brazilian uncle would come to Chiehting Village, Kaohsiung to visit the child, but the request was turned down and they didn't know why.
The child was not with them because they thought the occasion was not suitable for the child, Wu said.
After discussions, both sides agreed to meet in closed-door meeting with one interpreter with each.
Meanwhile, the child played happily during the whole afternoon in his Chiehting home, ignoring the media's question about whether he is happy to see his grandmother.

The Chiehting Village residents, not happy about the accusation of being cold-blooded, gathered near Wu's family, holding placards that said "we are family," and "we welcome the grandmother." They said that they hoped that Rosa Ergui would come to the village to see how Ergui lives.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN PRAISES KIWANIS FOR DEDICATION TO SOCIAL DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian Sunday praised International Kiwanis for its long-time dedication to social development.
Chen, speaking at the opening of the Kiwanis' 2001 conference in Linkou, suburban Taipei, paid his respect to Kiwanis members for their achievements in charity and public services.

He said that International Kiwanis was established in Detroit, the United States in 1915 with the aims of promoting cooperation among the peoples and safeguarding peace, and has now developed to such an important world organization with more than 600,000 members in over 80 countries around the world.

He added that the Kiwanis' Republic of China branch was formed in 1967. With 300 offices and 12,000 members around the island, the Kiwanis' ROC club is now the largest Kiwanis branch in the Asian-Pacific area and in areas outside of North America, winning itself the right to host the 2001 Kiwanis conference, the third time that a Kiwanis annual meeting was held outside of North America.

Chen said that the gathering, which was participated by some 10,000 members from International Kiwanis member countries, will help promote both the visibility of Taiwan in the international community and mutual understanding between the people of the nation and other parts of the world.

The four-day conference began earlier in the day with a carnival at the plaza in front of the Taipei City Hall. The carnival, organized by the Republic of China Kiwanis club, featured dragon dancing performed by a group of disabled in wheel chairs, folk dancing, and other folk entertainment.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Monday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Educational reform will undergo dramatic changes due to economic woes.
The China Times:
Taipei Bank has chosen cooperative partner for computer lottery.
The United Daily News:
Paris newspaper says French engineers divulge Lafayette-class frigate secrets to mainland China.
The Liberty Times:
The proposal to add the word 'Taiwan' to the ROC passport will be put into practice in the second half of this year.
The China Post:
Ex-President Lee departs for the United States.
The Taiwan News:
Thousands flee volcano in Philippines.
The Taipei Times:
Iruan meets Brazilian grandmother.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT ARRIVES IN LOS ANGELES ON TRANSIT STOP
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, June 24 (CNA) (By Lawrence Chu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui arrived in Los Angeles Sunday for a two-day transit stop en route to Cornell University, his alma mater in Ithaca, New York State.

ROC Representative to the United States Chen Chien-jen greeted Lee at the Los Angeles international airport and when he arrived at his hotel, he waved and shook hands with Taiwanese community representatives who were waiting there to welcome his arrival.
More than 300 well-wishers, including staunch supporters of Lee and incumbent ROC President Chen Shui-bian, turned out to greet Lee.
Lee, who earned a Ph.D. in agricultural economics in 1968 at Cornell, was scheduled to take a chartered plane to Ithaca Tuesday in the company of his wife and personal aides.

The primary event on his Ithaca itinerary is the dedication of a research center named after him. A ground-breaking ceremony for the Lee Teng-hui Institute for Scientific Research will be held on the Cornell campus Wednesday.
The Ivy-league university will use computer rendering to show what the finished center -- to be dedicated to nano-technology research -- will look like.
Cornell will also arrange for Lee to take a tour of its campus, where he last visited as ROC president and delivered a resounding speech in June 1995.

Cornell President Hunter R. Rawlings III will host a dinner in Lee's honor Wednesday. Lee is scheduled to fly back to Los Angeles from Ithaca Thursday and meet with his supporters there before concluding his visit July 1 and returning to Taipei July 3.
Lee, who originally planned to visit his alma mater in early May, postponed his trip because he went to Japan to have minor heart surgery in late April.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SENATOR: MILITARY SHOULD NOT REDUCE CAPABILITY

TEXT.P: U.S. Sen. John McCain stressed Sunday that the threat of terrorism, the threat of proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, and challenges from mainland China compel the United States to not reduce its military capability.

The senator said on TV that it is fine to get rid of the theory that the United States should be prepared to fight two major wars at the same time, but he opposes "using it as an excuse to reduce the size of our military further and our capabilities further, and not spend the money that we promised the American people, and make the changes that we promised the American people we would" during the presidential election campaign.
Noting that the possibility of a two-war scenario has become less and less likely, McCain said: "Let's not fool the American people that we don't live in a very, very dangerous world."

"Events where we have just had to pull our military units out of ports all over the Middle East clearly indicate that the threat of terrorism and the threat of proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, the rise of radical Islamic fundamentalism and of course our challenges with China, compel us to not reduce our military capability. In fact, we have got a lot of repair work to do," pointed out the senator.
When asked would he support and try to help President George W. Bush find more money for increased defense spending, McCain replied: "Absolutely."

He said what he really wants to do with Bush is to eliminate items that have nothing to do with national defense but have exploded to billions in the past few years on defense appropriation bills. For example, some US$250 million spending on breast cancer research in the current defense bill ought to be put over in the Health and Human Services bill, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI-WASHINGTON INTERACTION IN GOOD SHAPE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 24 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Relations between the Republic of China and the United States are in good shape and interaction between Taipei and the Bush administration is also good, ROC Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao said Sunday.

Tien made the remarks to CNA upon arrival at San Francisco airport from Denver, where he took part in a three-day world forum sponsored by the American Enterprises Institute (AEI) that ended earlier the same day.

Tien said he is confident about bilateral ties between the ROC and the U. S but was reluctant to comment on or explain the issues he discussed with U.S. officials during the three-day forum, saying only that many influential U.S. leaders -- including Vice President Dick Cheney -- also participated in the gathering. Tien also gave a speech at a panel discussion on the last day of the forum.
The foreign minister was slated to fly back to Taiwan the following evening.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND OFFICIAL DEBUNKS HK MEDIA REPORTS ON MAINLAND MILITARY DRILLS

TEXT.P: There are no signs that mainland China will conduct a massive-scale military exercise in the near future, a Ministry of National Defense (MND) official said Monday.

The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, was responding to a report by Hong Kong's Ming Pao Daily News that mainland China's People's Liberation Army (PLA) will prolong its ongoing military drills on Dongshan Island and expand the exercise area.
The MND official said the report was exaggerated and that there are no concrete signs to suggest that the PLA is going to hold a large-scale exercise.

In reality, the official said, the PLA's current Dongshan Island drills are routine and on a scale similar to those conducted in previous years, with the participation of about 10,000 servicemen, not 100,000 as claimed by the Hong Kong media.

Moreover, the official said, the MND has not spotted any signs that the PLA will expand its area of maneuvers to the East China Sea, the Yellow Sea and the South China Sea -- another claim made by the Hong Kong newspaper in its Monday issue.

Noting that some Hong Kong news media often publish "exaggerated reports" on mainland China's military activities, the official said the MND does not rule out the possibility that the Hong Kong media hype is part of a mainland Chinese publicity gimmick designed to intimidate Taiwan.
"We hope the people of Taiwan will strengthen their psychological defense and not be affected by false or exaggerated media reports," the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF NOTIFIES ARATS ABOUT RESCUED FISHERMEN

TEXT.P: The Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) sent a message to its mainland Chinese counterpart Monday to say that four of 22 mainland fishermen aboard a missing freighter have been rescued, while seven bodies have been found so far.

SEF officials told Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) counterparts that the four rescued had been identified as Chu Liwu, Chang Zhiyiou, Chang Shixuan and Chen ling, while the identities of the seven bodies had yet to be determined.
The search for the rest of the crew of the freighter Guang Yuan was continuing, according to the SEF message.
The SEF and ARATS are semi-official bodies set up by Taipei and Beijing, respectively, to handle exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in the absence of official ties.

The 4,200-ton Guang Yuan, carrying a heavy load of gravel, was broken in two by the strong wind and heavy rain brought about by the passage of typhoon Chebi off Anping Harbor in the southern Taiwan county of Tainan Saturday. The 22-man crew was forced to abandon ship.

Braving atrocious weather conditions, the Coast Guard Administration and the Republic of China Navy launched a search operation for the missing crew as soon as the freighter sent out a distress signal Saturday.

Meanwhile, two 500-ton coast guard patrol ships were reported to have arrived at the scene of a missing Taiwan fishing ship some 200 nautical miles from Luzon in the northern Philippines to join the search for 41-ton Chingchingfa No.16, registered in Tungkang, Pingtung County.

The vessel, with Taiwanese Captain Chen Shui-fa, one Filipino seaman and four Indonesian seamen aboard, lost power north off Luzon Friday afternoon and began taking in water after it came within the area affected by typhoon Chebi.
Taiwan had requested the Philippines rescue authorities to provide emergency assistance because the ship was so far away from Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN URGED TO USE PARAGUAY AS INTERNATIONAL GATEWAY
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, June 25 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Outgoing Republic of China Ambassador to Paraguay Agustin Liu Sunday urged Taiwan businessmen based in Paraguay to use the South American country as a gateway to launch their international ventures.

In the face of the sweeping globalization trend, Liu said, Taiwan business people here should first turn Paraguay into a regional food supply and telecommunications center, as well as a distribution, transport, and exhibition hub for computer parts and components, before expanding into the international market.

In addition to the country's rich natural resources and abundant water and electricity supplies, Paraguay has the potential to become a world food supply center and a regional exhibition, transport, air traffic, and distribution telecommunications hub because of its ideal location, Liu said.

Pointing out that it was decided in a recently concluded summit of the Southern Common Market in Asuncion to authorize Paraguay to produce automobile accessories for sale to neighboring countries, Liu suggested that Taiwan businessmen could consider setting up factories to make car and motorcycle components.

The ROC ambassador made the remarks during a conference with Taiwan businessmen operating in Paraguay. The meeting was held in the Brazilian city of Foz do Iguacu, which borders Paraguay's Eastern City.

The previous evening, Liu took part in a banquet sponsored by the Chinese community of Eastern City in Foz do Iguacu, in which he was awarded the keys to Eastern City by the city's mayor in recognition of his contributions to the city over the past seven-and-a-half years.
Liu is slated to leave his current post June 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, June 25, or the fifth day of the fifth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1788: Virginia becomes the 10th US state.
1843: Commercial production of cigarettes begins in France when the French National Tobacco Company turns out its first batch of 20,000 cigarettes.
1900: Louis Mountbatten, 1st Earl Mountbatten of Burma, British naval commander and colonial administrator, is born. He was supreme Allied commander in Southeast Asia in World War II, last viceroy of India, then commander-in-chief of Britain's Mediterranean fleet.
1903: Marie Curie, the Polish-born French chemist and scientist, announces the discovery of radium, a radioactive metallic element found in pitchblende and other minerals, remarkable for its spontaneous disintegration.
1942: Major General Dwight D. Eisenhower is appointed commander of US forces in Europe, and sets up his headquarters in London.
1944: Chinese Expeditionary Forces capture Magaung in northern Burma.
1945: Representatives of 50 nations, including the Republic of China, attend a United Nations meeting in San Francisco to pass the UN Charter. The ROC, the US, the USSR, France and Britain are made members of the UN Security Council.
1947: The ROC Foreign Ministry reveals repeated Soviet Union attempts to block Chinese troops from entering Dairen and Port Arthur.
1950: North Korea invades South Korea, marking the beginning of the Korean War.
1953: Heavy rain hits Kyushu, an island of Japan, killing 1,013 people.
1968: The ROC Cabinet is partially reshuffled, with Defense Minister Chiang Ching-kuo becoming vice premier.
1969: Pancho Gonzalez and Charlie Paserell play the longest-ever singles match at Wimbledon, which lasts five hours and 12 minutes.
1973: Mathieu Vangha Ekra, Ivory Coast state minister in charge of tourism, accompanied by his wife and a party of five, arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1974: Dr. Wang Ching-mow takes over as director-general of the National Health Administration.
1975: The 22-member Chinese track and field team returns from the Philippine national invitational track and field championships with 27 medals and a second-place victory.
1975: Mozambique becomes independent, with Samora Machel, a Marxist, as its president, after four centuries of Portuguese rule.
1975: More than 4,000 refugees from Cambodia, Laos, and South Vietnam are resettled in Taiwan.
1982: Alexander Haig resigns as US secretary of state and is succeeded by George Schultz.
1989: The British government refuses to allow residency rights in Britain to ethnic Hong Kong Chinese.
1990: Under international pressure, Beijing allows Fang Lichih, a noted Chinese physicist and democracy activist, to leave mainland China and study at Cambridge University in England.
1990: Reporters from mainland China are permitted to visit Taiwan for news-gathering purposes, and government employees from Taiwan are allowed to visit sick relatives or attend funerals across the Taiwan Strait.
1994: Japanese Prime Minister Tsutomu Hata resigns along with his minority government.
1996: A terrorist bomb blast tears through a Saudi Arabian military complex housing foreigners, killing more than 60 people and injuring nearly 400 others.
1997: Jacques Yves Cousteau, French underwater explorer and film producer, dies in Paris at the age of 87. The veteran oceanographer helped develop the aqua-lung in 1943, and popularized underwater exploration with his prize-winning films.
2000: Kaohsiung City Mayor Frank Hsieh was elected as chairman of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Confucius' lesson of the day: "To benefit the people without wasting the resources of the country is to encourage the people to undertake such profitable labor as will best benefit them, without it being necessary to give them any assistance out of the public revenue."

DOC.HEADLINE: JOINT VENTURE WINS BID FOR COMPUTERIZED LOTTERY
