TEXT.P: A joint venture by the Acer Group in Taiwan and a United States company has won the bid to provide technical advice and support to the Taipei Bank regarding the new national lottery.
Lottery Technology Services Corp. (LTSC) kept a low profile after learning that it had won the bid, saying only that it will not make any comment pending final approval by the Ministry of Finance.
Reports have said that the winning bidder would be offered a five-year contract for technical assistance in operating the computerized lottery which is scheduled to begin on January 25, 2002.
Sources said that the LTSC has paid-in capital of NT$500 million (US$14.49 million), with Acer accounting for 56 percent and the U.S. company, GTeck, accounting for the remaining 44 percent.

Taipei Bank estimated that the yearly revenue from the lottery will be at least NT$100 billion (US$2.89 billion), and it will bring more than NT$10 billion in business opportunities for related operators of the computerized lottery.

Fifty-six percent of the lottery earnings will go to cash payouts and after deducting 12.8 percent for management and marketing expenses, the remaining 31.2 percent will be used by the government for subsiding the national pension, funds for national health insurance and the care of the underprivileged.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT SAYS HE WILL NOT ESTABLISH NEW PARTY
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, June 24 (CNA) (By Chu Lu-sheng and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui said during a flight that arrived in Los Angeles Sunday that he will not establish a new political party in Taiwan and is only interested in "nurturing more young people."

Arriving from Taiwan for a two-day transit stop en route to Cornell University, his alma mater in Ithaca, New York, Lee denied media reports that he is prepared to form a new political group of "pro-Lee" legislators who will work together with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to gain a legislative majority in the year-end elections.

Lee was also chairman of the Kuomintang (KMT), the largest opposition party in Taiwan, before stepping down from that post last March following the defeat of his protege, Lien Chan, in the presidential elections.

He said that when he saw the poor domestic economic performance and the unstable political situation over the past year, he was concerned the democratic political system he helped establish after much difficulty seemed to be close to collapse.

Lee speculated that "the problem lies in the legislature," where the KMT retains a comfortable majority over the DPP and together with other opposition parties has presented a major obstacle for the ruling administration -- in effect a minority government.
He said that he is willing to help young and capable people with a clean image get elected in the upcoming legislative elections, when all 225 seats are up for grabs.
Lee added that he is not trying to cut into the KMT or DPP vote, or to take away their people.

Upon arriving at his hotel in Los Angeles, Lee was greeted by both supporters and protesters. About 300 well-wishers turned out to show their support for Lee, while another 200 protesters shouted slogans claiming that Lee was "disrupting politics and destroying parties."
Some of the protesters were overseas members of the KMT, students from Taiwan and even some mainland Chinese immigrants.

Meanwhile, three branches and a party service center of the KMT in the Western U.S. area jointly released an open letter to Lee, condemning his support of the DPP and urging him to continue to follow the teachings of his own party.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CHANG MAKES INSPECTION TOUR OF TUNGSHA ISLAND

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung made an inspection tour of Tungsha (Pratas) Island Monday to express his concern about the well-being of Republic of China Coast Guard staff members stationed on the small island in the South China Sea.

During his inspection tour, Premier Chang reaffirmed the ROC's stance that any South China Sea disputes, particularly sovereignty disputes over the Spratlys, should be resolved strictly by peaceful means.
This was Chang's first trip to Tungsha Island, some 240 nautical miles southwest of the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung, since he took over the premiership last October.

Chang flew to Tungsha Island in the company of Vice Premier Lai Ing-jaw, Minister of National Defense Wu Shi-wen, National Coast Guard Administration head Wang Chun and Deputy Kaohsiung Mayor Lin Yung-chien.
Chang presented the coast guard staff stationed on the island with NT$100,000 (US$2,941.18) in celebration of the Dragon Boat Festival, which fell on Monday this year.

The South China Sea is rich in natural resources, including crude oil and marine resources. Many countries have been expanding their presence in the area and conflicts have been reported from time to time. Mainland China reportedly intends to make the South China Sea its "inland territorial waters."

Premier Chang said Tungsha Island symbolizes the ROC's sovereignty claim to the South China Sea. Moreover, he said, Tungsha Island occupies a very important strategic location as it sits at the center of waters important to mainland China, Hong Kong and Taiwan and at a strategic point in major Taiwan Strait sea lanes.
Noting that true peace relies on strength, Chang encouraged all ROC personnel stationed on the island to beef up defense capabilities to ensure the ROC's territorial integrity.

Quoting the ROC' Policy Guidelines for the South China Sea adopted in 1993, Chang said the ROC is willing to cooperate with other countries in exploring and managing resources in the South China Sea and in protecting the ecology the area.

Chang encouraged coast guard staff stationed on the island to step up ecological protection and to crack down on fishing boats that operate illegally in the area. "Of course, you should also take care of fishermen who encounter troubles or disasters in the region," he added.

In the past, the ROC posted marines on Tungsha Island. Starting last year, coast guard officers took over garrison and patrol missions there. There are runways and piers on the island. The ROC air force's C-130 transports airlift supplies to the island regularly.

Tungsha Island is now under the jurisdiction of the Kaohsiung City Government. Deputy Kaohsiung Mayor Lin Yung-chien said the operator of a 27,000-ton passenger ship is negotiating with the city government for starting tour services to Tungsha Island.
Lin said the city government will step up efforts to develop the island's tourist resources, with fishing and diving as main attractions of Tungsha package tours.
A coast guard officer said Tungsha Island has beautiful ocean scenery and fishery resources, particularly lobsters, crabs and other marine resources.
If the government wants to develop the tourist industry in the Tungsha Island area, the officer said, power and water supply facilities must be improved first.

DOC.HEADLINE: CUSTODY BATTLE OVER BRAZILIAN-CHINESE BOY TEMPORARILY STALLS
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung County, Taiwan, June 25 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: The atmosphere of a high-profile international custody battle over a five-year-old Brazilian-Chinese boy turned sour again Monday after what seemed like a breakthrough earlier in the morning.

Rosa Leocadia Da Silva Ergui, the Brazilian grandmother of the child, Iruan Ergui Wu, or Wu Yi-hua in Chinese, visited the house of Iruan's uncle, Wu Hou-yuan, in Chiehting Village, Kaohsiung, where the boy has been living for the past few months, supposedly following his father's last wishes.

At first, the meeting appeared amicable as the entire village turned out to welcome Ergui. Her lawyer Hsu Wen-ping said that hostility no longer exists between the two sides, and that after seeing Wu's living conditions, Ergui does not rule out the possibility of allowing Iruan to stay in Taiwan.
It was the second time that she has been able to see Iruan since she arrived in Taiwan two days ago.
She is the child's legally appointed guardian after his mother died several years ago. Iruan was brought back to Taiwan in March by his father, a local sea captain who died a week afterward.

The meeting turned sour when during lunch Ergui asked to be able to spend an hour alone with Iruan, a suggestion that was turned down by the boy's uncle. Wu told her that he would accompany the two of them wherever they wanted to go.

With that, Ergui left, claiming that she was not feeling well. Afterward, she said through her interpreter that she had thought both sides were sincere, yet Wu still did not seem to trust her alone with the child.

After she left, Wu said that he did not refuse Ergui because he didn't care about human emotions, but rather because he was worried what would happen if some problem were to occur while the two were alone.

Speaking on behalf of Wu, Kuomintang legislator Lin Yi-shih, who has been closely helping the Wus with the custody battle, claimed that when Ergui was invited to dinner together with the family and the boy the previous evening, she would not let go of him and even intended to threaten to cut her own wrist.
That was the reason the Wu family refused her request to be alone with the child, Lin added.
The two sides decided to let their lawyers negotiate in the meanwhile, and an originally scheduled meeting for Tuesday between the two sides was temporarily canceled.

DOC.HEADLINE: KEELUNG STUDENTS SET NEW WORLD RECORD IN STANDING EGGS ON END

TEXT.P: More than 1,000 elementary and junior high schools in the northern Taiwan port city of Keelung jointly setting a new world record Monday by standing a total of 602 eggs on the end in 10 minutes.
The young Keelung students smashed the record set by the Bayfield elementary school in the U.S. state of Colorado on March 20, 1986 when a total of 467 eggs were stood on end.
Representatives of the London-based "Guinness Book of Records" witnessed the Keelung event and agreed to formally list the record in its authoritative book.
The event was sponsored by the Keelung City Government, with the participation of 1,046 students from two elementary and two junior high schools.

Keelung Mayor Lee Chin-yung and many other city government officials as well as Tai Sheng-yi, chairman of the Guinness Asian witness center, were on hand to see for themselves the proceeding of the event as part of the celebrations of Dragon Boat Festival, which fell on Monday this year.
Mayor Lee said he was very pleased to see the city's schoolchildren have managed to set a new world record.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN ATTENDS FOLK ACTIVITIES MARKING DRAGON BOAT FESTIVAL
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, Central Taiwan, June 25 (CNA) (By Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian visited a centuries-old temple Monday in Taichung as part of the celebrations for the Dragon Boat Festival.

The Dragon Boat Festival is one of the most important Chinese festivals and the president chose to mark the day with a visit to the Wanhe Temple in Taichung, central Taiwan, where he was welcomed by thousands of worshipers and people from nearby shops.
Accompanied by several government officials responsible for cultural affairs, Chen offered incense to the folk deity Matsu, the Goddess of the Sea, one of the most popular deities in Taiwan.

Chen said he was happy to see the positive spirit of the local people and said that this was not the first time that he had visited the 317-year-old Wanhe Temple. Chen said that the temple was well-known for the many charitable activities that it had sponsored in years past. He also said the temple has set a good example of compassion and has contributed much to society.

While in Taichung, the president also opened the central Taiwan office of the National Cultural Association, of which Chen is chairman. Chen encouraged the workers there to contribute to the promotion of Taiwan culture.

During the Dragon Boat Festival, also known as Poet's Day, rowing races are held and glutinous rice dumplings wrapped in bamboo leaves are eaten in remembrance of Chu Yuan, a famous scholar-statesman of the Warring States Period. Chu drowned himself after failing to convince the king of Chu to guard the kingdom against the enemy.

Chen said the opening of the Taichung office of the National Cultural Association was a significant event and he hoped that the office would bring a renewed energy to fostering Chinese culture in central Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PETROLEUM MARKET SATURATED: CPC EXECUTIVE

TEXT.P: There is no room in the domestic market for a new petroleum company because of fierce competition in Taiwan, Chinese Petroleum Corporation (CPC) Vice President J. H. Hsieh said Monday.

Since the government's opening of the local market in 1987 and the entry of Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) in September 2000, supply has outpaced demand in Taiwan's petroleum market. "No third petroleum company would be able to survive in the domestic petrochemical market," Hsieh said.
The local downstream petrochemical sector has requested the Executive Yuan to allow them to market their goods in mainland China.

Although challenged by foreign competition, the FPG and pressure from privatization, Hsieh said the CPC has been able to pull in NT$360 billion each year. He said that annual profit earmarked for the government and taxes contributed by the CPC to the national coffers also averages more than NT$20 billion and NT$100 billion, respectively.

In an effort to tackle increased competition following Taiwan's long-awaited admission into the World Trade Organization, the CPC has also taken measures to slash its production costs over the past three years, Hsieh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 54 PERCENT OF UNIVERSITY STUDENTS SUPPORT DPP: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Although 48 percent of a group of recently surveyed local university students said they believe that society has been "foundering" over the past year, 54 percent said they will continue to support the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

According to the poll, which was conducted by a weekly publication of the Chinese Culture University's Department of Journalism, 37 percent of the respondents said they believe Taiwan is "marching in place," while only 15 percent believe that it is "moving forward."
Also, 53 percent of the 632 northern Taiwan university students polled said they will not support President Chen Shui-bian if he seeks another four-year term.

However, 54 percent of the respondents said that they will support the DPP and are hopeful to see it become a majority party in the legislature after the year-end elections. The primary reason for supporting the DPP, according to 26 percent of the respondents, is because "other parties are too lousy."
Meanwhile, 41 percent of the students said that they believe if the DPP controls the legislature, where it is currently a minority, then "Taiwan's political situation will become better."
Also, 60 percent of the respondents said that Chen should create a coalition Cabinet with opposition parties.
Regarding the rising domestic unemployment rate, nearly 75 percent said that the fault should not lie with the DPP administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN LIEN CHAN ARRIVES IN SAN FRANCISCO
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 24 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan arrived in San Francisco from Denver, Colorado, Sunday after attending a symposium on international issues in Beaver Creek, Colorado.

Lien would not comment on the details of his meeting with United States leaders at the World Forum, organized by the American Enterprise Institute, saying only that it was very good to exchange views with more than 100 world leaders on international issues.
He brushed aside questions from waiting journalists at the airport about his opinions on reports that former KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui is putting together a political organization outside the party.
One of Lien's aides said it never occurred to Lien to telephone Lee, who arrived in Los Angeles Monday on his way to visit his alma mater, Cornell University, in New York.

Taipei's representative to Washington, Chen Chien-jen, who attended the World Forum in Colorado along with Lien, flew from Denver to Los Angeles to greet Lee Sunday. Lien was accompanied by Stephen Chen, former Republic of China representative to Washington.

Lee is reportedly trying to set up a political movement of Taiwanese politicians to run in the year-end elections against the KMT because he believes the KMT under Lien's leadership has strayed from the ideology that he had fostered during his 12-year tenure as KMT chairman.

Meanwhile in Taipei, KMT lawmakers are planning to give Lien a warm greeting at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan when he returns to the island on Wednesday, according to a Taipei evening newspaper, the China Times Express.

The paper quoted KMT sources as saying Monday that the party legislators, especially Lee's former followers, will voluntarily gather to welcome their chairman to quell speculations that many of them will desert the KMT and join Lee's movement.
The enthusiastic welcome for Lien will be in sharp contrast to the lukewarm send-off that Lee received at the same airport on Sunday when he left for Los Angeles.
Lee was seen off then by Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng and a cluster of KMT officials. Many KMT heavyweights were conspicuous by their absence at the occasion, according to the paper.

The paper quoted KMT sources as saying that the party will not officially jettison its former leader before Lee announces the formation of his own movement, but that Lien's status as the party leader is very solid with or without Lee's endorsement.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER CHAIRS SECURITY PANEL DISCUSSION AT WORLD FORUM
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 24 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao said Sunday at a plenary session of the 20th American Enterprise Institute World Forum in Denver, Colorado, that security concepts should be defined beyond the scope of military factors.

He added that the concepts should instead emphasize trade and economic cooperation as well as political integration, and that the development of democratic politics is the best guarantee to world peace because "it is difficult for war to break out between democratic countries."

On the topic of Taipei-Beijing relations, Tien said that ROC President Chen Shui-bian has already extended several olive branches, and that a high degree of economic and trade cooperation already exists between the two sides.

Tien made the remarks while serving as a co-moderator on the topic of "World and Regional Security" together with U.S. Vice President Dick Cheney and former French President Valery Giscard d'Estaing on the last day of the forum.

Although the three-day annual meeting is a traditionally informal and unofficial affair where government officials, think tank experts and business leaders meet to explore various global economic, social and security issues, inviting Tien to serve as a co-moderator with a senior U.S. official at a panel attended by all 250 guests from around the world was a new development in the interaction of ROC and U.S. ranking officials.

The ROC delegation included opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, a former vice president; Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien, a former foreign minister; and Chen Chien-jen, the ROC representative to the United States.
Senior U.S. officials attending the forum included Deputy Secretary of Defense Paul Wolfowitz and Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan.
The forum was chaired by former U.S. President Gerald Ford, who established the forum in 1982 and hosts it annually.
Lien, Chien, Wolfowitz and former U.S. Ambassador to mainland China James Lilley also co-chaired a small group discussion session on U.S.-Asia exchanges.
Tien is slated to fly back to Taiwan Monday evening via San Francisco.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FINANCE MINISTER IN LONDON TO LURE EUROPEAN INVESTMENT
DOC.DATELINE: London, June 25 (CNA) (By Mark Ou and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Finance Yen Ching-chang encouraged international investors Monday to participate in Taiwan's financial markets and promised to give them "national treatment."

Yen, who is in London heading a delegation of local finance and high-tech industry leaders for a 10-day tour of major European financial centers, said at a trade seminar in London that Taiwan realizes the importance of foreign capital in the development of Taiwan's financial markets, and is accelerating its financial reforms and improving its investment environment.

He said foreign investors always closely watch the financial situation of a country in which they want to invest. Yen emphasized that Taiwan's foreign debt constitutes only 24.4 percent of its gross domestic product (GDP), far lower than the 60 percent permitted by the Maastricht Treaty signed by European countries in 1992, indicating that Taiwan's financial situation is quite healthy.

Yen also said he believes that Taiwan's economic growth can reach 4 percent this year. He admitted, however, that the ratio of the nation's overdue loans has increased more than in the past, but he believes that the ratio will be kept under control by measures adopted by the government.

Taiwan has assigned 2001 as the year for financial reform, which Yen says demonstrates its determination to tackle the problems, adding that related financial bills that have been passed by the legislature and those which will be passed in the future will be good news for foreign investors. He also said that after tax reform, Taiwan's average tax has been reduced to 13.2 percent.

Underlining the difference between investment environments of Taiwan and its neighboring countries, Yen said under current financial reforms, Taiwan's financial structure will be further reinforced and can weather further difficulties.
Yen said he believes that the improved and more transparent investment environment in Taiwan will attract more attention from European investors.

During his stay in London, Yen will meet with representatives of many important international financial institutions. Yen's European tour will also bring him to Amsterdam, Frankfurt, Zurich and Paris.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT RUNNERS FINISH EIGHTH STAGE IN NANJING, CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Nanjing, China, June 25 (CNA) (By Chang Chun-yu and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Professional athletes from Taiwan and mainland China completed the eighth leg in Nanjing of a run held on both sides of the Taiwan Strait Monday in support of Beijing's bid to host the 2008 summer Olympic Games.

The 10-city, 15-day run began June 16 in Taipei. As of Monday, cross-strait runners have raced in Taiwan in Taipei and Kaohsiung, and in China in Shenzhen, Ningbo, Hangzhou, Shanghai, Wuxi and Nanjing.

The start of Monday's three-kilometer run was jointly presided over by Kong Qingpeng, the chairman of Jiangsu province's sports federation, Yang Chuan-kuang, the leader of Taiwan's athletes in the event, and Che Xiangdong, the leader of mainland China's runners. Some 2,000 local people joined professional athletes in the run which started from the Dr. Sun Yat-sen Mausoleum.
Runners are scheduled to fly to Qingdao Tuesday and to Beijing Thursday for the ninth and tenth legs of the event before returning to Taiwan Sunday.
A 23-member mainland Chinese delegation arrived in Taipei June 14 to take part in the first two legs of the cross-strait race held in Taipei and Kaohsiung.
The International Olympic Committee will vote July 13 to decide whether Beijing, Toronto or Paris will be chosen to host the 2008 summer Games.

Taiwan's Yang, a silver medalist in the decathlon at the 1960 Olympic Games, stumbled in front of his hotel on the way back from the run and suffered minors scrapes and bruises. He was taken to hospital for treatment and released.

Yang also caught cold while on the mainland as have a number of the other athletes in the Taiwan delegation. Observers say that the combination of swelteringly hot days and sudden rain showers may have contributed to the runners' problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTRY SAYS BEIJING MAY POSTPONE WAR GAMES

TEXT.P: Communist China is likely to postpone its planned war games near Dongshan Island off Fujian province because of Typhoon Chebi that wreaked havoc in the coastal areas of mainland China, a spokesman for the Ministry National Defense said Monday.

Maj. Gen. Huang Suey-sheng made the observation when asked to comment on a news report from Hong Kong that said the Communist Chinese military will stage large-scale military exercises because of the test-firing of Patriot missiles by Taiwan last week.

Huang said that the People's Liberation Army will have to delay its amphibious landing operations around Dongshan Island because of the damage wrought by Typhoon Chebi, which swept through the Taiwan Strait several days ago.
Huang said that there has been nothing irregular detected by the defense ministry which would lead them to believe that the PLA is gearing up for extended military exercises.

The PLA regularly stages war games between March and October each year, Huang said, adding that Dongshan Island is a common site for the amphibious landing exercise. He said that there is no indication that the programs of the drill and the number of military personnel involved in it this year are anything different from previous years.

Huang made the comments after a Hong Kong newspaper, the Ming Pao Daily, said Monday that Beijing will extend its ongoing military exercises on Dongshan Island in response to Taipei's test-firing of its U.S.-made Patriotic Advanced Capacity-2 anti-missile defense system on June 20.

The PAC-2 missiles were deployed to counter Beijing's missile threat to the island and the test-firing, the first outside the United States, was deemed by Beijing as a provocation, according to the Ming Pao.

In an attempt to allay any public concerns over Beijing's saber rattling against Taiwan, Huang said his ministry has always kept a close eye on China's military movements and will keep the public informed of events, but will not reveal information that could compromise ongoing intelligence work or issues of national security.
Huang also said that as the test-firing of the Patriot missiles were routine and not provocative, he saw no reason for Beijing to be overly concerned with the tests.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT AIMS TO RAISE NT$100 BILLION FOR BIO-TECH

TEXT.P: The government will encourage the formation of 50 private venture capital (VC) funds, totaling NT$100 billion (US$2.94 billion), to boost the development of the local bio-tech industry, according to statement made by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Monday.
The government will chip in its own funds to a maximum of 30 percent of the sum of any individual VC fund, according to CEPD officials.

In order to facilitate the acquisition of funds by bio-tech companies, the government will revise the regulation on listing stock on the open market to make it easy for them to trade their shares on the local security exchange or in over-the-count market.

With more than 6,000 graduates from bio-technology-related departments of local universities, the CEPD said Taiwan has great potential to develop the bio-tech industry and the government will create a climate favorable for its development by changing the rules and providing funds.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAISUGAR TO SWEETEN BOTTOM LINE WITH ORCHID-GROWING

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Sugar Corporation (Taisugar) plans to gradually close down its sugar producing factories and retrain its manpower to work in agricultural areas that are more cost-effective, a spokesman for Taisugar said Monday.
Lin Chin-hsing, deputy general manager of Taisugar said that the move would be in line with efforts to be more competitive ahead of Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization.
He said one direction that Taisugar will be moving into is the flower-growing industry, with an operating turnover goal this year of NT$1.22 billion.

In order to develop more cost-effective agriculture, Taisugar has set up horticulture centers and specialty shops at three of its factories in the southern Taiwan townships of Hsinying, Chishan and Nanching.
In addition, Taisugar has extended its operations abroad in the area of orchid producing.
Taisugar has finalized one such operation in San Francisco. The corporation estimated that the annual turnover in the future for the orchid business there would exceed NT$300 million.
Taisugar has recently completed the expansion of its orchid producing area in Costa Rica and plans to use it for the production of orchid seedlings.
The state-run corporation's orchid-growing facilities in British Columbia, Canada, are expected to produce 150,000 pots of orchids annually with a yearly turnover reaching NT$60 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
LEGISLATURE CONVENES EXTRAORDINARY SESSION TO DEBATE FINANCIAL BILLS

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan convened an extraordinary session Tuesday at the formal request of President Chen Shui-bian to discuss six pressing financial reform bills.

Following the adoption of a resolution by a 85-63 vote in the legislature earlier in the day calling on Premier Chang Chun-hsiung to report on the significance of the bills, Chang said that although he believes the resolution does not conform with related laws and constitutional norms, he would report to the legislature in the afternoon out of respect and partisan harmony, and out of hope that the bills' passage will infuse renewed vitality into the economy.

Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said that the resolution -- the first time that a premier has ever been requested to report to the legislature at an extraordinary session -- was not illegal or unconstitutional, but that it was a new constitutional precedence.

Ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislators criticized the resolution as setting a "bad precedence," and that the demand for Chang's presence was "seriously sidetracking" the main issues to be discussed at the special session.

However, opposition Kuomintang legislators said that the session has been convened primarily because the Executive Yuan requested it, and that the premier should therefore report to the Legislative Yuan.
The two-day special meeting marked the first time in the nation's history that an extraordinary legislative session was convened twice in the same year.
A previous session was convened Jan. 30 to debate the controversial issue of whether work on a partially completed nuclear power plant project should recommence after being halted last October.
Only two other extraordinary sessions have ever been convened in the past. In 1951 and 1952, special sessions to debate pressing international treaties with Japan were convened.

Under the Constitution, the country's lawmakers gather for two regular sessions each year, one lasting from February to May and the other from September to December. Extraordinary sessions may be held at the request of the president, or after a vote by more than 25 percent of the legislators.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S 2ND QUARTER ECONOMIC GROWTH FORECAST AT ONLY 1 PERCENT

TEXT.P: An evaluation report by the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research forecasts Taiwan's economic growth in the second quarter of this year at only 1 percent, less than the government's expectation of 3 percent.

Wu Rong-i, president of the non-governmental research institute, said that the government's forecast is based on a presumption that the government's economic stimulus measures can be approved by the Legislative Yuan and be effectively implemented.
According to the report, the composite indicator which reflects business climate seen by manufacturing companies dropped to 89.22 points in May, down 4.93 points from the previous month.

After dropping to an all-time low of 88.34 points in January, the composite indicator registered surges in February, March and April. However, as the forces of rebound failed to sustain the impact of the global economic slowdown, it receded again in May.

The report says that the business climate may show signs of recovery at the end of the third quarter or the beginning of the fourth quarter, though the development may be affected by unpredictable factors.
The U.S. economic recovery and an improvement in the international economic climate remain the keys to Taiwan's economic prospects, the report says.

It adds, however, that both the legislature and the administration should improve their efficiency in improving the domestic investment environment, boost domestic demand, encourage investments in infrastructure, and relax monetary policies.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SIGNS AGREEMENT TO HELP TRAIN GUATEMALAN YOUTH

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi signed an agreement with his Guatemalan counterpart, Marco A. Ventura, Tuesday to help train youth from the Central American nation.

Under the agreement, the Republic of China will train Guatemalan youths in Taiwan for one year in skills that will enable them to start their own businesses. The program will be made available to a maximum of 20 people.

Officials with the International Cooperation Department under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said that the project will promote the ROC's experience in small- and medium-sized industry development, as well as enhance the trade and economic relations between the two countries.

The officials noted that the Guatemala youth will also help the ROC's exports if they buy machinery from Taiwan after returning to their homeland. Domestic manufacturers who take the Guatemalan trainee could also use the chance to increase their trade opportunities to invest overseas.
The Guatemalan youths will be trained in electrical engineering, auto mechanics, construction, food and metal processing.

The officials said Guatemala is well situated as the gateway to central America, and is near the economic free trade zone in Mexico which services the United States and Canada. Guatemala also enjoys preferential tariff treatment from Europe and the United States.
Statistics released by the Ministry of Finance showed that trade between the ROC and Guatemala in 2000 totaled US$111.12 million, with Guatemala importing US$95.2 million from the ROC.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK INDEX DROPS TO NEW LOW

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) dropped further Monday amid slow trading, with the benchmark weighted price index losing 119.22 points to close at 4,785.12, the lowest level so far this year.
Market turnover totaled NT$36.56 billion (US$1.08 billion) in thin trading.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SAYS ROC SUPPORTS GLOBAL ANTI-LANDMINE CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday he is willing to sign an international declaration against landmines and warfare on behalf of the Republic of China government.

"We are more than willing to sign the declaration to show our opposition to the use of landmines and military force and to signify our support for love and peace," Chen said while meeting with visiting Cambodian Nobel Peace Prize laureate Tun Channareth.

Chen lauded Channareth for his longtime devotion to the global anti-landmine and anti-warfare campaign. "Anti-landmines, anti-war, love and peace are just like freedom, democracy and human rights. They are all universal values," Chen said.
The president further said the ROC fully supports the activities of the International Campaign to Ban Landmines (ICBL), of which Channareth is now a goodwill ambassador.

The ICBL, founded in 1990, is now a coalition of more than 1,000 non-governmental organizations in over 60 countries. The campaign and its director, Jody Williams, as well as Channareth were co-winners of the 1997 Nobel Peace Prize.
"I admire the ICBL's anti-landmine campaign. Its activities are significant. It will never go it alone. The ROC government will not hesitate to support its cause," Chen told his guest.

For his part, Channareth said during his visit to the ROC's frontline island of Kinmen a few days ago that he was impressed by the ROC government's efforts to hire foreign engineers to assist in clearing landmines from the offshore island.
"I think that your country can ask the United Nations to send its demining experts to help clean up Kinmen," Channareth said, adding that he hopes Kinmen can soon become a landmine-free area.
Channareth further suggested that the ROC government offer landmine victims more support and care to help them rebuild their lives.

Channareth admitted that promoting the anti-landmine drive is no easy task. "But I'll never be daunted by any difficulty and will continue carrying out the campaign," he said, adding that more than 140 countries around the world have signed the ICBL-initiated anti-landmine declaration. "I look forward to seeing all countries around the world endorse the declaration and restrict the use of landmines," he said.

Channareth, an ex-soldier who lost both his legs in 1982 when a landmine exploded while he was patrolling with his troops near the Thai border, arrived in Taiwan last Thursday to take part in a series of activities aimed at helping the public understand the hazards of landmines and experience how it feels to be confined to a wheelchair.

According to U.N. estimates, about 110 million landmines still exist in the world, with over 100,000 of them located on the ROC-held frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu, both of which lie far closer to mainland China than to Taiwan. Channareth urged Taiwan to pass a law banning landmines to prevent further civilian injuries.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIGHT AGAINST HIV/AIDS GOES ON AT SPECIAL SESSION OF U.N.

TEXT.P: As the special session on HIV/AIDS began Tuesday at the United Nations Headquarters in New York, Ambassador Bagher Asadi of Iran, chairman of the Group of 77 (G-77), called on the developed nations of the world to increase their contributions to the global fight against the pandemic.

Asadi, echoing the words of the secretary-general earlier at the session that "the response has not measured up to the challenge," said that the funds made available so far are simply inadequate for an effective campaign against the deadly virus. Asadi also emphasized the importance of debt relief to free national resources in developing countries.

Asadi considered the 26th Special Session of the United Nations General Assembly a welcome development and a timely indication of the global awareness of the devastating HIV /AIDS menace. Characterizing the situation as a major crisis, he said that the world now seems to have realized the real, multi-faceted dimensions of the emergency.
He expressed hope that the special session would be able to muster the necessary political will and the requisite resources to address and deal with the emergency.

The G-77 chairman also welcomed the decision of some of the major pharmaceutical companies to lower their prices for HIV/AIDS drugs. He added, however, that the prices are still far too high for most developing countries to afford.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRANDMOTHER OF BRAZILIAN-CHINESE BOY IN CUSTODY BATTLE LEAVES TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung County, Taiwan, June 26 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: The Brazilian grandmother of a Brazilian-Chinese boy at the center of an international custody battle left Taiwan Tuesday without her grandson, vowing she will seek legal recourse to gain custody of the orphaned child.

Rosa Leocadia Da Silva Ergui's three-day trip to Taiwan ended after talks with the Taiwanese uncle of the child failed to produce a consensus on the issue of guardianship of five-year-old Wu Yi-hua -- or Iruan Ergui Wu as he is known in Brazil.

Ergui was appointed by a Brazilian court to be the boy's guardian about three years ago after his mother died. However, following what were supposedly his father's last wishes, Iruan has been living with his uncle in Taiwan after his sea captain father died in March.

The uncle, Wu Huo-yen, said that because the local Brazilian representative office did not answer questions about when Ergui would be flying out of Taiwan, he felt that the Brazilian side was not reciprocating his offer of good will. Wu did not see Ergui off at the airport.
Meanwhile, Kuomintang legislator Lin Yi-shih, who has been closely helping the Wus with the custody battle, questioned the motives behind Ergui's just-concluded trip.

Lin said that Ergui had continuously tried to create friction between the two sides and even "acted out" in front of a Brazilian television camera the determination that she would bring Iruan back to Brazil or else slit her own wrists.
He charged that her crying and not letting go of the child seemed aimed at creating a scene of tragic familial separation for the viewers back in Brazil.

Lin also questioned Ergui's sometimes amicable, sometimes hostile attitude, citing as an example the previous evening when she seemed pleasant when the television crew was on hand to witness her returning the child to the Wu family after spending two hours alone together, and then doing an about-face immediately after the media left by being unwilling to engage in any further communication with the Wus.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, June 26, or the sixth day of the fifth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
363: Roman emperor Julian the Apostate, the first non-Christian emperor since Constantine, dies of spear wounds inflicted during a battle with the Persians. He was 32.
1541: Francisco Pizarro, the Spanish conqueror of Peru who played a major part in crushing the Inca Empire, is attacked and killed in his house in Lima. He was 66.
1843: Hong Kong is proclaimed a British colony, with Sir Henry Pottinger as its first governor.
1844: John Tyler, the 10th president of the United States who succeeded to office after the death of President William Henry Harrison, secretly marries Julia Gardiner in New York. His administration was marked by the annexation of Texas in 1845.
1858: The Treaty of Tientsin is signed, ending hostilities between China's Ching court and Britain and granting British trade rights.
1892: Pearl S. Buck, the American writer who won the 1938 Nobel Prize for literature, is born. Her life as a missionary in China lent a vivid immediacy to her novels, including "The Good Earth."
1907: Mark Twain, pen name of Samuel Langhorne Clemens, American author and humorist, receives an honorary doctorate from Oxford University. He drew on his childhood experiences along the Mississippi River to create masterpieces of humor and sarcasm, including "Tom Sawyer" and "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn."
1908: The US Congress votes to return the so-called "Boxer Indemnity" in the amount of US$14.8 million. The money was used three years later to found Tsinghua School and to help finance Chinese students' studies in the United States.
1930: Joseph Stalin announces that his murderous purges are "purifying" the Soviet Union.
1945: Representatives from 50 nations including the Republic of China, one of the UN founding members, sign the United Nations Charter in San Francisco. The charter became effective on Oct. 24.
1956: The Tainan College of Technology in Taiwan is formally transformed into National Cheng Kung University.
1960: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with the Malagasy Republic.
1962: The United States declares it will not support any attempt by the ROC on Taiwan to land forces on the Chinese mainland.
1963: A million and a quarter West Berliners turn out to give a tumultuous welcome to US President John F. Kennedy who addresses the 120,000-strong crowd in Rathaus Square near the Berlin Wall.
1975: Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi declares a state of emergency and arrests hundreds of political opponents.
1976: A strong earthquake rocks Irian Jaya province in Indonesia, killing more than 400 people.
1986: The ROC Executive Yuan announces that, due to opposition by Lukang residents, the Ministry of Economic Affairs has ordered a hold on the Du Pont Corporation's plan to construct a titanium dioxide plant in Lukang and the carrying out of an environmental impact study on the project.
1989: Student leaders who have escaped from the Chinese mainland after the Tiananmen Square massacre leave Hong Kong for exile to Western countries.
1991: Approval is given to 15 of 19 applications to set up private commercial banks in the ROC.
1992: A peoples court in mainland China's Tsingtao sentences Li Hsienpin, an air force pilot who defected to Taiwan and later returned to the mainland, to 15 years in prison for "surrender to the enemy and mutiny."
1993: US forces hit targets in Iraq following a failed assassination attempt on former President George Bush while he was visiting Kuwait in April.
1998: President Bill Clinton opens a state visit to mainland China in Beijing's Tiananmen Square, where a protest movement was brutally suppressed nine years earlier.
1999: ROC Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang leaves for Auckland, New Zealand, to attend an annual trade ministers meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.
1999: The Ever Power IPP, Taiwan's first private power plant to use natural gas to generate power, is inaugurated at Luchu, Taoyuan County, in northern Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In the employment of people in forced labor on works for the public good, if you select those who are most able to bear it, who will have any cause for complaint?"

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK INDEX FALLS TO YEAR'S LOW

TEXT.P: Prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) dropped further Monday amid lingering economic woes.
The weighted TAIEX price index, or the market's key barometer, lost 119.22 points to close 4,785.12, the lowest level so far this year.
Market turnover totaled NT$36.56 billion (US$1.08 billion) in thin trading as many investors kept on the sidelines due to gloomy economic outlook.
A total of 124.16 million shares changed hands during the four-and-half-hour trading session.

The market opened slightly higher than last week's finish and reached a high of 4,948.33 points around mid-session. The market then weakened amid heavy selling in the Internet and communication services sectors.

All the eight major categories of stocks lost ground, with cement stocks plunging 3.5 percent; food issues falling 2.9 percent; plastics and chemical issues dropping 2 percent; textiles slid 1.9 percent; electronics issues declining 2.9 percent; paper stocks moving down 1.8 percent; construction issues diving 2.4 percent; and financial issues dropping 1.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 469 to 69, with 58 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTRY OF ECONOMIC AFFAIRS APPROVES CAL INVESTMENT IN XIAMEN

TEXT.P: The Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) Tuesday approved 21 mainland China-bound investment applications from Taiwan.
China Airlines' US$3.4 million investment in Xiamen International Airport Corp. to run bus transportation, distribution of containers, and warehouse operations was among the approved cases.
The application by Taiwan Glass to remit US$35 million to invest in the Taichia Glass Company in mainland China was also approved.
The Formosa Group's plan to invest US$187.3 million in a PVC company in Ningbo was not discussed this time, however. It may be submitted for discussion next month.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures markets closed lower Tuesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for July plunged 131 points to close at 4,834, with 5,601 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for August lost 88 points to finish at 4,850, with 43 contracts traded. September futures lost 55 points to close at 4,900, with six contracts traded.
December futures plunged 121 points to close at 4,885, with one contract changing hands, while TAIEX Index futures for March lost 48 points to finish at 4,905, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 4,965 for July, 4,938 for August, 4,955 for September, 5,006 for December and 4,953 for next March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, both closed lower.

July TE futures moved down 8.3 points to close at 241, with 1,292 contract transactions, while August TE futures lost 6.9 points to finish at 243.1, with five contracts traded. September TE futures moved down 10.9 points to close at 242.1, with three contracts traded, and TE futures for next March lost 17 points to finish at 237, with two contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
July TF futures moved down 9.2 points to finish at 662, with 423 contracts changing hands, while TF futures for next March lost 4.8 points to close at 662.2, with 18 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: N.T. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.021 against the U.S. dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Tuesday, closing at 34.413.
The local currency opened Tuesday at 34.408 and was traded between 34.393 and 34.457.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$271.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FINANCE MINISTER CONFIDENT OF PROMOTION EFFORTS IN BRITAIN
DOC.DATELINE: London, June 26 (CNA) (By Mark Ou and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Visiting Republic of China Minister of Finance Yen Ching-chang said Monday that his efforts to promote investment in Taiwan will see positive results after his intensive round of meetings in Britain.

Yen, in London at the start of a five-nation European tour, delivered a speech at a seminar to promote Taiwan's investment environment in which he made specific mention of his country's ongoing financial reforms.
In addition, Yen spent most of Monday meeting with executives of international investment management companies, including Goldman Sachs, Legal & General, Gartmore, Britannic and Aegon.
Yen tried to sell them on Taiwan's overall environment and lauded especially the lure of high-tech shares and financial stocks in the Taiwan stock market.

He noted that with the rising labor and land costs in Taiwan, as well as the environmental impact assessment of any investment projects, it is more difficult to attract foreign manufacturers to set up plants in Taiwan, although he stressed that shares in the above two categories are still attractive.
Yen pointed out that Taiwan's high technology shares have a competitive edge in Asia and rest of the world.

Although he admitted that there are still some misgivings about Taiwan's financial systems, he said that compared with other Asian countries and mainland China, which has bad loans reaching as high as 40 percent, Taiwan still enjoys a competitive edge in the Asia and Pacific region.
Yen said that his focus is not to encourage foreign investors to set up plants in Taiwan, but to let them know that if they invest in its high-tech shares, the prospects are rosy.
On Taiwan's financial issues, Yen said that investors are naturally concerned about the lack of transparency and credibility, and whether the financial system is healthy.
He said that his trip aims to address some of the misgivings directed at Taiwan's financial system, and he reiterated the government's determination to push for financial reforms.
After the series of meetings and promotions, Yen said that he expects foreign investors will increase their investments in Taiwan in the medium term, if not in the short term.
He was scheduled to visit the London stock exchange and be interviewed by the Financial Times Tuesday before continuing to Amsterdam, Frankfurt, Zurich and Paris.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-CZECH JOINT-VENTURE WINS ORDER FOR NEW AIRCRAFT
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, June 25 (CNA) (By James Kuo and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's aerospace industry has achieved a breakthrough, with an ROC-Czech joint-venture firm receiving orders for a new type of commercial aircraft at the just-concluded Paris Air Show.

IBIS Aerospace, a joint venture formed by the ROC's state-owned Aerospace Industry Development Corp. (AIDC) and the Czech Republic's Aero Vodochody Co. (AV), received orders for 27 units of its 10-seater AE-270 commercial aircraft at Paris Air Show which ended last weekend.

The orders came from Australia, the United States and South Africa. In addition to the definite orders for 27 AE-270 planes, the joint-venture firm may be able to secure orders for 24 additional AE-270 planes later.
Senior executives of AIDC, AV and IBIS signed an agreement in Prague Monday on cooperation in producing 10-seater AE-270 commercial planes.
ROC Representative to the Czech Republic Roy Wu also attended the signing ceremony.
Speaking on the occasion, Wu said the ROC and the Czech Republic have spent four years jointly developing the new type of commercial aircraft.
"We are very pleased to see our efforts finally bear fruit. And the development of the new plane has laid a solid foundation for our bilateral cooperation in the aerospace industry," Wu said.

The prototype of AE-270 had been successfully displayed in aviation shows in the United States, Britain and France. "After the stages of development and marketing, the plane now formally enters the stage of mass production," Wu said, adding that he believes the joint-venture firm will have a bright future through concerted efforts from both sides.

AIDC, Taiwan's only aircraft maker, formed a joint venture with AV Co. in 1997 to develop AE-270 commercial aircraft. The development, production, testing and certification have all proceeded smoothly. IBIS is expected to be able to produce 50 planes annually. The first plane is scheduled to be delivered to its customer in the fourth quarter of next year.
AE-270 stands 12.23 meters long and 4.78 meters high. It is powered by a PT6A-66A or a PT6A-42A engine. It can fly up to 389 km per hour.

AIDC was originally operated by the ROC's military. It managed to develop and produce 130 IDF jet fighters, which, together with 150 U.S.-made F-16 and 60 French-made Mirage 2000-5 jet fighters, form the backbone of the ROC's new-generation air defense arsenal.

DOC.HEADLINE: THIRD MEETING OF APEC PRIVATIZATION FORUM OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The third Privatization Forum meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum opened in Taipei Tuesday, with more than 100 delegates from 14 member countries participating.

The establishment of the Privatization Forum was decided at an APEC Finance Ministers meeting held in 1999 to provide member countries with a mechanism for exchanging experiences and views on the issue and to offer investment and technical cooperation opportunities.
The topics up for discussion include the various types of privatization, the government's role in the process of privatization and the study of individual cases of privatization.
The delegates to the forum are from the United States, Australia, Canada, Chile, Indonesia, Japan, Peru, Malaysia, Russia, Thailand, Singapore, Hong Kong, the Philippines and Taiwan.
Experts from the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development and the World Bank were also invited to the meeting.
Council for Economic Planning and Development Vice Chairwoman Ho Mei-yueh was invited to deliver a speech at the opening of the forum.
The previous two meetings of the forum were held in Thailand in 1999 and in Indonesia last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENGHU DECLARED DISASTER-AFFECTED AREA

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) sent officials to the offshore island of Penghu again Tuesday to inspect conditions there in the wake of the passage of typhoon Chebi over the weekend.

Due to the havoc wreaked by Chebi on the Taiwan Strait archipelago, the COA declared the area disaster-affected and said it will start reconstruction work immediately of its agricultural and fishery industries.
The disaster-affected status allows farmers and fishermen to apply to the government for cash assistance and loans to start the reconstruction of their livelihoods.

The COA's initially estimated that cage aquaculture in the west islet of Penghu County suffered the most serious losses, with about 900 metric tons of cobia, snapper and grouper lost, while Paishah Village and Makung City also lost 230 metric tons and 200 metric tons of assorted cage-reared fish, respectively.
Initial loss estimates for this sector alone were estimated at more than NT$200 million.

Penghu has been listed as a major areas for the development of cage aquaculture by the government over the past few years, but faced with the effects of Chebi, the future of the industry is in jeopardy, with even the roof of the fry hatchery blown away.

COA officials reported that 109 fishing boats sank during the typhoon, while some 88 others were damaged. The losses were estimated at around NT$18 million, with damage to Chimei and Yuanan islets yet to be determined.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIX FINANCIAL BILLS HELPFUL BUT NOT A PANACEA: PREMIER

TEXT.P: The passage through the legislature of six bills related to financial reforms will help improve Taiwan's overall economic situation, although they are not a "wonder drug," Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Tuesday.

Speaking at the opening of an extra ordinary legislative session to explain the importance and urgency of the six bills, Chang said financial reforms are the most pressing issue on the government's agenda in face of the greater international competition inevitable after Taiwan joins the World Trade Organization in the near future.
The Legislative Yuan opened the additional session Tuesday to discuss the six bills at the request of President Chen Shui-bian.

Citing Ministry of Finance estimates, Chang said about NT$200 billion will be needed to set up a "finance reconstruction fund" designed to resolve the problems arising from debt-ridden banks and grassroots financial institutions. According to the premier, delay of the establishment of the fund will cost the public an additional NT$10 billion each year.

Following the approval of the bills, the government will be able to handle poorly operated banks and court foreign capital more efficiently, which Chang said will improve the current economic slump and curb the rising unemployment.

Elaborating on the bill on setting up financial holding companies, Chang said it will provide the government with a legal basis upon which to allow foreign and local financial institutions to be merged, consolidated or forge joint ventures. That will help boost the competitiveness of Taiwan's financial sector and stimulate the local economy, he added.

Timely passage of the six bills through the legislature will not only strengthen Taiwan's international image among foreign financial and rating institutions, it will also boost the Ministry of Finance's ability to lure foreign investment to Taiwan, the premier stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CONSIDERING ALLOWING GAYS TO ADOPT, START FAMILIES

TEXT.P: The government of the Republic of China is considering allowing gay couples to organize families and adopt children as it drafts a bill to strengthen human rights protection, sources from the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) reported Tuesday.

For the first time in ROC history, law articles are expected to be enacted to show respect to homosexuals, allowing male and female homosexuals to legally form families and adopt children, MOJ officials said.

However, the Human Rights Protection Law, which has just been drafted by the MOJ and is pending approval from the Executive Yuan before being sent to the Legislative Yuan for passage, stipulates that homosexuals will not be allowed to "marry."

MOJ officials said male and female homosexuals will be allowed to live together as families but the arrangement would not be considered "marriage" in the eyes of the law, as ROC law defines marriage as a man and a woman committing themselves to each other.
People of the same sex living together as families can be described as "sexual partners" but not "married couples," the officials said.
MOJ officials were clarifying false reports made by local reporters in early June saying that the ministry was drafting statutes to allow homosexuals to legally marry.

The just-drafted bill also emphasizes protection of people's rights to privacy, medical care and work, and their rights of freedom of speech, religion and communications. The people will also be protected from being illegally drafted into military service or having their personal property requisitioned for military use, MOJ officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, June 27, or the seventh day of the fifth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1801: British troops defeat a French militia force and take control of Cairo, Egypt.
1829: James Smithson, British chemist, mineralogist and philanthropist, dies in Genoa, Italy, at the age of 64. He helped establish the Smithsonian Institution in Washington.
1880: Helen Keller, American teacher, social worker, and writer, who was deaf and blind from birth, is born.
1893: A major stock market plunge begins in the United States, leading to a depression. By the end of 1893, 600 banks and 74 railroads had gone out of business.
1926: Chiang Kai-shek, who became commander-in-chief of the National Revolutionary Forces on June 5, launches the Northern Expedition from Canton.
1939: Pan American Airways operates the first scheduled transatlantic air service by the Dixie Clipper, a 19-seat flying boat, leaving Port Washington, New York, for Marseilles in France.
1945: Premier and Foreign Minister T. V. Soong, accompanied by Deputy Foreign Minister Hu Shih-tse, Shen Hung-lieh and Chiang Ching-kuo, leave for Moscow to discuss matters concerning the Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance.
1950: US President Harry Truman orders US forces into battle to aid South Korea following an invasion across the 38th parallel by North Korean troops.
1950: US President Harry Truman orders the US 7th Fleet to prevent a communist attack on Taiwan and asks the ROC government to cease air and sea operations against the mainland.
1953: Some 30,000 ROC government troops stranded on Dao Fhu Quoc (Fukuo Island) off the coast of South Vietnam begin returning to Taiwan.
1954: The world's first nuclear power station is opened at Obninsk in the Soviet Union, about 55 miles from Moscow.
1973: Dr. Chester W. Clark, new American commissioner of the Joint Commission on Rural Reconstruction, arrives in Taipei.
1975: Some 1,000 ROC military leaders conclude a five-day conference on modernizing Taiwan's military equipment and strategy.
1976: Six Palestinians hijack an Air France Airbus from Athens, Greece with 246 passengers and 12 crew onboard and force it to fly to Entebbe, Uganda, where Israeli commandos storm it on July 4.
1977: The Kaohsiung steel mill of China Steel Corp. begins production. The construction of the integrated steel mill was financed by a US$200 million loan from the Continental Illinois National Bank and the Trust Company of Chicago.
1979: The Republic of China's first "buy American" mission of the year, led by H.K. Shao, director general of the Board of Foreign Trade, departs with a shopping list for goods worth US$850 million.
1982: Broad gauge trains begin to operate on the widened railroad on the east coast area between Hualien and Taitung.
1986: The 1986 National Administration Conference opens in Taipei. More than 260 government officials and specialists attend the meeting.
1988: Intrepid British mountain climbers Dave Hurst and Alan Matthews become the first blind climbers to reach the summit of Mont Blanc in Switzerland, Europe's highest mountain at 4,810 meters.
1989: Another wave of refugee boats from Vietnam hits Hong Kong, where closed refugee camps are already bulging with 45,000 "boat people."
1991: Government spokesman Shaw Yu-ming announces that mainland Chinese journalists will no longer have to renounce their membership in the Chinese Communist Party when applying to visit Taiwan.
1998: US President Bill Clinton and Chinese President Jiang Zemin hold a press conference in Beijing. The two leaders clash over dissidents, the Dalai Lama, and the Tiananmen Square massacre.
1999: George Papadopoulos, Greek military officer and politician who became premier after a 1967 coup, dies at the age of 80. He was overthrown in 1973.
1999: A Republic of China congressional delegation led by Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng leaves for a visit to Macedonia.
2000: The Legislative Yuan adopts a special resolution requiring the government to reduce the number of foreign laborers in Taiwan starting next year.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Make it your aim to wish for moral well-being and you will never be accused of being covetous."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REPRESENTATIVE TO MACEDONIA RETURNS HOME

TEXT.P: Peter Cheng, Republic of China's minister to Macedonia before the ROC announced it had severed diplomatic ties with the Balkan country June 18, returned home Wednesday.
Cheng said he takes full responsibility for not being able to maintain relations with Macedonia after diplomatic relations ended after only two years and five months.
He also said that the staff of the ROC embassy, including his wife, are remaining behind in Macedonia to take care of the administrative work needed after the two countries severed ties.
As the fighting between Macedonian government forces and ethnic Albanian rebels could reignite at any minute, he said he was worried about the safety of the staff at the embassy.

He said that before his return to Taiwan, he called on Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski, who is friendly to the ROC. He said the real reason for breaking ties is the civil war plaguing the nation, adding that Macedonia wants to get the support of mainland China in the United Nations to send peacekeeping forces to the civil war-torn nation.
He said that he would report to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs immediately about the full situation and take responsibility for the rupture of relations.
Cheng also said that the technical mission now stationed in Macedonia will be transferred to Guatemala.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CRIMINALS REPATRIATED FROM MAINLAND

TEXT.P: Four Taiwanese criminals who fled to mainland China were repatriated to Taiwan Wednesday in accordance with the "1990 Kinmen Agreement," sources from the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) reported.

The four criminals -- Huang Shih-fang, Kuo Chun-wei, Chiu Fu-chin, Yeh Jui-chi -- were taken by officials from mainland China's Red Cross Society from Fuzhou's Mawei port to the Republic of China's frontline Matsu Island by ship.
In Matsu, the fugitives, who were wanted by Taiwan police authorities on different charges, were received by personnel from the ROC Red Cross Society, CIB officials said.
The repatriation was arranged by Taiwan's quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation.

The Kinmen Agreement, signed between the Red Cross Societies of Taiwan and the mainland on Sept. 12, 1990, governs the repatriation of mainland Chinese stowaways in Taiwan and criminals from Taiwan who have fled to mainland China.
