DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND AFFAIRS OFFICIAL ADVISES CROSS-STRAIT INVESTORS TO BE WARY

TEXT.P: In an interview with Taiwan's Central News Agency, Teng said that mainland China is an important part of the world economy and one which cannot be ignored. He said that Taiwan businessmen's activities in China are bound to increase.
"Currently there are no less than 50,000 Taiwanese companies operating on the mainland and they have recruited some 500,000 staff members, mostly of the executive levels, from Taiwan," Teng said.
"As a matter of fact, the figures are very likely underestimated, because no official records are kept," he added.

"Taiwan's media have been enthusiastic in reporting on the positive side of mainland China's developments and have very often failed to provide a more complete picture," Teng pointed out, adding that Taiwan businessmen should study the market more thoroughly and must not be overwhelmed just by a glimpse of the skyscrapers in Shanghai.

Since Taiwan's domestic market can no longer sustain the growth of the business and industrial sectors, internationalization is the only alternative, and in recent years many Taiwanese businessmen have tried their luck in a market with a more familiar cultural background, according to Teng.

But even with similar cultural backgrounds, the different political and economic systems and mentalities between Taiwan and China can be challenging. "Taiwan businessmen are taking a risk when they deal with ambiguous laws and regulations and unpredictable human factors in law enforcement while investing there," Teng said.

He said that personal safety and investment guarantees are the major concern of investors in every part of the world. However, Taiwan businessmen are guaranteed none of these in mainland China. Even when both Beijing and Taipei are admitted into the World Trade Organization (WTO), no guarantees are assured, according to Teng.

Teng foresees that Taiwan businessmen's participation in mainland China's economic activities will continue to rise in view of the fact that people there are becoming more affluent. Mainland China's membership in the WTO will also mean that the market will open even further, he said.

Statistics compiled by the Mainland Affairs Council show that in the first five months of this year, Taiwanese investments in mainland China amounted to US$1,068.4 million, a 33.18 percent year-on-year growth. In 2000, Taiwanese businessmen poured US$2,607 million in that market. Investments in mainland China account for 40 percent of Taiwan's overall overseas investments.

In order to lure more high-technology and capital-intensive industries to invest there, authorities in mainland China are offering investors from abroad favorable treatment, such as tax holidays, convenient land acquisition and advantages to market access.

Teng said that the offers are tempting, but investors are advised to take the security factor into consideration. Direct investments in mainland China are not permitted by Taiwan's authorities yet, partially because Taiwan businessmen's safety and interest are not legally guaranteed by Beijing authorities, he added.
The lure of cross-strait exchanges and investment is strong, but it must not endanger Taiwan's interests, according to Teng.

He said that Taiwan companies seeking more opportunities across the Strait should keep corporate ethics and social obligations in mind. Any moves to China must not result in large numbers of jobless workers in Taiwan and the deterioration of the upstream or downstream sectors of the industries involved.
Most of the Taiwanese investments in mainland China are concentrated in the coastal provinces of higher development, including Kiangsu, Kwangtung, Fukien, Hopei, and Chekiang.

Teng said that rapid development in these regions undoubtedly have impressed not only businessmen but also tourists from Taiwan. Last year, Taiwanese tourists made over 3 million visits to mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP LABOR AFFAIRS OFFICIAL SAYS ROTC WILL HELP EASE UNEMPLOYMENT

TEXT.P: An increasing number of college graduates are opting to enter the Reserve Officers Training Corps (ROTC), a situation that should ease the jobless situation, Taiwan's top labor affairs official said Wednesday.

Chen Chu, chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA), said she welcomed the record number of openings in the ROTC program now offered by the Ministry of National Defense (MND) for college-level men.

The ROTC, a legal framework for recruiting domestic civilian college students for training as reserve officers, is more than welcome now at a time when the country's unemployment has shot up to an annual rate of 4.22, a 20-year high, Chen said.
Of those currently unemployed, she said, more than 80,000 of them are between the ages of 20 and 24. Nearly 60,000 people between 25 and 29 are not working or looking for a job.

At a press conference held at the Executive Yuan Wednesday marking the ROTC recruitment campaign, Minister of National Defense Wu Shih-wen welcomed young men with college-level education to join the ROTC program, which was originally designed to help relieve an acute shortage of low-ranking military officers.

According to Chiu Chao-li, an executive officer of the Armed Forces Recruitment Center, the ROTC program has a record-high 8,373 openings this year. Of the total, 545 openings have already been filled.

Chiu said the remaining 7,828 openings are available to young men aged between 18 and 27. The current ROTC program has three levels, available for young men aged between 18 and 25 who are college graduates, those who are master degree holders and aged between 20 and 27, and those who are high school graduates and aged between 18 and 24.

The ROC Army will offer each trainee at least NT$10,000 (US$290) a month in tuition aid and living allowance until their graduation after a service of three to five years, depending on their service requirements in the ROTC, Chiu noted. The ROTC trainees are also entitled to a retirement pension when they leave the military, he added.

The ROTC system, patterned after the one in use in the United States, has been successful there and in South Korea. Several noted American generals, including the current U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell, entered the military through an ROTC program.

Trainees must serve in the military for at least three years. They can either continue to serve in the military or retire after they finish their ROTC term and mandatory military training, which generally lasts for two to three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN LIEN CHAN RETURNS FROM OVERSEAS TRIP

TEXT.P: Lien Chen, chairman of the largest opposition party, the Kuomintang (KMT), said Wednesday that it would be "immoral" if someone wanted to create rivalry among the people of Taiwan by using religion, ethnicity or issues relating to unification (with mainland China) or Taiwan independence.

Lien was responding to reports that someone from the KMT is trying to establish a new political group. He made the comments while presiding over the first KMT Central Standing Committee meeting since his return from an overseas trip early Wednesday morning.

Huang Chu-wen, a former interior minister, recently said that he was working to form a political group, and his words came at a sensitive time because observers have said former ROC president and former KMT chairman Lee Teng-hui would help President Chen Shui-bian of the Democratic Progressive Party to control more than half of the legislative seats in the year-end elections.
Lien said that although the Constitution guarantees the right of the people to form political parties or groups, the proposed group needs to clearly state its ideals and its direction.

Lien said that if someone is trying to use religion, ethnicity or gender issues to splinter the people of Taiwan for his own political ends, it would be an "immoral" act as the island is small and cannot afford rivalry.
Lien also said democracy is about party politics and the ruling party has to shoulder its own responsibilities, while the opposition party has the responsibility for checks and balances.

Lien criticized some of the current rhetoric that said the new government should be given more time to learn, adding that running the nation requires minute-to-minute attention, and there is no time to waste in sitting idly by.

If the party is ready to rule the country, it will have to point out its policy and implement it, but Lien said he wondered where the government that has been in office for the past year is leading the country.

Earlier, Lien was welcomed by his four deputies, including Wang Jin-pyng, Wu Poh-hsiung, Chiang Chung-lin, and Helen C.C. Lin, KMT legislators Chen Horng-chi, Kao Yu-jen, Chu Fong-chi and James Chen and hundreds of KMT supporters when he flew into the CKS International Airport from the United States.
Lien, left Taiwan June 10 to visit London, Paris, and New York and Denver, said that those he met on his trip were concerned about the development of the ROC over the past year.

During his interview with the U.S. media, Lien said he was asked why the ratings for President Chen Shui-bian were falling. He said that the reason is a combination of factors -- Taiwan's sluggish economy, stalled cross-strait relations and a constitutional crisis.
Lien also said that many have expressed the idea that the KMT, because of its sound policies, its ample talent pool and broad vision, is the mainstream party of the Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD BUSINESS LEADERS PLEDGE ACTION AGAINST AIDS

TEXT.P: Leaders of some of the world's biggest companies, including The Coca-Cola Co. and MTV Networks International, announced their commitment Tuesday to fight the global AIDS epidemic, and called upon other business leaders to join the cause.
The business leaders announced their resolve after a meeting Tuesday with United Nations Secretary-General Kofi Annan during a U.N. Special Session on AIDS.

"HIV/AIDS sets unique challenges for society, but business has demonstrated that it can bring some unique strengths to bear on those challenges," said Bill Roedy, President of MTV Networks International and chair of the Global Business Council on HIV and AIDS (GBC) ,an international group of companies spear-heading the business response to match the ingenuity and innovation that some have already shown.

Roedy unveiled the GBC's blueprint for business action on AIDS, designed to encourage business leaders to mobilize a response to the epidemic by their own companies. Illustrated with case studies from companies leading the business response to the epidemic, including MAC Cosmetics, Unilever and Standard Chartered Bank, the blueprint calls for businesses to implement workplace policies and program, harness business strengths to solve the problems created by the epidemic and provide advocacy and leadership in the fight against HIV/AIDS.
In today's meeting with Annan and other business leaders, Roedy announced that Richard Holbrooke, former U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, has been named president and CEO of the GBC.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK INDEX REBOUNDS

TEXT.P: Prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) rebounded as electronics shares rose after hitting a new low Wednesday.
The weighted TAIEX price index, or the market's key barometer, rose 40.16 points to close at 4,825.28.
Market turnover totaled NT$37.19 billion (US$1.08 billion) in thin trading as most investors stayed on the sidelines due to economic uncertainty.
A total of 1.68 billion shares changed hands during the four-and-half-hour trading session.
The market opened higher at 4,822.67 points and reached a high of 4,871.74 points and hit a low of 4,773.88 points.

All eight major categories except electronics issues lost ground. The electronics stocks gained 1.5 percent, while paper stocks dropped 2 percent, cement shares declined 1.1 percent, foodstuffs issues fell 0.9 percent, textile issues dropped 0.6 percent, and construction, financial, plastics and chemical issues dropped 0.3 percent each.
Losers outnumbered gainers 298 to 207, with 86 stocks remaining unchanged. (By Lilian Wu) EDNITEM ZCZC CEP011 06-27-01 KAOHSIUNG OFFICIAL DENIES HONG KONG GAVE VISA TO MAYOR HSIEH

Kaohsiung, June 27 (CNA) An official with the Kaohsiung City Hall denied Wednesday that the Hong Kong authorities have granted an entry visa to Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh, saying that some local newspaper reports have been "too optimistic."

Hung Fu-feng, director of the Research, Evaluation and Development Committee under the Kaohsiung City Government, said he is leaving for Hong Kong Wednesday afternoon to gain a better understanding of the matter.

Hsieh was planning to join Kaohsiung municipal government officials in charge of development, construction, mass rapid transit (MRT), news and research and evaluation affairs, on a three-day fact-finding trip to Hong Kong scheduled from June 29 to July 1.
The Kaohsiung officials hope to familiarize themselves with Hong Kong's development, particularly the MRT systems and harbor development projects.
All Kaohsiung city officials who applied to visit Hong Kong obtained their visas by June 20, except for the mayor, according to Hung.

Hung denied recent local reports saying that Hsieh is ready to go to Hong Kong as he has obtained a visa from the Hong Kong authorities for entry. As a matter of fact, he noted, a visa for Hsieh was still nowhere in sight as of Wednesday noon.

Meanwhile, according to Hung, Hsieh, a stalwart of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party, plans to visit Hong Kong in his capacity as the mayor of Kaohsiung. He refuses to land at the airport in Hong Kong, however, and then apply for a landing visa, Hung added.
Hsieh tried to visit mainland China's port city of Xiamen several months ago, but was denied an entry visa by the mainland Chinese authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: REPORT AGAINST BREAST SELF-EXAMS CAUSING CONTROVERSY IN CANADA

TEXT.P: A major medical report advising against teaching breast self-exams to women aged 40 to 69 is causing controversy in Canada.
A study in Tuesday's issue of the Canadian Medical Association Journal said teaching women how to do breast self-exams causes more harm than good.

Dr. Nancy Baxter and the Canadian Task Force on Preventive Health Care conclude, "Because there is fair evidence of no benefit, and good evidence of harm," routine breast self-exams shouldn't be recommended.
The major downsides include unnecessary anxiety for women and money spent on biopsies on benign lumps caused by suspicious self-examiners.
That money will be better spent by more effective screening measures like mammography and breast exams done by medical professionals, the study suggested.
But the Canadian Breast Cancer Network urged doctors to ignore the "flawed" report and keep teaching women how to examine their breasts for lumps.

The network cited a woman who lost her mother to breast cancer and started to get mammograms when she reached 40. Since then, the woman has twice found cancerous lumps that didn't show up on mammograms.
Over the last 30 years, the self-exam has been recommended by leading cancer organizations, such as the National Cancer Institute.

Dr. Cornelia Baines, professor of public health sciences at the University of Toronto and a specialist in breast cancer screening, wrote a scathing review of the article in the Canadian Medical Association Journal before it was published.
To start with, she said the study uses data from groups of women in mainland China and Russia, where the level of medical treatment and public information is much inferior to that in Canada.

Baines said false alarms are inevitable with other screening methods as well as breast self-exams. The real problem is that all available screening methods have flaws, and it's counter-productive to single out breast self-exams, she stressed.
The one thing that Baines agreed with in the study is that doing self-exams may cause anxiety to some women, while not doing such exams may make them feel guilty.
The Canadian Cancer Society said it's still a good idea for women to know their own breasts and report any changes to their doctors.
Breast cancer is the most common form of cancer in Canadian women. Breast self-exams have helped some women detect lumps earlier.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING ORDERS PURGE OF MEDIA IN HONG KONG

TEXT.P: A purge of errant publications and editors has been ordered in a Chinese Communist Party document issued to tighten mainland censorship in the run-up to the 16th Party Congress in autumn next year, the South China Morning Post reported Wednesday.

According to the report, the key document, which spells out curbs on politically incorrect articles and rules on other media restrictions and ownership, is scheduled to come into effect on Sunday, but the measures have already begun, with the closure or temporary suspension of eight publications this month.

"Leaders were alarmed about 'active thinking' among intellectuals recently and feared that critical essays, especially those calling for political reform at the 16th party plenum, would muddle the minds of cadres and the public," a senior official of the Central Publicity Department reportedly said, which issued the document with the State Press and Publications Administration.
The report revealed that President Jiang Zemin had ordered the 2,000-word document to be circulated to all publications to alert them that offending publications would not be given a second chance.
More publications would be closed when the new rules came into effect, it quoted sources as saying.
According to the document, publications will be shut permanently without further warning if editors break rules or express opposition to the party line.

The internal document also lists several criteria for punishment. Strictly forbidden are articles and reports speculating on leadership changes or calling for political reforms at the 16th Party Congress, such as a multi-party system; articles and reports violating the "cardinal principles of Marxism"; material contradicting main party and state policies; pornography; violence; material containing military or other state secrets; material threatening social stability or going against Beijing's policies toward ethnic minorities; and fabricated reports.

The rules ban news gathering on major corruption scandals, major criminal cases and human and natural disasters. All publications are required to use only reports from Xinhua for these items. Selling periodical licenses will also be severely punished.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures markets closed higher Wednesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for July rose 56 points to close at 4,890, with 7,552 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for August gained 15 points to finish at 4,865, with 61 contract changing hands. September futures dropped 41 points to close at 4,859, with six contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 4,834 for July, 4,850 for August, 4,900 for September, 4,885 for December and 4,905 for next March.
Electronics (TE) and Financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, both closed higher.
July TE futures moved up 4.4 points to close at 245.40, with 1,696 contract transactions, while August TE futures rose 1.8 points to close at 244.90, with three transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
July TF futures moved up 4 points to close at 666, with 344 contracts changing hands, while TF futures for next March gain 13.8 points to close at 676 , with 22 contacts trades.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar dropped NT$0.043 against the U.S. dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Wednesday, closing at NT$34.456.
The local currency opened at today's high of NT$34.398 and had a low of NT$34.470.
Interbank U.S. dollar transactions totaled US$351 million. (By Bear Lee)

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MINISTER ENCOURAGES DUTCH BUSINESSMEN TO INVEST IN TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, June 27 (CNA) (By Tang Ping-chun and Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Finance Yen Ching-chang Wednesday encouraged businessmen and foreign investors in the Netherlands to make investment in Taiwan.
He made the appeal while speaking at a "Taiwan Investment Forum" held at an Amsterdam hotel to solicit foreign investment.

At the forum, attended by representatives from Dutch and foreign financial institutions, Yen reported on the economic development and foreign investment in Taiwan, as well as the progress of Taiwan's financial reform.
He said that owing to Taiwan's sound financial structure, Taiwan was not affected by the financial storms that hit most Asian countries several years ago.
In order to attract more foreign investment, Yen noted that the Taipei government is establishing a new financial reform mechanism to improve the investment environment.

A group of Taiwan financial and industrial experts, who came with Yen, held talks with their Dutch counterparts to exchange views on the development of Taiwan's financial, scientific and technological sectors.
Amsterdam was the second leg of Yen's European tour to seek foreign investment. He visited London earlier and will now go to Frankfurt Wednesday evening.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT VISITS CORNELL UNIVERSITY
DOC.DATELINE: Ithaca, New York, June 26 (CNA) (By Eric C.Y. Tseng and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui returned Tuesday to his alma mater, Cornell University, to a welcome from nearly 1,000 overseas Chinese supporters.

The primary event on his Ithaca itinerary is the dedication of a research center named after him. A ground-breaking ceremony for the Lee Teng-hui Institute for Scientific Research -- to be dedicated to nano-technology research -- was scheduled to be held on campus Wednesday.
Lee earned a Ph.D. in agricultural economics at Cornell in 1968. He last visited the campus in June 1995 when he was ROC president and delivered a resounding speech.
At an evening reception Tuesday, Lee delivered a 50-minute speech to approximately 700 guests, who frequently interrupted him with warm applause.
Lee said that there is "nothing bad" about letting the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) rule the Republic of China after the Kuomintang (KMT) has ruled it for the past 50 years.
Lee, who until last year was the KMT chairman, added that "for the good of the nation, of course it is okay" to have another political party in power.
He also urged the people to give the DPP administration some time to adjust because it lacks experience.
However, he stressed that he will "never" help the DPP -- as others claim he is doing -- because to do so would be "disloyal" to the KMT.

Cornell President Hunter R. Rawlings III was scheduled to host a dinner in Lee's honor Wednesday. Lee is slated to fly to Los Angeles from Ithaca Thursday and testify his belief in Christianity there at a gathering of his overseas Chinese supporters before concluding his visit July 1 and returning to Taipei July 3.
Lee, who originally planned to visit his alma mater in early May, postponed his trip because he went to Japan to have minor heart surgery in late April.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE ECONOMICS MINISTER COURTING INVESTMENT IN NEW YORK

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice Economic Affairs Minister Lin Yi-fu presided over an investment symposium Tuesday in New York in which he strongly recommended Taiwan as "the best" stronghold for U.S. firms seeking globalization.

Describing Taiwan as located "at the junction of Northeast Asia and South Asia," Lin said Taiwan's economic clout and abundant capital, as well as its hi-tech manpower and upgraded industrial levels, make the island an ideal investment site for U.S. companies.

Lin made the remarks while introducing Taiwan's investment climate to more than 70 representatives of U.S. enterprises, including Vision System, X-Ray, Optical System, Prime Mediate International and Sprint Investment Corp. at the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York.

Lin told CNA following the event that the Taiwan government will fully back the development of local hi-tech industries, which have a much greater potential than traditional industries. He said his ministry has adopted the strategy of first contacting those local firms interested in expanding into Taiwan and than focusing on convincing them that Taiwan is worthy of their investments.

The vice economic affairs minister further pointed out that his ministry will cooperate with other government agencies and joint venture companies to sponsor similar activities in North America, Europe and Japan in search of greater investment in Taiwan by foreign hi-tech companies.

In response to the question of how Taiwan will tackle the situation in the face of increased foreign capital pouring into mainland China, Lin claimed that Taiwan's advantages such as innovation and marketing ability will not be matched by mainland China in the short term. He stressed that the government should do its best to tell foreign investors about this.
Lin was scheduled to proceed to Boston later that day, where he was slated to hold an investment symposium and visit three hi-tech companies.

He paid a visit a day earlier to the Long Island-based Symbol Technologies -- the world's largest maker of bar code scanners, whose business turnover totaled US$1.5 billion in 2000, up 27.3 percent over the 1999 level.
A Symbol executive told Lin that his company has a high interest in setting up a branch and a technology center in Taiwan in the future.
Symbol currently has two agents and several outsourced contractors in Taiwan for its production of optical fiber for bar code scanners and connectors.

Later the same day, Lin also called at the New York-based eMagin, which is an OLED maker. Although eMagin said it has no plans to invest in Taiwan at present, it will send company officials to visit Taiwan next month.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PEOPLE FAIL TOTAL QUALITIES AVERAGE: POLL

TEXT.P: The average Taiwanese person has a total quality management (TQM) score of just 47 points on a scale of 100, according to the results of a survey released Wednesday.

The survey, conducted by the Open Weekly magazine from June 1-2 by telephone, found that the Taiwanese population as a whole has a TQM of 47 points, compared with an even lower 41 points for Taiwan's legislators, 55 points for mayors and magistrates, and 61 points for ministerial-level officials.

The survey of 1,088 adults islandwide -- divided into the general public, legislators, mayors, magistrates and ministerial-level officials -- found that the Taiwan public gave themselves a flunk score of 47.7 points, using a score of 60 as a pass, while legislators gave themselves the lowest rating among the various sectors of local society.

Based on the criteria of five indicators -- innovation, altruism, legality, participation and effectiveness, Taiwan's lawmakers scored particularly low because most of them are considered unable to avoid possible conflicts of interest, have been mired in too many political, financial and sexual scandals and have screened and legislated too few bills, according to the pollsters.

On the issue of altruism, 34.7 percent of the Taiwan public said most passengers on domestic transportation systems would yield their seat to the elderly, pregnant women or little children, while 37.7 percent said this virtue is not prevalent at all.

On the legality aspect, 64.2 percent of the survey respondents said running red lights is the norm on Taiwan streets, while 29.3 percent disagreed. 73.9 percent said buying fake goods is the norm, while only 11.4 percent disagreed.

According to the pollsters, the ministerial-level officials gave themselves a scrape-through pass of 61 points because those officials are not popularly elected, have generally higher educational backgrounds and they are from the "same team" -- all of them are appointed by the Democratic Progressive Party-governed administration -- leading them to evaluate each other more highly.

DOC.HEADLINE: 175 ILLEGAL MAINLAND CHINESE IMMIGRANTS REPATRIATED

TEXT.P: A total of 175 illegal mainland Chinese immigrants were repatriated Wednesday from Fu Au Port on the frontline island of Matsu through arrangements by the Red Cross Societies of Taiwan and mainland China.

A spokesman for the Matsu-based Mainland Chinese People-Handling Center said the 175 illegals had previously been housed at the "Ching Lu" Detention Center, while another 124 -- including four airplane hijackers -- still at the detention center would be sent back to the mainland Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PLANNING FOR PRESIDENTIAL ECONOMIC ADVISORY COMMITTEE TO BEGIN

TEXT.P: The first preparatory meeting for a new presidential economic development advisory committee is slated to take place July 8, with Premier Chang Chung-hsiung serving as convener for the preparatory committee.

Presidential Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun said Wednesday after a second coordination meeting for the advisory committee that the preparatory committee will be made up of 35 people representing various political parties and government agencies.

He added that the five deputy conveners of the preparatory committee will be members of the Kuomintang, Democratic Progressive Party, People First Party and New Party, as well as an "impartial member of the public."

The idea of forming the advisory committee was proposed by President Chen Shui-bian, who pledged to chair the committee himself to solicit the opinions of experts and scholars on how to reform the nation's sagging economy and plan for the island's future economic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: RARE APRIL DROP IN TAIWAN EXPORTS TO MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Affected by a slumping international economy, Taiwan exports to mainland China in April fell by 3.8 percent from a year ago, a rare decline for that month since 1998, government tallies show.

According to statistics released Wednesday by the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT), Taiwan shipped US$2.74 billion-worth of products and services to mainland China in April, down 3.8 percent from the year-earlier level. During the same month, Taiwan imported US$566 million-worth of mainland Chinese goods, up 2.2 percent over the 2000 level.

Although BOFT estimates indicate that cross-Taiwan Strait trade is unlikely to improve in the near term, the board said slashing of customs duties by mainland Chinese authorities on 3,462 items, ranging from 16.4 percent to 15.3 percent, should help boost local demand for foreign products, including those from Taiwan.

Taiwan's trade with mainland China totaled US$9.55 billion during the first four months of this year, a 0.7 percent increase over the corresponding period of last year, leaving Taiwan with a trade surplus of US$5.66 billion, according to the BOFT tallies.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRANDMOTHER OF CHINESE BRAZILIAN BOY LEAVES FOR HOME

TEXT.P: Rosa Leocadia Da Silva Ergui, the grandmother of the Chinese Brazilian orphan Iruan Ergui, left sadly for home Wednesday after failing to resolve the custody issue over the five-year-old child.
Ergui, accompanied by her son-in-law, arrived in Taiwan four days ago in an attempt to regain custody over the child from his Taiwanese uncle.

Prior to her departure, Ergui told local reporters at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport that she will bring the case to court in accordance with Republic of China law to get back the boy, over whom she has had official guardianship since her daughter's death three years ago.
The boy was brought to Taiwan to visit his local relatives in March this year by his father, Wu Ding-shu, the captain of a fishing vessel.

However, Wu died 11 days later in Taiwan and his brother, Wu Hou-yen now claims it was his brother's wish that the boy be raised in Taiwan, despite having officially and legally given the boy up to Ergui.
A day earlier, the boy's registration for permanent residence in Taiwan was completed.
Meanwhile, Wu expressed hope that the inconclusive consultations between him and Ergui will be continued so as to effect a peaceful resolution to the custody issue.

Kuomintang Legislator Lin Yi-shih, who tried to help resolve the dispute, said that he has proposed to Ergui's local lawyer that the guardianship issue and the issue of where the child is raised can be resolved separately, but added that Ergui's lawyer had not responded.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S LEADING ECONOMIC INDEX CONTINUES TO DIP

TEXT.P: Taiwan's leading economic index continued to drop for the 16th consecutive month in May to its lowest level since September 1985, the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) announced Wednesday.
As the leading index reflects the economic situation in the coming three to six months, it means that the chances of a recovery in the third quarter of this year are very slim.
Like last month, the island's economy flashed a "blue" light in May, representing a recession based on the country's official rating system.

In the CEPD-devised rating system, a "red" light means the economy is overheated, "yellow-red" indicates the economy is heating up, "green" reflects steady growth, "yellow-blue" signals economic sluggishness and "blue" represents recession.

Hu Chung-ying, director of the CEPD's Economic Research Department, told reporters that if the leading economic index continues to slip in the coming months, it will be very difficult for Taiwan to achieve even a 4 percent real growth rate this year.

As the second quarter is going to end soon, he said that it seems unlikely that a 3.26 percent growth rate will be attained for the second quarter as had been predicted by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
He said that the Taiwan Institute for Economic Research has predicted that the island's growth for the second quarter will be around 1 percent, far lower than the prediction made by the DGBAS.

DOC.HEADLINE: DETAILS OF KAOHSIUNG MAYOR'S UPCOMING H.K. TRIP NOT CONCLUDED
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Southern Taiwan, June 27 (CNA) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh said Wednesday that details of his upcoming visit to Hong Kong still have not yet been concluded.
However, he said he is not planning to meet Hong Kong Chief Executive Tung Chee-hua because the main purpose of his trip is to observe Hong Kong's mass rapid transport system and bay construction.

He noted that other members of his delegation -- comprised of Kaohsiung City construction, rapid transit and labor affairs officials -- will go to Hong Kong as scheduled because they had already obtained entry visas.

The local press had reported that the Hong Kong authorities had approved his visa, but Hsieh said he would have to wait and see. The visa is proving controversial, as Hsieh refused to accept entering the former British colony on a landing visa, opting instead to apply for an entry visa.

Meanwhile, Hung Fu-feng, director of the Commission of Research, Development and Evaluation of the Kaohsiung city government, left Wednesday for Hong Kong to check the progress of Hsieh's visa application and said there was a 50-50 chance of the visa being granted.
Hsieh said that he hopes to visit Hong Kong June 29-July 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT ADVOCATES EASING LIMITATIONS ON TRADE WITH MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: An opposition Kuomintang (KMT) official advocated Wednesday a significant easing of limitations on trade with and investment in mainland China.

Kao Koong-lian, who served as vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council between 1991-1997, also criticized the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) for failing to show leadership in its policy toward Beijing since taking power last year.
The DPP government was forced to tinker with the policy it inherited from the KMT, but never revamped it in perspective, despite the considerable changes in the political situation, according to Kao.

Noting that President Chen Shui-bian promised during his presidential campaign to phase out limitations on economic exchanges with mainland China during his first year in office, Kao said the promise has proved to be "just another rubber check" which cannot be paid.

As to the idea floated by DPP economic officials of levying a "national security tax" on firms investing in mainland China after the prohibition is lifted, Kao said such a move would be no less than a punishment for Taiwan businessmen who are forced to venture into the mainland Chinese market in order to survive.
He criticized the government's proposal to limit the island's investment in mainland China to a fixed percentage of its gross national product as "unfeasible."

The government should also take into account the forthcoming accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO) by both Taiwan and mainland China while charting its new policy toward Beijing, he went on.

Kao said the National Policy Foundation -- a KMT think tank -- has just finished a thorough review of the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area and suggested to change 12 articles to the following effect:

-- Getting rid of the current legal limitations on trade with and investment in mainland China, as the unnecessary prohibition on the fields in which local businessmen may invest in mainland China only dampens their competitiveness against their foreign counterparts;

-- Opening direct trade with and investment in mainland China, without which, strategic business alliances forged between local firms and foreign counterparts with the purpose of developing the mainland market will be useless;

-- Allowing ships flying flags of convenience to ply directly between Taiwan and mainland China ports, which would ease the pressure on local material and component manufacturing firms to relocate to mainland China and promote the competitiveness of Taiwan's Kaohsiung Harbor;

-- Improving Taiwan's investment climate to attract the inflow of overseas capital, which entails the infrastructure construction of waterways, electrical generation and transmission, as well as the use of the government's power to dispose of illegal obstructions to investment projects;

-- Forming a vertical division of labor between Taiwan and mainland China, which would serve the interests of both sides by getting rid of the competition and confrontation between the two sides that leads to the waste of resources;

-- Making the island an Asia-Pacific regional operations center on the strength of its geographic position, which would require the island's thorough globalization, including the disposal of the current limitations on economic exchanges with mainland China; and

-- Shifting the emphasis of development away from the manufacturing industry, which is withering under the competition from mainland China, to the hi-tech industries such as information, optical-electrical industry and biotech industry.
The above proposals were referred to the KMT policy committee, which will ask party legislators to initiate changes to regulations to allow their translation into government policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE APPROVES SIX FINANCIAL REFORM BILLS

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan concluded a two-day extraordinary session Wednesday with the approval of four major financial reform bills, adding to two that were already passed the previous day.

The last and most time-consuming bill to clear the legislature was the Financial Holding Company Law, which from Nov. 1 will require a company with controlling interest in a bank, insurance company or brokerage firm to establish a holding company.
The law is expected to help consolidate the financial sector by facilitating mergers and acquisitions.

Also passing the legislature was a statute for the establishment and management of a NT$140 billion (US$4.06 billion) financial rehabilitation fund similar to the U.S. Resolution Trust Company of the 1980s to clean up bad loans, particularly at local farmers' cooperatives.
The major source of money for the fund will come from a 2 percent business tax on financial institutions over the next four years.
A revision bill to the Business Tax Law passed earlier in the day decrees that the 2 percent tax will be abolished beginning 2006.
A bills finance management law also cleared the legislature Wednesday.
The previous day, the legislature approved an Insurance Law revisions bill and a Deposits Insurance Act revisions bill.

Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said that he had already informed the Presidential Office of the results of the extraordinary session and would submit the six laws to be promulgated by President Chen Shui-bian, who requested the extraordinary session in order to debate and ratify the urgently needed bills.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TOUTS TAIWAN'S BUSINESS ENVIRONMENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian made a pitch for the island's business environment Wednesday to a gathering of local businessmen who operate in mainland China.
Speaking at the gathering, Chen reiterated his promise to make "Taiwan's interest, economic development and encouraging investment" his government's top priorities.
He also restated the four directions his government is pressing ahead with at full steam, namely "all-out efforts to woo business, solicit investment, revitalize the economy, and create jobs."

Chen said he believes Taiwan and mainland China will firmly anchor the region to prosperity and stability so long as the governments and people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait can arrange exchanges on the basis of "sincere reconciliation, aggressive cooperation and eternal peace."

Noting that it is the duty of the government to take care of Taiwan businessmen in mainland China, Chen said his government will set up Taiwanese primary and junior high schools in mainland China to educate the children of mainland-based Taiwan businessmen and is seriously considering a proposal to set up senior high schools there.

He also promised to properly address Taiwan businessmen's demands for the import of products made in mainland China by Taiwan firms, direct shipment of personnel and cargo across the Taiwan Strait via Kinmen and Matsu, allowing Taiwan businessmen's mainland Chinese spouses to work in Taiwan and be covered by the national health insurance program and relaxation of the restrictions on the introduction of skilled hi-tech workers from mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI OFFICIAL MEETS TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN IN SHANGHAI
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, June 27 (CNA) (By Liao Chen-yu & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The director of the Cultural Affairs Department under the Taipei city government met Wednesday with Taiwan businessmen in Shanghai.

Lung Ying-tai affirmed the businessmen's courage in exploring a new life in the booming mainland Chinese city, but several of the businessmen complained about the Taiwan government's restrictions on investing in the mainland.
Lung told them that business competition is borderless and added that it is natural for Taiwan businessmen to seek business opportunities in mainland China.
She said that the issue regarding "one China" or "two Chinas" should be resolved by the governments of both sides and should not become a burden for businessmen.

During the talks, Lung expressed her hope that the businessmen will be able to play a positive role in the promotion of cultural exchanges between Taipei and Shanghai, which the businessmen said that they are willing to do.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO CHIEF MEETS WITH JOURNALISTS IN BELGIUM
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, June 27 (CNA) (By Tang Ping-chun & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Government Information Office (GIO) Director-General Su Tzen-ping met with Belgian and foreign journalists stationed in Brussels Wednesday to explain the Republic of China government's major policies.

The topics raised during the talks included mainland China's and Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization, democratic and social development in mainland China, the construction of Taiwan's fourth nuclear power plant and direct trade, postal and transport links between Taiwan and the mainland.
Su, who is the official spokesman for the Executive Yuan, arrived in Brussels Tuesday and is scheduled to give a speech on "Taiwan's New Middle Way" at the European Policy Research Center Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSTRUCTION OF 8TH GUIDED MISSILE FRIGATE PROCEEDING SMOOTHLY

TEXT.P: Construction of the Perry-class guided missile frigate "Tientan" is proceeding smoothly and will be delivered to the Republic of China Navy in 2003 as scheduled, a spokesman for the China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) said Wednesday.

The navy ordered the frigate, the last of an order of eight Perry-class frigates, in March this year. The other seven ships were delivered by November 1997, with the eighth vessel held up by budget constraints.

According to U.S. Navy data, the Perry-class high-speed frigate has a gross weight of more than 3,000 tons and is equipped with advanced radar, Standard missiles, rockets, torpedoes, depth charges, 40-caliber and 60-caliber machine-guns and Hsiungfeng-II attack missiles. The frigate can also be equipped with two anti-submarine helicopters.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GOVERNMENT RANKED 27TH FOR `CLEANLINESS'
DOC.DATELINE: London, June 27 (CNA) (By Mark Ou & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan was ranked 27th in terms of its government's cleanliness Wednesday by international private anti-corruption organization Transparency International.
In its annual survey of 91 countries around the world, Taiwan got a score of 5.9 out of a possible 10, with 10 the least corrupt government and zero the most corrupt.
The island came in 28th place in a 1999 survey, with a score of 5.6.
The organization metes out the corruption perception index according to interviews with academics, business leaders and analysts.

An executive from the organization said the latest survey was prepared from the data of the last three years and noted that any government's newly launched anti-graft efforts might not be immediately reflected in its ranking.
Finland led the pack with an index of 9.9, followed by Denmark with 9.5, New Zealand with 9.4 and Iceland and Singapore tied at 9.2.
Hong Kong led its Asian neighbors with an index of 7.9 in 14th place, followed by Japan with 7.1 for 21st place, and Taiwan.
Asian states trailing Taiwan were Malaysia, with 5.0 at 36th, South Korea, with 4.2 at 42nd, and mainland China, with 3.5 at 57th.
Thailand, the Philippines and Vietnam were further behind still in terms of government corruption.

DOC.HEADLINE: WIFE OF TAIWAN BUSINESSMAN KIDNAPPED, FREED AFTER PAYING RANSOM
DOC.DATELINE: Panama, June 27 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan businessman's wife in Honduras who was kidnapped at the end of May was released June 24 after her family paid a US$20,000 ransom, sources with the Republic of China embassy in Honduras said Wednesday.

After her release, the hostage, identified only as Mrs. Chan, was rushed to a hospital for checkup. She had suffered a slight cut on her ear, caused when the kidnappers sliced off a "small piece of skin and muscle" and mailed it to her husband.

Meanwhile, the Taiwanese community in Honduras said that Mrs. Chan, her husband and a secretary were abducted on their way to their textile factory on the eve of ROC President Chen Shui-bian's visit to Honduras late last month.
Her husband and the secretary were released shortly afterward to allow them to collect the ransom. The businessman had twice been kidnapped on the same route in the past.

The ROC embassy in Tegucigalpa is helping Chan's family by pressing Honduras police authorities to solve the case and it also asked the Taiwan reporters covering Chen's Latin American trip not to break the news before the hostage was released.
The abductors originally asked for a ransom of US$1 million, but after one month of negotiations, agreed to lower the sum to US$20,000.

The Honduras police were reported to be searching for the kidnappers, who apparently were from several neighboring countries, the sources said, while Mrs. Chan is returning to Taiwan with her children.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The extraordinary legislative session ends after lawmakers approve six financial reform bills.
The China Times:
The Legislative Yuan passes a new statute on the establishment of financial holding companies, but the bill will not take effect until Nov. 1.
The United Daily News:
Premier Chang said he is pleased to see the passage of six financial reform bills to facilitate market restructuring.
The Liberty Times:
The passage of financial holding firms bill is expected to accelerate Taiwan's financial service globalization.
The China Post:
New financial bills expected to solve economic woes.
The Taiwan News:
The Legislative Yuan passes financial reform bills.
The Taipei Times:
Legislators pass financial reform.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOXIC CHEMICAL SPILLS INTO SEA AFTER TWO SHIPS COLLIDE

TEXT.P: Hazardous chemicals were released into the ocean after a Republic of China naval ship collided with a Panamanian vessel offshore near Tainan City in southern Taiwan early Thursday morning, sources from the Navy Fleets Command reported.

The 8,840-ton navy ship, the "Chung Cheng," was on a routine training mission in the waters off Tainan City's Anping port when it collided with the 3,668-ton Panama-registered freighter the "Golden Chemical."

No one aboard either ship was injured but an estimated 96 cubic meters of poisonous P-Xylene leaked from the chemical ship, which still has some 3,000 tons of P-Xylene in its hold, officials from the fleets command said.
Neither of the two ships lost power. The "Chung Cheng" returned to the Kaohsiung Naval Base at 6 a.m. while the chemical ship was instructed to anchor offshore, pending an investigation.

Since P-Xylene is hazardous to both humans and sea life, officials from the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) have rushed to Kaohsiung to find out the extent of the damage and what help they may be able to render.

According to Cheng Hsien-jung, director of the EPA's Water Quality Protection Bureau, P-Xylene is a flammable and poisonous substance which is harmful to humans through contact with the skin or by inhaling the vapors of the chemical. Excessive exposure can cause liver and kidney damage, and adversely affect the central nerve system.

A light substance which does not dissolve in water, the P-Xylene is expected to float on the water. Cheng said the spill, although small, is expected to pollute the area about 12 nautical miles northwest of Kaohsiung Harbor.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI STOCK MARKET LOSES STEAM

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost steam Thursday after a moderate rebound the previous day.
The benchmark TAIEX weighted price index slid 56.73 points to close at 4,768.55 amid slow trading.
Market turnover totaled NT$33.4 billion (US$982.35 million) during the four-and-half-hour trading session.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-ROC SPY BARRED FROM LEAVING COUNTRY

TEXT.P: A former Taiwan spy who worked in mainland China and has accused former President Lee Teng-hui of sabotaging his work was barred Thursday from leaving Taiwan, according to the Public Prosecutors Office of the Taiwan High Court.

The prosecutors office issued an order Thursday restricting Chang Chih-peng from leaving the country because it is feared that he may give over state secrets and leak military information that could threaten national security.
When the 80-year-old Chang heard of the order he broke down, saying that he was committed to his "contacts" on the mainland and that he would go there even if he had to make the trip illegally.

Chang said Tuesday at a new conference that he booked a flight for Thursday afternoon to Beijing, where he had planned to turn himself in to the mainland military authorities in a trade for a reduced prison term for Yao Chia-chen, a business manager at Chang's Hong Kong office, who has been sentenced to life imprisonment by a mainland court which held that she had close relations with Chang.

Chang, who worked for the Military Intelligence Bureau (MIB) under the Ministry of National Defense for six years under his code name "001," said he has suffered greatly after former President Lee spoke publicly on secret intelligence information that ultimately led to the execution of two men.

Chang said he appealed to the MIB in April for NT$100 million (US$2.9 million) in compensation because Lee's "loose remarks" had led to the discovery of a spy ring that Chang had been running. The MIB has not acted on Chang's claim.

At a news conference in March 2000 in Taipei, Chang called on the government to help him because, according to Chang, two mainland Chinese military officers had been executed and a manager of his had been arrested as a result of Lee's remarks.
Chang filed a lawsuit in December against Lee alleging that his careless talk had allowed Beijing to break a major espionage ring.

He claimed that a comment by Lee during the 1996 Taiwan Strait missile crisis had resulted in some spies being arrested and his own factories in the mainland confiscated, forcing him to flee to Taiwan.
Chang's spy ring discovered in early 1996 that the ballistic missiles to be fired into the sea north of Taiwan in a military exercise would only be "dummies," -- missiles without warheads.
Chang said he quickly provided the MIB authorities with this crucial information.

However, according to Chang, Lee made public the secret in a speech when he was running for his second term for president. Lee called for the people of Taiwan to stay calm in the face of Beijing's attempt at intimidation since "the missiles carry only dummy warheads."
Lee's public disclosure of the confidential information immediately aroused Beijing's suspicion and led to a massive investigation that cracked the spy ring in 1999.
Two People's Liberation Army officers -- Major General Liu Liankun and Colonel Shao Zhengzhung, his key mainland contacts, were tracked down and executed in August 1999, according to Chang.

The MIB authorities have kept mum on the entire accusation, saying only that the MIB's position is that it will not comment on any operations involving intelligence work in consideration of national security and for the safety of its personnel.

On Thursday, hours before Chang's scheduled departure for Beijing, People First Party legislator Lee Ching-hua called for the government to demonstrate its crisis management skills to keep Chang from heading to the mainland, where he would most likely be arrested and would not be allowed the chance to speak.

Lee, meanwhile, called for the MIB to be fair to Chang since Chang has made a major contribution to the nation's security. The former MIB director, Yin Tsung-wen, once gave Chang a medal for his intelligence work.

DOC.HEADLINE: VISA DENIAL COUNTERPRODUCTIVE TO BEIJING'S UNIFICATION SCHEME: MAYOR

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh said Thursday mainland China's decision to reject his application for a Hong Kong visa is counterproductive to its own "one country, two systems" unification scheme.

Hsieh, who concurrently serves as chairman of the Republic of China's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), made the remarks after the Taiwan Affairs Office (TAO) under mainland China's State Council denied that Beijing has agreed to grant Hsieh a visa to visit Hong Kong.

Hsieh said the Kaohsiung City Government had applied for Hong Kong visas for him and several other senior municipal officials out of its belief that Beijing really meant to implement its "one country, two systems" formula in Hong Kong for 50 years.

Noting that Hong Kong and Beijing have rights to determine whether to approve their visa applications, Hsieh said the event also offered Taiwan an opportunity to evaluate mainland China's policy on relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Beijing used the "one country, two systems" formula after regaining sovereignty over Hong Kong from Britain in July 1997 and has since been advocating the use of this same scheme for cross-strait unification.

Hsieh pointed out that Beijing's rejection of his Hong Kong visa application was "negative teaching material" for its much-hyped unification scheme as it would remind the people of Taiwan that Beijing didn't honor its own promise to give Hong Kong full autonomy.

Hsieh was originally scheduled to head a delegation of Kaohsiung City Government officials to visit Hong Kong June 16-18 or June 29-July 1 to learn from Hong Kong's experience in mass rapid transit system management and harbor affairs modernization.
Hong Kong authorities have issued visas to all senior Kaohsiung officials, except Hsieh.

Some people have suggested that Hsieh visit Hong Kong via a 72-hour landing visa. However, Hsieh rejected the advice, insisting that he would visit Hong Kong only when Hong Kong authorities formally approves his entry application in his capacity as mayor of Kaohsiung, Taiwan's largest sea port and second largest city.

Mainland China's TAO spokesman, Zhang Mingqin, told a news conference in Beijing Thursday that Hsieh's visa application would be handled in line with regulations governing civilian exchanges between Taiwan and Hong Kong as well as the current state of cross-strait relations.
Zhang further said mainland China would consider relations with the DPP so long as the party accepts Beijing's "one China" principle and the so-called "1992 consensus."
The ROC government has said it cannot agree to Beijing's "one China" principle because it downgrades the ROC to a local-level government under the "People's Republic of China."
