DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, June 28, or the eighth day of the fifth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1776: British forces are defeated at the first Battle of Charleston during the American Revolution.
1836: James Madison, fourth president of the United States, is born. His influence at the Constitutional Convention in Philadelphia in 1787, which drew up the constitution, gained him the name "Father of the American Constitution."
1838: The coronation of Queen Victoria, 19, is held in Westminster Abbey. Her sense of duty and strict moral code greatly influenced 19th-century British society.
1902: The United States authorizes the construction of the Panama Canal.
1919: A peace treaty officially ending four years of devastating war is finally signed by a humiliated Germany and the allies at Versailles, France.
1919: The Republic of China refuses to sign the Versailles Treaty because German rights in Shantung are given to Japan.
1932: Chiang Kai-shek, who became chairman of the National Military Council on March 18, arrives in Hankow from Lushan to direct the campaign against Chinese communists.
1940: Japan declares a blockade against Hong Kong, cutting off land and sea traffic between Hong Kong and the Chinese mainland. Air transportation is excluded from the blockade.
1948: A strong earthquake rocks Fukui prefecture in Japan, killing more than 5,000 people.
1948: The Yugoslav Communist Party is expelled from COMINFORM at a meeting in Bucharest, marking the formal breach in relations between Yugoslavia and the rest of the communist bloc.
1950: Foreign Minister K.C. Yeh (Yeh Kung-chao) declares the Republic of China has in principle accepted the American government's proposal to cease military operations against mainland China and that the necessary orders have been given to the navy and air force.
1950: General Douglas McArthur, commander of the Allied forces in the South Pacific, flies to South Korea soon after North Korean troops capture Seoul.
1958: Brazil wins the World Cup in Stockholm thanks to the outstanding performance of the 17-year-old soccer player Pele, whose real name is Edson Arantes do Nascimento.
1970: US troops begin their pullout from Cambodia.
1976: Fifty-one American scholars, researchers, teachers and students arrive in Taipei for a five-week Seminar on China Studies.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives H.A.E. Scheels, permanent honorary vice president of the International Badminton Federation.
1977: Ma Chi-chuang, board chairman of the China Steel Corporation, puts a torch to the blast furnace of the company's new Kaohsiung steel plant to signify the start of steel making.
1979: The ROC government approves two new appointments proposed by the Kuomintang's Central Committee, naming H.K. Yang, political vice foreign minister, as ambassador to South Africa, and Ding Mou-shih, administrative vice foreign minister, as ambassador to South Korea.
1981: To promote cultural communication and economic relations, the Sino-Nigerian Cultural and Economic Association is established in Taipei.
1986: Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew of Singapore arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1987: The 70th Annual Lions Clubs International Convention is held in Taipei. The convention lasts seven days, with 40,000 members and their families joining the gathering.
1996: The ROC exchanges economic and trade representative offices with the Republic of Belarus. Belarus is the second (Russia being the first) member of the Commonwealth of Independent States to establish such relations with the ROC.
1999: The 1999 International Seminar on the Protection of Clean Coasts opens in Kaohsiung with more than 100 experts from home and abroad attending.
2000: Just as scientists from around the world have finished the first big step toward mapping the human genetic code, Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh announces that Taiwan will establish its own genetic research center within one year.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man, whether dealing with a few people or many, with great matters or with small, is never presumptuous and never regards anything as beneath his notice or as unworthy of serious and careful attention -- that is what is meant by being dignified without being supercilious."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI STOCK INDEX CLOSES LOWER

TEXT.P: Prices dropped on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Thursday following a moderate rebound the previous day as investors kept on the sideline due to gloomy economic forecast.
The benchmark TAIEX weighted price index lost 56.73 points to close at 4,768.55 on a market turnover of NT$33.4 billion (US$982.35 million).
A total of 1.12 billion shares changed hands during the four-and-half-hour trading session.

All of the eight major categories of stocks lost ground amid sluggish trading. Textile stocks registered the largest decline of 2.1 percent; electronics issues dropped 1.3 percent; cement, foodstuff and construction issues all fell 1.2 percent; plastics and chemical stocks dropped 1 percent; financial issues moved down 0.8 percent; and paper issues dip 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 317 to 175, with 98 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CHANG CALLS FOR CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE ON TOURISM PLAN
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung County, central Taiwan, June 28 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung called for a quick resumption of cross-strait dialogue Thursday to allow tourism exchanges between Taiwan and mainland China to begin as soon as possible.
Although Taiwan is ready for cross-strait tourism exchanges, Chang said, authorities from both sides need to "sit and talk over" technical issues surrounding the plan.

Issues involved in the tourism initiation, including scenarios where mainland Chinese tourists overstay their entry visas and "disappear" in Taiwan, should be tackled first in the cross-strait dialogue, he added. Chang also said the possibility of mainland China barring its citizens from traveling to Taiwan needs to be addressed.
The premier made the remarks during a ceremony marking the establishment of the Taichung Harbor Administration Committee, under which a passenger and tourist service center has also been inaugurated.
Both facilities are considered measures paving the way for the Taichung Harbor to become the "gateway" to Taiwan and a key destination for holiday-makers from mainland China.
Chang said Taichung Harbor, with its updated facilities and geographical convenience, has great potential to become one of the most important international harbors on Taiwan.

Chang announced last Oct. 20 that visitors from mainland China will be able to take leisure trips to Taiwan beginning June 2001 as part of the ROC government's efforts to address the cross-strait political impasse.
The plan, nevertheless, has not been implemented and it remains unknown when it will begin.

DOC.HEADLINE: EIGHT MAINLAND CHINESE AIRPLANE HIJACKERS REPATRIATED

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has repatriated eight mainland Chinese who were convicted of airplane hijacking in accordance with the bilateral Kinmen Agreement, the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Thursday.

Four of them -- Qi Daquan, Gao Jun, Han Shuxuye and She Yuehpo -- were repatriated early Thursday from the ROC's frontline island of Matsu via a mainland boat under the escort of staff members of the Red Cross Society in the southeastern mainland province of Fujian, MAC officials said.
Four other mainland hijackers -- Zhang Hai, Zhang Wenlung, Yuan Bin and Xu Mei -- were repatriated in the same way Wednesday, according to MAC sources.
The MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, kept a low-profile toward the repatriation of the mainland hijackers to avoid any possible unexpected developments.
Noting that aircraft hijacking is a universal crime, the MAC said all the eight mainland hijackers have served jail terms and have been released on parole in accordance with ROC law.

Based on the principles of humanitarianism, safety, convenience and a consensus reached between the Red Cross Society on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, the MAC said it authorized the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) to handle the mainland hijacker repatriation issue earlier this month.
The eight mainland hijackers were sent to Matsu under the escort of police officers as well as SEF and Red Cross Society staff members earlier this week for repatriation.

A total of 18 mainland people were involved in hijacking 13 mainland commercial aircraft to Taiwan between 1993 and 1998. Two mainland hijackers -- Huang Shugang and Han Fengying -- were repatriated in October 1998 after they were released on parole.

In February 2000, the MAC again authorized the SEF to repatriate four other mainland hijackers. One of them, Yang Mingde injured SEF Deputy Secretary-General Jan Jyh-horng on the flight from Taipei to Matsu for repatriation.

The incident caused a suspension of repatriating mainland hijackers for more than a year. After extensive discussions with relevant authorities, the MAC decided to resume repatriation. Because mainland China declines to recognize Taiwan's judicial authority, mainland hijackers must stand trial again after their return to the Chiense mainland. As a result, some mainland hijackers reportedly were unwilling to go home.
"Police officers and SEF staff have exercised great prudence in handling repatriation of the two batches of mainland hijackers in the past two days," said an MAC official.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures markets closed lower Thursday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for July lost 51 points to close at 4,839, with 6,273 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for August lost 21 points to finish at 4,844, with 32 contracts traded. September futures lost 44 points to close at 4,815, with four contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 4,890 for July, 4,865 for August, 4,859 for September, 4,941 for December and 4,961 for next March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, both closed lower.

July TE futures moved down 2.95 points to close at 242.45, with 1,017 contract transactions, while August TE futures lost 2.9 points to finish at 242, with four contracts traded. TE futures for next March lost 3.4 points to close at 238, with 13 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
July TF futures moved down seven points to finish at 659, with 369 contracts changing hands, while December TF futures lost one point to close at 650.2, with 20 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar dropped NT$0.009 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Thursday, closing at NT$34.465.
The local currency opened Thursday at NT$34.442 and was traded between NT$34.410 and NT$34.495.
Interbank U.S. dollar transactions totaled US$411.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OFFICIAL CONFERS WITH LDP LEADERS IN TOKYO
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 28 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Executive Yuan Secretary-General Chiou I-jen paid visits to leaders of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) in Tokyo Thursday to exchange views on matters of mutual concern.

During his talks with LDP Secretary-General Taku Yamazaki, Chiou expressed his appreciation to the Japanese government for permitting former President Lee Teng-hui to visit Japan to receive medical treatment in late April.
Chiou also met with LDP Party Policy Research Council Chairman Taro Aso.

He told the LDP leaders that Taiwan expects Japan's relations with the United States will be strengthened and that Taiwan's exchanges with Japan and the United States, as well as their exchanges with Beijing, will be instrumental in the promotion of cross-strait exchanges.

Chiou, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's former representative to Washington, will attend a symposium on "The way to stability and prosperity in east Asia" under the auspices of the Asian Research Council Thursday afternoon.

Major topics to be discussed at the symposium are the current state and the outlook of cross-strait relations and the issues related to the security of the Taiwan Strait and the development of Japan's and the United States' relations with mainland China.

Chiou arrived in Tokyo June 23 to hold talks with Japanese political and business leaders to exchange views on the security of the East Asian region and Japan's experiences in disposing of the banking institutions' bad loans.
He was invited to deliver a speech at the Foreign Correspondents' Club of Japan Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONDURAS ARRESTS 7 SUSPECTS FOR KIDNAPPING OF TAIWAN WOMAN
DOC.DATELINE: Panama, June 27 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Honduras police authorities have arrested seven suspects involved in the kidnapping of a Taiwanese businessman's wife in late May, the Republic of China Embassy in Honduras said Thursday.
Quoting the Honduras national police administration, the embassy said the suspected kidnappers came from a cross-border criminal ring.
Two of the suspects hailed from other Central American countries, the embassy said, adding that one was from Guatemala and the other from El Salvador.
Honduras police authorities are contacting relevant countries to obtain further information about the suspects, the embassy said.

According to the embassy, the Taiwan businessman, identified only by his family name Chan had kept close contacts with Honduras police and public security authorities since his wife was kidnapped on the eve of ROC President Chen Shui-bian's visit to the Central american country at the end of May.
Chan asked Honduras law enforcement authorities to do their utmost to handle the case under the top principle of ensuring his wife's personal safety.
The kidnappers originally asked for a ransom of US$1 million, but after one month of negotiations agreed to cut the sum to US$20,000.

Mrs. Chan was released June 24 after her husband paid the ransom. The Taiwanese Chamber of Commerce in Honduras had helped Chan raised money for the release of his wife. Mrs. Chan endured torture during her captivity. Her abductors sliced off a "small piece of skin and muscle" of her right ear and mailed it to her husband. The kidnappers also used cigarettes to burn her. Mrs Chan is returning to Taiwan with her children.

The ROC embassy said Honduras law enforcement authorities had mobilized large police forces and used highly advanced communications equipment to search for kidnapping suspects after the hostage was relased.

Embassy sources said Chan, his wife and a secretary were abducted on their way to their textile factory in suburban Tegucigalpa, the Honduras capital, at the end of May. Chan and the secretary were released shortly afterward to allow them to collect the ransom.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. AMBASSADOR-DESIGNATE: BUSH ADMINISTRATION SUPPORTS `ONE CHINA'

TEXT.P: The United States continues to insist on a peaceful resolution to the Taiwan Strait situation while adhering to the "one China" principle, the U.S. ambassador-designate to Beijing said Wednesday.
"As the president has plainly articulated," said Clark T. Randt, Jr., "we insist on a peaceful resolution of the Taiwan issue and do not support a declaration of independence by Taiwan."

"Our consistent position, based on the Taiwan Relations Act and the three communiques (signed with Beijing), is that there is but one China," he said while delivering a testimony before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
"It must be clear that we will honor our commitments under the Taiwan Relations Act," Randt added. He was speaking as one of three ambassdorial nominees testifying at their confirmation hearing.

Randt pledged that if confirmed, he would "always stand squarely for American interests and American values" when dealing with mainland China, adding that he would approach mutual differences "with a spirit of respect."

Calling the crackdown on religious freedom in mainland China "a disturbing reality," he said that one of his highest priorities as ambassador to Beijing would be to convey Bush's concern to the mainland leaders.

Randt also promised to work for the release of Chinese American scholars and Chinese scholars that are permanent U.S. residents detained under suspicious charges by the mainland authorities, a pledge he repeated when he met briefly after the hearing with the wife and daughter of Li Shao-ming, one of the detainees.
Randt, 56, has been a trade lawyer with an international law firm in Hong Kong. He was formerly first secretary and commercial attache at the U.S. embassy in Beijing.
The nominee is best known, however, for his personal ties to Bush. The two were classmates at Yale University.

DOC.HEADLINE: CORNELL UNIVERSITY TO NAME RESEARCH CENTER AFTER FORMER ROC PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Ithaca, New York, June 27 (CNA) (By Eric C.Y. Tseng and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Cornell University President Hunter R. Rawlings III formally announced Wednesday that a new research center to be completed in 2004 will be named after former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui, a Cornell alumnus.
The Lee Teng-hui Institute for Scientific Research will be dedicated to nanotechnology research.
Rawlings made the announcement at a private welcoming banquet, where Lee had the opportunity to do a walk-through of the research center on a computerized virtual reality model.
Lee, who arrived at his alma mater Tuesday, also toured the campus, which he last visited in June 1995 while he was still ROC president.
He earned a Ph.D. in agricultural economics at Cornell in 1968.

Lee briefly met with American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Richard Bush. AIT represents American interests in Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic ties. Bush, however, would not comment on the details of their 50-minute meeting.

A group of mainland Chinese students at Cornell and nearby universities organized a protest on campus to denounce what they said was Lee's pro-Taiwan independence stance, while a New York-based group of pro-unification supporters also joined in the protest.
A Lee supporter observing the demonstration questioned whether the students from mainland China -- who have been raised under communist rule -- truly understand democracy and freedom.
Lee was slated to fly back to Los Angeles Thursday after a nine-hole round of golf. His U.S. visit is scheduled to wrap up July 1.
Lee had originally planned to visit his alma mater in early May, but he postponed his trip because he went to Japan to have minor heart surgery in late April.

DOC.HEADLINE: 39% OF GOVERNMENT-FINANCED STUDENTS FAIL TO RETURN FOR SERVICE

TEXT.P: People First Party (PFP) Legislator Lee Ching-an said Thursday that 399 government-financed students failed to return to Taiwan after completing their studies abroad in the past 10 years.

She said at a news conference at the Legislative Yuan that the government should strictly follow the regulations by demanding that these students -- representing 38.8 percent of the students studying abroad on state scholarships -- repay the money they received from the government.

According to Education Ministry regulations, all government-financed students are required to return to Taiwan for service, otherwise, their guarantors are required to repay the money, estimated at US$30,000-US$40,000 annually.

Lee complained that the Education Ministry has failed to faithfully follow the regulations by failing to demand repayment and an Education Ministry official admitted that so far, only nine such students have repaid the money.

The government is considering whether to reform the system of sending students for study abroad at government expenses, but the official denied speculation that foreign scholarship examinations will not be repealed in 2003, saying that evaluation of the system is still under way.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG MAYOR CANCELS HK TRAVEL PLAN

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh said Thursday he has decided to cancel a visit to Hong Kong planned for Friday because as of Thursday noon, he had not yet received a Hong Kong visa.

Hsieh, who concurrently serves as chairman of the Republic of China's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), also expressed his doubts as to whether Beijing "really meant to implement" the so-called "one country, two systems" scheme in Hong Kong.

"If the `one country, two systems' were for real, it would be the Hong Kong government, not the Taiwan Affairs Office (TAO) under mainland China's State Council, that would decide whether to grant me a visa," Hsieh said.
The lawyer-turned-politician made the remarks after TAO spokesman Zhang Mingqin denied at a news conference in Beijing Thursday that Hsieh had been granted a visa to visit Hong Kong.
"Since Beijing has repeatedly promised to allow Hong Kong to keep its own political system and lifestyle for 50 years, why has the TAO meddled in my Hong Kong visa application case?" Hsieh asked.
"I simply cannot understand why the TAO has skirted the Hong Kong government and announced on its own its denial of my visa application," Hsieh added.
In his view, Hsieh said, Beijing's denial of his Hong Kong visa application is counterproductive to its own "one country, two systems" unification scheme.

Beijing used the "one country, two systems" formula after regaining sovereignty over Hong Kong from Britain in July 1997 and has since been advocating the use of the same scheme for cross-Taiwan Strait unification.

Hsieh pointed out that Beijing's rejection of his Hong Kong visa application was "negative teaching material" for its much-hyped unification scheme as it would remind the people of Taiwan that Beijing has not honored its own promise to give Hong Kong full autonomy.

Hsieh was originally scheduled to head a delegation of Kaohsiung city government officials on a visit to Hong Kong June 16-18 or June 29-July 1 to learn from Hong Kong's experience in mass rapid transit system management and harbor affairs modernization.
The Hong Kong authorities issued visas to all the senior Kaohsiung officials in the delegation except Hsieh.

Some people had suggested that Hsieh visit Hong Kong on a 72-hour landing visa, but Hsieh rejected the advice, insisting that he would visit Hong Kong only when Hong Kong authorities formally approve his entry application in his capacity as mayor of Kaohsiung, Taiwan's largest sea port and second-largest city.
Hsieh said the city government had followed three principles in handling the Hong Kong travel plan:
-- The delegation would respect Hong Kong's stance and keep its itinerary transparent; and
-- The delegation would not accept any political conditions since the visit was purely for learning about Hong Kong's experience in city administration and construction.
Zhang said Thursday that the TAO would handle Hsieh's visa application based on the current state of cross-strait relations and regulations government Taiwan-Hong Kong civilian exchanges.
Zhang further said Beijing would consider relations with the DPP only after the party accepts Beijing's "one China" principle and the so-called "1992 consensus."
The ROC government has said it cannot agree to Beijing's "one China" principle because it downgrades the ROC to a local-level government under the "People's Republic of China."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REAFFIRMS `NO COMPROMISE' ON ROC SOVEREIGNTY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed his commitment Thursday to safeguarding the Republic of China's national sovereignty, dignity and social stability.

"As the ROC president, I'm obligated to defend national sovereignty, dignity and social stability in accordance with our constitution. I will never offer any discount, compromise or concession in fulfilling this mission," said Chen.
The president made the reaffirmation while meeting with a group of overseas Chinese community leaders from the northern California area.

Chen's statement came on the heels of a remark by the spokesman for the Taiwan Affairs Office (TAO) under mainland China's State Council, Zhang Mingqin, who told a press conference in Beijing that Beijing would forge contact with Chen's administration only after Chen accepts Beijing's "one China" principle and the so-called "1992 consensus."
The ROC government has rejected the "one China" principle because it downgrades the ROC to a local-level government under the People's Republic of China.

During his meeting with the overseas Chinese community leaders, Chen also lauded the large number of overseas Chinese for their contributions to the ROC's progress and development over the past decades.
"Your staunch support has been one of the major driving forces behind our country's development. We need your continued support," Chen stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE ECONOMICS MINISTER VISITS BOSTON TO LURE INVESTMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Boston, June 27 (CNA) (By Bill Wang and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu attended a symposium on Taiwan's investment climate Wednesday in Boston in an attempt to lure more United States' investment into Taiwan's high-tech sector.
Lin, traveling at the head of a 13-member delegation, arrived in Boston June 26 from New York.

During its stay in Boston, the delegation will call on Taiwanese high-tech entrepreneurs operating in the United States and will visit American high-tech firms, including Biopure, Polaroid, Tyco, Stone and Webster.

Taiwan and Boston, state capital of Massachusetts, have maintained close economic and trade relations in recent years, with the state's exports to Taiwan reaching a value of US$1.15 billion last year, an increase of 61.9 percent over 1999.
Taiwan is currently Massachusetts' sixth-largest export market, after Canada, Japan, United Kingdom, Germany and the Netherlands.

About 250 companies with Taiwanese investment are operating in the Boston area, mainly in computers, information services, software design, finance, construction, restaurants, real estate and cargo transport service.

The number of U.S. companies based in Boston which have invested in Taiwan totals 50, focusing on electronics, information and telecommunication technology, national defense industry, construction advisory services, biotechnology, aerospace, environmental protection and financing. Among these companies, Raytheon Corp. and Digital Equipment Corp. have signed strategic alliance agreements with the ROC Ministry of Economic Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO REFRAIN FROM COMMENTING ON TAIWAN POLITICS

TEXT.P: Mainland China should refrain from commenting on Taiwan's domestic political developments or general situation, a senior negotiator with mainland China said Thursday.

Shi Hwei-yow, vice chairman of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and secretary-general, was responding to comments made by Zhang Mingqin, spokesman for the Taiwan Affairs Office (TAO) under mainland China's State Council, at a news conference in Beijing Thursday.
Shi said the Republic of China has consistently refrained from making concrete comments on mainland China's domestic political affairs based on the principle of mutual respect.
In contrast to mainland China's frequent verbal attacks on incumbent and former ROC presidents, Shi said Taiwan has seldom criticized mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin.
Commenting on Zhang's criticism of former ROC President Lee Teng-hui, Shi said Zhang's move would be counterproductive to the development of relations across the Taiwan Strait.
In his view, Shi said, the people of Taiwan would have their own views on and evaluation of Lee's performance and achievements.
Shi further said mainland China's insistence that Taiwan accept its "one China" principle as a precondition for resumption of cross-strait dialogue is unreasonable and unfair.
"Even the United States has said that no prerequisite is needed for cross-strait dialogue," Shi noted.

Shi said mainland China's reluctance to resume talks with Taiwan has hindered expansion of the direct "mini three links" between the ROC's frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu and mainland China's Xiamen and Mawei.
Worse yet, Shi said, mainland China refusal to cross-strait consultations has also hampered Taiwan's plan to open its door to prospective mainland Chinese tourists.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCIAL GROUPS READY TO TRANSFORM INTO FINANCIAL HOLDING COMPANY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's leading financial groups with multiple operations are ready to transform into financial holding companies and the monetary market is expecting a series of mergers and acquisitions in the coming months.
The Legislative Yuan approved the Financial Holding Company Law late Wednesday at an extraordinary session.

The new law opens the door for financial groups to transform into financial holding companies with their operations covering banking, stocks and securities, futures, credit cards, trust, insurance, and venture capital.

The Fubon Commercial Bank under the Fubon Group, the Grand Commercial Bank under the President Group, the E. Sun Commercial Bank under the Cathay Group and the Far Eastern International Bank under the Far Eastern Group had begun the deployment work long before the bill was approved.

Commercial banks, such as the First Commercial Bank and Bank SinoPac, and stock and securities firms like Polaris, Core Pacific and Jih Sun are seeking opportunities for mergers or acquisitions to facilitate the transformation.
To qualify for the transformation, a financial institution must keep its capital adequacy ratio below 8 percent, according to Vice Finance Minister Chen Chun.

As financial institutions are facing the challenges of making choices or becoming choices of their rivals, the monetary market will undoubtedly experience a period of turbulence. It is hoped that the transformation will help local financial institutions to streamline their operations in the long run and improve their international competitiveness.
Since the new law allows foreign financial companies to wholly own Taiwan banks, foreign investors may have higher interest in Taiwan's monetary market.

The new law will not go into force until Nov. 1, while a majority of lawmakers insist that a draft bill regarding controlling interest in a financial holding company should be screened and approved before the end of October.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSMC CLARIFIES RUMORS ABOUT PLANT CLOSURES

TEXT.P: A spokesman for Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corporation (TSMC) said Thursday that the company has no plans to shut down any of its plants, despite the current economic slump sweeping semiconductor contractors.

TSMC is not planning salary cuts or layoffs and salary raises were implemented as scheduled in April, the spokesman said, dismissing market speculation that TSMC may resort to plant closures or layoffs to ride out the present difficulties.
"In the face of the economic slowdown, the only thing that the company has done is to adjust its capital spending from US$3.8 billion to US$2.2 billion," the spokesman noted.

The declaration had already been set forth in an e-mail message sent by TSMC Chairman Morris Chang a day earlier to the company's 14,000 workers, which claimed that the company will be challenged with its severest task to date as a result of declining business.

Chang said that the company's production utility rate has fallen to less than 40 percent at present, which is in stark contrast to 120 percent and 45 percent increases in 2000 and 1999 business turnover, respectively.

Calling on workers to cherish the company's intention to take care of them even in hard times, the TSMC chief called on company employees to do their best to help boost company operations by seeking technology upgrades and strengthening services to customers as a means of preparing for the coming next boom.

Meanwhile, United Micro Electronics Corporation (UMC) said on the same day that all the firm's silicon wafer plants are operating normally despite the fact that the production utility rate of its plants dipped to 45 percent in the second quarter.
A UMC spokesman said he had not heard of any company plans to shut down plants or lay off workers and would not comment on rumors in this regard.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S CENTRAL BANK CUTS KEY INTEREST RATES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Central Bank of China (CBC) announced Thursday that effective the following day, three key interest rates would be cut by 0.25 percentage points to stimulate investment and consumer spending.

Closely following a U.S. Federal Reserve decision to lower interest rates, the CBC lowered its rediscount rate, secured loans rate and short-term uncollateralized accommodation rate to 3.5 percent, 3.875 percent and 5.75 percent, respectively.
It is the CBC's seventh such interest rate cut since the end of last year, resulting in a combined slashing of 1.25 percentage points for its rediscount rate and secured loans rate.
The CBC last lowered its interest rates in mid-May.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR U.S. FIRMS TO INVEST IN TAIWAN: MOEA

TEXT.P: Four U.S. high-tech firms have confirmed that they will invest a total of US$155 million (NT$5.3 billion) in Taiwan, an official from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Thursday.

The official said that as a result of efforts made by a MOEA-organized high-tech delegation to the United States, Kinetics Biopharm plans to invest US$70 million to produce biotech products in Taiwan, Caleb plans to invest US$50 million to produce lithium batteries, Sat Com will invest US$5 million to produce satellite antennae and Rogers will invest US$30 million to produce wireless antennae.

According to information provided by the MOEA delegation led by Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu, the official said, members of the delegation were negotiating with nine other U.S. firms over a combined investment of US$167 million.
These nine potential investors are Trimax, Polymerex, Space Link, Pulse Matrix, L&H Bio, Accutech, E-commerce Solution, Symbol Technologies and Biopure.

The delegation left Taiwan for the United States June 21. They have already visited Los Angeles, San Diego, New York and Boston. The trip will also take them to Silicon Valley, where they are expected to meet officials of Novellus, Fortrend and Dielectric Systems to sound out further investment possibilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT THINK TANK UNVEILS NEW POLICY GUIDELINES

TEXT.P: New policy guidelines featuring a "confederation" with Beijing and a "double economic triangle" covering Taipei were unveiled Thursday by an opposition Kuomintang (KMT) think tank.

The guidelines worked out by the National Policy Foundation are an attempt to flesh out the idea of a "confederation" proposed by party head Lien Chan as a formula for ultimate reunification with mainland China.
It calls for the pursuit of a friendly win-win situation with Beijing in compliance with the existing Guidelines for National Unification.

In practice, the guidelines preach stable ties with Beijing on the basis of the so-called "1992 consensus" said by the KMT to have been reached between Taipei and Beijing that there is only "one China," with Taiwan and the mainland free to interpret the meaning of the phrase as they see fit.
It also advocates the establishment of a "Taiwan Strait peace zone" through a military trust-building mechanism with Beijing, which would lead to the eventual confederation between the two sides.

The current limitations on direct trade and shipping with the mainland should be relaxed to set the stage for two economic "golden triangles," one of which would have Silicon Valley, Taipei and Shanghai as its apexes, while the other would have Tokyo, Taipei and Shanghai as its apexes, according to the document.
The policy guidelines are seen as an attempt by Lien to put his own stamp on party policy and an assertion of his leadership within the party.

Lien reportedly tried to made his "confederation" scheme a vital part of his platform in his disastrous 2000 presidential campaign, but withdrew it "grudgingly" because of disapproval from then-KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui, who claimed in 1999 that Taipei-Beijing ties are a "special state-to-state" relationship.
The guidelines were referred to the party's policy making committee for review before being presented to the party congress for approval.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW EVERGREEN CONTAINER TERMINAL IN ITALY TO BE OPENED
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, June 27 (CNA) (By Tony Fang & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: A new container terminal built by Taiwan's Evergreen Group at Taranto in southeastern Italy will begin operations Friday, an Evergreen spokesman said Thursday.

Due to its geographic position, described by the spokesman as "excellent," the Taranto terminal will gradually replace Gioia Tauro terminal to become Evergreen Marine Corp.'s maritime freight transition center in the Mediterranean, the spokesman said.

The terminal has a one-kilometer long pier, which can berth three large container ships at the same time. This will be lengthened to 2.5 km long in a second stage of construction and will be capable of berthing seven container ships.
The terminal will be able to handle two million TEU's (twenty foot equivalent unit) containers per year.
Evergreen will also make its facilities available to other marine transport companies, the spokesman added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW CABINET COULD INVOLVE ANY POLITICAL PARTY: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian told a group of ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers Thursday that he cannot yield his constitutional right to name a premier and that he has never said that only the DPP will be involved in a new Cabinet.

Commenting on possible political developments after the year-end legislative elections, DPP Legislator Shen Fu-hsiung said after a three-hour meeting with Chen and 12 other DPP legislators that he can fully accept the president's reasoning.

Shen, who is known to be concerned with issues regarding the possible formation of a coalition Cabinet, also quoted Chen as saying that not being able to hand over the right to name a premier does not mean he cannot yield some administrative powers or administrative resources.
Chen was also quoted as saying that it is still too early to talk about the issue and that the possible partners for cooperation in forming a new Cabinet could be any of Taiwan's political parties.
"Every political party in Taiwan is a friend; there are no enemies," Shen quoted Chen as saying.
The president also described the future of local politics as "brothers climbing a mountain together, with each exerting his own efforts."

DOC.HEADLINE: SENEGAL PRESIDENT TO VISIT ROC

TEXT.P: Senegal President Abdoulaye Wade is slated to arrive in Taipei Saturday for a five-day state visit, traveling at the head of a high-profile delegation, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced Thursday.
Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian will preside over a military salute and host a state banquet in Wade's honor in central Taiwan's Taichung City, according to a MOFA statement.

While in Taiwan, Wade and Chen will discuss issues of mutual concern and bilateral cooperation, as well as signing a joint communique and conferring medals upon each other, the statement said. The Senegal head of state will also visit local cultural and agricultural establishments.

The ROC and Senegal have maintained very close ties in trade, infrastructure, agricultural training and industrial development since resuming full diplomatic relations in January 1996, MOFA said. Rice and asparagus planted by ROC agricultural missions based in the African country are particularly popular among Senegal farmers.

Meanwhile, Adama Sarr, the newly appointed Senegal ambassador to the ROC, will present his credentials to the president Friday and will start preparations for Wade's visit immediately following the ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOJ EXPRESSES `DOUBT' OVER LOW CLEANLINESS RANKING

TEXT.P: Officials of the Republic of China Ministry of Justice (MOJ) cast doubt Thursday on the nation's low government cleanliness ranking released by the anti-corruption organization Transparency International (TI).

The officials maintained that during the last year, the MOJ's efforts to curb corruption and sweep away "black gold," or the ilegal connections among political figures, gangsters and businessmen, are well known to local people and claimed they could not imagine why Taiwan obtained a such low ranking in TI's Corruption Perceptions Index (CPI).
However, earlier news reports had been very clear in reporting that the TI survey data was compiled over the previous three years, long before the MOJ crackdown.

TI, the world's leading non-governmental organization that monitors both international and national corruption, evaluates the CPI according to interviews with business people, academics and country analysts.
In its latest annual survey of 91 countries around the world, Taiwan got a score of 5.9 out of a "maximum cleanliness" score of 10, and was ranked 27th on the CPI 2001 list.
Finland led the list with an index of 9.9, followed by Denmark with 9.5, New Zealand with 9.4 and Iceland and Singapore tied at 9.2.
Hong Kong led its Asian neighbors with an index of 7.9 in 14th place, followed by Japan with 7.1 in 21st place, and Taiwan.
Mainland China scored 3.5, tying with Argentina in 57th place.

The results of the survey show that some of the richest countries in the world - Finland, Denmark, New Zealand, Iceland, Singapore and Sweden - scored nine or higher out of a clean score of 10 in the new CPI, indicating very low levels of perceived corruption. But 55 countries - many of which are among the world's poorest - scored less than five, suggesting high levels of perceived corruption in government and public administration.
The countries with a score of two or less are Azerbaijan, Bolivia, Cameroon, Kenya, Indonesia, Uganda, Nigeria and Bangladesh.

Anti-corruption efforts have been among the most applauded achievements of the Chen Shui-bian administration during the last year. MOJ officials indicated that the ministry is aiming to establish an anti-corruption administration in an attempt to create a "clean" political environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNCERTAINTY OVER ECONOMIC RECOVERY IN SECOND HALF: CBC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: There is no sign that Taiwan's sagging economy will turn around in the second half of this year, despite the government's "soft" monetary policy and measures to stimulate growth, a Central Bank of China (CBC) official said Thursday.

In a report presented at a meeting of CBC councilors and monitors, Shih Yen, director-general of the CBC's Economic Research Department, said all statistics in the first five months of this year suggest gloomy prospects for the near future.

The abrupt plunge in the world economy, especially the sharp slide in demand for electrical and information products, has taken a heavy toll on Taiwan's international trade, which has seen a 9.5 plummet in exports, a 15.2 percent plunge in imports and a petty trade surplus of US$4.89 billion in the January-May period, said Shih.
A similar downward trend has been seen in industrial output, with the Industrial Production Index posting a growth rate of minus 5.29 percent in the first five months of this year, she went on.

The downsizing or relocation of local firms overseas has driven up the unemployment rate to 3.83 percent in the period, or 1.03 percentage points up over the corresponding period of the previous year, Shih continued.
Inflation was tame, thanks to a slump of international commodity prices and a slide in the price of local agricultural and livestock products, she pointed out.
The consumption price registered a modest annual growth of 0.4 percent and the core consumption price a growth of 0.64 percent, she added.
CBC Governor Perng Fai-nan said after the meeting that there is still a long way to go before the economy can reverse its fall in the second half of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TAX, INVESTMENT PROTECTION ACCORD URGED

TEXT.P: A local leading entrepreneur called Thursday on the authorities on both sides of the Taiwan Strait to sign accords on tax and investment protection as soon as possible.
Hsu Sheng-hsiung, chairman of the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers Association (TEEMA) said the issue causes deep concern among Taiwanese businessmen working in mainland China.
Hsu made the remarks at a press conference before publishing the results of the 2001 mainland China investment climate and risk survey.
The survey results indicate that the Yangtze River delta offered the best investment climate in mainland China, while Bo Hai bay retained the lowest investment risk.

TEEMA recommended the best three mainland cities for Taiwanese investors as Suzhou, Kunshan and Wujiang and the three worst areas as the mainland's southeastern coast, Shenzhen and Dongguan -- the three areas with the highest concentration of Taiwanese investors.
The cities with the highest investment risk were named in the survey as Shantou, Haikou and Dongguan.
Hsu said that TEEMA will submit the survey results to the relevant government agencies and will also provide copies to those planning to invest in the mainland.

Noting that signing tax and investment protection accords is a must for Taiwanese investors in the mainland, Hsu called on the Beijing authorities to set up a "Taiwan Businessmen Special Court" to deal with business disputes.

Prof. Lin Tzu-chia of National Cheng Chi University, a chief planner for the survey, said that about 29 percent of Taiwanese businessmen have suffered trade disputes in the mainland. Of them, 36 percent sought resolution through legal means and 34 percent were resolved through private channels.

The survey results also show that about 59 percent of the respondents were dissatisfied with the results of the resolutions, no matter whether through legal or private channels. About 32 percent of the respondents agreed that a special court should be set up to deal with trade disputes.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TO BLAME FOR CROSS-STRAIT IMPASSE: ROC PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian was quoted as saying Thursday that problems between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are the fault of the mainland Chinese side for its lack of sincerity in wishing to resolve bilateral disputes.
Lawmakers Chien Hsi-chieh and Tang Pi-o of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party quoted the president's remarks to reporters following a meeting with him.

Chien and Tang, quoting Chen, said the Republic of China government stands firm on its "active opening and efficient management" stance when touching on the "no haste, be patient" policy regulating mainland-bound investment by local businessmen.

Taiwan has displayed a great deal of goodwill in establishing direct trade, transport and postal links -- the "mini three links" -- between ROC-held frontline Kinmen and Matsu islands and two ports in the mainland's Fujian Province. It has also reiterated its willingness to reopen dialogue with the mainland with no conditions attached, Chen was quoted as saying.

The president further pointed out that mainland China, however, has given no response to Taiwan's moves and that the mainland should be held responsible for the current impasse between the two sides, according to the lawmakers.

Chien and Tang also mentioned that Chen believes that the United States is fully aware of Taiwan's "open and active" stance and that it has been adopted without pressure from Washington, but laments that Beijing has not budged on its own ideas and concepts and continues to politicize things every step of the way.

Tang also quoted Chen as saying that certain media outlets have "overly embellished" mainland China. In the eyes of the ROC president, the mainland is faced with many problems in the areas of social security, the wealth gap and the financial situation, Tang noted.

She added that the president also encouraged the people of Taiwan to have faith in the government and never to fall into the trap of thinking that mainland China presents the only survival route for Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW POLITICAL GROUP TO COOPERATE WITH GOVERNMENT: FORMER OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Former Minister of the Interior Huang Chu-wen said in an interview with a local magazine that a new political group he plans to form next month will cooperate with the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government to stabilize the political situation.
"The new group will play the role of the `middle way' power to support the new government in stabilizing the political situation, based on the consideration of the country's interests," he noted.

Huang, a former member of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), said that former President Lee Teng-hui "completely supports the new political group" and added that Lee has promised to help campaign for members of the group during December's legislative elections.
"I believe the new group will be able to garner 10 percent of the votes in the upcoming legislative elections," Huang remarked.

He predicted that the emergence of the new political group will thwart the expansion of the People First Party headed by former Taiwan Governor James Soong and will also affect the performance of the KMT in the elections.

Huang said that he declined to return to the KMT because the party "has gradually departed from the `Taiwanization' route and has inclined more toward the mainland" since the presidential election of March 2000, during which the KMT lost its 55-year grip on power to the DPP.

He said the failure of the opposition parties to play an appropriate opposition role in the past year prompted him to decide to form the new political group aimed at helping the government stabilize the political situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITORS' NOTE:
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 27 (CNA) (By David Wang and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu attended a symposium on Taiwan's investment climate Wednesday in Boston in an attempt to lure more United States' investment into Taiwan's high-tech sector.
Lin, traveling at the head of a 13-member delegation, arrived in Boston June 26 from New York.

During its stay in Boston, the delegation will call on Taiwanese high-tech entrepreneurs operating in the United States and will visit American high-tech firms, including Biopure, Polaroid, Tyco, Stone and Webster.

Taiwan and Boston, state capital of Massachusetts, have maintained close economic and trade relations in recent years, with the state's exports to Taiwan reaching a value of US$1.15 billion last year, an increase of 61.9 percent over 1999.
Taiwan is currently Massachusetts' sixth-largest export market, after Canada, Japan, United Kingdom, Germany and the Netherlands.

About 250 companies with Taiwanese investment are operating in the Boston area, mainly in computers, information services, software design, finance, construction, restaurants, real estate and cargo transport service.

The number of U.S. companies based in Boston which have invested in Taiwan totals 50, focusing on electronics, information and telecommunication technology, national defense industry, construction advisory services, biotechnology, aerospace, environmental protection and financing. Among these companies, Raytheon Corp. and Digital Equipment Corp. have signed strategic alliance agreements with the ROC Ministry of Economic Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT HOPES TO SET UP `INTERNATIONAL PEACE PRIZE'

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that he hopes to set up an "International Peace Prize" for people who have made outstanding contributions to peace.
He made the remarks while conferring with a dozen Democratic Progressive Party legislators at the Presidential Office.
According to Legislator Chien Hsi-chieh, Chen stressed that "peace is a universal value" and mentioned his idea of establishing a "National Peace Foundation" to present the peace prize.
Chien said that the president hopes legislators will support the idea and approve a plan for the government to appropriate a whopping NT$2 billion (US$58 million) to finance the project.
Chen reportedly noted that human rights diplomacy may sometimes encounter resistance, while peace is "always acceptable to all quarters."

During the reception, some legislators proposed that Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Koo Chen-fu should represent Chen at the informal leadership conference of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum to be held in Shanghai in October, if Beijing refuses to allow Chen to attend.
Chen said that he strongly hopes that he will be able to attend the APEC meeting himself, but said it is still "too early" to talk about who can and who cannot attend the meeting.
Beijing, however, has had no such reservations and has already declared strongly that Chen will definitely not be allowed to attend the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT'S MIDDLE WAY APPROACH `IMPROVES CROSS-STRAIT TIES'

TEXT.P: Republic of China Government Information Office Director-General Su Tzen-ping claimed Thursday that President Chen Shui-Bian's "middle way approach" has improved cross-Taiwan Strait ties since the inauguration of the new administration.

In a speech delivered at the Center for European Policy Studies in Brussels, Su pointed out that the peaceful transition of political power last year in Taiwan was highly significant to political scientists and observers and that no matter how people wish to describe Taiwan's political development, one thing is clear: Taiwan is a genuine, full-fledged "liberal democracy."

Despite the tense situation between Taiwan and mainland China in the immediate post-election period last year, he said: "In fact, cross-strait relations have improved to a certain degree since the inauguration of the DPP (Democratic Progressive Party) government" and the main reason lies in Chen's "middle way" approach.

He told the audience, which included officials from the European Union Commission, members of the European Parliament, journalists, diplomats, scholars and members of Association of Taiwanese in Belgium, that there is a solid majority in Taiwan that supports the "middle way" on the cross-strait issue and that the DPP and Chen have to take the majority view into consideration in managing cross-strait relations.

The ROC government spokesman said: "In his inauguration address, President Chen announced that as long as China has no intention of attacking Taiwan, he will not declare Taiwan independence. The declaration received overwhelming approval from the Taiwan public, because it forfeited China's excuse of attacking Taiwan militarily and this was in accordance with the majority view."

Su added that stable public opinion in Taiwan can lay the most important foundation for stabilizing cross-strait relations and in turn, cross-strait stability can become an important source of security and stability in East Asia. He said: "Maintaining the status quo and preventing military conflict by avoiding any extreme measures is indeed a middle way, a successful way to make the people of Taiwan feel safe and secure without having to worry about a war with China."

However, he pointed out in his speech titled "Taiwan's New Middle Way" that the DPP government understands the complexity and difficulty of the cross-strait issue and making announcement that the Taiwan government will not pursue any policy that is likely to trigger a cross-strait military conflict is not enough to bring long-term peace to the region. The real issue, he said, is a rising China that is dissatisfied with its regional role.

Su added that mainland China's economy has been growing rapidly over the last decade but parallel to the economic growth is the rise of its military power. "With several hundred missiles aimed at Taiwan at all times, we do not have the luxury of trial and error. In fact, Chen's administration has to make an extra effort to improve cross-strait ties," Su said.

Touching on the "mini three links" and other cross-strait policies currently under review, Su said: "Taiwan's policy objective is that through frequent and extensive exchanges of all kinds, people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait may gradually eliminate their distrust and hostility toward each other."
Su also expressed Taiwan's wholehearted support of the mainland's accession to the Word Trade Organization (WTO).

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT URGES BEIJING TO GIVE PEOPLE FREEDOM
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 28 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Visiting former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui urged Beijing Thursday to give its people freedom, democracy and the chance to develop.

Lee, who arrived in Ithaca, New York, Tuesday for a three-day visit to Cornell University, his alma mater, said Beijing should not think it is a strong country simply because of its huge area and population, while ignoring that democracy and freedom are "goals of global value."

He made the comment in response to a demonstration staged by a group of pro-Beijing students against his visit to Cornell, saying that he would like to tell the students, who were mainly from mainland China, to go back to the mainland and tell the Beijing authorities to give its people some freedom.
He said the student protesters were barking up the wrong tree and should turn on their own government and demand freedom and democracy.
Lee canceled a golf game Thursday after two hectic days and took a walk on campus and visited a campus bookstore instead.
He was scheduled to leave for Los Angeles later in the day on his way back to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MINISTER PRESIDES OVER TAIWAN INVESTMENT FORUM IN FRANKFURT
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, June 28 (CNA) (By James Kuo & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Finance Yen Ching-chang presided over a "Taiwan investment forum" in Frankfurt Thursday to solicit German businessmen to invest in Taiwan.

Yen reported to the forum, which was attended by nearly 100 bankers and businessmen, on the ROC government's ongoing financial reforms designed to improve the island's investment environment and its international competitiveness.

Benny Hu, former president of the China Development Industrial Bank, presented a report on the present condition of Taiwan's financial market, while other members of the ROC mission provided information on Taiwan's scientific and technological development.

Major topics raised during the symposium included the flow of Taiwan's capital to mainland China after the two sides join the World Trade Organization, mergers of Taiwan's banking institutions and Taiwan's efforts to improve its investment environment.

Yen, traveling at the head of a delegation made up of executives from 13 major Taiwan firms, had already visited London and Amsterdam before arriving in Frankfurt Thursday. The delegation was also scheduled to visit Zurich and Paris.

A similar mission, to be headed by Vice Finance Minister Chen Chung, is slated to visit Singapore, Hong Kong and Tokyo from Sept. 10-Sept. 14. Yen will also head another mission to Boston, San Francisco and New York from Sept. 20-Sept. 26.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN URGED TO HELP MORE IN MAINTAINING EAST ASIAN STABILITY
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 27 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: A senior official from the Republic of China called Thursday on Japan to play a more active role in maintaining the stability and prosperity in East Asia.

Executive Yuan Secretary General Chiou I-jen said that ROC President Chen Shui-bian has implemented an opening-up policy and a cross-Taiwan Strait policy with goodwill so as to maintain stability across the Taiwan Strait since he assumed power one year ago.

Chiou further said that Beijing should not insist that Taiwan should accept its "one China" principle as a precondition for the resumption of talks between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait if it really intends to reopen the stalled cross-strait dialogue.
Taiwan will try to reopen cross-strait dialogue through an international framework under those conditions, according to Chiou.

Chiou, who is a former representative of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party to Washington, made the remarks at an international seminar sponsored by the Asian Survey Association of the Mainichi Shinbun newspaper.
Later in the day, he dined with Taiwan reporters and briefed them on the purpose of his visit.
Chiou arrived in Tokyo June 23 for a lecture tour and to gather first hand information about Japan's new administration.
During his stay in Japan, Chiou also called on Japanese political and civic leaders to exchange views on bilateral affairs.

He called on ruling Liberal Democratic Party Secretary-General Taku Yamazaki, Japan-ROC Dietmen's Council Secretary-General Takao Fujii, Lower House Foreign Relations Committee President Takaichi Doi and various other officials.
He is also scheduled to call on Lower House President Tanesuke Wataneki Saturday before concluding his visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The KMT party platform enshrines Lien Chan's cross-strait 'confederation' proposal.
The China Times:
Streamlining and restructuring of poorly managed grassroots financial institutions to kick off in July.
The United Daily News:
Lien Chan's cross-strait 'confederation' proposal is enshrined into the KMT's draft party platform.
The Liberty Times:
Four airport police officers were detained on suspicion of corruption.
The China Post:
President Chen is open to possible political partners in coalition.
The Taiwan News:
Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh derides Beijing meddling in HK travel plans.
The Taipei Times:
Kaohsiung Mayor Hsieh cancels his trip to Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'CONFEDERATION' CONDUCIVE TO CLEARING CONFUSION: KMT OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The cross-strait "confederation" idea proposed by opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan is conducive to peaceful reconciliation between Taiwan and mainland China and can bridge the gap between supporters of independence and unification, a KMT official said Friday.

Lee Cheng-tsung, a KMT party whip at the Legislative Yuan, said it remains to be seen whether the cross-strait confederation proposal will be made part of the KMT platform, but he is sure that the concept is capable of serving as a bridgehead for leaders from both sides of the Taiwan Strait to overcome the current political impasse.
The confederation proposal can also help clarify disputes and controversies in Taiwan surrounding the issues of independence and unification, Lee added.
The guidelines, featuring a confederation with Beijing and a "double economic triangle" covering Taipei, were unveiled by the KMT's National Policy Foundation Thursday.

The guidelines are an attempt to flesh out the idea of a confederation which was proposed by Lien as a formula for unification with mainland China. They call for the pursuit of a friendly win-win situation with Beijing in compliance with the existing Guidelines for National Unification.

Part of the groundwork is based on the concept that ties with Beijing should be built on the basis of the so-called "1992 consensus," whereby Taipei and Beijing agreed that there is only "one China," with Taiwan and the mainland free to interpret the meaning of the term as they see fit.

The confederation framework also advocates the establishment of a "Taiwan Strait peace zone" through a military trust-building mechanism with Beijing, which would lead to the eventual confederation between the two sides.

On Friday, P.K. Chiang, executive director of the KMT National Policy Foundation, said: "It will still take some time and effort" to know whether the confederation formula will be incorporated into the KMT's party platform.

The issue will have to be discussed first by the KMT Central Advisory Council, the Central Committee and receive the blessing of the 16th Party Congress before it has a chance to be made part of the party's platform, Chiang said.

Meanwhile, an official of the opposition People First Party (PFP) said Friday that the PFP shares common perceptions about the reality of cross-strait relations with the KMT, but that does not mean that the PFP supports KMT Chairman Lien Chan's cross-strait confederation proposal.

Chang Hsien-yao, director of the PFP's Policy Research Center, said although the PFP has much in common with the KMT on many issues related to the development of cross-strait relations, the PFP is skeptical that the confederation concept will be workable or will be acceptable to Beijing.

According to Chang, the PFP's position supports a three-stage approach toward the development of cross-strait relations: beginning with economic exchanges, gradually expanding and deepening to social exchanges between people from both sides and eventually entering the level of political negotiation.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'CONFEDERATION' CONCEPT SNUBBED BY MAINLAND SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: The cross-strait "confederation" idea proposed by opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan was snubbed Friday as "unrealistic" by a mainland Chinese scholar who is currently in Taipei for an academic symposium.

Zhou Jianming, director of the Asian-Pacific studies of the Shanghai Institute for Social Sciences, said confederation is a new nation formed by two sovereign states and that this is not applicable to Taiwan and mainland China because Taiwan is not a sovereign state.

Zhou, who spoke and presented a paper Friday at the roundtable forum on cross-strait relations sponsored by the National Policy Foundation, a KMT think-tank, said he does not think that Lien's cross-strait confederation concept would be acceptable to the leaders in Beijing.
Both sides may agree that Taiwan and mainland China will eventually unify, but how and when will be a point of discussion for a long time, Zhou noted.

Zhou suggested that negotiators from both sides should reopen cross-strait dialogue based on Taiwan's Guidelines for National Reunfication and the so-called "1992 consensus," whereby Taipei and Beijing agreed that there is only "one China," with Taiwan and the mainland free to interpret the meaning of the term as they see fit.

Currently, there is still no concrete basis on which both sides of the Taiwan Strait can talk about unification, Zhou said, adding that "even if the KMT advocates the confederation framework, it won't be achieved in a short five or 10 years."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK MARKET REBOUNDS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) rebounded Friday, thanks to active buying by institutional investors and large business groups.
The benchmark TAIEX weighted price index rose 114.88 points to close at 4,883.43, on a market turnover of NT$48.16 billion (US$1.42 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: DIRECT FREIGHTER SHIPMENT OF GRAVEL REFUSED BY MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The direct "mini three links" suffered a setback earlier this week when mainland China banned a Taiwan freighter from shipping gravel directly from a mainland port to Taiwan via Kinmen, sources said Friday.

The 777-ton Kaohsiung-based cargo ship "Ho Peng No. 1" was hired by a local company to transport 300 tons of gravel from mainland China's Weitou Port in Fujian province to the southern Taiwan port of Kaohsiung.

It was the first Taiwan-registered freighter approved by the Republic of China government to sail directly across the Taiwan Strait to mainland China via Kinmen since the direct "mini three links" was launched early this year.

The "Ho Peng No. 1" sailed from Kinmen's Liaolo Port Tuesday noon and reached waters off Weitou Port about two hours later. Mainland China's public security authorities, however, blocked the ship from entering the port, saying that exporting sundry goods was not permitted from the port.

The "Ho Peng" crew then moored the vessel off Weitou Port. Over the past two days, the ship owner has negotiated with mainland authorities by phone, but to no avail. The freighter finally gave up and sailed back to Kinmen Friday morning.
Observers have speculated that mainland China's entry ban on the gravel ship was prompted by Taiwan's premature announcement of the event for alleged publicity purposes.
Kinmen County Government officials said if that were true, the prospects for the Taiwan-initiated "mini three links" would be gloomy.

As part of its efforts to forge rapprochement with mainland China, the ROC government opened its two frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu for direct trade, mail and shipping with mainland China's Xiamen and Mawei ports in Fujian province, commonly known as the "mini three links," at the beginning of this year.
Because of Beijing's reluctance to fully support the program, it has yet to make much headway. Mainland China approves direct Kinmen-Xiamen or Matsu-Mawei voyages only on a case-by-case basis.

According to county government tallies, 51 direct voyages from Kinmen to mainland China's Xiamen Port have been made since Jan. 1, with 3,949 passengers making the trip. During the same period, only two voyages from Xiamen to Kinmen were made, with a total of 153 mainland residents on board.
As for cargo shipments, mainland freighters have so far made five direct voyages to Kinmen, transporting a total of 7,141 tons of gravel.

Under the "mini three links," only Kinmen and Matsu residents and freighters are allowed to make direct voyages to mainland China. The "Ho Peng No. 1" was the first Taiwan cargo vessel allowed to make the direct passage via Kinmen as part of the ROC government's efforts to expand the "mini three links."
The Kinmen County Government expressed regret over mainland China's refusal of the first Taiwan-registered ship's participation in direct cross-strait shipping services via Kinmen.
County government officials said they will negotiate with mainland authorities through proper channels to remove unnecessary obstacles to the "mini three links" on a reciprocal basis.
The "Ho Peng No. 1," with an 11-man crew on board, left Kaohsiung June 16. It is now berthing at Kinmen's Liaolo Port and awaiting further instructions from its owners.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES REBOUND ON TAIWAN STOCK EXCHANGE

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) staged an across-the-board rebound Friday on active buying by institutional investors and large business groups.
The TAIEX weighted price index, the market's key barometer, surged 114.88 points to close at 4,883.43.

Market turnover also increased to NT$48.16 billion (US$1.42 billion), with 1.15 billion shares changing hands during the four-and-half-hour trading session, also the last trading session for the first half of this year.

The market opened higher at 4,854.6 points, with traditional large blue-chip stocks and electronics issues leading the rally. The TAIEX index reached a high of 4,898.99 points at mid-session, but lost some ground later.

All eight major categories of stocks posted gains, with cement issues rising 3.2 percent; foodstuffs advancing 2.3 percent; plastics and chemical stocks picking up 1.3 percent; textile issues surging 2.1 percent; electric and electronics stocks shooting up 2.7 percent; paper issues increasing 1.1 percent; construction stocks jumping 2.1 percent; and financial issues chalking up a 1.9 percent gain.
Gainers outnumbered losers 451 to 68, with 79 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEMPLE CITED FOR CHARITY AS OWNER MAKES BAIL ON LAUNDERING CHARGE

TEXT.P: The chairman of the renowned Taoist Hsing Tien Temple in Taipei may have taken the expression that charity begins at home a little too seriously.

Huang Chung-chen and his wife were arrested Thursday on charges of embezzlement and money laundering -- a day before the government recognized the temple as an example of social responsibility because of its cash donations to charities over the last year -- the most generous of all religious organizations in Taiwan.

In a ceremony Friday presided over by Minister of the Interior Chang Po-ya, the ministry cited 137 religious organizations for their contributions to Taiwan society. The same morning, Huang and his wife, Wei Hui-chun, were being released on bail of NT$1 million and NT$100,000 bail, respectively.

According to ministry figures, religious groups reportedly made donations totaling NT$4.024 billion (US$118 million) in cash last year. Of that total, NT$595 million (US$17.5 million) was contributed by the Hsing Tien Temple.

Officials from the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau said Huang and his wife are suspected of stealing huge sums of cash from the temple group's coffers and then laundering the money through six banks in Singapore.
The couple were interrogated overnight Thursday and made bail on Friday, but investigators have barred them from leaving the country. Huang currently holds a United States passport.

The Hsing Tien Temple, dedicated to Kuan Yu, a legendary hero of the ancient Chinese Three Kingdoms period from A.D. 222 to A.D. 265, maintains a general hospital, a cultural and educational foundation and several libraries in addition to a number of similar temples in Taipei City and Taipei County.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, June 29, or the ninth day of the fifth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
48 B.C.: Julius Caesar defeats his brother-in-law and former ally Pompey at Pharsallus and thus becomes absolute ruler of Rome.
1880: France formally annexes the Pacific island of Tahiti (or Otaheite).
1911: Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands is born. He is the husband of Queen Juliana and a founder of the World Wildlife Fund.
1920: China joins the League of Nations.
1928: Peking is renamed Peiping.
1932: A group of Thais revolt against King Prajadhipok, forcing the king to change the government from an absolute monarchy to a constitutional monarchy, thus limiting the power of the king.
1944: China and Japan begin a major battle at Hengyang, a city in Hunan province, with Japanese troops using poisonous mustard gas in their attack.
1953: More than 1,400 mainland Chinese prisoners of war in Korea who refuse to return to the Chinese mainland write a blood letter to Presdient Chiang Kai-shek, asking him to allow them to go to Taiwan to join the Republic of China's armed forces.
1954: A total of 1,735 diamonds, with a total weight of 368.17 carats, are shipped to Taipei. The diamonds were stolen by the Japanese in mainland China during World War II.
1966: American planes bomb Hanoi and Haiphong for the first time in the Vietnam War.
1972: The US Supreme Court rules that the death penalty is unconstitutional.
1974: The ROC government announces the suspension of diplomatic relations with Venezuela, which recognized the Chinese communist regime.
1974: The 6th National Little League Baseball Tournament ends with the Li Teh team from Kaohsiung City designated to represent the ROC in the Asian playoffs.
1978: The ROC government approves a commercial agreement between flagship-carrier China Airlines and Cargo Lux and Lux Air of Luxembourg. The agreement makes it possible for CAL to extend its flight service to Europe.
1980: President Chiang Ching-kuo promulgates the new Commissioned and Noncommissioned Statute of the Armed Forces and the new Entertainment Tax Law.
1981: Hu Yaobang takes over as chairman of the Chinese Communist Party, succeeding Hua Guofeng.
1982: Premier Sun Yun-suan receives Richard Allen, senior counselor for foreign policy to the Republican National Committee of the United States.
1984: The Legislative Yuan approves the long-awaited and controversial Genetic Health Law, or Eugenics Bill, after a third reading.
1986: Argentina wins the World Cup soccer title again in Mexico, thanks to Diego Maradona, 25, who was directly or indirectly responsible for all the goals in the championship game.
1992: Mohamed Boudiaf, president of Algeria, is assassinated as he opens a cultural center in Annaba.
1994: The Peruvian Trade Office opens in Taipei.
1995: A department store collapses in Seoul, South Korea, killing 450 people and injuring 922 others.
1999: The ROC wins the right to host the annual global Information Technology conference in Taipei from June 12 to 14, 2000.
2000: Taiwan-based China Airlines signs an agreement with eight other regional airlines to establish a Pan-Asia Travel Portal webside by the end of this year.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man has only to watch over every minute detail connected with his daily life, not only of conduct and bearing, but even in minor details of dress, so as to produce an effect upon the public mind, which, without these influences, could only have been produced by fear."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TAIEX Index futures for August gained 56 points to finish at 4,900, with 26 contracts traded. September futures rose 57 points to close at 4,895, with one contract traded.
