DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REAFFIRMS COMMITMENT TO BANKING REFORM, CROSS-STRAIT PEACE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed the Republic of China government's commitment Friday to promoting financial reforms and normalization of trade and economic relations with mainland China.
Chen made the reaffirmation while meeting with Ewald Kist, chairman of the Netherlands-based ING Group.

Noting that Taiwan needs globalization and liberalization to sustain its trade and economic growth, Chen said the ROC's Legislative Yuan has recently passed six bills to facilitate the island's financial reforms.

"The passage of the six financial reform bills marks a good beginning for our market restructuring task," Chen told his guest, adding that the new bills are designed to upgrade Taiwan's financial service quality, ensure market stability and avert any possible financial crisis.
Chen went on to say that his administration has consistently attached great importance to the development of relations across the Taiwan Strait.
"We look forward to seeing early resumption of regular cross-strait dialogue and normalization of bilateral relations, particularly normalization of trade and economic ties," Chen noted.
He further said the ROC is willing to adopt an open-door policy on cross-strait commercial exchanges under the principles of market economy and no hurt to Taiwan's security.
"Active openness and effective management are our guiding principles for cross-strait trade and economic exchanges," Chen explained.
The president also said opening direct cross-strait trade, mail and transportation links, commonly known as "three links," is a trend and a necessity.

"We are more than willing to discuss this issue with mainland China. However, mainland China has consistently imposed political conditions to hinder resumption of cross-strait dialogue and stall talks on the 'three links' issue," Chen regretted.
Nevertheless, Chen said he remains optimistic about future cross-strait relations.

"I'm convinced that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait would sooner or later resume talks on various topics and issues of mutual concern since we share same cultural and historical backgrounds and have a common language," Chen said.
Meanwhile, Chen said he hopes more Taiwan companies can forge strategic alliances with multinational firms to jointly tap the vast mainland Chinese market.
For his part, Kist said the ING Group has set up a foothold in Taiwan for 16 years. "We regard Taiwan as one of our major long-term investment destinations," he noted.

To signify Taiwan's importance in the ING Group's global investment plan, Kist said, the group has especially chosen Taipei as the venue for its board meeting this year. "By so doing, we hope our board members can get a better understanding of Taiwan's general investment climate," he added.
Kist told President Chen that the Netherlands began sweeping financial reforms 10 years ago. He suggested that Taiwan learn from the Dutch experience in liberalizing its banking and financial system.
Kist further suggested that Taiwan tighten management of its banking, insurance and other relevant financial service industries to prevent irregularities.
In his view, Kist said the Taiwan legislature's passage of a financial holding company law will enhance the island's appeal to foreign investors.

"With its strategic location and outstanding manpower resources, Taiwan has long been an attractive investment destination for foreign entrepreneurs," Kist said, adding that more multinational groups would be willing to invest in Taiwan if the island further liberalize its financial services to meet international standards.
Noting that Taiwan can serve as a springboard to the vast mainland market, Kist said closer cross-strait trade and economic ties would be conducive to luring more foreign investors to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ILLEGAL ALUMINUM SMELTERS IN TAINAN DEMOLISHED BY ORDER

TEXT.P: An operation mounted by the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) to forcibly demolish illegal aluminum smelters along the Erhjen River in Tainan proceeded smoothly Friday.
Some 450 policemen were mobilized against the possibility of disturbances by protesters, but no drastic resistance was reported, although some operators voiced bitter complaints.
Sixty-eight illegal smelters were targeted in the two-day operation, the largest government move to evict polluters. In three previous operations, 55 smelters were forcibly demolished.

EPA Administrator Hau Lung-pin, who inspected the operation, told reporters that the Erhjen River has been among the worst-contaminated rivers in Taiwan for more than 10 years because of the existence of the illegal smelters.

He said the operation was aimed at destroying only the actual buildings at the sites, while operators would be allowed to remove their machinery and other equipment. He added that the Industrial Development Bureau will help a dozen of the illegal operators to move to nearby industrial zones.
The EPA chief noted that the government is determined to implement the policy of evicting the illegal aluminum smelters along the river.
In April and May, when he last inspected the scene, he stated that all illegal smelting operations along the river would be removed by June 30. Since then, a dozen operators have moved voluntarily.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT CONCLUDES CORNELL VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, June 28 (CNA) (By Chu Lu-sheng, Eric C.Y. Tseng and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui concluded a three-day visit to his alma mater, Cornell University in Ithaca, New York Thursday and flew to Los Angeles for a transit stop before his scheduled return to Taipei July 3.
A devout Christian, Lee was slated to preside over a testifying service at a Presbyterian church in upscale Bel Air July 1 at the invitation of overseas Taiwanese Presbyterians in the area.

Lee and his wife visited Cornell to visit their granddaughter, who is studying there, and to take part in an official ceremony marking the establishment of a scientific research center named in Lee's honor.

To be completed in two years, the Lee Teng-hui Institute for Scientific Research will be dedicated to nanotechnology and materials science research. Lee received a Ph.D. in agricultural economics at Cornell in 1968.

In marked contrast to his previous visit to Cornell in June 1995 when he was still ROC president, his just-concluded trip was more private and leisurely in nature and he brushed aside most questions on sensitive political issues.
Lee had originally planned to visit his alma mater in early May, but he postponed his trip because he went to Japan to have minor heart surgery in late April.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TEMPERATURE SETS RECORD HIGH

TEXT.P: Taipei temperatures set a new record high of the year Friday, reaching 37.8 degrees Celsius, mainly due to the effects of urbanization, weather forecasters said Friday.
The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said the highest temperature in Taipei was recorded Friday noon, while other areas of Taiwan did not register more than 35 degrees.
The CWB officials attributed the high Taipei temperature to the effects of high-level urbanization, the city's location in a basin and overpopulation.

In addition, the CWB went on, areas of low pressure in the South China Sea and the eastern Philippines exacerbated the local weather conditions. The forecasters said there is a slight possibility that the low pressure area in the South China Sea will develop into a typhoon, although it was too early to say whether the Philippine low will become a typhoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO EASE RESTRICTIONS ON RECRUITING MAINLAND CHINESE TALENT

TEXT.P: The Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Friday that local private enterprises will be given help to recruit foreign and mainland Chinese high-technology personnel from July 1.
In the past, the MOEA allowed local private businesses to hire only high-technology personnel who are citizens of the Republic of China living in foreign countries.
Under the new regulations, foreigners and mainland Chinese personnel who have been living abroad for more than two years can also be hired.
MOEA subsidies for the salaries of foreign and mainland Chinese high-technology personnel will remain unchanged from the present levels.

The Investment Commission is planning to organize a talent-hunting mission to San Francisco, New York and Dallas in September to recruit more talent to work in Taiwan to help improve the island's industrial quality.
It will hold symposiums in Hsinchu, Taichung and Tainan in the coming weeks to invite local businessmen to join the talent-recruiting mission.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, PRC NOT SUBJECT TO EACH OTHER: MAC

TEXT.P: The Republic of China and the People's Republic of China are not subject to each other, a senior mainland affairs official noted Friday.

Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the remarks after the Taiwan Affairs Office under mainland China's State Council reiterated Thursday that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can resume talks only after Taiwan accepts the "one China" principle. The MAC charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China.

"As the ROC is an independent sovereign democratic state, it is not subordinate to the communist-led PRC," Lin explained, adding that Beijing's "one China" principle is unacceptable because it downgrades the ROC to a local-level government under the PRC.
Lin expressed regret over mainalnd China's consistent strategy of highlighting political disputes to hinder cross-strait interaction and rapprochement.

"Beijing's resistance to shelving political disputes and its insistence on imposing political prerequisites (as the basis for negotiation) have formed the biggest obstacle to normalization of cross-strait relations," Lin said.
He went on to say that peaceful solution to all disputes and the consent of the people of Taiwan remain the ROC's basic stance on handling cross-strait issues.
Lin urged mainland China to resume dialogue with Taiwan to forge mutual trust, pave the way for normalization of bilateral relations and jointly deal with the issue of a "future one China."
Touching on Beijing's recent denial of a Hong Kong visa for Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh, Lin said it is regrettable that Beijing got involved in the issue.

"If Hsieh had been allowed to visit Hong Kong, it would have contributed to exchanges and cooperation between Taiwan and Hong Kong," Lin said, adding that Beijing's involvement in Hsieh's Hong Kong travel plans will only make the people of Taiwan even more suspicious of Beijing's "one country, two systems" unification scheme.

Meanwhile, Lin refrained from commenting on the opposition Kuomintang's plan to enshrine into its party platform the proposal that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait form a confederation, saying only that whether the "confederation" formula is feasible will depend on Beijing's attitude.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO EASE MAINLAND CHINA INVESTMENT POLICY

TEXT.P: The government should adjust its current "no haste, be patient" mainland China investment policy to help local firms accomplish globalization as a way to boost Taiwan's economy, a well-known economist said Friday.

P.K. Chiang, secretary-general of the opposition Kuomintang-affiliated National Policy Foundation, made the call in a speech delivered at the opening of a two-day seminar sponsored by the KMT on cross-Taiwan Strait relations and the Bush administration's policy toward Taiwan and mainland China.

Peaceful co-existence and jointly shared prosperity have always been the mainstay public opinion in Taiwan regarding cross-strait ties and the KMT strongly believes that only through smooth and orderly trade and economic activities and exchanges of viewpoints can Taiwan and mainland China resolve their current impasse, Chiang said.

He said it is lamentable that relations between Taiwan and the mainland have been deteriorating since the transfer of power last year and that regular negotiation channels have also been cut since then.

"Worse yet, the clear course to boost bilateral trade and economic activities and two-way exchange mechanisms started by the KMT while it was the ruling party are also being lost because of the current government's vacillating policies," he pointed out.

Chiang suggested that the government ease the "no haste, be patient" policy on Taiwan investment in the mainland based on "industrial competitiveness." He contended that competitive local businesses should not be allowed to invest there, while those without a competitive edge should actually be helped to set up in the mainland or elsewhere.

As for those businesses which are still competitive but whose mainland investments can help fuel Taiwan's economy, he urged the government to gauge their investment applications on a "case-by-case basis" and to review industries' competitiveness swiftly to tackle all changes across the strait to secure national security.

In the face of the long-awaited entry by Taiwan and mainland China to the World Trade Organization, expected by the end of this year, Chiang said the two sides will face a new juncture in bilateral trade ties under the principles of mutual benefit and reciprocity. He further voiced his hope that two-way relations in other fields will also be normalized gradually.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW LAW ON U.S. PASSPORT APPLICATIONS FOR CHILDREN UNDER 14

TEXT.P: From July 2, a new U.S. law will require that both parents sign passport applications for children under the age of 14, the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) announced recently in a press release.

The new law requires that when only one parent is available to sign the application, that parent must provide AIT with documentary evidence demonstrating that he or she has sole legal custody of the child or has the written consent of the other parent to the issuance of the U.S. passport.
Exceptions to this requirement may be made in special family circumstances or emergencies requiring the immediate travel of the child, according to the new requirement.
The purpose of the law is to lessen the possibility that a U.S. passport might be used in the course of an international parental child abduction.
Also effective July 2, the age at which a minor may execute his or her own passport application is being raised from 13 to 14.
The press release included the AIT website at www.ait.org.tw and the AIT American Citizens Services Unit at (02)2709-2000, ext 2306.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSINCHU INDUSTRIAL PARK UNDERGOES STRUCTURAL TRANSITION

TEXT.P: Twenty years after its establishment, the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park has become a center for Taiwan's high-technology industries, but "Taiwan's Silicon Valley" needs to undergo a structural transition if it wants to advance.

The integrated circuit (IC), computer/peripherals, telecommunication and optoelectronic industries have been major foreign exchange earners in the park. However, in the first four months of this year, sales of the IC industry grew by only 1.4 percent over the same period of last year, while the optoelectronics industry registered a sales growth of 5.3 percent and sales in the computer/peripherals sector declined by 16.9 percent.
On the other hand, the precision machinery, telecommunication and biotechnology sectors in the park in the January-April period all registered impressive sales growth.

Despite the sluggish international economic climate, the precision machinery manufacturers in the park attained a 47.2 percent growth in sales in the first four months of this year as compared with the same period of last year, while the biotechnology sector enjoyed growth of 35 percent and the telecommunications sector, 31.8 percent.

A breakdown of sales of different sectors in the park in the January-April period shows that the IC-related sector grossed a sales revenue amounting to NT$151.53 billion, followed by computers/peripherals, with NT$59.58 billion, optoelectronics, with NT25.69 billion, telecommunications, with NT$18.68 billion, precision machinery. with NT$1.79 billion and biotechnology, with NT$350 million.

With United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) topping the list, there are 129 IC manufacturers among the 330 companies in the park. IC-related companies account for the lion's share of the overall sales and their revenue also registered the highest growth in the past 10 years, growing nearly 24-fold in 10 years, from NT$23.3 billion in 1991 to NT$575.7 billion in 2000.

While Taiwan's upstream electronics industry is following in the footsteps of downstream manufacturers in seeking opportunities overseas, the Hsinchu park administration hopes that the industrial structure in the park can be transformed from concentrating on manufacturing to emphasizing research and innovation.
Currently, there are only 58 telecommunications companies, 25 biotechnology-related companies and 11 precision machinery manufacturers in the park.

When the government chose Hsinchu as the location of the science-based industrial park in the late 1970s, research environment was a major concern. Located close to the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI), National Tsing Hua University and National Chiao Tung University, the science park has the advantages of easy recruitment of qualified human resources and obtaining newly developed technologies from the academic sector.
The ITRI in the past 20 years has created more than 30 spin-off companies in the park. To advance the structure of the industrial park, the research institutes will continue to play important roles.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER CONCERNED ABOUT POSSIBLE LEAKAGE OF MIRAGE SECRETS

TEXT.P: An opposition Kuomintang lawmaker presented a written interpellation to the Cabinet Saturday expressing his concern about possible leakage of classified information concerning French-made Mirage 2000-5 jet fighters to mainland China.
Quoting a recent French newspaper report, Legislator Kuo Jung-chen said a French engineer had already leaked classified information about Lafayette-class stealth frigates to the mainland.

Kuo said the Republic of China Navy's purchase of six Lafayette-class frigates and 980 medium-range MICA missiles from France in the early 1990s was mediated by Thomson-CSF, the French manufacturer of the RDY multi-mode radar installed on Mirage 2000-5 fighters.

Against this backdrop, Kuo said in his interpellation that he is worried French engineering experts might have also leaked to mainland China critical Mirage-related information, regarding in particular the various electronics warfare weapons installed on the fighters.

The ROC has purchased 60 Mirages, which together with the 150 U.S.-made F-16 jet fighters and 130 home-made Indigenous Defense Fighters form the backbone of Taiwan's second-generation airborne defense arsenal.

Kuo asked the Ministry of National Defense (MND) to study how to control possible damage and to demand that Dassault Co., the French contractor of the Mirage fighters, ensure the safety of all Mirage-related secret information.

If necessary, Kuo said, the MND should demand that Dassault assist engineers at Taiwan's Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology and Aerospace Industry Development Corp. in adjusting the Mirage fighters' computer and electronics warfare equipment to ensure the ROC's air supremacy over the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS TO TAKE ON CHALLENGES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday at a workshop for senior government officials that they must face the challenges ahead by taking on their responsibilities to support and serve society.

Chen told the Executive Yuan officials that Taiwan is facing the challenge of a "deconstruction" of political and economic systems, challenges in its democratic order, challenges in national security and other challenges to society.
He added that mainland China's refusal to give up the option of using force against Taiwan and its "magnetic effect" on Taiwan capital has made national security an issue of primary concern.

To take on these challenges, Chen continued, the government should clearly understand its responsibilities by clarifying its role, understanding public opinion, accepting the responsibility for its policy-making and asserting its leadership.

Listing the goals for government reform, Chen said that the government must reduce its size, increase its ability to solve problems, rid itself of corruption, establish partnerships and alliances, and reorganize.
He criticized the organization of the Executive Yuan for being too weak on policy-making and recommended a large-scale merger of "functional-oriented" departments.

Chen also suggested cutting the total number of ministries and agencies by a third, while establishing a few independent "special" politically oriented committees to improve the Executive Yuan's policy planning, coordination and leadership abilities.
However, he stressed that the reorganization is not aimed at benefiting certain political parties but rather because it is necessary.

The two-day workshop -- the first of a series of seminars for a total of 127 officials from the Executive Yuan, Legislative Yuan, Control Yuan, Judicial Yuan and Examination Yuan -- was organized to let government officials come together to achieve a common vision in policy-making.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO MODERATE QUAKES RATTLE TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Two moderate earthquakes struck eastern Taiwan Saturday, seismologists at the Central Weather Bureau said, but there were no immediate reports of injuries or damage.
The first temblor, measuring 5.2 on the Richter scale, struck at 6:41 a.m. with its epicenter 13 kilometers east of the Hualien City seismic station, off the coast at a depth of 46.6 kilometers.

The second earthquake, which seismologists said is likely unrelated to the first, also registered 5.2 on the Richter scale, and came at 12:07 p.m., located inland 5.5 kilometers west of the Hsincheng seismic station in Hualien County, at a depth of 18.7 kilometers.
Taiwan is frequently rattled by earthquakes.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, June 30, or the 10th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1520: Montezuma II, the Aztec sovereign of Mexico, is killed by Hernando Cortez, the Spanish invader who overthrew his empire and took him prisoner.
1815: Stephen Decatur, an American naval officer known for his heroic deeds in the Tripolitan War, the War of 1812, stops continued attacks by Algerian pirates by threatening to bombard Algiers.
1837: Use of the pillory is banned in Britain. The device is a wooden framework on a post, with holes for the head and hands, in which offenders were locked to be exposed to public scorn as punishment for petty crimes.
1859: A crowd of some 25,000 people hold their breath in stunned admiration as Charles Blondin, a daring 35-year-old Frenchman, crosses Niagara Falls balanced on a tightrope.
1894: Tower Bridge across the River Thames in London is opened by the Prince of Wales.
1918: Susan Hayward, the American actress who won an Oscar for "I Want to Live," is born.
1934: Adolf Hitler eliminates all his political opponents in the "Night of the Long Knives" in Germany.
1943: American general Douglas MacArthur assumes his new post as commander of the Allied forces in the Southwest Pacific.
1950: U.S. President Harry S. Truman orders American forces to resist North Korean troops which are invading South Korea.
1963: Cardinal Giovanni Battista Montini is enthroned as Pope Paul VI. He was noted for easing regulations on fasting and interfaith marriages.
1971: Three Russian cosmonauts are found dead in their spaceship after a record-breaking 24 days in space which ended in oxygen failure in the final stage.
1977: The Southeast Asia Treaty Organization (SEATO) is dissolved after 23 years.
1980: Hung Mao Cheng (Fortress of the Red-Haired People), formerly the British consulate at Tamsui, northern Taiwan, is returned to the Republic of China government after the expiration of a 113-year lease.
1983: Hsu Shih-hsien, mayor of Chiayi and Taiwan's first female mayor, dies of liver cancer at the age of 76.
1987: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo receives Sten A. Akestam, president of the International Association of Lions Clubs, and six other top-ranking Lions officials.
1987: The construction of Feitsui Reservoir in Taipei County, with a price-tag of NT$14 billion, is completed.
1989: ROC Interior Minister Hsu Shui-teh and Vice Defense Minister Kuo Tsung-chin jointly preside over a ceremony marking the inauguration of a national boundary stone tablet inscribed with the words "Shield of the South China Sea" on Tungsha Chuntao (the Pratas Islands) in the South China Sea.
1990: East and West Germany merge their economies, with East Germany adopting the deutschemark as its currency.
1993: The ROC Executive Yuan approves an economic stimulus package to accelerate industrial upgrading and develop Taiwan into an Asia-Pacific Regional Operations Center.
1995: The U.S. government officially announces cancellation of the sanctions against Taiwan issued under the Pelly Amendment.
1996: South African Foreign Minister Alfred Nzo arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1997: Britain hands Hong Kong back to the Chinese at the stroke of midnight, ending 156 years of colonial rule.
1999: The U.S. ratings agency Standard and Poor's gives the ROC's long-term foreign currency credit a rating of AA+, indicating its belief that the country has a high level of capability in fulfilling its financial commitments.
2000: A total of 251 sinologists from around the world meet at Taiwan's Academia Sinica to discuss the digital preservation of traditional Chinese literature and language archives.
2000: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan is elected as the chairman of the newly established KMT think-tank, the National Policy Research Foundation.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In the conduct of government, the first bad principle to be avoided is cruelty. That is, the undue punishment of crimes committed through ignorance arising out of a neglected education."

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL HEALTH INSURANCE PROGRAM OFFERS MORE BENEFITS TO ELDERLY

TEXT.P: New regulations for the National Health Insurance program offer senior citizens more benefits, while people with high incomes are required to pay higher premiums, the Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) announced Saturday.

From July 1, citizens aged over 65 need not pay if they make fewer than 48 visits to hospitals or clinics in a year. They will be required to pay NT$50 per visit for the 49th to 156th visits and NT$100 each time for more visits.
An earlier regulation ruled that only the first 24 visits to hospital would be fully covered by the health insurance program, after which NT$50 would have to be paid.
A survey conducted by the health insurance authorities shows that senior citizens in Taiwan make 20 to 25 visits to hospital a year on average.

Since the National Health Insurance program came into effect in March 1995, the highest coverage has been NT$57,800. In view of the fact that more than 3 percent of those belonging to high-income tier are under-insured, the health insurance authorities decided to raise the premium by setting the ceiling at NT$60,800, effective August 1.

The health insurance authorities in the past years have suffered heavy losses due to large pay-outs. To avoid waste in this regard, the bureau has ruled that patients must pay for prescriptions worth over NT$100, although they will not have to pay more than NT$200.
Last year, the people of Taiwan made 280 million National Health Insurance claims, while prescriptions were worth NT$340 billion, according to the bureau.

DOC.HEADLINE: LONG-RANGE FRAMEWORK WILL ACHIEVE REAL CROSS-STRAIT PEACE: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: A long-range framework agreed upon by Taipei and Beijing will achieve real long-term cross-Taiwan Strait peace and stability, a researcher on European and American affairs claimed Saturday.

Lin Cheng-yi, director of the Institute of European and American Studies under Academia Sinica, Taiwan's highest academic research organization, made the remark in a report on preliminary research of U.S. President George Bush's policies toward both sides of the Taiwan Strait presented at a seminar on cross-strait relations.
The seminar was sponsored by the National Policy Research Foundation, an opposition Kuomintang think tank.
According to Lin, the Bush administration has taken a more intransigent attitude toward mainland China, while adopting a more supportive attitude toward Taiwan.
The attitude is characterized by the close watch on the promotion of the mainland Chinese power structure and its effects on the security of the United States, Taiwan and the Asia-Pacific region.

Lin went on to say that although the United States does not intend to act as an intermediary between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, it might be forced to get involved in cross-strait affairs if the tension escalates.

Lin claimed that the United States will guarantee to mainland China that Taiwan will not seek independence, while pledging to Taiwan that it will not allow mainland China to use force against Taiwan. This, he said, means that as long as Taipei and Beijing reach peaceful agreement, the United States will support the agreement.
Lin said in the report that Bush's remarks on arms sales to Taiwan and the joint defense of Taiwan have also effectively conveyed the United States' message to Beijing.
However, he added that the United States' friendly gesture will not necessarily guarantee real long-term cross-strait peace.
He concluded that cross-strait peace and stability will hinge on the formation of a long-range framework that can be accepted by both Taipei and Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OFFICIAL EXPLAINS TRADE POLICY TOWARD MAINLAND CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 29 (CNA) (By Neil Lu & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: A senior trade official from the Republic of China briefed an investment symposium held at Silicon Valley on the ROC's trade policy toward mainland China.
Vice Economics Minister Lin I-fu arrived the previous day at the head of a 13-member ROC delegation trying to lure more U.S. high-tech manufacturers to invest in Taiwan.

Regarding private sector investment in mainland China, Lin said that the government has "adopted a stage-by-stage opening up policy" although he added that core industries and high-technology industries must stay in Taiwan.

Lin made the remarks in response to questions raised by the participants on the ROC government's attitude toward Wang Yung-ching, president of the Formosa Plastics Group, who asked the government to relax its "no haste, be patient" policy which puts a ceiling on Taiwan's investment in mainland.

Lin pointed out that the government and the industrial sector have gradually reached a consensus that some high-tech industries, excluding the semi-conductor industry, can receive orders and conduct research and development in Taiwan, with manufacturing to be carried out overseas or on the mainland.
The government will decide on a case-by-case basis what kind of high-tech industries can invest in the mainland, Lin said.
Lin told the seminar participants that both the ruling and opposition political parties in Taiwan have gradually been reaching a consensus that priority should be placed on economic development.

In addition to improving Taiwan's investment climate, the government has been trying to lure more foreign investment and introduce updated high technology into Taiwan so as to reshape the island's industrial structure and create more job opportunities, Lin said.
Lin and his colleagues had already visited Los Angeles, San Diego, Boston and New York.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS TO TRIM EXECUTIVE BRANCH

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian pledged Saturday to complete government restructuring over the next three years in order to cut government expenditure and upgrade overall national competitiveness.
Chen made the vow in a speech delivered at the opening of a workshop for senior government officials.

Outlining five goals for government rejuvenation, Chen said the government must slim down, reorganize, upgrade its ability to solve problems and wipe out official corruption, as well as forge partnerships and alliances between central and local governments and among various government agencies.
He pointed out that each Republic of China national has to spend more than NT$100,000 (US$2,941) per year supporting the operations of governments at various levels.

"It's a very heavy burden for our people. We can't find any convincing reason to continue this costly way of administration," Chen said, adding that Taiwan should trim its bureaucracy and establish a small but highly efficient government.

Chen said he fully understands the difficulties in trimming the government work force. "Nevertheless, we must still learn from other countries' experiences and set a clear goal for gradually slashing the total number of civil servants, including administrative staff at public schools, over the next few years.
Government agencies, Chen went on, can work out various kinds of incentives to encourage early retirement to facilitate personnel restructuring.
For the moment, he said the Executive Yuan, or the Cabinet, should give the top priority to its own organizational restructuring.

Noting that the Executive Yuan is burdened with too many functionally oriented departments while lacking in policy research and planning staff, Chen said the executive branch much undergo a sweeping structural reform to enhance its capabilities in policy planning, coordination and leadership.

As to how the Cabinet should be restructured, Chen outlined four directions -- a massive-scale merger of functionally oriented departments; setting up a limited number of independent supervisory and control commissions as well as politically motivated special commissions; cutting the number of Cabinet ministries and councils by at least one-third; fundamentally changing the Executive Yuan's structure by opening several major policy planning units and legislating a new law governing the role, duty and functions of political appointees.
Chen said one major purpose of the Executive Yuan restructuring is to prevent it from becoming a bureaucratic body dominated by civil servants.
The president complained that the government restructuring and rejuvenation have been delayed for too long. "I hope that a new bill on the Executive Yuan organization can be drafted soon," he added.

Meanwhile, he stressed the importance of establishing a clean government. "We can learn from foreign experiences in setting up an independent organization to crack down on political graft and corruption," he suggested, adding that the government can consider appointing prosecutors to head government ethics departments and encouraging ethics departments to maintain close contacts with the watchdog auditing authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN: ONLY KMT CAN GIVE TAIWAN `REBIRTH'

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan claimed Saturday at a meeting of party representatives that Taiwan can only be "reborn" if the KMT regains power.

He told the KMT's Taipei Committee members and its eight Taipei candidates for the year-end legislative elections that the party must reassess what it did wrong in the past and retain its legislative majority by winning the elections.

Lien said that the nation has "changed beyond recognition" over the past year under the rule of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration, and "major foreign academic groups and their media organizations" have been asking, "What happened in Taiwan?" "Is Taiwan sick?" "Where is Taiwan headed?"

He criticized the DPP for blaming its difficulties in policy promotion on the KMT, claiming that the KMT has been "cooperative and supportive" in helping to pass bills in the Legislative Yuan, even when an extraordinary session had to be convened to approve major financial reform bills.
In contrast, he alleged, the DPP "opposed for the sake of opposition" in the legislature before it came into power.
He also criticized the DPP for blaming the current political and economic quagmire on the legislature, the opposition parties and the media.

At the same meeting, KMT Central Standing Committee member Ma Ying-jeou, who serves concurrently as Taipei mayor, said that Lien's idea of establishing a "confederation" between the Republic of China and mainland China can be taken as a "transitory concept" to serve as an alternative model to Beijing's "one country, two systems" model that can be discussed during future negotiations.
However, Ma added that related measures must be taken to make the idea feasible because the ROC Constitution and the Guidelines for National Unification do not mention the concept of a confederation.
The ultimate, permanent goal for both sides of the Taiwan Strait is unification, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PUPPET TROUPE TO PERFORM IN LATIN AMERICA
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, June 29 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: The prestigious Taiwan-based Hsiao Hsi Yuan Puppet Troupe arrived in Panama City Friday on the first stop of a three-nation tour.

The 12-member group, led by Chinese Folk Art Foundation Chairman Tseng Yung-yi and troupe director Hsu Wang, is scheduled to put on two performances in Panama before traveling on to Costa Rica and Nicaragua.
For those who do not understand the Taiwanese dialect, the troupe plans to project dialogue and story summaries in Spanish onto a screen during its performances.

Founded in 1913, the puppetry troupe has toured abroad more than 30 times in the past 10 years, traveling to France, Sweden, Holland, Germany, the United States, Canada, South Africa, Australia, Japan, Thailand, Hong Kong and Singapore.
Up until the 1960s -- before television arrived in Taiwan -- puppet shows were one of the primary forms of entertainment on the island and nearly any festive occasion called for a puppet performance.

In glove puppetry, the stage design features intricate gilded carvings that resemble the entrance to a traditional Chinese temple. The elaborate setting is ideal for presenting the finely embroidered costumes, exquisite headdresses and delicately carved faces of the puppets, which stand nearly a foot high.

As in Chinese opera, many of the stories used in puppet shows are adapted from classical literature or ancient legend. Some popular examples are The Tale of the White Serpent and Journey to the West. Live music always accompanies traditional puppet performances.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL FINDS 14% TAIPEI VOTERS WOULD BACK CANDIDATES OF `LEE GROUPING'

TEXT.P: The majority of Taipei citizens are aware that former President Lee Teng-hui is planning to form a new political grouping, but less than 15 percent of them are willing to vote for its candidates in the year-end legislative elections.

These were the findings of a public opinion poll released Saturday. The telephone survey of 1,085 adult residents in Taipei was conducted from June 22-24 by the Taipei City chapter of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
The poll results show that 77 percent of the respondents said they were aware that Lee intends to organize a new political group to take part in the legislative elections to be held in December.
But only 14 percent said they would vote for candidates to be nominated by the group, while nearly 50 percent said they would snub candidates recommended by the new grouping.

As for the possible impact of the Lee grouping on Taiwan's future political landscape, 29 percent said they think that the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) would bear the brunt of the adverse impact. Lee served as KMT chairman for 12 years until after the party suffered an embarrassing defeat in the 2000 presidential election.

Meanwhile, 25 percent said they think that the Lee group would sway voters away from DPP candidates; 1.5 percent said they think that it would affect the opposition People First Party's (PFP's) support rate in the year-end elections; 0.7 percent said they think that it would affect independent candidates' support rating; and a mere 0.1 percent said they think that it would influence the voting behavior of New Party followers.
Analyzing the survey results, Chin Heng-wei, editor-in-chief of the Contemporary Magazine, said it remains premature to make any survey or judgment on the results of the year-end elections.
In his view, Chin said, Lee's involvement in the year-end elections and his meddling in relevant campaign activities will certainly affect the electoral outcome.

The same survey also found that 19.3 percent of those interviewed said they would vote for DPP candidates in the year-end legislative elections; 18.9 percent said they would opt for PFP nominees; 10.6 percent said they would throw support behind KMT standard bearers; 1.8 percent said they would cast their ballots for New Party stalwarts; and 1.3 percent said they would vote for independent hopefuls.

Asked about their views on the "joint campaign" strategy, 84 percent said they look forward to seeing political parties or groups adopt a "joint campaign" strategy for their candidates; but 13.3 percent said they do not support such a tactic.

While 31 percent said they would vote for the candidates recommended by their party headquarters under a joint campaign strategy, 51 percent said they would vote in accordance with their own free choice.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT SET TO TRIM 15,000 EMPLOYEES NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government has been trimming its work force since the mid-1990s and is set to reduce the total number of its administrative staff by 15,000 next year, the country's top personnel administrator said Saturday.

Chu Wu-hsien, director-general of the Central Personnel Administration (CPA), made the remarks after President Chen Shui-bian listed government downsizing as the top goal of his administration's government restructuring policy.

Addressing a workshop for senior government officials, Chen also said he hopes that his administration can score outstanding achievements in government restructuring and rejuvenation over the next three years.
In response, Chu said the government has slashed 3.73 percent of its workforce since 1996. In the current fiscal year, he went on, the government has so far rid itself of several thousand employees.

As several state-owned enterprises are scheduled to be gradually privatized or downsized and the government's total administrative staff will be further reduced, Chu said, the government workforce is expected to shrink by an estimated 15,000 in 2001.
Responding to Chen's complaint that the Cabinet should have organized a workshop for senior government officials much earlier, Chu said he sincerely accepted Chen's criticism.

He added that the CPA will continue to organize similar workshops in the future to brief all senior government officials on major policy guidelines and facilitate the cultivation of esprit de corps to improve administrative efficiency.

DOC.HEADLINE: ETHNIC DIVIDE SHOULD NOT BE BASIS FOR POLITICAL GROUPING: KMT CHAIRMAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, southern Taiwan, June 30 (CNA) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan called Saturday on "those" who intend to form a new political group to tell the public clearly of its purpose and direction.
Lien made the remarks in Tainan County when he called on local KMT county magistrate and legislative candidates for the year-end elections.
Lien pointed out that although Lee had denied organizing the so-called Lee Grouping, "some" have insisted that the group will be formed.
"If you want stability for Taiwan, please do not create ethnic hostility," Lien said.

Lien also said that the "confederation" idea proposed by him corresponds with the KMT's "middle road" policy. He stressed, however, that the scope of such a confederation between Taiwan and mainland China should be negotiated by the two sides.

Meanwhile, former Interior Minister Huang Chu-wen, widely regarded as the driving force behind the new grouping, rebutted Lien's remarks, saying that organizing a political party or group is a normal thing to do in a democratic nation and pointing out that if the KMT were capable, there would be no need to establish a new political group.
He further said that the new group will be formally set up in August.

Huang, who used to have very close ties to Lee, denied that he was using the ethnic factor to organize the political group and instead accused the KMT of being the main fomenter of ethnic confrontation in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT RUNNERS FINISH LAST STAGE IN BEIJING
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, June 30 (CNA) (By Chang Chun-yu and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Athletes from Taiwan and mainland China completed Saturday the last leg in Beijing of a run held on both sides of the Taiwan Strait in support of Beijing's bid to host the 2008 summer Olympic Games.

The 10-city, 15-day run began June 16 in Taipei. As of Saturday, cross-strait runners had raced in the Taiwan cities of Taipei and Kaohsiung and in mainland Chinese cities of Shenzhen, Ningbo, Hangzhou, Shanghai, Wuxi, Nanjing, Qingdao and Beijing.
Several thousand runners, business representatives and Beijing citizens joined the athletes in the run which started from the city's Chaoyang Park.
The International Olympic Committee (IOC) is scheduled to vote July 13 to decide whether Beijing, Toronto or Paris will be chosen to host the 2008 games.

In order to win the right to host the games, mainland China has organized many activities in support of its bid. The cross-strait race -- the biggest activity -- was expected to be the last of these public relations exercises before the IOC announces the winning city.
The runners from Taiwan are scheduled to return to Taiwan Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: SENEGAL PRESIDENT ARRIVES FOR FIVE-DAY STATE VISIT TO ROC

TEXT.P: Senegal President Abdoulaye Wade, accompanied by a high-profile delegation, arrived in Taipei Saturday for a five-day state visit to the Republic of China at the invitation of President Chen Shui-bian.
ROC Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao greeted the Senegal head of state at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport upon arrival on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian.
Chen was scheduled to preside over a military salute and host a state banquet in Wade's honor in central Taiwan's Taichung City Monday.

During his stay in Taiwan, Wade and Chen will discuss issues of mutual concern and bilateral cooperation, as well as signing a joint communique and conferring medals upon each other. Wade will also visit cultural and agricultural establishments in the ROC.

The ROC and its West African diplomatic ally have maintained very close ties in trade, infrastructure, agricultural training and industrial development since resuming full diplomatic relations in January 1996.
The ROC provides assistance to Senegal in agricultural skills, training, road and irrigation infrastructure construction and industrial zone development.
Rice and asparagus planted by the ROC agricultural technical mission based in the African ally are particularly popular among Senegal farmers.
